column2: Three hundred angry Queens and Brooklyn home owners picketed City Hall yesterday over recent increases in the assessed valuations of their properties.
A 21-year-old messenger and a 4-year-old girl survived falls from great heights yesterday. They were the third and fourth persons in less than two weeks here to live after such experiences.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is planning for production next year a musical extravaganza under the title, "The Ziegfeld Story."

The Ford Foundation has made a grant of $85,000 to the American Assembly for a study of relations between the United States and Latin America. The assembly, an adjunct of Columbia University, is a nonpartisan conference organization.
ROME, March 2 -- An unidentified American collector is negotiating for the sale back to Italy of a Renaissance Bible with hand-written comments by Friar Gerolamo Savonarola.

If the nation's steel industry achieves the production it has scheduled this week, it will turn out more raw steel than ever before in a single week. Output has been sched uled at 2,535,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, representing operations of 89.5 per cent of the industry's capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

MESA, Ariz., March 2 -- Moving around the Valley of the Sun in the Grand Canyon State, where four major league baseball clubs are in spring training, an intent listener gets an earful. Some of it may be idle chatter, to be taken with a grain of cactus.

A nine-story apartment building has been planned for the west side of Third Avenue between Twenty-fourth and Twentyfifth Streets. Jack B. Schleifer, realty investor, announced that he had acquired the site of 155 by 85 feet.
ZOMBA, Nyasaland, March 2 (Reuters) -- The Governor of this British protectorate said today troops could not hold Nyasaland against the wishes of 3,000,000 African residents.
PORT - AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 2 (UPI) -- "The Caribbean today is an extremely explosive area," President Francois Duvalier said in an interview today.
Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was light in most markets, but copper had the second largest volume this year and rubber had its most active day.

DUBLIN, Tuesday, March 3 -- If this city's verdict is meaningful, "Goodwill Ambassador," which had its world premiere at the Olympia Theatre here last night, seems assured of a successful run in New York.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Governor Rockefeller has before him a suggestion that New York put an end to taxes on the homes of all United Nations delegations except those of the Soviet Union.

NORWALK, Corn., March 2 -- Natives of Silvermine, a bosky community of artists, antique dealers and ad men, were perturbed today by reports that U. S. Route 7 would be relocated right through their lilacs and dogwood.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Ahmadou Ahidjo, Premier of the French Cameroons, appealed to the Asian and African members of the United Nations today not to request another election before his country achieves independence, Jan. 1.
Mayor Wagner appointed a three-member citizens mediation committee yesterday in the labor dispute involving gravediggers and other workers in cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

NEWARK, March 2 -- Essex County Judge James R. Giuliano issued a bench warrant today for the arrest of John V. Serratelli, 50-year-old business manager for Teamsters Union Local 945 of Clifton. The judge acted when Mr. Serratelli failed to show up for arraignment on a conspiracy charge.

THOSE accustomed to thinking of James Ensor as a specialist in the phantasmagoric will be interested in a large, gentle seascape on view at tte Feigl Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue, along with other European paintings of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The Committee for a National Trade Policy urged today that any decision on restricting imports of heavy electrical equipment take into account the effect of such a decision on United States foreign relations.

LONDON, March 2 -- Increased selling caused sharp falls in virtually every section of the stock market today. The retreat was general among the industrials and losses ranged to around 1s 6d (21 cents).

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, defended today the Administration's decision not to order production of an Army missile being developed as a defense against enemy ballistic missiles.
General Motors Acceptance Corporation cleared $53,323,446 in 1958, Charles G. Stradella, president, reported yesterday. This compared with $46,037,136 the year before.
AMHERST, Mass., March 2 (UPI) -- James D. Ostendarp, an assistant coach at Cornell under Lefty James, today was named head coach of football at Amherst College.
OPERATING lighting fixtures without dimmer controls is like using a television set or a radio without a volume switch.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The Rockefeller Administration court reform program, to be submitted to the Legislature soon, will leavve the justices of the peace virtually unchanged.

SANTHA RAMA RAU went to Russia to study the arts of life rather than the threats of death. This sets her superb book, "My Russian Journey,"* apart from many another volume of sputnik-haunted lore. As an exceptionally perceptive novelist and travel writer she knows how to set a scene, start dialogue spinning down the page, and let her characters, drawn from life, make their own contributions to the general revelation.

The General Motors Corporation, which cut its corporate advertising sharply last year, is slated to begin a campaign of about $3,000,000 in April. This undoubtedly would be a large increase in spending by the automaker in this ad category.

Although the firm of Bowden, Barr Bullock is dedicated to Broadway, the team is enlarging its scope to include Off Broadway. Their initial project in that sphere is "Season of Choice," with a cast headed by Betsy von Furstenberg and Douglas Watson.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 2 -- Gov. Sir Hugh Foot moved quickly today to carry forward the agreement for the independence of Cyprus.

Three city concerns received certificates of merit yesterday from Abe Stark, president of the City Council, at City Hall. The concerns were winners of the first Collins Tuttle Awards for realty transactions contributing most to the city's economic development.
PARIS, March 2 -- The Executive Council of the French Overseas Community opened its second session here today.
ALBANY, March 2 (AP) -- A band of placard-carrying state employes, marched on Albany today to back up demands that include wage increases totaling $63,500,000.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today a plan under which one state could reach into another for witnesses wanted in criminal proceeding.

An intensive search for new city taxes as substitutes for an off-track betting levy or a sales tax increase is under way in case neither of these two taxes is found to be feasible. Asked last night what the substitutes might be, Mayor Wagner said:
A 32-year-old Brooklyn man, Jack Seiderman, and his bride, Rose, 30, slipped away from their wedding reception early yesterday to prepare for their Florida honeymoon.

IRVINGTON, N. J., March 2 Three gunmen held up the Public Service Garage at 328 Sixteenth Avenue today at 3 A.M. and carried off 1,100 pounds of coins totaling $11,000. The money represented weekend receipts from four bus lines.

BERLIN, March 2 -- West Berlin has stored foodstuffs, raw materials and coal in such quantity that the city could hold out for a full year in the event of a Soviet blockade, the head of the city government's Economic Department said today.
ISLAND PARK, L. I., March 2-- Sharp-eyed, dive-bombing sea gulls are playing havoc with the sleeping habits and safety of the Martin family here by shelling their home with clams.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Tuesday, March 3 -- The Army, in its second try at the moon, sent a huge rocket soaring into the star-studded sky at 12:10:30 A. M. today.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The House of Representatives passed unanimously and without debate today a bill to help counteract curbs placed on the Smith Act by Supreme Court decisions.
Stefan Redl of Passaic, N. J., will meet Eddie Jordan in the feature ten-round welterweight match at Madison Square Garden Friday night.

DARIEN, Conn., March 2 -- A luncheon and card party will be given at six Darien homes on Thursday to raise funds to meet a deficit in support of community projects of the non-partisan League of Women Voters. Public patronage for the benefit is invited and reservations may be made by calling Mrs. Ralph L. Evans.
David A. Wright, president of National Marine Service, Inc., of New York, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the American Waterways Operators, Inc,
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 2 -- A noted engineer who supervised the design of the ventilation system for the Holland Tunnel accidentally hanged himself yesterday while attempting an escape trick.

LITTLE ROCK, March 2 -- A poll of Little Rock Chamber of Commerce members revealed today a decisive majority in favor of re-opening the city's public high schools under a plan of "controlled minimum" integration.

Sales in the eight major department stores in the New York area last month showed a gain of 8.5 per cent over volume of February, 1958, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. This compared with a 2.2 per cent increase in January over 1958.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate Republican leader failed today in a surprise move in committee to delay action on the Kennedy-Ervin bill for labor-management reform.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The New York Central Railroad won in he Supreme Court today its long fight to abandon two passenger ferry lines across the Hudson River.

HARTFORD, March 2 -- The New England Governors' Conference appointed a three-member subcommittee today to discuss with Federal officials the "continuing serious" textile situation in the New England states.
MIAMI, March 2 (AP) -- Sam Boulmetis rode Bally Ache and Ouija Board to victory in the two divisions of the $10,000 added Juvenile Stakes today at Hialeah.

In one of those sudden reversals of form and manners that mark their diplomacy the Soviets have agreed to join in an East-West foreign ministers meeting, proposed by the West to deal with the gathering crisis over Berlin. They suggest next month as the time and either Vienna or Geneva as the place, which should be acceptable to the West.
MOSCOW, March 2 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of the Soviet note handed to Britain here today (similar notes were handed to France and the United States):

Re-employment during the present recovery has lagged behind the rise in production and aggregate economic activity. This is true when measured in terms of total unemployment, though less true on the basis of the percentage of the labor force out of work, a figure that is adjusted to take account of seasonal considerations and changes in the size of the labor force.
The Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation is making an effort to get young Soviet pianists to come to this country in the fall to compete for its annual prize.

The New York City Housing Authority will receive bids on March 17 for $57,840,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of rune low-rent projects that are subsidized by the Public Housing Administration.

BOSTON, March 2 (UPI) -- The American League president, Joe Cronin, today named his brother-in-law, Calvin R. Griffith, to succeed him on the major league rules comittee. Griffith is president of the Washington Senators.
The start of a $6,060,000 fundraising campaign for Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., was announced here yesterday by John M. Kemper, the headmaster.
The second event of Town Hall's first annual Festival of Music took place last night.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- About 3,000 building trades workers came to Washington today to exercise their constitutional right to petition. They are lobbying for a six-item legislative program.
The spring semester got off to a belated start last night at the city's sixteen evening high schools.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 3 -- The Army apparently succeeded today in sending a payload toward the vicinity of the moon and then into orbit around the sun.
Plans have been completed for Art Carney to star in a musical fable adapted from Paul Dukas' symphonic composition, "The Sorcerer's Apprentice."
A total of 10,595 pints of blood was donated in February to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Service, the service announced yesterday. Friday's total was 514 pints.
A top official of a leading insurance company and an aircraft manufacturing executive disagreed yesterday on the danger of rapid obsolescence in electronic computers.
Plans have been announced for a thirty-two-story office building to be constructed at 235 East Forty-second Street, on the northwest corner of Second Avenue.
HARRISBURG, March 2 -- Gov. David L. Lawrence presented today a record general fund budget of $1,907,012,354, involving the imposition of more than $400,000,000 in new taxes.

MONTREAL, March 2 -- Canada announced today that she would not accept "at this time" the decision by the International Civil Aviation Organization adopting as a world standard the air navigation aid developed by the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 2 -- The head of the Rabbinical Council of America appealed tonight to President Eisenhower to extend "special emergency assistance" to Israel to help that country absorb the heavy influx of immigrants from East Europe, particularly Rumania.
MOSCOW, March 2 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan appeared on Moscow television for thirty minutes tonight with the most forceful presentation of Western views and ways ever permitted here.

MIAMI, March 2 -- Paul Richards tilted his chair against the railing and sprawled in the blazing sunshine that poured into Miami Stadium. The boy philosopher from Waxahachie, Tex., looked more indolent than the laziest tourist. But his mind raced, his lips moved and his eyes missed nothing of the Baltimore workout. Seated alongside of him was Lew Fonseca, one-time American League batting champion and now the head of the major league film library.

CAGNES-SUR-MER, France, March 2 -- Except for the way he trots, high, loose-jointed and fast, there is nothing about Jamin to suggest a champion. The French wonder horse won his seventh straight race here yesterday and his adherents claim he is the greatest trotter ever.

S. D. Fuller Co. and Howard, Weil, Labouisse, Friedrichs Co. and associates are offering today $1,200,000 of Blossman Hydratane Gas, Inc., 5 per cent subordinated convertible debentures, due 1978, land 120,000 shares of common stock.

Russia well deserves the sharp rebukes aimed at her in your editorial of Feb. 13 "Deadlock at Geneva" for the numerous obstacles she has placed in the path of a ban on nuclear weapons testing. And our negotiators merit great praise for their infinite patience in dealing with the Soviet conferees.

MOSCOW, March 2 -- Declaring Britain's resolve to stand by her defensive alliances, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan firmly rejected tonight Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's offer of a nonaggression pact that would liquidate United States air bases in Britain.
BONN, Germany, March 2--Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, picked up the flag of rebellion today raised by his party's parliamentary delegation against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

F. V. Krais Jr. of the New York A. C. and F. G. Travis of the Downtown A. C. were among the winners as competition began yesterday in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C singles championship.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 2.816 per cent, compared to 2.589 per cent last week, and the average rate on $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.111 per cent, compared to 2.978 per cent last week.
The extent of the business recovery in the latter part of last year is showing up in corporate earnings reports now pouring off the presses.

The board of trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday that William T. Gossett, vice president and general counsel of the Ford Motor Company, had been elected a life trustee of the university.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- If you are getting along in years but still want to remain active and feel only half your age, buy yourself a farm.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Rockefeller conferred today with his transportation experts and members of his staff in an effort to find a solution for the financial problems of the commuter railroads.

Butler University's basketball team, the champion of the Indiana Collegiate Conference, became the ninth selection in the National Invitation tournament yesterday. The event will begin in Madison Square Garden on March 12.
Sales, number of policy holders and assets of the Allstate Insurance Companies reached new highs during 1958, Judson B. Branch, president, announced yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has been informed formally that Iran regards as invalid articles in a 38-year-old treaty giving Soviet troops the right to enter Iran under certain conditions, Deputy Foreign Minister Javad Sadr announced today.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., March 2 -- This was a big day for the Russians. Two of them, Pavel Kolchin and Dmitri Kochkin, scored victories as the North American skiing championships neared their close.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The Senate approved unanimously tonight a bill to increase the number of racing days at thoroughbred tracks by ten this year. The bill now goes to the Assembly.

The McCrory-McLellan Stores Corporation has announced the election as directors of Maurice E. Olen, J. M. Nicely, J. M. D'Assern, J. L. Freed, Herschel Harris and Ivan Allan Ezrine. All also are directors of the H. L. Green Company.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Western diplomats found little in the latest Soviet notes on the German problem to encourage hope for any easy, quick solution.

THE high school basketball star stands 6 feet 4 inches and wears size 13 sneakers. He is 16 years old and cannot understand why everyone makes a fuss over him. His name is Roger Brown and he plays for Wingate High School in Brooklyn.

HENDERSON, N. C., March 2 (AP) -- A crowd of about 200 strikers and strike-sympathizers outside the South Henderson textile mill became a mob late this afternoon when a non-striker leaving the mill brandished a pistol.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points up to 20 points off yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- A. Government witness in the antitrust proceedings against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., suggested today that du Pont itself help to implement a Government plan to divorce du Pont and General Motors Corporation.
There were pronounced weak spots in yesterday's stock market, most of them in apparent reaction to gains last week, but the general tone was strong and the close higher.

WAISTS will be shown off this spring and belts are back with a boom. On the main floor of Saks Fifth Avenue they come in all materials, widths and prices. For the tailored type who frequently wear skirts and blouses, there is a black or brown alligator belt with a covered oval buckle.
Cecil Shorts, a substitute for Randy Sandy, scored an impressive upset victory over Benny (Kid) Paret in a rough ten-round middleweight bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The familiar Red Cross flag went up in City Hall Park yesterday, signaling the start of the Red Cross' annual fund drive in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census said today preliminary figures indicated that sales of wholesalers fell about 7 per cent in January.

Four United States banks participated yesterday in signing a $40,000,000 loan agreement to be used by Pemex (Petroleos Mexicanos), the Mexican government oil monopoly. The proceeds will be used to build a gas pipeline from Ciudad Pemex on the Tehuantepec Peninsula to Mexico City, a distance of 500 miles.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 2 (UPI) -- The Air Force said tonight that new signals were received today from the Discoverer I polar rocket. It said they "substantiate our earlier belief that it is in orbit."
City Administrator Charles F. Preusse will urge the Board of Education tomorrow to implement swiftly his recent recommendations for improving the administration of the school system.
A Brooklyn tavern owner who received wide publicity for passing out $20 bills to Bowery bums during the Christmas season pleaded guilty yesterday to income-tax evasion.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 2 -- A group of part-time ditch-diggers, carpenters and house painters celebrated tonight ten years of successfully providing their 3-year-old and 4-year-old children with Junior Ivy League educations.

Having spent the year 1957-58, in the Central African Federation doing research on a Ford grant into the politics of the area, I am doubly concerned that the American public keep certain basic facts in mind as political events so rapidly unroll out there.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Abba Eban will relinquish his dual post as Israeli Ambassador in Washington and chief United Nations delegate in mid-May to return home and begin a new career in Israeli politics.
The treasury of Local 333 of the tugboat union faced expropriation yesterday in a court action instituted by Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longeshore-men's Association.
The radio signal from the Army's moon rocket was picked up in the New York area early this morning.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A concerted counter-attack by the United States and allied nations on the economic offensive of the Communist bloc was urged today by a Presidential study group.

A WOMAN named Emme could sell vodka to the Russians. It so happens that Emme styles and sells hats, but her persuasiveness is such that she has converted hundreds of stubbornly bareheaded: women. With the help of her designer, a small, blond Cuban named Adolfo, she has shot to the top of the class millinery field.

It would be hard to find two composers more different than John Lessard and Morton Feldman, who made strange bed-fellows on last night's Composers Showcase, transferred from the Nonagon Gallery to the Circle in the Square.

The Arkansas Fuel Oil Corporation Public Common Stock Committee filed a motion yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to reject a plan filed on Feb. 19 by the Cities Service Company to absorb Arkansas Fuel.

SHAW'S "Widowers' Houses," which was done last night at the Downtown Theatre, East Fourth Street and Second Avenue, contains some delicious characterizations, some capital comedy scenes and some wonderful bits of dry humor.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Golda Meir of Israel said today that her nation had no intention of asking any Arab citizen to leave to make room for Jewish immigrants. She said Israel regarded Jewish and non-Jewish citizens alike.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- A 14-year-old Chicago Negro boy's dream of entering the Congressional page school came true today.
Today is the day when the writer, as writer, comes in for his due. This afternoon the tenth annual winners of the National Book Awards are to be announced in fiction, nonfiction, and poetry.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

There will be basketball in Madison Square Garden morning, afternoon and night today. The evening will be devoted to two National Basketball Association games topped by the last regular-season contest between the New York Knickerbockers and the Syracuse Nationals.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A process that gives promise of a "remarkable breakthrough" in converting salt water to fresh water was selected by the Government today for use in demonstration plant.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 2 -- Crowds of angry demonstrators burned an American flag today and stoned the United States Embassy and United States Information Service office. President Hernan Siles Zuazo went into the streets to calm the mob, and succeeded partly.
BONN, March 2 -- Two of West Germany's leading diplomats went on trial today in a case that has been an intermittent sensation of Bonn political life for six years.
The closing of the Deer Park, L. I., plant of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of Hagerstown, Md., was announced yesterday by Fairchild's president, J. H. Carmichael.
The latest rocket launching marked man's sixth reported attempt to send an instrumented space vehicle to the vicinity of the moon.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 (AP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Wrigley Rich, 33 years old, and Thomas W. Chauncey, 45, eloped to Albuquerque, N. M., on Friday.

Somewhat nervously, six members of the New York Stock Exchange went through their daily trading paces the other night before 500 students and parents at Nyack (N. Y.) High School. The place was a little off beat for them, but the student-built trading post gave them an authentic setting.
A SCENIC designer named James Trittipo virtually stole the Bing Crosby Show last night over Channel 7.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2 -- The new Nationalist party Government has taken over the administration of a country whose economic difficulties could brew political dangers if they are not quickly attacked.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 -- An earthquake shook the Central California, coastal area today. It set off fire and burglar alarms, left residents gasping in swaying buildings, but apparently caused little damage.

CHICAGO, March 2 (UPI) The medical officer of the Seawolf today told how painted decks and luminous dials were a greater medical problem than a nuclear power plant during the ship's two months under water.
CAIRO, March 2 -- Egypt and Britain have waived all claims for war damages against each other arising from the British-French attack of 1956, according to their financial agreement made public today.
State and city officials called yesterday for an enlarged daycare program.
Any barring of public assistance to persons who have lived in the state less than a year would "turn the state clock back to 1873," Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Banks agreed unanimously today on a new omnibus banking bill that would allow commercial and savings banks in New York City to expand into the suburbs.
Justice Morris Spector reserved decision yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court on whether the lawyer for major league ball players should be named to their pension plan committee.

A luncheon and fashion show to aid the new training center of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, in Brookville, L. I., will be given next Tuesday at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senator Kennedy of Massachusetts, who apparently believes it is the public duty of a Presidential aspirant to discuss all issues, including the tougher ones, with candor, is now going through the first phase of the usual experience of politicians who follow this concept.

Officials decided yesterday to continue engineering and architectural work on the proposed Narrows Bridge despite a Board of Estimate decision to postpone final action on land acquisition until March 25.
MOSCOW, March 2 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's addresses today, one delivered on Soviet television and the other at a Kremlin reception:

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- Insurance executives urged the Senate Finance Committee today to cut the tax increases that would be imposed on their companies by a new life insurance tax bill passed in the House.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- A brokerage concern headed by a former governor of Maine, Burton M. Cross, was disciplined today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for illegal promotion of a stock offering in which Mr. Cross had a major interest.
The author of the Democratic housing bill, Senator John Sparkman of Alabama, defended the measure here yesterday as not inflationary.

NEWARK, March 3 -- The representatives of twenty-six municipalities in northern New Jersey were assured today of state support in a long-range plan for the reclamation and development of Jersey's 30,000 acres of meadowland.
Stocks boiled upward yesterday to historic highs in heavy trading.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev reported today that they had failed to reach any agreement on key issues regarding Germany and West Berlin. They agreed, however, that early negotiations were urgently needed to try to settle these issues.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Statehood for Hawaii was approved unanimously today by the Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs.

"Rededication to Freedom," by Benjamin Ginzburg, will be published next Wednesday by Simon Schuster. The author contends that although McCarthyism has subsided there has grown up a system of Congressional investigations and loyalty-security programs that undermine the civil liberties guaranteed in the Bill of Rights.

The Spoleto Festival Ball will be held in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on April 14 for the benefit of the Festival Foundation, Inc., the organization that supports Gian Carlo Menotti's annual Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.
NEWARK, March 3 -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents tonight arrested two young men they accused of staging a Wild West hold-up on a commuter bus last Friday.
Production staffs for seven works to be given by the New York City Opera Company in its spring season of American opera at the City Center were announced yesterday by Julius Rudel, general director.

CELAYA, Mexico, March 3 (AP) -- Twenty-eight persons were killed today in the blazing cras of a passenger truck carrying alcoholic beverages. There were six s,vivors. The crash occurred on the Pan American Highway about 150 miles northwest of Mexico City.

THE late Manie Sacks, one of the very few men in show business of whom an ill word was never heard, was honored last night in a special ninety-minute program featuring some of the stars he had aided and befriended.

LITTLE ROCK, March 3 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said that the results of a Little Rock Chamber of Commerce poll -- which showed a majority favoring reopening the city's public high schools -- did not reflect the attitude of the people of the city.

Two monumental figures in swimming will exit from the collegiate scene simultaneously at Cambridge on Saturday with the Harvard - Yale dual meet, which, as usual, will decide the Eastern League title.

MIAMI, March 3 -- The family discussions had been casual for a couple of weeks. Whenever the 19-year-old Sammy Boulmetis mentioned his yearning to become a part of the horse race business, papa and mama laughed him off. The boy wasn't serious. Of that they were certain. No young man in his right mind would abandon a promising career in the printing trade for anything as ephemeral as becoming a jockey.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Federal Communications Commission officials said today a series of conferences was being held with the House Commerce Committee concerning proposed tests for subscription television systems.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 3 -- About 1,000 demonstrators, approximately 800 of them students of the National University, staged riots in the streets of downtown Bogota this afternoon and tonight.
COLUMBIA, Mo., March 3 (AP) -- A Nicaraguan editor appealed to the World Press Congress today to help his country "avoid the consummation of a bloody tragedy."
LONDON, March 3 -- The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by 16,000,000 ($44,800,000), the Treasury announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Union economists declared today that wage increases negotiated this year should equal or exceed last year's.
MISS LESLIE MORRIS' finishing school came to order yesterday noon. Opening session of the spring term at Bergdorf Goodman was a brilliant lesson in how to dress with taste, charm, decorum and wit.
Drug treatment that tricks a cancer cell into breeding its own biochemical "fifth column" was described here yesterday by a British biologist and physiologist.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- George Mason Miller, a North Carolina high school junior who aspires to be United States Ambassador to Ghana, left today on a two-week visit to that country as the guest of its Prime Minister, Dr. Kwame Nkrumah.
The Board of Education reported last night that enrollment in the city's sixteen evening high schools was down about 5,000 from a comparable date last year.
TAINAN, Taiwan, March 1 -- The fate of Quemoy and Matsu is linked inseparably with the fate of Taiwan, in the opinion of native Taiwanese in this area.

The Metropolitan Opera will sponsor its first evening of ballets by its corps de ballet on Sunday evening, March 22, at 8 o'clock at the Opera House. The program will consist of four new works, composed especially for the occasion, and will enlist the services of five guest soloists from outside the ranks of the company.
Capt. William Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, yesterday drew a picture of himself as a one-man tugboat men's local under questioning in State Supreme Court.

We published a news story yesterday telling how three hundred angry Queens and Brooklyn home owners had picketed City. Hall in protest over recent increases in the assessed valuations of their properties. City officials were accused of a "conspiracy" against owners of one-family and two-family homes. Several pickets charged that assessed valuation on their home had increased more than 100 per cent.

Another estate in the Riverdale area of the Bronx is yielding to the demand for apartment sites there. It is at 2473 Palisades Avenue near Old Independence Avenue and has been sold by Lawrence Fields to Robert S. Olnick for improvement with an apartment building.

A Federal court has ruled that the Armour Research Foundation and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation have no exclusive right to a magnetic tape that is used widely in sound recording, television and ballistic missiles.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington, a strong critic of Administration defense policies, was named today to head a new Senate subcommittee to investigate "wasteful rivalry and duplication" in space programs.
ROME, March 3 -- The German-speaking people of Upper Adige, or southern Tyrol, received two setbacks today in their fight for a greater degree of autonomy.
TIFTON, Ga., March 3 (AP) -- Five girls and four boys drowned today when their school bus plunged into a roadside pond five miles from this community in southern Georgia.
THE gazebo, a perennial favorite of yesterday's gardens, probably will be making a comeback, at least if the interest shown in one at the National Antiques Show is any indication.
GENEVA, March 3 -- The United States urged again today that fast-moving on-site inspection teams be permanently ready to check possible violations of the proposed ban on testing nuclear weapons.
New highs in payments to policyholders and beneficiaries, total amount of life insurance in force and the number of persons insured were attained by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company last year.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- The Philadelphia Bar Association repudiated today recent implied criticisms of the Supreme Court made by the American Bar Association.
The Transit Authority undertook yesterday to obtain the removal of Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley's ban on advertisements on the outside of its 2,000 buses.
A hereditary defect that afflicts the small intestine was described yesterday as the cause of abdominal disease in children and an anemia-like disease in adults.

A FARM, Algeria, March 3 -- Monsieur D., who owns a farm in Algeria's war-ravaged hinterland called the Bled, requests that his identity be obscured because: "If the fellaghas, the rebels, learn that I've been talking, I will be egorge." Egorge is a common word in the Bled. It means to have one's throat cut.

State and municipal long-term financing in February aggregated $850,565,533, the largest monthly total since May of 1958, according to The Daily Bond Buyer, trade newspaper. In May of last year, borrowing exceeded $876,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today two criminal indictments accusing a coal company at Scranton, Pa., of making payoffs over a five-year period to a United Mine Workers official.
THE time is midnight. The place is a wooded glen coated with cobwebs. Clouds drift slowly across the night sky. Fireflies flicker in the branches. An owl quizzically surveys the scene before it.

THE world may be divided into gigantic alliances and rightly terrified by the prospect of too much power in the nervous hands of a few fallible statesmen. But the role of small countries happily does not seem to diminish. Many of them are represented in the General Assembly of the United Nations, countries with scarcely more divisions than the Pope, such as El Salvador, Ethiopia, Liberia and Paraguay.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday to its members the dollars and cents results of last year's trading -- the most active since 1930. The increased turnover raised the Big Board's total income by 30 per cent to $16,258,951 while at the same time increasing its expenses for salaries and wages by $747,000.

A nation-wide survey indicates that every technological, economic and conceptual means needed to solve New York's commutation problems for the present and foreseeable fu ture now exists. A canvass of technical experts, engineers, social scientists, public specialists and transport executives leaves no doubt that we possess an abundance of methods and forces capable of coping with the revolutionary consequences of the automotive age.
The Canadian National Railways in January spent $4,746,000 more to operate its 24,497 miles of track than it received in fares and freight revenues.

Despite a plucky fourth-quarter bid, the New York Knickerbockers failed once again in their bid to clinch second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association last night at Madison Square Garden. And once again it was the Syracuse Nationals who stopped the Knicks, this time by a 127-to-120 score.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation announced plans yesterday to sell up to 621,353 shares of its holding of 1,030,504 shares of the common stock in the New York Shipbuilding Corporation. At last night's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange of $36.25 for Shipbuilding's shares, Merritt-Chapman would realize more than $22,500,000 if it should proceed with its plans.
PARIS, March 3 -- Whatever hope Britain had had of resuming last year's unsuccessful negotiations for a European free-trade area appeared to have vanished today.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 3 -- The necessity for tooling to meet the increase in wash-and-wear fabrics was emphasized today to representatives of the laundry industry attending the annual convention of the American Institute of Laundering.

Tickets are still available for a theatre party Monday evening for the benefit of the Guidance Center of New Rochelle, N. Y. It will take place at the perfomance of "Redhead," in which Gwen Verdon is starring at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 3 -- The Greek Cypriote terror organization, E. O. K. A., will be called upon to surrender its guns to the British Government, Archbishop Makarios, political and spiritual leader of the Greek Cypriotes, declared today.
TRENTON, March 3 -- New Jersey moved swiftly today to meet an expected commuter crisis when the New York Central Railroad abandons its ferry services between Weehawken and Manhattan.

The bond market continued to show strength yesterday on all fronts except in the Treasury bill market. Buyers were undaunted by another burst of rising prices in stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- The annual spring merry-go-round in the Yankee camp is now in full swing. Players are being shifted here, there and everywhere.

A long-rumored proxy contest at the Philip Carey Manufacturing Company came into the open yesterday as an opposition stockholders' group filed preliminary material with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 3 -- A test of strength between Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike and Ceylon's Trotskyite Opposition ended in a stalemate today.

The First National City Bank of New York has opened its latest branch in two converted house trailers in Rego Park, Queens. The branch, the bank's seventy-eighth in the metropolitan area, will provide service until a permanent branch is built on an adjacent site.
BALTIMORE, March 3 (AP) -- J. Harold Grady, who waged a "good government" campaign, scored a smashing victory today over Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro in the Democratic primary election.
T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton will put on a new musical at their Phoenix Theatre in conjunction with the scene designers, William and Jean Eckart.
NEW YORK, March 3 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the United States woolen textile industry criticized the United States Treasury today for revoking an extra tariff on wool tops imported from Uruguay.
LONDON, March 3 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told his fellow-countrymen today that he was sure his trip to the Soviet Union had been worth making.

The need for a more flexible -- and more generous -- immigration law remains as important now as at any time in the past. It is therefore discouraging to note in The Times (Feb. 20) that Senator John Kennedy proposes a new immigration bill whose main provision is as narrow and dogmatic as any in the most recent "reform" legislation, the justly criticized McCarran-Walter Act.

Washington High's basketball team upset the defending titleholder, De Witt Clinton, 64 to 61, in the Public Schools Athletic League play-off tournament yesterday. The contest was the third on a four-game program that started at 11 A. M. and attracted a record schoolboy crowd of 15,800 to Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize his appointment of a five-member commission to make a thorough investigation of the Federal Government's role in the management of telecommunications.
The New York Central Railroad was ordered yesterday to continue its passenger service and retain its waiting room facilities at Thornwood, Hawthorne and Valhalla, in Westchester.

MOSCOW, March 3 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of a British-Soviet communique signed today by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union and of an agreement on cultural relations, as made public by the British delegation:...
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Embassy of Israel announced today that Ambassador Abba Eban was leaving his post at the end of May to return to Israel.
The proportion of city residents with hospital care insurance is less than might be expected, according to the current bulletin of the Hospital Council of Greater New York.

The May 14 performance of "First Impressions" will be benefit sponsored by the Ethel Walker School Alumnae Association. The musical version of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice," starring Polly Bergen, Hermione Gingold and Farley Granger, is scheduled to open at the Alvin Theatre on March 19.
Fifty students at Hamilton College in Clinton, N. Y., are getting the rudiments of a course in logic by machine in an experiment to see whether a gadget can do part of a professors job.

MANILA, March 3 -- The Foreign Ministry was informed by a cable message from Washington today of representations from Moscow concerning the detention of five Soviet fishing trawlers in the territorial waters of the Philippines.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke said today that a day-to-day possibility of Soviet submarine warfare against the western nations' ocean commerce demanded constant alertness.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today he believed that the continuing negotiations on a declaration of peaceful intent by the Soviet Union and Britain would be crowned by success.

MONTREAL, March 3 -- The vast steel processing, and producing complex planned near here by the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation (Dosco) will be developed jointly by Belgian, Canadian and British interests.

The International Harvester Company incurred a decline of 21.8 per cent in sales in the quarter ended Jan. 31 as a result of a two-month strike by the United Auto Workers, the report disclosed yesterday.

The price of copper was advanced one-half cent a pound yesterday, to 31 1/2 cents, by a leading custom smelter. Other major smelters withdrew temporarily from the market, but it was assumed in the trade they would move to that price -- or a higher one -- before long.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- Eight African countries proposed today that the General Assembly call for new general elections in the French Cameroons before independence is granted Jan. 1.

MIAMI, March 3 -- Rosewood of the Calumet Farm won the $40,000 Black Helen Handicap today at Hialeah, and her accomplishment posed an important problem for the favorite players. The problem was "what are we going to do for shipping money?"

THE jocund press agent always seems to be a little busier at this time of year, sending out a jolly stream of items that may be either newsworthy or only fascinating to hunters and fishermen. Here is a bucketful from the stream:
The expert musicians of the New York Woodwind Quintet gave the first of two concerts last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

JERSEY CITY, March 3 -- The seizure of a $14,092 "boodle fund" of the C. F. Mueller Company here was disclosed today by Hudson County Prosecutor Lawrence A. Whipple. The sum has been impounded in the prosecutor's office.
A man was indicted here yesterday as an agent "in unlawful arrangements between property owners and city personnel."
HAVANA, March 3 -- Premier Castro denounced today the acquittal of forty-three Air Force men by a court-martial yesterday in Santiago de Cuba and said the accused would be retried.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A labor union took a strong stand today against "featherbedding."
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority has rejected arguments that last month's contract to buy a British steam turbine will injure the national security of the United States.

OTTAWA, March 3 -- Canada has sent a note to the United States protesting the possible mandatory application of oil import cuts, Sidney Smith, Secretary of State for External Affairs, told the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- In the personal and political crisis of recent days, Washington has begun to show a little more appreciation of its much maligned and criticized corps of professional Government employes.
BONN, Germany, March 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer accepted today the refusal of Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, to run for the West German presidency.

A champagne reception and a preview of "Art: U. S. A.: '59," an extensive collection of contemporary American art, at the Coliseum on the evening of April 4 will benefit the American Ballet Theatre. The event has been arranged to raise funds for the company's twentieth anniversary season.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 8 -- Two student officers of the all-white Lane High School in Charlottesville, Va., have come here to find out what an integrated school is like.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States expressed to Bolivia today its "grave concern" about anti-United States violence in La Paz.

The Ninth Assembly District Republican Club announced yesterday that it was opposing Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley's proposal to make Fifth, Madison, Lexington and Third Avenues one-way traffic streets.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower invited Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today to come here to discuss the Berlin crisis at his convenience.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 3 -- Rioting spread throughout Nyasaland following the declaration of a state of emergency today. Twenty-three persons were reported to have been killed.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Wheat futures backed and filled over a fairly broad range today on the Board of Trade but closed with most contracts well on the up side. Other grains and soybeans were mostly lower.

TRENTON, March 3 -- New Jersey has recovered thirty legislative acts signed by Woodrow Wilson and the will of a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The documents were stolen from the state house two years ago.
PROVIDENCE, March 3 (AP) -- Student criticism rose today against a Brown University instructor who is seeking to end intercollegiate football at the Ivy League school.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 3 (UPI) -- The medalists, James McAlvin of Lake Forest, Ill., and Thomas B. Robbins of Pinehurst, today advanced to the semi-finals of the Pinehurst Country Club's senior four-ball golf tournament.

THE fear of being mystified is an effective deterrent to the imagination -- a fact Belgian painter Rene Magritte recognized as a youth. His paintings and drawings, on view, respectively, at the Alexandre Iolas Gallery, 123 East Fifty-fifth Street, and the Bodley Gallery, 223 East Sixtieth Street, defy that fear: they are mystifying and breathtaking to the highest power in their silent poetry.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, received an injection of radioactive gold today in his struggle against intestinal cancer.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Assembly Republicans today beat down an attempt to force from committee a bill designed to protect New York City utility customers from a $10,000,000-a-year rate increase.
LONDON, March 3 -- Bitterness reminiscent of the atmosphere in the Suez and Cyprus disputes flared in the House of Commons tonight over the mounting strife in the British territories of Africa.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba has accepted an invitation to speak in Washington next month.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The American Council on Education called today for unity among the nation's colleges and universities.
The Advertising Federation of America is alerting its membership to what it terms "serious problems" facing the industry.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 3 (AP) -- Tuleg, a stablemate of the sidelined Tomy Lee, has been made a supplementary nominee for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Derby Saturday.
LINDEN, N. J., March 3 -- The 1959 budget adopted by the Linden City Council tonight had that rare quality -- something for almost everybody at a lower tax rate.
AS acted at Henry Miller's last evening, "Look After Lulu" is too funny to be amusing. Everyone in it works so hard that the audience becomes exhausted.

IT is possible to build programs that rely heavily on our century without offending conservative tastes or being dull. It is even possible to believe that the repertory of our century is broad and substantial enough to assume an increasing share in our concert fare.
Radio specialists in the metropolitan area said last night that the Army's moon rocket Pioneer IV might be passing beyond range of their equipment.
Union gravediggers and groundkeepers in nine cemeteries in Queens and Westchester County were ordered on strike early this morning.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, March 3 -- Attempting to board a flight from here to Blantyre, Nyasaland, John Stonehouse, a British Laborite Member of Parliament, was forcibly detained today by two federal immigration officials.
Bolivia, high in the Andes -- most of the population dwells at 8,000 feet or above -- lives with the specter of exhausted mines.
BOSTON, March 3 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following reports on ski conditions today along with the weather forecast for New England:
The former manager of a Long Island bank pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn to charges that he had approved $150,000 in "shaky" loans to a building contractor in 1957 and 1958.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- More than 500 firemen won a battle today over two Central City fires that had broken out four blocks and two hours apart in the historic district.
Patrolman Charles Wagner could have used track shoes instead of policeman's brogans to issue a jaywalking summons yesterday.

Michigan borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of the Detroit-Metropolitan Expressway. The money was raised by the sale of serial obligations secured by a pledge of state revenues, stemming from taxes on gasoline and other motor fuels and from fees on motor vehicle registrations.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower was told today that a bill to permit self-employed persons to set up their own tax-exempt pension funds might cost $3,000,000,000 in Federal revenues.

Prime Minister Macmillan has returned from his ten-day reconnaissance trip to Russia with what the British hail as a "limited triumph" which for the moment at least has warmed the international atmosphere above the sub-zero point to which Premier Khrushchev had reduced it. But the trip has not broken the East-West deadlock, and the real results can only be revealed by Soviet actions.
A group supporting the Rev. William Howard Melish lost its court fight for church funds yesterday.

Mayor Wagner continued yesterday to keep shrouded in mystery his plans for new taxes. All he would say was that he was "searching around" among possible new taxes and having research done on some of them.
ALBANY, March 3 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State CommerceI Department today:

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP) -- Bob Carpenter, the owner of the Philadelphia Phillies, is considering buying the remainder of a seventy-five-acre tract in Delaware Township, N. J., that has been suggested as a new site for his baseball team.

Ever since a fateful meeting of foreign ministers in New York back in 1950, the central fact of our official policy in Europe has been the rearming of Western Germany under NATO. This appears to have been instigated first by Sir Winston Churchill as an expedient for countering a series of Soviet expansionist moves in Europe, instituted largely by Stalin. Since that date the military, political and personal factors have all changed.
A Nobel Prize scientist yesterday called on American writers to create the visions to guide the burgeoning human and technical powers of the world.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower exchanged gifts and conversation today with six teenagers here for the National 4-H Club Week.
Apparently provided with new ammunition after his clash with Mayor Wagner in Albany on Monday, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa continued his battle here with the Board of Education yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower touched a golden telegraph key on his desk today and more than a mile away "the world's most mechanized post office" came alive with moving conveyer belts and electronic sorting machines.

The Brierfield, a fifteen-story apartment hotel containing 118 suites at 215 West Eighty-third Street has been purchased by Charles Zurechi, Isaac H. Pinchuk and Abraham Gorodechi. The deal was for cash over a mortgage of $393,000.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., March 3 -- All was quiet on the Olympic Village front early this evening as the last of the competitors taking part in the North American championships packed their gear and headed for home.

The Norwegian tanker Jalanta disappeared from the radar scope of the American Export liner Constitution two miles before the two ships collided in dense fog Sunday morning southeast of Ambrose Lightship.
Copper futures registered one of the sharpest advances of the year yesterday on the heaviest volume on the Commodity Exchange since Dec. 3.

The Mayor's nonpartisan and knowledgeable committee studying Welfare Department operations has acted wisely in releasing its considered opinion on an important immediate issue: should people who have lived in New York State less than a year be denied public assistance? A bill to do this is now before the Legislature, for which Republican Senate Majority Leader Mahoney has announced his support. Governor Rockefeller, however, has opposed any such restriction -- as does the Mayor's committee.

LEIPZIG, March 3 (AP) -- At the fair's Soviet pavilion, statues of Stalin and Lenin have gone. Instead there are copies of the Soviet earth satellites. Behind the sputniks stretches a long array of machine tools, models of power plants and other heavy machinery.
The Jersey Central Railroad is threatening its 12,500 daily passengers with a 60 per cent rise in all fares.

Penn State filed an official protest yesterday against the judging reversal that cost it the team title in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America indoor track and field championships last Saturday night.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

As a member of the Municipal Affairs Committee of the Citizens Union I have frequently voiced rather sharp protests over the deficiencies in the subway service of our city. The files of the Transit Authority contain many letters from me containing questions regarding such deficiencies, and in several instances suggestions for improvement.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Democrat called today for a Congressional investigation of "outside influence" and "backdoor" operations in the Department of Agriculture.
WARSAW, March 3 -- The Polish Government has announced new incentives to attract more settlers to the former German territories in western Poland.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders said today that President Eisenhower shared their view that new curbs should be voted on the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Battle lines began to be drawn yesterday over the bill to revise the state's branch banking and bank holding company laws introduced in Albany on Monday.

LONDON, March 3 -- A Government decision to raise landing and passenger service charges at British airports to the point that they will be the most expensive in Europe, except Dublin, is being vigorously protested here by both British and foreign airlines.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- Work will start tomorrow on a two-mile sports car track in the infield of Daytona's International Speedway. Bill France, speedway president, today said the new course would be ready for practice immediately following the twelve-hour international sports car race at Sebring, Fla., on Saturday, March 21.

The appointments of Anthony I. Eyring and Robert R. C. Pape as vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank were announced yesterday by George Champion, president. Both were formerly assistant vice presidents.
A Yiddish-language book has been published in the Soviet Union for the first time in more than a decade.

Jack Brause, realty operator, has contracted to buy the five-story building at 142 West Forty-sixth Street, near Times Square, from Norge Italian Restaurant, Inc. The property is assessed at $42,000 and was held by the seller for $75,000.
WASHINGTON March 3 -- Pioneer IV, a small gold-plated capsule of instruments, soared toward the vicinity of the moon tonight, on the way to an orbital rendezvous with the sun.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 3 -- The Rabbinical Council of America, the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinical group in the country, urged the Soviet Union today "to allow its Jewish citizens the privilege of emigrating to the lands of their choice."

DETROIT, March 3 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins overcame a 2-0 deficit on goals by Bronco Horvath and Johnny Bucyk to gain a 2-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings and regain third place in the National Hockey League ahead of the idle New York Rangers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Sidney Poitier will return to Hollywood in the summer to play a starring role in "All the Young Men," a drama dealing with contemporary social issues and set against the background of the Korean conflict.

DETROIT, March 3 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins overcame a 2-0 deficit on goals by Bronco Horvath and Johnny Bucyk to gain a 2-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings and regain third place in the National Hockey League ahead of the idle New York Rangers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Sidney Poitier will return to Hollywood in the summer to play a starring role in "All the Young Men," a drama dealing with contemporary social issues and set against the background of the Korean conflict.
PARIS, March 3 -- Twelve African republics in the French Community are united with France in resisting efforts by the Soviet Union to force the Western allies out of Berlin.
Three sailors chased a suspected hold-up man last night through Manhattan streets. They were credited with assisting in his arrest by a policeman.

Lever Brothers Company is reportedly negotiating for George Gobel to star on a half-hour television series that would alternate with Jack Benny next season over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Consolidated net earnings of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company last year aggregated $13,803,000, more than doubling the $6,886,000 cleared in 1957, the annual report disclosed yesterday. Sales rose 53 per cent to $187,849,000 from the preceding year's volume of $122,605,000. The results were the best in the company's 114-year history.
MOMBASA, Kenya, March 2 -- The large Indian minorities in East Africa are deeply involved in the swift currents of change sweeping the continent.

ST. LOUIS, March 3 (AP) -- Ray Bluth and Dick Weber moved into fourth place in the doubles standings, and Bill Lillard took over fourth, Weber grabbed sixth and Tom Hennessey ninth in the all-events as the St. Louis Budweisers wound up their appearance today in the American Bowling Congress tournament.
Alexander L. Guterma obtained a court order yesterday calling on the Government to show tomorrow why a criminal complaint against him should not be dismissed or immediately heard.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Federal Government has a plan to catch the driver who loses his license in one state but continues to drive on another state's license.

BUENOS AIRES, March 3 -- Paraguayan exiles trying to topple the regime of President Alfredo Stroessner incline to the belief that what they call South America's last dictatorship will crack from within if not attacked by force.
ALBANY, March 3 -- A tax-conscious Republican majority in the Assembly balked tonight at approving a tax and budget compromise recommended by the Republican legislative leadership.
A Department of Sanitation task force opened a campaign yesterday to tidy up the city and made a tangle of pre-noon traffic in the midtown area.

Mayor Wagner was put on notice yesterday that failure by the city to close Washington Square Park permanently to traffic might be used against Carmine G. De Sapio in the brewing Democratic primary fight in Greenwich Village.
The City Council was asked yesterday to come to the aid of a venerable New York institution -- the Greenwich Village sidewalk painter.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The racing season at the state's flat tracks would be permitted to open five days earlier this year, with a total of ten extra racing dates, under a bill approved unanimously by the Assembly today.

ALTHOUGH arrowroot is a standard ingredient in many European kitchens, the thickening agent is relatively unknown in American homes. However, in the opinion of George Muller, this situation is changing rapidly.

Three new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Lonelyhearts," with Montgomery Clift, Robert Ryan, Myrna Loy, Maureen Stapleton and Dolores Hart, is at the Victoria Theatre, Broadway and Forty-sixth Street.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 3 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev will arrive here tomorrow for three days of Soviet Strategy talks with East German leaders on the Berlin crisis against a background of a proud exhibit of Communist industrial power.
Letters Abroad, Inc., a clearing house for correspondence between adult Americans and persons abroad of similar professions and interests, will hold its first benefit on April 6.
LONDON, March 3 -- The stock market threw off the dullness of yesterday and most sections finished strong.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 7 points, (5 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday, except for the July, which advanced 6 points (30 cents).
MINEOLA, L. I., March 3 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors' appointment of Arthur M. Weiss as an Election Commissioner was declared illegal in State Supreme Court here today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 -- A glum figure in the camp of the San Francisco Giants is Bill White. The first baseman, who in 1956 belted twenty-three homers and proved he could hit big-league pitching for distance, feels he is being shunted aside without a chance.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Republican majority in the Legislature decided today to reduce by $10,000,000 the new aid to the city proposed by Governor Rockefeller. The decision revived Democratic charges that the state regularly short-changed New York City.
Imports of crude oil and refined products continued to edge upward last week, pending announcement of the Government's new control program.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Despite Governor Rockefeller's personal intervention, the Republican legislative leadership still lacked tonight enough Assembly votes to win approval of an income tax increase.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4 (UPI) -- Judy Bell and Mrs. Maurice Glick coasted to victories today in the opening round of match play in the women's Florida East Coast amateur golf championship.

HALLANDALE,, Fla., March 14 -- Gulfstream Park opened its fifteenth season today and the turnout was less than it was for opening day a year ago. The difference was hardly enough to cause concern among the stockholders, though; and if the attendance continues at the same rate for the rest of the meeting, they will be satisfied.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 4 -- The North Carolina General Assembly was air-lifted here today from Raleigh, the state capital, for a tour of the state's largest city.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company (3-M) achieved the highest sales and earnings in its fifty-six-year history last year even though income in the first half was 10 per cent below the 1957 level.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A bill that could force the premature retirement of 3,500 Navy and Marine Corps officers was passed by the House of Representatives today. The vote was by voice. The measure now goes to the Senate where concurrence is expected.

Bertrand Russell, the 86-year-old philosopher, teacher, author and Nobel Prize winner, has a new book on Simon Schuster's list for publication later this month. Called "My Philosophical Development," it traces his search for certainty beginning at the age of 15.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The American Bankers Association added its voice to that of the Eisenhower Administration today in urging Congress to approve increases in this nation's financial backing of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

A Board of Education official balked at telling a grand jury the contents of a report on insurance for children yesterday. He was threatened with contempt charges by Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -President Eisenhower told a group of meat packers today that he recently sold a steer for "a fancy price." They agreed.
BOSTON, March 4 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following reports on ski conditions today along with the weather forecast for New England:

President Colgate W. Darden Jr. of the University of Virginia announced his wish to retire a year ago. The Board of Visitors has now announced that Dr. Edgar Finley Shannon of the university's English department has been chosen as the new head of the university Thomas Jefferson founded in 1819.
The Beth Din, the divorce court of Conservative Judaism, has set up a marriage counseling service that could diminish its divorce docket.

BOSTON, March 4 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers clinched second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association tonight, rallying for a 118-115 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors. Richie Guerin's 32 points paced the Knicks' triumph.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 4 -- A proposal to establish an animal-lending library for children here has run afoul of the Connecticut Humane Society.
LONDON, March 4 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today that he intended to discuss with other Western leaders the possibility of limiting nuclear and conventional forces in Central Europe.
Philadelphia borrowed $25,480,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance water supply, sewerage and other public improvements.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., March 4 -- After having been a New York police lieutenant, Mayor of Mount Kisco, chairman of the Union Political party here and a security officer for the Government and several hospitals, Bertrand Wray intends to become a brother in the Roman Catholic Society of Jesus.

" Green Mansions," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film version of the W. H. Hudson novel, starring Audrey Hepburn and Anthony Perkins, will have its premiere at the Music Hall on March 19. The film, which was directed by Mel Ferrer, will be accompanied by the showcase's annual Easter stage program.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 4 -- Calm returned to Bogota today after the student riots yesterday. Groups of students attempted to overturn vehicles at noon but they were dispersed by large contingents of the Army and the national police.
Important opposition is develing upstate to holding company aspects of the proposed revision of the State Banking Law introduced in the Legislature early this week.

RENO, Nev., March 4 -- Pavel Kolchin, the little Russian who won the North American 1,500-kilometer cross-country championship last Monday, is one of those skiers who had to learn how to use the hickory boards through necessity.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 4 (AP) -- L. J. Rittner's Bobby Rit, the 7-5 favorite, survived a foul claim and won the $7,500 Inaugural Handicap today as Lincoln Downs launched the 1959 New England racing season before a crowd of 15,018.

David Francis, a 7-year-old New York boy, has been selected to portray a leading role in the ninety-minute television adaptation of William Saroyan's "The Human Comedy." His only professional appearances have been in filmed television commercials.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 4 -- Demonstrators stoned United States Information Agency offices in two central Bolivian cities today. Windows were smashed but no injuries to United States personnel were reported in the third consecutive day of anti-United States outbursts in this country.

HANS HARTUNG, who was born in Germany in 1904 and who settled in Paris in 1935, is now considered a leader in the School of Paris avant-garde. With an honorable record of having been "abstract" since 1922, Hartung is one of the painters who established "forces" as the subject matter of abstract painting.
The mass demonstration through which union chiefs hope to focus Congressional attention on the plight of the nation's unemployed will be held at the National Guard Armory in Washington, April 8.

Helen Menken, president of the American Theatre Wing, announced yesterday the nominees for the 1959 Antoinette Perry Awards, better known as the Tony Awards. The candidates, selected by the nominating committee, will be voted on by the wing's board of directors.

NEWARK, March 4 -- Two men who admitted the hold-up of a commuter bus last Friday said today they had got the idea from a television Western. Law enforcement agents began questioning them about another bus robbery and the hold-up of a toll station on the Garden State Parkway.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., March 4 (AP) -- Thirteen persons were arrested today -- one of them twice -- in skirmishes between pickets and workers at the International Knitting Mills plant here.

ALTHOUGH the subject of "Royal Gambit" is old, the point of view is new. Henry VIII is the subject of Hermann Gressieker's play, which opened last evening at the Sullivan Street Playhouse (181 Sullivan Street).

MIAMI BEACH, March 4 (UPI) -- Charley Powell, a former professional football player, blasted Nino Valdes to the canvas three times tonight and scored a spectacular knockout at 2:03 of the eighth round of their scheduled ten-round bout.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. will receive the Maritime Association's fourteenth annual award for distinguished contributions to the development of shipping in the Port of New York.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 4 (AP) -- Scattered new violence was reported tonight in Nyasaland.
A Union of hospital employes accused the Greater New York Hospital Association yesterday of heading a "union-busting conspiracy" in the city's voluntary hospitals.
A strike of gravediggers, chauffeurs and general maintenance workers halted burials yesterday at seven of nine struck cemeteries.
Two whistle signals were heard coming from the left of the liner Constitution by members of her crew minutes before she collided with the Norwegian tanker Jalanta in dense fog.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

BUFFALO, March 4 -- Mr. Maull complimented the Joint Legislative Committee on Banks today for "coming up with a solution" to new banking legislation. He told the annual meeting here that Marine Midland's situation was "good." He said:

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Treasury announced today a technical change in its regular weekly issue of bills. The change results from the introduction late last year of a new cycle of 182-day bills in addition to the regular ninety-one-day bills.

The concept of setting up commissions with power to review and direct compliance with approved plans of desegregation of the schools as proposed by Gov. Le Roy Collins of Florida is sound in principle, provided the following safeguards are included:
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The State Department said today that it had not been officially informed of the intended visit here of Fidel Castro, but he would be welcome.

The strength of long-term United States Government bonds continues to be the major topic of interest in the bond market. The long Treasuries assumed the market leadership about a week ago as institutional orders came in for the new 4 per cent bonds of 1980.

Two auxiliary bishops have been appointed to assist Bishop Bryan J. McEntegart of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. They are the Very Rev. Charles R. Mulrooney, 53 years old, rector of Cathedral College, Brooklyn, and the Very Rev. Joseph P. Denning, 52, pastor of Queen of Angels Church, Long Island City, Queens.

THE "Bell Telephone Hour" now must rank as one of the more civilized additions to this season's programing schedules. The early promise of its premiere has been sustained, and the sixty-minute presentation is proving a consistently delightful sampling of the concert world.

One of Broadway's fastest sandwich-makers, Nickolas Katsalidas, turned in his white cap yesterday and, after a sandwich party, retired from Horn Hardart's automat near Forty-sixth Street. He had worked there for thirty-two years.
Two subway breakdowns on the East Side IRT delayed thousands of morning rush-hour commuters yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- Another closing rally wiped out all but a few small minus signs on the Board of Trade today and left most prices substantially ahead of previous finishes.

CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- Bank employes testified today that a union official accused of income-tax evasion had made at least forty-three withdrawals of union funds since 1951. One was for $37,000, they said.

NEW JERSEY farmers have again made it plain that they aim to have a great deal to say about the harvest of deer in their state next fall. It is not likely that they will speak with one voice, but they will speak often and loudly.
A second bus company would like to build a new terminal in the "forbidden" midtown zone east of Eighth Avenue, it was made known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

TRENT, Italy, March 4 -- A dynamite explosion shook Trent last night. It damaged the mausoleum and grave of Cesare Battisti, Italian patriot and irredentist agitator who was hanged by the Austrians in his native city of Trent in 1916.
GENEVA, March 4 -- The United States emphasized today that veto-free majority rule must be the basic operating principle of the proposed organization for policing a ban on testing nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The House Democratic leadership made a surprise announcement today that it planned fast action on a one-year extension of emergency Federal aid to the unemployed. The Democratic plan constitutes the biggest threat yet raised against President Eisenhower's budget-balancing policy and raises it on the sensitive issue of lingering post-recession unemployment.

IF present trends in women's employment continue, nine out of ten young women will be wage earners an average of twenty-five years. This prediction was made here yesterday by Dr. Henry David, director of the National Manpower Council, in an address before the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Bronx Zoo is offering, in the form of twin tiger cubs, a study in the influence of environment. The cubs, now about three months old, were separated shortly after birth at the Bronx Zoo. The male remale remained with his mother. The female was raised by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Martini, keepers at the zoo, in their home.
A NOTED lighting expert called on manufacturers yesterday to produce a 100-watt lamp bulb the size of an olive.

Just as expected, state financial aid to New York City was among the first tempting targets when Republican legislators began trimming down the Rockefeller budget. The cries of pain and outrage from New York City Democrats were instant. To Mayor Wagner the $10,000,000 economy taken out of the city's hide was "a travesty on good government."

MIAMI, March 4 -- "You done splendid," said Casey Stengel, enthusiastically shaking the hand of Billy O'Dell of the Orioles in the clubhouse after last year's All-Star game. "Your pitchin' was amazin'. I'm glad I picked you."
New York Airways sought permission yesterday for the eventual operation of aircraft more advanced than conventional helicopters.
The Celanese Corporation of America had, last year, the highest sales since 1950 and lifted earnings 48 per cent over those of 1957, according to the annual report released today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that it would be futile and disastrous for the non-Communist world to mount a general mobilization to achieve constant readiness against possible Soviet attack.
TRENTON, March 4 -- Paul M. Butler predicted today that Adlai E. Stevenson would not get the Democratic nomination for President next year, even as a compromise candidate.
