The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which owns 65 per cent of the stock of Cuban Telephone Company, issued a statement here yesterday confirming the action of the Cuban Government.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Officials of a mutual and a stock life insurance company today gave qualified endorsement of the House-passed life insurance tax bill but suggested to the Senate Finance Committee amendments they said would make it more equitable.

PARIS, March 4 -- The meeting of President Charles de Gaulle and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in Paris today gave new emphasis to a unique alliance between France and West Germany. It is a marriage of convenience rather than of love.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Feb. 25.

Mrs. Harold I. Pratt, philanthropist, was selected yesterday for the 1958 citation of merit by the Park Association of New York. The selection was made by the group's board of directors at a bimonthly meeting in the National Arts Club, 50 Gramercy Park South.
The proposal to increase the city's 3 per cent sales tax to 4 per cent is "dead," Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

Directors of Federated Department Stores, Inc., increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 50 cents a share on the common stock for payment April 30. This action placed the stock on a $2 annual rate, compared with $1.80 formerly, when shareholders received 45 cents quarterly.

The custom smelter price of refined copper advanced 1/2 cent a pound again yesterday to 32 cents. However only one of the three major custom smelter concerns was offering any metal. The others remained out of the market, as they had on Tuesday.

HAVANA, March 4 -- The Government took over control and management of the Cuban Telephone Company today. The concern is a wholly-owned affiliate of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation reported yesterday new highs in 1958 operating revenues and net income.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Draft exemption for men over age 21 was proposed today by Representative Merwin Coad, Democrat of Iowa.
BOSTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Coast Guard began operating today of its international ice patrol for the 1959 ice season.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Officials here intimated today that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan had discussed with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev the "threshold" principle as a way to break the stalemate on banning tests of nuclear weapons.
Huntington, W. Va.'s scrappy boxers won the team title with 16 points in the twenty-third annual Eastern Golden Gloves championships at Madison Square Garden last night.
LONDON, March 4 -- Britain complained today that the choice of a United States system of aircraft navigational aids over a British system had been based on other than scientific grounds.
The twelfth annual card party of the Women's Board of Church Charity Foundation of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will be held April 24 in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Pioneer IV sped past the moon today and headed for its own lasting orbit around the sun.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The steady outflow of gold from the United States halted in February, final figures for that month revealed today.

DARIEN, Conn., March 4 -- Brown University will receive $1,000,000 from the estate of the late John Laporte Given Jr., a grandson of Henry John Heinz, founder of a pickle fortune. Mr. Given died in New York Sept. 15, 1957, at the age of 50.
IF there had been as many failures in the launching of the early American atom bombs as there were in the launching of the early American satellites, what might we all be saying today?

ALBANY, March 4 -- Several changes in the Regents Examination Program -- including the establishment of a minimum passing mark -- were announced today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 4 (AP) -- Stanley Benham of Lake Placid, said today nine countries had signed and five others were expected to sign a pledge to participate in the 1960 world bobsledding championships here if they could obtain Olympic status.
Johnny Saxton, former world's welterweight boxing champion, was arrested last night in a Queens burglary that the police said netted $5.20 in cash.
American scientists have reached a major landmark in the exploration of inner space.

Records fell in a highly irregular session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. With only the nonferrous metals and the steels showing consistent strength, historic highs were established for both The New York Times' combined average of fifty stocks and the industrial average.

LOS ANGELES, March 4 -- Spring and the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of California, arrived approximately simultaneously on the University of California campus here today. The result was a teapot tempest about "separation of church and state."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 (AP) -- Dick Fischer scored four goals tonight as Harvard defeated Princeton, 5 -- 1, and clinched second place in Ivy League hockey. Mike Graney tallied the other Harvard goal and George Morris scored for Princeton.

Everett C. Drake was elected president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., yesterday in a realignment of top officers of the textile manufacturing concern. Mr. Drake, who had been controller, also was elected a director. As president, he succeeds Donald B. Tansill, who was named chairman.
The Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc., and ten leading rubber companies, were indicted yesterday in Federal Court on criminal charges of conspiring to fix the price of rubber belting.
The Fourth Avenue Association expressed opposition yesterday to the revived proposal for an elevated crosstown roadway over Thirtieth Street.

Income on premiums of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company last year reached a new high of $335,494,837, according to Frazer B. Wilde, president. The previous record was $317,848,469 in 1957.

By action of its House of Delegates taken on Feb. 24 the American Bar Association failed the American public in interpreting for the citizens the work of the Supreme Court in our constitutional and legal system. What the bar association did, in short, was to align itself with lay critics of the court.

Hal Roach Jr., chairman of the F. L. Jacobs Company, has filed his first report with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a holder of more than 10 per cent of that concern's stock, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The National Cancer Institute, after lengthy negotiations, has declined to test Krebiozen, a controversial cancer drug, on the terms proposed by its chief supporter, Dr. Andrew C. Ivy.
Premier Khrushchev has executed another typical zigzag in Soviet foreign policy.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- A freshman Representative from Indiana has put both his wife and his front porch on the Government payroll.

Stockholders in the Lehman Corporation were told at their annual meeting here yesterday that the big closed-end company was "interested in increasing its capital by acquiring additional personal holding companies."
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, attacked Senator William Proxmire for his recent criticism of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson as majority leader.
TRENTON, March 4 -- Senator Cilfford P. Case said today that he would offer a resolution in the Senate tomorrow to block the further curtailment or abandonment of commuter railroad services.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- More than 1,000 educators expressed their opposition today to requiring college students to take an anti-subversion oath before qualifying for Federal aid.
An enjoyable novelty at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University last night was a program of Russian folk songs sung in Russian by the Yale Russian Chorus.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 4 -- The Connecticut Commission on Civil Rights accused the Bridgeport Housing Authority today of racial bias.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower left two distinct impressions at his news conference today: he is assuming more personal responsibility for the conduct of United States foreign policy and he sees no need yet for emergency measures to deal with the Berlin crisis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Lee Remick, young actress with four pictures to her credit, was engaged today to replace Lana Turner as the feminine lead in "Anatomy of a Murder." Otto Preminger, the director-producer of the picture, also reported that his arrangement with Miss Remick provided for additional pictures.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 28 points ($1.40 a bale) off to 1 point (5 cents) up yesterday, with near March, May and July showing the biggest losses. Only the far May contract rose.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- The Veterans Administration announced today that it would review the cases of 284,000 World War II and Korean conflict veterans whose claims of service-connected disabilities were turned down.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 4 -- Although nothing positive has been found linking it with the Sea Venture, flagship of a Virginia-bound fleet wrecked off Bermuda in 1609, Dr. Mendel Peterson of the Smithsonian Institution says there is a chance that wreckage found off the colony's east end last October is that vessel.

Heitor Villa-Lobos, Brazilian composer and condctor, celebrated his seventy-second birthday yesterday at the Alrae Hotel, 37 East Sixty-fourth Street, by praising New York's Handel Festival. The Festival opened Sunday with a concert at Carnegie Hall.

All domestic sugar positions fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by a 2-point (hundredth of a cent a pound) decline in the spot price, making the quotation the lowest since June, 1956.

There are many reasons for feeling disturbed over the anti-American riots in Bolivia. However, two sources of anxiety are obviously over-ruling. There is, first, the new evidence that hostility to the United States is always close to the surface in many Latin-American countries. The other problem lies in Bolivia itself: whether this disturbance will not worsen the already precarious political and economic state of the nation.
LONDON, March 4 -- The stock market continued its advance today, with only the oil and South African gold mining sections lagging.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad went deeply into the red again in January. The company, one of the last in the industry to issue January results, reported a net loss of $1,386,251. In January of 1958, after a special tax refund of $339,000, the company reported a net loss of $1,214,197.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A spokesman for the American Dental Association put the need for international goodwill ahead of the advancement of his profession in testifying today for the "health for peace" bill.
CAIRO, March 4 -- Lieut. Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, who seized power in the Sudan last November in a bloodless coup, dismissed his twelve associates on the Supreme Council today and assumed full powers.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 4 (AP) -- A downpour flooded Melbourne's new $45,000 outdoor music bowl last night, and the crowds that turned out to hear Billy Graham were blamed.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn began a record-breaking forty-seventh year in the House of Representatives today. He said he was feeling as frisky as "a 2-year-old colt."

A taxpayer on plot 85 by 100 feet at 1552 to 1562 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Morris Karp and Bernard Sanford, realty operators, to the Monty Realty Corporation. The deal was negotiated by the Philip Fogel Company, broker.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that he and Governor Rockefeller were "at least two people that believe we ought to live within our means."
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that broader executive training was required for key city aides if New York was to provide more efficient services "in an era of increased demands and limited resources."
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- High unemployment has dissuaded the Federal Reserve Board from adopting a more restrictive credit policy, M. S. Szymczak, a director, said today.
DETROIT, March 4 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company plans to spend more than $35,000,000 to improve its steel-making facilities in Dearborn.
Joseph M. Tocci said yesterday that he was abandoning his political fight against Carmine G. De Sapio after having reached a "meeting of the minds" with the Tammany leader.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 4 -- President Urho Kekkonen declared today that Finland's relations with the West depended on how well she handled her relations with the East.
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 4 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev promised the East German people today a peace treaty whether the Western powers liked it or not.

Although Pioneer IV passed the moon yesterday and is now in orbit around the sun, it cannot be said that at any point it "entered" such an orbit. It was, in fact, orbiting the sun before it left the pad in Florida.
Roman Catholic high school teachers were warned yesterday to prepare students for oblique attacks on their religious precepts in secular colleges and universities.
BRIDES and budgets go together, but never were they so firmly wedded as yesterday.
THE chemise took the starch right out of the petticoat business. Full skirts have put it back.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union became yesterday the first union ever to sign a $1,000,000-a-year advertising contract.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 4 -- Finis was written today to the active pitching career of Bob Lemon, one of baseball's most effective hurlers.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Establishment of a new state agency to deal with problems raised by the development of atomic energy was speedily approved by the Legislature today.

TOKYO, March 4 -- Foreign Minister Alichiro Fujiyama appealed to Foreign Minister Cho Chung Whan of South Korea today for "understanding" on Japan's decision to permit Koreans in Japan to go to Communist North Korea if they wish.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower suggested cautiously today that there might be some "lessening of the rigidity" of the Soviet Union on East-West issues. But he cautioned that "we can't tell until events unfold a little bit further."

New York, known for many generations throughout the world as the city of tomorrow, for one week each year makes its obeisance to yesterday when the annual National Antiques Show comes to occupy the exhibition hall of Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, March 4 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Department of Commerce:

The final collegiate basketball double-header of Madison Square Garden's regular season will be played tonight. St. John's University will meet New York University in the feature and Manhattan College will face Lafayette. The opener will begin at 7:15.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The New York State Council of Churches endorsed today eleven bills proposed by the Joint Legislative Committee on Matrimonial and Family Law. It opposed three others, but said they might be made acceptable by amendments.

LONDON, March 4 -- One of the figures suddenly illumined in the electrical storm of African nationalism was given many years ago the name Bwana M'Pengo, which means "Boss Gap-in-Teeth," because of a dental characteristic believed by Africans to bring luck.

ISLIP, L. I., March 4 -- The State Public Works Department's projection of traffic needs on a thirty-year basis was called a "very short-sighted policy" here today by Suffolk county and town officials.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, March 4 -- A young British Labor member of Parliament charged here today that Sir Roy Welensky was using the critical situation in the federation to bring about a state of independence contrary to the will of the British Government and electorate.
The G. M. Basford Company held yesterday a Madison Avenue version of "operation candor." It talked about its 1958 billings and did not report an increase above those for 1957.

Assemblyman Bernard Haber has died of auto crash injuries which might have been prevented by safety equipment he tried to make compulsory. Senator Pine, co-sponsor of the legislation, was injured in the same accident.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 4 -- The Soviet Union accused France today of "assassinations" in the French Cameroons and demanded new general elections before the territory becomes independent next Jan. 1.
Stockholders of a company formerly controlled by Alexander L. Guterma won a court action yesterday to examine company records.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it would immediately implement many of the main recommendations made recently by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.
Having caught his second wind during a stage sabbatical, Tyrone Guthrie has returned to the fray in his usual vigorous fashion.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- House investigators have reported that the Spanish Government resold United States cotton to textile mills in Spain at much higher prices than it had paid for the surplus stock.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -The Civil Service Commission suggested today that Congress pass a law if it does not like the commission's policy of secrecy on who gets Federal retirement pay.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A remark by President Eisenhower left the impression today that he was becoming reconciled to the idea of having a Secretary of State other than John Foster Dulles.

The E. W. Bliss Company, manufacturers of metal working presses and rolling mills, has purchased for cash 109,400 shares of the outstanding common stock of the Gamewell Company, Newton Upper Falls, Mass. The purchase represents 30 per cent of the outstanding shares.

VIENNA, March 4 -- Foreign Minister Leopold Figl announced today that the Austrian Government would submit the case of Upper Adige (South Tyrol) to competent international organizations if negotiations with Italy failed.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen accepted today an offer of Republican leaders to be their candidate for Mayor.
ALGIERS, March 4 -- European settlers showed irritation and some apprehension today over friendly gestures recently addressed to President Charles de Gaulle by Moroccan and Tunisian leaders.

While state officials and the New York Racing Association were trying to agree yesterday on the opening date for the local thoroughbred season, the hundred-odd race horses at Jamaica continued their daily drills against the prospect of a March 25 debut.
The sordid story of the degradation of a 29-year-old veteran by a Government narcotics informer ended yesterday in Federal Court here.

SMALL electrical appliances for the kitchen are purchased at the rate of almost 30,000,000 annually. In many homes, however, their use is limited because of scattered and insufficient outlets, inadequate wiring and inconvenient storage facilities.
TORONTO, March 4 (UPI) -- Bobby Pulford scored two goals tonight to lead the last-place Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League contest.

On the subject of prospective inflation, the pessimists among economists tend to outnumber the optimists. Yesterday, one such optimistic economist addressed an American Gas Association meeting in Cleveland. He was John D. Wilson, vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
LONDON, March 4 (UPI) -- A white-haired woman spoke to a British television audience with pride tonight about her beloved brother. His name was Adolf Hitler.
ALBANY, March 4 -- The Rockefeller administration came out strongly today in favor of the lease or transfer of the Barge Canal to the Federal Government.
A woman transit detective and her male partner yesterday seized a subway hold-up suspect who, the police said, was responsible for a series of underground robberies.

PARIS, March 4 -- An East-West summit meeting prepared briefly by the foreign ministers appeared tonight to French diplomatic sources to be the most likely result of current diplomatic maneuverings over the Berlin crisis.

The third annual luncheon and fashion show in memory of Humphrey Bogart, the actor, will be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Easter Sunday, March 29. The event, which is being sponsored by Evyan Perfumes, will benefit the Daman Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.

There was recently published in your columns a letter from A. A. Berle Jr. in which Mr. Berle indicated his support for Governor Rockefeller's tax program. The identification of Mr. Berle in connection with this letter as honorary chairman of the Liberal party has occasioned some confusion as to the position of the Liberal party on the Rockefeller proposals.
Outdoor recreation has evolved from a luxury for the few to a necessity of the many, Laurance S. Rockefeller told the twenty-fourth North American Wildlife Conference yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A growing "full-scale Congressional revolt" against recent reductions in price supports on feed grains was reported today by a Kansas Democrat.

Jacob Perlow, realty investor and builder, has purchased three buildings at 313, 315 and 317 East Seventeenth Street from Nationwide Investors, Inc., Eugene Hegy Jr., president. Mr. Perlow plans to raze the structures and improve the site with a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building to be called the Stuyvesant Park.
COLUMBIA, Mo., March 4 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said tonight he wished he could be a newspaper editor for awhile so that he could get what he wanted in the paper.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Congressional hearings on new civil rights-legislation got under way today with an appeal for "light and not heat" from spokesmen for both sides.
Asher W. Schwartz, counsel for the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, said last night that he had resigned.

BONN, Germany, March 4 -- A new era has begun in West Germany domestic policies. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer remains the major figure on the scene but for the first time in a decade he does not dominate it to the exclusion of all others.
LOUIS BROMFIELD spoke of mushruins; Robert Southey, of lowly mushrumps. Whatever they are called, mushrooms are an inspiration for the appetite.

Plans for the first sale of stock in the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., by members of the Hartford family was announced yesterday. The proposed 1,800,000-share offering would represent $83,250,000 at yesterday's closing prices. This would make it the largest secondary stock sale since the $108,450,000 offering of the Upjohn Company's shares last December.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- Amid a maze of trade rumors buzzing around the Yankee camp in the wake of a brewing Cleveland-Kansas City deal, a couple of Bomber pitchers stepped out today to ease the pressure on Casey Stengel.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee announced today the letting of ten contracts for non-governmental foreign policy research studies.

Stockholders approved the proposed merger of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., into the Guaranty Trust Company of New York at special meetings of both institutions yester day. The merger plan, which must be approved by the State Superintendent of Banks and the Federal Reserve Board, would create the third largest bank in this city and the fourth largest in the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Purchases by the secondary mortgage market operation of the Federal National Mortgage Association passed $2,000,000,000 last week, the agency disclosed today.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 4 (AP) -- Anisado, a 5-year-old grass-running specialist from Argentina, won the $28,900 Camino Real Handicap at Santa Anita Park today.

MANILA, March 4 (AP) -- The Philippines today asked the Soviet Government to order balky crewmen of five detained Russian trawlers to cooperate with intelligence officers investigating their surprise appearance in a remote North Luzon Bay.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- A free throw by Carl Belz with 41 seconds left lifted Princeton to a 61-60 victory over Penn tonight in an Ivy League basketball contest at the Palestra.
Two former lieutenant colonels in the Civil Air Patrol were indicted here yesterday on charges of stealing $54,350 of the agency's funds.
RHODES, March 4 -- Greece and Yugoslavia have agreed to strengthen their friendship and promote the closest cooperation "within the framework of existing accords."
ATLANTIC CITY, March 4 -- The Rabbinical Council of America called on New York and other states today to establish legislative commissions to study religious celebrations in public schools.
Mrs. Lydia Lempe gazed through the window of her studio apartment at 204 East Twenty-sixth Street upon the trees and shrubs in a tidy courtyard.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 4 -- Premier Manouchehr Eghbal said today he hoped that the signing of a defense pact with the United States would open a new era of mutual respect and peace for Iran.
A deferred playment plan for dental care was offered last night to the 10,000 dentists and their patients in the New York metropolitan area.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- Malaya and Ceylon plan to introduce an amendment under which the General Assembly would take note of plans by the Government of the French Cameroons to hold new general elections "at an early date" after independence is achieved.

Business loans by the larger New York City banks increased $8,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $147,000,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.

Armco Steel Company is planning to borrow $75,000,000 in the bond market through a public offering of debt securities. Reports in the financial district said that the investment banking house of Smith, Barney Co. would manage the marketing. The banking house declined to make any comment on the report.

ALGIERS, March 5 -- An American photographer and his German interpreter were killed and a second American was critically wounded yesterday when their car was ambushed by nationalist rebels in western Algeria, according to French authorities here.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., March 5 (AP) -- The bodies of a man and baby found in a brush pile near here yesterday were identified today as those of a Louisa County man and his daughter, who had been missing seven weeks.
Robert Moses urged the city's Roman Catholic schools yesterday to maintain a true balance between science and the humanities and to resist pressure "to tip the scales toward materialism."
CHELTENHAM, England, March 5 (AP) -- Roddy Owen, an Irish bred and trained gelding, got a break on the last jump and sped to a three-length victory today in the Cheltenham Gold Cup steeplechase.

Copper futures tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Volume was the largest since Dec. 3. The market was influenced by unconfirmed reports that a strike at a Kennecott Copper Corporation mine in Chile had been settled.
THE first catches of giant bluefin tuna off the Outer Banks of North Carolina ought to be showing up in a few days now. Fish have been raised in the last few days, though none has been hooked.
The battle over whether the proposed Northway from Albany to the Canadian border should go through the eastern fringe of the Adirondack Park will be on again in this session of the Legislature.

Mayor Wagner has wisely pronounced the death sentence on the 4 per cent sales tax. Public opinion was overwhelmingly against the increase from 3 to 4 per cent. It is somewhat surprising that the administration ever considered a revenue measure so objectionable.

A Communist radio broadcast has raised the question of the United States' right to put military satellites into orbit without getting the permission of countries over whose territory the satellites pass.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Treasury said today the Government would lose hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue unless Congress reversed court decisions on the tax depletion allowance for the mining and mineral industries.
LONDON, March 5 -- Britain agrees fully with her Western allies that there should be no summit talks unless there is prior assurance that constructive progress will be made.
There is at least one chink in the Iron Curtain. Nine American soldiers who crossed the taut border between East and West Germany last July can attest to that.
Enforcement of the city's jaywalking regulations -- and compliance with them -- continue at high levels seven months after the law became effective here.
LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note to the United States protesting the boarding of a Soviet trawler, as broadcast today from Moscow:
GENEVA, March 5 -- The United States proposed today an international staffing plan for the headquarters of the proposed organization for policing a ban on testing nuclear weapons.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 5 -- Hints of a new "tough line" against the Soviet bloc's attacks on President Tito's regime were heard here today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Zellerbach Commission on European Refugees today recommended that the United States admit 50,000 refugees in the next two years in an international "crash program" to wipe out the refugee problem.
Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan said yesterday that the city's Hospital Code regulations for nursing homes were inadequate.

The long, slow process of developing (some would say keeping alive) the Baghdad Pact continues. Yesterday the United States signed bilateral military defense treaties with the three remaining active Middle Eastern members of the pact -- Iran, Turkey and Pakistan. Iraq is now a member in name only and Britain needs no fresh commitment.
Boys High made a successful debut in the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs with an 80-37 victory over Long Island City in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Three thousand building trades unionists who had gathered here for Operation Buttonhole reported today that the Senate was ready to pass the Kennedy-Ervin labor-management reform bill with votes to spare.
MANILA, March 5 -- Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen talked for two and a half hours about Philippine-American problem with President Carlos P. Garcia at breakfast today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Head Knode of Forest Hills, Queens, and Janet Hopps of Seattle moved up a notch in an international tennis tournament today.
Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $73,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $529,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 5 -- Homer A. Tomlinson, continuing his world tour as self-styled "King of all the Nations of Men," almost caused a riot today when he set up a portable throne in front of Emperor Haile Selassie's palace and appeared in a mandarin robe and a gold crown.

The egghead -- sometimes defined as a nonconformist -- has come into style in this country, as evidenced by the products Americans are buying. At least that is the belief of John R. Bunting, an economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- On the bedroom wall of Paul Frederick Foster hangs a wooden cabinet containing the nation's highest decorations for heroism. On the wall of his office in the Atomic Energy Commission hangs a plaque with the Biblical quotation: "For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who shall prepare himself to the battle?"
New York Airways announced yesterday that it planned to purchase a fleet of five British-made convertiplanes.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 5 -- Denmark is to reduce the size of her armed forces and cut the military conscription period from sixteen months to fourteen.

MIAMI BEACH, March 5 -- A leader of the Israel Bond Organization declared here tonight that Israel could now make sharp industrial and agricultural progress because of a new process for desalting sea water developed in the United States.

The financial dealings of Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, with George A. Brenner were injected yesterday as a key issue in a lawsuit for the control of a tugboatmen's union treasury.
BIG fashion shows appear to be going begging as television bait.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With reference to your editorial of Feb. 21 "Indonesia and Foreign Aid," guided democracy, which you characterize as "Communist-inspired," came into being in early 1957 when political parties and their leaders requested President Sukarno to devise a formula as a way out of the political confusion.
With the varsity winter sports program rushing to a conclusion, championship meets and tournaments start bobbing up all over this week-end. The fun will carry on apace through the rest of this month.
Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Aiken, S. C., recent winner of the world open championship, in court tennis, reached the semi-final round in defense of the United States amateur title yesterday.

Simeha Pratt, Israeli Consul General here, told a group of industrialists yesterday that his country's need for technical assistance was greatest in the fields of food processing, machine tool production and mining.

PERHAPS one of the most agreeable and yet most distressing sights on returning to the United States after two years in the Soviet Union is the overabundant department store counter. Filled to overflowing with twenty individually styled hats, each in five different colors, and priced from $3 to $30, it invariably leaves the returnee unaccustomed to variety vexed: What to choose?
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 5 (AP) -- Anti-United States tension eased in La Paz today and the United States Embassy said it would reopen partly tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Figures from the Department of Agriculture showed today that farms in all states except eight gained in net income last year.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower presided over a special meeting of the National Security Council today to discuss the Berlin crisis and Germany. Then he called Congressional leaders of both parties to the White House tomorrow for a discussion of the same subjects.
Puerto Rican migrants are being exploited by farmers in the New Haven area, according to a report made public here yesterday by the National Advisory Committee on Farm Labor.
Hospital-surgical and convalescent nursing home insurance for all persons over 65 will be offered today on a national basis for the first time.
Los Angeles and Forest Hills both are under consideration as sites for the 1959 Davis Cup challenge round. A decision is expected the first week in April.
TRENTON, March 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today characterized unemployment in New Jersey as a "real emergency."

MILWAUKEE, March 5 -- Democratic leaders of the thirteen Midwestern states gathered here tonight for a two-day strategy meeting. It is designed to consolidate the party's gains in the 1958 Congressional and Gubernatorial elections and to prepare for successes in 1960.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Paul F. Foster, deputy general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission and a decorated naval hero, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be United States representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 5 -- A third solution to the General Motors Corporation's professed need for expansion of its factories here was offered tonight by Edwin A. Jacobsen, the Republican candidate for Mayor.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 5 -- Cornell University's athletic director, Robert J. Kane, tonight filed a formal protest to Yale's Delany Kiphuth, chairman of the Ivy League administrative committee, regarding the award of the league's individual scoring championship in basketball.
The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago reported yesterday new highs in 1958 for kilowatt hour sales, operating revenues and net income.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Next to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the 100 newspaper, magazine and radio representatives who make up the Hollywood Foreign Press Association are about the most heterogeneous award presenters in the entertainment world.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 5 -- Five Africans were killed and four injured in a new clash with security forces tonight as the strife in the African nationalist campaign continued.

Van Cliburn, still weak after an operation on an abscessed fingertip, was more anxious yesterday to return to his schedule of piano concerts than he was concerned about the condition of his middle right finger.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz accused a New Rochelle fund raiser yesterday of keeping 90 per cent of the contributions he had collected for the W. C. Handy Foundation for the Blind.
RICHMOND, Va., March 5 (AP) -- Southern Baptists are being urged to join world-wide prayers on March 15 for religious liberty of evangelicals in Spain.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- The Government rested its case today for a plan to divest E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. of 63,000,000 shares of common stock of the General Motors Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Joseph S. Clark told the Senate today that Congress should increase the budget for the next fiscal year by $4,170,000,000 over the $77,000,000,000 proposed by President Eisenhower.

Earned premiums of the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, Bloomington, Ill., were $379,611,794 last year, 16.4 per cent above the 1957 figure, Adlai H. Rust, chairman, announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, March 5 -- The nation's latest satellite launching attempt from the West Coast definitely was successful, the Defense Department's Advanced Research Projects Agency announced today.
The delicate strains of a Handel sonata floated through the long corridors at City Hall yesterday as music lovers gathered to pay homage to the great eighteenth century composer.
ALBANY, March 5 -- The New York State Nurses Association announced today that it was seeking salary increases for nurses employed by the New York City Departments of Hospital and Health.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor, Minneapolis rookie, put on another sparkling display of shooting and all-around play as he led the Lakers to a 135-115 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has assembled the blockfront on the east side of Tenth Avenue between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets in two transactions negotiated by Stanley Russell of Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., broker. Mr. Horwitz was represented by E. Louis Gothelf, attorney.
The New York Chamber of Commerce disapproved yesterday of both the Kennedy and the Administration labor reform bills, but it said the Administration measure was preferable.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- A well-educated group of lawmakers, who obviously have not been helping the children with homework lately, tangled in hopeless disagreement today over this one:
ANKARA, Turkey, March 5 (AP) -- Iran, Turkey and Pakistan, scorning Soviet threats and denunciations, signed separate defense pacts today with the United States.
TORONTO, March 5 -- A group of Indians led by hereditary chiefs seized the council house today and declared itself the new government of the populous Six Nations reserve near Brantford, Ont.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 5 -- School officials told the Federal Civil Rights Commission today that neither academic standards nor discipline had been adversely affected by desegregation.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- Take a cow, add an army of Soviet fighters for communism, stir in some modern-day economics and mix with a gentle word from the leader and you have a problem, the kind of problem that plagued Moscow today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Administration is discussing several proposals for the extension of emergency Federal aid to the unemployed, short of the one-year extension proposed yesterday by House Democratic leaders.
HONG KONG, March 4 -- Communist China in two related moves accused the United States today of sabotaging peace in the Far East and called for United States withdrawal from the area.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower nominated S. Hazard Gillespie Jr. today to be United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He will succeed Paul W. Williams, who resigned last year to seek the Republican Senate nomination.

HAVANA, March 5 -- An important section of the Cuban public viewed with concern today the retrial of forty-three airmen acquitted by a military court in Santiago de Cuba Monday and the demand of a new prosecutor for death or prison sentences for all except two of the group.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- The Defense Department's manpower chief urged Congress today to extend the draft a full four years as a signal to the world that there would be no "slackening" in the United States defense effort.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Pioneer IV, caught in the sun's gravitational grip, raced on into space today, more than 300,000 miles from its launching pad in Cape Canaveral, Fla.

As the central Protestant welfare and health organization for Greater New York, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., 251 Fourth Avenue, New York 10, has a role tested by thirty-seven years of flexible growth.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 5 -- Officials confirmed here today that among the Africans detained under the emergency regulations is Patrick Matimba, the only African living in the colony with a white wife.
Eleven George Polk Memorial Awards for "distinguished achievements" in journalism in 1958 were announced yesterday by Long Island University.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 5 (AP) -- Twelve candidates, including an unbeaten filly named Silver Spoon, today were entered in the Santa Anita Derby Saturday.
John E. Jackson, Bronx research chemist, died last night in Morrisania Hospital of injuries that he suffered in an attack last Friday.
The Norwegian tanker Jalanta was stopped "dead in the water" when the liner Constitution struck her last Sunday at "very great speed," the tanker's master said here yesterday.

LONDON, March 5 -- Sarah Churchill, actress daughter of former Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill, was fined 2 ($5.60) in a Liverpool Magistrates' Court today on a drunk and disorderly conduct charge.

THIRTY-EIGHT years after its completion, "Wozzeck," one of the great, original works of our time, has joined the Metropolitan Opera repertory. Since the production is worthy of the piece, the long delay may be forgiven.
HAZLETON, Pa., March 5 (AP) -- Flames roaring up an elevator shaft in a five-story hotel early today killed at least four persons.
ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Rockefeller was accused today of followinw a "soft" policy on civil rights and promptly labeled the charge as a misrepresentation of his position.
WARSAW, March 5 -- Across the front of the gloomy gray building on Leszno Street, the words are chiseled into the stone: "Justice is the basis of the strength and durability of the Republic."
A shcool project involving art, science and healthy curiosity brought a class of fourth-graders yesterday from New Jersey to the American Museum of Natural History.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Lively activity in wheat futures took prices of that grain up and down over a broad range today on the Board of Trade. Other grains and soybeans dragged along within narrow limits.
GENEVA, March 5 -- Steel production rose in the Communist countries in 1958, while it declined in the rest of the world, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

BONN, Germany, March 5 -- Diplomats here are profoundly disturbed over a spreading belief in Western Europe that two camps have formed among the West's Big Four over how to proceed on the German question.
Two boys in khaki uniforms, carrying a boy's idea of a perfect cake, showed up at Girl Scout headquarters yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We wish to congratulate The Times for its effective support of the $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction in New York City. Your editorial of March 3 pinpointed the central issues -- namely, our desperate need for schools and the undisputed financial crisis of our city which make it necessary to secure funds outside the legal debt limit.

Asher W. Schwartz disclosed yesterday that he had resigned as counsel for the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union because he believed that it was wrong for an attorney who was paid with union funds to represent union officers accused of betraying members' interests.
ALBANY, March 5 -- The Republican revolt against raising the personal income tax appeared to be collapsing rapidly tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- The Netherlands has begun an ambitious scientific expedition into an unexplored area of Netherlands New Guinea.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 5 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community decided today that its six member nations should curtail the mining and importing of coal.
While sixty Columbia College physics students rapidly took notes, their heads bobbing from notebook to blackboard, another student sat quietly yesterday and just looked and listened.

TOKYO, March 3 -- Japan's new sports idol is a 19-year-old sumo wrestler of such bulk that he regularly loses and regains 20 pounds in a day without showing it on his 5-foot 8-inch frame. Until a few months ago he was content to be scrubbing the backs of visitors to the steaming hot baths in the Flower Basket Gymnasium in Tokyo.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 5 (AP) -- A disabled airliner turned turtle today when the pilot apparently tried an emergency landing after two engines failed. Twelve passengers and two crew members died in the crash. There were eighteen persons aboard.

Local 144 of the Hotel and Allied Service Employes Union has purchased the four-story business building at 797 Eighth Avenue, between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets. The group plans to remodel the building and use it for its offices and meeting rooms.
Rails and textiles were strong yesterday in an otherwise uneven and uncertain stock market.
Police protection on a round-the-clock basis was ordered last night for nine struck cemeteries in the New York area after a funeral party was molested in a Long Island cemetery.

A bakery union ordered 150 workers back to work at the Pechter Baking Company in Brooklyn early this morning when tentative agreement on a new three-year contract was reached, a union spokesman announced.
ALBANY, March 5 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the New York City Board of Education must not favor women over men when appointing principals and junior principals.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 5 -- Twenty-one boys died behind locked doors today in a fire that consumed the dormitory of the Arkansas Negro Boys Industrial School.
Source Perrier, said to be France's leading bottler of natural sparkling mineral water, is going to attempt to make some changes in this nation's drinking habits.

The Zeckendorf Hotels Corporation has withdrawn its plan to turn the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue into a cooperative. Instead, a 160-room addition will be built on the north side of Fifty-sixth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.
MADRID, March 5 -- An emotional clash over Spain's civil war dead threatens to divide and distress the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- Senator James O. Eastland attacked recent Supreme Court decisions on internal security today and offered seven bills to curb their "disastrous trend."

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- An 18-year-old Virginia youth said today that he had quit the Congressional Page School after only two days' attendance because he had learned that three Negro students were enrolled.

LEIPZIG, Germany, March 5 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev suggested today that the Soviet Union might defer beyond May 27 its deadline for turning over its occupation functions in Germany to the East German Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial about Gen. Bill Donovan and Ambassador David Bruce's letter paying tribute to him published in your issue of Feb. 15 were earned by his life of devotion to our country and of almost unparalleled bravery.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The State Department was unimpressed by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's suggestion today that Moscow might extend its Berlin ultimatum beyond May 27.
Stefan Redl, a welterweight who became 26 years old yesterday, will meet undefeated Eddie Jordan of Brooklyn in the ten-round main event at Madison Square Garden tonight.

THE manufacturer of Claire McCardell Clothes announced yesterday that both the McCardell label and the collection of clothes bearing it would be discontinued. Instead, he said, he will manufacture and present the creations of Donald Brooks, 30-year-old sportswear designer.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 5 (UPI) -- The Belleville McFarlands began defense of Canada's world amateur ice hockey championship tonight by shutting out Poland, 9 -- 0. The United States opened its title bid with a 10-3 triumph over Norway.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- An early decision on the admission of Hawaii as the fiftieth state was in sight today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial "Making Monetary Policy" in the Feb. 26 Times may have intended to discredit the A. F. L.-C. I. O. proposal for improving the composition of the Federal Reserve Board. Actually, the editorial inadvertently supported the A. F. L.-C. I. O.'s request for a necessary change in the Federal Reserve Act.

Matthew Raimondi, violinist, and Russell Sherman, pianist, have made a reputation here as interpreters of contemporary music, but they were just as much at home in three works of Beethoven last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- If there is one commodity of which the Yankees have no shortage this spring, it is young pitching talent.
Old crop cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 14 to 18 points yesterday but new crop months advanced 4 to 12 points. A point is 5 cents a bale.

YONKERS, N. Y., March 5 -- The 9,000 shares of Yonkers bank stock owned by George A. Brenner, former Westchester surrogate and county judge accused of larcenies totaling $626,300, were sold at public auction today for $17,100.
BOSTON, March 5 -- Following is the text of an address tonight by Adlai E. Stevenson:
The University of Denver basketball team accepted a bid to the National Invitation Tournament yesterday while still in the running for the Skyline Conference championship.

PARIS, March 5 -- The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community has urged this six-nation common market to give active backing to the tariff-reduction proposal made last fall by C. Douglas Dillon, United States Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
Proceeds of the 147th anniversary dinner of the New York City Mission Society will help to provide scholarships for deserving students in area colleges and seminaries.

Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell predicted last night that by the end of this year the country would achieve "the highest level of employment and the lowest level of unemployment it ever experienced in peacetime."
The price of lead was advanced 1/2 cent a pound yesterday to 11 1/2 cents by all major sellers. They reported a moderate pick-up in demand from all types of users.
A Spanish student leader said yesterday that broadcasts of the Voice of America in Madrid had been integrated with daily Spanish radio propaganda.
The Port of New York Authority borrowed $30,000,000 yesterday on thirty-year consolidated bonds at an interest cost of 3.683 per cent.
Five alleged members of an East Harlem narcotics gang that used three children as couriers were charged yesterday with the possession and sale of heroin.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 5 (Reuters) -- A new Supreme Military Council has been appointed to succeed the one that resigned yesterday, the Omdurman radio reported tonight.
The Essayons, the world's largest sea-going hopper dredge, sailed from New York harbor last night to remove 11,000,000 cubic yards of silt and sand from the Suez Canal.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 5 -- It was the first inning of an intra-squad game involving the Milwaukee Braves. The rookie catcher let himself get tangled in his own feet as the pitch flashed in. The result was a passed ball.

Events today: "La Boheme," special student performance, Metropolitan Opera, 1 P. M.; New York Philharmonic, Pierre Monteux, conductor; Joseph Szigeti, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Macbeth," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Cleveland Orchestra, George Szell conductor; Rudolf Serkin, pianist; Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Fordham University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Louise Patterson, soprano, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.
The Long Island Rail Road has presented a bill for $3,000 to a group of Brooklyn and Queens savings banks for "unauthorized advertising" on railroad property.
Any new zoning worked out for the city must not increase the bulk of large buildings, Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, declared yesterday.
St. Luke's Hospital has served eviction notices on the tenants of 501 West 113th Street, a modern apartment house on Amsterdam Avenue just across the street from the hospital.
MONTPELLIER, France, March 5 -- France's new regime is being put to a severe, although localized, test by protests of some 70,000 wine growers in the Herault department.
Perry Como and Kraft Foods signed a television contract yesterday that was said to involve an expenditure of $25,000,000 by Kraft over a period of two years and four months.
ALBANY, March 5 -- Legislation designed to make it easier for minority groups of stockholders to obtain representation on state bank and trust company boards was filed in the Legislature today.
LONDON, March 5 -- Makers of Soviet foreign policy are gradually disengaging from their tough policy on Berlin, Western diplomatic sources in Moscow believe.
Three patrolmen were indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of attempted burglary and grand larceny from a Fifth Avenue shoe store last month.
LONDON, March 5 -- The industrials turned irregular in the stock market here today after a good start. But Government funds were firm and rose as much as 3s. 9d. (52 1/2 cents).
A housewife said she had answered her doorbell yesterday and been shot by a teen-aged robber when she tried to take a pistol from him. Her wounds were not serious.
A strike that could have immobilized the Moore-McCormack Lines' operations here was averted yesterday when the company agreed to discuss the organization of its office personnel.
ZANZIBAR, March 3 -- This clove-scented island in the Indian Ocean off Tanganyika is the place where Arab and African nationalisms intersect.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) -- Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that he would lead a fight to revive the controversial "Title III" that was stricken from the 1957 Civil Rights Law.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Bill Hartack, national jockey champion in 1955-56-57, escaped serious injury when he was kicked by a horse while dismounting following the sixth race today at Gulfstream.

The New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Banks has agreed unanimously on an omnibus banking bill that appears to have met with a generally favorable response from most of the various and often conflicting interests in the banking community.
LONDON, March 5 -- A radar photographic system that, by using four aircraft, could produce a reconnaissance map of an area as big as the United States is being developed for Britain's bomber force.
Bond houses were thrown into confusion late yesterday by the announcement that four Federal Reserve district banks were raising their discount rates from 2 1/2 per cent to 3 per cent.

Lester B. Granger, executive director of the National Urban League, called on this country yesterday to provide Africa with industrial and agricultural aid and assistance in developing a larger, educated group of leaders.
ONE of the outstanding devotees of welded metal sculpture, Barbara Lekberg, is exhibiting recent work at the Sculpture Center, 167 East Sixty-ninth Street.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 5 -- It has been said that Frank Lane, the general manager of the Cleveland Indians, is a "fellow who keeps trading until he gets the best of it."

A Board of Education official who said on Wednesday that he had been threatened with criminal contempt for falling to answer questions, returned yesterday to tell a Brooklyn grand jury about an insurance plan for children.
The United Parents Associations charged yesterday that the city's school needs had been underestimated and its debts exaggerated.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The New York City Board of Education asked the Court of Appeals today to permit it to discharge teachers refusing to give information about fellow teachers they once knew in the Communist party.
A Maytime Cocktail Dance to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 4 will further the work of the auxiliary of the Youth Consultation Service at Dana House.

WHEN Scottish - Americans feel homesick for the oatcakes, haggis and shortbread of the old country, they travel or write to Drewes Bros., Inc., 6815 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. This combination bakery, butcher shop and fancy grocery specializes in edibles of Scotland and, to a smaller extent, the rest of Britain.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Barbara Fitton of Hamilton, Ohio, upset Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore in the second round of the women's Florida East Coast amateur golf tournament today and then swept into the semi-finals with a victory over Lanny Cranston of San Marino, Calif.
WHITE PLAINS, March 5 -- Many a motorist has served as a guinea pig on Westchester roads in the last fortnight in tests made by county, state and Federal highway officials.
The Arabian American Oil Company has started operating a new, $30,000,000 gas injection plant in the 'Ain Dar area of the Ghawar Field in Saudi Arabia.

DETROIT, March 5 (AP) -- Thirty - seven Michigan residents, bent on carving new lives in an Alaskan wilderness, began the 4,300-mile trek today in a traffic jam generated by relatives, well-wishers and the curious.

Four Federal Reserve Banks increased their lending (discount) rate to member banks yesterday from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent. The move was interpreted as an effort to help the Treasury keep the growing Federal debt where it would do the least to increase the dangers of inflation.

Tony Jackson's basket in the last second enabled St. John's to beat New York University at Madison Square Garden last night. For a brief moment the crowd of 10,565 waited in anxiety. Then the ball fell through the cords, giving a 57-to-55 victory to the Redmen.

Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, charged last night that Governor Rockefeller was spending more than $100,000 in tax money on a personal publicity staff "geared primarily to the project of selling [his] $277,000,000 soak-the-poor tax program.
BOSTON, March 5 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called tonight for unity in the Berlin crisis.
One of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's top assistants was named yesterday to take over the division of housing in the Department of Buildings.

There is a "reasonable chance" of an increase in prices of book and printing papers by the middle of the year, William H. Chisholm, president of the Oxford Paper Company, a leading producer, said yesterday.
Andy Bathgate yesterday was named the most valuable player on the Rangers, thereby becoming the first player to win the award three consecutive seasons.

The election of three new directors was announced yesterday by the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, formerly the General Telephone Corporation. They are Don G. Mitchell, William Jed Wardall and Lawrence A. Appley.

HATTIE CARNEGIE'S spring-summer custom collection is pure hearts-and-flowers. At the press showing yesterday, all that was missing were ardent violinists. Never more romantic or soft, the clothes were devoid of any boyish touches.

A new Civil War Book titled "Secret Missions of the Civil War," by Philip Van Doren Stern, will be issued by Rand McNally on March 16. The author has woven into a narrative the first-hand accounts of the men and women who risked their lives in underground activities for the North and the South.

Alexander L. Guterma was arrested yesterday for the second time in three weeks. This time, the Federal Bureau of Investigation charged that he had obtained an unauthorized $250,000 loan from a bank president now under arrest.

The "really important thing about a deterrent force is not numbers but invulnerability; not total numbers built, but numbers we will be able to use," Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, declared in a recent speech.

ROME, March 5 -- Pope John XXIII asked today for prayers throughout the Christian world in 1960 for the successful organization of the Ecumenical Council, to meet in Rome at an unspecified date. He also asked prayers for the return of the "separated" Eastern Church to the fold.
MOSCOW, March 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Union denounced today the United States detention of a Russian fishing trawler off Newfoundland as a provocative act.

IT is written in the First Book of Kings that Solomon, the son of David, reigned for forty years. Only eleven short chapters are devoted to Solomon's story and only eleven verses of the Tenth Chapter to the celebrated visit of the Queen of Sheba to Solomon in Jerusalem. Yet that visit, about which next to nothing is known, has intrigued the imaginations of men for many centuries.
The Pure Oil Company last year cleared $28,821,730, or $3.35 a common share, compared with $35,523,971, or $4.13 a share, in 1957, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Everything seems to be set for Constance Carpenter to costar with Ron McNeil in "Single Man at a Party." The drama is the work of Richard Kayne, also a song writer. It will open April 16 under the direction of Peter Flournoy at the Theatre Marquee, 110 East Fifty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 5 --- The Federal Reserve Board's annual survey of consumer finances had only moderately good news for the automobile industry today.

Bills to give the city power to impose eight new or increased special taxes were introduced in the Legislature yesterday. The eight bills had been sent to Albany by Mayor Wagner with the unanimous approval of the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The International Monetary Fund and the Export-Import Bank together made $190,000,000 available to Mexico today to stabilize the peso.
Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, yesterday gave an answer that a grand jury had been unable to obtain from him earlier.
TORONTO, March 6 -- North America's newest "nation" -- called Grand River -- quietly began acquiring some of the perquisites of independence today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Mining groups took exception today to Treasury proposals to revise and tighten the tax laws governing depletion allowances on their income.
The new capital market is slated to be considerably more active next week than it was this week.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 6 -- Robert F. Kennedy said here today that a company and a labor union involved in the Senate rackets inquiry had approached him in the last year with political proposals.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 6 -- A disbarred New Jersey lawyer, William J. Baker, told last night how he had masterminded the $3,500,000 financial transaction that transferred the C. F. Mueller Company into a trust organization in which New York University became full beneficiary.
LONDON, March 6 -- The stock market closed the week on an unsettled note with a general decline.
Banton L. Wyckoff, the real estate agent, was arraigned in Special Sessions Court yesterday after waiving extradition in New Jersey, where he had been arrested a week ago.
A Quonset hut structure abandoned in 1947 as a useless reminder of the post-war housing shortage has been bustling for the last two years with the activities of a Jewish Community Center in Brooklyn.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 6 (UPI) -- Canada and the United States clinched berths in the world amateur ice hockey championships final round today when they defeated their preliminary-round opponents by lop-sided scores.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Seven nations proposed today a compromise on the issue of the French Cameroons. The seven are Burma, Cambodia, Ceylon, Malaya, Guatemala, India and Japan.
A delegation from the New York Board of Rabbis presented to Governor Rockefeller yesterday an illuminated scroll of Scripture readings.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 6 -- Britain expressed to the Government of the Irish Republic today her disquiet at the release of men of the Irish Republican Army from internment.
IT will be difficult this spring to find a new hat that isn't pretty. Most stores look as if the Flower Show were opening in their respective millinery departments, instead of at the Coliseum today.

ROME, March 6 -- The Senate gave the Christian Democratic Government of Premier Antonio Segni a vote of confidence this evening by the largest majority any government had had in the last twelve years.

Seven buildings containing sixty-one apartments at 2315 to 2333 Barnes Avenue and 2316 to 2336 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, were sold by Henriette H. Van Gelder and associates. The properties, which are assessed at $450,000, were purchased by Louis Eisen and associates through Anne Inselstein, broker.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it was easing proposed requirements on brokers' reports on foreign transactions in securities.
Tobias Stone, whose charges of cheating touched off international fireworks in the contract bridge world, lost an important round in court here yesterday.
Fellowships for a year of study in the humanities have been awarded to sixty-three public high school teachers by the John Hay Fellows Program.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 6 -- New violence broke out tonight in this British protectorate. One African nationalist was shot dead and three were wounded in a noisy gathering of 600 who carried primitive weapons in a defiant stand against colonial forces.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The states and territories paid out in December more than $29,892,000 in general assistance, or relief, a record for any month of recent years.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The Connecticut Light and Power Company reported yesterday new highs in 1958 revenues and net income.

HAVANA, March 6 -- Premier Fidel Castro warned Cubans today against what he called the counter-revolutionary activities of vested interests. He said his revolutionary movement would continue to carry out its aims.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A male turkey hatched from a nonfertilized egg has sired a healthy brood of young turkeys.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- The grain futures market appeared today to have exhausted all its recent bullish influences. Prices made a fairly broad general retreat, with wheat among the leaders on the setback.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Pioneer IV established a record for long-range communications today, then fell silent in its endless orbit around the sun.
The city urged a Yonkers bus line yesterday to apply for a franchise to avoid further traffic tickets for travel in the city area.
BRIGHTON, Ill., March 6 -- A hunter got a surprise shot on two quail today, wheeled and waited for them to line up in a high wind, and dropped both of them dead.

A GOURBI, Algeria, March 6 -- Algeria's Bled, that lovely countryside so scarred by terror, is filled with modest peasant huts called gourbis. Here dwell the Moslems, both Berber Kabyles and Arabs, who are the flotsam of war between the French and rebel Nationalists.

Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, has declared that recent anti-Semitic actions in Germany "in no wise represent the attitude of the German people as a whole." He said "these single occurrences are always rejected and condemned by the overwhelming majority of the German people."
The M. A. Hanna Company has announced the election of William A. Hobbs and William L. West as directors.
The Uniformed Firemen's Association began placing a series of advertisements in newspapers yesterday asserting that firemen were poorly paid for work that was hazardous.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 6 -- Two men who had been accused of freeing 1,500 privately owned rainbow trout were awarded $7,000 in State Supreme Court today for malicious prosecution.
Four days of testimony on the collision last Sunday between the American Export liner Constitution and the Norwegian tanker Jalanta ended yesterday.

IT is amazing to think that the ballet premiere of Ravel's "Daphnis et Chloe" in 1912 was led by a 37-year-old conductor, Pierre Monteux, the same gentleman who directed the music at yesterday's New York Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 6 -- Dr. Hubert A. Lechevalier sat at the end of a long table here today, doodled conic sections on a lined yellow pad, and told what it is like to spend five months working with Russian scientists in their own laboratories.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Family savings of the "cash" type rose last year by a peace-time record, the Home Loan Bank Board reported today. American families saved 6 cents of every dollar of income after taxes.

CHERRY POINT, N. C., March 6 (AP) -- A Marine transport plane making an instrument landing approach in a wind and rain storm crashed into a lowland area early today and exploded, killing eight of the nine crewmen.

Boston University's basketball team yesterday was named to an "at-large" berth in the National Collegiate championship. The Terriers will meet Connecticut in the first game of a triple-header at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 6 -- Guy W. Calissi, Bergen County Prosecutor, said today he would press for the extradition of Frank Borelli from Chicago, despite the death last night of John E. Jackson, the principal witness against Borelli in a narcotics case.
Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to order an investigation of the circumstances under which a sponsor was chosen for the controversial Gramercy Park redevelopment.
BLANTYRE, March 6 -- Governor Sir Robert P. Armitage declared today that "all evidence" pointed to a plan by the African National Congress to massacre Europeans, Asians and loyal Africans here.

" ERRAND AT SHADOW CREEK,"* by Geoffrey Cotterell, is either a travel book masquerading as a novel or a novel masquerading as a travel book. In any case it tells a good story and takes us on a fine voyage to Australia that is just right for these days when March alternately masquerades as winter and spring.
BUTTE, Mont., March 6 (UPI) -- A temporary Federal court injunction today halted a one-day-old railroad strike that had closed the mines on Butte Hill.

The bond market was weak yesterday as a result of the raising of the lending (discount) rate by four Federal Reserve banks from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent. A semblance of a rally appeared in the late morning but failed to follow through.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A New York investment banker testified today that the Administration plan to help build schools by a Federal-state program of guaranteeing school bonds for poorer districts would disturb the bond market.
Other short-term interest rates moved upward yesterday as an aftermath of Thursday's rise in the member-bank lending (discount) rate from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent at four Federal Reserve banks.

GEORGE SZELL and the Cleveland Orchestra dutifully brought to New York an unfamiliar work in their third and final Carnegie Hall concert of the season last night. And New York would have been no worse off if it had missed this "Symphonie de Danses" by the French composer Andre Jolivet.

MADRID, March 6 -- Young leaders of the clandestine Spanish Socialist party have urged Don Juan de Bourbon, 44-year-old exiled pretender to the Spanish throne, to break openly with Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 6 -- An education official blamed the Federal Government today for the strife arising from school desegregation and another attributed it to poor and sometimes unscrupulous Southern political leadership.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower urged Americans today to observe Red Cross Sabbath and Sunday this week-end as an aid in "promoting the progress of mankind."
The Hudson River Day Line offered yesterday to carry West Shore rail commuters across the Hudson on excursion steamers after the New York Central Railroad discontinues its ferry service.
PARIS, March 6 -- President de Gaulle exchanged views on the Berlin and German problems with the Soviet Ambassador, Sergei A. Vinogradov, for fifty-five minutes today.
The Port of New York Authority's $85,000,000 master plan for the redevelopment of more than two miles of Brooklyn waterfront is turning a blighted area into a model of urban progress.

Interchemical Corp. Directors of the Interchemical Corporation have voted a split of the common stock. Shareholders on April 1 will receive one-and-a-half common shares for each common share outstanding on the record date of March 16. H. B. Woodman, president, said that the board intended to declare a dividend of 28 cents a share at its April meeting.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 6 (AP) -- Michael Davies and Christine Truman of Britain gained the semi-finals of the mixed doubles in an International Tennis Tournament today. They defeated Mimi Arnold of Redwood City, Calif., and Jack Douglas of Los Angeles 6 -- 2, 10 -- 8.
A gold mine of rare books and papers, assiduously guarded for seventy years, has just been opened to the public.
Charges of building violations against Sidney J. Ungar, a lawyer and realty man, were dismissed yesterday in Municipal Term Court on a technicality.
ROME, March 6 -- Faced with a storm over abstractionism, the Italian Government has promised impartiality toward all tendencies in modern art.
More than 5,000 Masons in the metropolitan area are expected to attend their fourteenth annual dedication services and breakfast tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The State Department's legal adviser said today that the Soviet Union would have to do considerably more than "stick a Red flag in the ground" to be able to claim sovereignty over the moon.
A three-day strike by gravediggers and other workers against nine cemeteries in the Metropolitan area was settled here at 1:30 A. M. today.
PARIS, March 6 -- The European common market -- a customs union embracing France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- has functioned so far mainly on the diplomatic level

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today the United States Ambassador had assured India that the Baghdad Pact agreement signed yesterday by the United States with Pakistan, Iran and Turkey was limited to combating aggression by Communist countries.
A PLUMP, dark-haired woman walked into a Second Avenue poultry market this week, ordered two chickens and then, after the seller had weighed them, quickly flashed a silver badge.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 10 points (20 cents to 50c a bale) yesterday, after fluctuating within a narrow range.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 6 (AP) -- Tony Tashnick of Michigan and Frank McKinney Jr. of Indiana smashed three American records between them tonight in the Big Ten swimming championships.

CAIRO, March 6 -- From the border of the Sudan 600 miles north to the Mediterranean and from the green verges of the Nile 300 miles westward to the Libyan frontier lies what Egyptians call the Western Desert. Only five small oases and a lake a few miles southwest of Cairo break the brown expanse of 180,000 square miles.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 6 -- Communist China is driving a hard bargain with Ceylon in negotiations toward a rubber-rice barter agreement for the current year, it was stated here today.
CHICAGO, March 6 (UPI) -- A Northwest Orient Airlines plane, caught in turbulent weather north of Chicago, plunged 4,000 feet in a downdraft last night.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Through an application of the Boston and Maine Railroad Company to the Interstate Commerce Commission, a stalemate was disclosed today in some railroad efforts to get Government guarantees for proposed private loans.

ASPEN, Colo., March 6 -- The championship Alpine skiing circuit, which moves to the East next week, began its final Western stand today as almost 100 men and women took part in the national giant slalom title events on Ajax Mountain.

Fresh credit-control moves by the Federal Reserve banks were accepted quietly by Wall Street yesterday. Prices of stocks were a little lower at the opening but had recovered about half that moderate loss at the end of grading. However, the slight decline came after four days of successive gains.
PARISIANS by the thousands are ogling a middle-income apartment of the future, which is the hit exhibit at the annual Salon des Arts Menagers, now taking place here.
LONDON, March 6 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will urge President Eisenhower and other Western leaders to negotiate with the Soviet Union or Berlin and Germany.
Commodity futures prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 6 -- A Federal judge ruled today that the 1957 Civil Rights Act did not give the Federal Government authority to sue individual states accused of violating the voting rights of Negroes.

PICKING and choosing among the many excellent nineteenth and twentieth century pictures in the large group show at Hirschl Adler, 21 East Sixty-seventh Street, is no easy matter. Both European and American artists are represented by oils and water-colors, and the honors are more equally divided than is usually the case.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- If he wanted to, Premier Ahmadou Ahidjo of the French Cameroons could not only make his speeches at the United Nations but also transmit them personally by radio to his West African homeland.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 (AP)--Magistrate Louis Vignola, president of Local 410 of the Boilermakers Shipyard Workers Union, is the new president of the Maritime Trades Department of the Greater Delaware Valley.
LONDON, March 6 -- A revolutionary advance in antibiotic medicine, described as the most important since the discovery of penicillin's curative power, has been made by four young British scientists.
The airlines' international battle over the sandwich may switch now to an international battle over cold cuts.
BUENOS AIRES, March 6 -- Argentina's monetary stabilization program has survived the first shock of public criticism and is beginning to stem the inflationary tide.
