Northrup Knox, world open champion, and Jimmy Bostwick will meet today at 12:30 for the national amateur court tennis championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- President Tito returned today from his three-month tour of Asia and Africa. He promptly accused his Soviet block neighbors of having slandered and lied about Yugoslavia.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., March 6 -- A 51-year-old dentist was severely beaten and tied up early today in his home, which was then set afire. He managed to get halfway out of the cellar door, where he was assisted by two policemen at 4:30 A. M. He was taken to Valley Hospital here, where his condition was reported satisfactory.
MORE pigs were raised last fall than in any time in the last fifteen years. That pork crop is now coming to market and, as shoppers will find, at reasonable prices.
A twenty-inch water main burst early yesterday morning in the downtown section of Brooklyn, disrupting BMT subway service for several hours and flooding basements of several commercial buildings.

A merger of the Glen Alden Corporation and the List Industries Corporation was proposed by their directors yesterday. Under the plan Glen Alden would be the surviving corporation. Stockholders of record on March 10 will vote on the union at special meetings in the near future.
MESA, Ariz., March 6 -- Over in Phoenix, about sixteen miles west of here, some San Francisco Giants were talking this morning about the time they were New York Giants.

ST. LOUIS, March 6 (UPI) -- A Federal judge denied new trials today for Matthew J. Connelly and T. Lamar Caudle, officials in the Truman Administration. He branded new evidence offered by an excused co-defendant as testimony from "an admitted perjurer."
LEIPZIG, Germany, March 6 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev may confer with representatives of East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia in East Berlin early next week, Otto Grotewohl said tonight.
DETROIT, March 6 -- Michigan's unemployment rose in February for the third straight month. One worker in eight is unemployed despite a modest boom in the auto industry.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee will hold closed hearings in New York Monday to explore some aspects of the strike that paralyzed the city's newspaper industry in December.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- More legal maneuvering developed today in the Chicago White Sox family feud, plus a charge that Mrs. Dorothy Comiskey Rigney accepted a "rotten deal" in the projected sale of her majority holdings to Bill Veeck.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas said today he hoped to get Senate passage of the Hawaiian statehood bill before Congress quits for an Easter recess, probably on March 26.
BONN, Germany, March 6 -- The West German Government's press chief said today that West Germany and France were opposed to any disengagement of East and West forces in Central Europe.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the city's Superintendent of Schools, defended yesterday his action in accompanying a Board of Education official to the Brooklyn Central Courts Building Thursday.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Labor leaders attacked the Federal Reserve Board today for permitting a rise in the discount rate from 2 1/2 per cent to 3 per cent.
Ron Delany will return tonight to the scene of the crime.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad Feb. 26 -- The Federation of the West Indies, established only last year, is in difficulty. Just how serious the difficulty is will probably be known later this year.
The Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held in the Plaza on May 5.
The weather man served up a pot-pourri yesterday.
MADISON, Wis., March 6 (UPI) -- The Big Ten bid today to continue its Rose Bowl agreement with West Coast colleges.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 6 (UPI) -- The presence of unbeaten Silver Spoon, C. V. Whitney's speedy filly, in the $100,000 added Santa Anita Derby tomorrow has aroused such interest that the track today made preparations for the largest crowd of the meeting.

Events today: "Die Meistersinger" at 1:30 P.M., "Cavaleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; H. Peter Sliker, bass-baritone, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, Pierre Monteux, conductor, Joseph Szigeti, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Celebration and Concert of the One Hundredth Anniversary of Sholom Aleichem, Town Hall, 8:30; The New Opera Theatre Society, operatic excerpts, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.

BERLIN, March 6 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said tonight on his return from a four-week goodwill tour of the United States, Canada and the Far East that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India might be willng to offer his "good offices" if the Berlin crisis came to a climax.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the House Commerce Committee, said today he has no plans for scheduling consideration of the natural gas bill he introduced earlier.

Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in a letter printed on your editorial page of Feb. 15 characterized as "neither wise nor justified" the remarks of the National Broadcasting Company's commentator, Chet Huntley, who had proposed on a recent nation-wide program on school integration in Atlanta that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People withdraw from its activities.

MANILA, Saturday, March 7 (AP) -- Five Soviet trawlers sailed for Vladivostok today after having satisfied Philippine authorities that they had put into a remote North Luzon bay a week ago only to repair an engine and not to spy.

Accidents are the fourth leading cause of death in the country and the Red Cross is working to reduce this tragic toll. One can scarcely walk a block in New York City without encountering someone trained in Red Cross first aid. It is basic training for every new policeman and fireman, for teachers, for utility workers and for thousands of others.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- On paper and perhaps even more so on the ball field the St. Louis Cardinals, share the City of Sunshine with the Yankees as a training site, may not look so hot. Especially is this true if you measure them by Yankee standards.
Broadway ticket brokers asked a State Senate committee yesterday to suspend restrictions on theatre ticket premiums for one year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Fred Stone, the actor, died today at his home. He was 85 years old.

Mount Sinai Hospital was picketed yesterday by a union seeking bargaining recognition and pay increases. About 800 unionists used their lunch periods to take part in the demonstration, which lasted from 11 A. M. to 1:45 P. M.

THE dedicated antiques fan has had his footwork cut out for him this season. The end of trudging and dickering is in sight, however, with the opening today of the last of three closely spaced fairs. The newest one, at the Coliseum, will continue through March 15.
DETROIT, March 6 (AP) -- With spring around the corner, new car sales in the nation are booming compared with the recession lag a year ago.

Title to seventy-five acres of land in North Bergen, N. J., has been taken by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company for improvement within a year with a warehouse containing 200,000 square feet of space. The plant will be for the buyer's glass container division.
The flower show opens today at 2 P. M. in the New York Coliseum. For the first time the show will run for eight days, closing March 14.

A collection of manuscripts giving insights into the life of Jews in North America two centuries ago is contained in "American Jewry Documents, Eighteenth Century." It will be issued March 16 by the Hebrew Union College Press and distributed by University Publishers.

HISTORY was made yesterday morning. Four men actually were invited to air their opinions on women's fashions. This precedent-shattering event occurred in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

In an article entitled "The Frustrated Army of France" which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 28 C. L. Sulzberger wrote, "In 1940 it [the French Army] was overwhelmed because the Third Republic failed to prepare it for modern conflicts.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Republican legislative leaders were hopeful today that the revolt of Assemblymen against Governor Rockefeller's plan to increase the income tax would be resolved in the Administration's favor at a meeting of the rebels Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The four top Congressional leaders proclaimed nonpartisan support today for President Eisenhower's policy of firmness in the Berlin crisis.

Americans saying "cheese" to the Dutch these days had better not smile. In fact, within Dutch hearing they might find it best not to talk about cheese, butter or any dairy products, for that matter. Ordinarily, talk of cheese is a good starting point for discovering real Dutch friendliness.

Ten rounds of bristling fighting in the feature welterweight bout at Madison Square Garden last night went for naught -- except money -- as far as the two rivals were concerned when the firing ceased.

GOIANIA, Brazil, March 6 (UPI) -- Thousands of rioting students burned two movie theatres today in a demonstration against policemen who killed one student and wounded more than 160 in a clash last night.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 6 -- Midwestern Democratic leaders congratulated themselves today on their party's victories in the 1958 elections and then settled down to tackle expected problems of the 1960 campaign.
BOSTON, March 6 (UPI) -- Prosecutors today discontinued an anarchy charge against Alan Freed, New York disk jockey.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The daughter of Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat of Brooklyn, was crowned New York State Cherry Blossom Princess tonight by Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, majority leader. Ambassadors, Senators, Representatives and Government officials attended a reception and ball for Miss Diana Anfuso, 24 years old, who will represent New York at next month's Cherry Blossom Festival here.

Alexander L. Guterma said yesterday his troubles with the law were the result of a two-year "vendetta" conducted against him by Paul Windels Jr., regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A defense system that will permit at least 600 bombers, one-third of the Strategic Air Command's striking force, to be ready for take-off in fifteen minutes is still some months away.
Mayor Wagner will make a fifteen-minute television report tomorrow on his efforts to get additional revenue to balance the city's 1959-60 budget without curtailing essential services.
Thirteen more defendants were indicted here yesterday for grand larceny on charges of fraudulently obtaining welfare payments.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 6 -- Retail cash registers are jingling faintly in this suburban community because too many residents are going elsewhere to buy. This conclusion was drawn by Albert Solit, Town Planner, in a survey made public today.

Quietly but surely, the Little Board -- the American Stock Exchange -- is narrowing the trading gap between it and the Big Board, or the New York Stock Exchange. So far this year, volume of trading on the American Exchange has amounted to 88,460,000 shares, 216 per cent above the 27,950,000 traded in the like period of last year.
The new Sigmund Miller play, "Masquerade," which until recently was known as "Lovely Star, Good Night," has found a Broadway showcase. It will open at the Golden Theatre on March 16.
The nation's three largest producers of copper announced yesterday that their prices would rise 1 1/2 cents a pound on Monday to 31 1/2 cents.
A major upswing in sales of large household appliances since the beginning of the year is making manufacturing plants hum.
An elder statesman of the pulp and paper industry will celebrate his eightieth birthday tomorrow.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 6 -- The Singer Manufacturing Company will vacate its main factory and consolidate its production in newer structures equipped for automation, it announced today. The move will be made over a two-year period.

NEW DELHI, India, March 4 -- During the last few months three of the four international news agencies distributing world news in India have been compelled to suspend their services or have been given notice by the Government to do so.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Organized labor, agriculture and financial groups were the top spenders in the first listing of registered lobbyists for the Eighty-sixth Congress, published today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- An engineer for the Texas Company, New York, has developed a method of keeping oil pipes clear by the use of hard candy balls -- the same "jawbreakers" that puff children's cheeks.
New York lags behind Londo in rail commuting facilities bu leads Paris, according to a survey by the American Geographical Society.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 6 -- The Arkansas Senate today approved a bill calling for a special election at Little Rock to break a 3-3 deadlock on the school board over the handling of an integration dispute.

An exhibition called "Art in Film," devoted to the work of artists in motion-picture production, will be presented from April 11 through May 15 by the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration, Fourth Avenue and Seventh Street.

State Assemblyman Michael G. Rice told 150 owners of cooperative apartments last night that a drive by the Consolidated Edison Company to end conjunctional billing was "inequitable and unconscionable."

When John Reilly of Mount St. Michael steps to the starting line this afternoon for the 880 race in the Catholic High Schools track championships at the Garden, more than fifteen college coaches and scouts will move forward in their seats and automatically begin to wind their stop watches.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., March 6 -- Petitions, telegrams, letters, telephone calls and doorbell ringing were used by Greenburgh residents from White Plains to Yonkers today in a fight to block the rezoning of Central Park Avenue.

Your realty tax editorial of March 4, referring to "angry Queens and Brooklyn home owners," was a complete defense of the act of city assessors. Your editorial language, "Many property owners have been getting away with murder for years * * * real estate taxpayers should share and share alike in the burdens of government, regardless of borough," is as accurate as it is forceful.

A British social anthropologist, a French physical anthropologist and an American archaeologist received last night the 1958 Viking Fund Medals and awards of $1,000 each for their scientific achievements.

The Westinghouse Air Brake Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that its sales and earnings were lower last year than in 1957. A sales upturn in the final quarter, the report said, is expected to continue throughout 1959 and earnings may show a larger rise than sales.
VIENNA, March 6 -- Austria's two-party Government coaltion agreed today to settle its differences in a general election this spring.
A former Brooklyn bank teller charged with embezzling $13,000 was sentenced yesterday to eighteen months in prison.
The annual K-Day fund drive of the New York Kidney Disease Foundation has developed into a concerted community effort, of which New Yorkers have cause to be proud.

There has been no news out of Cuba recently more disturbing than the refusal of Premier Fidel Castro to accept the verdict of the military court in Santiago de Cuba acquitting forty-three airmen. Dr. Castro has not only ordered a retrial, but according to accounts from Cuba has made it clear that he considers the airmen guilty and wants them to be condemned.

LONDON, March 6 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's exhortations to the Soviet Union to catch and overtake the United States in industrial production have evoked a sardonic Russian comment: It is all very well to catch the United States, but if we overtake it Americans will see we have no seat to our pants.

PROVIDENCE, March 6 (AP) -- Brown University's athletic director and new football coach will debate with a Brown instructor who has started a petition to abolish intercollegiate football from the campus.

With the spotlight on education, as it is these days, a discussion of athletic scholarships in our universities was bound to come up. The discussion could scarcely have opened on a better level -- the initiator being A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale, and his immediate supporter being Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton.
DANVILLE, Va., March 6 -- Stockholders of Dan River Mills, Inc., were informed today that three new directors would be elected at the annual meeting to be held here on April 1.
Ocasionally a shipping line gains a nonpaying passenger when it cannot put off a harbor pilot owing to rough weather. This week the United States Lines virtually went into the business.

An official broadcast of the Peiping radio quotes a message that was delivered to the British Charge d'Affaires for delivery to the nations within the United Nations Korea Command. It states flatly that because of United States "domination" of the United Nations, Communist China will henceforth consider any United Nations resolution on Korea as "unilateral" and therefore "null and void."
Strains of the bacteria that cause gonorrhea and which appear to have increased resistance to penicillin have been found recently in the Orient, in Britain and in the United States.

The statements of the Greater New York Hospital Association and Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union on the subject of organizing the 30,000 nonprofessional employes of the city's eighty-one voluntary hospitals reveal a situation of grave public concern.
Secondary schools in this country were advised yesterday not to regard college admission too lightly.
The Soviet Union has reached settlement with E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., of a long-disputed wartime claim.
A new filmed television series with David Niven as host will start April 7 on the National Broadcasting Company network with the Singer Sewing Machine Company as sponsor.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., March 6 (AP) -- In West Virginia, where coal once was king, chronic unemployment "is the uninvited guest at the dinner table of upward of 300,000," a Senate subcommittee was informed today.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 6 -- The state police are holding $19,495.28 in cash found in an automobile yesterday after its driver, a retired New York police sergeant, had been arrested for drunken driving.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 6 -- Terrence Wood, 21-year-old Bronx man, was arraigned on first-degree murder charges today after a gun battle in Manhasset that left two men dead and a third wounded.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 6 -- The heads of Israel's government made strong appeals here today to American Jews to provide the economic resources to enable Israel to absorb the heavy influx of immigrants from Europe.
Mayor Wagner was accused yesterday of permitting Budget Director Abraham D. Beame to nullify a promise to city employes.

Virginia Electric and Power Company plans to spend $53,000,000 on construction in 1959. The company's directors approved an outlay of $24,662,000 for generating facilities; $9,160,000 for the electric transmission and distribution systems; $2,236,000 for mains, production equipment and facilities for gas operations on the Peninsula and at Norfolk; and $1,477,000 for service buildings and shops.
" MY LIFE," writes John Haynes Holmes. "has been a happy one; I would not have missed it" Nevertheless to the end of his story, he is a lonely St. George seeking to slay a Dragon that won't be slain.

WHILE watching a delightful production of Turgenev's "A Month In the Country" at Arena Stage in Washington a few days ago, one member of the audience had a rueful thought: The nation that gives us the most anxiety has made a rich contribution to our culture.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 -- Silver Spoon, the only filly in the race, ran to the sixth straight victory of her brief career today by capturing the $147,300 Santa Anita Derby.
BONN, Germany, March 7 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer moved over a bit in the seat of West German political power this week. He was making room for Dr. Ludwig Erhard, his Minister of Economics.

MANY homemakers agree that lamps are the hardest accessories to select in decorating a house. One reason is that lamp design generally has not kept pace with style developments in home furnishings. And another source of trouble is the wide and bewildering selection of shapes and sizes available.

TO many travelers, a trip to Africa means primitive accommodations and a minimum of six weeks to see the great continent. Last summer, however, we discovered the best of Africa in nine days, stayed in attractive lodges, photographed more animals than we had seen on two safaris, and saw two of Africa's most unusual tribes.
As reported in The Times of Feb. 26 United States importers are alarmed at the Supreme Court's decision which upheld states' rights to tax stored imports.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 (AP) -- Williams retained the New England intercollegiate swimming championship today.

A meeting of the committees planning the ninth annual Easter Luncheon and Fashion Show to benefit the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation will be held at Mrs. Barbara Rockefeller's apartment here tomorrow afternoon.

In the twenty-one years that the Republicans have controlled the New York State Legislature the party machinery has become so firmly entrenched that the individual legislator can have little impact on the law-making processes.
NEW ORLEANS, March 7 -- Master Palynch jumped to an early lead, outlasted the favored Sputnik's stretch charge and won the $50,425 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds today.

HARRISON, N. Y., March 7 -- The Westchester Dance Council will bring a professional ballet program to White Plains High School on April 11 to aid the council's scholarship fund. Andre Eglevsky, star of the New York City Ballet, will present his "Petit Ballet" program. Nora Kaye will dance the female lead.
A burning operation to eliminate weeds and brush that have grown up on about 200 acres of Transit Authority property will begin tomorrow.

HARTFORD, March 7 -- Republican members of the General Assembly, who already have declared their opposition to a court reorganization proposal backed by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, have come out against another reform bill sponsored by the Administration.

ARE the hundreds of amateur orchestras in the United States serving the cause of music? When they give formal programs, hire big-name soloists and charge admission just as if they were professional ensembles, should they not be expected to perform with professional competence?

EVER since man first made a dog do sentry duty and a horse to take a load off his back, he has been trying to teach animals new tricks, generally without the beast's consent, often despite dangerous resistance.

EVERY good itinerary should contain some blank spots, like those white areas tantalizingly rked "Unknown" on old ps. For no matter how much traveler reads and studies or to going abroad, he will quently hear of something fectly wonderful to do or once he is over there, of ich he had not known before. t invariably he hears about it t when his schedule demands t he must leave.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 7 -- The Soviet Union beat the United States and Canada whipped Czechoslovakia tonight in the world amateur ice hockey championships. The Russians, who are favored with the defending champion, Canada, for the world title, scored three times in the final period for a 5-3 victory over the United States.

NO backward glance at the beginnings of American painting can overlook the manifold activities of the Peale family of Philadelphia. The Revolutionary portraitist Charles Willson Peale established it and among its many members, each devoted to a particular genre, none eclipsed Raphaelle Peale in the painting of still-life.

LET'S suppose," says Joanna Foster, "you have decided to write a book and this is what might happen." It will probably be some years before the present reader will begin to wonder why the volume he has written is so long coming from the presses, but in the meantime he will have acquired a new respect for a book as the product of the combined efforts of many craftsmen.

SENATE inquiries into labor-management rackets have made America dismally aware that high moral character is not always an attribute of union leadership: over the last few years, many headlines have reminded us all too often that men steeped in venality and sick with lust for personal power have made their way into positions of authority in some of the country's most strategic unions.

A sketch made from a description given to the police by a shooting victim yesterday led to the arrest of a 17-year-old youth. Detectives recognized the sketch as that of a young man they had previously arrested.

Retirement is a complex problem which cannot be solved by the enactment of dogmatic legislation such as the Social Security Act or of mandatory Civil Service retirement laws. I have only to point out the cases of some of the more eminent teachers in this country who have reached the "mandatory" retirement age of 65, to show that static; inflexible dictates are not the answer.

IF you were to ask an English boy what he thought an American school would be like, the chances are that he would answer in terms of creweuts, cigarette ends, handpainted ties and flashy sports cars. In short, he would expect it to be loud and devastatingly informal.
ON the fiftieth anniversary, April 6, of Rear Admiral Robert Edwin Peary's discovery of the North Pole, a 4-cent blue commemorative stamp will be issued by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A substantial movement is developing within the Administration and in Congress to strip the Atomic Energy Commission of its primary responsibility for protecting the public against radiation hazards.
HACKENSACK, N. J., March 7 -- A plan to unite Girl Scout organizations in Bergen County into a single council will be presented at a series of meetings, beginning Monday, during Girl Scout Week.

HARLAN, Ky., March 7 (AP) -- An official of the United Mine Workers of America told a cheering crowd of union miners and pensioners today that Harlan County's holdout independent coal mines would be struck Monday.

BEFORE the Metropolitan Opera gets around to its first experiment with a full evening of ballet, now set for Sunday, March 22, something must be said, however reluctantly, about the more regulation part of its ballet activity during the current season.

Africa is making a compelling demand today for greater attention from the world outside. The single underlying force felt almost throughout the continent is the tide of nationalism. What follows is a description of the land, its people, its history and current problems and prospect for the future.

The current three-power negotiations at Geneva for a nuclear test ban agreement represent, by their very existence, a momentous step toward the realization of two of man's major hopes in this anxious time: hope that the pollution of our earthly environment by radioactive fall-out may be ended, hope that one of the essential preconditions for a concerted disarmament program may be achieved.
BY tomorrow the world's weariest group of actors and technicians should be the "For Whom the Bell Tolls" company.

AT the moment there is probably no writer in the English language more in favor with the critical fraternity than Henry James. Reflecting his vogue, paperback publishers rarely let a month pass without bringing out a new edition of at least one of his works.

Mr. Bellow's "deep reading" has indeed become dangerous to literature but it just may be that "serious" readers are forced into this ridiculous search for symbols because the story material itself is so poor. In this same section were fiction reviews of a Spanish juvenile gang, a Russian Mickey Spillane, an agrarian Oliver Twist, a melange of somnambulant women unable to define boredom, and, most charitably, a sort of lower depths unconsumptive Camille, called "Cammie."

Steel production continued on a high level in the week ended Feb. 28 with the Cleveland-Lorain district rate scheduled at 86.5 per cent of capacity. Output figures for the previous week were revised upward to 87 per cent of capacity.

HOME owners interested in improving their basements to make these unused areas a pleasant place to work or play can often do so easily and inexpensively by applying a bright coat of fresh paint to walls and floors.

ROD SERLING, a television writer who gained distinction by his contributions to "Playhouse 90," will take on the added job of producer next fall. He will produce a half-hour weekly filmed drama series titled "The Twilight Zone," which he created for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ORIGINAL works of art are becoming commonplace in upper middle class American homes. There was a time not so long ago when, aside from the great and wealthy collectors, it was only those "highbrows" -- so brilliantly satirized by Russell Lynes -- who regularly included works of art in their homes.
Spring 1959 expands the horizons in decorating, enlarges still further upon a whole wide wonderful world of furnishings. The keynote: individuality.

MOSCOW, March 7 -- Revolution swept the giant stage of the Bolshoi Theatre tonight with the first showing in Moscow of Prokofieff's ballet fantasy, "The Stone Flower." New York audiences are scheduled to see this spectacular dance drama in early May.
irs. Anthony M. Del Balso loves riding to hounds and does so every--or nearly every-chance she gets.

RANGOON, Burma, March 7 -- Reform has swept over Burma with dramatic swiftness under the new regime of Gen. Ne Win, commander of the armed forces. Many foreign residents here say they have never seen anything like it in this slow-moving part of the world.
THE recent Old Vic production of "Hamlet" appears to have raised anew a familiar argument regarding the application of critical standards to television.
It's likely to be a long, long time before the mineral wealth on the ocean floor is exploited commercially.

A shift in emphasis on research in mental disease is apparently following the recent freer exchange of scientific information between the United States and the Soviet Union. This was indicated here yesterday by three Soviet scientists just before they started on the last leg of a month-long tour of American laboratories.

THE principal economic issue dividing the American people today is the issue of growth of the economy vs. stability of the price level. Mr. Eisenhower has declared that a stable price level "is an indispensable condition for achieving vigorous and continuing economic growth" and has placed strong emphasis on the prevention of inflation in his State of the Union message, his budget message, and his economic report.

THERE is a fundamental difference between the American preparatory school and its British equivalent, the public school. Because it is within the means of more American levels of society than of British to send their children off to at least one year of prep school, and because there are few class barriers in America, one finds a very different atmosphere in American schools.

THE author of this book of short stories, John Innes Mackintosh Stewart, is a Scottish-born scholar who has been praised for his academic criticism ("Character and Motive in Shakespeare") and for a few novels ("Mark Lambert's Supper," etc.) in which, Punch observes, "his direction is generally toward a clarified and even dilute [Henry] James."
Representative Chester Bowles accused the Eisenhower Administration yesterday of encouraging the United States' economy to stagnate.
The deficit-ridden Treasury's recent late-winter vacation from borrowing chores is about over. So is the bond market's concurrent rally.

NEWARK, March 7 -- The Blue Cross Hospital Service Plan of New Jersey expended a record total of $54,188,878 for hospitalization benefits to its subscribers in 1958, it was reported today. The sum was nearly $6,600,000 greater than that of the previous year.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Sunshine Festival, scheduled for March 28-April 3 this year, is the annual event that ushers out the winter season here and welcomes the spring tourists. This year the young people will share a considerable part of the program with the adults.

BRIGHTON, Ill., March 7 -- Blood strains of pen-raised game birds and methods of conditioning them for field shooting have got to be improved if commercial preserve hunting is not to degenerate into mere live-bird shooting.

WITH so many city-boy-in-the-country situations in children's literature one might think that by now those green meadows would be thoroughly trampled. Maureen Daly, how ever, steers Patrick away from the usual routes and keeps her story as fresh as the sun-warmed tomatoes and newly-pulled carrots the young boy eats.

THE current loan exhibition sponsored by the Friends of the Whitney Museum may come as something of a surprise to the museum's regular visitors. The eighteen artists represented were selected through a poll of the members of the Friends organization for their choice among living American artists and, although all eighteen have been repeatedly represented in Whitney annuals, this show has a different cumulative effect.

BRAVOS to the United States Information Agency for its concern about the visual arts in the American National Exhibition for Moscow. Plans for the display of painting and sculpture move encouragingly forward, though private funds for the terribly necessary catalogue are needed.

New York has embarked upon a three months' celebration of the music of George Frederick Handel. This is the 200th anniversary of the death of the great composer. This happens to be the first time that the City of New York has undertaken such an enterprise.

MATTRESSES, a home-furnishings "best seller" in stores across the nation, pose many problems for purchasers. Not the least of these is the variable "comfort" and how it can be determined. The next matter to decide on is which construction gives the longest life. Price is a third consideration.
MIAMI BEACH, March 7 -- A record sale of $19,558,250 in Israel Bonds officially marked the floating of a $300,000,000 Second Development Issue tonight for the expansion of Israel's economy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26 -- The principal of the school stood in the center of the corridor like a rock dividing a stream. On his right, a long double line of children marched down the hall and out the front door. On his left, an equally long line marched up the back stairs toward the classrooms.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- An electronic computer has been harnessed for the first time to a continuous commercial petroleum production process.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 7 (UPI) -- African mobs burned European and African homes and religious buildings in this British protectorate today.

AFTER being celebrated in every other medium, two of man's most imaginative feats in this century, the launching of the satellites and the sub-Polar voyage by submarine from the Pacific to the Atlantic, now get their innings on records.

TO the average family, stereophonic sound can be an auditory joy and a financial headache. Stereo on disks, the system introduced last year, is a means of recording by which an ordinary-looking LP disk carries two channels. Signals from those two channels are fed through two amplifiers and two speakers.
Astronomical expenditures and grinding effort by thousands for almost a full year preceded last Tuesday's "moon shoot."

TOKYO, March 4 -- Japanese engineers, now preparing for the construction of a huge rail-highway bridge across the Inland Sea by way of Awaji island, have completed an undersea craft to survey sea bottom conditions.

THE amazing quantity of contract bridge literature grows apace. By an offhand but uncommonly well-informed estimate it must now exceed 12,000 full-fledged books, 50,000 pamphlets and 25,000 issues of bridge periodicals, not to speak of the occasional articles in general magazines and the bridge features that more than a thousand newspapers have been publishing every day since heaven knows when.

THE revamped Columbia Pictures studio setup, which now consists of thirty - three individual production units financed by the corporation, will shift into high gear this week with the start of filming of a group of eighteen pictures -- all scheduled to go before the cameras by mid-June.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 7 (UPI) -- Betty Kerby of Akron won her first major Florida tournament today with a 4-and-3 upset victory over Judy Bell, the medalist, in the Florida East Coast women's amateur championship.

Although the first of the conventions is sixteen months away, there were significant stirrings in the political corral this week where a varied field of Presidential hopefuls are being groomed -- or are grooming themselves -- for an early breakaway in the quadrennial scramble for the Republican and Democratic nominations.

One of pleasure boating's frightening bugaboos -- getting fogged in with no visibility -- has another new safety device that makes skippers grateful to the genuises of electronic science who invented it. It is not only good for boats but also serviceable on small aircraft.
PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- A $500,000 project is planned to construct a reproduction of Tun Tavern, the Colonial building where the first members of the Marine Corps were recruited.

W HEN I came to ray writing desk on a recerit morning, I found lying on my desk top an ,unmailed letter that I had written. I began reading it and found this sentence: "We are all civilized .people, which means that we are all savages at heart but observing a few amenities of civilized behavior.

The advertising push by trans-Atlantic airlines is under way, long before most travelers have had an opportunity to think about packing. By the time they are packed the ad programs will be virtually ended.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 7 -- The sponsor of an animal lending library replied today to criticism of the plan by the Connecticut Humane Society.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 7 -- A meeting to organize a cooperative library system in Nassau County will be held at the Franklin Square Public Library on Thursday. The system would facilitate loans between libraries and provide centralized services.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Communism has lost none of its menace to the United States despite its shrunken official party membership, the House Committee on Un-American Activities told Congress today.

BOWIE, Md., March 7 (AP) -- The Triple M. Farm's Tinkalero, tired but game, lasted to defeat Harold H. Polk's Mlle. Dianne by a nose today in the $28,050 Barbara Frietchie Handicap at windswept Bowie Race Course.

WHERE is the cultural exchange program with the Soviet Union getting us? Besides pleasant dancers and thrilling music, what are we giving each other? Are ideas being planted, is there understanding and appreciation of one another's problems?

THE migration from Puerto Rico to New York City has created a spectacular boom in Spanish- language films here. In the early Nineteen Forties, only one movie house -- in Harlem -- catered exclusively to the Spanish-speaking trade.

THIS novel recaptures the all-absorbing quest of a Harvard University graduate to find who he is and what he wants to do with his life. From the first page, David Polonsky, Charles Angoff's protagonist in "Between Day and Dark," draws the reader into the secret places of his inner world where past, present and future flow together into the turmoil of growing up.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -The United States and Canada have agreed in principle on joint control of nuclear weapons and stockpiles of warheads to be based in Canada.

Mr. Doherty's Law of Political Syllabification is important, but equally important is the Law of the Presidential Double-Letter: each twentieth-century President has had a double letter somewhere in his name, as Herbert HOOver or HaRRy Truman, and even D. D. Eisenhower.

MAKE no mistake about it, a onetime Miss America is a marked woman. Particularly if she is a non-conformist who appears to be almost as wise as she is beautiful, and not quite as talented as she is neurotic.

The Kremlin is making an extraordinary and rather mystifying fuss over Iran's sovereign decision to sign a security pact with the United States. The country has been served with severe warn ings over and over again. Similar warnings have been extended to Pakistan.

WHEN the city rooftop gardener makes his first trip to a suburban nursery this spring, he should take along a list of appropriate and inappropriate plants. It is easy to get carried away with prospects of mountain laurel and lilac on the terrace.
The Manhattan College basketball team staged a closing sprint to defeat Fordham at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night, 73 to 64.

THE unruly English language of Chaucer, Milton and Gertrude Stein is being tamed by the Patent Office to fit the needs of the Computer Age. The office hopes that computers may some day take over the job of checking every new patent application against some 7,000,000 American and foreign patents to determine if it is a novel idea.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 7 -- President Tito declared today that from here on the Yugoslavs would answer in kind all attacks on his regime from the Soviet-bloc nations.

THE annual college music festival is assuming an increasingly important role in American life. It is an institution that has proved stimulating to local populations, both in and out of the universities.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 7 -- Camping experience for needy children in Westchester will again be made possible by the annual benefit dessert bridge party of the Westchester Alumnae of Gamma Phi Beta, national social sorority.
A number of well known European and American artists are represented in the many group and one-man shows in local galleries this week.

" THE LOST GENERATION," as Miss Gertrude Stein called the young expatriate Americans who discovered their literary talent in Paris in the Twenties and put down the first roots of the modern American novel in the Left Bank, is having its first complete retrospective exhibition this week, appropriately held in the St. Germain des Pres quarter, where most of the writers had transplanted themselves and where their novels grew.
As reported in your March 2 issue the Deputy Premier and Defense Minister of Communist China pledged support for East Germany in case of "imperialist assault."

REGISTRATION for four garden tours and three courses can be made at the International Flower Show this week. The tours have been arranged by the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc. for show visitors who come from a distance to attend.
The third annual cocktail tea dance for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service, on April 12, will aid the organization in expanding its facilities. The fete will be held at the Pierre.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific has protested the Navy's plan to use ships of the Military Sea Transportation Service with civil service crews in tracking missiles fired from the California coast.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I. March 7 -- The Town of Hempstead was under court order today to hold a hearing on the proposed incorporation of this resort community. Incorporation would make Atlantic Beach the first new village to be formed in Nassau County in more than thirty years.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 7 -- A demand that more power be put into the hands of lay professors in Roman Catholic colleges and universities was voiced last night at a public forum at the University of Notre Dame.

CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti, March 7 --In a radio speech to the nation tonight President Francois Duvalier declared that Hatian-United States relations were entering a new phase of cooperation. He described the cooperation as the most complete in their relationship.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Nepotism -- that practice of favoring one's relatives that is all right when you do it but pretty shocking when a member of Congress does -- has caused another rumpus in the headlines.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The omnibus banking bill designed to allow the state banking system to accommodate itself to postwar business and economic developments appeared today to have strong support in both political parties.

MILWAUKEE, March 7 -- The growing international crisis is making it imperative that President Eisenhower act "very shortly" to decide whether Mr. Dulles can continue as Secretary of State, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey declared today.

WALPOLE, Mass., March 7 -- State troopers firing machine guns smashed into a workshop at Walpole State Prison today to seize six convicts and rescue seven hostages. The hostages included the prison's warden and its Roman Catholic chaplain.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Army Board of Review has overruled the court-martial conviction of a young lieutenant who was accused of mistreating recruits at Fort Jackson, S. C.
WASHINGTON, March 7--Hot words over defense contracts are threatening to erupt into a cold war between New York State and California.

There is increasing evidence that cosmic rays come from the stars and perhaps from distant galaxies, but not from the sun, according to a report presented last week by Dr. H. V. Neher, Professor of Physics at the California Institute of Technology and a member of the United States Panel on Cosmic Radiation of the International Geophysical Year.

The earth swings slowly but inexorably on its trunnions and now we in this Northern Hemisphere begin once more to face the sun directly. Sunrise is almost east again, and sunset west; and at midday the sunlight begins to probe the winter-armored soil instead of glancing off. The vernal equinox approaches.

OSLO, March 7 (AP) -- Sverre Stensheim of Norway won the fifty - kilometer cross - country race of the Holmenkollen Ski Festival today. An outbreak of colds had knocked out thirty-two of the original entrants, including several favorites.
HAVANA, March 7 -- A law ordering the confiscation of property of officials and legislators of the Batista regime was expanded today by President Manuel Urrutia Lleo and the Cabinet.
An elderly watchman, apparently the victim of a thief who smashed him on the head with a sash weight, was found dead yesterday afternoon in a shanty at a Park Avenue construction project.
The New York Coliseum was filled with the fragrance of hyacinths yesterday at the opening of the forty-second International Flower Show.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 7 -- What is it like to do business with the Russians?
BOSTON, March 7 -- Border warfare over taxes has flared anew in neighboring New Hampshire. State officials here and in Vermont remained calm.
LIMBE, Nyasaland, March 7 -- Eleven persons believed to be nationalists, including the only African lawyer in the protectorate, were arrested today in a renewed drive to curb the violence.

To moon rocketeers on earth, a scientist noted recently, the moon with its diameter of 2,160 miles and its mean distance of 239,000 miles represents a target about two feet across to an archer standing some 220 feet from it. An expert archer might hit such a target with a few tries.
A list of "Books to Remember," the selection by a committee of librarians of works of "permanent interest" published in 1958, is in a new pamphlet of the New York Public Library.
A warning that New York City might be confronted by a shortage of 5,000 public school teachers next year was voiced yesterday at the annual spring conference of the New York Teachers Guild.
A program for the treatment and study of heart diseases that may provide facilities not now available in New York City is planned for the New York Medical College-Metropolitan Hospital Center.
THERE are two major publishing seasons in Paris: September-October and April-May. So now is a good moment to draw up a balance sheet of recent months.
BONN, Germany, March 7 -- The West German Navy plans to acquire at least four and probably eight destroyers equipped with multipurpose rockets capable of delivering nuclear or conventional warheads.

The business recovery is going along "in an orderly manner," according to reports from purchasing executives, summarized yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. But the survey found a wide variation in the rate of recovery among industries.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March (AP) -- The fourth international bonspiel ended today after completion of the quarter-finals and the Toronto curling rink was declared the winner on points.
BALTIMORE, March 7 (AP) -- The Army has no intention of treating its soldier-scientists as a class different from other military personnel, an Army spokesman said today.

MADISON, Wis., March 7 (AP) -- With Tom Robinson leading the way, Michigan today swept to its eighteenth Big Ten indoor track title since 1911. The Wolverines totaled 71 points. The defending champion, Illinois, was second with 48.
ONE of the greatest of all composers, Roland de Lassus (or Orlando di Lasso, to use the more familiar, Italian form of his name), has long had the most niggardly representation on disks.

THIS latest biography of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi is complete and readable. B. R. Nanda makes the "Father of Indian Independence" a personality from the opening paragraphs, wherein Gandhi the schoolboy is wrongfully accused by his teacher of lying.

We are living in a period of astonishing accomplishment in medical science. The last week has brought news of still another achievement. A team of young British research men, after three years of hard work, has come up with the isolation , in its pure form, of the basic substance of penicillin.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller has pitched into the first real intraparty scrap of his political career wearing kid gloves.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The chairman of the Corregidor-Bataan Memorial Commission is angry.

BHILAI, India, Feb. 26 -- In less than two years, a task force of Russian engineers in pith helmets and khaki work clothes has helped transform this dot on the map of central India from a drowsy cluster of huts to a booming industrial community of 65,000 steel and construction workers.
LOS ANGELES, March 7 -Two hundred residents of an ancient wooden tenement in downtoxm Los Angeles had a close brush with death thist week -- from red tape.

ALAMOGORDO, N. M., March 7 -- Riding an Astrodyne rocket sled, two squealing white rats have survived a ride of 1,050 miles an hour down the 35,000-foot test track at the Air Force Missile Development Center.

LONDON, March 7 -- Along the echoing corridors of the Foreign Office and in the rooms where the coal fires blaze merrily in open grates, the sharpest brains of British diplomacy are busily ruminating over the feast of information that Prime Minister Macmillan brought back from the first, but probably not the last, summit meeting of the year with Premier Khrushchev.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -- Coach Bob Kiphuth's Yale swimmers turned in a 60-26 victory over Harvard today for an undefeated schedule in Kiphuth's final season. The Crimson loss was the first of the season for Coach Hal Ulen, who also retired today.

SIBELIUS: Symphony No. 2; Sir Malcolm Sargent conducting the British Broadcasting Corporation Symphony Orchestra (E. M. I. Capitol). Sir Malcolm conducts with the big line, the power and the momentum Sibelius requires.
Final arrangements have been made by the Christ Child Society for its annual spring luncheon and card party on April 2 at the Pierre.
Governor Rockefeller has been urged by Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, to support Mayor Wagner's proposal for legalizing and taxing off-track betting on horse races.
New York rabbis called upon their coreligionists yesterday to help raise a special fund of $100,000,000 "over and above the regular budget" of the United Jewish Appeal.

SOLOMON is an ideal subject for the historical novelist. The facts are few and the opportunities unlimited. Aside from some twenty chapters of the Biblical record (carefully edited by a Rabbinate loyal to the builder of Jerusalem's famous Temple) there is nothing to restrain the producer of synthetic cineramic epics.

Longer lives under modern conditions are creating needs for help to the aged that out-strip present resources, Msgr. George H. Guilfoyle said yesterday in his annual report as executive director of New York Catholic Charities.

The designers who fashion schoolrooms and teaching equipment have been peering into the future and looking over teachers' shoulders. They have noted the variety of space-age subjects being taught and they have seen the new methods of teaching in action.

THE successes and failures of the various moon probes have introduced us to one of the basic facts of astronomical life. Here on earth we assume that to drive an automobile 100 miles requires 100 times as much gas as to drive it one mile. This simple relationship breaks down completely in space, as the examples of the Russian Lunik and our own moon shots have proved.
LEONIE RYSANEK, the Metropolitan's new Viennese soprano, adds another role to her local repertory Saturday evening by singing Elizabeth of Valois in "Don Carlo."
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The United States Weather Bureau is planning to calculate and announce a "discomfort index" on an experimental basis this summer.

Auction sales this week take in the old and the new. They offer such items as English period furniture and decorations, modern paintings and prints and ceramics by Pablo Picasso, French and Venetian furniture and American and English books.

FOR THIS WEEK: More sunshine and longer days spur house plant growth. Use plant food every two to three weeks. . . . Spray broadleaved evergreens which show signs of leaf spot with a fungicide. . . . Mild days are good for repairing broken gates and fences. . . . Seed can be sown directly on top of patchy lawns now.

The Virginia Day Nursery will benefit from a special preview of the motion picture "The Sound and the Fury" on the evening of March 19 at the Twentieth Century-Fox projection room at 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Representatives of labor and industry will speak at the Paul Abelson Public Lectures in Labor Relations to be delivered at City College during the spring semester. The first lecture will be given on March 19.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- When the foreign and military affairs experts from Congress arrived at the White House yesterday evening, President Eisenhower took them into the library, rather than the Cabinet Room, and offered them a drink.

THE best things about Fred M. Hechinger's book are his conclusions. He wants to introduce national minimum standards into American high schools, and he wants to clean the trash out of the curriculum. He thinks that if we do this we can be certain of maintaining an educated citizenry, and that with an educated citizenry we can stop staying up at night worrying about the latest innovations in the Moscow schools.
The threat of a Berlin crisis prompted many public queries and discussions last week about United States' military readiness.

The latest fashion in the business outlook is to be shaped in retail stores over the next three weeks. If they do well with Easter apparel, business will be good. If the new spring lines fail to sell in volume other aspects of the economy will suffer too.
Stockholders have less than six weeks to compile their dividend and other 1958 income records for Federal income tax returns, due on April 15.

SINCE World War II, monasticism has become a literary mode in America, like mountains during the English Romantic movement. Such best-sellers as Thomas Merton's "The Seven Storey Mountain," Monica Baldwin's "I Leap Over the Wall" and Kathryn Hulme's "The Nun's Story" have brought monastery and cloister, and their problems, close to millions here.

PARIS, March 7 -- Ahmed ben Bella, captive Deputy Premier of the provisional Algerian rebel government, was transferred today from Sante prison in Paris to a tiny island fortress off the French coast north of Bordeaux.

Resident offices are predicting that suits will be the favorite Easter costume on the basis of heavy orders in every price range. It is expected that this will be one of the best suit years in some time. Fabrics include silks, light worsteds and tweeds.
SEVERAL volumes recently added to the growing list of practical photographic literature offer technical guidance on a wide range of applications.

" ANTI-CORONARY CLUB" -- Dr. Norman Jolliffe, director of the New York City Health Department's Bureau of Nutrition, presented some preliminary findings from the city's two-year-old "anti-coronary club" project at the annual meeting of the National Vitamin Foundation last week. In a group of seventy-nine middle-aged men, Dr. Jolliffe reported, a "prudent" diet significantly lowered the amount of cholesterol in the blood during a six-month period.
Hugh Borton, president of Haverford College, warned yesterday against overspecialization in science and mathematics in secondary schools.

IT'S a dull month that doesn't produce at least one book by a Van Doren. We had an autobiography from Mark Van Doren last fall and more recently an anthology of letters from his son Charles. Now comes Mark's wife with a volume of reminiscence to supplement her husband's memoir.
BONN, Germany, March 7 -- A sharply intensified and sometimes crude anti-Communist propaganda campaign is under way in West Germany.

CAIRO, March 7 -- President Nasser of the United Arab Republic is in the enviable position these bright spring days of a young man with fresh money in his pocket and the fair maidens of both East and West competing for his favor.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 7 (AP) -- "Look," said the Australian, with a laugh, as he passed over a newspaper to a companion in a country pub, "here's a story, about a joker in America who's selling his farm and coming to Australia because he doesn't like the Government telling him what to do.

FREQUENTLY the dramatic episodes of history are unimportant, and the really significant events make dull reading. This is nowhere more true than in the maritime field. The emergence of England as a dominant oceanic power in the time of Elizabeth, however, was an exception.

LIFE in a reflective mood appears to be the prevailing theme of Harry Lapow's first show at the Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, where it may be seen evenings to April 12. Ordinary people, mostly older women, some men and children, are depicted in a variety of quiet situations, relaxed, thoughtful, often bored and lonely, with an occasional reminder that life can be pleasant too.

THE English system of education strikes the American at first as quite stiff -- and quite good. At the age of 15, the student takes his "Ordinary Level" examinations. These form the first section of the General Certificate of Education examinations, a nation-wide testing system sponsored by Oxford and Cambridge -- far more inclusive and effective than the College Board exams.

WHEN adhesives must be spread for application of wall or floor tiles, make certain the correct tool is used. Most manufacturers recommend special notched spreaders or towels which have notches cut to specific dimensions.

Using the approach that if the passenger won't pay his way in full, maybe the truckers will, the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway began last week to hitch five flat cars and a caboose on the end of its crack passenger trains, No. 1 (westbound from Washington, D. C.) and No. 2 (eastbound from Cincinnati), better known as the George Washington.
Beatrice and Ira Freeman didn't carry their accurate article far enough to warn the unwary bunny of her probable future if, glory be!, she gets her man.
The Committee for Scholarships of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing will hold its twelfth annual card party and tea April 15 at the Nurses Residence, 1320 York Avenue.

THE theme of human brotherhood is contrasted with the dark spirit of the fifteenth century in the distinguished new novel by the author of "Sons of the Steppe," published here last winter. It follows the adventures of two orphaned brothers, Tinoco and Aires, who leave their small fishing village to travel to the monastic court of the Infante Henrique of Portugal -known to history as Henry the Navigator.
WARSAW, March 7 -- Delegates from Communist parties in about fifty countries began arriving in Warsaw today for next week's national congress of the Polish Communist party.

When Roy Campanella was a patient at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, he had one painting in his room. It was a Vermont winter scene, which hung on the wall at the foot of his bed.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -President Eisenhower has taken personal command of the Berlin crisis and has told Congress he needs no additional money for missiles or conventional warfare forces to deal with it.

THIS timely and encouraging guide book for parents covers a broader field than the title indicates. Although there is much information here about purely urban situations -- from a child's first visit to a museum to handling pets in a small apartment -- many of the ideas and attitudes which the author presents have a wider application.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 7 -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike of Ceylon sees no future in Asia for Parliaments modeled on Westminster or Washington.

The concert series called "Jazz Profiles," which began auspiciously earlier this season at the Nonagon Art Gallery on Second Avenue, moved Friday at midnight to the more spacious Circle in the Square Theatre at 5 Sheridan Square.
CHICAGO, March 7--Dr. W. Horsley Gantt of The Johns Hopkins University, who did research under Ivan Pavlov for six years in the early Nineteen Twenties, characterizes Soviet medicine as conservative.

BOSTON -- Any day now, a New England farmer trudging through his grove of sugar maples will hear the cheerful "tunk, tunk, tunk" of maple sap dropping into the galvanized buckets he hung on the trees several weeks ago.

MENDELSSOHN: Octet in E Flat, Op. 20; Sinfonia No. 9 for Strings: Arthur Winograd and String Orchestra (M-G-M). The Sinfonia is a polished and highly elaborated work of a 14-year-old boy, and it shows flashes of things to come.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 7 -- The Little Orchestra Society of New York gave a concert here last night before an appreciative audience in a sweltering college auditorium.
The world's indoor record for the mile run took a big tumble toward four minutes last night.
TRENTON, March 7 -- The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene here Monday, ending a three-week recess.

The educational and recreational services provided by the Union Settlement at 237 East 104th Street will benefit from the April 14 evening showing of "Green Mansions." The film starring Audrey Hepburn, Tony Perkins and Lee J. Cobb will be at the Radio City Music Hall.
A committee of lawyers who specialize in state legislation has approved the court reorganization plan of the State Judicial Conference.
If the man in the gray flannel suit expects to continue his reign on Madison Avenue, he will have to fight off a challenge by three girls wearing white whipcord riding breeches.
The 100th anniversary of the birth of Sholom Aleichem, famous writer in Yiddish, received wide attention in the Soviet Union last week.

Columbia University will be host this week to 4,500 young journalists and their faculty advisers from public, private and parochial schools over the country. They will attend the thirty-fifth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention.
A protest that a projected Herald Square parking garage was unnecessary and unwise because of the city's fiscal position was made yesterday by the Thirty-fifth-Thirty-sixth Street Merchants Group.

BOSTON, March 7 -- The mud of the moderator's gavel the podium, a sure sign of ring in New England, was beginning to be heard this week at town meetings. It was accompanied by the impassioned areas of taxpayers' associations spokesmen for economy.

SERIOUS questions of constitutional law, polities and state sovereignty are being raised over the proposal for a multi-state pact whereby convictions for speeding and other major violations of motor vehicle laws would be carried over from one participating state to the other.

All Hallows raced to a 12-point lead early in the second period, then held off a late rally by Power Memorial to win the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship, 59 -- 52, before 2,500 at Fordham University yesterday.

ALMOST any literate Japanese can write a haiku. Bankers at a convention, steelworkers on a picnic, even drunks at a bar can write haiku -- three lines of five, seven and five syllables -- with seeming effortlessness.

East and West were engaged last week in an intense dialogue. Behind the words lay a quickening search for a way out of the impasse over Berlin and Germany which both sides clearly recognized contained the threat of a major explosion.

NO matter if the snow flies or the wind howls outside a young reader's window. It is summer on Mike's island -- in Long Island Sound -- hot sun on sand, fishing, swimming. Mike's two-week vacation did not really start until another fellow his own age showed up to share the fun -- mostly treasure hunting -and the trouble -- mostly female.

THE Ballets Africains of Keita Fodeba continue their extended engagement at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, with performances nightly from Tuesday through Sunday, and matinees on Saturday and, beginning next week, on Sunday also.

IN a country where the slogan "Up with communism, down with capitalism!" sets the pattern of daily life, it is probably natural to find every means of communication enlisted in the campaign for world superiority -- even an object two inches long, one and a half inches wide and five-eighths of an inch high.

ST. THOMAS, V. I., March 7 -- Ten years ago, St. Thomas, once the shipping center of the Caribbean, welcomed one cruise ship in twelve months. This year, ninety cruise ships are expected to debark some 50,000 visitors in St. Thomas.
It is hard to believe that V. J. Skutt, president of the world's largest exclusive health and accident insurance company, once rode the rails with a load of cattle.
The American Merchant Marine Institute, representing owners of vessels using the Port of New York, is taking its fight against increased pilotage charges to the Legislature.

PROOF that youth will be served both in the theatre and in the movies came from London the other day with the revelatory information that a new play, "A Taste of Honey," eventually would be filmed. The word is that it is being planned by Woodfall Productions, the independent English company headed by producer Harry Saltzman, playwright John Osborne and director Tony Richardson.

The annual Long Island boat and sportsmen's show opened yesterday at the 104th Field Artillery Armory, Jamaica, Queens. A display of more than 150 small craft, plus skiffs, cruisers, runabouts and other nautical exhibits, attracted several thousand boating and fishing fans.

Mr. Bellow's position would have been stronger if the student and teacher he cites had read the "Iliad" of Homer a little more "deeply." If they had done so, in fact, if they had read it all, they would never have talked about Achilles dragging the corpse of Hector round the walls of Troy.
EACH outdoor game has its own requirements as to space, appropriate groundcovers and enclosures. Play areas can be included on the home property provided that the ground is level.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- It's becoming increasingly obvious that Casey Stengels flamboyant plan to make a first baseman out of Lawrence Peter Berra has collapsed against the stone wall of Yogi's massive resistance. The only time Yogi is found in the vicinity of first base is when he runs the bases.

At 11:30 Friday morning Pioneer IV, America's first artificial asteroid, sent its last message to earth. It had by then reached a distance of more than 410,000 miles from the earth and was traveling at a speed of almost 4,000 miles an hour into an orbit around the sun.

SUFFERN N. Y., March 7 -Michael H. Prendergast, New York State Democratic chairman, said today that if the Republicans forced through the Rockefeller budget and tax program the Democrats would have their best chance in twenty-three years to control the New York State Legislature.

A 21-year-old man who fell ten stories in an elevator shaft last Monday died yesterday afternoon at St. Clare's Hospital. He was Herman Santiago, a messenger of 102 West 109th Street. He had fallen from the eleventh to the ground floor in a loft building at 224 West Thirty-fourth Street.

THE American family, a subject of which statisticians never seem to tire, has finally stumped the graph-and-chart fraternity. The furniture-buying patterns of families have defied organized analysis if, indeed, any patterns exist.
BERLIN, March 7--Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev declared today in a speech at Leipzig that the Soviet Union would never permit Communist rule in East Germany to be liquidated through unification.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 7 -- Southern School News reported today new efforts to accelerate integration in Southern schools and legislative counter-moves to delay it.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- While the local view that "you haven't seen the South until you've seen Savannah" may be set down to civic loyalty, there is no denying that Savannah still retains much of the romantic atmosphere that is associated in song and story with the Old South.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 7 -- This missile-testing center is being expanded to serve as a nursery for the United States' youngest weapons, and perhaps the most important.
BROADWAY folk, like baseball folk, have a deep-rooted passion for statistics. This week four "firsts" will go down on Broadway's books in a single evening.
ANDORRA, high in the Pyrenees, is as pretty as a calendar picture, a mere twenty-some miles across and one more entry stamp on, the passport.

ONE of the surest signs of approaching spring is the increase of water cress in rustic brooks. The tiny leaves and slender stalks of the delicate emerald plant are as much a harbinger of the incoming season as the first robin.

A team of leading United States earthquake specialists, assembled by the Government to map a program aimed at foolproof detection of underground nuclear blasts was understood to have completed its work yesterday.

American higher education's fastest-growing source of support in the last fifteen years has been private gifts, the Council for Financial Aid to Education reported last week. In a study of the period since the wartime increases in income tax rates made philanthropic giving more attractive, the council found that gifts have increased nearly 800 per cent.

TOKYO, March 4 -- The average wage for Japanese workers increased 3.5 per cent in 1958 over 1957, to 21,161 yen ($58.78) a month, the Labor Ministry reports. Employes of public enterprises, such as utilities, had the largest increase, 8.6 per cent.

ONLY eleven of the plays, musicals and theatrical whatnots produced in New York last season recovered their cost. Of the forty-four flops -- flop is the trade epithet for a feckless undertalking -- sixteen perished within three weeks of their christening; another nineteen were annulled short of one hundred performances.

WHEN Aubrey Menen's first witty, ironic novel, "The Prevalence of Witches," burst on a delighted American audience eleven years ago, its author admitted to a singular "mental weakness." He could, he said, only do his thinking in the form of stories.
CLARKSBURG, W. Va., March 7 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington said tonight that there was "real danger of a shooting war or shameful surrender" in the Berlin crisis.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The New York Rangers mathematically eliminated the Chicago Black Hawks from the National Hockey League race for first place today. The Blues scored a 6 -- 1 victory over the Hawks behind Lorne (Gump) Worsley's fine goaltending in the nationally televised contest.

Dr. George S. Counts, professor emeritus of education of Columbia University, has joined the faculty of the University of Pittsburgh's School of Education as visiting professor. . . . The appointment of Dr. Peter S. Derthick, Commissioner of Education. . . .
A courageous effort that saw him recover from two falls yesterday brought the plucky John Regilly of Mount St. Michael High in the Bronx to the most important victory in his school boy career.
ASPEN, Colo., March 7 -- Bud Werner, the Steamboat Springs (Colo.) express, roared down a sixty-gate course twice today on the Aspen Highlands to gain his second national crown in two days.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service continued last year its role of good customer of the American maritime industry. In 1958, 78 per cent of the service's total of $425,000,000 in incurred operating expenses went to this industry.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 7 -- Bolstered by victories in the mile and two-mile relays, Yale's squad won the twelfth annual Heptagonal Games Association indoor track and field championship today. Over the flat board of Barton Hall on the Cornell University campus, the Elis completed their title bid with 51 7/10 points.

LONDON, March 7--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's visit to the Soviet Union has won widespread approval here. The assessment varies from the "modified success" of the pro-Labor Daily Mirror to the "emphatic success" of the Conservative Yorkshire Post.
New York State is being asked to take a hesitant step toward state-wide branch banking.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Senator Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota called today for full exposure of what he called "bribes and deals" offered to Robert F. Kennedy, chief counsel for the Senate rackets inquiry.

TO the hard-drinking American expatriates who gather daily in the bar of the little hotel in Oxahuitcoatl, Maria Mendoza is only the proud-looking old Mexican woman who helps serve the drinks and speaks no English.
UNION, N. J., March 7 -- The United States could become a second-rate nation without "some real tough thinking" to meet national needs, Senator Harrison A. Williams said here today.

Once again New York is offering residents and visitors an advance look at spring. The forty-second International Flower Show opened yesterday in the New York Coliseum, where it will hold forth until 6 P. M. next Saturday. This is the first eight-day run in the show's history. Hours today are 2 P. M. to 10 P. M.; Monday through Friday, 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

Aase Nordmo Loevberg, Norwegian soprano who made her Metropolitan Opera debut in "Lohengrin" on Feb. 11, took the part of Eva in Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" for the first time at the Met in yesterday afternoon's performance.

TORONTO, March 7 -- The rebellious braves of Grand River -- an Indian reservation that re-established Thursday its tribal system of government by hereditary chiefs and "seceded" from Canada -- laid down a blueprint for economic independence today.

MODERN plastics have opened the way for more home owners to have a decorative fountain, lily pool or fish pond. The job of bringing water to the site (and carrying away overflow, if necessary) now is considerably easier because of the widespread availability of new forms of plastic water pipe and fittings.

ON Tuesday at the Martin Beck, Tennessee Williams will attend the New York premiere of his "Sweet Bird of Youth." On Wednesday his calendar says he is to plan an immediate retreat to Key West to start thinking of his next play,

A part of midtown New York will be turned into a giant toy store this week. The hundreds of thousands of toys that will be displayed are not for the eyes of children or prospective gift givers, but for the trade. Some 15,000 buyers and 1,500 manufacturers of playthings will begin the serious business of filling retail channels for 1959.

In an emergency, blood transfusions may mean the difference between life and death. About 10,000 New Yorkers roll up their sleeves every month to help make sure that blood is available when it is needed.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Come Wednesday, the country will probably be advised that Americans looking for jobs in February were just about as numerous as they were a month earlier.
MONTREAL -- In the average year the snowfall in the Laurentian resort country is sufficient to insure good skiing for most of the month of March. This season the weather has been unusually favorable.

HELSINKI -- Well aware that visitors to their country do not expect to find the type of attractions that are readily available in the more populated parts of Europe, Finnish tourist officials are once again promoting the special charms of their land.
