If some young couples who live in town have been wearing cat-with-canary-inside smiles lately, it may be the result of that news story the other day headlined, "Crazy Couple Clubs Sprouting to Amuse Jaded Suburbanites."

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 8 (Reuters) -In a communique broadcast over the Mosul radio, the Iraqi rebels called on the eldest officers in all army units to take command and be responsible only to the revolutionary command.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 8 (Reuters) -In a communique broadcast over the Mosul radio, the Iraqi rebels called on the eldest officers in all army units to take command and be responsible only to the revolutionary command.

In seven years of poring over cryptic clay tablets, a Staten Island professor has brought to light new details of highly organized communities that existed more than 5,000 years ago on the shores of the Persian Gulf.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Angler Biddle Duke of New York, former diplomat, has been appointed a member of the advisory committee on foreign policy of the Democratic Advisory Council.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 22 -The rapid growth of Brazil's automotive industry has raised the question of who is going to buy the production and how.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) -- The world's population increased by 90,000,000 in 1957-58 and will reach nearly 7,000,000,000 by the year 2000 if present trends continue, a research group reported today.

MLANJE, Nyasaland, March 8 -- Security forces combed the southeastern tip of this British protectorate today in a futile effort to round up about 200 Africans accused of trying to foment a general strike on tea plantations.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 8 -- The president of the International Finance Corporation was in Switzerland last week trying to learn what backing might be had in raising funds for less-developed countries.
Demand for money on the capital market this year is likely to be strongly influenced by the problems of Treasury financing, according to Dr. Roy L. Reierson, chief economist of Bankers Trust Company.

The visit of President Jose Maria Lemus of El Salvador to the United States has some especially pleasant aspects. It gives us a chance to show that the head of the smallest nation in the Western Hemisphere is just as welcome as if he were President of one of the largest.
ASSEMBLYMAN JAMES EUGENE GODDARD began his political career as a "community psychiatrist." He has spent much of the time since then talking instead of listening.
Discovery of an alternative structure for life's basic chemical of heredity has been reported by a biophysicist at California Institute of Technology.
Thomas Richner has been known here in the last few years for his Mozart programs but he let Chopin share half of his recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall

Senator Kenneth B. Keating told 4,000 Masons yesterday that there was a "reasonable" hope of emerging from the Berlin crisis "with the world still at peace," provided this country remained "firm and strong in dealing with the Russians."

FOR many years Larry Adler has been demonstrating that the harmonica is a fullfledged musical instrument and not a toy. But it took television yesterday morning to give a new and intimate insight into the dazzling virtuosity that he brings to the mouth organ.
Fair skies continued to shine on the Flower Show at the Coliseum. Since Saturday, visitors have filled the exhibit's aisles from the minute the doors opened until the closing at 10 P. M.

The New York Shipping Association announced yesterday that it had agreed with the International Longshoremen's Association to continue discussion of the port's "containerization" problem for another month.

IT'S to put the saccharin back in the coffee. After several seasons of flirting with the loose, no-waisted chemise, Paris is once again embracing women around the middle. Nowhere is it more evident than at Bonwit Teller, where fifty French imports ordered by Nona Park and Sophie Shonnard have just arrived.
MOTHER and daughter will look alike this Easter if they dress in new finery from Martin's.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- It was a delightful spring day. The sun beat down from a pale, washed-out blue sky. Beyond the left-field fence the waters of Tampa Bay glistened, the slate gray speckled by white sails.
"The Jewel Box," a play by Ed Kamarck, Professor of Drama at the University of Wisconsin, is being planned for Broadway next season.

The Brooklyn Philharmonia gave the last concert of its fifth season Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Academy. The program was an ambitious one, consisting of Norman Dello Joio's "A Psalm of David" and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

Coexistence as anything more than a temporary expedient is not a term that belongs to Christianity, the Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams said yesterday at the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), Park Avenue at Eighty-fifth Street.
CAIRO, March 8 -- A revolt by some brigades of the Iraqi Army against the pro-Communist regime of Maj. Gen. Abdul Karim Kassim apparently is in progress.

LONDON, March 8 -- Some of the smaller members of the Western alliance are beginning to fear that "flexibility" by the United States and Britain in negotiating European security with the Soviet Union may be wrongly interpreted as softness.
BAMAKO, the Frrench Sudan, March 8 (Reuters) -- Two million voters in the republic of the French Sudan balloted today to elect eighty deputies to a new Legislative Assembly.
A 10 per cent rise in garage rates will go into effect here next month.

AN ENCAMPMENT, Algeria, March 8 -- From the air an observer would discern nothing but pastoral landscape: hills divided by creek beds and grazing grounds; rocks and scrub thickets with, every here and there, tree groves such as the one beneath which these guerrillas are located.
The Transit Authority and two labor groups have agreed to a union representation election for the authority's 31,000 workers by June 15.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Labor's top political directors announced plans today for a coast-to-coast series of meetings to rally union forces for the 1960 election campaign.

The City Council is trying to establish a dangerous precedent by adopting a local law that in effect would make it the boss of city traffic rules instead of placing the authority where it properly belongs -- in the hands of the Traffic Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Democratic leaders of the Senate began to break openly with President Eisenhower today on his policy of cutting the ground forces of the Army and the Marine Corps during the Berlin crisis.
LONDON, March 9 -- Prices continued to fall in the stock market here today, with government securities leading the retreat.
Dartmouth and Princeton each placed two players on the all-Ivy League basketball team, announced yesterday by the Ivy coaches.
The Florida Development Commission is planning to sell $25,000,000 of Dade County road revenue bonds on April 9. Dated Feb 1, 1959, the bonds will come due serially on Feb. 1 from 1963 to 1989.
JERSEY CITY, March 9 -Two union officials were indicted here today on charges of accepting $14,500 in bribes from the personnel director of the C. F. Mueller Company.
Raw steel production rose to a historic high of 2,556,000 net tons last week. It was expected to continue climbing this week, for the seventh consecutive week.

" Can you reach my son?" This plea by a distraught New York mother touched off a nation - wide search to find an airman and bring him home to his dying father. The airman had left Tulsa en route to Seattle.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- Two more Republican members of the Senate rackets committee demanded today that Robert F. Kennedy, committee counsel, disclose the names of witnesses who tried to influence him with offers of political help for his brother.
THANKS to a vivid prologue, "Juno." which opened at the Winter Garden last evening, begins well. It begins with an overwhelming dance, song and dramatic incident.

The Lehman Corporation announced yesterday that its directors had approved a proposal to acquire the Peacock Corporation through an exchange of stock. The action would be subject to the approval of stockholders of Peacock. If approved, the transaction was expected to be concluded on March 23.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (AP) -- Bill Collins of Baltimore posted a two-under-par 70 today and won the $20,000 New Orleans open golf tournament. He had a four-round card of 68-72-70-70 -- 280, Jackie Burke Jr. of Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., who shot a 67 today, and Tom Nieporte of Bronxville, N. Y., tied for the runner-up spot at 283.

Net sales of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. Inc., last year fell 7 per cent to $1,829,249,758 from the 1957 record of $1,964,624,295, the annual report disclosed yesterday. Physical volume of sales was about 6 per cent less.

The blockfront on the west side of Castle Hill Avenue between Homer and Virgil Avenues in the Bronx has been purchased by Raneri Brothers for improvement with one-family homes. The plot, running back 325 feet, was assembled in two parcels through Houlihan-Martocci brokers.
TRENTON, March 9 -- The defense of privilege in libel suits was widened by the New Jersey Supreme Court today.
ST. LOUIS, March 9 (AP) -Bill Gran of Akron took third place in the singles of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a 708 series. Detroit's Ed Lubanski is the leader with 764.

MOST women have a secret vision of how they might look in a beautiful hat. Even the woman who has given up the search for the perfect hat might fulfill this vision at DePinna's. This store's spring collection of European imports and American designs, shown to the press yesterday, has such a diversity of shapes and styles that no woman need ever feel that hats are not flattering to her.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 9 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim's Iraqi Government asserted tonight that the army revolt against his regime had been crushed.
Lack of snow this winter has come fairly close to setting a city record.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, proposed a bill today designed to promote confidence in the integrity of Federal officials.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 9 (AP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that neither the French Government nor the French Line was entitled to exoneration from or limitation of liability in the freighter explosion that set off the 1947 Texas City disaster.
FAIR LAWN, N. J., March 9 -- The Fair Lawn police late this afternoon found the missing superintendent of the garden apartment here that was destroyed in a boiler blast yesterday.
LAPAZ, Bolivia, March 9 -Bolivia is in danger of a monetary collapse that could undermine the continuance of United States financial aid to the present Government on economic grounds.

Recognizing, as we must, the failures of the past to get a cooperative attack, joined by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, upon the problem of the commuter railroads, we nevertheless remain convinced that only by such cooperation will maximum results over the long term be achieved. There was evidence yesterday in the New Jersey Legislature of new desire to revive a common approach to the problem.
WASHINGTON, March 9--Lyndon B. Johnson and his Senate Democratic leadership came under sharp criticism today from two Northern Democrats.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 9 -- Members of the Stamford Junior League will be models in the league's benefit fashion show Wednesday afternoon at 12:30 and 4 P. M. at the Stamford Yacht Club.
There will be a small ripple in the staid atmosphere of the Colony Club on May 13 engendered by the introduction of rousing selections from popular Broadway musicals in a varied program of music.
Eight old BMT subway cars, their vintage disguised by a coat of paint, red plastic seats and brighter lighting, were put into service yesterday on the Brighton Beach line.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -President Eisenhower is expected to act by executive order tomorrow to replace present voluntary curbs on oil imports with a mandatory control system that would slash quotas of major importers up to 20 per cent.

The results of the first round of votes in Paris and the twelve biggest cities of France were just about as expected. New Yorkers do not need to be told today that tax increases and other measures which hit the pocketbook are unpopular with voters.

Historic highs were recorded yesterday by both The New York Times industrial stock average and the combined average of fifty stocks. Industrial bonds, heavily influenced by the convertible issues, made a new high for 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -The Treasury bill rates rose sharply this week in the wake of last Thursday's increase in the Federal Reserve discount rate, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (UPI) -- Terrang, the king of Santa Anita's handicap performers, won the $52,350 San Bernardino Handicap today after surviving a claim of foul.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that the current reorganization of the department's division of medical care had been undertaken on his initiative. He denied a report that it had been ordered by the state Department of Social Welfare.

Col. Harry D. Henshel, an administrator in amateur sport for half a century, yesterday was chosen to receive the Amateur Athletic Union's Gold Medal Award for 1959. The announcement was made by Charles Starke, the president of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 9 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors is expected to approve the acquisition of 450 acres of South Shore beach property for park purposes Thursday.
SAYREVILLE, N. J., March 9 -- B. Frank Samsel is 93 years old and he still runs the general store he opened in this Middlesex community sixty-nine years ago.

The policy of the State Department as reported in The New York Times on Feb. 28 to extend financial and diplomatic support to the Government of Dr. Francois Duvalier of Haiti is incomprehensible. In the light of recent Latin-American and Caribbean developments this support can only raise extremely serious difficulties for the United States in the future.
BORN in Rumania but now assimilated by the School of Paris, Natalia Dumitresco is having her first American exhibition at the Saidenberg Gallery, 10 East Seventy-seventh Street.
WALPOLE, Mass., March 9 (UPI) -- Six convicts, who staged a rebellion Saturday in an attempt to escape Walpole State Prison, were transferred under heavy guard today to the Concord Reformatory.
The Moore-McCormack Line yesterday faced the renewed possibility of a strike by its 450 office workers.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 9 -- For a ball club that blew a world series many folks thought it should have won, the Milwaukee Braves did right well today. In fact, they defeated the world champion Yankees, 9 -- 6, in their first meeting since last October's series.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (MONY) had a net gain of $47,666,172 accruing to policy holders last year, Louis W. Dawson, president, said in his annual report issued yesterday. This compared with $45,605,439 in the previous year.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that the number of cattle in the nation would climb to a new high this year. But it foresaw no overexpansion in the near future.
Pressure mounted yesterday both here and in Albany for approval of Mayor Wagner's plan to legalize and tax offtrack betting on horse races.

The Third Congress of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party opens in Warsaw today and many eyes, inside and outside Poland, will be following that meeting's deliberations. This is the first such congress since Wladyslaw Gomulka took power in October, 1956, and the meeting will provide him a forum at which to account for his stewardship over Communist power in Poland.

After a brief ownership, Joseph L. Steinfeld and Frederick Katzenell, real estate operators, have sold the four-story building at 686 Grand Street, Brooklyn, to a client of Wikler, Gottlieb Wikler, lawyers. Edward Maltz was the broker in the deal, and Jacob S. Linett acted for the sellers. The property is under a long-term lease to John's Bargain Stores.
The New York County Lawyers Association at a meeting of its board of directors yesterday opposed "any attempt to curtail the jurisdiction" of the United States Supreme Court.

NICE, France, March 9 -- For sports excitement, few European cities could have matched this one this past week-end. Yesterday all attendance and receipt records were broken as the Nice Eagles blanked Rheims in soccer.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 9 -Dr. Fazil Kuchuk and Rauf R. Denktash, Turkish Cypriote leaders, have been called to Ankara for discussions with the Turkish Government on the implementation of the London agreement on Cyprus.
The battle against childhood cancer at the Children's Pavilion of Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases will be aided by the annual Easter fashion luncheon on Easter Sunday, March 29.

Following are the conclusions and recommendations made yesterday by a New York County grand jury on the Department of Buildings. Since November, 1957, the panel has been investigating charges of graft and corruption in the department.

WASHINGTON, March 9 --The Supreme Court upheld today the contempt conviction of a New York dress manufacturer who had refused to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating garment industry rackets.

William B. Mischo, general counsel for the International Longshoremen's Association, was barred yesterday from giving testimony on the financial dealings between the labor organization and George A. Brenner.

Two subjects of Queen Elizabeth will meet in Madison Square Garden Friday night under the modernized version of the Marquis of Queensberry rules. The principals are Yama Bahama of Bimini, the Bahamas, and Wilfie Greaves of Edmonton, Alberta.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., March 9 -- The general assumptions which regularly emerge from any discussion of politics in this part of Texas are that: Senator Lyndon B. Johnson is receptive to the Democratic nomination for President in 1960; he will be nominated; and he will be elected.
Mayor Wagner denied yesterday that he had instructed city assessors to raise the assessed valuations on one- and twofamily homes to help bail the city out of its financial dilemma.

BECAUSE the New York City Handel Festival is planned to cover all aspects of the composer's output, a half dozen of its events will be devoted to chamber music. The first of the chamber music concerts was given last night at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Harpsichord Music Society, which is one of the more than thirty musical organizations participating in the festival.
BOSTON, March 9 -- Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston came to the defense today of one of the most prominent members of his archdiocese, Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Leaders of railroad labor and management are to discuss a possible request that a Presidential commission be created to study and recommend a modernization program in railroad work practices.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 9 -- Maurice van Hemelrijck, Belgian Minister for the Congo, will fly to Leopoldville tomorrow to seek a working arrangement with the Abako, a tribal group that was declared illegal after the riots there in January.

WHITE PLAINS, March 9 -The omnibus banking bill that would permit New York City banks to operate in Westchester was seen today by the County Board of Supervisors as an ominous and symbolic attack on suburban home rule.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -Administration officials expressed fear today that the anti-Government uprising in northern Iraq might serve as a pretext for far-reaching Soviet penetration of that country.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator and builder, has purchased 668 to 674 Lexington Avenue and 132-34 East Fifty-sixth Street, the southwest corner, from the Berwick Land Corporation, which owned the property since 1947.
Four bandits armed with two machine guns, a rifle and an automatic pistol held up a bank in Massapequa, L. I., yesterday afternoon and escaped with an estimated total of $75,000.
March, May and July cotton futures advanced 12 to 14 points (60 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday. The rest of the list declined 6 to 8 points (30 to 40 cents a bale).

FOR several years now, it hasn't been easy to interest New York women in a new spring coat. For one thing, spring as such just doesn't seem to exist here anymore. It's either too cold, too hot or too rainy.
News of the Army revolt in Iraq strengthened several commodities yesterday on the New York exchanges.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The net income of class I railroads in January was estimated by the Association of American Railroads today at $22,000,000. This compared with $18,000,000 in January, 1958.
CAIRO, March 9 -- The two young officers who led to Iraqi Army rebellion against the Government and their commander in chief are well known in Iraq, if not outside the country.
The 191 tiny stockholders in the General Electric Company, who have owned their shares from birth, made a good investment by being born on Oct. 15, 1953.

Steve Nagy, a number of other fine bowlers and some not so fine spent a chilly evening in Chicago that Nagy remembers well. A cold night in the Windy City isn't unusual. However, this night was spent indoors.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 9 (AP) -- Crowds danced, clapped and sang in the streets of Baghdad today after the Government announced that the insurrection in northern Iraq had been suppressed. The demonstrations went on into the night.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -Republicans and Democrats on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee split along party lines today on the issue of what is needed for the American economy in 1959.
The New England town meeting holds a place in the affections of this nation that is on the rarefied level of Plymouth Rock, the Declaration of Independence and Lincoln's letter to Mrs. Bixby.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Robert S. Stevenson, the president of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, advised commercial bankers today to change their basis for deciding when to lend to business and industry and to increase their installment lending in this area.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Rockefeller moved today to restore Bayard F. Pope, New York City banker, to the Port of New York Authority.

ST. LOUIS, March 9 (AP) -Matthew J. Connelly and T. Lamar Caudle, both former Truman Administration officials, were granted permission today to remain at liberty while they appeal a court decision that denied them a new trial.
MADRID, March 9 -- The Spanish Government has cracked down on 369 Spanish citizens found guilty of having maintained unauthorized deposits in Swiss banks.
WARSAW, March 9 -- Erich Koch, one of Hitler's chief lieutenants, was sentenced to death today by a Polish court.
THOSE striped bass are still hanging around in New Jersey's Great Bay and some of them are even in the Mullica River, but nobody has been able to catch any of them yet.

DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -Sharp production increases by Chrysler's Plymouth and Dodge divisions have advanced the industry's assembly pace. The two divisions were among the principal sufferers from the glass shortage that hampered Chrysler operations in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles had another X-ray treatment for cancer today. He also had a thirty-five minute talk with President Eisenhower and a twenty-five minute telephone conversation with a State Department aide.
CAIRO, March 9 (UPI) -- The Italian Davis Cup star, Nicola Pietrangeli, and the other favorites advanced today in the second round of the men's singles in the tennis tournament here.

Dolores Wilson, who made her first Metropolitan Opera appearance of the season last night in the title role of "Lucia di Lammermoor," had customers sitting on the edge of their chairs. They were wondering whether she would get through the performance.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 9 (AP) -- Herb Elliott, the world's fastest miler, won an invitation event at Olympic Park today in 4 minutes 4.1 seconds. He finished twenty-eight yards ahead of California's Don Bowden, who was fourth.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that the Pennsylvania and Santa Fe Railroads could acquire joint control of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad.
TRENTON, March 9 -- Political activities in the state capital here were interrupted briefly today by a one-man show of oils and water-colors at the State Museum.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Senate gave final approval tonight to a bill creating six new district court judgeships for Nassau County. The bill now goes to the Governor for consideration.
For a few hours on March 19 boxholders attending the Anniversary Ball of the Year can imagine themselves staying in their favorite Italian city or province.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens, introduced legislation in the House of Representatives today that would pay a Federal bounty for the conviction of narcotics peddlers.

JAKARTA, March 9 -- The president of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company said today that the company was prepared to make new capital investments in oil business in Indonesia if the Government would grant its eleven-year-old request for new exploration concessions.
Net income of the Phelps Dodge Corporation dropped 16 per cent last year as the company's production of copper fell to the lowest level in years.

PINE HILL, N. Y., March 9 -- Next to the Irish sweepstakes and Russian roulette, the biggest gamble probably is the operation of a ski center. Too little snow and the skiing fanatics will stay away; too much snow and they can't get there.

The Senate rackets committee held a closed hearing here yesterday on the system of newspaper and magazine delivery in the metropolitan area.
A new ACF Industries, Inc., plan for leasing freight cars to American railroads came to fruition yesterday.

A cruise ship that had visited three Soviet ports was searched thoroughly for radioactivity yesterday by a large force of Coast Guardsmen and Customs inspectors. Nothing suspicious was found, the Coast Guard reported.
BERLIN, March 9 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union suggested today that West Berlin might be garrisoned by Big Four or neutral troops if it became a free city.

LONDON, March 9 -- The Admiralty announced today an agreement providing United States power and training for Britain's first nuclear submarine. It foresaw, too, the prospect that one day all navies might be both nuclear-powered and "very largely submersible."
The skills that once made Jimmy Slade a "spoiler" have departed with age and too little work.

YOU know how people like to ask for a traveler's main impressions of some faraway place. Well, one of the strongest points made in Robert Trumbull's new book, "Paradise in Trust: A Report on Americans in Micronesia -- 1946-58,"* is that the roadways are generally terrible on those star-scattered islands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Ryan Garrick, 23-year-old newcomer from Beaver Falls, Pa., has been signed to a term contract by Columbia and will make his screen debut in "The Battle of the Coral Sea."

A 50 per cent interest in the W. T. Grant Building, known also as 1441 Broadway and 575 Seventh Avenue, has been acquired by Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman, realty investors, from clients of Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt Mosle.

TAMPA, Fla., March 9 -- "I hate to put a 20-year-old kid on the spot," said Senor Alfonso Ramon Lopez, the managerial grandee, in his courtly fashion, "but we're depending an awful lot on Johnny Callison coming through for us. If he misses, you lose confidence in everything. Yet I can't see how he can miss."
CAIRO, March 9 -- The first clash between Government troops and rebellious Army units in Iraq was reported today from rebel headquarters in Mosul.
TRENTON, March 9 -- The Assembly moved today to achieve a mutually acceptable agreement with the New York Legislature on transit district legislation.

PARIS, March 9 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's proposal to put a free city of West Berlin under neutral or four-power security garrisons was foreshadowed in his recent talks with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain.

GENEVA, March 9 -- A new international wheat agreement was approved here today by the United Nations Conference of Exporters and Importers. The conference of fifty nations has been meeting in secret here for six weeks. The conference will hold its last formal meeting tomorrow morning.

Cuba's Premier Fidel Castro is the subject of at least two books to be published this year. Bobbs-Merrill has scheduled for publication later this year, "Fidel Castro: Rebel -- Liberator -- Dictator?" by Jules Dubois, a biography and an evaluation of the Cuban leader.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- William Denman, retired Chief Judge of the Ninth United States Circuit Court of Appeals, was found shot to death tonight in his bedroom in his home. The police said it was an apparent suicide.
A New York builder who tried to buy Ellis Island last year has now more than tripled his bid for the surplus Government property, on which he wants to build an elaborate resort.
PARIS, March 9 -- The nonCommunist press and political leaders called today for a joining of "Republican" forces to stop the Communists.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt declared today that the KennedyErvin labor control bill "leaves many gaping loopholes for abuse by conniving and corrupt union officials."
The Hospital Council of Greater New York predicted yesterday that hospital costs would increase in the near future even more than they had in the past.
The Flower Show at the Coliseum continues to supply a breath of spring to visitors. It will be open until Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -Ulysses S. Grant once declined to have a bed put up for him in the billiard room of Decatur House, a letter turned over today to the Library of Congress disclosed.
The resignation of Thomas Bradshaw as president and a director of the International Railways of Central America was announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders.
Textile mills have long had the problem of removing waste fibers in making combed cotton yarns. These are the short fibers that are not wanted in percales, broadcloths and other quality fabrics.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Rockefeller's income tax program was assured tonight the votes needed for Assembly approval. Senate passage previously had been pledged.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor plans to retire June 30 unless the Administration has additional active duty in mind for the Army Chief of Staff.
GENEVA, March 9 -- The United States called today for periodic reviews of the proposed system for controlling a ban on nuclear weapon testing.
We applaud the fact that The Times has spoken out in favor of unemployment insurance coverage for employes of nonprofit agencies.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 9 -- Tickets for "Redhead" are still available for a theatre party next Monday evening which is being sponsored by the Westchester Pleasantville League, Inc.

Heavy attendance, sizable shopping and sampling and good business were reported yesterday at the opening of the American Toy Fair. The event, sponsored by the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., will run through Saturday at the Sheraton - McAlpin and New New Yorker Hotels and in permanent show rooms maintained by manufacturers in the city.
HARLAN, Ky., March 9 (AP) -- A United Mine Workers' strike closed twenty-six Harlan County coal mines today.
The Board of Education proudly showed off one of its new schools yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -The director general of the International Atomic Energy Association complained today that neglect of the nuclear powers to cooperate fully had hampered the development of the atomsfor-peace program.

LONDON, March 9 -- The Foreign Office said today that the Government had not replied to a request from Guy Burgess for a guarantee that he be allowed to return to Moscow if he came here to visit his mother.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -The Department of Agriculture announced today that the Government's "investment" in farm price-support programs climbed over the $9,000,000,000 mark as of Jan. 31.
A 3-month-old girl, the smallest of five young children left alone in a Harlem apartment, died yesterday afternoon in a fire of undetermined origin.

Six leading basketball teams from the East and South will compete in a triple-header at Madison Square Garden tonight in the first round of the Eastern regionals of the National Collegiate championship.

Ten American concert artists have chosen ten American composers to write works for them to play or sing with symphony orchestras. Ford Foundation grants totaling $130,000 will provide funds for the project.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Jackson of Chicago, president of the National Baptist Convention, U. S. A., said yesterday that a return to religious principles was the "greatest need" in the modern world.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -The latest suggestion by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on Berlin found no favorable response in this capital today.

Forty-seven known or suspected policy operators and bookmakers were arrested in Manhattan yesterday as a direct result of the increasing investigations into the financial affairs of Joseph Luberda, a retired police sergeant.

Senator John L. McClellan last night accused the United States Supreme Court of an "instability" that "threatens the very foundations of our republic."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's rugged, hard-checking ice hockey team trounced the United States by 5 -- 1 today in the opening round of the final series for the world amateur championship.

ATHENS, March 9 -- The 1959 budget was presented to the Chamber of Deputies today. It calls for a growing program of industry, agriculture, expansion of electric power, the bulding of roads and improvement in communications.

The number of cumulative preferred stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange with dividend arrearages dropped sharply in 1958. This was reported yesterday by the Big Board in its official magazine, the "Exchange."

The top company in the former financial empire of Alexander L. Guterma was represented yesterday by its new chairman, Hal Roach Jr., as solvent with "substantial net worth." Mr. Roach strongly opposed a Securities and Exchange Commission application for receivership.
The Kedroff Vocal Quartet, which gave a concert last night at Town Hall, first appeared in this country more than thirty years ago.

It is easy to imagine how we would all feel if a great new nation, with an entirely new population of, let us say, ninety millions, were to appear on the face of the earth. Yet this is approximately what happened in the two years 1957 and 1958, as reported by the Population Reference Bureau, Inc. This rate of increase rests on an annual world population growth of about 1.6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -A bill to set up a $2,000,000,000 revolving fund for low-interest loans to builders of private housing for middle-income families was introduced in the Senate today.
Lit Brothers of Philadelphia and the A. W. Lucas Company of Bismarck, N. D., were named yesterday as "Retailers of the Year" in two department store categories.

A letter to the editor of The New York Times by Richard Robbins, printed in your issue of March 4, has been called to my attention. It is a thoughtful and cogent statement of the undesirability of replacing the rigid national origins quota system in our immigration policy with merely a blood relationship formula.
EAST MORICHES, L. I., March 9 -- Four young persons returning from a movie were killed early today when their small foreign car crashed head-on into a tree.

TOKYO, March 5 -- The refusal of the North Korean Government to accept the International Committee of the Red Cross as an agency for repatriation of Koreans in Japan has raised new complictions in this already complex issue here.

KHARTOUM, The Sudan, March 9 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. Ahmed Abdel Wahab, a key figure in the Sudan's newly constituted Supreme Military Council, was dropped from all his duties today as the council was sworn in.
MOSCOW, March 9--The Soviet Government called for volunteers tonight for new "peoples' brigades" to police the behavior of their fellow citizens in all public places.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider a suit by Negroes to force the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen to drop racial restrictions and admit them to membership.
CAIRO, March 9 -- The dismissal of General Wahab in the Sudan is said here to indicate a swing toward Cairo.
Thousands of Manhattanbound commuters were delayed up to twenty-five minutes on the Long Island Rail Road yesterday morning by a faulty signal.
LONDON, March 9 -- For the first time in 200 years there were no lights in "The Elephant" tonight and thirsty Cockneys went elsewhere for their pint of beer or "slice" of gin.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -The Iraqi uprising imparted some strength to grain futures today and there were fairly active dealings on the Board of Trade.
The bond market still was unsettled yesterday as a result of last week's increase in Federal Reserve Bank lending rates from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent.
Antonino Rocca and Miguel Perez, who always seem to win, won another professional tagteam wrestling match last night at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 19,990 paid $60,738 to see the show.

MIKE WALLACE, who has not been overly active in television this season, appears bent on making up for lost time. Last night he began two programs, which are to be seen Monday through Friday evening over Channel 13. By way of marking his new association with the station, he is also doing a few additional ninety-minute stints this week.

Two members of Robert Whitehead's production staff, Oscar Olesen (general manager) and Lewis Allen (play-reader), are planning to join the managerial ranks. While continuing their affiliation with Mr. Whitehead, the team is preparing "A Sound of Distant Thunder," formerly called "Deadlock."

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 4 -- Jamaica's economic development program has become an indirect issue in the boisterous political campaign under way here for general elections at a date still to be announced.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A painting showing Abraham Lincoln in a white nightshirt was unveiled today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower has given exercise-minded members of his staff permission to put the old White House tennis court back into use.
May I refer to a paragraph of your obituary of the late Ambassador of Yugoslavia, Constantin Fotitch, in The Times of Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that employer contributions to welfare funds negotiated by collective bargaining were not entitled to the same priority as wages in bankruptcy proceedings.
The departure of American Airlines from Lennen Newell, Inc., caused a buzz on Madison Avenue yesterday.
The city's sturdy firemen walked to new heights last night.
Along came this good letter the other day from a youngster who wanted to know about high school basketball in New York in the Nineteen Twenties.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a case posing the question whether United States citizens lose their citizenship if they leave the country in war time to avoid military service.

MILWAUKEE, March 9 (AP) -- Ireland's Ron Delany, who set a world indoor record of 4:01.4 forty-eight hours ago, scored a four-yard victory over Istvan Rozsavolgyi in the Journal Mile at 4:05.4 tonight. Both runners narrowly missed disqualification.

FLEMINGTON, a small, quiet town in western New Jersey, is known as the home of Stangl pottery and the scene of the Lindbergh kidnap trial. Situated there, too, is the Flemington Auction Market Cooperative, where many of the eggs New Yorkers eat for breakfast have been scrupulously candled, sized and packed in the familiar, twelve-compartment cartons.
The National Broadcasting Company apparently intends to move Steve Allen's television show out of its Sunday evening schedule and into an hour on another day next fall.
RANGOON, March 10 -- Communist and other insurgent groups are a steadily diminishing force in Burma.

CHERUBINI's "Medea" is a glorious opera -- classic in breadth, noble in spirit and searing in power. The American Opera Society is lucky to have what amounts to exclusive local rights to it, since the other opera companies keep neglecting it.
ROME, March 10 -- The Communist party opened a drive for a popular front in Italy today.
KINGSTON, N. Y., March 10 (AP) -- An executive of a New Jersey road oil concern was indicted today on charges of offering bribes to town highway superintendents of eleven Ulster County towns.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Gardner C. Means, the economist whose theories on "administered price" inflation have caught the attention of some powerful Congressmen, returned to the attack today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) to 4 points (20 cents), off yesterday after holding in a narrow range all day.
The sports car rally season never ends. It slackens a bit in the severe winter months when only those hardy souls who like ice and snow and ear muff venture forth.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower imposed mandatory controls on all petroleum imports today.
The city school system, whose evening teachers recently ended a month-long walkout, may be headed for new troubles -- this time involving the day teachers.
LONDON, March 10 -- The British Government voiced fears today that African nationalist agitation would spread from Nyasaland to the neighboring protectorate of Northern Rhodesia.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Leo Biagetti, a St. Paul, Minn., pro, carded a 5under-par 67 today and led the qualifying round for the Pensacola open golf tournament. He was one of 119 golfers competing for the seventy-nine spots in the $15,000 open, which will start Thursday.

A new management has taken over the operations of TMT Trailer Ferry, Inc., following approval of a reorganization plan by the Federal District Court in Miami, according to an announcement made by the company yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- The Senate Interior Committee approved today the nominations of Elmer F. Bennett to be Under Secretary of the Interior and George W. Abbott to be solicitor of the Interior Department.
The city joined yesterday the procession of prospective employers who are shopping early for June college graduates.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 9 -- "Poor old Trotsky," said the Prime Minister of Ceylon. "His unhappy ghost seems to have found its only refuge in this country."
The real estate license of Banton L. Wyckoff has been suspended.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Harry Bridges, head of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, has been subpoenaed to appear before the House Committee on Un-American Activities on March 24.

THE woman who owns a mink coat as long as a blanket might feel overdressed this spring. New furs make much of brief jackets, small shrugs and dainty capelets. The ubiquitous stole, trimmed down a little, is still an American fixture.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 10 -- A new salary schedule that permits some public school teachers to receive $13,000 a year was adopted today by the Board of Education of Scarsdale District 1. The scale is one of the highest in the nation.
TRENTON, March 10 -- Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court took an Assistant Prosecutor to task today for his handling of a stock fraud trial and ordered the case retried.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10 -- The riding sensation here at Turf Paradise, a picturesque mile track in the middle of the desert, is Hugo Dittfach.
BERLIN, March 10 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union opened bilateral talks on Berlin with his East German allies today and announced "agreement in all things" four hours later.
WEMBLEY, England, March 10 (UPI) -- A Welsh heavyweight, Dick Richardson, gained a ten-round decision over Bert Whitehurst of Baltimore in a bout at the Empire Pool tonight.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- The Yankees are still having a time impressing their importance as world champions on the Braves.

Harrison E. Salisbury's three articles about the commuter situation were a great service to New Yorkers in representing this serious danger to the survival of metropolitan centers, and in suggesting possible solutions.

STILL possessed of the demons, Tennessee Williams has written another vivid play. "Sweet Bird of Youth" he calls it with ironic pity. Under Elia Kazan's direction it is brilliantly acted at the Martin Beck, where it opened last evening.
The Deepwater Officers Association has won the representation rights to the seventy-five engineer officers employed in the tanker fleet of the Cities Service Oil Company.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Senate approved unanimously today a bill to require registered vessels to pay pilot fees while navigating the Hudson River between Yonkers and Troy. The bill now goes to the Assembly for consideration.

BLANTYRE,Nyasaland,March 10 -- The Rhodesian Air Force dropped food and medical suplies today to troops combating roadblocks and arsonists in the malarial northern region of Nyasaland. The area has been a scene of strife in the campaign for African nationalism.
CAIRO, March 10 -- Iraqi Air Force planes were reported tonight to have strafed and bombed a village three miles inside the Syrian frontier.
The Budd Company sold its 94,000-share interest in Solar Aircraft Company yesterday to Fairbanks, Morse Co. in a single-block transaction on the New York Stock Exchange at $20 a share.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy appeared for more than two hours yesterday before a New York County grand jury investigating relief chiseling.

GROTON, Conn., March 10 (AP) -- The Navy's newest atomic submarine, the Skipjack, returned today from two days of sea trials, during which she attained the highest speed of any United States submarine.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 10 -- Pakistan's President Mohammed Ayub Khan promulgated a decree today giving him arbitrary power to suspend, dismiss or compulsorily retire or otherwise punish corrupt or inefficient government employes.
An influential group of upstate bankers has proposed that upstate banks be permitted to join in new holding companies with any but the three largest New York City banks.

PITTSBURGH, March 11 (UPI) -- A bus swerved into a crowd of commuters waiting at a street car stop in downtown Pittsburgh at the height of the rush hour this evening, killing two persons and injuring fifteen.
Generosity cost a pet shop owner $25 yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- President Jose Maria Lemus of El Salvador was greeted by President Eisenhower and a twenty-one-gun salute today on his arrival here for a three-day state visit.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Times of London has just published a twenty-page supplement on "Britain's food." It contains twenty-four articles that show Britain as an imaginative producer and an eager consumer.
Sales of the Boeing Airplane Company increased last year to $1,711,929,576 from $1,596,508,515 in 1957, but earnings declined the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.
POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., March 10 -- Mount Pleasant town officials reported today that contractors had begun work for the Rockefeller family that would cost $380,000.
NEWARK, March 10 -- Essex County Republicans will enter rival slates in the April 21 primary, it was indicated today.

LONDON, March 10 -- A British concern of bankers and bullion merchants estimated today that the Soviet Union had sold about 6,000,000 ounces of gold last year. This compared with sales of 7,500,000 ounces in 1957, the record year for these sales, and 4,300,000 in 1956.

PARIS, March 10 -- French and British leaders concluded today two days of talks on East-West relations in substantial agreement on immediate tactics. There were some significant gaps in their thinking on long-term strategy, however.
The New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers will hold its seventeenth annual Metropolitan Appraisal Conference at the Astor Hotel on March 20.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -Wheat futures led the setbacks in a mostly weak grain futures market today, with the old-crop contracts giving up all the broad advances of the previous session on the Board of Trade.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 10 -- Turkish Cypriote leaders disclosed plans today to get more Turks in the newly independent Cyprus into business and industry.
The managing director of the Shelton Towers Hotel, an ex-convict, was named yesterday as the mastermind of loan frauds laid to former Westchester Judge George A. Brenner.
ALBANY, March 10 (UPI) -Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
RANGOON, Burma, March 9 -- One of the achievements of the Burmese regime of Gen. Ne Win has been a clean-up of illegal business operators.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 10 -- This bustling Israeli business and cultural hub inaugurated its jubilee year today.
The New York Rangers will be out to increase their Stanley Cup play-off chances tonight when they skate against the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

GENEVA, March 10 -- The United Nation's wheat conference has concluded a new three-year international agreement to It will be opened for signature replace the one expiring July 31, in Washington from April 6 to 24.
The Transit Authority is considering accepting subway tokens for bus fares.

Major sales finance companies yesterday increased by 1/4 of 1 percentage point the yields on their short-term obligtions sold directly to investors. The move was the latest in a series of short-term rate increases that followed on the heels of last week's increase from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent in the Federal Reserve discount rate.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The text of President Eisenhower's statement in ordering mandatory controls on oil imports follows:
ANN COX, who showed her spring-into-summer fashion collection yesterday, believes there is no such thing as "old ladies' clothes" and that good design and simplicity of cut are right for all ages.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate authorized $48,354,000 today to expand the nation's space research program and to accelerate efforts to place man in space.

Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman announced an agreement yesterday by which three more directors with special powers will join the F. L. Jacobs Company. On its part, the Securities and Exchange Commission withdrew an application for receivership of the company, which formerly was controlled by Alexander L. Guterma.
BERLIN, March 10 -- Mayor Brandt rejected today the proposal by Premier Khrushchev that Soviet troops be stationed alongside Western forces in a free city of West Berlin.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller scored a major political victory today with the collapse of Republican Assembly opposition to his income tax increase plan.
MONTREAL, March 9 (Canadian Press) -- Despite lower net income, 1958 was a year of solid achievement for the Canadian Pacific Railway, N. R. Crump, president, said today in the annual report.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate rackets committee today dismissed the political "threats" and "deals" offered to its counsel as unworthy of the public attention that they had received.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Democrats have built an impressive case against cutting the Army and the Marines in the middle of the Berlin crisis, but in the end, President Eisenhower will have the last word.

The Shell Chemical Corporation has started producing a man-made duplicate of tree-grown rubber at prices competitive with the natural variety. And the United States Rubber Company has become the first to use the "synthetic natural rubber" in commercial production of truck tires.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 10 -- On the day spring training opened for the Detroit Tigers, a wandering writer entered the clubhouse. He instantly sensed a marked difference in attitude.
NEWARK, March 10 -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today approved an examiner's report recommending cuts in schedules of trains operated by the Erie Railroad.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Six House committees spent close to $100,000 last year in foreign money owned by the United States.
Robert E. Barnes, a contender for the Queens Borough Presidency, offered a program last night for "saving" New York City from an "accelerating flight into bankruptcy."

WHEN Ruth Whiting came home that early autumn evening she arrived just in time to see her 18-year-old daughter, Angela, ride off with an Oxford student on the back of his Vespa. That might seem like the obvious beginning of Ruth's troubles, but she knew in her heart that they had begun long before that, with her own imperatively hasty marriage to Rex when she was not much older than Angela.
Major railroads in the nation moved yesterday to meet competition from the St. Lawrence Seaway by reducing rates on export grain shipments.
A new attempt to bring commercial television to France is being made by certain advertising interests there.

Bradley, University of Peoria, Ill., yesterday was named to compete in Madison Square Garden's National Invitation Tournament and the Braves' quintet was seeded No. 1. Bradley's selection completed the twelve-team field for the tourney, which opens tomorrow.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 10 (UPI) -- The United States, with Bill Cleary of Cambridge, Mass., scoring three goals, trounced Sweden, 7-1, tonight at the world amateur ice hockey tournament.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- There apears to be a reawakening of Hollywood interest in the writing of John O'Hara.

President Eisenhower told a friend in a letter a year ago that he favored a new Cabinet post to be called "The First Secretary of the Government." His choice for the job was John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State.

LONDON, March 10 -- The stock market shook off its mild despondency of yesterday. Small gains predominated among the principal sections. Selling contracted and a little demand was enough to put a few pence on most of the textile, tobacco, engineering, motor, aircraft and oil stocks.
Television teaching won support in a comparison with standard classroom instruction yesterday by a group of Russian-language students.
PARIS, March 10 -- Popular fronts uniting the Communists with other, normally hostile Leftist groups have sprung up in scattered localities in France during the last twenty-four hours.
Considerable reassurance returned to the bond market yesterday as institutional investors resumed buying of long-term Treasury bonds of post-war issue, especially the new 4s of 1980.
A 3-year-old boy was killed in a fire in his Staten Island home yesterday despite his mother's efforts to save him.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city's third annual World Trade Fair designed to stimulate trade between the United States and foreign countries, would be held at the Coliseum May 8 through May 19.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In a surprise move the Hawaiian statehood bill was scheduled today for Senate consideration tomorrow.
Stocks moved unevenly yesterday in a market in which oils, metals and steels made consistent advances.
The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau melted the snow from its thoughts yesterday by choosing Charlene Hargrove as its Summer Festival Queen.

Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield called on business leaders yesterday to support a balanced national budget and a bold anti-inflation program, a fairer tax system and legislation to crush "union monopolists."

A referee's recommendation that would in effect return working control of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., to the Alleghany Corporation was approved yesterday by New York State Supreme Court Judge Owen McGivern.

New York City borrowed $26,340,000 yesterday on serial bonds to finance school construction and other capital outlays. The cost to the city was 3.174 per cent, just about the same paid on $32,800,000 of new bonds it sold last November.

The Babcock Wilcox Company cleared $13,035,310 on last year's operations. This was equal to $2.13 a share on 6,122,093 shares outstanding, M. Nielsen, president, reported. Net income for 1957 was $14,205,949, or $2.32 a share.
The Chrysler Corporation has a small car "ready to release for production," L. I., Colbert, president, said yesterday.

Your editorial of March 7 "Unions for Hospital Workers?" is of grave concern to those of us who are intimately familiar with the complexities of the day-to-day operations of our voluntary hospitals. You raise four specific points which deserve immediate answer.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 10 -- A poll of locals of the International Typographical Union is under way to get sentiment on the establishment of a daily newspaper in Westchester County to be operated by the printers.

Before leaving for the West Coast last Sunday, H. C. Potter let it be known that he would be back next month to establish a New York producing office. Exercising the traditional reticence of the Broadway showman, Mr. Potter would only say that his first venture next season would be a new script by a Hollywood scenarist.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 10 (AP) -- Premier Kassim's Government appears to have smashed the revolt in northern Iraq.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 10 -- Walter Eytan, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, protested today to the Rumanian Minister in Tel Aviv, Dr. Petro Manu, against the expulsion from Bucharest of an Israeli attache, Amnon Keren.

A realignment of top executives of Loew's Theatres, Inc., was announced yesterday. The company, which operates a chain of motion picture theatres, has been a subsidiary of Loew's, Inc., motion picture producer.

New York's Constitution and its statutory framework always assume that the state's wisdom is infinite. This papa-knows-best philosophy of government was never better illustrated than by the bill, just passed by the Legislature, that permits New York City to increase the charge for performing a civil wedding in the City Clerk's office from $2 to $3.
BROADBEACH, Australia, March 10 (AP) -- Both the United States and the Soviet Union promised continued help today in the development of Asian countries.
Helped by a rising stock market, two new issues of convertible securities were bid up to premium prices by investors yesterday.
Ten rebellious police plainclothes men took legal steps yesterday to thwart official inquiries into their possible relations with gamblers.
MOSCOW, March 10 -- Soviet policy-makers seem to believe that Bonn is the tail that is wagging the Western dog these days.
TORONTO, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- Algom Uranium Mines, Ltd., has received $16,500,000 from the exercise of warrants for the purchase of its common stock, the company has announced.

Central and South West Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in operating revenues and net income during 1958. John S. Osborne, president, said that operating revenues increased about 7 per cent during the year, despite decreased activity in the heavy industrial field, strict proration of oil production and unfavorable weather conditions.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 10 -- Twenty young women will be honored at the Stamford Junior League's third annual Debutante Ball on June 20 at the Stamford Yacht Club.

BOSTON, March 10 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers built up a big first half lead and coasted to a 138-116 victory over the crippled Boston Celtics tonight in the finale of the regular National Basketball Association schedule. Richie Guerin and Kenny Sears led the New York attack with 22 points each.
WARSAW, March 10 -- Poland's Communist leader told Communists from forty-two countries today that Soviet intercontinental missiles had "bankrupted" Western policy.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Basic changes in the bill designed to promote international medical research were asked today by the Eisenhower Administration. They drew immediate objections from the bill's supporters.
People get quite chatty over a garden fence. And so it is at the Flower Show in the Coliseum.

A New York County Grand Jury has found, after prolonged investigation, that in what is now called the Department of Buildings "essential services were administered in a completely disorganized, if not chaotic, manner." This led to "improper and corrupt practices."

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- Bill Veeck bought a majority interest in the Chicago White Sox today, twenty-one days ahead of schedule. He immediately sought peace with Chuck Comiskey, the club's minority stockholder and vice president.
Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, president of the American Red Cross, said yesterday that the free world would more than hold its own in any test of strength with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Henry J. Friendly of New York was nominated by President Eisenhower today to fill the year-old vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
LOCAL premieres of two contemporary American works were features of the second of two Tuesday evening concerts given by the New York Woodwind Quintet last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

WHEN Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter was a professor at the Harvard Law School, he selected graduating students to serve as law clerks to several Supreme Court justices. In 1927 he sent Henry Jacob Friendly to the late Justice Louis D. Brandeis.
BONN, March 10 -- Herr Ollenhauer told Mr. Khrushchev yesterday that Soviet proposals for Germany and West Berlin were just as unacceptable to his Opposition party as to the West German Government.

GENEVA, March 10 -- The United States proposed today that the duration of the proposed treaty on banning tests of nuclear weapons be conditioned only by the observance of its obligations by all signatories.

A record of $329,766,601 in premiums was written by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, Boston, last year, S. Bruce Black, chairman, reported yesterday. This was $24,929,393 more than the 1957 total.
Blood will be given to the New York regional Red Cross blood program today at The New York Times, 229 West Forty-third Street, and the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., 150 East Forty-second Street.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed Bernard Katzen, New York attorney with long experience in official positions, to the State Commission Against Discrimination. The salary is $15,000.

Do you know how to take care of a new baby or a sick member of your family? You will if you take a Red Cross home - nursing course. Six thousand expectant mothers -- and fathers -- took the free Red Cross Mother and Baby Care courses offered last year throughout New York City.

The Democratic Advisory Council, at a meeting held some weeks ago, issued a policy statement that described "The Democratic Task During the Next Two Years" largely in terms of more Federal spending and subsidizing.

MUROC, Calif., March 10 -The plane designed to carry a man into space took to the air today for the first time. It is a hybrid of aircraft and rocket dubbed the X-15. It was carried aloft from Edwards Air Force Base slung under the right wing of an eight-jet B-52.
Pope John XXIII is the subject of two biographical studies by priests who teach at Seton Hall University.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that it had successfully tested miniature atomic devices with an explosive force of only a few tons of TNT.
A major phase of the thirty-eight-day strike in bakeries here is now settled, according to Benjamin H. Wolf, a state mediator.
WHEN Henri Matisse saw a film showing him at work in 1946, he made a discovery about himself.

The nomination of Henry J. Friendly to be Judge of the Second Circuit of the Federal Court of Appeals, which embraces New York, Connecticut and Vermont, is well-merited recognition of his outstanding qualifications for the post. Our congratulations go to him and also to Attorney General Rogers and the President, who recommended and selected him.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- A jet-powered Snark, destined to be the nation's first operational intercontinental-range missile, returned to the Cape without a scratch today after completing a highly successful round-trip ocean flight.

MONASTIR, Tunisia, March 10 -- The Arab world, now seething with nationalist revolutions, has so far produced only one genuinely democratic leader, selected by democratic processes and advocating Western ideologies. This man is Habib Bourguiba, President of the fledgling Tunisian Republic, powerful orator and fervent enemy of both Khrushchev and Nasser.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The A. F. L.-C. I. O. hung an "anti-labor" tag today on President Eisenhower's union-management legislation. It said it failed to deal with management abuses and was designed to impede practical Congressional action.
The Ford Foundation will subsidize, at an expense of $110,000, the producti0n of eight American plays.

Brandeis University offered a Performing Arts Festival at Hunter College Auditorium last night. The event was presented by faculty and students of the university under the direction of Robert Lincoln Koff, director of Performing Activities in Music.
A resolution supporting the United States Supreme Court was unanimously adopted last night by a membership meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The revolt in northern Iraq has destroyed hopes of reconciliation between President Nasser and Premier Kassim of Iraq, in the view of diplomats dealing with the Middle East.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 10 (AP) -- Santa Anita winds up its twenty-second winter racing season tomorrow on an international note.

Navy pulled away with an upset victory over North Carolina in the first round of the Eastern regionals of the National Collegiate basketball championship last night. The midshipmen beat the favored Tar Heels by 76 to 63 at Madison Square Garden in the final game of a triple-header.

KANSAS CITY, March 10 (AP) -- Fairleigh Dickinson of Rutherford, N. J. defeated Culver - Stockton of Canton, Mo., 77 -- 66, as play continued in the first round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner ruled today that the Pillsbury Company of Minneapolis, the nation's second largest flour milling company, had violated the Anti-Trust Law by buying up two major competitors.

IF a present trend continues, New Yorkers may switch from knives and forks to chopsticks. Another Chinese restaurant has opened in the city. Called the Eastern Garden, it is at 2628 Broadway, near 100th Street. Although the decor of the new establishment is routine, the cuisine is generally excellent and reasonably priced.
The student-ticket of the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy will be furthered as the result of two theatre benefit nights.

Futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Potatoes, copper, zinc, tin, hides and cottonseed oil rose; cocoa, coffee, rubber, burlap, lead and platinum declined, and price movements for sugar and wool were mixed.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Bills to humanize further the adoption laws and impose more responsibility on the courts in the placement of abandoned or neglected children were filed in the Legislature today. They were drafted by the Joint Legislative Committee on Matrimonial and Family Laws.
PARIS fashion has a dozen faces this spring. She is young and girlish. She is rangy and tailored. She is countess, American debutante and Italian movie star.

The Luckenbach Steamship Company filed suits for $100,000,000 yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, naming two companies as responsible for a $15,000,000 fire and explosion on the line's Brooklyn pier.

BISHOP FULTON J. SHEEN resumed his television appearances last night on Channel 13. As in past years on other outlets, he is wearing the vestments of his office before the cameras, speaking without notes in a carefully measured delivery and seasoning his remarks with a contemporary joke now and then.

Mr. Reid, whose residence is at Purchase, N. Y., was formerly president and editor of The New York Herald Tribune. Republican, he is 33 years old. His father was Ogden Mills Reid and his grandfather Whitelaw Reid.
VIENNA, March 10 -- An economic reorganization is in full swing in Czechoslovakia, according to reports from Prague.
Venus, Mercury and a thin crescent moon will put on a rare show in the western twilight sky tonight.
Nine young singers will make their debuts with the New York City Opera Company in major roles during the American opera season, which opens on March 30.
A public school on the lower East Side was dedicated last night to the memory of Meyer London, the first Socialist to serve in the House of Representatives.
"Your Hit Parade," a twenty-four-year-old program that originally was titled "The Hit Parade," is expected to be retired from service April 24.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz will make his debut Saturday as the host on a weekly radio discussion program sponsored by a Long Island home builder.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Dulles expects friction to develop between Communist China and the Soviet Union in the long run but does not foresee a break between them in the near future.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 10 -- By a vote of 25 to 20, Congress censured President Mario Echandi last night for his friendly meeting last month with President Luis Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A State Department representative suggested today that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's latest statement on the Berlin problem was designed primarily for its effect on world public opinion.

A lawyer who said he represented a group of investors headed by a "very substantial" New York industrialist declared yesterday that his clients were prepared to improve on the offer of the Consolidated Edison Company for the city's subway power plants.

Mrs. Samuel Averbuck and Mrs. Gerhart L. Kobrak, co-chairmen for the theatre party at the April 9 performance of "Sweet Bird of Youth," Tennessee Williams' new play at the Martin Beck Theatre, have announced the names of subscribers for the event. Proceeds will benefit the scholarship fund of the Encampment for Citizenship.
Constantinos Loumanis, 32 years old and still blind after eleven operations, sails for his native Greece today aboard the Home liner Queen Frederika.

Dr. Albert Simard's rebuttal of Hans Froehlich's attempt to absolve the German industrialist Alfried Krupp from the war crime of which he was justly convicted deserves vigorous support and consent. WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The State Department disclosed today that the United States had agreed to an increase in the capitalization of the proposed new Inter-American Development Bank.

Mayor Wagner will go to Albany Saturday in a new effort to win over Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders for off-track betting and his entire fiscal program. The meeting between the Governor and the Mayor will be the third on city tax needs.

Convertible bonds showed bounce yesterday, with many setting new highs for 1958-59. Trading in the convertibles was so heavy that six popular issues alone accounted for more than a fourth of the $7,340,000 face value of all bonds traded on the new York Stock Exchange.

Governor Rockefeller has won a political victory of impressive magnitude in legislative approval yesterday of his budget and tax program. It was a triumph of principle over expediency, of fiscal courage over a temporizing drift into debt, of immediate attack on fundamentals of government over the temptation to put off until tomorrow what should be done today.
Janet Blair and John Raitt will return as co-stars of a television musical series this summer over the National Broadcasting Company network.
WARSAW, March 11 -- Poland's Communist party, which once received scowls from Moscow and Peiping, received their official blessings today.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -A rebirth of hemisphere goodwill is essential to solve serious problems of Latin America, President Jose Maria Lemus of El Salvador said here today.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., March 11 -- Plans for a countrywide cancer detection service were announced here tonight by Alan Stevenson, executive director of the New York State Division of the American Cancer Society.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed Elwood R. Quesada today as first administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency despite some misgivings voiced by Senator Clair Engle, Democrat of California.
SCANDINAVIA has many claims to culinary fame. Best known as the source of sumptuous smorgasbords, it also is the land where the fantasies known as rosettes originated.

The annual flower festival, bridge and canasta party of the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church will be held in the ballroom of the Pierre on April 20. The Youth Consultation Service of the Episcopal Diocese of New York will benefit from the event.
