WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- A bill that would cancel a Tennessee Valley Authority contract with a British concern for a steam turbine was introduced in the House of Representatives today.

An agency that spends an estimated total of $35,000,000 a year for spot television advertising spoke out yesterday against "questionable local station practices" that affected the efficiency of these messages.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday renewed her attack on Carmine G. De Sapio, Tammany leader and Democratic national committeeman.
The skipper of the luxury liner Constitution was charged yesterday with negligence in the collision between his ship and the Norwegian tanker Jalanta on March 1.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11 -There was something familiar about the back and the broad shoulders of the fellow in the lobby of the Adams Hotel this morning. They turned out to be the back and shoulders of a former catcher and manager who recently turned from the field to the front office.

BERLIN, March 11 -- The Soviet Union and East Germany pledged themselves tonight to strive for conclusion of a German peace treaty "as soon as possible." The two Governments called for a summit conference of the great powers to be convened at the earliest possible moment.

The Graham-Paige Corporation, a closed-end, management investment company, registered a proposed offering yesterday of 350,000 shares of new $10 par, 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Times for March 3 carries a dispatch which confirms the Never-questioned desirability, practically and economically, of having the Police Department employ dogs. You print the news that in London they now have 200 dogs "on the squad," and are establishing a department for dog training.

TWO American designers have finally shattered that old wives' tale of the fashion industry that "if it's new, then Paris designed it." They are California's James Galanos and New York's Norman Norell and their spring designs, which are just now arriving in New York stores, were first shown way back last December.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -Chicago's Jimmy Jones, 18, outpunched Carl McClure, 26, of Fort Worth, for the heavyweight title in the Golden Gloves tournament tonight.
A New York County grand jury charged yesterday that the police had permitted gambling to flourish in East and West Harlem.

Ten days and approximately eighteen hours after the meet ended, Penn State was officially declared the team victor in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America indoor track and field championships.

MOST women do not wander on the fourth floor of Best Co. They head for the racks of David Crystal suits like welltrained retrievers. At the store's recent press showing of these spring-into-summer suits, it was clear why customers look for this label.

Long Island's first indoor event of its kind, the Island Horse Show, will be held at Island Gardens in West Hempstead on Saturday and Sunday. Proceeds will go to the Mineola (L. I.) Kiwanis Club's fund for underprivileged children.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -The Senate passed the Hawaiian statehood bill tonight by a vote of 76 to 15.
Mayor Wagner strongly defended the city school system yesterday against charges of waste and extravagance in new construction.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today he did not want any "yes" men in his cabinet.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -The National Park Service has proposed that the Federal Government rescue the outer arm of Cape Cod from the march of commercialization by creating a "national seashore" along the entire Atlantic Ocean front.
Russians will have a chance to go house-hunting in Long Island style when they visit the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer.

" Herbert Hoover and the Great Depression," a political and economic history by Harry Gaylord Warren, will be published March 23 by Oxford University Press. The author, who is chairman of the Department of History at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, describes the conditions that produced the depression and outlines the politicoeconomic philosophy that Mr. Hoover brought to bear upon the problem.
DETROIT, March 11 -- The Ford Motor Company acknowledged publicly for the first time today that it planned to introduce a small economy car in the 1960 model year.
NICE, France, March 11 -The State Department's foreign language school here is scheduled to close March 28, apparently a victim of its own pleasant surroundings.

Twenty-three editors who are members of the Pulitzer Prize Journalism Juries for 1959 will meet at Columbia University today and tomorrow. They will pass on nominations for the prizes in eight journalism categories, based on work published in 1958.
The bond market moved forward again yesterday as financial institutions continued to bid for the Treasury's newly issued 4s of 1980 and other long-term Government obligations.

The Western Casualty and Surety Company is offering its shareholders rights to subscribe for 100,000 shares of additional capital stock at the rate of one share for each five held on March 11. The shares are priced at $45.50.

TORONTO, March 11 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau scored his thirtyeighth and thirty-ninth goals of the season as he paced the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-2 decision over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game before 13,676 fans tonight.

For some reason that has proved puzzling to all hands, the Chicago Black Hawks fatten up when they visit the Rangers. Last night the secondplace Hawks rebounded to stop the Blues, 5 to 3, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., March 11 -- A $6,000,000 contract for the "complete reconstruction'' of the Albany Post Road (U. S. 9) here will be awarded this year.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 11 -- World forces challenging this country were called the most formidable in its history tonight by Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force. He charged that the nation's attempts to solve the problems were "wholly inadequate."
OTTAWA, March 11 -- The Royal Canadian Mounted Police sent reinforcements to Newfoundland today to try to maintain order in a bitter labor disput raging in the woods.
The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation achieved new highs last year in natural gas deliveries, operating revenues and earnings, according to the annual report released yesterday.

ALPINE, N. J., March 11 -The American Cyanamid Corporation of New York presented its plans for building an office here before a meeting of residents tonight. Two hundred and fifty persons jammed the Community House for the session.

The lobby at the Martin Beck, where "Sweet Bird of Youth" opened Tuesday night, was jammed with customers yesterday. They were waiting patiently to buy tickets for the Tennessee Williams drama, staged by Elia Kazan.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The Board of Regents today endorsed the licensing of chiropractors.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- A breach of protocol by the White House was corrected last night when Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, the House Democratic leader, spent an hour with President Eisenhower.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, zinc, lead and hides rose; cocoa, sugar, rubber and burlap declined and price movements for copper, potatoes, coffee and wool were mixed.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 11 -- To combat the campaign for African nationalism, the Southern Rhodesian Government introduced a bill today to give severe repressive powers to the police and civil servants.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 11 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser accused Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq and Communist "agents of a foreign power" today of trying to split the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria.

LONDON, March 11 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the House of Commons today that he would make clear his Government's views on United States trade practices that affect British industry during his forthcoming visit to Washington.

The 201 East Eighty-third Street Corporation, A. Phillip Goldsmith, president, has purchased property at the north-east corner of Third Avenue and Eighty-third Street for investment.
David Campanella was adjudged a juvenile delinquent in Queens Children's Court yesterday.

LONDON, March 11 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today that the United States, Britain and France had agreed that the Berlin issue should be settled by negotiation.

The unemployment figures for February are again less than encouraging. The increase in the number of jobless from 4,724,000 to 4,749,000, or by 25,000, was, it is true, a very modest one compared with the spectacular jump of 616,000 between December and January. But a sharp increase was to have been expected in January on the basis of normal seasonal considerations.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" in concert form, Jean Morel, conductor, Phyllis Curtin, Regina Resnik, Mildred Allen, Nicolai Gedda, Martial Singher, Kenneth Smith, soloists, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Manon Lescaut," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Don Cossack Chorus and Dancers, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Zara Doloukhanova, mezzo-soprano, Town Hall, 8:40.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senator Henry Martin Jackson is a man whose interests are as varied as his own Pacific Northwest.

BOSTON, March 12 (UPI) -- Don McKenney scored his twenty-ninth goal and added three assists to lead the Boston Bruins to a 5-4 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers at the Garden tonight.
HONOLULU, March 12 -- The kamaaina and the malihini celebrated today Congressional assurance that the nation was ready to welcome Hawaii as the fiftieth state.

At the moment there is some danger that Senator Lister Hill's "Health for Peace" bill may be bogged down in rather pointless debate and attempted amendment. There is no real opposition to what this proposal really means. There is, instead, discussion of what functions should be allocated to what source of authority, and how.
The Federal hearing on the 29,000-foot dive of a jet airliner last month was told yesterday about a number of instances of automatic-pilot trouble on this plane and sister craft.
All roads will lead to the ski areas in the snow country today -- if snow running enthusiasts are able to find them.

A warning that the city's day high school teachers might resign en masse unless they received satisfactory salary increases was issued yesterday by the lawyer for the High School Teachers Association.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 12 -- Two cars were derailed tonight, blocking two tracks and causing eastbound New Haven Railroad commuters to be late for dinner.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -At the isolated mountain retreat where Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill planned how to win a war, their successors in office will talk next week about how to avoid another one.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee put unions of public employes under the reform provisions of the Kennedy-Ervin bill today.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 12 -- A tin miners' strike threatened today to snowball into a general strike against the Bolivian Government.
PARIS, March 12 -- French tourists going abroad after June 1 will be permitted to take with them 50,000 francs worth of foreign currencies as well as 20,000 French francs.
New York University acquired a new library yesterday.

Universal Controls, Inc., announced yesterday that it had acquired the Grant Money Meters Company of Providence, R. I., maker of automatic toll collectors and fare registers. Although terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed, it was learned that Universal paid about $4,000,000 for Grant.

LONDON, March 12 (UPI) -- Piccadilly Circus, London's famed circle with its flashing neon signs and Edwardian buildings ringing the statue of Eros will be converted into a rectangular, skyscraper-bordered plaza under a building plan announced today.
TRENTON, March 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner made a strong plea today for the cooperation of New York in setting up a bi-state agency to effect a long-range solution to the commuter transit problem.
ALBANY, March 12 (AP) -- The state's highest court held today that a woman who quit her job to marry was entitled to unemployment insurance benefits.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 12 (AP) -- A special press court has sentenced an opposition editor to sixteen months in prison for reprinting a summary of articles by Eugene C. Pulliam, a United States publisher, and his wife Nina.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Proposed regulations under which Alaska would receive more than 103,000,000 acres of Federal lands were announced today.

AUMALE, Algeria, March 12 -- A beribboned French general stood stiffly in a driving snowstorm here today and watched his armored cars, a swarm of weapons carriers and a black sedan deliver two sobbing farm wives and their five children to his command post.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 12 (AP) -- Willie Mays, star center fielder of the San Francisco Giants, split his right leg open to the shin bone sliding into the plate during an exhibition baseball game with the Boston Red Sox today. The Red Sox won, 7 -- 4, for their fifth straight triumph.

ONE store that is not going to let any Paris grass grow under its feet is Stern's. It has enthusiastically joined the Paris fashion landslide in great style. Ben R. Gordon, the store's new president, has seen to that.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 11 -- A citizens' committee reported tonight, after a two-year study, that while the community's schools were regarded as among the best, its graduates did not do as well in college as they should.

As a former Councilman and as a resident of the Borough of Queens I feel compelled to express my dissent to your March 4 editorial approving, even lauding, the proposed increases in assessed valuations of real property, primarily in Queens. These proposed increases in valuations of ordinary real property in our borough total more than the proposed increases of the other four boroughs combined.
MOSCOW, March 12 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev returned to Moscow from East Germany today, apparently confident that East-West negotiations on the Berlin and German questions would take place soon.

NO "right-thinking person" can approve of crime, not out loud and in public at least. But there are crimes and crimes and it is impossible to muster up as much indignation about illegal parking, for instance, as about felonious assault or murder. One variety of crime that many people find themselves almost admiring, if not altogether approving, is the forgery of works of art.
THIRTEEN years having gone by, "Lute Song" has returned in a glorious production to the City Center, where it opened for a limited engagement last evening.
DETROIT, March 12 -- A day of decision in Michigan's cash crisis appears close at hand in the State Legislature in Lansing.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 12 -- The Governor of Northern Rhodesia outlawed the Zambia African National Congress today. The group has been urging Africans to boycott the territorial election a week from tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill for a three-month tapering-off of emergency Federal aid to the unemployed.

The newspapers report that the New York City Transit Authority urges the general use and acceptance of the subway token as a 15-cent coin. This leads one to wonder whether the T. A. has thought the matter through to its logical conclusion.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A small, gray-haired, quick-witted, easy-going dynamo who likes to refer to himself as "one of the laziest men alive" has nonetheless found sufficient energy to pilot two new states into the union.
Two of New York's collegiate quintets saw action last night as the twenty-second annual National Invitation Tournament opened before 12,235 persons at Madison Square Garden, but only one survived.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 12 -- Ceylon's Senate armed Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike tonight with sweeping new powers to outlaw political strikes and put down civil disorders.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused the Department of Justice today of anti-labor motives in the indictment of a New York garment workers' union on anti-trust charges.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The State Senate today approved a bill that authorizes the State Controller to pay $1,620 to the family of a horse-racing fan who died before he could cash his winning pari-mutuel tickets.
Simplified procedures for handling immigrant visas are to be introduced in United States consular offices over the world within two years, a State Department official said here yesterday.

THE Polynesian influence, apparent in the United States for the last few months, doubtlessly will be underscored with the admission of Hawaii as the fiftieth state. Back-yard luaus, the traditional native feast, are likely to become as popular as the hula hoop was last summer.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 12 (AP) -- The thirteen-day-old strike against the three daily newspapers here ended tonight with an agreement on a new contract for striking pressmen.

A four-man group seeking to obtain seats on the board of the Philip Carey Manufacturing Corporation last night sent out its proxy statement and a letter to stockholders of the Cincinnati building materials concern.
Earnings Of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company last year set a new high, but sales were below the peak reached in 1957, according to the annual report of J. P. Levis, chairman, issued yesterday.
The Federal Maritime Board voted unanimously yesterday to maintain a complicated and long-standing jurisdictional arrangement on the New York waterfront.

Two Brooklyn teams, Boys and Erasmus, advanced to the semi-final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 4,000 was on hand for the double-header.

LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- Walter B. Stone, an associate Professor of English at Vassar College, was found hanged last night in a house where he was staying in suburban Hampstead. He was 42 years old. Officials would not comment on he cause of death pending an inquest.
MOSCOW, March 12 (AP) -- Soviet leaders stepped in today to help the citizen who still must wait and wait for a haircut or a radio repair job in this sputnik age.

OTTAWA, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- James E. Coyne, governor of the Bank of Canada, contends that both Canada and the United States are in the grip of an "inflation psychosis" that has aggravated the rise in interest rates.
The city's street light poles may provide information on soap and cigarettes, as well as illumination, it was learned yesterday.

New Yorkers can expect a good year in the convention and tourist business, directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau were told yesterday. The optimistic forecast was made at the annual meeting of the board of directors in the Plaza Hotel.

For the second day in a row, the seven New York drama critics welcomed a new Broadway presentation with unanimous reviews. The muchsought-after distinction went to "A Raisin in the Sun" yesterday. On Wednesday the accolade was bestowed upon "Sweet Bird of Youth."

Subject to the expected approval of the Legislature today, Yonkers Raceway will open for business next Friday night.
For more than 150 years New York has had its fashionable, but restricted, dances, limited to congenial friends in an atmosphere removed from the impersonality of the usual charity ball.
Hartford, Conn., is planning the sale of $4,023,000 of general obligations on April 21. The money will be used to finance public improvements.

Flag manufacturers appealed yesterday for postponement of the inauguration of the fifty-star national flag until July 4, 1960, "or the flag industry faces ruin."
LONDON, March 12 -- A wild scramble to buy shares of a new real estate company dominated early trading in the stock exchange here today.

The highly controversial proposal to widen part of Fulton Street in lower Manhattan was withdrawn from further consideration yesterday by Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.

New York State has once again demonstrated its leadership in upholding progressive child labor standards by blocking passage of the State Senate bill that would permit 12-year-olds to work on certain agricultural crops. Only five states have set a minimum age of 14 years for employment in agriculture when school is not in session; of these, only the New York State law has no loopholes to permit employment at an earlier age.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- Senator Estes Kefauver proposed a constitutional amendment today to abolish the present electoral college. The Tennessee Democrat would replace it with a system for crediting Presidential candidates with the proportion of the popular vote they receive in each state.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Friday, March 13 -- Six million Dutchmen voted yesterday in an election that made no more noise than the crocuses that suddenly sprouted, white and yellow, all over the country.
Hawaii summons up for most people visions of sugar cane, pineapples, hula dancers, tourists, leis and ukeleles.

LONDON, March 12 -- Britain narrowed its trade gap in February. Figures for the short month released by the Board of Trade showed declines from January levels in both exports and imports, the latter registering the sharper drop.
The hearing on charges of failure to provide heat in five tenements managed by Banton Wyckoff was adjourned yesterday until April 28.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Justice Department has asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here for permission to intervene in the legal battle over the Niagara River power project on the side of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A group of tenants and property owners fighting the Lincoln Square Redevelopment project in New York asked the Supreme Court today to take a second look at the constitutionality of the $250,000,000 plan.

LONDON, March 12 -- Britain and the Soviet Union are to exchange industrial exhibitions in 1961. It will be the first such exchange between them.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- Dr. Willard F. Libby, scientist member of the Atomic Energy commission, will receive the 1959 Albert Einstein Medal and award for outstanding contributions to scientific knowledge.
ATLANTA, March 12 (AP) -The appointment of Don E. Carter, city editor of The Atlanta Journal, as staff executive of The Wall Street Journal was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The House of Representatives approved a bill today to extend the Selective Service Act four years. It went to President Eisenhower for his signature.
HONOLULU, March 12 (AP) -- To William F. Quinn statehood for Hawaii means "equality with fellow Americans."
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -The division between strength and weakness in grain futures prices on the Board of Trade generally was along the line of old and new crop contracts today.

BONN, Germany, March 12 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, testified today in the trial of two of West Germany's leading diplomats that he had been convinced from the start of the innocence of the man they are accused of having slandered.
BARRY MORELL, young New York tenor, made his first Metropolitan Cavaradossi one of the most impressive roles he has undertaken at the opera house in his debut season.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd has challenged the tax exemption now allowed to contributions to the Legal Defense Fund of the National Association for Advancement of Colored People.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Ford Foundation will offer 2,000,000 shares of Ford Motor Company stock for public sale soon, it notified the Securities and Exchange commission today.

In spite of the snow, sleet and rain yesterday, spring continued its week-long lease in the Coliseum undaunted. Flower Show visitors may have been impeded by umbrellas, boots and raincoats, but they were there, nonetheless.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 12 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, strode into the midst of an A. F. L.-C. I. O, attack on him today, making clear that he was bent on organizing all Standard Oil independent unions.

Governor Rockefeller's appointment yesterday of Keith S. McHugh to be Commissioner of Commerce is of first-rank importance. An able man, successful in business, widely acquainted, of congenial, persuasive personality, devoted to the well-being of state and city, Mr. McHugh is resigning as president of the New York Telephone Company to take a post in state government that the Governor ranks as a foremost essential in the success of his own program.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 12 (AP) -- Benito Mussolini's son Vittorio was acquitted today of a charge of having deserted the Italian Air Force, in which he was a captain, in World War II.
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- A feminine voice rang out in the House of Commons tonight, "Oh, Edith, you really are an ass!"
The sixth Archbold Expedition to New Guinea will get under way today.

Young journalists from thirty-two states gathered at Columbia University yesterday to hear about the gathering, writing and disseminating of news. They attended the opening of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.
BERLIN, March 12 -- Premier Khrushchev left East Berlin by air today after a strenuous eight-day visit of political conferences and public appearances in East Germany.
The New York City Mission Society, believed to be the oldest religious welfare organization in the metropolitan area marked its 147th anniversary at a dinner in the Delmonico Hotel last night.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its twenty-first annual campaign last night. Advance gifts of $10,000,000 to help meet Jewish needs over the world, particularly in Israel, were announced.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 12 -- One of the immediate implications of Hawaii's prospective admission as the fiftieth state is a hastening of the decline of Southern power in the Senate and a strengthening of the Senate's new power bloc, the West.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Representative Charles A. Buckley, Democrat, of Manhattan, said today his $38,497 a year allowance for office help is paid to eight political friends in New York who do part-time work for him.
MEXICO CITY, March 10 -- Political storm warnings are up in virtually the entire Caribbean area.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- The American Jewish Congress challenged today a Pennsylvania law requiring Bible reading in public schools.

The Bank for Savings in the City of New York and the Union Square Savings Bank are considering a merger. While the heads of the two banks could not be reached for con firmation yesterday, a spokesman for one said he would not deny the report.

ALEXANDER KING, raconteur, iconoclast, part-time obstetrician, author, former narcotics addict, artist, playwright, critic and presumably almost anything else upon appropriate demand, began his own weekly television program on Wednesday (11 P. M. to midnight) over station WNTA-TV, the house of talk.

GENEVA, March 12 -- The International Labor Organization's governing body voted today to set up an appeal procedure for settling disputes between the employer delegates of the free-enterprise countries and those of the Communist bloc.

The retired police sergeant who was sentenced on Wednesday to thirty days in jail for refusing to answer questions before a New York County grand jury, faced the threat yesterday of another prison term in Brooklyn.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The State Tax Department began mailing withholding forms and instructions to employers today so that collection of the state income tax through payroll deductions could start April 1.

BAYARD, Fla., March 11 -This little town, situated on the broad divided highway (US No. 1) that leads from Jacksonville to St. Augustine and the legendary Fountain of Youth, is the post-office address of a horse-racing plant that is unusual in several respects.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The new state of Hawaii will receive specific benefits for its voting population that include the following:
OTTAWA, March 12 -- The Canadian Government reserved decision today on the question of intervention in Newfoundland's violent strike of woodlands workers.

ATHENS, March 12 -- Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza told British press representatives today that the "disturbed period of bitterness and suspicion between Greece and Britain was over." He added that the two nations would now resume their historic collaboration, as in the two world wars.
PARIS, March 12 -- The French Government seized last night the current edition of the Leftist weekly L'Express to suppress an interview with an Algerian rebel who had deceived his French captors.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Administration has no intention of intervening in school desegregation disputes with weapons like holdbacks of Federal funds or Federal operation of general public schools, Congress was told today.

ALBANY, March 12, -- With his own program for higher state taxes out of the way, Governor Rockefeller has decided to take personal command of the Albany action needed to help New York City balance its budget for the fiscal year starting July 1.

TEL AVIV. Israel, March 12 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion told an international gathering of Socialist youth leaders here tonight that they must act to bridge the abyss between the rich people of Europe and the United States and the poor of Asia and Africa.
ROME, March 12 -- Pope John XXIII gave the red hat today to three Cardinals whom he appointed last December.
Governor Rockefeller completed his Cabinet in Albany yesterday with the appointment of Keith S. McHugh to head the Department of Commerce.
A scale model of the first of two projected 90,000-ton passenger liners will be tested next Tuesday.

LONDON, March 12 -- Prof. Albert B. Sabin of the University of Cincinnati, a leading advocate of live vaccines against poliomyelitis, argues the case for their adoption in place of the inactivated Salk vaccine in an eighteen-page article to be published by The British Medical Journal tomorrow.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek announced tonight a program for increasing food production and improving distribution. He outlined the Government's plans in the face of rising protests over high prices.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Jay Hebert, Art Wall Jr., Freddie Haas of New Orleans, Arnold Palmer, and Bill Blanton of La Mesa, Calif., tied for the lead with 68's today in the first round of the $15,000 Pensacola open.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 12 (AP) -- A member of the Air Force precision flying team known as the Thunderbirds was killed today. His plane tipped another during a practice and his parachute apparently failed him.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- John Joseph Frank, Washington lawyer, withdrew today his plea of innocent to a charge that he had acted illegally as an agent of the Dominican Republic. The effect was to throw himself upon the mercy of the court.

Asher W. Schwartz, former counsel for the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, yesterday discussed the principles that he believed should guide union attorneys in deciding whether to represent union officers accused of betraying members' interests.
The Judson Health Center, 34 Spring Street, will benefit from a fashion show and luncheon on Easter Sunday in the Rendezvous of the Plaza.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Rockefeller called on the Legislature today to join him in prosecuting a war against organized crime "more vigorously than ever before."

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 12 (AP) -- Ray Eliot, the dean of Big Ten football coaches, today resigned from his post at the University of Illinois, effective at the close of the 1959 season. He will remain at the university as assistant director of athletics.
LONDON, March 12 -- Londoners queued and crowded today to see England's first retrospective show of paintings by Sir Winston Churchill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- Joseph N. Welch was introduced to Hollywood today in his new capacity as motion-picture actor. But the lawyer in him still dominated at the luncheon interview that attracted the unusually large number of eighty reporters, radio and television representatives.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- The General Assembly's trusteeship committee approved today a resolution recommending the admission of the French Cameroons to the United Nations after the trust territory becomes independent Jan. 1.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- Solomon Joseph Hemus, the new manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, is a man of many small talents. The comparison between him and Eddie Stanky is more than striking. It's inevitable. They are about the same size and each is so ungifted that he became a major leaguer through determination, brains and an overabundant store of what Branch Rickey describes as "the intangibles."

HARLAN, Ky., March 13 -- The International Harvester Company and the Progressive Mine Workers Union today reached an agreement for ending a three-day strike at the company's coal-mining town of Benham, Ky.
GENEVA, March 13 -- David A. Morse, director general of the International Labor Organization, announced today the opening soon of a branch office in Moscow.

OLYMPIA, Wash., March 13 (AP) -- Fifteen runaway freight cars crashed through the Union Pacific depot tonight, crossed the city's main street and smashed into a restaurant at dinner hour. At least one person was killed and seventeen were injured.
TROY, N. Y., March 13 -- Michigan State cut loose for three goals in the second period tonight to defeat Boston College, 4 -- 3, and gain the final of the National Collegiate hockey championship.

A cantilevered concrete foundation to support a twenty-story apartment house over a bed of quicksand was poured in Harlem yesterday. The builders said the device was the only one of its kind in their experience.
PORT LAMY, Chad, March 13 (Reuters)--The month-old Government of Premier Gontchome Sahoulba resigned today and a new all-party regime ' was formed under Ahmed Koulamallah, Socialist leader.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 13 -- The Soviet Union surprised delegates today at a conference of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East by opposing limitation of the fast-growing Asian population.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower created a Federal Council for Science and Technology today. Its responsibility is to strengthen and coordinate the nation's scientific activities.
A national gathering of student journalists heard the United Nations described yesterday as an imperfect organization, but one that mankind must look to for the prevention of another world war.

Two four-story buildings containing seventy-eight apartments and occupying a plot 216 by 100 feet at 7802 to 7814 Fourth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn have been purchased by David Goodman for investment.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Solicitor General J. Lee Rankin urged the country's lawyers today to support the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Eisenhower's request for $3,930,000,000 for foreign aid faced a highly uncertain future in Congress, judging from the immediate reaction to his message today.

ATLANTA, March 13 (AP) -- George W. Woodruff, one of the principal stockholders of the Continental Gin Company, announced today an offer had been received to buy all of the company's common stock at $40 a share in cash. The offer of $11,693,080 was made through Jay Levine, chairman of the board of Fulton Cotton Mills, Inc., of Atlanta.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March -- 13 Hofstra College opened its tenth annual Shakespeare Festival tonight with a performance of "The Merry Wives of Windsor."

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 13 -- Violence flared in Northern Rhodesia early today in the wake of the Government's ban on the Zambia African National Congress in the drive to counter the campaign of African nationalism.

Yonkers Raceway began preparing last night for its opening next Friday night, ten days earlier than originally scheduled. Snow will be removed from the racing strip, which will then be raked and harrowed.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies gained 11.8 per cent in February over the same period of 1958, according to a survey just completed by The New York Times. Sales for the month totaled $1,231,043,146 for the forty reporting companies, compared with $1,101,246,718 in February, 1958.

NEWARK, March 13--The New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads were ordered today to consider a plan for getting commuters on the Central's West Shore Division into New York City after the Central stops ferry service across the Hudson River.
College basketball, via the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, goes on national television today and a lot of people in Rye, N. Y., and Denver no doubt will be looking in.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 13 -- The National Organization of Cypriote Fighters, otherwise known as E. O. K. A., handed in its arms today at selected delivery points throughout Cyprus.
HONOLULU, March 13 -- The Chinese-American president of Hawaii's last Territorial Senate told islanders today that "God made us His children of destiny to spread the brotherhood of man."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Leaders of a Republican program committee pledged tonight an effort to state "right," not "expedient," policies for the party even if it meant the loss of a national election or two.
Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate have abandoned their proposal to increase the city's tax on hotel-room occupancy. They had proposed to raise the present 5 per cent levy to 10 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 13--President Eisenhower will report to the nation Monday night on the Berlin situation.

A recent letter from Jefferson B. Fordham deplores any criticism, and especially lay criticism, of court decisions. Mr. Fordham overlooks the fact that the most far-reaching court reforms resulted from lay criticism by Charles Dickens and Jeremy Bentham. Mr. Fordham also forgets that the great American whose name he bears, Thomas Jefferson, was a frequent and sharp critic of Supreme Court decisions.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Government sources said tonight that Jerome D. Fenton was expected to resign soon as general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

A one-story taxpayer occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 48 to 58 East 183d Street in the Bronx has been sold by Bellerose Investors, Inc. It was bought by a client of Milton Levitan for cash over mortgages amounting to $40,000. The Philip Fogel Company was the broker.

A "Musical Surprise Party" at Carnegie Hall on April 8 will be the second New York Philharmonic concert to be given this season for the benefit of the orchestra's pension fund. Leonard Bernstein will conduct and Jack Benny will appear as violin soloist.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower visited his former Army chief, Gen. George C. Marshall at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center today.
A State Supreme Court justice excoriated eleven Police Department members yesterday when he directed them to appear before a Brooklyn grand jury.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Bell Telephone Laboratories, research affiliate of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, received a patent this week for a machine that plays ticktacktoe.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Paul Harney of Worcester, Mass., fired a seven-under-par 65 today as he took the 36-hole lead in the $15,000 Pensacola open with a total of 134.

Frank Lloyd Wright, the dean of American architects, is a genius; the new Seagram Building, designed by Mies van der Rohe, is magnificent; and, in general, the new architecture in New York is very nice.

LOS ANGELES, March 13 (AP) -- The Union Oil Company said today it was raising the price it pays for crude oil from California and Four Corners Fields. It said the increase was tied in with a Government order restricting oil imports. The Four Corners field lies generally around the point where Colorado, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico meet.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that the nation's military chiefs agreed that the United States had adequate plans and strength to meet the Berlin crisis.
STARA PAZOVA, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- The winter wheat stirring under the warm sun covered the black earth of the Vojvodina with a carpet of green fuzz.

" HE'S a sort of John Foster Dulles among editors," a colleague said of Erwin Dain Canham. "He's always traveling and making speeches. And he belongs to everything. I don't know when he gets time to do his editing."
Morris High School in the Bronx celebrated its tenth anniversary as a fully integrated public high school yesterday.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 13 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser led a massive national display today of enmity to Premier Abdel Karim Kassim of Iraq and to communism in the Arab world.
LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- Communist China charged today that Nationalist Chinese troops based in Laos have been invading border areas in China's Yunnan Province frequently in he last six months.
PARIS, March 13 -- The one-third of the French Mediterranean fleet earmarked for the Atlantic alliance command in time of war will remain under French command.

If the Juilliard School of Music's records are accurate, New York has not heard a stage performance of Rossini's "Le Conte Ory" since 1831 -- and it was composed in 1828. It came back last night in a snappy little production at the Juilliard School, sung in a clever and workable English translation by Robert A. Simon, and it proved as jolly a romp as one can see anywhere in New York.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 13 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has agreed to visit Scandinavia toward the end of August.
Three new directors of the F. L. Jacobs Company failed yesterday to win a two-week delay in litigation over a proposed sale of some of the company's securities assets.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Agencies serving the blind marshaled their forces today against a blind California college professor who demands that the blind lead the blind.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 13 -- A revolution has broken out in the southern atolls of the Maldive Islands and a new government has been set up with a president and a committee elected by the people.

NEW HAVEN, March 13 -- Occasionally an understudy in the theatre or in sports gets a chance to take over a star's role. That is what has happened to Philip E. Moriarty, Yale's assistant swimming coach.
The mystery surrounding Joseph G. Luberda, the retired police sergeant, grew more complex yesterday.

It took the New York Knickerbrockers three years to get into a National Basketball Association play-off. After forty-eight minutes last night the Knicks found themselves half-way on the road out of it.
ORADELL, N. J., March 13 -- Four men came to this country in 1906 and helped to establish here a religious order that has grown into an important contributor to education throughout the nation.
BOSTON, March 13 -- Gov. Foster Furcolo asked the Legislature today to vote a 3 per cent sales tax to provide $120,000,000 of new revenue.
NICOSIA, March 13 (AP) -- E. O. K. A.'s war is over and the boys are heading home.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Crews of thirty-two craft made eleventh-hour repairs and adjustments today in preparation for tomorrow's start of the twenty-sixth annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- State and civil officials from the Northeast continued yesterday to press the Civil Aeronautics Board for more and better airline service within their region.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., March 13 (Canadian Press) -- Premier J. R. Smallwood said in Newfoundland's Legislature today that he had sent a message to Prime Minister John Diefenbaker requesting an immediate royal commission investigation into the Newfoundland labor situation.

MADRID, March 13 -- The Spanish Government announced today details of an anti-inflationary law aimed at controlling public and private investment. It is designed to steer capital into areas useful to the nation.
WILMONT, N. H., March 13 (AP) -- The two men on the Board of Selectmen have resigned because a woman was elected to serve with them for the first time in this town's history.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States elected a newspaper man as its president today for the first time. He is Erwin D, Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
BOSTON, March 13 (UPI) -- The New England Council issued the following reports on ski conditions at 10 A. M. today, along with the weather forecast for New England:

MORTON WISHENGRAD'S sensitive and probing drama on human fears, "The Rope Dancers," was given a tenderly stirring performance last night at the De Witt Clinton Adult Center, 100 West Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx.

PARIS, March 13 -- One of the paradoxes of our time is that the greatest imperial powers in the Islamic world, Russia and China, still make so much propaganda headway among the devoutly religious Arabs. From Iraq to Morocco agents of Moscow and Peiping have achieved deep political penetrations at the expense of Western prestige.

A three-way battle for the Eastern Collegiate swimming championship developed last night during the opening portion of the two-day meet. Pittsburgh, New York University and Rutgers were virtually even after eight races at the Violets' Quigley Memorial Pool.
No progress was made yesterday by Federal mediators in an attempt to settle a dispute between the Publishers Association of New York City and New York Typographical Union 6.
Generally low admission prices that limit profits and the need for increased theatre construction are two principal problems hampering the expansion of the film industry in the Far East.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 13 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Cattlemen's Association, said today that from July, 1958, through December, 1958, 807 cattle and calves were reported stolen, strayed or missing.

The international exhibits from South Africa and Israel staged a spectacular finale at the International Flower Show yesterday. Delayed by the snowstorm for Thursday's competition, these entries were judged yesterday.

Distillers Corporation - Seagrams, Ltd., and its United States and Canadian subsidiaries, realized an after-tax net profit of $15,379,000 in the six months ended Jan. 31, according to the annual report issued for release today.

The Council of Free Czechoslovakia, the political organization of the Czechoslovak exiles in the free world, has been informed that the Slovak separatists here want to "commemorate" on March 14 Slovak independence day. On that date, twenty years ago, Hitler forced on the Slovak people the so-called independent Slovak state in order to disrupt democratic Czechoslovakia.

WHITE PLAINS, March 13 -- The General Motors Corporation modified its proposal today to buy all the eighty-five acres of Westchester County's Kingsland Park, a swimming and picnicking area on the Hudson River at North Tarrytown.

TORONTO, March 13 (Canadian Press) -- Changes in the structure of Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., interests in Britain and rearrangement of its manufacturing operations in France, were envisaged today by W. Eric Phillips, chairman, at the company's annual meeting.
ROME, March 13 -- The factions of the Christian Democratic party held confidential discussions almost around the clock today in preparation for a crucial party caucus tomorrow.
TRENTON, March 13 -- A bipartisan legislative committee reached final agreement today on measures to circumvent a state Supreme Court ruling on 100 per cent assessments.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- The General Assembly voted tonight to grant independence to the French Cameroons next Jan. 1 without further elections.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 13 -- Penn State maintained its 3-point margin through the quarter-final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships before 2,500 spectators in Barton Hall tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The House voted, 231 to 94, today to allow citrus growers in Texas and Florida to color their oranges artificially. The measure, passed by the Senate last month, went to President Eisenhower.
WILTON, Conn., March 13 -- The annual fund-raising program for the Wilton Cooperative Nursery School will end with two matinee entertainments for children at the Wilton High School auditorium.

The idealistic "communes" in this country in the last century are discussed in a new book called "Escape to Utopia: The Communal Movement in America." It will be published Monday by Hastings House as a volume in its American Procession Series.

Events today: "Wozzeck," 2:15, and "Don Carlo," 8, Metropolitan Opera; Betty Egan, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:15; Boston Symphony, Charles Munch, conductor, Samuel Mayes, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Sarah Fleming, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, conductor, Jean Morel, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:30; Milton Stern, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- Henry M. Garsson and the estate of his brother, Murray W. Garsson, have agreed to pay $963,000 in back income taxes, the Government announced today.

New York welcomed President Jose Maria Lemus of El Salvador, the Western Hemisphere's smallest republic, yesterday with Manhattan's ritual, a ticker-tape parade. For the crowd, lining lower Broadway, it was as it has been in the past -- few knew for whom the cheers rose.

DOROTHY PARKER once said, I believe, that when she had trouble going to sleep she counted Van Dorens. In a new book called "The Professor and I"* Dorothy Van Doren says she can't get to sleep counting sheep. May be she should try counting stories attributed to Dorothy Parker.

A COMFORTABLE seat in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 2:30 P. M. on Fridays becomes, after a bit, a seat in a plane, car, bus or anything else that moves. It heads for all the places one has always wanted to see or wants to see again and better.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Palmyra is actually a group of fifty-two little coral atolls arranged in a rough oval shape surrounding two or three lagoons. The biggest islet is 288 acres; the smallest, less than one acre. It is uninhabited, but habitable.
PANAMA, March 13 -- Six maritime nations have now filed protests with the Foreign Office against Panama's extension of her territorial waters from the previous three miles off shore to twelve miles.

BONN, Germany, March 13 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan flew back to London today after having established "complete agreement" with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on the problems facing the Western Allies in Europe.

The professional nurse shortage in the municipal hospitals has reached a critical point, the hospitals' director of nursing services said yesterday. The condition, according to Dorothy Weddige, the director, is probably due as much to the hard work as to the low salaries.
HENDERSON, N. C., March 13 (AP) -- A truck loaded with cotton burst into flames today near one of two strike-bound Henderson-Harriet cotton mills.

RANGOON, Burma, March 13 -- General Ne Win, who became Premier of Burma last fall to restore political order, said today that his Government was acting to increase the people's buying power and end waste. A long-term economic policy is still under consideration, however, he added.

" The tightest copper market in three years." That's how some copper authorities described the situation yesterday as the major custom smelters remained out of the market for the fourth consecutive day.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 13 -- The Bolivian Central Union gave the Government tonight until Monday to meet the demands of striking tin miners or face a possible general strike. A meeting of representatives of more than twenty labor confederations resolved to create a commission to negotiate for the miners. A committee also was formed to prepare for a general strike.
WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 13 -- Florida's Great Orange Blossom Rally, the first national championship event of the year on the Sports Car Club of America calendar, started here today.
The near May cotton contract on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 points yesterday but other months declined 1 to 7 points. A point is 5 cents a bale.
LANSING, Mich., March 13 -- Republicans in the Michigan Senate defeated today a $50,000,000 bond proposal aimed at solving the state's cash crisis.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- A House Education subcommittee wound up its hearings on Federal aid to education today with statements from witnesses for and against the proposal.
William Shatner has been signed to star with Kurt Kasznar in a pilot film that may be the basis for a "Nero Wolfe" television series.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Government today set a quota of 968,100 barrels a day on imports of crude and unfinished oils and petroleum products with the exception of residual fuel oil. This quota was made effective as of last Wednesday and is to continue through June 30.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 13 -- The United States defeated Czechoslovakia, 4 -- 2, tonight in a rough and rowdy hockey game marked by jolting body checks, angry shoves, threatening gestures and six near fist fights.
CLEVELAND, March 13 (AP) -- A proposed merger of the North American Coal Corporation and Warner Collieries Company was announced by the two concerns yesterday.

New York University took the Little Iron Man Trophy for the third straight year last night in the sixty-second annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships with an outstanding team performance in the foils competition.

TORONTO, March 13 -- Sixty Royal Canadian Mounted Policemen swept down early today on the Six Nations Indian reserve at Ohsweken, Ont. They arrested four members of an insurgent faction that seized the council house last week and established a "government."
CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 13 (AP) -- Boston University upset Navy, 62 -- 55, in overtime tonight in the National Collegiate Eastern regional basketball tournament.
ALBANY, March 13 -- Following is the text of Governor Rockefeller's special message to the Legislature today on providing a remedy for certain labor abuses:
The Court of Appeals will hear new argument on whether the Waterfront Commission has the right to subpoena the books and records of longshore union locals.

With special reference to the threatening crisis over Berlin President Eisenhower has opened the annual battle to maintain the collective military defense of the Western powers and the defensive strength of the whole free world.
The New York Teachers Union said yesterday that if the city failed to grant satisfactory salary increases to teachers, the teachers might be "too ill" to work.

NORFOLK, Va. -- Virginia's countryside starts to bloom in April. In the Tidewater country of the Old Dominion, the tender green of new leaves accents the dark pine woodlands, dogwood is in bloom along the highways and in public and private gardens, and the countryside itself is a garden of wildflowers.

The Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University has announced the names of the five women selected to receive the 1959 Spirit of Achievement awards. The presentations will be made at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria on April 13.

NORWALK, Conn., March 14 -- The heads of several of the this community's largest industries have joined with labor and professional leaders and housewives to re-activate a centralized welfare and charity drive here.
Two teen-age boys were found shot to death just before dawn yesterday in different parts of the city.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 14 -- Contested elections are scheduled in eight of the eleven Suffolk County villages that will vote for officials next Tuesday.

Mrs. Leonard Bernstein and Mrs. Charles Donahue are co-chairmen of the committee for the theatre party to be held for the benefit of the League for Emotionally Disturbed Children. The fete will take place at the May 14 performance of "Destry Rides Again."

LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) -- The skeleton of a ship found recently off Bermuda is not that of the Sea Venture, an English emigrant ship that brought the first settlers to the island 350 years ago, experts here said today.
A considerable amount of behind-the-scenes jockeying for the honor of having the first ship to enter the St. Lawrence Seaway, scheduled to open on April 20, was reported from Montreal last week.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Price and wage developments during last year's recession have brought a quiet revolution in the thinking of key Government economic officials.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- The restoration of this ancient city along the lines of what has been done in Williamsburg and Jamestown, Va., is the aim of the Florida State Government and people here.
THE new everblooming climbing roses show what remarkable improvements have been made in the type in the last ten years. Modern climbers are tailored in growth to blend with contemporary architecture.
FORT WORTH, March 14 (AP) -- Bill Woodhouse of Abilene Christian, aided by a twenty-five-mile-an-hour crosswind, equaled the world's 100-yard dash record of 9.3 seconds today.

THERE is at first sight something extraordinary in the publication of another book on T. E. Lawrence. A great war has come and gone since he died in a road smash. The whole fabric of British-patronized Arab nationalism, based on the Hashimite dynasty, has crashed to the ground.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 14 -- An American offer to help the scientific experiments of other nations by launching earth satellites containing their apparatus was announced here today at the meeting of the Committee of Space Research.
STARA PAZOVA, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- An up-to-date version of an old Balkan institution is working for a revolution in the Yugoslav countryside.

Employment in Pennsylvania has fallen 28,300 below the year-ago level, according to records of the Pennsylvania State Employment Service. Preliminary data indicated about 1,641,000 are employed in the Commonwealth.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- "Why does your Government want to start a war over Berlin?" a taxi driver asked as he sped through the tangled traffic and crowded crossings of Moscow's main thoroughfares.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The abortive revolt in northern Iraq this week was in itself a small, futile thing. But this little affair had political implications and symbolical value for President Nasser of the United Arab Republic, for Premier Kassim of Iraq, for the whole Middle East, for Soviet policy, and for the policies of the United States and the Western powers in the Middle East and in the wider areas of Africa and Asia.
SYRACUSE, March 14 (AP) -- Indian leaders of the Iroquois Confederacy met here today with a retired Army general to plan a march next Thursday on the White House.

The crucial wage negotiations in steel are still two months off, but everyone from President Eisenhower down has already had a word of advice for the union and company bargainers. Members of Congress, economists, industrial executives, labor leaders, editorial writers, television commentators and professional viewers with alarm of every description have set forth in infinite detail their ideas of what the talks signify and what yardsticks both sides should apply in reaching a settlement.
Customs receipts from shipping and aviation activities increased last month by 14.3 per cent over the February, 1958.

A SOLEMN, heavy-faced Englishman who might have been a bishop or a butler, Edward Gratiano Vanbrugh was looking for an escape from his manifold embarrassments. Bored by a dull wife, involved with a blowsy mistress and facing bankruptcy as a singularly incompetent dealer in antiques, he searched for a scapegoat -- and found one in his father.
Flag manufacturers divided yesterday on whether a fifty-star national flag should be adopted speedily or postponed until July 4, 1960.

ON a barren hilltop in west central Korea called Panmunjom, American and Communist negotiators meet frequently around a baize-covered table in an oblong hut of corrugated iron. Five officers on each side of the table represent, respectively, the United Nations Command and the North Korean and Communist Chinese armed forces.

THE amazing increase in the earth's population in recent years, justly described as an "explosion," is shown by the United Nations latest projections to be merely a forerunner of a still greater burst of human multiplication to come. Only sixteen years from now, according to the U. N.'s medium estimates, the earth will contain a billion more people than now, and in forty-one years nearly four billion more.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 14 -- The Mental Health Consultation Center of Bergen County has begun to provide low-cost psychiatric service to adults in a limited form, it was reported today. It was expected that by fall the program would be expanded.

TWELVE self-governing republics have been created among French colonial possessions in Africa. Each is issuing stamps. Some of their stamps have, indeed, already reached New York. Thus once more a point is made which philately has long noted -- namely, that the postage stamp often precedes the map-maker's product.
The Third International Automobile Show will open at the City Coliseum on April 5.
Harvard University's court tennis players won the James H. Van Alen Cup for the fifth successive time yesterday in the intercollegiate tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

BROOKS HAYS, whose lengthy career (1943-58) as Congressman from the Little Rock district was ended in the last November election by a write-in purge supported by Gov. Orval Faubus, has written a brief book quite typical of the man.

THERE are ways left to become more confused about stereophonic sound. One of them is talking about it with the record companies' artists and repertory men, who choose what music you will hear and who will perform it.
Negotiations between the basic steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America will open here May 18.

Parents who make it possible for their children to attend the matinee of the circus in Madison Square Garden on April 10 may be assured that "a treat for their child this spring will bring a treat for an underprivileged child this summer."

JUNEAU, Alaska, March 14 -- Acting Gov. Hugh J. Wade offered the Alaska Legislature yesterday a balanced budget of $26,500,000 for the twelve-month period beginning July 1. The budget does not call for any new tax measures.

THE sometimes disconcerting attempts made so far to record jazz groups stereophonically have brought into the open a rather provocative point: The people who make the recordings -- the jazz A R (Artists and Repertory men) -- have not been at all certain what jazz in stereo should sound like.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 14 -- Long before the electorate designated Danny Murtaugh as manager of the year last season, Bill Mazeroski had become convinced that the Pirate skipper was a genius of such rare perception that he ranked at the top with John McGraw and Dorothy Dix. Murtaugh, you see, also managed Mazeroski into matrimony.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Republican leaders reported today that Philadelphia's chances of winning their 1960 National Convention had lessened since Harold E. Stassen was slated as the G. O. P. candidate for mayor of that city.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- W. S. Miller's Better Bee missed the Gulfstream Park track record for a mile and an eighth by three-fifths of a second while winning the $17,650 Appleton Handicap today.
STOWE, Vt., March 14 -- Bud Werner, America's top Alpine skiing hope in next year's winter Olympics, had a near miss today.

ALL too many trees, shrubs and evergreens that are planted -- although suitable when young -- become too large and broad when mature for the average home grounds. Some species spread rampantly and form dense growths at the expense of other plants.
Optimistic and pessimistic views on the possibility of averting war with the Soviet Union were voiced yesterday by members of the New York Times Forum.

Penicillin, the first of the antibiotics, was discovered accidentally by the late Sir Alexander Fleming in 1928, but it was not until a dozen year later that its powerful potential value was at last recognized. Many more years might have passed before it was made available as one of the most potent weapons against bacterial disease had it not been for the needs of soldiers dying from infected wounds in World War II.
A WILD garden bright with early bulbs is a delightful welcome for spring. Many flowers appear in March while winter is very much around.

Brooklyn College will celebrate its eleventh annual Shakespeare Festival from Wednesday through next Sunday. A symposium of visiting specialists, an exhibit and a presentation of "Romeo and Juliet" will be the highlights of the Festival.

In a program of "Folklore in Film" five tales will be recounted on Thursday at noon and again at 1 P. M. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street. The free showings will include the Grimm brothers' story of "The Gallant Little Tailor."

THE newest plaything for that avant-garde modern composer who has everything is electronic music. This rather mysterious and misleading term is not used very much anymore to refer to Hammond organs, the Theremin, the Ondes Martenot and other such inventions. These are regular musical instruments which happen to have an electronic mechanism instead of a mechanical one.

Iona College of New Rochelle moved a step closer to its second consecutive Collegiate Track Conference title yesterday when it took an early lead in the indoor track and field championships at the Queens College Field House in Flushing.

Already some of the more vocal opposition to President Eisenhower's mutual security progam proposals has revealed some wrong standards in judging what we can do and what we ought to do. There is always a tendency to reduce programs and proposals of this sort to a given number of millions and billions of dollars, and then suggest that across-the-board economies are necessary.

ZUNI, N. M., March 12. -- More than four centuries after the Spanish first came here, the Zuni Indians still carry on their traditional dances, already ancient when Coronado came seeking the seven cities of Cibola.

WHEN William Blackstone (1723-1780), after a singularly unsuccessful fling at the practice of law, turned to teaching in 1758, he was determined to pass on to his students the principles of the English common law rather than the Roman law which made up the standard legal curriculum of his time and which he was convinced had led to his own failure.
A new polio vaccine taken by mouth is being given to every child in Costa Rica and Uruguay in a test to demonstrate its effectiveness.

The explosive Berlin crisis, with all its repercussions, held center stage in Washington last week. It dominated a Presidential news conference and a Presidential message asking support for his mutual security program. It was the theme of Congressional hearings which brought forth the views of the highest officers in the Pentagon.
Nan Robertson's story on Lorraine Hansberry, author of "Raisin in the Sun," was lively and so true about the chances of a Negro writing for our stage.

NOT many people domesticate the otter, yet that charming and playful creature can be a fine pet, as Walter von Sanden proved. Mr. von Sanden and his wife bought an otter, sight unseen and certainly got their money's worth. Ingo became a member of the family, with quarters and bathtub of his own and a devoted servant to feed him.

TAMIKO, an aristocratic, soundly-educated Japanese girl, has more the quality of symbol than central character in Ronald Kirkbride's latest novel. For the author tells us repeatedly that Tamiko is the voice of all he finds best in the ethical tradition of Japan, though her behavior is strangely inconsistent with the demands of this tradition.
JEAN-RABEL, Haiti, March 13 -- More than 45,000 persons are suffering from the thirteen-month drought that has spread famine through this once-productive farming area.

An all-America performance by Tony Jackson carried St. John's to an 82-74 victory over St. Bonaventure and into a semi-final berth in the twenty-second annual National Invitation Tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.

IT may comfort the hi-fi fan who has had to dig deep into both pockets to go stereo to know that record manufacturers find going stereo doubly expensive too. Nevertheless the difference in price between monophonic and stereophonic records is negligible now -- only a dollar separates the two -- and will probably become less as various problems are ironed out.

There is much that is meritorious in the proposal of the National Park Service that the Atlantic Ocean front of Cape Cod be turned into a "national seashore," a permanent noncommercial area designed as a national park. It would cost several million dollars to acquire all the privately owned property on this forty-mile stretch of beach, but it could well be a national investment worth many times its expense.

THE waddling "quill-pig" or porcupine (from the Latin porcus, swine, and spina, thorn) has become so plentiful that organized action has been taken to thin its ranks. Many of the big lumber companies in the West are trying to protect their tree farms by setting traps and poison or by hiring snipers to lay low the prickly beasts.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- Nottingham Forest defeated Aston Villa by 1 -- 0 today and gained the final of the English soccer cup competition for the first time since it captured the trophy in 1898.

We do not hear live performances "stereophonically," therefore, and stereo, instead of giving us "the best seat in the house" gives us, in fact, a kind of omnipresent seat not found in any house.

LONDON, March 14 -- The word "bowler" has had three meanings in English English. The American translations are derby hat, pitcher (in cricket) and player of lawn bowls. A fourth meaning is about to be added.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 14 -- The Government announced today that it had formally recalled its Minister to Albania and left its diplomatic mission there in charge of a junior officer.

HAVANA, March 14 -- An expedition of 112 armed men is reported to have been halted and the men arrested by Cuban revolutionary authorities as the expedition left a beach near Santiago de Cuba on the way to make a landing in the Dominican Republic.

The House Ways and Means Committee has voted to taper off over a period of three months the emergency unemployment benefit program, which would otherwise automatically expire at the end of this month. The committee's action seeks to avoid an abrupt cut-off of such aid to an estimated 300,000 workers who will be drawing benefits as of March 31.
HONOLULU, March 14 -- The tempo of living shows signs of speeding up from a saunter to a leisurely walk as Hawaii, "Paradise of the Pacific," prepares for the responsibilities of statehood.

BAY HEAD, N. J., March 14 -- Commissioner Salvatore A. Bontempo, head of the New Jersey State Department of Conservation and Economic Development, was honored today as the man in public life who has made the most important contribution to boating in the state.
BONN, Germany, March 14 -- Alfried Krupp called today for a quick Allied decision to release him from the obligation of selling the Krupp company's vast coal and iron holdings.
The Young Men's Philanthropic League Junior Auxiliary will give a cocktail party next Sunday in the Roosevelt. Daniel A. Birnant is president of the nonsectarian organization.

Bruce Heiss, 15-year-old brother of Carol Heiss, the women's world figure skating champion, won the senior men's singles event in the thirty-eighth annual Middle Atlantic Championship at Iceland last night.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 14 (Reuters) -- Two thousand persons were killed and hundreds more injured in the unsuccessful uprising against the regime of Premier Kassim in northern Iraq last week-end. The Baghdad newspaper Al Thawra reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- Europeans are eating more fish from their inland waters than they used to, Present commercial production is about 100,000 metric tons a year, an increase of 10,000 tons in about five years.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 14 -- Swedish labor has been hailed by industry for its "responsible" attitude in accepting a wage cut to keep Swedish products competitive on the world market.

WHITE PLAINS, March 14 -- When twenty of the twenty-two incorporated villages of Westchester County go to the polls on Tuesday fifteen will have contests for Mayor, Trustee or Police Justice.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 14 -- A 200-mile run, mostly on citrus grove dirt roads, provided a challenge today for the fifty-one cars in Florida's Great Orange Blossom Rally. This was the second day of the three-day national championship event of the Sports Car Club of America.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 -- Construction of a three-story, $5,500,000 cargo-passenger terminal as part of a long-range port development program has been tentatively approved by the Long Beach Harbor Commission. WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The jargon of the Battle of the Budget is a confusing thing to the uninitiated. The words "authorization" and "appropriation," for example, are much used and little understood. Sometimes the confusion is compounded by erroneous use of the term "expenditure" as a synonym for appropriation or authorization.

The Development and Scholarship Fund of the Professional Childern's School will benefit from an evening at the ballet. The school has taken a number of orchestra and parterre box seats at the Metropolitan Opera House for the April 22 performance by the Bolshoi Ballet.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 14 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette and Warren Spahn, the two pitching aces of the Milwaukee Braves, each yielded a three-run homer today, and the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the National League champions for the third time in three spring exhibitions, 8 -- 1.

Glazier collection. NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. March 14 -The inauguration of Dr. Mason W. Gross as sixteenth president of Rutgers University has been set for May 6.

E. A. (Bill) Butler, an energetic young man who heads his own management consulting concern, has many of the manners and attitudes of the legendary denizen of Madison Avenue.

AN ancient Goldwynism relates to the movie-theatre operator who, on being asked how was business, replied: "Colossal, but maybe it will pick up after Labor Day."

BOSTON, March 14 -- A new chapter in the battle of Walden Pond in Concord, Mass., was written this week in the State Supreme Judicial Court. The Save Walden Committee of the Thoreau Society filed an appeal from the Superior Court's vacating of a temporary injunction that halted construction work at the pond reservation.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Jerome D. Fenton quit today as general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, saying he has to earn more money than the $20,000 a year the job pays.

THE new large-flowered African violet hybrids are charming additions to the list of popular house plants. Many varieties are marked by interesting and improved foliage. They grow well in the average home. Double-flowering types require water and fertilizer more frequently than the single-flowered sorts.

The New York Cardiac Home, 1440 Broadway, has taken over the May 8 performance of "Destry Rides Again" for its annual theatre benefit.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- "The day of missionary colonialism, as well as political colonialism, is over," a church leader said today.
SUFFERN, N. Y., March 14 -- There will be contests in nine of the eleven Rockland County village elections Tuesday. In six, the contests are between Republicans and Democrats.
BRISBANE, Australia, March 14 -- Herb Elliott ran the mile in 3 minutes 58.9 seconds today and then apologized for not producing a faster clocking.
Production of paperboard has been moving along at a rapid clip in recent weeks. It was near a record level at last report.

SEATTLE, March 14 -- Tobias Stone, a leading figure of international tournament bridge, was barred last night from competing in American Contract Bridge League tournaments because of "conduct unbecoming a (league) member."
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will sign the Hawaiian statehood bill early next week.

The Belmont Spring Ball will be held on May 30 at the John S. Phipps estate in Old Westbury, L. I. For the second successive year the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will be the beneficiary.
BOWIE, Md., March 14 -- Hare Raising, a 6-1 shot from the W. H. Bishop Stables, won the $28,750 Bowie Handicap by three lengths today after surviving a foul claim.

The six-week debate over higher income taxes for New York State ended last week. A modified Republican tax program passed by a margin of one vote in the State Senate and two in the Assembly. GENEVA, March 7 -- "Urgent and intense" problems have been raised by the present high rates of population growth, the United Nations Population Commission found at its recent tenth session here.

In the Middle East, long dominated by the struggle of Arab nationalists vs. the West, the focus now is upon the struggle of Arabs vs. Arabs. The followers of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic are in conflict with Arabs influenced by communism.

KINGS POINT, L. I., March 14 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy won the sectional championship of the National Rifle Association's intercollegiate title matches today. The Mariners scored 1,437 points.

HARTFORD, March 14 -- A political and legislative free-for-all broke out at the State Capitol this week over the proposal by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to abolish all of the 168 town and city courts which have been in existence in Connecticut since 1639.

Construction of a revolutionary new type of "atomic microscope" in which electrons, the negatively charged fundamental particles of matter, will be made to collide head-on with an effective total energy of one billion electron-volts, will begin soon at Stanford University, it was announced last week.

While we are as fascinated as the next man by the space race, we take leave to wonder whether it isn't time we stopped being hypnotized by it, and came down to earth again.
IN "77 Sunset Strip," a program shown Friday nights over the American Broadcasting Company television network, Efrem Zimbalist Jr. plays the role of a Hollywood private detective named Stuart Bailey.
