IN Asia Minor, where today poverty-stricken Turkish peasants lead their unvarying primitive lives, Homer once smote his lyre and Thales helped launch the science of physics. It was an exciting and dynamic place in ancient days, and the ruins of its bygone greatness are still visible all over the landscape.

AS musicians who teach, we cannot escape from the grand argument on how best to educate American youth. If we are to succeed in preserving and expanding music's place as one of the basic humanities to which man should be exposed in his formative years, we must be prepared to prove that we teach music with a high regard for its serious educational values.

NEW HAVEN, March 14 -- More than 1,000 students at Yale University rioted today as the last division of a St. Patrick's Day parade passed the campus. Eight students were treated for injuries and sixteen were arrested.
PARIS, March 14 (AP) -- Herb Carper, a former University of Pittsburgh sprinter, equaled his own world indoor record for the 60-yard dash today by running the distance in 6 seconds.
EVANSTON, Ill., March 14 -- Dr. Forest R. Noffsinger, safety-education specialist of Northwestern University's Traffic Institute, has issued some startling statistics On teen-age drivers.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Customs Bureau has ruled as illegal the proposed cruise of a British-owned ship from San Francisco to Honolulu, Vancouver, B. C., and back to San Francisco.

MOMBASA, Kenya, March 1 -- The celebrated dhows are still the most picturesque aspect of Mombasa's harbor. But the progress of Kilindini, its new port, is all the more striking because of the counterpoint of the dhows.

MACAO, March 14 -- Despite the appalling poverty of this overpopulated and decaying island colony of Portugal, terror-stricken refugees from Communist China continue to seek haven here at a rate of 200 to 300 a month.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 12 -- What the new Jewish immigration from Eastern Europe will mean to most Israelis will be painfully emphasized beginning April 1.
The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation reported over the week-end gains in gross revenues, net income and sales for 1958.

When the National Hockey League game ended at Madison Square Garden last night, the Toronto Maple Leaf skaters joyfully pounded their goalie, Johnny Bower, on the back. Their exuberance was unregained, despite the fact that lower had yielded five goals of the New York Rangers.

PITTSBURGH, March 13 -- Up and down the river valleys of western Pennsylvania smoke is shooting once again from steel mill stacks. After two years of recession and unemployment, it is a signal read in various ways by various persons.

The touring Halsingborg team of Sweden and Hakoah of the American League sloshed through ninety minutes of soccer yesterday at Ebbets Field and all the elevens got out of it was a tie game -- and a mud bath.

There was nothing humorous in the riots that took place at Yale University twice within the past week. They were, as President Griswold said, "childish" and "boorish." The young men involved -- over a thousand of them on Saturday -- "disregarded the rights of their fellow-citizens and failed to live up to their responsibilities as members of the community."
The mass was described yesterday as "a living memorial'' of the passion of Christ. The Rev. Raymond T. Powers made the observation at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The first annual Conference for Student Editors ended at the Overseas Press Club yesterday.

Henry Purcell, who died in 1695 at the age of 34, is considered England's greatest composer. He is much written about, but aside from a few pieces his music is seldom played. Thus the program of Purcell's sacred vocal music Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Museum was of more than ordinary interest.
Man's eventual conquest of space was seen yesterday as a powerful force that will strengthen religious beliefs, merge world cultures and generally make life easier.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, left his hospital room today for an hour and twenty-five minutes to ride through the park and visit at home with his toy French poodle Pepin.

After an ownership of one year, Ren-Lef Properties, Inc., resold the six-story apartment house at 354 Ocean Avenue, corner of Woodruff Avenue, Brooklyn, to an investing client of Jack Convisser of Caserta Co., brokers. The building occupies a plot 134 by 100 feet and contains fifty-four apartments.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 15 -- Dr. Michael F. Walsh, Superintendent of Education for Rhode Island, warned tonight that professionalism and commercialism threatened amateur sports in the United States.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack said yesterday that he was against one-way traffic on Third and Fifth Avenues, as proposed by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

Those of us who live round about the Pacific Ocean but who are not in the cold war are naturally impatient over the delay in an agreement being reached at Geneva about the suspension of test explosions.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 (AP) -- About 4,000 Yale University undergraduates remained confined to their campus today as the aftermath of a St. Patrick's Day parade yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority accepted with pleasure and alacrity yesterday its nomination as "managing and fiscal agent" for commuter rail equipment.
The Parents Association of the New York School for Nursery Years has chosen this Thursday's performance this "Sweet Bird of Youth," at Martin Beck Theatre, for its annual benefit.
Pliable clay seems to be the best material for Marshall Brown.

TOKYO, March 15 -- The North Korean Red Cross agreed today to meet with Japanese Red Cross representatives in Geneva on "practical matters" concerned with repatriation of Koreans in Japan who wish to go to North Korea.
MACAO, March 15 -- Although the effort and risk in escaping from Communist China have increased, the number of refugees arriving in Macao each month has not declined.

SHEFFIELD, Mass., March 15 -- There has been something strange happening on the nearby Hillsdale (N. Y.) Road. At a point where the Massachusetts boundary meets the New York line, a school bus has been discharging students almost daily.
FRESNO, Calif., March 15 -- The projected abolition of primary "cross-filing," which has long made California politics a puzzle, may be thwarted by a battle within the Democratic party.

THIS is the time to register for a summer camp. From now through April, parents and youngsters must make their decisions or risk being disappointed about the camp of their choice. Even at this seemingly early date, some camps have almost a complete enrollment for the coming eight-week season, which generally begins the first week of July.

Many "long-entrenched underworld leaders" have left the state because of recent jail sentences for seven silent gangsters, the State Investigation Commission said yesterday in its first annual report.

The steadily rising tension between Albania and Yugoslavia has now led President Tito's Government formally to recall its Ambassador to Tirana. Whether this step will be a prelude to a rupture of diplomatic relations remains to be seen, but certainly the volume and intensity of the verbal abuse now being exchanged between those two countries has no equal anywhere else in Europe.
HONOLULU, March 15 -- Hawaiian leaders tentatively bill Quinn vs. Burns as the main event of the first elections of the fiftieth state.

STOWE, Vt., March 15 -- Joan Hannah, the Bennington College sophomore who does her best when it is least expected, turned in one of her surprises today by capturing the Vermont downhill skiing championship.
A New York Times survey of metropolitan transportation problems has stimulated ordinary citizens, engineering speialists and public officials to propose a variety of approaches to the problem.

Psychoanalysts were told here yesterday that opportunities for research in the understanding of dreams and the nature of psychic processes had been opened up through Dr. Nathaniel Kleitman's techniques for the investigation of dreams.

" OMNIBUS," which in the past has had good luck in pursuing items of nostalgia, fared less fortunately yesterday afternoon in the revival of "Forty-five Minutes From Broadway," the George M. Cohan musical of 1906.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 15 -- A spokesman for the United Arab Republic's First (Syrian) Army charged thirty Iraqis crossed the frontier today and attacked two Syrian guards.
SEATTLE, March 15 -- Western contact bridge pairs this afternoon won the men's and women's championships, opening events in the Spring National championships.

BONN, Germany, March 15 -- A German Jewish write, troubled by the meaning of a recent flare-up of anti-Semitism, has posed the question of whether Jews in West Germany should "prepare for emigration again."
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced over the week-end that C. L. Burrill and H. W. Fisher had been designated candidates for election as directors at the annual meeting May 27.

The city's proposal to tax stock transfers was attacked yesterday by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange. The imposition of a city tax, he said, might drive the securities business from the city and force the Exchange to move out of the state.
CHICAGO, March 15 -- Radio and television stations would like to editorialize just as newspapers do but they are hindered by a lack of governmental clarification of the thorny "equal time" issue.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 15 -- Sir Edmund Hillary, who with the Sherpa Tenzing conquered Mount Everest, said here today that Communist China had ignored his request for permission to lead a scientific and mountaineering expedition to the north face of Everest in April, 1960.
Milton Stern, pianist, made his appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday evening.

New York spent anxious hours last fall as Hurricane Helene swirled up the Atlantic from the Caribbean. Down along the Eastern seaboard where Helene was a more immediate menace the waiting period was worse.
Roger Tuckerman of Harvard retained the John Hay Whitney Cup as intercollegiate court tennis champion yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek's message formally opening Congress today declared the hemisphere's economic development with massive United States aid "triumphs all along the line."
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- One of the Federal Government's three new assaults on national economic problems has borne fruit in an extraordinary form of limited price regulation.

Governor Rockefeller has served the public interest in his message to the Legislature, and the accompanying bill, dealing with financial abuses in labor unions and participation in them of business management. His contribution is notable, not only in the wisdom of the curbs he favors but in his approach to the whole problem of improper practices in the labor and management field which has been so thoroughly documented by the McClellan committee.
MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Soviet Union declared today it considered its nonaggression treaty with Iran still in full effect despite the Iranian Government's recent denunciation of certain clauses.
" WHEN we saw customers trying on skirts in the telephone booths, we knew the time had come for us to expand."
Dr. Ferdinand Durcansky, who served as Foreign Minister of the Nazi puppet regime in Slovakia in 1939-40, made his first public appearance here yesterday.
" DON CARLO," one of the finest works in the Verdi canon, returned to the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night. It was late in the season, the end of the twentieth week, but better than not at all.
Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has set up a separate electronics division and has chosen Dr. Louis N. Ridenour to head it as general manager.
Frances Langford, who withdrew from the entertainment world after her marriage in 1955 to Ralph Evinrude, returned last night in a special hour-long variety attraction over Channel 4.
Prices of cotton futures were generally lower last week, with only the near-by May contract showing a gain.
Each day at sundown, motorists commuting over the Henry Hudson Parkway witness a "black blizzard" of birds at 125th Street.
To combat what it called an "emergency" economic situation, the Liberal party of New York State made public yesterday a 9,000-word national legislative program.

BONN, Germany, March 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that the West must be ready for a series of summit meetings with the Soviet Union drawn out over several months after the opening session, which probably will take place this year.
Two tunnels will be cut through the Palisades at Fort Lee as part of expanded New Jersey approaches for the second deck of the George Washington Bridge.
The task of solving the troubles of the key company in the onetime financial empire of Alexander L. Guterma has been described by three new directors as too tough.

Building service employes in 2,300 mid - Manhattan commercial structures have won a $3 weekly increase under a wage reopener in a three-year contract that has one year to run. Time and a half pay for Sundays also is provided.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 15 -- The Stock Exchange's response to last week's Dutch elections for the lower chamber was tepid and undecided.
Bruno Walter will return to the Metropolitan Opera after a season's absence to conduct performances of the Verdi "Requiem" on Good Friday (March 27) and Easter Sunday (March 29).
The cable ship Monarch began laying the first telephone cable between North America and the mainland of Europe yesterday.

Lou Rossini, New York University's coach, Oscar Robertson of Cincinnati and Bob Pettit of the St. Louis Hawks were among those honored last night at the twenty-sixth annual awards dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Manhattan.

PARIS, Monday, March 16 -- The French Communist and Socialist parties, both hostile to the Government of President Charles de Gaulle, appeared early today to be still strong as a result of run-off elections yesterday for 17,760 municipal councils.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 15 (UPI) -- The Iraqui Foreign Minister, Dr. Hashim Jawad, charged today that the abortive revolt last week against the Baghdad Government was "organized by the United Arab Republic" and supplied with its weapons.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced price discrimination charges today against the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company of New York City, Mohasco Industries of Amsterdam, N. Y., and Hat Corporation of America, South Norwalk, Conn.

I refer to your court reform editorials of Feb. 9 and March 9, both of which insist that the Republican bill (Mitchell-Walmsley) "incorporates the judicial conference proposals," and that the differences between it and the Democratic bill (Zaretzki-Travia) are minor.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 15 (UPI) -- The Soviet Ambassador is leaving Iran, following the signing of the Iranian-United States defense pact.

Joseph G. Luberda, the retired police sergeant whose finances are being investigated will be offered immunity from prosecution today if he will tell the Kings County rackets grand jury how he had acquired his wealth. If he fails to tell, he may face a new jail term.

The current concern of professional educators over the loyalty oath that will be required of scholarship recipients under the National Defense Education Act of 1958 prompts the observation that this may be unfair to the students, but is hardly more than the educators deserve.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Mrs. William B. Long's Pembroke Welsh Corgi, Ch. Cote de Neige Sundew of Concord, Mass., became the best-inshow winner of the biggest event ever held by the National Capital Kennel Club tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 15. -- A leading rocket expert said today that liquid-propellant rocket engines with 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 pounds thrust would be available in the not-too-distant future.
Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy called on 6,000 members of the Police Department yesterday to use the Lenten season as a "time of inventory to improve our moral and professional lives."
Six films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
HONOLULU, March 15 -- Less than a year ago John Anthony Burns was regarded by many Hawaiians as little short of a traitor to his island constituency.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The members of President Eisenhower's Cabinet are being subjected to bipartisan criticism at the Capitol for their failure to turn up at last Wednesday's joint session of Congress.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 15 -- A champion 4 1/2-year-old Great Dane took the top award in an entry of 749 tonight in the forty-third annual all-breed show of the Providence County Kennel Club.

LONDON, March 15 -- Diplomats here regard as highly speculative a theory that the Soviet Union is using the Berlin and German problems to force the West to abandon all political aspirations in Eastern Europe. This would involve the West's acceptance of an all-European settlement.
The Port of New York Authority opened Newark Airport to jet aircraft yesterday on a "stand-by" basis. Heretofore the airliners had been restricted to New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 (AP) -Michael Roche won the Middle Atlantic badminton championship for the fourth straight year by defeating Dick Bail in an aliBaltimore final today at St. Joseph's College.

DETROIT, March 15 (AP) -- Gene Shue kept Detroit in the National Basketball Association's Western Division play-offs by scoring 32 points tonight as the Pistons stopped the Minneapolis Lakers, 117 -- 103. The Piston victory evened the two-of-three series. The deciding game will be played Wednesday at Minneapolis.
SYRACUSE, March 15 -- The New York Knickerbockers reached the end of the trail today. A 131-115 defeat by the Syracuse Nationals eliminated them from the National Basketball Association play-offs.

One worker in every fourteen was jobless last month. The regular joint report of the Federal Labor and Commerce Departments showed 4,749,000 unemployed and 62,722,000 employed. The total of idle was 424,000 below the figure for the recession month of February, 1958, but 1,628,000 above that for the pre-recession month of February, 1957.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15 (AP) -- Louise Suggs won her fourth women's Titleholders golf championship today with one of her finest clutch rounds. Miss Suggs fired a 1-under-par 71 for 297 and withstood a brilliant bid by Betsy Rawls.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The Republican legislative leaders are expected to go along with the tax program that Mayor Wagner put before Governor Rockefeller yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Lobo de Mar, a sixty-seven-foot cutter, sailed far ahead of her rivals tonight in the twenty-sixth annual St. Petersburg - to - Havana yacht race.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Robert F. Kennedy, chief counsel to the Senate rackets committee, has received anonymous threats from a telephone caller that someone would throw acid in the eyes of his six children.
Unemployment is a figure in a Government report, as dreary and lifeless as the Federal debt or the death rate.
DETROIT, March 11 -- Mrs. Charles Lawrence listened quietly as her husband, a carpenter, sat in the living room of his small Oak Park home and told about his futile efforts to get a job.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -The Government is being urged by a group of universities to construct a national center that specializes in research into the earth's weather.
THE sun has set on the Edwardian Empire in Britain. The Flare Line is next on the horizon.

A MORE original or striking first novel than "Spinster,"* by Sylvia Ashton-Warner, is not likely to be published this year. Although novels about old maid schoolteachers have been published before as well as novels written almost entirely in the present tense and in the stream-of-consciousness technique, "Spinster" still does not seem even remotely like any other novel I can recall at the moment.

ALBANY, March 15 -- A comprehensive program for solving commuter problems and the financial difficulties of rail and bus lines was submitted to Governor Rockefeller today by Robert W. Purcell, his special consultant on transportation.
Mary Lyons, coloratura soprano who made her debut here in 1951, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The chief of the Uzbek Republic's Communist party and one of his aides have been ousted from their posts because of "serious shortcomings and mistakes" in virtually every aspect of party activity, the Soviet press reported today.
HONOLULU, March 15 (AP) -- Government investigators say the Communist menace in Hawaii is waning.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 5 -- Natural gas has been found by oil prospectors in the Judean wilderness, west of the Dead Sea.

PARIS, March 15 -- A "Common Market mentality" is developing swiftly in France. Observers credit it with advancing the new European economic community at least as much as steps taken by the Government under the Common Market treaty.
PRACTICALITY has become a secondary attribute of plastic plates, cups and saucers with the introduction this spring of many floral patterns.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Grain futures brokers on the Board of Trade appeared last week to have priced themselves out of some competitive commercial advantage on broad advances for December contracts.
DAVOS, Switzerland, March 15 (AP) -- Nando Pajarola of Switzerland won the 6.2-kilometer (3.85-mile) Parsenn Derby ski race today in 6 minutes 1.2 seconds.
VENICE March 15 -- The very idea is enough to make any true Venetian's hair stand on end.

Volume slacked off last week in the steamship charter market as vessel owners showed renewed resistance to prevailing low rates. Rates were off slightly, forcing another dip in the freight rate index.
MILWAUKEE, March 15 (AP) -- A passenger train with 150 tired and hungry persons aboard -- stuck in the snowdrifts of a late winter storm -- was pulled free by five Diesel units tonight.

Representatives of those supposed archenemies -- life insurance companies and mutual funds -- sat down at a press luncheon last week and had nothing but nice things to say for each other. There were also a representative of the banking industry and several from mutual fund plan sponsors.

State Controller Arthur Levitt said last night that he would urge the passage of legislation to permit the State Dormitory Authority to help private colleges and universities build classrooms and conduct other instructional activities.
Traffic will be detoured from an area of Riverside Drive beginning this morning to permit reconstruction of the elevated structure between West 153d and 155th Streets.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- The Cardinals had vacated Al Lang Field before noon yesterday, leaving it to the Yankees and Dodgers. But some of the older stragglers remained in the clubhouse, their work for the day over. Stan Musial, Sal Maglie, Marv Grissom and a few others were sitting in front of their lockers when Don Zimmer walked in, a glint in his eye and a chip on his shoulder.

RUTLAND, Vt., March 15 (AP) -- Mike Wallace of Boston Unversity became the first two-time winner of the downhill award and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology captured the team prize today in the eleventh annual Walter Foley Memorial Trophy ski races at Killington basin.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York said tonight that the public had a right to be upset when Congress members employed relatives simply "to ride the gravy train."
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A free-for-all on foreign aid will begin tomorrow when Congress opens hearings on President Eisenhower's proposals for next year's program.
Louisville's torrid basketball team is two victories away from a grand-slam of upsets in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's post-season tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) -- The sponsor of a bill to reward "do-it-yourself" pension plans denied today that it would open a tax loophole for the wealthy.
A GRAPHIC review of the campaign to supply China during World War II was shown last night on "The Twentieth Century" over Channel 2.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Eisenhower has received strong backing for his controversial defense policies from Gen. Thomas D. White, Chief of Staff of the Air Force.

ROME, March 15 -- The Christian Democratic party, the principal force in Italian politics, appeared deeply split in a crucial caucus today. Left-wing factions were feuding with moderates and conservatives over the extent of party support for the new Center-Right Government of Premier Antonio Segni and over control of the party machine.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -With time approaching when exhibition games begin to take on some meaning, it should be understandable why Solly Hemus, a quiet, serious-minded fellow, allowed himself to indulge in a broad smile today as he walked off Al Lang Field.
CAIRO, March 15 -- Cairo received with remarkable calm today a report of yesterday's renewed violation of Syrian air space by Iraqi Air Force fighters.
A national policy of "thinking small" in fighting communism was advocated yesterday by the president of the Navy League.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Mrs. Cecilia De Mille Harper, daughter of the late Cecil B. De Mille, today announced that she would carry through with the filming of "On My Honor," and that Henry Wilcoxon would be the producer.

Christian Ferras, a young violinist with a big talent, reinforced in a sonata recital at Hunter College last night the considerable impression he had made in his United States debut last Wednesday with the Boston Symphony.

Alfred Letourner arrived at New York International Airport, idlewild, Queens, yesterday with the contracts of twenty-six European competitors in the six-day bicycle race starting Sunday night at the 102d Engineers Armory.
LONDON, March 15 -- International development affected the stock market adversely early last week. But there was a gradual recovery and the week closed on an optimistic note.

If it is any consolation to the citizens of New York, the people of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania are having their tax troubles, too. In Pennsylvania -- as almost everywhere else, for that matter -- the problem is the collision between the pressure for more services by the state and the people's reluctance to pay for them.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 15 (Reuters) -- A nonwhite was killed and two wounded tonight as resistance to the Federal Government drive against militant nationalist leaders flared in the northern part of Nyasaland.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 10 -- Thousands of unemployed coal miners have used up their "rockin' chair money" and are living on "mollygrub" in the coal fields of West Virginia.
More than 1,000 printers voted yesterday to ask union permission to take a strike vote against ten newspapers in the New York area.

The consolidated net income of the nation's largest lead producer, the St. Joseph Lead Company, dropped sharply last year. It fell to $3,986,880, equal to $1.47 a common share, from $8,026,273, or $2.95 a share, in the preceding year, the company reported over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended March 14:
Committees have been chosen to plan for a theatre benefit for Guideposts for Children, Inc., under the chairmanship of Mrs. Clyde M. Newhouse.
OTTAWA, March 15 -- The next moves in the struggle between Newfoundland's Government and the striking loggers of the International Woodworkers of America are expected to come from Ottawa tomorrow.
Twenty-year-old Ronald Chapman, who was released from city penitentiary only last Monday, was charged yesterday in the slaying of an aged man for 35 cents.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 15 -- Jack and Irene Steinbuhler of Titusville, Pa., won the Great Orange Blossom Rally today in a Jaguar 150 coupe. Jack navigated and his wife was driver on the three-day event of 753 miles that opened the 1959 national championship program of the Sports Car Club of America.
FORTY-SIX years ago, when George MacManus created two comic strip characters known as Maggie and Jiggs, he started a legend relating corned beef to the Irish. That legend still persists to this day.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his support of legislation to improve retirement conditions for the city's school teachers.

A report to Governor Rockefeller by his special consultant on transportation offers, for discussion and action a new program dealing with commuter railroad problems and the omnibus industry, which has long been suffering attrition, especially upstate. Robert W. Purcell, author of the report in consultation with several advisers of varied experience, received his assignment in mid-January and has been under the necessity of presenting his report quickly in anticipation of early adjournment of the Legislature.
Frances Lanahan, daughter of F. Scott Fitzgerald, is writing a musical comedy about grass-roots politics.
Bob Sweeney and Cathy Lewis have been chosen to star in the TV series "Fibber McGee and Molly."
TRENTON, March 15 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner feels the report on rail commuter problems prepared by Robert W. Purcell must be subjected to a thorough analysis.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) -- A new citizens' group called today for a 50 per cent slash in President Eisenhower's $3,929,995,000 foreign aid program. It also proposed an end to foreign aid within three years.

PARIS, March 15 -- On leaving one area of crisis, North Africa, for another area of crisis, Europe, one wonders how the great statesmen who dwell perpetually amid these crises can possibly survive the strain. An answer was perhaps offered this week when the Royal Academy opened a one-man London show of paintings by Sir Winston Churchill.

The Electricar Manufacturing Corporation of Freeport, L. I., one of the largest manufacturers of electrically operated golf carts in the country, has leased office and showroom space in the Tyler Building, 17 John Street. The deal was negotiated by the Henry Baker Management Company.
Opposition to off-track betting for tax purposes was urged yesterday by the social action committee of the Union Church of Bay Ridge, Presbyterian, Ridge Boulevard at Eighty-first Street in Brooklyn.
The New York City Committee on Slum Clearance will recommend to Mayor Wagner today that further steps be taken toward starting the Soundview cooperative middle-income housing project in the Bronx.
Suggestions that the longstanding dispute between airline pilots and flight engineers has affected the safety of some passenger flights were made yesterday by the flight engineers' union.

Scotland is preparing for a fete for a "clan" this summer. It will be made up of some 30,000 foreign-trade buyers expected to attend the third Scottish Industries Exhibition in Glasgow's Kelvin Hall, Sept. 3 to 19.

PITTSBURGH, March 15 -- A further increase in steel order volume, another expansion in backlogs, higher steel output and fear that many orders were being duplicated were highlights of the steel market last week.

CLEVELAND, March 15 -- The outlook for an accelerated Great Lakes iron ore movement in 1959 became brighter today when the American Iron Ore Association reported January consumption exceeded that of the 1957 period by more than 1,500,000 tons.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 15 -- The world hockey tournament swept to a tremendously exciting, bone-jarring close today as Czechoslovakia upset Canada, 5 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Western Allies are beginning to draw together on Berlin and Germany, and on foreign ministers' and summit conferences with the Soviet Union to deal with these problems.
The April 4 performance of "Juno" will benefit the New Dramatist Committee. The musical opened March 9 at the Winter Garden.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 15 -- The tin industry, long the mainstay of the Bolivian economy, is now a burden to it -- a burden being shared with increasing discomfort by the United States.
The Alabama Highway Authority is planning the sale of $20,000,000 of highway revenue bonds on April 7. Dated May 1, the bonds will come due serially on May 1 from 1960 to 1979.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 15 -- By far the major part of all stock exchange business last week was in the stocks of three Swiss holding companies whose chief assets are in other countries. They are Interhandel, Italo-Suisse and Swiss Metallwerte.

Skaidrite Prince, Latvian soprano, made her United States debut in a recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Miss Prince sang arias by Wagner and Verdi, songs of Schubert, Brahms, Grieg and Strauss, a group of Latvian songs ,and other works of Carissimi, Haydn, Gounod, Fenton and Tyson.
Meldrum Fewsmith, Inc., of Cleveland, and the Barnes Chase Company of San Diego, Calif., are joining to form an organization with annual billings involving $15,000,000.
About 200 men, women and children paraded quietly in East Harlem yesterday in a demonstration urging the city to help narcotic addicts fight the habit.
A worker who earns $4,500 a year has to labor almost one working day out of three just to pay his taxes, according to Tax Foundation, Inc.

David Wark Griffith, a pioneer in the film industry, is the subject of a biography by Homer Croy, called "Star Maker." Griffith, who died in 1948, constantly lived in the limelight, but his personal life was "shrouded" in reticence.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 15 -- Eleven Federal employes today won the Rockefeller Public Service Awards for the academic year 1959-60. Five were honor graduates of New York City high schools in the Nineteen Twenties and Thirties.

SALISBURY, March 15 -- The African Railway Workers Union, meeting in Ndola, Northern Rhodesia, warned last night that it might resort to strikes and stoppages if the Government of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland failed to broaden job opportunities for its membership.

Either all gambling for money is illegal and morally unacceptable, or else none of it should be. If off-track betting and commercial bingo are "legal," why not every other type of gambling? Should not all anti-gambling laws be repealed? And if we are willing to take any of our support from such sources why not be consistent and derive a really good income from gambling as a whole ?

DUBLIN, March 15 -- Last week's attack on the Northern Ireland border at Clogher, County Tyrone, was condemned by Premier Eamon de Valera today at a meeting of his party members in Mullingar, County West Meath.
The "cold war" between Protestants and Roman Catholics is in the process of "thawing out," the Rev. John B. Sheerin, editor of The Catholic World, said yesterday.

The chairmen for the eleventh annual Spring Frolic and officers and directors of the Humane Society of New York will be guests at a cocktail party to be given tomorrow by Mr. and Mrs. August M. Funke at their home, 784 Park Avenue.
Following is the text of Pesident Eisenhower's radio and television address last night from Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

In your editorial March 1 you refer to the problem of the annual spring floods. You mention that every swamp that is drained, every bog that is filled, adds to the flood problem. We have created one new flood factor for every old one that we bring under control.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation that would make it easier to prosecute persons who commit offenses against the Government while abroad.
The National Fund for Medical Education announced yesterday that it had awarded grants totaling $2,925,180 to the nation's eighty-two accredited medical schools.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of L. Judson Morhouse, Republican State Chairman, to fill a vacancy on the State Thruway Authority that has existed for more than a year.
Many dinner parties will be given before tonight's performance of "Redhead" at the Forty-Sixth Street Theatre for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.
Studies just completed in Paris show poliomyelitis viruses to be very sensitive to increases in the temperature of the body or to changes in the normal alkalinity of body fluids.
A petition for the establishment of a grievance procedure in the Police Department was denied in State Supreme Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The director of the United States Information Agency called today for more understanding and less patronizing by Americans who want to get along with foreigners.
WHITE PLAINS, March 16 -- Westchester's demand for a county tax on admissions at the Yonkers Raceway was modified today because of opposition in the Legislature.

JERSEY CITY, March 16 -- The City Commission today slashed $5,370,183 from the proposed city budget. The cut reduced the 1959 tax rate from an estimated figure of $103.84 to $89.95 on each $1,000 of assessed valuation.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- A two-stage mystery missile pierced the clouds with a crackling roar today on a security-cloaked flight test.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Jazz came to Washington tonight under the most respectable auspices in town.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quietly steady yesterday. Prices were unchanged to 2 points lower except for the old May contract, which advanced 7 points. A point is 5 cents a bale.
TAMPA, Fla., March 16 -- Throughout spring training last year Birdie Tebbetts kept rubbing his eyes in disbelief. The then manager of the Reds would watch Vada Pinson in action and shake his head.
Harry Shapolsky, a 48-yearold real estate operator who has been described as a "front man for high officials" in the Department of Buildings, was convicted yesterday of rent gouging.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The highest - ranking Soviet official to defect to the West has supplied United States intelligence with an intimate view of the Kremlin rulers and their private lives, it was disclosed today.
A five - month - old infant was rescued recently by two Bronx policemen who had received Red Cross first aid training. The child had stopped breathing.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The Legislature appeared ready tonight to give the Department of Conservation broader powers to control deer-hunting limits.
Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover carried a preachment of austerity to the Yale Club last night and said that the American standard of living was a product more of luck than of brains.
About 250 volunteer workers of the Friends of the Philharmonic were guests at a tea given yesterday by Mrs. Robert F. Wagner at Gracie Mansion.

TOKYO, March 16 -- While the fate of more than 600,000 Koreans in Japan is being bitterly debated on international levels, the persons most directly concerned are also divided in their wishes for their future.

Cutter Laboratories, Berkeley, Calif., pharmaceutical producer, has signed an agreement to acquire the assets of Olympic Plastics Company, Inc., and Oylmpic Containers, Inc., both of Los Angeles. The terms were not disclosed.

Britain's J. Arthur Rank Organization announced yesterday that it would cease to distribute its own films in this country, effective March 28. The announcement marks another terminal point in the efforts of the company to secure a wider footing on the American film scene.

LONDON, March 16 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will urge President Eisenhower to accept a British proposal for the limitation and inspection of troops and arms in Central Europe as a salient point of Western policy in projected negotiations with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- All imports of crude and unfinished oils will require specific authorization after midnight tonight.
Belated attacks on the city's one-way avenue program after its approval at the top level were decried yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 16 -- A minority of white Rhodesians failed tonight to disrupt a series of meetings sponsored by the liberal Central African party at a hall in the European section.

WARSAW, March 16 -- Communist leaders from forty-two countries today cheered a harsh denunciation of the United Arab Republic and applauded Iraq as the "unconquered bastion of the Arab nationalist movement."
Two organizations that have worked in this country with the foreign born have merged into the American Council for Nationalities Service with offices at 20 West Fortieth Street.
Joseph P. McMurray, former State Housing Commissioner, has been appointed president of the new Queensborough Community College.

New York locals of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners have closed ranks behind a high official accused by Senate racket investigators of using his union influence to sell overpriced oil products to builders.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Finland received a loan of $37,000,000 from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) today. The money will be used to help nine private companies to expand and modernize pulp and paper plants.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The economy continued to advance slowly but steadily in February, Government reports revealed today.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman contended yesterday that unfair immigration laws had caused this country to lose its lead in scientific achievement by limiting the entry of experts.

There are few rustic dwellings left in the heart of Manhattan, so New Yorkers, particularly sidewalk superintendents, take what nostalgic pleasure they can from the sight of the little shacks put up by construction men when major building, or demolition, is being done.
SOME pre-Easter thoughts, mostly about flowers:
PINEVILLE, Ky., March 16 (AP) -- Six shots were fired at the operator of a truck coal mine today as contracts of the United Mine Workers began running out in Bell County.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 16 -- Ahamed Zaki, Maldivian Government representative in Colombo, said at a news conference here today that there "has been no revolt in the Maldives."
KAMPALA, Uganda, March 16 (UPI) -- The brother of the King of Buganda forfeited today any claim to the throne for his offspring by a white wife.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders tonight rejected Mayor Wagner's request for power to levy city taxes on stock transfers and bank checks.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The United States would gain nothing by "knuckling under" in Berlin because the Soviet Union could find many other excuses to start a war, Admiral Arleigh A. Burke says.

OTTAWA, March 16 -- The Newfoundland labor dispute brought about the resignation of the head of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police today and an attack by the Prime Minister on the head of the Newfoundland Government.
ROME, March 16 -- The discovery of new evidence purported to prove that Apostle Peter was buried where St. Peter's Basilica now stands was announced by the Vatican today.
The importance of speed alone as an accident factor has been disproved by the newest Federal traffic study, a top American Automobile Association official asserted yesterday.
Workmen yesterday began planting the 398 young London plane trees that by Easter will line both sides of Seventh Avenue in Harlem from 110th to 155th Street.

Major custom smelters offered refined copper on the market yesterday for the first time in about a week -- but at 34 cents a pound, or 2 cents higher than the last smelter quotations on March 9. So pressing was the demand for copper, however, that even at the new price level the custom smelters had very little metal to sell.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $22,835,000 of temporary loan notes next Tuesday. The obligations are to finance development of Benjamin Franklin Houses, a city-subsidized project now under construction in the area bounded by First Avenue, East 106th Street, Third Avenue and East 109th Street.
The Weather Bureau has promised mostly sunny skies and seasonably mild temperatures for today -- St. Patrick's Day.
An interunion rivalry to organize workers in the city's eighty-one voluntary hospitals is threatening to erupt in strike action against some of the institutions.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 16 -- Three leaders of the Belgian Congo's insurrectionary movement said here today that they "agree to discuss at the right time and in the right place the application of the Belgian Government's new policy for the Belgian Congo."
NORWALK, Conn., March 16 -- Residents of the lower Strawberry Hill Avenue area organized yesterday to protest a proposed industrial rezoning.
In the face of mounting unemployment, help wanted advertising in newspapers in February registered a 27 per cent gain above the total in the 1958 period.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California offered a six-point program today to meet urbanization problems plaguing cities, counties and larger regions throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating called today for Congressional revision of half a dozen recent Supreme Court decisions dealing with crime and communism.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A New York psychologist urged Congress today to make a study of blind children who were also handicapped by emotional disturbances, cerebral palsy, epilepsy or other ailments.
HONOLULU, March 16 -- An apparition that has long disturbed some Southern Senators -- a person of Oriental ancestry in the membership -- may materialize in the wake of Hawaii's first state election.
LONDON, March 16 -- Mikhail A. Suslov and other influential members of the Supreme Soviet got a close look today at the workings of the British parliamentary system.
" Captives of the New Haven arise -- " was the way the handbill started out. And before the incident on the 8:53 from Westport was over yesterday morning, nearly everyone was aroused.

PARIS, March 16 -- France's political Right gained at the expense of the Center and Left in the number of municipal officials elected Sunday and a week earlier, the Ministry of Interior announced tonight.

Dr. Ferdinand Durcansky of Munich, Germany, amplified yesterday his denial that he had been a World War II war criminal. He was Foreign Minister of the Republic of Slovakia in 1939-40, when it was under the protection of Nazi Germany.
The first American-flag participation in overseas shipping between the Great Lakes and foreign ports moved another step toward realization yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- There is a feeling of uneasiness in the camp of the world champion New York Yankees, and it isn't only the result of the two drubbings the Bombers took last week from the Dodgers and Cardinals.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 16 -- Gov. Orville L. Freeman will head a Minnesota delegation of fourteen that will go to New York Thursday to promote use of the westernmost port of the St. Lawrence-Great Lakes Seaway system, Duluth.

If the sales tax increase, now abandoned, was the worst possible tax that New York City could have imposed, one of the taxes chosen as a substitute and wisely rejected last night by Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders was the second worst. A stock transfer tax at half the rate imposed by the state, to raise $25,000,000, was the proposed measure.
The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had denied its request for an increase in the ceiling on commercial bank savings deposits from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent.
HENDERSON, N. C., March 16 (UPI) -- Striking textile workers battled the police and highway patrolmen with rocks, bottles and clubs today at the Harriet-Henderson cotton mills.
ALBANY, March 16 -- A court reorganization bill that confines almost all its major changes to New York City was agreed on by the Republican legislative leaders today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A single hearing examiner took up this morning the three most discussed cases now before the S. E. C. and whisked through them in forty-five minutes.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- William Joseph Steury of Bluffton, Ind., has been selected to receive the 1957 Young American Medal for Bravery, Attorney General William P. Rogers announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- An increase in research into the safe limit of strontium 90 in food and water was announced here today.

TOKYO, March 16 -- Communist China has laid down three principles as a basis for normal relations with Japan. Unless Japan accepts these principles, Peiping has indicated the previous informal trade between the two countries will not be resumed.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Strong opposition was developing here tonight to the omnibus banking bill that would widen the opportunities for branch banking.

MOSCOW, March 16 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev declared tonight that President Gamal Abdel Nasser's anti-Communist policy was "doomed to failure." The Soviet Premier warned the Egyptian leader against trying to force Iraq into union with the United Arab Republic.

Arthur H. Bienenstock, realty investor and builder, has purchased the fifteen-story Cocoa Exchange Building at 82 Beaver Street near Hanover Square in the downtown Manhattan financial district. He bought the property from Klausner Associates, who acquired it recently.

THE voice of God spoke to Noah. Noah and his sons built the ark. The birds and the beasts were led aboard. The storm raged, and the rains came for forty days and nights. The raven flew forth, and then the dove, which returned with an olive branch.

The Nassau County Clearing House Association described as"fabrication" yesterday the conclusion of a group of educators that interest rates charged by New York City banks were considerably lower than those charged by Nassau County institutions.
CAIRO, March 16 -- Cairo held a city-wide memorial service today for the dead of the Mosul revolt against the Government of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq.
LONDON, March 16 -- An Opposition move to censure the Conservative Government over the Suez invasion in 1956 was defeated in the House of Commons tonight, 300 votes to 230.

Dr. A. Harry Kleiman says many are. However, before the once-a-week bowler starts popping the buttons on his embroidered bowling shirt, he should be told that he doesn't fall into this athlete category. This fellow probably exerts much energy just convincing his wife he should be out with the boys once a week. But in the opinion of Dr. Kleiman, he doesn't carry on his bowling in a manner to earn ranking as an athlete.
Actors Equity has initiated a move to expand the welfare benefits of a membership reportedly numbering 10,000.
A map of Manhattan's midtown East Side area hung on the wall of a real estate broker's office has been causing a stir among realty professionals.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -Following is the text of a speech in the Senate today on the Berlin situation by Senator J. W. Fulbright:

THE role of Macduff in Verdi's "Macbeth" is not a large one, but it does have one fine aria in the last act. Barry Morell, young American tenor, who sang the part for the first time last night at the Metropolitan Opera, made the most of that aria.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Christian A. Herter, Acting Secretary of State, was warned today that fresh, strong leadership would be required to save this year's Mutual Security Program from a "disaster" in Congress.
Joseph G. Luberda, retired police sergeant who had refused to give investigators any information about his finances, ended his silence yesterday.

Plans are being made for the Silver Ball, the fifth annual dance of the Manhattan Chapter of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America. It will take place in the St. Regis Roof on April 11 under the chairmanship of Mrs. Herbert R. Silverman.
An offering of 203,250 shares of Simplex Wire and Cable Company capital stock at $27 per share is being made today by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and associates.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- An Administration proposal to set up a co-ordinated pay system for the Federal Government drew bipartisan support today.
TRENTON, March 16 -- The State Assembly approved and sent to the Senate today a bill under which the state would guarantee loans to help needy students meet their college tuition costs.

Your editorial of March 11 refers to some data on economic growth used recently by the Democratic Advisory Council. You also cite in challenge of the full significance of these data some other data presented recently by Raymond J. Saulnier, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Alexander L. Guterma was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to defraud by impeding Securities and Exchange Commission requirements for protecting stockholders.
Steel production last week set a high record for the second consecutive week, again exceeding expectations. An additional increase has been scheduled for this week.

A $105,000 grant by the General Foods Corporation to set up a rehabilitation center in the Philippines for the physically handicapped was announced here yesterday by Brig Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House passed today a bill to extend to June 30 the temporary Federal unemployment compensation benefits, which had been scheduled to expire April 1. It has been estimated that 405,000 unemployed will benefit by the extension.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 16 (UPI) -- Booth Newspapers, Inc., announced today it would cease publication of The Grand Rapids Herald, a morning publication, March 29.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, March 16 -- Jules Dassin, director and writer, and Lew Kerner, who has an arrangement with James T. Farrell to film "Studs Lonigan," have formed a partnership and will produce movies. Their work will be released through Lopert Films, headed by Ilya Lopert, foreign film producer-distributor.
ALBANY, March 16 -- If you've been hiring boys under 18 years old to shovel your driveway, you've been violating the law.

A group of employes of the American Sugar Refining Company has challenged the right of the International Lc gshoremen's Association to continue to bargain for the concern's 1,600 pier and packing-house workers here.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., sent out the last report covering its affairs as a partnership yesterday. It described the ten-and-a-half months ended on last Jan. 12 as "the most extraordinary period in our history."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights opened its fifteenth session here today with a rare display of agreement. It unanimously re-elected R. S. S. Gunewardene of Ceylon as its chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that the chances of war in Europe could be diminished by negotiating a mutual military withdrawal, "however slight," of Soviet and Western forces in Germany.
VENTURA, Calif., March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth Duncan, 54 years old, was found guilty of first-degree murder today in the hired killing of her son's pregnant bride.
President Jose Maria Lemus of El Salvador said yesterday that coffee-producing countries looked to the "friendly cooperation" of traders in this country to help maintain "fair and stable" prices.

RANGOON, Burma, March 16 -- U Nu, former Premier of Burma, expressed resentment here today over the treatment of members of his faction of the Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League by certain elements in the army.
PLANS for an American fashion show at next summer's fair in Moscow are well under way except for one crucial factor -- money.

Traffic on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive below Fourteenth Street was delayed for an hour yesterday at 4:30 P.M. after a newspaper delivery truck and two taxicabs collided. Two persons were injured slightly.

A junk dealer who lived in a junk-filled house in Bucks County, Pa., has willed his $250,000 estate to Yeshiva University. He was 74-year-old Charles Fraiman, who died Feb. 10 in Philadelphia's Lankenau Hospital.
CONTINUING the heartening trend among galleries this season to exhibit drawings, the Bodley Gallery, 223 East Sixtieth Street, is offering a large group of works by modern European artists.

Residents of three East Side blocks marked for slum clearance charged Robert Moses yesterday with "serious distortion" of City Housing Authority figgures about their chances of being relocated in public housing.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 16 -- Last night there was a gala for players in the world hockey tournament. The entertainment was superb -- a Gypsy orchestra from Bohemia, peasant singers and dancers in traditional costume, a mixed glee club from the Czech Army, and even a symphony orchestra. WASHINGTON, March 16 -- George Meany asked a subcommittee of Congress today why stockholders should not vote in labor-management disputes if a law would require a secret ballot by employes to authorize strikes.
VIENNA, March 16 -- Relations with the United States have become an issue in the general election campaign that started last week.

ONE store believes that, in the high fashion race, laurels do not always go to the swift. Ohrbach's, in copies of original designs culled from the new French and Italian collections, proves its point. The store has sacrificed speed to achieve a painstaking degree of workmanship, which, it believes, the public has come to expect.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Ross L. Malone, president of the American Bar Association, has been making a series of speeches lately in which he has advanced a line of reasoning that must be difficult for many to follow. It is that the criticism of a large body of decisions by a court is not at all criticism of the court itself.

Seventh - Day Adventists in the eastern area contributed an average of more than $600 apiece over four years to foreign missions and ministerial support. This excluded amounts for local church expenses and home missions.

HAVANA, March 16 -- The Cuban yacht, Lobo de Mar, a sixty-seven-foot cutter owned and sailed by Dr. Clemente Inclan of Havana, arrived in the harbor at 9:54:50 this morning. She was the first craft to finish in the twenty-sixth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana race.

A Navy task force led by the aircraft carrier Tarawa is scheduled to sail from port this morning after a three-day visit. The Navy estimated that 50,000 persons had inspected the fifteen vessels during their stay.
LONDON, March 16 (UPI) -- Gild - edged invitations brought twenty - five diplomats from ten nations to a tea party yesterday tendered by a charwoman and her husband in a dingy London flat.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Following is the text of a joint statement issued tonight by Governor Rockefeller, Senator Walter J. Mahoney, the Senate Majority Leader, and Assemblyman Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, on New York City's tax program:

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd. (Inco), and subsidiaries, reported yesterday that their net income dropped sharply last year to $39,665,000, equal to $2.71 a common share. That compared with $86,141,000, or $5.90 a share, for the preceding year. Net sales fell to $322,038,000 from $442,886,000.

Market values on the New York Stock Exchange declined by about $2,900,000,000 yesterday. The drop appeared to be in reaction to a Federal Reserve Board suggestion that credit rules for the carrying of securities be tightened.
An accountant testified in New York Supreme Court yesterday that he had been instructed to set up a bookkeeping facade for a maritime union local.

The Community Service Society announced yesterday that its committee on housing had voted opposition to a bill in Albany that would deny residence in public housing to any person "knowingly a member" of a subversive organization.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Eisenhower announced tonight his willingness to attend a conference of heads of government with the Soviet Union if preliminaries offered prospects of worth-while results.
DETROIT, March 16 (AP) -he auto makers this year have bilt 4,289,812 passenger cars, his compares with 1,055,483 in the 1858 period.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The chairman of the National Broadcasting Company proposed today that all elements of the television industry unite in a campaign to combat charges that TV is mediocre, unworthy and time-wasting.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 16 (Reuters) -- An unbeaten century today by Peter May, who also passed the 4,000-run mark in his test career, put the touring English cricket side well on the way to victory over New Zealand after two days of play in the second test match.

Announcement was made yesterday of the opening of the first community rehabilitation center in Asia, at San Pablo, Laguna, in the Philippines. This project is unique and significant in several respects.
MEXICO CITY, March 16 -- Political disturbances have swept across Mexico in the last few days.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 16 -- Edward E. Rigney resigned today as Special Prosecutor in the Suffolk County scandals investigations.
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., March 16 -- The General Electric Company shut its industrial air-conditioning plant here today, two weeks in advance of the scheduled April 1 closing.

Capital expenditures of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway aggregated $35,800,000 last year, according to the road's pamphlet report. Of the total, $28,600,000 was spent for new equipment and $7,200,000 for roadway and structures. Increased capital expenditures are expected this year.
A Federal mediator will renew his efforts this afternoon to avert a possible strike of union printers against ten daily newspapers here.
A hearing to determine whether Robert Maurice Sherwood should be cited for criminal contempt opened yesterday before Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman. The Canadian financier was present.
FINAL figures on the deer kill of last hunting season in New York have been released by the Conservation Department, and they are disappointing.
If the shamrock-wearers take a few moments this fine day to scan the Kentucky Derby entries, they will find little trouble in picking an Irish-blood favorite in the May 2 classic.
BONN, Germany, March 16 -Six months of secret negotiations aimed at re-establishing diplomatic relations between West Germany and Yugoslavia have broken down.

Commerce and Washington, a pair of Manhattan entries, gained the semi-final round of the Public School Athletic League basketball tournament with close victories over Brooklyn schools before 8,500 at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Commerce eliminated Manual Training, 59 -- 57, and Washington defeated Madison, 67 -- 59, in the opener.
NEW HAVEN, March 16 -- Yale placed all 4,000 undergraduates on indefinite general probation today because of the snowball riots last Thursday and Saturday.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- A witness in the antitrust action against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., testified today that a Government proposal for ending close trade relations with General Motors Corporation would cost du Pont shareholders nearly a billion dollars.
Long-term bonds took a back seat yesterday in the market for prime fixed-income investments. For the first time in weeks, short-term yields assumed the leadership.
The Bestwall Gypsum Company's management intends to recommend to the board at its next metting on Friday a 2 1/2-for-one split of the common stock, Rawson G. Lizars, president, announced yesterday.

" The Sound and the Fury," Twentieth Century-Fox' film version of the William Faulkner novel, starring Yul Brynner, Joanne Woodward and Margaret Leighton, will open at the Paramount Theatre on March 27. Jerry Wald produced the drama, which was directed by Martin Ritt.
ST. LOUIS, March 16 (AP) -- Gene Vetrone of Newark moved into second place in the all-events division of the American Bowling Congress tournament today with a nine-game total of 1,961.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 16 (Reuters) -- The three Benelux countries of the European common market made a new move today to establish closer trade ties between the six-nation market and eleven other European nations.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The United States Government is quietly and unofficially encouraging the participation of able and thoroughly prepared American students in the Communist-dominated World Youth Festival in Vienna this summer.

A twelve-acre shopping center is being built by Joseph Gluckman and Frank Gencorelli in Lake Ronkonkoma, L. I. It is adjacent to a 400-home residential community built by the developers on a 200-acre tract.

Unusual interest centers today on the sale of $6,500,000 of Territory of Hawaii bonds. The sale entails a rare kind of double tax immunity -- one that will become even rarer this summer when Hawaii is scheduled to formally shed the status of a territory to become a state.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The Legislature cleared the way today for the opening of the harness-racing season at Yonkers Raceway next Friday night.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs dropped sharply this week more than offsetting the sharp rise registered last week.

Out of the baffling complexities of France's municipal elections there seems to be a tendency to fasten upon the fact that the Communists have maintained their strength. Another feature receiving prominence is that the Gaullist vote has shown a proportionate decline since the national elections of last autumn.
The Purcell proposals for state aid to commuter services won a hearty welcome yesterday from the New York Central and New Haven Railroads.

ONE delectable way to enjoy chocolate is in an angel meringue pie filled with a rich and flavorful cream made with sweet cooking chocolate. The pastry, with a meringue shell that is crisp outside and as light as a feather inside, is a simple one to make.
President Sean T. O'Kelly of the Republic of Ireland arrived here yesterday radiating Gaelic charm.
A Federal Aviation Agency spokesman in Washington said yesterday that an apparent feud between airline pilots and flight engineers on Eastern Air Lines did not require "overt action" by his agency.
CAIRO, March 16 (AP) -- Vice President Amer declared today Communist agents deliberately provoked the Mosul garrison uprising in Iraq as an excuse to crush Iraqi nationalists.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- A major drive got under way in Congress today for legislation to let manufacturers of branded products fix retail prices. The proposal is for a national "fair trade" law to operate everywhere, regardless of state laws, and without approval of distributors. Such a law presumably would end price-cutting by discount houses on appliances and other branded merchandise.

Charley Scott, a welterweight from Philadelphia, upset Isaac Logart in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night. Logart, who lost a welterweight elimination bout to Virgil Akins a year ago, was the 3-1 favorite.
Informed last night of the rejection in Albany of part of his 1959-60 tax program, Mayor Wagner called the Board of Estimate into session at 10:30 A. M. today at City Hall.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 16 -- A shortage of at least $4,000 has been discovered in tolls on the Mid-Hudson Bridge, the chairman of the State Bridge Authority said today. Several toll-takers have been discharged, he said.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 16 -- The strike against the nationalized tin mines ended today, eliminating the threat of a general strike.
SEATTLE, March 16 -- A petition urging withdrawal of the Bridge League's directors' action was drawn here today by bridge players who had gathered for the beginning of the league's spring tournament.
BOSTON, March 16 (UPI) -- Bob Pettit was named the National Basketball Association's most valuable player today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -When President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan meet here late this week, they will try to resolve several differences that have arisen between the State Department and the Foreign Office on the German question.
ROME, March 16 -- Premier Antonio Segni scored a personal success today in a decisive caucus of his faction-torn Christian Democratic party.

The Times of March 9 contains a letter from Dr. Harry Gideonse and George Field of Freedom House recommending that the Federal Government and private parties help to offset the effects of Communist literature in various countries by supplying their reading public with copies of writings by Jefferson, Franklin, Hamilton, etc.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature tonight to increase and improve state programs for the rehabilitation of handicapped persons.
