THE story of a man's search for a splendid girl he loved with considerable enthusiasm a long time ago is frequently appealing to novelists. So is the recollection of war. These two ideas, I suspect, are in themselves enough to assure material for novel writers from here to the suburbs of eternity.

THREE years ago, Robert Briscoe became the first Jew to be elected Lord Mayor of Dublin. Last July, Mrs. Catherine Byrne became the second woman in Dublin's history to wear the city's gold mayoral chain.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16 -- Dr. Djalal Abdoh of Iran began his new duties as plebiscite commissioner for the British Cameroons today by drafting plans for an intensive study of the small West African territory whose political future he will be helping to protect.
The city's Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that he would soon submit recommendations to Mayor Wagner to eliminate fradulent claims by relief recipients.

With President Eisenhower's speech last night and the impending arrival of Prime Minister Macmillan the great debate among the Western powers on how to meet the Soviet challenge over Berlin is now approaching the time for decision.

Jazz and poetry, a mixture brewed in San Francisco, sputtered and fizzled when it was introduced to New York last year. It was given a second chance last night at The Living Theatre, 530 Avenue of the Americas.
An assistant to Mayor Wagner disclosed yesterday that the city and state were joining in an experimental program to develop effective methods of treating narcotic addicts.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives brushed aside Treasury protests and voted overwhelmingly today to grant a special tax concession to self-employed persons trying to build up old age retirement funds.

Tobias Stone, a leading figure of international tournament bridge, applied yesterday in Supreme Court for legal relief from action of the American Contract Bridge League, which barred him from competition in the spring national championships at Seattle.

TODAY'S child faces a future of continued conflict and ever-increasing change. To help him live with some comfort in such a world -- and perhaps even to survive -- parents must foster in him courage, creativity and the ability to change. This was the consensus of the speakers at a conference yesterday of the Child Study Association of America. The parley was held at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Coffee, copper and wool were strong in active trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Coffee climbed about 1/4 to 1 1/4 cents a pound, copper rose 1/2 to 1 cent and wool gained 1 to 2 1/2 cents a pound.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 to 9 points (20 to 45 cents a bale) lower. The volume was rather light.

HAVANA, March 17 -- The Cuban Government is committed to support revolutionary movements against dictators in Latin America, but some circles believe it will not hastily participate in armed movements on a large scale to overthrow those dictatorships.
The Palm Beach company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of branded men's and boys' suits, will manufacture its entire fall 1959 line of fabrics blended of wool and synthetics.

When a snowstorm strikes, that is the time above all when the man who works at home can laugh at office wretches. The same applies, of course, to the retired millionaire, almost anyone on week-ends, and the person with just enough of a cold to overcome his conscience.
LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- Representatives of the Soviet Union and Iraq pledged today that their countries would become closer friends.

A look at America with its abundance and its emphasis on comfort and a warning that complacency can have serious consequences are given by Edgar Ansel Mowrer in his new book "A Good Time To Be Alive." His topics range from Russia, the Cold War and this country's foreign policy to the virtues of nonconformity and the problems of overpopulation.

LOS ANGELES, March 17 (UPI) -- Hogan (Kid) Bassey of Nigeria and Davey Moore of Springfield, Ohio, the world's best featherweights, will meet in a fifteen-round title bout tomorrow night to decide who is the better.
BONN, Germany, March 17 -- West Germany and five Allied powers completed negotiations today on a new treaty governing the status of North Atlantic Treaty forces stationed in the Federal Republic.
H. I. Romnes was elected president of the Western Electric Company yesterday at a special meeting of the company's directors.
American Electrio Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday the highest February earnings on record. Earnings for two and twelve months ended Feb. 28 also rose to new highs.
CANNES, France, March 17 (UPI) -- Willem Maris of the Netherlands defeated Straight Clark of Los Angeles in the Cannes international tennis tournament today, 5 -- 7, 9 -- 7, 6 - 4.
Under blue skies and under gray, in sun and in snow, 130,000 Celts and their friends marched up the concrete glen of Fifth Avenue yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- The Senate rackets committee brought out evidence today indicating that two Chicago teamster officials were secret stockholders in an insurance agency that collected inflated commissions on union welfare policies.

THICK ice and heavy snow during the last couple of months may have had a strong and bad effect on the dwindling number of native trout in New York streams. Fishermen will be able to find out when the season opens, but they have to find out first when the season does open.
UPTON, L. I., March 17 -- The world's first nuclear reactor designed specifically for medical research was fired up for a short test run here this week at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -Discoverer I was written off as missing and presumed dead today amid serious doubts among some space experts that the satellite ever had been in orbit.

Of the original four seeded quintets, only top-rated Bradley of Peoria, Ill., remains in the National Invitation Tournament. Last night at Madison Square Garden, St. Louis and Oklahoma City, the No. 2 and the No. 4 teams, respectively, dropped by the wayside in the twenty-second annual postseason competition.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, March 17 -- The Rockefeller Administration submitted to the Legislature today a proposal to give all state employes pay increases ranging from $200 to $486 a year starting April 1.

The reasonably harmonious relations that had existed between City Hall and the state Republican leadership at Albany, as efforts were made to solve the city's financial problems, broke down yesterday with the issuance from City Hall of an ill-tempered statement from Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate. It represents a regrettable turn of events, provoked in turn by a Republican statement the night before that was not in itself a model of wisdom.

The nation's proved reserves of crude oil and natural gas were at record high levels at the end of 1958, according to the annual survey of the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association.

The quarrel between Cairo and Baghdad has become serious. There is no apparent hope of patching it up or letting it die down. Since such a conflict cannot be isolated in modern times, there is ample reason for anxiety.

Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, yesterday prevented another of his former lawyers from testifying in court. He invoked the attorney-client privilege for the second time in a lawsuit against a tugboat union.
A 5-year-old boy died yesterday in a fire that he had apparently started while playing with matches.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Because of splits among Republicans, Democrats appeared to hold the fate of the omnibus banking bill in their hands tonight. The measure is slated to come to a vote in the Senate tomorrow.
Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., has lost the $3,000,000 advertising account of Wildroot hair preparations, which it had handled for some thirty years.
CHICAGO, March 17 -- John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that he favored repeal of Section 315 of the Federal Communications Act.
Mrs. J. Gould Remick is chairman of the patroness committee for this year's holiday dances for subdebutantes, preparatoryschool students and college freshmen.

Three five-story apartment houses at 744-48-52 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx were sold by the Miliet Realty Corporation to the Tifan Realty Corporation, A. Schattner, president. George B. Leddy and Stanley Russell Associates Inc. were the brokers.
Sigmund Miller's new comedydrama, "Masquerade," made a quick get-away from Broadway yesterday after giving a single performance at the John Golden Theatre.

HAVANA, March 17 (AP) -"O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!" Callooh, a yacht with a name out of Lewis Carroll's "Jabberwocky" verses, today emerged as the over-all winner of the St. Petersburg-to-Havana race. She was sailed by Emil (Bus) Mosbacher of New York.
LONDON, March 17 -- A threeman tribunal opened its inquiry today into the case of John Waters, a 16-year-old Scot who has accused policemen of beating him.

Spring is just around the corner but, knowing from bitter experience that spring weather lags considerably behind the calendar in these parts, the varsity set will head south en masse during the next couple of weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- As "one Irishman to another" and as one of his visitor's loyal "subjects," President Eisenhower put on a Kelly-green necktie and stood at the head of an emerald-green carpet today to welcome Sean T. O'Kelly to Washington as President of all the Irish.

The General Time Corporation, manufacturer of clocks and electronics equipment, leased a floor in the new office building at 355 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Fortieth Street. Arthur Collins Jr. of Collins, Tuttle Co., was the broker.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 17 (AP) -- Guy Lombardo today said he would resume speed-boat racing with a newly designed boat and a powerful turbo-jet engine, a combination he believes capable of 275 miles per hour.
Investment banking syndicates competed keenly yesterday for new issues of local government bonds totaling more than $66,000,000.
The two Valenti brothers, jailed for refusal to answer questions about the Apalachin gangland convention, were reported yesterday to be ready to talk.
Automobile manufacturers were urged yesterday to increase grants to dealers to assure the continuance of the national high school driver-education program.

A team of Protestant speakers from Taiwan and South Korea declared here yesterday that recognition of Communist China by the United States and the United Nations would be a "betrayal" of Christians throughout the Far East.

ROME, March 17 -- A shift toward the Right within the dominant Christian Democratic party appeared to be the outcome of a decisive caucus that ended tonight. Political commentators here spoke of a "new reality" on the Italian scene and predicted domestic and international repercussions of the new trend.

BY going off the deep end, a playwright and some actors have come up with an ingenious and amusing fantasy. "The Geranium Hat," put on last evening at the Orpheum Theatre (Second Avenue and Eighth Street).
ALBANY, March 17 (AP) -Governor Rockefeller signed bills today permitting New York State's flat and harness race tracks to open their 1959 seasons early.

The J. C. Penney Company, department store chain, attained record sales last year, but earnings fell below those of 1957, according to the results released for publication today. At the end of January the company had 1,687 stores in operation.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -The House Public Works Committee approved a bill today to permit the Tennessee Valley Authority to issue bonds for expansion of its power facilities.
Local communities were warned yesterday to face up to the problem of family desertion or suffer the consequences in increased adult and juvenile crime and mental breakdown.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 17 -- The cleverest versifier the Polo Grounds press box ever produced was George Phair. In four crisp lines he could sum up a ball game or a situation with penetrating exactitude. About a quarter of a century ago the Giants, as usual, were battling the Cards, as usual, for the pennant and late in September the futile Phils came to town.
The Grolier Club, founded seventy-five years ago, is taking a look back over the years through an exhibition showing the fruits gathered by some of its members who are book and manuscript collectors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Revival of agitation to curb the Supreme Court will be an inevitable result of the unwise action of those members of the American Bar Association responsible for the resolution calling for Congressional legislation which would restrict the high court.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -The Western Big Three will offer to meet the Russians at a summit conference this summer, it was reported today.

BOSTON, March 17 (AP) -Paul Pender fought his way back to ring prominence tonight. Employing a furious left-hand attack, he gained a unanimous ten-round decision over a highly regarded middleweight contender, Ralph (Tiger) Jones, at Boston Garden.
James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, proposed yesterday that schools in large metropolitan areas be administered by federations of local school districts.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said that "it was an excellent speech, one of the President's best efforts." But the Arkansas Democrat said he still felt it was bad psychology to reduce the Army, Navy and Marines when the country was facing negotiations on situations like the Berlin crisis.
WARSAW, March 17 -- The history of Poland's political upheaval of 1956 is being drastically rewritten in a concert hall in a Warsaw skyscraper.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee found a unaimous solution today to a troublesome problem. If enacted, it should speed the election machinery of the National Labor Relations Board.
I hope that Khrushchev is beginning to realize that he cannot succeed in his current campaign to panic the West.

The Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad, which affords to the New York Central System its entry into the PittsburghYoungstown steel area, plans to repurchase about 12 per cent of its outstanding stock. The carrier announced yesterday that it would ask stockholders to tender as many as 100,000 shares of stock for purchase. The stock closed yesterday at 93 3/4.

Casts for Lee Hoiby's opera "The Scarf" and Carlisle Floyd's "Wuthering Heights" were announced yesterday by Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera Company. The works will be presented during the company's spring season at the City Center beginning March 30.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had found no solution to conflicts between freedom of the press and due process of law arising from a reporter's refusal to reveal confidential sources of information.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although the bill introduced by Assemblyman Joseph J. Corso of Brooklyn to permit New York City's teachers to use "reasonable force in a moderate degree" on children has passed the Assembly, it is not too late to defeat it in the Senate or for the Governor to veto it if the Senate adopts it.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "What will New York City look like?" asked the outraged letter writer Marjorie Thompkins March 13 of the Transit Authority's proposal of bus-side advertising.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -President Eisenhower invited nine Governors today to confer with him Monday on strengthening the Federal-state unemployment compensation program.

SEATTLE, Wah., March 17 -The American Contract Bridge League today withdrew its action that last Friday had barred Tobias Stone of New York from competing in the spring national championships held here at the Olympic Hotel.
ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Senate today to confirm Oliver Townsend as the state's first director of atomic development.
A woman's life was saved last August when a Liberty, N. Y., surgeon flew his own plane to LaGuardia Airport for three pints of Red Cross O-negative blood not available at his hospital.
OTTAWA, March 17 -- The split between the Federal Government and the Premier of Newfoundland over the loggers' bitter labor strife in the province grew wider today.
The managements of 234 American corporations operating overseas plants were warned yesterday that they faced a threat from a new principle adopted by organized maritime labor in the United States.
LONDON, March 17 -- Britain and Italy engaged in a thorough exchange of views today on the West's policy toward the problems of Germany and European security.
Five boys and five girls, ranging in age from 10 to 15 years old, were picked up last night in a West Side raid on charges of particpating in immoral parties.
It was "a great day for the Irish" even within the exclusive portals of the University Club at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.
Underwriters led by Straus, Blosser McDowell are offering publicly today 100,000 shares of Waste King Corporation series C 6 per cent cumulative convertible, $17.50 par preferred stock at par.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Republicans decided today to approve a constitutional amendment exempting $500,000,000 for school construction from New York City's debt limit, but to tie a few strings to it at the same time.
A 66-year-old woman was burned to death yesterday in her apartment at 14 Sutton Place South, near Fifty-sixth Street. A fire marshal said the flames had apparently been caused by a lighted cigarette.

The Federal Maritime Board and American Export Lines signed yesterday a $44,000,000 contract under which four cargo ships will be built for American Export by five West Coast companies acting jointly.

ALBANY, March 17 -- A bill designed to stretch the volume of middle income housing that can be erected with the $100,000,000 bond issue approved by the voters last November was filed today in the Legislature.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Tennessee Williams, the playwright, and Arletty, the French actress, scored a modest critical success last night with the opening of the Paris adaptation of Mr. Williams' play, "Orpheus Descending."

Following is the statement issued yesterday by Mayor Wagger, with the concurrence of the Board of Estimate, replying to the action of Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders in rejecting the Mayor's request for power to tax stock transfers and bank checks :
The last marcher in the St. Patrick's Day parade yesterday played the sousaphone, a kind of tuba with curves, skillfully and strode majestically, yet was cheered on by nobody.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -Lewis L. Strauss was notified today that he faced a long and exhaustive examination before the Senate decided whether to confirm his appointment as Secretary of Commerce.

Gagaku, the dancers and musicians of the Japanese imperial household, will appear with the New York City Ballet at the City Center beginning May 21. The joint announcement was made yesterday by Mitsuo Tanaka, Japanese Consul General in New York, and Lincoln Kirstein, director of the New York City Ballet.
ATHENS, March 17 -- The leader of the Cypriote underground received a hero's welcome here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of March 14 expressing satisfaction with the action of the United Nations on the French Cameroons will meet with many dissenting voices; among them every independent African state except Ethiopia, a sizable minority of others, and most of the interested nongovernmental agencies which followed the debates, including this accredited league and the American Committee on Africa.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -A long-range program providing about $2,400,000,000 a year in military aid abroad and economic assistance averaging about $1,000,000,000 annually was recommended today by a Presidential study committee.
DALLAS, March 17 (AP) -The successful creation of a urinary bladder from a segment of the small intestine was reported yesterday by the Veterans Administration Hospital in Dallas.

While most of the city's Irish were strutting up Fifth Avenue yesterday, a few were busy in Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A bill designed to protect commuters from becoming isolated by discontinuations of trains and ferries will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow.
TRENTON, March 17 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court shortened the third hole at the Ramsey Golf and Country Club today.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign for the Presidency, which has carried him from Minneapolis to Moscow, has apparently moved into high gear.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower's plans for balancing the 1960 budget ran into trouble today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted, with a flick of the calendar, to throw it out of balance by $1,375,000,000.
Seeman Brothers, Inc., distributors of White Rose Foods, has acquired Francis H. Leggett Co. and its line of Premier brand foods for $3,500,000 cash, it was announced yesterday.

The Pennsylvania Railroad plans to refinance $35,000,000 of consolidated mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds when they mature Aug. 1, 1960. The refunding will be undertaken through the sale of bonds of the Pennsylvania Company, its investment subsidiary, according to the railroad's annual report.

Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Democrats made substantial gains in spring elections held yesterday in ninety villages of four New York suburban counties.
Gunther Jaeckel, a Fiftyseventh Street specialty store for women, joined Bonwit Teller and Tiffany Co. yesterday under the banner of the Hoving Corporation.

Stocks won back yesterday about three-quarters of their heavy Monday losses, Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 4,730,000 shares from 4,420,000 shares on Monday.

The New York Rangers, with a 3-point edge for a Stanley Cup play-off berth and three games remaining, will skate against the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The St. Petersburg Senior High School Band, after coming here from Florida in the expectation of marching in the St. Patricks' Day parade, sat it out instead yesterday in the Paramount Hotel lobby.

The Texas Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $310,167,805 for 1958, or $5.31 each on the 58,388,074 capital shares outstanding at the year-end. Gross income from sales and other sources was $2,475,629,730.

The National Dairy Products Corporation set new records for sales and earnings last year, according to the annual report of E. E. Stewart, president and chairman, issued for publication today.

The First National City Bank of New York announced plans yesterday to transfer a large part of its operations and a majority of its employes to its new building at 399 Park Avenue, between Fifty-third and Fiftyfourth Streets, when the structure is completed in 1961.

BESIDES the ensemble training it gives its members, the National Orchestral Association likes to give hearings to young American musicians. In its third concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall, it gave such opportunities to a composer and a pianist.

THIS is the season for lamb, which is favored not only for Easter but also throughout the spring. There is a logical reason for the popularity of lamb now, for supplies are at their peak. Grant Beglarian, 32-yearold composer of Plymouth, Mich., has won the fourteenth annual Gershwin Memorial Foundation Award for the best orchestral composition by a young American composer.

A union-management fund announced yesterday awards of $269,150 to promote the training of plumbers and pipefitters for jobs in plants manufacturing atomic equipment, missiles and other advanced products.
PARIS, March 17 -- The nonCommunist leftist opposition to France's Gaullist regime has regrouped its scattered forces under a charter of association issued today.
Asher Dann Sons, builders, have purchased several parcels at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street in the fourth sale of the property to be reported in two weeks.

The Glickman Corporation, a privately-owned real estate investment concern of this city, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, covering the proposed public offering of 3,100,000 shares of common stock at $10 a share.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it would reconsider a proposal by the Railway Express Agency to increase rates on carload express shipments by 15 per cent.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., March 18 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's plea for a two-week cooling off period in the Newfoundland loggers' strike was answered early today by a new outbreak of violence.
The May 5 performance of "A Raisin in the Sun" at the Barrymore Theatre has been taken over for the benefit of Prescott Neighborhood House, 247 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board, Controller of the Currency and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today urged passage of a bill giving the three banking agencies, rather than the Department of Justice, control over bank mergers.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Two Republican spokesmen rebuked Mayor Wagner today for an "intemperate" attack on Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Farmers intend to increase substantially their plantings of feed grains this year despite a sharp cut in Government price supports.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service announced yesterday the deportation to Italy of Gaetano Gagliano, described as a leading figure in the Mafia crime syndicate.
Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and associates are offering today 150,000 shares of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation 5.60 per cent $100 par preferred stock at par.

SEATTLE, March 18 -- Eighty contract bridge teams played the first knockout round this afternoon in the Vanderbilt Cup Team of Four championship. It is the most important event of the Spring National Championships being held here at the Olympic Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- An investigation into whether contributions to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are deductible in computing income taxes has been begun by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.
The executive committee of the High School Teachers Association voted last night to set up the "machinery" for a mass resignation of teachers in the city's day high schools.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 18 -- A bloodless coup has ousted the leader of the rebel forces in northern Sumatra and has paved the way for a solution of the revolt there, the army information department said today.
SEATTLE, March 18 (AP) -- Victor Denny denied a Davis Cup rumor today and criticized a regulation adopted last year by the International Lawn Tennis Federation.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 19 (UPI) -- The United States fired a series of three nuclear devices "at a very high altitude outside the earth's atmosphere" last September, the Defense Department confirmed today.
LOS ANGELES, March 18 (UPI) -- Davey Moore tonight won the world featherweight championship when the manager of Hogan (Kid) Bassey, the titleholder, stopped the fight after thirteen bloody rounds.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Eisenhower Administration was subjected to a cross fire of Congressional criticism today by advocates and opponents of new civil rights legislation.
The American Airlines turbine - propeller plane that crashed here Feb. 3 was controlled by an automatic pilot device right up to the final moments, Co-pilot Frank S. Hlavacek testified yesterday.
ALBANY, March 18 -- A bipartisan deal is in the making for the creation of five new judgeships for the City Court in Brooklyn. It would double the present size of the court.
Eugene Dennis, national secretary of the Communist party, gave lukewarm approval yesterday to President Eisenhower's move for a foreign ministers' conference.
Delaware borrowed $12,500,000 in the public market yesterday to finance school, state highway and other public improvements.
THE story of Arthur J. Sussel incorporates, in true Horatio Alger tradition, all the essential ingredients -- the rise from obscurity to renown and from "rags to riches."
A Fire Department lieutenant who would have been eligible for retirement in twelve days was dismissed from his post yesterday on charges that he took $300 from five fire houses.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- A California insurance broker refused to tell Senate investigators today whether he had made secret pay-offs in cash and stock to Chicago labor leaders who directed union business to him.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson protested tonight that the Administration was proposing to buy plutonium from Britain for $30 a gram while the established British price was only $14.

Labor reporting has improved substantially in recent decades, but it still falls far short of the ideals that American newspapers and magazines profess, a panel representing labor and the press agreed yesterday.
The Government securities market guessed yesterday that the Treasury would choose to effectuate its $4,000,000,000 cash financing next week without the aid of a new issue of long-term bonds.

Several hundred prominent persons will be guests of Prince Aly Khan, Pakistan's permanent representative to the United Nations, at a dinner dance this evening. The fete will take place at the formal reopening of the Cafe Louis XIV in Rockefeller Center.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Brae Burn Farm's General Arthur slipped through along the hedge in the stretch to score a length and a half victory in the $12,950 Green Valley Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.
First Landing, the colt that was favored to win the Flamingo in Florida on Feb. 28 but ran a poor third, took his first canter at Jamaica yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- Daniel B. Maher, a Washington lawyer, today replaced L. N. D. Wells Jr. of Dallas, Tex., as a member of the board of monitors that policies the teamsters union.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, March 11.
The discovery of an ancient document containing 114 sayings attributed to Jesus, many of them previously unknown, was reported last night at the Union Theological Seminary.
OTTAWA, March 18 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain was assured of Canada's support today for the suggestions he will make in Washington for the relief of world tensions.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 to 14 points (20 to 70 cents a bale) higher than on Tuesday's, except the far July contract which fell 1 point (5 cents).
The Board of Estimate has agreed with the Transit Authority that ads on the outside of city buses are a good -- and profitable -- idea.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The United States Information Agency is seeking new transmitters capable of carrying the Voice of America broadcasts directly, without relays, from North America to listeners behind the Iron Curtain.
George J. Abrams, formerly advertising vice president at Revlon, Inc., has moved to the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company.

Never before in such a short time have so many important discoveries for the study of the Bible been made as in the last ten years. The discovery of the Dead Sea Scrolls pertaining to a Jewish sect at Qumran has been made known to the general public through a veritable flood of publications and lectures.

LONDON, March 18--Conservative members of the House of Commons cheered today when Iain MacLeod, the Minister of Labor, announced that the number of unemployed had dropped in the last month by more than 58,000.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange declined in the month ended last Friday by 384,365 shares to 3,793,575. This was the lowest figure since Jan. 15, 1958, when the total was 2,832,740 shares.

NEW YORKERS don't get many chances to hear zarzuelas. But two years ago the Teatro Lirico Experimental presented Federico Moreno Torroba's "Luisa Fernanda" at Hunter College and last night the same composer's "La Chulapona" opened a run at the Greenwich Mews Theatre in an English version entitled "Ole."

Copper futures fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. During the session the decline in the July position was only 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) short of the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit. The volume was 1,082 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), the largest since trading began in the metal in 1933.
JACK BENNY'S special show last night on Channel 2 was characteristically light variety entertainment, with some highly diverting moments and a few that were not overly inspired.
A tall calculating man, with a ruddy complexion, handed a note to a teller yesterday in a downtown bank and got $1,184 "fast and easy."
ALBANY, March 18 -- Following is the text of a special message on housing sent to the Legislature by Governor Rockefeller today:

Merrill's Maraunders, 3,000 handpicked infantrymen, who battled the Japanese in Burma, are the subject of a book by Charles Ogburn Jr. Called "The Marauders," it will be published April 15 by Harper. The unit marched almost 700 miles over the mountains and through the jungles of Burma and took part in five major and seventeen minor engagements in a campaign that drove the Japanese from an area the size of Connecticut.
ALBANY, March 18 (AP) -- Newburgh has been omitted from a special historical map and tempers there are soaring.
Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, has signed for a tune-up title fight against Brian London of England, the former British Empire titleholder.
HOLLYWOOD, March 18 (UPI) -- A restaurant owner and a jazz musician were killed early today when they staged a gun duel in a Hollywood home.

ALBANY, March 18 -- A bill designed to prohibit the Allstate Insurance Company from conducting business in New York State was approved today in the Assembly by a vote of 104 to 40. It was sent to the Senate for concurrence.
LONDON, March 18 -- Demand was extended to most of the principal sections of the stock market here today, although buying remained selective and price advances were generally in pennies.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- A committee to formulate plans for a public-relations campaign that would answer the detractors of television was appointed today by the National Association of Broadcasters.
IT is doubtful that Nicholas Constantine Christofilos, whose theory on a man-made radiation curtain was apparently verified by Project Argus, has ever really lost an argument.
The harbor received its annual salute yesterday as the varied phases of the maritime industry observed Port of New York Day.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 18 -- The New Jersey Turnpike hired a group of Rutgers University students today to help man its toll booths as a strike of toll collectors and maintenance men went into its second day.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- President Sean T. O'Kelly of Ireland told a joint session of Congress today that Ireland would work "to dissipate unnecessary suspicions" among nations of the world.
ALBANY, March 18 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department, today.
THE trout stocking program is already well under way in New York State, but there has been a change in policy that will make some difference to fishermen, probably for the better.

It is one of the more pleasant quirks of contemporary history that two outstanding British statesmen are half-American. The more famous, of course, is Sir Winston Churchill, whose mother was Jennie Jerome of New York. The present Prime Minister, Harold Macmillan, who is arriving in the United States today, is half a Hoosier, as his mother, Helen Artie Belles, was from Spencer, Ind.
NEWARK, Thursday, March 19 -- A wayward son shot and killed his 58-year-old mother last night when she resisted his attempt to hold up her small cafe.
An important legal precedent governing libel was set in New York State yesterday as a result of a case settled in favor of Toots Shor, midtown restaurateur.

The Boston Bruins clinched second place in the National Hockey League last night at Madison Square Garden and made the New York Rangers' position more precarious in the locals' bid for a Stanley Cup play-off berth.

" Lady Chatterley's Lover," D. H. Lawrence's novel about a grande dame's affair with her husband's gamekeeper, will be published in unexpurgated form for the first time in the United States May 4. At that time Grove Press, Inc., will release an initial printing of 10,000 copies.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Rockefeller called today for a partnership between private enterprise and the state to help meet the demand for middle-income housing.
Mrs. J. Sargent Cram has sold Peace House, a two-story building at 1280-82 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of 109th Street, where she maintains headquarters for her world peace movement.
A committee of parents and community leaders in the Crown Heights area of Brooklyn last night tentatively approved the opening of new Public School 289 on a limited basis.
A BIG retrospective exhibition of paintings, ceramics, book illustration and other graphic work by, Joan Miro, the Spanish artist, opens to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Israel complained to the Security Council today against the seizure by the United Arab Republic of cargoes from Israel aboard two foreign-flag freighters passing through the Suez Canal.
Many of Chester T. Lane's friends throughout the United States have been saddened by the recent report that our good friend, devoted public servant and fine legal scholar has crossed the bar.
TOKYO, Thursday, March 19 -- The engagement of Princess Suga, 20-year-old sister of Crown Prince Akihito, was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright introduced the Administration's mutual security bill in the Senate today. He gave notice that he had little confidence in the Administration's capacity to meet Soviet challenges.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- In preparation for the visit of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain, who arrives here tomorrow, the State Department has at least defined a flexible negotiating position on Germany.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 18 -- Federal Highway Administrator Bertram D. Tallamy warned today that, if Congress failed to appropriate needed funds at the current session, the 41,000-mile interstate system would run into a "dead end."
PARIS, March 18 -- Italy's Premier and Foreign Minister arrived in Paris tonight for two days of consultations with the French Government on the Berlin crisis and the German problem.

ALEXANDER BRAILOWSKY played a tried-and-true program in his annual Carnegie Hall recital last night, though the pianist did insert a tiny piece of unexpected topping by including the Hummel E flat Rondo.

The six-story building containing sixty-seven apartments at 1245-53 Findlay Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Popham Associates to a client of Nathaniel Zelikow. The deal was for cash over mortgages amounting to $220,000.
Last September the United States drew a thin curtain of radiation around the earth. For a period whose duration is still secret it enveloped almost the entire inhabited portion of the globe.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Diane Varsi, one of the more promising newcomers being developed by Twentieth Century-Fox, surprised studio executives last night by announcing that she was giving up her screen career.

The nation's airlines have "promises" of $1,400,000,000 of loans from banks and insurance companies to help finance purchases of new jet aircraft. But to obtain those loans they are going to have to increase their net worth substantially.
The Greyhound Corporation accused the Port Authority yesterday of "jealousy and fear of competition" in opposing Greyhound's plan to build a $10,000,000 bus terminal in midtown Manhattan.

MANY oriental restaurants have opened in New York within the last two years. Most of them have a Chinese or Polynesian flavor. An exception is the Saito restaurant, which is one of the city's most colorful dining spots.

At 69 years of age, Jawaharlal Nehru is, as ever, a man with a purpose. After devoting so many years of his life -- including thirteen in British jails -- to securing India's political independence, his ambition today is to lead his country to what he calls economic independence.
The use of reserve funds to help balance the city's 1959-60 expense budget was unanimously ruled out by Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP) -- A six-day work stoppage that made about 6,000 employes idle at Westinghouse Electric Corporation's suburban Lester plant ended today.

IBADAN, Nigeria, March 18 -- West African intellectuals and politicians who are gathered here for a seminar on representative government and national progress applauded speeches today advocating African federation.

" DON PERLIMPLIN," an opera by Vittorio Rieti Based on a play by Federico Garcia Lorca, attempts to catch the blend of wild comedy and ironic tragedy that marked the work of this greatly gifted Spanish poet and playwright.
PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP) -- Al Cervi resigned as coach of the Philadelphia Warriors today, leaving what he called the "insecurity" of coaching for the "security" of business.
SKI SKETCH: Peter Ryan, one of the East's top Alpine skiers, has lived in Canada for most of his life. Now he finds himself seeking a berth on the 1960 United States Olympic team.
A realignment of high officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and one of its principal operating affiliates was announced yesterday.

Nicholas Silfa, representative in the United States of the Dominican Revolutionary party, charged yesterday that a lieutenant of the Dominican merchant marine, Israel Clark, was murdered by the Dominican political police last Jan. 6 in Ciudad Trujillo.
ALBANY, March 18 -- The Rockefeller administration's bill to curb union abuses went through the Senate today with hardly a word in opposition and only one "no" vote.
Higher prices of stocks at the opening and for the first hour gave way yesterday to a slow downward progression, and the market closed with a moderate loss.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator John F. Kennedy warned today that ineffective action at the state and county level could force Congress to move toward meeting problems of metropolitan growth.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla was found guilty by the Colombian Senate today of having acted "in violation of the national Constitution" and of "abuse of power by improper conduct in the exercise of the office of President."

A young girl given Salk vaccine in a polio-threatened Greek village . . . a teenager fed and clothed in a Ceylonese town devastated by flood . . . an Algerian refugee sheltered in Morocco . . . these and many thousands more in every corner of the globe gave thanks for the Red Cross last year.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- A New York investment banker forecast today that shares in E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and General Motors Corporation might plunge 20 to 25 per cent in value if a Government plan for stock disposal were adopted.

Among the several subjects proposed for interim study by the New York Legislature is the question of strikes by governmental employes and their prevention. The Mitchell-Brook bill suggests for this purpose the creation of a temporary state commission on public employe labor relations. It would consist of four members, two of them appointed by Governor Rockefeller and one each by Senator Mahoney and Speaker Heck, and would report back to the 1960 Legislature.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Trading in grain futures was slow and dull today. Brokers worked toward evening up commitments in the expiring March contracts while awaiting a Government report on farmer intentions for 1959 plantings.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A union-sought provision that would have narrowed the definition of "supervisor" in the Taft-Hartley law was beaten in the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee today.
MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) -- A Soviet Union hockey team defeated the United States All-Stars, 6-1, tonight in Lenin Stadum.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A new experiment in government economic policy got under way today with the swearing in of W. Allen Wallis, dean of the University of Chicago School of Business, as executive vice chairman of the new Cabinet Committee on Price Stabilty for Economic Growth.
The two Valenti brothers jailed last August for refusing to testify about the Apalachin gangland meeting will appear before the State Investigation Commission today, ready to talk.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- America's "man in the street" was thanked by the Austrian Government today for his contribution to that nation's reconstruction through the Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower's order to curb oil imports came under Republican attack in the Senate today as inflationary, harmful to hemispheric unity and discriminatory against non-oil-producing areas.

BOSTON, March 18 (UPI) -- Tom Heinsohn scored 28 points tonight as he led the Boston Celtics to a 131-109 victory over the Syracuse Nationals in the opening game of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division play-off finals.

The benefit premiere performance of the Twentieth Century-Fox film, "The Diary of Anne Frank," at the Palace Theatre last night drew a large audience including well-known personages of the entertainment and social worlds. Proceeds from the screening went to the American Association for the United Nations, Inc.
A program of vocational training inside prison walls should be set up by labor groups, Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of the Kings County Court, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower started a move today to exempt news programs on radio and television from a Federal requirement that equal opportunities be afforded all candidates for a public office.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 18 -- The death toll in Nyasaland and Northern Rhodesia since the outbreak of nationalist disorders rose to at least fifty today.
Mediation sessions to head off a threatened strike of printers against ten daily newspapers here were recessed yesterday "without making any material progress."
It would be cheaper for the city to place its prisoners in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel than in the city's jails, the Board of Correction said yesterday in its first report.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A raiding party of 100 or so Indians, more or less on the warpath, moved in on the capital today.

I think most of us recognize the dilemma confronting the taxpaying citizen: Over the years he has come to expect many services which, until recently, have been paid for out of various sales, property, excise and income taxes.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)--The Senate finance committee was told today the life insurance tax bill passed by the House discriminated against mutual companies.
The revolving-door inquiries into the finances of Joseph G. Luberda, a retired police sergeant, continued yesterday when he was questioned for the second time by a New York County grand jury.

Cecil Simmons, pianist, made his appearance in recital at Town Hall last night. The holder of a master's degree from the Juilliard School, Mr. Simmons has taught at Dartmouth and is now on the faculty of Idaho State College.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee ordered a 1.4 per cent cut today in the first major Eisenhower spending bill to come before it at this session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower signed today the legislation to make the Territory of Hawaii the fiftieth state.
PIKEVILLE, Ky., March 18 (UPI) -- Gov. A. B. Chandler refused a request today to send National Guard troops to keep order in a strike in the southeastern coal fields.
BONN, Germany, March 18 -- An altercation between Soviet Army officers and a United States airman who caught them photographing a secret military installation in West Germany has come to light.

The program of the Child Guidance League will be furthered as a result of the appearance of Mischa Elman, the violinist, in a concert at Brooklyn College on March 28. Mrs. Henry Everett is benefit chairman.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 (UPI) -- The cases of forty-two Yale University students, accused of participating in two snowball riots with police last week, were continued to April 11 in City Court today.

ROME, March 18 -- Inscriptions found in an ancient cemetery under St. Peter's Basilica were said today to indicate that Christians made pilgrimages to the site about eighty years after the death of the Apostle Peter.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower named Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer today to succeed Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor as Chief of Staff of the Army. General Taylor will retire June 30.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- John Foster Dulles has completed the planned series of deep X-ray treatments for abdominal cancer, the State Department said today.
YONKERS, March 18 -- Considerable progress was reported today in the conditioning of the main racing strip at Yonkers Raceway. The metropolitan harness racing season will open there on Friday night.

A Federal Court in Detroit claimed jurisdiction over the F. L. Jacobs Company yesterday as a result of a creditors suit. The suit may supersede previous rival receiverships by a Federal Court here and a Michigan state court.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 18 (Reuters) -- England's cricket tour of Australia and New Zealand ended in a damp atmosphere today when the second test against New Zealand was abandoned without a ball being bowled for two days of the four-day match.

Events tonight: "Un ballo in maschera," Metropolitan Opera, 8 o'clock; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; David Hancock, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Dora Kartakova, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

The Government has called upon authorities in 100 port cities of the United States to help plan for the continued operation of essential harbor facilities under wartime emergency conditions -- including full-scale nuclear attack.

For more than six months those concerned with Project Argus have debated -- sometimes heatedly -- whether its findings should be made public. The tendency was for the scientists to favor publication and for the military and political leaders to oppose it. Recently, however, it was learned that at least some of those highly placed in the Pentagon favored limited publicity.

What does a new breed have to do for acceptance into the American Kennel Club's official family of pure-bred dogs? One such, the German wire-haired pointer, was introduced into the circle last month. Another, the Australian Silky Terrier, is close to being "recognized," a word the A. K. C. dislikes.

The Rev. Martin Luther King, who led the bus boycott against segregation in Montgomery, Ala., returned here yesterday from a month's tour of India. He said the visit had strengthened his belief in using nonviolence to achieve racial justice.

As depressing as it may sound, that brand-new sled that was delivered with a red ribbon around it by Santa Claus is still standing in the cellar without so much as even a shakedown run through the snow.
Columbia University announced yesterday that it had received a "substantial gift" from the Seeley Wintersmith Mudd Foundation for its proposed engineering center.

Experience gained by Sylvia Harris in helping to bring Sam Levene to Broadway in "Make A Million" has encouraged her to plan a second venture, an independent one. It will be a song-and-dance conception of "Tovarich."

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 18 -- The director of the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization expressed the judgment today that the nation could sustain itself and recover in the event of a nuclear attack. He is, however, seeking $29,685,000 in additional appropriations for next year to strengthen the nation's non-military defense program further.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- The first half of the Yankees' exhibition campaign in this sector ended today on a wet and distressing note. For the third successive day the Bombers were forced to remain idle when rain washed out their game with the Senators.
A television documentary on Hawaii will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, March 29.
The Lexington Democratic Club has informed Mayor Wagner that if he wants the club's support he must take a more active interest in the reform movement in the Democratic party.

Net assets of the 15 member companies of the National Association of Investment Companies reached a record high of $14,002,458,000 on Feb. 28, the trade group reported yesterday. George A. Mooney, executive director of the mutual fund association, said this compared with $13,705,526,000 in 153 funds on Jan. 31 and $9,193,238,000 in 144 funds on Feb. 28, 1958.
The rebellion by employes of the American Sugar Refining Company here against continued representation by the International Longshoremen's Association assumed impressive proportions yesterday.

PARIS, March 18 -- In a report published today the commission, or executive body, of the European common market made proposals for limited concessions to Britain and other nations that have sought a free-trade area as a counterweight to the common market.

Theodore L, Blumberg of Philadelphia, a director of the Penn-Texas Corporation, announced yesterday that he had accepted nomination on the management slate for the board for another term. Mr. Blumberg won his seat by leading a proxy contest in which he opposed the previous management.
Scientific developments have brought a time of intellectual crisis, the president-elect of the American Association for the Advancement of Science said here yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 18 (AP) -- A physician choked to death last night on a piece of steak. Four months ago his son, a farmer, saved him in a similar situation by operating on him with a paring knife.
The Transit Authority promoted three members of its police force yesterday. One was a woman detective.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Green Mansions," a color adaptation of the W. H. Hudson novel, costarring Audrey Hepburn and Anthony Perkins, is at the Radio City Music Hall. Edmund Grainger produced the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer presentation and Mel Ferrer directed, from a screen play by Dorothy Kingsley.

At a luncheon given yesterday by Mrs. Anthony Del Balso at her home, 740 Park Avenue, chairmen and committee members for the annual Kips Bay dinner dance completed plans for the fete. It will be held in the Balroom of the Plaza on April 16.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company formally began its hundredth anniversary celebration yesterday with the dedication of a wall-mounted medallion honoring the founder and his two sons.

TRENTON, March 18 -- A suit to force sixty - nine Bergen County communities to begin immediately the assessment of all of their real properties at 100 per cent of true value was filed in Superior Court here today.

Secret nuclear test detonations at more than 300 miles above the earth were conducted by the United States early last September. The tests, which have not previously been revealed and are believed to have been undetected by other countries, resulted in data of great military and scientific importance.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate deferred action again today on the omnibus banking bill, presumably because it lacked the thirty votes needed for passage. It is scheduled to come up for a vote tomorrow.

The United States Maritime Administration blazed a new trail yesterday for American shipping. It found "tentatively" that a trade route from the Great Lakes to the Mediterranean was "essential" to the nation's foreign commerce.
Six gunmen yesterday held up a lower Manhattan greeting card concern after its payroll had been distributed and got $15,000 in cash, jewelry and personal effects from twenty-five persons.
The 2 o'clock matinee, begun yesterday, was pronounced a success last night by theatre operators and by Mrs. Emilio Mayer, a suburban housewife, who sparked the idea.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 18 -- The warehouses and yards at the mouth of the Golden Horn bulged today with imports such as Turkey had not seen in five years.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Army announced today that it would send another Redstone missile group to Germany early next month to strengthen the North Atlantic Treaty's defenses in Europe.

Mrs. Hilton H. Stothers is chairman of the committee for the annual benefit luncheon and fashion show of the auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital. The ballroom of the Pierre will be the setting for the event on April 7.

The nation's inventories of gasoline increased 3,275,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 210,290,000 barrels, compared with 207,015,000 a week earlier and 216,525,000 a year ago.
ARE you timid or a temptress? Insecure or a healthy extrovert ?
American Airlines, Inc., last year achieved record revenues and increased earnings 43.5 per cent over those of 1957, according to the annual report issued for publication today.
SEBRING, Fla., March 18 -- Most of the more than sixty cars here for the twelve-hour championship sports car race on Saturday practiced in rain today.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate Rules Committee approved the introduction of a bill today that would permit Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam to file a claim for $7,900 against New York City. The money represents a pay cut she was forced to take while serving as a justice of the Municipal Court between 1939 and 1946.

NEW DELHI, India, March 18 -- The United States agreed today to lend India the equivalent of $200,000,000 earned by the sale of surplus wheat and other agricultural commodities to the New Delhi Government.

XENIA, Ohio, March 18 (UPI)) -- Ten persons, eight of them Girl Scouts, were killed today when a Pennsylvania Railroad frieght train hit their station wagon on a rural crossing near here.

The state Labor Department's Division of Employment announced yesterday a full investigation of its referral practices and personnel policies after new charges of discrimination were made by a labor union.
BONN, Germany, March 18 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has indicated to two West German Social Democratic leaders that the Soviet Union is flatly opposed to the reunification of Germany.

Programs for the coming engagement of the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning April 16 have been announced by S. Hurok, American impresario who is bringing the company to this country in collaboration with the American National Theatre and Academy.
Deliveries of oxygen tanks and other vital supplies were interrupted yesterday by a picket line at the Presbyterian Hospital.

This part is represented by the mutual security program, mislabeled "foreign aid."

BRADENTON, Fla., March 18 -- "Don't try to figure out how it happened, because you can't," said Carleton Willey, wincing slightly at the memory. "It was a freak accident that sounds so silly I almost hate to tell about it. I was pitching for Atlanta in 1952 when I snapped off a curve. It was some snap.
In a letter published Feb. 25 State Senator Dutton S. Peterson made a number of incorrect statements regarding the sales outlets for potentially dangerous proprietary (patent) medicines.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Jubilant Democrats maintained today that they had scored a major victory in yesterday's village elections.

David Green sold the eleven-story loft building at 33-35 West Seventeenth Street to clients of Maurice A. Schnur for cash over two mortgages amounting to $185,000. The property is 50 by 100 feet and was sold through H. M. Oppenheimer of the Key Realty Company, Forest Hills brokers.

Directors of the Bell Howell Company yesterday voted to split the common stock two-for-one. They also announced their intention to raise the dividend to 14 cents from 12 1/2 on the new shares. The stock now receives 25 cents quarterly.
ALBANY, March 18 -- The state's withholding tax program is flushing tax cheats out of their coverts two weeks before it goes into effect.
Samuel Perlman, a seasoned theatregoer, proclaimed himself the victor yesterday in his war 'against a Broadway box office that sold him two orchestra seats with an obstructed view of the stage.
Missiles, space vehicles and radios one-tenth the size of those now produced were promised yesterday for the near future.

ALBANY, March 18 -- A bill to revise the planned Brooklyn approach to the Narrows bridge was rushed through both the Assembly and Senate today. It now goes to Governor Rockefeller, whose attitude toward it is uncertain.

POLITICS is merely war carried on in another sphere. We see that as we read Stimson Bullitt's bright, battle-scarred memoir, "To Be a Politician,"* a superb guide to one of the most interesting and dangerous callings in America.
FORT DIX, N. J., March 18 -- On a chill, windswept field here this morning four youthful G. I.'s milled about a massive bronze statue of a fully equipped combat infantryman.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Lewis L. Strauss complained today that the delay in Senate confirmation of his appointment as Secretary of Commerce was creating a morale problem in the department.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Over solid Democratic opposition, the Senate today gave final approval to the Republican measure fixing Sept. 15 as the date for this year's primary election. The bill now goes to Governor Rockefeller.

Harry Winston, Inc., jeweler, has purchased the five-story Steuben Glass building at 718 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street. The buyer plans to convert and occupy the building. The jewelry concern is now at 7 East Fifty-first Street.
A Kings County grand jury investigating relief chiseling demanded yesterday that the Welfare Department tighten its procedures in handling children born out of wedlock.

President Sean T. O'Kelly of Ireland said here yesterday that he had "casually" brought up the question of Irish unity in his St. Patrick's Day conversations with President Eisenhower. He said he had received no response.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The Navy has a problem with absentees, but for a few months there were not enough of them, and this has upset the budget.
PARIS, March 19 -- While labor agitation increased in various parts of France, Finance Minister Antoine Pinay optimistically reported today that the nation's economy was "in robust health."
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- New York is back in the bidding for the 1960 Republican convention site.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -The Treasury announced a major new debt-management device today.

DEABORN, Mich., March 19 (AP) -- Teamsters picketed the Dearborn City Hall today as Mayor Orville H. Hubbard stomped and spat on a subpoena ordering him to appear at a labor mediation hearing for organized city employes.

Tony Anthony will get another chance in the Madison Square Garden ring tonight. The Harlem boxer will be back with the light heavyweights as he opposes Sonny Ray of Chicago in the main bout of ten rounds.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 19 -- A foreign-language experiment on the elementary school level here is proving a success, owing in large part to the efforts of a French-educated Parent-Teacher Association member and a babysitter.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic was "a rather hotheaded young man" who "took upon himself more than his stature permitted" in assailing Communists in the Middle East and the Iraqi regime.
The Junior Council of the Museum of Modern Art will sponsor a benefit preview of "Recent Sculpture USA" at the museum on May 12.
TAMPA, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds and the Los Angeles Dodgers, inactive since Sunday because of rain, decided today to fly to Havana to play an exhibition game tonight.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Rockefeller Administration is moving to take control of the State Civil Service Commission and to install a new president, H. Eliot Kaplan.
CARLSTADT, N. J., March 19 -- Dutch experts today unfolded a $15,000,000 construction plan to put 15,000 acres of the Hackensack Meadows into condition for development.
ALBANY, March 19--As administration aides worked on the final draft of legislation aid hard-pressed railroads, was disclosed today that one item of relief--revision of the full-crew law--was dead.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A research psychologist at the National Institutes of Health said today that Sigmund Freud was wrong about babies.
Two Soviet scientists made public twelve days ago their strong suspicion that the United States had carried out something like what is now known to have been the Project Argus.
MONTREAL, March 19 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs trounced the Montreal Canadiens, 6 -- 3, tonight and moved to within 1 point of the fourth-place New York Rangers.
Don't look now, but someone may be watching you.

All-America Don Hennon of Pittsburgh, Rudy LaRusso of Dartmouth's Ivy League champions and three players from New York colleges yesterday were named to the United Press International all-east basketball team.

HAVANA, March 19 (UPI) -- The number of alleged "war criminals" executed by firing squads since early January reached 483 today. The newspaper Revolucion, organ of Fidel Castro's revolutionary movement, called in a first-page editorial for an end of the executions.
The city is entitled to know whether "all reasonable steps" are being taken to prevent unnecessary hospital costs, the chairman of the new Commission on Health Services said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger of Oregon today urged a fellow Democrat, Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, to join him in an attempt to revise the seniority system of the Senate.

Copper futures continued to decline yesterday in heavy trading on the Commodity Exchange. Heavy commission house selling again touched off stop-loss selling. New speculator and dealer buying absorbed the offerings.
Increases in prices for domestic and foreign petroleum products were forecast yesterday by the president of the nation's largest oil company.
GENEVA, March 19 -- The three-power conference for a ban on testing nuclear weapons recessed today until April 13 at the West's request.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 19 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority tonight made what it called a final conciliatory gesture to more than 400 striking toll collectors and maintenance men.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- It cost the Justice Department $390,000 last fall to assemble and train a group of United States Marshals for use in school integration trouble spots -- chiefly Little Rock, Ark.
WESTFORD, Mass., March 19 -- The first known radar contact has been made with the planet Venus. A research team from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology reported on the experiment today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Israel has appealed to neutral maritime nations to support her demand for release of Israeli cargoes seized by the United Arab Republic within the last month in the Suez Canal.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 19 -- Transfer home for twenty members of the United States Operations Mission in Bolivia has been requested as a first step toward reducing the $26,000,000 United States aid program.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 19 -State Senator Joseph Cowgill, Democrat of Camden County, today declared that opposition in Delaware Township to construction of an $8,000,000 ball park had "torpedoed" any prospect of luring the Philadelphia Phillies baseball team to South Jersey.

SEBRING, Fla., March 19 -- Rain continued to fall today and only a few sports cars took practice runs on the water-logged course where the annual twelve-hour world championship race is scheduled on Saturday.
In his latest statement, made in Moscow yesterday, Mr. Khrushchev once more blew hot and cold, cajoled and threatened. He did, however, make three points which should be noted for the record.
Fifteen prominent Minnesotans, led by Gov. Orville L. Freeman, swung through the Port of New York yesterday to open a selling and learning expedition.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 11 -- The Yugoslav economy showed a generally upward trend in 1958 despite a slowdown in industrial productivity and a drought that cut agricultural output by about 20 per cent.

Maurice Epstein, representing a syndicate of investors bought two five-story store and apartment houses on a plot 40 by 95 feet at 518-20 Madison Avenue near Fifty-third Street. The property was purchased from the William Waldorf Astor estate in a deal negotiated by Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., broker.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 19 (UPI) -- An Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile equipped with a new recoverable nose cone fell into the ocean last night after having covered less than a fifth of its planned flight, the Air Force announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Britain is carrying out an ambitious development program in her small mainland area of China.

IF the Metropolitan Opera did not have performers like Mary Curtis-Verna, it would have to invent them. A repertory company involved in a long season in which more than a score of operas are presented must have singers like the American soprano who are prepared to step in and do exacting roles proficiently at short notice.

Once again the New York Legislature, with its omniscient wisdom for dealing with local matters at a distance, has volunteered by overwhelming majority to substitute its superior judgment for the decision of engineering experts in the location of the approach route in Brooklyn to the Narrows bridge.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Controller General has told Congress that "weaknesses" in the Government's administrative controls contributed to a more than $28,000,000 increase in the cost of the first full-scale atomic power plant at Shippingport, Pa.

WASHINGTON, March 19--The United States, on the basis of information obtained from last summer's three high-altitude atomic explosions, can be expected to demand that a space detection system be incorporated in any agreement on a test ban.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union opened negotiations with the coat and suit industry yesterday without asking for a general wage rise for 46,000 members.

As a former Town Moderator of the Town of Saugus, Mass., I greatly enjoyed your sympathetic and interesting column under Topics on March 10, concerning the New England town meeting system of government.
LONDON, March 19 (AP) -Two American sisters, Judy and Sue Devlin of Baltimore, today advanced to the semi-finals of the women's singles in the all-England badminton championships.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Damage suits totaling more than $22,000,000 resulting from the 1950 explosion at South Amboy, N. J., have been settled for $3,310,000.
The young man in the maroon hospital bathrobe beamed. "I sure never thought I could play one of these things," he said as he picked out the chords for "Home on the Range" on a guitar.
