EVERY bedroom in the house soon will blossom into spring, if Altman's has anything to say about it.
THE sense of guilt often felt by the parents of an only child is not justified by the existing scientific data.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- A gathering of Indians marched in front of the White House for hours today, but failed to get an audience with President Eisenhower to ask redress for "bitter injustices."

Jacob Grumet, State Investigation Commissioner, indicated yesterday that he would not consent to a move to release Frank J. Valenti from civil jail although Valenti had testified before the commission about the Apalachin gangland meeting.
The sweet potato probably tastes sweeter to 110 residents of Williamston, N. C., than to many persons elsewhere. The factor behind this possibility is employment; not taste buds.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature sent to Governor Rockefeller today a pioneer labor racketeering bill that he believes will stand as a prototype for other states.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature has under consideration two measures designed to curb County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of Brooklyn in his handling of grand juries.
VIENNA, March 19 -- A draft agreement aimed at curbing unfair trade competition was submitted yesterday to the executive committee of the International Metal Workers Federation meeting in Vienna.

General Electric Company displayed yesterday a new combustion gas turbine that it said it believed would help electric utilities cut rising power production costs. Details were announced at a press conference in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
The fifteenth anniversary of Boys Towns of Italy was observed last night at the Ball of the Year in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The proceeds will aid the organization.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 18 -- Twenty officers and 172 enlisted men of the Navy have returned to their base here from a cruise in two submarines under the ice pack off Newfoundland. They found it the calmest voyage they had ever taken.

WARSAW, March 19 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka ousted most of his opponents -- particularly former Stalinists -- from the top ranks of the Polish Communist party today. He replaced them with the Marxist version of the organization man.
A site at Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, fronting on Lincoln Square, has been chosen for a new motion picture theatre. It will be the first constructed in Manhattan in about ten years.

The possibility of Versailles Debutante Ball's taking place on July 9 as planned seemed all but obliterated yesterday with the resignation of Mrs. Edward J. MacMullan of Philadelphia as general chairman of the American committee, and the withdrawal of Daggett Ramsdell, cosmetics house, as a sponsor of the fete.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York said tonigth that the continuance in power of Carmine G. De Sapio or of any New York Democratic boss raised formidable barriers to the election of any Democratic state-wide candidates.

Thirty-eight Queens youths were arrested on disorderly conduct charges yesterday after many of them were said to have taken part in vandalizing a BMT train running from Brooklyn to Forest Hills, Queens.

LANSING, Mich., March 19 -- The Michigan House of Representatives failed by two votes today to pass a bill aimed at providing needed cash to avert payless pay days for state employes in late April or early May.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature is preparing to act on a bill that would empower the New York City Planning Commission to fix the population density of a given area in the city.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The capital's only two-headed agency, the National Labor Relations Board, has bought itself a $50,000 management engineering report that advises it to streamline quickly to avoid sinking deeper in a case-load morass.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The House of Representatives passed a $297,000,000 airport construction bill today, as the old Republican Southern Democratic coalition lost the session's first test of strength.
Viveca Lindfors and Alvin Epstein have been signed to appear in a double bill composed of a Greek tragedy and an eighteenth-century French comedy of love.

NEARLY all of the canvases on view in this month's City Center exhibition, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, are abstract. And nearly all of them are in the loose, expressionist vein that rightly or wrongly has come to be identified with the New York painters.
Plans for the launching of the Actors Fund 1959 Blood Bank Drive were announced yesterday during a cocktail party for theatre people at the Playbill Restaurant in the Manhattan Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -Preliminary information from last summer's atomic tests indicates that radioactive strontium is falling from the stratosphere much faster than had been supposed.

The Italian political situation has long been complicated; it is now paradoxical. So far as one can tell, the majority sentiment in the country is left-of-center. But there is now a Government under Premier Segni that is oriented to the right. Yet Signor Segni is definitely not a man of the right. President Gronchi, for his part, is definitely a man of the left-center -- and he is still President.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Upstate Republicans were told today that failure to pass the pending omnibus banking bill would have dire consequences for small banks in their areas The warning came from the Joint Legislative Committee on Banks as part of a drive to dissuade upstate Republican lawmakers from voting against the measure.
LONDON, March 19 -- An appeal was issued today for $30,000 to rescue thousands of animals threatened by the rising waters of the Zambesi River in East Africa.
The second-in-command of the United Steelworkers of America predicted yesterday that 100,000 idle members would never go back to work despite the steel industry's recovery.

NEW DELHI, India, March 19 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union seems to have promised India more substantial economic assistance in the future as a result of his seven-year plan to overtake the United States.

ON Page 79 of Pat Frank's new novel, "Alas, Babylon,"* hydrogen bombs start falling all over the United States and all over the other major members of the democratic alliance. In a surprise attack on the Pearl Harbor model the bombs were "lobbed" in from hundreds of submarines and rocketed to their targets by hundreds of intercontinental missiles.

A chapter from the past of Alexander L. Guterma came to light yesterday with the disclosure that he had been ordered deported from Hawaii on Dec. 4, 1935. He had been accused of having entered that United States territory illegally on the previous July 22.
Group Health Insurance is willing to cover physicians' visits for the 100,000 members of small employe groups that will no longer receive such protection from Blue Shield after June 1.

AMONG the many symbols that characterize the celebration of Easter, the lamb is one of the most significant. In generations past and in many countries, a cake baked in the shape of a lamb provided the centerpiece, as well as the dessert, for Easter Sunday dinner.

The Islip, L. I., Union Free School District 9 has sold $2,385,720 of serial bonds to a group headed by the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank and Spencer Trask Co. The price was 100.43 for obligations bearing 3.9 per cent interest. Maturing from 1960 to 1989, they were re-offered at prices to yield from 2.2 to 3.95 per cent.
Wedemann Godknecht, Inc., a freight-forwarding concern, failed to reach agreement yesterday on a representation election for its office workers.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan called today for an Allied policy combining "firmness and reasonableness" in dealing with the Russians.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -The end of trading in the March futures contracts was the main business on the Board of Trade today. Dealers also reacted quickly to a Government report on indicated crop plantings this year.
DURHAM, N. C., March 19 -- Malcolm H. Bryan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said today that the end of managed money might be in sight.
BOWIE, Md., March 19 (AP) -- Howard Grant equaled the Maryland riding record and set a new one for Bowie today, winning six of the eight races in which he had mounts.
LONDON, March 19 -- Steel shares scored sharp gains in the stock market here today. Elsewhere, industrials went ahead and Government securities were also firm.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -Some results of the Project Argus experiment are being prepared for publication by the National Academy of Sciences through "normal scientific channels."
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature sent to Governor Rockefeller today a plan for licensing pilots who guide ocean-going vessels on the Hudson River.
TORONTO, March 19 (UPI) Johnny Longden, who rose from a dollar-a-day Alberta miner to a millionaire jockey with more winners than any other rider, soon will be through with race riding.

William Zeckendorf, head of the real estate firm of Webb Knapp, Inc., yesterday announced plans to build a $50,000,000 indoor harness racing plant in the Baychester section of the Bronx. According to the realtor, the plant would operate when New York's outdoor tracks are closed.
Unbeaten Jose Torres, a Puerto Rican middleweight who lives in Brooklyn, gained his eleventh victory before a capacity crowd of 2,470 at the Sunnyside Garden in Queens last night.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The Senate started work today on a $389,500,000 depressed areas bill that one of its supporters said would "give new hope and new opportunity to despondent peoples."

The city Housing Authority came out ahead of itself yesterday when it opened bids for construction of the 998-unit Samuel J. Tilden Houses. Low bids on five contracts totaled $10,112,070, which was $900,000 less than the Authority's own estimate.
THE world's first stainless steel cooking utensil -- a saucepan that cost about $8,000 to make -- goes on view at Hammacher Schlemmer today as part of a store-wide promotion on stainless steel.
CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of the Kings County Court called last night for a conference of legislators and correctional experts to set up a "sensible, workable and equitable system of equal justice and sentences" for law violators.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- John Wexley, author of the play "The Last Mile," filed a breach of contract damage suit today in Los Angeles Superior Court against the producers of the second film version of the drama.

LONDON, March 19 -- The House of Common approved tonight the plan for the independence of Cyprus drawn up here last month by the Premiers of Britain, Greece and Turkey and leaders of the Greek and Turkish Cypriote communities.
" PLAYHOUSE 90" completed last night its taped dramatization of "For Whom the Bell Tolls" with a remarkably effective studio depiction of the climactic battle scenes.
Under the stimulus of the approach of spring and a crucial basketball game, 1,500 New York University students took advantage of a bomb scare yesterday to stage a midday revel in Washington Square.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 19 -- Edwyn Silberling of Huntington was appointed special prosecutor today to continue the Suffolk County scandals investigation.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 -Dr. James Van Allen, one of the nation's leading experts on space radiation, said at the California Institute of Technology today that sufficient neutrons released in space by a nuclear blast could trigger the warhead of an incoming ballistic missile.

LIKE a fine champagne punch, Bernard Newman's clothes have a delayed but powerful impact. His quiet, understated ensembles build gradually in sharp contrast to the volatile designs of Gigliola Curiel. The latter flash across the senses in joyous cartwheels of color.

Joseph G. Luberda, the retired police sergeant whose finances are being investigated by two grand juries, appeared before the Brooklyn grand jury yesterday morning for the third time. He testified for ninety minutes.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Die Meistersinger," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Juliene Berk, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
Boys High and Commerce, the city's speediest scholastic quintets, will meet to decide the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 19 -- The local correspondent of Agence France Presse was arrested today on orders of the Indonesian Attorney General, it was officially disclosed.
YONKERS, March 19 -- The current school year is only two-thirds over, but school officials here have already begun worrying about the year that starts in September.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 19 -- A three-year survey shows many Presbyterian parents wish the church would give them more help on how to guide their children.
The Government securities market was caught completely unprepared by the Treasury's announcement of new financing yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The House subcommittee on information declared today that the Air Force's refusal to give Congress a secret missile report was "a step toward despotism" that would cost thte taxpayers about $125,000.

DURING the last year a new form of cookery has evolved that makes it possible to serve gourmet specialties in a matter of minutes. It is the result of the development of special plastic and foil pouches that withstand extremes in temperature, from freezing to boiling. Breakfasts in bags may be next on the market.

GENEVA, March 19 -- James B. Carey, a United States labor leader, revealed today that he had asked President Eisenhower for an "impartial investigation" of the controversy over the awarding of contracts for heavy electrical equipment to foreign manufacturers.

LOUISVILLE, March 19 -- Before and during the season, college basketball coaches did a lot of sounding off about the rules. At the end of the campaign they are strangely silent. In the questionnaire circulated by Alvin (Doggy) Julian of Dartmouth, the chairman of the rules committee of the National Association of Basketball Coaches, his fellows gave an overwhelmingly affirmative reply to the query, "Are you generally satisfied with the present rules?"

SE habla Espafiol at Saks Fifth Avenue. Spanish-speaking visitors will find a warm welcome at the store's new "Bureau Latino-Americano," which opened on the fifth floor this week. Presiding over a percolator there is Anna Maria Fuentes, a tiny, charming Chilean who will offer all comers far more than a cup of steaming black coffee.

GENEVA, March 19 -- Labor leaders from thirty nations ended a two-day conference today by adopting a resolution calling on all Western Governments to take "early and resolute action to solve the burning economic problems with which they are confronted."

Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken honored yesterday the memory of Dr. Kenneth S. M. Davidson, founder and first director of its Experimental Towing Tank Department, by renaming the facility the Davidson Laboratory.
LONDON, March 19 -- Britain repaid today $200,000,000 of the $561,000,000 she drew from the International Monetary Fund in December, 1956.
MOSCOW, March 19--Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that he accepted in advance the forthcoming Western proposals to convene a foreign ministers' conference May 11.
RICHMOND, Va., March 19 -- A Federal appeals court raised the question today whether local pupil placement tests could be applied only to Negroes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19 -- The textile industry, long in recession, has made a remarkable recovery in recent months in production, prices and profits, members of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, Inc., were told today by their president, Halbert M. Jones.

MIAMI, March 19 -If ever a manager would gladly part with a right leg or a twenty-game winner if only he could be in two places at once, it would have to be Casey Stengel. In fact, because he does not want to run the risk of losing a potential twenty-game winner, the Yankee skipper finds himself in this predicament.
Mrs. Norma Bucher, 38-year-old secretary to former Westchester Judge George A. Brenner, "shortchanged" her employer by at least $125,000, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.
A shake-up in radio programing was announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company network.
Governor Rockefeller was denounced in the City Council yesterday as "far more vicious than any previous Governor" in his attitude toward the city's fiscal problems.
Many blueprints have been drawn for winning friends for the United States.

Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense; Herbert York, director of Defense Research and Engineering; Roy W. Johnson, director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency; Dr. Frank H. Shelton, technical director of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project, and Dr. William J. Thaler, head of the field projects branch of the Office of Naval Research:
The flight engineer of the airliner that crashed in the East River on Feb. 3 insisted yesterday that the captain's altimeter read 500 feet at the moment of read impact.
JERSEY CITY, March 19 -- A belated St. Patrick's Day parade was held here today for the special benefit of eighty-eight youngsters, members of the St. Petersburg, Fla., Senior High School Band.
LORIENT, France, March 19 -- Spring has come to this port in Brittany and with it the first stirrings of labor unrest under the Fifth Republic.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 29 (AP) -- A criminal court jury today convicted three teamsters union members for conspiring to intimidate a truck driver who said he was shot in the face with a tear gas gun.
LONDON, March 19 -- In by-elections today the Conservative party retained two seats it won in the House of Commons in the 1955 general election.

Lumber production climbed to 249,425 boar dfeet last week from 241,931 a week earlier, according to reports to The New York Times yesterday by regional associations. Production was 9.4 per cent higher than the level of a year ago, shipments were 19.9 per cent and orders were 12.3 per cent higher.
An attractive young soprano, Dora Kartakova, who appeared here two years ago, gave a program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP)--Extension Magazine, official publication of the Roman Catholic Church Extension Society, said editorially today that the "true American and the true Catholic will support the man who will make the best President" regardless of religious affiliation.
NOTHING has been done to relieve the barren musical comedy situation with "First Impressions," which opened at the Alvin last evening.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Bills to give New York City power to levy $125,000,000 more in local taxes were speeded through the Legislature today. They now go to Governor Rockefeller, whose approval had been promised.
Directors of Smith, Kline French Laboratories voted a three-for-one split of the capital stock yesterday. The move is subject to approval of shareholders at their annual meeting, May 21.

A labor union cannot dispute the forced retirement of an employe under an employer's pension plan unless the subject is included in the union's contract, according to a ruling yesterday by Federal Judge Alexander Bicks.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Bill Hartack, whose actions have put him in hot water many times, plunged in again today at Gulfstream Park.

LOUISVILLE, March 19 -- Tomorrow night's East-West semi-finals of the National collegiate basketball tournament, which originally involved twenty-three teams, will send Louisville against West Virginia at 8:30 P. M., New York time, and Cincinnati against California about two hours later.
Two hundred prominent persons have been invited to attend a dinner party and a private showing of the movie, "The Diary of Anne Frank," on Tuesday.
LOGAN, W. Va., March 19 (AP) -- An ex-convict was captured after shooting at pursuing police late today and his four hostages -- a young mother and her three children -- were rescued unharmed.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Soviet Union has chosen the last four of ten films that it is buying from United States studios, the State Department announced today.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, March 19 -- Fifteen arrests were reported in Northern Rhodesia today on the eve of elections in the British protectorate.

Loans to business by the seventeen major New York City banks rose $266,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $354,000,000 for the similar week a year earlier.

BONN, Germany, March 19 -- The Social Democratic party, to which about one-third of West Germany regularly votes allegiance, announced today a plan to solve the German problem and the country's reunification.

Today's new film is "Girls of the Night," a French-made drama with Nicole Berger, Claus Holm and Georges Marchal, at the World Theatre, Forty-ninth Street east of Seventh Avenue. Maurice Cloche directed the Continental Distributing release, which has English subtitles.
MOSCOW, March 19 (AP) -- The United States national ice hockey team blew a two-goal lead tonight and bowed, 4 -- 3, to a Soviet junior squad.
The establishment of a national council of the unemployed will be recommended by New York's central labor body. Its members would be recruited from union and non-union workers.

It was like the old, pre-scandal college basketball times last night at Madison Square Garden. Two good games and the biggest crowd since the 1955 Holiday Festival made it a banner night as Bradley and St. John's gained the final of the twenty-second annual National Invitation Tournament.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Republican legislative leaders hammered out an agreement on rent control at a conference this afternoon with Governor Rockefeller.
ROME, March 19 -- Pope John XXIII marked his saint's day today by saying mass for Rome's street cleaners, comforting sick persons and taking part in Lenten rites.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 19 (AP) -- R. Niles Galbraith, assistant circulation director of The Philadelphia Inquirer, died early today in a fire that destroyed his home, a Bucks County showplace. He was 46 years old.
The copper-buying scramble by users trying to lay in supplies as a hedge against possible copper strikes this summer was reported yesterday to have moderated.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -For a few minutes today Dr. Frank Harvey Shelton stepped out of the anonymity that goes with his role as the Pentagon's chief atomic weaponeer. From the way the young, retiring scientist nervously wet his lips, it was apparent that he did not like the unaccustomed glare of publicity.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 19 (AP) -- Doris Phillips of Belleville, Ill., a co-medalist, was eliminated as match play began today in the North and South women's amateur golf tournament. Mrs. Joseph Nesbitt of Greenwich, Conn., beat Phillips, 2 up.

Thirty animals will be exhibited by their new owners in the Adopt-A-Pet Parade, a feature of the annual tea dance of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which will take place in the Roof Garden of the Pierre on Easter Sunday.
Four men, a union local and three blouse industry associations pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court to an antitrust indictment charging conspiracy and monopoly.
A parking lot where an accurate toss of 35 cents opens the toll gate and a strident gong and telltale light discourage cheaters was opened yesterday in Rego Park, Queens.

ST. LOUIS, March 19 (AP) -- Two men with similar bowling backgrounds flirted with a 300 game today in the American Bowling Congress tournament. Each had to be content with 289 when he left one pin standing on the eleventh roll.
United States consumption of newsprint in February was 5.4 per cent above that in the corresponding month of 1958, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
MIAMI, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- The Sun 'n' Fun Festival at Clearwater is about to throw in the sponge. No sun.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Justice Department is investigating the Air Transport Association, the airline industry's biggest trade group, for possible violation of the antitrust laws.
Albert M. Greenfield resigned yesterday as chairman of the Bankers Securities Corporation, Philadelphia. He had held the post since he formed the holding corporation thirty-one years ago.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The bill to prohibit the Allstate Insurance Company from doing business in the state was considered dead today.

I would like to congratulate you on the appraisal of a difficult and awkward situation in your March 16 editorial "New Haven in March." As ample news coverage has been given to the students' misbehavior, I feel that a passing reference to the "impatience" of the New Haven police is inadequate to convey proper appreciation of a serious problem.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -The Customs Bureau has decided to permit the importation of Henry Miller's long-banned novel, "Tropic of Cancer" -- but only for literary and scholarly purposes.
HONOLULU, March 19 -- The imminent statehood of these mid-Pacific islands is being viewed as a tonic by shipping men.

There are three Germanys, not two. Between the wars many Americans were in sympathy with the anschluss, and blamed France for blocking it. Bismarck did not unite Germany: committed to Prussian hegemony, he disrupted the Fatherland.

A spokesman for Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the Mayor would ask Governor Rockefeller to veto the bill barring the use of Seventh Avenue in Brooklyn as an approach to the proposed Narrows Bridge. The measure has been adopted by the Legislature.

A rank-and-file protest by members of Local 1814 of the independent International Longshoremen's Union against an appointed shop steward caused a half-hour work stoppage yesterday afternoon on a Brooklyn pier.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Four Chicago officials of the Teamsters Union were likened today to "robber barons of old" after testimony that they had tapped their local's treasury for more than a million dollars since 1952.
Far fewer than one-third of the families displaced from slum-clearance sites have been relocated in public housing, the City Housing Authority said yesterday.
A RIVAL has arisen to challenge the nature-writing mastery of Joe Durso Jr., 13 years old, of Locust Valley, L. I., who sometimes writes brilliant reviews of boys' outdoor books in this space.
A record salesman was killed last night, the police reported, by a private detective outside the Harlem Bar and Grill at 401 Lenox Avenue.

YONKERS, March 19 -- "Now the Harness Horses," reads a headline published in this newspaper on Sept. 4, 1899, from the racing center called Yonkers. The sixty-year-old headline is just as appropriate now as it was then, for tomorrow night Yonkers Raceway opens its 115-night meeting with a six-decade history behind it.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate approved President Eisenhower's request for expanded authority in international financing today. But it made a bookkeeping change that could destroy the delicate balance of his budget for the coming fiscal year.

A rupee equivalent of about $200,000,000 is to be loaned to India for agricultural projects. This comes from the sale of surplus American agricultural products, especially wheat, that the United States has shipped to India to ease food shortages. In a nutshell, the money stays in India to get on with the good work.
Mayor Wagner expressed the hope yesterday that union printers and the publishers of ten daily newspapers here would avoid a strike "in the public interest."
BOLZANO, Italy, March 19 -- Relations between the Italian-speaking and German-speaking groups in the Alpine Province of Bolzano are worsening.

RAY, Ariz., March 19 (AP) -- Kennecott Copper Corporation officials said today it would take at least two days to restore normal operations at the company's plants here and at Hayden following settlement of a three-week strike.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission clashed in court today over the propriety of off-the-record pleas in connection with the transfer of television Channel 2 from Springfield, Ill., to St. Louis.
Corning Glass Works, manufacturer of a wide variety of glass products and ceramics, improved its sales and earnings last year over those of 1957.
Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $178,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $525,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

A Certain Naivete There is a certain refreshing naivete about the request on the part of the authorities of Our Town that its citizens suggest new areas in which they can be taxed so that the city's financial troubles will be ended.
The Iron Ore Company of Canada has decided to proceed with its second major iron ore mining project in the wilderness of Labrador.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The three atomic blasts in space fired by the United States last summer advanced the nation's research in attack and defense weapons, Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said today.

BERLIN, March 19 (AP) -East German Communists congratulated President Eisenhower today for, they said, giving his speech on Berlin in front of a map showing the present boundaries of Germany rather than the pre-war ones.
The West Penn Electric Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in operating revenues and net income for 1958.

ROME, March 19 -- Two canaries that belonged to the late Pope Pius XII are back in the pontifical apartment in the Vatican's Apostolic Palace. Pope John XXIII asked for them recently and now keeps them in his living room, as was shown by television tonight.

SEATTLE, March 19 -- Sixty contract bridge teams started the second day of knockout competition this afternoon in the Vanderbilt Cup Team-of-Four championship. This is the top event of the Spring National Championships being held here at the Olympic Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 595,302 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The first translation into English of the letters of Camille Ferri Pisani, aide-de-camp to Prince Napoleon during his twomonth tour of America in the summer of 1861, will be published April 13 by Indiana University Press.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee decided today to extend the non-Communist affidavit requirement in the Taft-Hartley Law to employers.

Twenty-two European bicycle riders arrived yesterday to take part in the six-day race that will start Sunday at the 102d Engineers Armory on 168th Street. Four Americans and two Europeans who had arrived earlier will make up the racing teams.

DAVID HANCOCK broke precedent somewhat in his Town Hall piano recital last night. There were two pianos on the stage, and he alternated between them. One was a Boesendorfer concert grand, shipped here for the concert.

The Texas Railroad Commission yesterday set the state's oil production for April on an eleven-day basis. This will mean a permissible output of 3,065,472 barrels a day next month, 107,214 barrels a day below last Saturday's level. This month's output is on a twelve-day basis.

LONDON, March 19 (Reuters) -- Following in translation is the text of a statement by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in Moscow at the beginning of a news conference today, as issued by the Soviet agency Tass:

PIKEVILLE, Ky., March 19 (AP) -- Striking miners and coal operators agreed verbally to an armistice today. It will be in force until Pike Circuit Court rules on a request for an injunction against the United Mine Workers.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- The Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union re-elected most of its top officers in convention here today -- including a vice president now in jail in Alabama.

PARIS, March 19--Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Allied Commander Europe, expressed in guarded and diplomatic terms today his concern over France's decision to keep her Mediterranean fleet under national instead of allied command in time of war.

Stock prices moved unevenly yesterday in a market dominated by the low-price issues. Eleven of the fifteen most-active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange closed below $25 a share. All but one of the fifteen gained although the market averages slipped.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union could commit an illegal secondary boycott by refusing to dispatch workers to a job because of a dispute involving a neutral employer.

The Long Island Rail Road yesterday disclosed its plans to "cover" the New York thoroughbred racing season, which begins at the Jamaica race track on Wednesday. Mondays through Fridays the line will run six special trains from Penn Station, stopping at Woodside, and four from Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, stopping at Nostrand Avenue and East New York.
A limited number of highly qualified high school graduates will be admitted to Columbia University's School of Engineering next fall for the first time since 1914.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A recent ruling by a Supreme Court majority of five, and the dissent of the other four justices, in a case dealing with the proper use by judges of the Federal rules of procedure in criminal contempts have an unusual number of claims on the public interest.

Agreement with the Soviet Union on Germany is impossible "in the present state of affairs," according to Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Writing in the April issue of Foreign Affairs, he said only one compromise seemed possible.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, March 20 -- Maj. Gen. Kang Sang Ho of North Korea demanded today that the United Nations Command "remove promptly" all new types of weapons from Korea, including atomic devices and guided missiles.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- The House Civil Service Committee approved a bill today to restore Federal pensions to some workers disqualified in 1954 by passage of the so-called "Hiss act."
Trans World Airlines will introduce commercial jet service today on its transcontinental route.
PARIS, March 20 -- Paris was almost without taxis today as the annual exodus began for Easter vacations.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Occidental Life Insurance Company of California said today it had severed business connections with Harland R. Maris, Chicago insurance man, and concerns with which he is connected.

First there were about 2,000. Then there were a few hundred. Yesterday afternoon there were fifteen. Now there are two. And the Metropolitan Opera next season will have those two as new additions to its roster of singers.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Court of Appeals was asked today to hold unconstitutional the State Department's ban on travel to Communist China.

Any reduction in the state banking districts will make an extremely difficult task of dealing with proposed consolidations and absorptions in the future. It is recognized that it is only the very largest banks that are actively seeking expansion at the present time.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 20 -- About twenty white women, wearing black sashes of mourning, staged a silent demonstration outside Southern Rhodesian Parliament today in protest against the Government's preventive detention bill.

Premier Samir el-Rifai of Jordan arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, from London last evening and complained to reporters about the treatment accorded him by Federal immigration officers.
PARIS, March 20 -- With little evidence of support from private French interests, the Government took two important decisions today to step up the industrialization of Algeria.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The recipients of the 250 Regents College Teaching Fellowships, which are intended to encourage capable students to prepare for careers as college teachers, were announced today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner.
A party of visiting Minnesota leaders forecast yesterday a bright future for the new "seaport" of Duluth. They assured maritime officials here it would not hurt the Port of New York.
How the proposed 10-cent tax on city taxicab fares will be collected was still uncertain last night.

Juliene Berk's debut program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall had much to recommend it. The soprano made an attractive appearance on the stage, she chose an excellent program and sang it intelligently, and her pianist, Lawrence Smith, was top-notch.
VIENNA, March 20 -- The emigration of Jews from Rumania has been stopped since March 9 but Jewish welfare workers here hope it will resume in the near future.

Mayor Wagner sent to the printer yesterday the first draft of a 1959-60 expense budget. It reduces some essential city services and withholds part of the pay rises that had been planned for thousands of city employes.

HAVANA, March 20 -- Jose Figueres, former President of Costa Rica and one of the leading figures of the Caribbean revolutionary movement, arrived here this afternoon as the guest of the Cuban revolutionary Government.
Payroll experts attended school here yesterday to learn how to withhold the proper amount of New York State income tax from paychecks.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 20 (AP) -- A 19-year-old airman sealed himself inside a high altitude test chamber set for 73,000 feet, then ripped off his oxygen mask to commit suicide at the Davis-Monthan Air Force Base.

YONKERS, March 20 -- Ten nights earlier than ever, harness racing made its seasonal debut before a course-record opening crowd of 35,023 at Yonkers Raceway tonight. With a bow to Governor Rockefeller, who requested the extra dates because the State needs money (Who doesn't?), the nine-race program went off with only one hitch -- some got shut out.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will try to convince President Eisenhower that the Western powers should revise their position on German re unification, diplomatic sources believe.
Palm Sunday, the first day of Holy Week, will be commemorated with joyful reverence tomorrow by the churches of New York.
IT IS not only by name that Sean Thomas O'Kelly is suited to be President of Ireland.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Saturday, March 21 -- At least 75 per cent of the 7,800 registered nonwhite voters went to the polls yesterday in Northern Rhodesia's legislative elections, according to Government sources.
ALBANY, March 20 -- It's a little late for St. Patrick's Day, to be sure, but the Board of Regents has decided to recognize Irish medicine.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Air Force said today that mysterious lighted objects reported recently by a commercial airliner were the lights of three jet bombers refueling in the air.
LONDON, March 20 -- Profit-taking at the end of the week caused the industrials to move irregularly in the stock market here today.
PROFESSIONAL advice on how to make both ends meet is available without charge. It is contained in more than a score of pamphlets offered by local banks and the Institute of Life Insurance.

A possible proxy contest apparently has been averted by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad (Milwaukee Road). The road has agreed to give three directorships to an Eastern investment group that has been purchasing large blocks of the carrier's stock in recent months.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Air Force today picked Convair division of General Dynamics Corporation to design the bomber aircraft to be equipped with a nuclear propulsion plant.

NEWARK, March 20 -- A possible settlement of the four-day-old strike of toll collectors and maintenance men on the New Jersey Turnpike was indicated today after a meeting of representatives of both sides.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- It is the hope of the Administration that when courts require the integration of public schools "it will never be necessary again" to use Federal armed forces.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- Labor and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People apparently have patched up a rift over alleged racial discrimination by unions.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Four persons died today in the collision of a northbound Greyhound bus and an automobile on heavily traveled U. S. 1 during a rainstorm.
CAIRO, March 20 -- The United Arab Republic will continue to seize Israeli cargoes shipped through the Suez Canal from Israel to other countries, informed sources said today.

LONG BEACH, Calif., March 20 (UPI) -- Southern California, which is having its driest winter in years, today started a movement to transfer major league spring training activities here from rain-soaked Florida.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the reappointment of Robert Moses for a five-year term as a trustee of the State Power Authority. The appointment is subject to Senate confirmation.

PARIS, March 20 -- France agreed today to propose Italian participation in an eventual East-West conference on Germany and security questions if efforts were made to enlarge the membership and to expand the agenda to include matters of direct concern to Italy.

Over the more than twenty-five years of its existence the Tennessee Valley Authority has been criticized by its natural enemies as battening on the taxpayer's money and competing unfairly with private utilities. As far as the taxpayer's money is concerned, T. V. A. has had the use of about $1.2 billion, of which about $300 million has been paid back into the Treasury.
LONDON, March 20 -- The British Atomic Energy Authority announced today changes in its organizational arrangements, to become effective July 1.

Mayor Wagner's television speech last night continued and expanded the recently conceived City Hall strategy of placing the major blame on the Albany Republican leadership for his budgetary and taxation troubles.

The Cities Service Company sold more petroleum products in 1958 than in any other year in its history and for the second consecutive year had gross operating income of more than $1,000,000,000, according to the annual report released yesterday.

DURHAM, N. C., March 20 -- A critic of monetary policy suggested today that more could be done to achieve growth and stability in the economy through Congressional control over spending and taxes than through the Federal Reserve's influence over the cost and availability of credit.

Stockholders of the Carborundum Company elected Leon A. Patt, William H. Wendel and Clarence D. Shepard directors at the annual meeting in Niagara Falls, N. Y., on Thursday. The company manufactures abrasives. sives.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- In a re-evaluation of the Government report on indicated crop plantings this year, grain futures brokers became a bit more friendly today to oats and rye contracts on the Board of Trade.
A $250,000 trust fund, $5,000 in cash, and jewelry and furniture have been left to a Park Avenue maid.
ALBANY, March 20 -- The Legislature received a bill today that would require unemployment insurance coverage for all employed persons.

The possibility that the Soviet Union will devote more attention to consumer goods output than was originally planned appears to arise as a result of Alexei N. Kosygin's appointment as chief Soviet planner.

A syndicate represented by Maurice Epstein has purchased two six-story apartment houses on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 329 to 335 East Forty-ninth Street between First and Second Avenues. The seller was a client of Nathan Miller, the broker in the deal.
YAKIMA, Wash., March 20 (AP) -- Bill Marolt of Aspen, Colo., dropped down Pigtail Peak at a mile a minute today to win the boys' downhill title in the national junior ski championships.

At 4 P. M. today St. John's basketball team, buoyed by the hopes of metropolitan fans, will face Bradley at Madison Square Garden in the final of the National Invitation Tournament. A crowd of 16,000 is expected to attend. The game will be televised over Channel 4.
Banton L. Wyckoff, 32-year-old real estate operator, surrendered in Municipal Term Court yesterday to answer charges of illegal conditions in tenements he operated.
WHAT, we may ask, is Anthony Bailey trying to do in his new novel, "Making Progress"*? How well has he accomplished his mission -- if any? And what on earth is his book all about?
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A board of directors was announced today for a project that plans to send a civilian-operated hospital ship on a goodwill medical mission to Southeast Asia.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 20 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that it had successfully tested a nuclear weapon that would give a two-man bazooka team the striking power of a World War II bomber.

Directors of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation yesterday voted to split the common stock in the ratio of 1 1/4 for 1, which would give one additional share of common stock for each four held. Stockholders are to vote on the proposal at the annual meeting April 22, the plywood, lumber and paper producer said.
A Federal mediator continued his efforts yesterday to head off a threatened strike by union printers on ten daily newspapers in the city. But no progress was reported.
The highest trading volume in more than twenty-nine years hit the American Stock Exchange yesterday, almost overwhelming its ticker service.
A STIMULATING, if inconclusive, half-hour of morning-after quarterbacking analyzed the telecast of "For Whom the Bell Tolls" in a new Channel 5 program yesterday.

DETROIT, March 20 -- Two court-appointed trustees for the F. L. Jacobs Company indicated today that they would investigate the advisability of accepting an offer by three stockholders of the Symphonic Electronic Corporation to buy back Symphonic stock owned by Jacobs.

MEXICO City March 20 (UPI) -- Mexico's nationalized oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), has borrowed an additional $12,000,000 from American banks, it was announced today. This brings to $72,000,000 the total borrowed so far this year for expansion projects.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Ninth grade youths of today are as mature as eleventh and twelfth graders of twenty years ago, as measured by lipstick.
A patch of low clouds and fog hung over the East River area where an American Airlines plane crashed Feb. 3.
NEWARK, March 20 (AP) -- One of two men accused of the Wild West robbery of passengers in a commuter bus in Secaucus on Feb. 27 pleaded guilty today.
Can this city of 8,000,000, beset by tax problems, legally secede from the rest of the state? Can it become the fifty-first state of the Union without resorting to armed rebellion?

Of all the tragic and outrageous aspects of the fire which burned to death the twenty-one boys who had been locked up and left unattended in the Wrightsville, Ark., "reform" school, was that revealed in the last paragraph of your report:

For those who are baffled by the feature and price claims in appliance advertising, a helpful new buying guide is available. It is a twenty-eight-page booklet entitled "How to Buy an Electrical Appliance."
ROME, March 20 -- The slum-clearing program started by Rome to prepare for next year's Olympic Games is proving a tantalizing task. More shacks spring up overnight than are pulled down.

PAUL PARAY, who is taking over the last of Dimitri Mitropoulos' scheduled Philharmonic concerts this season, demonstrated his skill and sympathy for an all-French program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.
The Government bond market was moderately lower yesterday in fairly active trading following Thursday's surprise announcement that the Treasury would sell $500,000,000 of ten-year bonds next week.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has enclosed with its pamphlet report to stockholders a statement that the manner of determining quotas among refiners under the Federal Government's new mandatory controls on oil imports is "grossly discriminatory.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Col. William F. Friedman (U. S. A., Ret.), to whom Congress awarded $100,000 in 1956 for his inventions in military cryptography, received a patent this week for a ciphering and deciphering machine. The machine can be used also as an "authenticator" to determine whether a message comes from a genuine source.

At a moment when so much is at stake in Europe it is disappointing to note an increasing tension between two West European countries that are our friends -- Italy and Austria. The tension arises because of the demands for greater political, economic, cultural and linguistic autonomy by the German-speaking population of the Italian province of Bolzano, or Alto Adige.
CHANDELIERS, once the mark of a millionaire, are moving from mansions to walkups.
DECATUR, Ill., March 20 (AP) -- The General Electric Company announced today it was gettting out of the plastics business.
Heavier markets are in prospect for lightweight papers.
David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said yesterday that if there was a steel strike this summer it would be "deliberately'' forced on the union by the industry.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

MIAMI, March 20 -- The rain-stalled Yankees and Braves, after being held idle four successive days, finally got around to flexing their muscles today with matinee and evening performances that drew a combined crowd of more than 10,000 to Miami Stadium. The Bombers bagged both games.
The ticker-tape parade up lower Broadway for visiting celebrities has been undergoing a change of face.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, expressed hope today that new mandatory quotas on oil imports would stabilize United States oil prices and encourage greater United States production.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., March 20 -- Miss Edna V. O'Brien, 73-year-old civic leader, died in a fire that destroyed her four-room cottage on Sleepy Hollow Road at 2 o'clock this morning. She was a descendant of an aide to Gen. Robert E. Lee.

Costenze Valenti, a lean, curly haired man, sat before the State Investigation Commission for two hours yesterday but shed no light on the Apalachin gangland convention at the home of Joseph Barbara on Nov. 14, 1957.
ALBANY, March 20 -- The State Superintendent of Banks today announced the appointment of William R. Brennan Jr. of Garden City, L.I., as a special consultant for not more than six months.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- A dispute between the suburban all-white community of Rutledge and a Negro couple was settled today in the Delaware County Court.
BOSTON, March 20 (AP) -- The New England Council issued the following reports on ski conditions today, along with the weather forecast for New England:
CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A group of Indians tried today to put Indian Affairs Commissioner Glenn L. Emmons under "citizen's arrest." Balked in the effort, they decided to give up and go home.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A Congressional investigation into the problems of the economy opened today with a witness whose position sharply contradicted pet theories of both liberals and conservatives.
The Public Schools Athletic League of New York will sponsor a football championship for the first time next fall.
The Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center at 652 West 170th Street will receive the proceeds of a supper dance to be held at the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East on April 5.

An option to purchase the six-story store and residential building at 4 West Fifty-sixth Street has been exercised by Rosemary Gilbert and William C. Mulligan. The property was sold by Fontana, Inc., Philip Smolowe, vice president.
A man whose named appeared on a list found in the possession of Joseph G. Luberda, retired police sergeant, was arrested yesterday morning on a vagrancy charge.
HAVANA, March 18 -- The economic difficulties of the revolutionary Government are mounting as its program of reforms goes into effect.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 20 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan began a series of talks today in search of a joint approach to negotiations with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on Berlin and the future of Germany.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 20 -- Western diplomats believe that the similarity of the United States and British appraisals of the relationship between the future of Berlin and the Soviet hold on East Germany could provide the first step toward a joint Western position in talks with the Soviet Union.

AINTREE, England, March 20 (UPI) -- Mr. What, a 9-year-old Irish horse owned by a former Florida real estate dealer, is an 11-to-2 favorite to win the Grand National steeplechase tomorrow for the second straight year.

State revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages in 1958 showed an increase of $696,777 over 1957 receipts, the State Liquor Authority reported yesterday. The gain was made despite a decrease in income from licenses and permits attributed to operators' cancellations, during the recession.

PASADENA, Calif., March 20 (AP) -- A conference of scientists at California Institute of Technology was thrown into an uproar late today when speakers began questioning the value of America's missile and space research.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The House Appropriations Committee refused today to approve an urgently requested supplementary appropriation for the Development Loan Fund.
LONDON, March 20 -- Art sales at two leading auction concerns established record prices today in two narrow categories -- Venetian glass drinking cups and Turner watercolors.
If Sonny Ray of Chicago had started punching a little sooner, he might have scored a notable victory in the ten-round star bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A contract for the preliminary design of a Government demonstration plant to convert saline water into fresh at the rate of 1,000,000 gallons a day has been awarded to W. L. Badger Associates of Ann Arbor, Mich.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission blocked today a proposed 15 per cent increase in railway express rates on shipments of merchandise from retail stores to customers.

Out of the welter of court reform measures, of varying degrees of thoroughness, which have been introduced at Albany this year one has emerged on which public attention must now focus -- the Erwin-Lounsberry resolution, which the Senate passed yesterday by a vote of 33 -- 21. It provides for a new judiciary article in the State Constitution to replace the present one.

A program of six art films has been compiled for public showings in connection with "Art: U. S. A. '59," the exhibition to be presented by American Art Expositions, Inc., at the New York Coliseum from April 4 through 19. The program of short subjects will the first of its kind at the exhibition hall.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 20 (UPI) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser denounced Nikita S. Khrushchev in a balcony speech to cheering thousands today and accused the Soviet Premier of "interference in our affairs."
ROOSEVELT, L. I., March 20 -- A $200,000 building to house the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd will be started here this summer.
A Dublin man who modestly described himself as "the president of a very small island" got a big reception from New Yorkers yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, March 20 -- Samuel C. Johnson Jr., a student of Bennett High School, Buffalo, won the state finals in the twenty-second annual American Legion national oratorical championships today.
MEXICO CITY, March 20 -- Cost reductions through price and tariff cuts on at least fourteen makes of automobiles have been initiated here.
NEW DELHI, India, March 20 -- Open warfare against the Chinese Communist overlords of Tibet has broken out in Lhasa, according to official information reaching New Delhi.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- It will be Bardstown against the field in tomorrow's $122,300 Gulfstream Park Handicap at a mile and a quarter.
LOUISVILLE, March 20 -- The greatest crisis in the twenty-one year history of the National Collegiate basketball championship was resolved tonight by the simple expedient of 600 folding chairs.
A hypothesis about inactivation of poliomyelitis virus, which challenges one of the theoretical concepts on which the Salk Vaccine is made, was presented here yesterday.

Science fiction writers long ago took it for granted that men would some day voyage through our solar system and beyond and communicate with each other over immense distances by use of radio. During the last year and a half the successes in creation of artificial satellites of the earth and the sun have made the dream of space travel seem far less remote than ever before in humanity's history.
An English television comedian is being imported as a replacement when Milton Berle goes off the air in May.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 20 -- Greater use of railroads was urged here today as the way to alleviate "vehicular strangulation'' declared to be handicapping commerce.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- Iosif I. Kuzmin, who charted Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's new seven-year plan, has been removed as head of the State Planning Commission and demoted from his post as a Deputy Premier.

HONOLULU, March 19 -- Hawaii houses a defense establishment whose annual expenditures exceed $300,000,000. This approaches the $340,000,000 total yearly income of the sugar and pineapple industries and the tourist business in the soon-to-be fiftieth state.

BUENOS AIRES, March 20 -- President Arturo Frondizi announced today that beginning April 1 all public employes would have to work uniform eight-hour shifts. Under thce plan, he said, he expected to reduce the public rolls.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- A spokesman for California Grocery and Drug Store Associations asked Congress today for Federal laws to protect owners of trademark on goods.
IT would appear from the first American showing of work by members of the Swedish Graphic Society, at the Meltzer Gallery, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street, that printmaking thrives in Sweden.
SEBRING, Fla., March 20 -- Ed Lawrence, a 30-year-old sports car race driver from Detroit, was killed during a practice session tonight for tomorrow's twelve-hour world championship race.

IT is a reassuring experience to attend a recital by Artur Rubinstein. He reminds one that, though group attractions are now the thing, man alone at the piano is not obsolete. All that is needed is the right man involved with music that means the world to him.
MADRID, March 16 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco faces one of the most difficult decisions in his twenty-two year-dictatorship.

Several girls were enjoying a spring picnic on the banks of the East River at Hell Gate. Henry Plimack, a Queens Boy Scout, was walking nearby when, suddenly, he heard shrill cries for help. One of the girls had fallen into the river, and her friend had jumped in to rescue her.

RYE fritters, which early Americans consumed in quantities for breakfast, seldom appear on tables now. One reason may be that we eat more modestly now, especially at breakfast. But another cause for the disappearance of the fritters is that rye meal, the essential ingredient, no longer is readily available.
Requests for seats on flights to Europe this summer are three times heavier than they were a year ago, Willis G. Lipscomb, vice president of Pan American World Airways, reported yesterday.

Anyone who has ever thought of building a boat in his cellar can sympathize with the seventy-five carpenters and twelve helpers who have to transform $10,000 worth of lumber into a bicycle track by 9 o'clock tomorrow night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- C. Hart Schaaf of Fort Wayne, Ind., has been named executive agent for the development program of the Lower Mekong Basin in Southeast Asia. The announcement was made in Broadbeach, Australia, this week at the meeting of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East.

There was a time when city-dwelling women dared not venture forth on their neighborhood chores in anything less conventional than a tweed suit or a sweater and skirt. Opposition to the proposed tax on real estate transfers was expressed yesterday by Robert S. Curtiss, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

PITTSBURGH, March 20 (AP) -- A Federal Grand Jury indicted six men today in connection with a Government seizure of guns being flown from Russelton, Pa., to Morgantown, W. Va. The guns, at the time they were confiscated, were reported by Federal authorities to have been destined for the followers of Dr. Fidel Castro in the Cuban rebellion.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20 -- Five major factors helping the market for the textile industry's products were listed today by Dr. Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, as brightening the outlook for the long-depressed manufacturers and processors.

The Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad explained to its stockholders yesterday why it announced plans earlier this week for re-acquiring up to 100,000 of the 825,003 shares of the company's outstanding stock.
LONDON, March 20 (UPI) -- Judy Devlin of Baltimore, the defending champion, gained the final in the all-England badminton championships tonight by defeating Iris Rodgers of Britan, 11 -- 3, 11 -- 4.

M., and "Rigoletto," 8, Metropolitan Opera; Lyric Trio, Carnegie Recital Hall, 3; Concert Artists Guild, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 3; Elaine Weil, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, conductor, Paul Paray, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Sidor Belarsky, basso, Town Hall, 8:30; Frantz Gasseus, guitarist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission asked Congress today to permit the merger of this country's international telegraph companies to meet competition from new trans-Atlantic telephone cables and jet-carried air mail.
The rustle of spring descended upon the city yesterday -- prematurely by one day, but no one complained.

CLEVELAND, March 20 (AP) -- Ireland's Ron Delany opened a 10-yard lead on the final lap, then held off Istvan Rozsavolgyi to win by a yard tonight for his thirty-third straight indoor mile triumph. His time in the Cleveland Knights of Columbus track meet was 4 minutes 6.6 seconds.

One of the largest American operators of "flag of necessity" vessels confirmed yesterday that he had formed a British subsidiary that would control more than 250,000 tons of shipping.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Urgent Treasury appeals for a halt to increasing income tax benefits for the oil, gas and mining industries appear to have been quietly shelved in the House.

PARIS, March 20 -- One may earnestly hope if not assume that new endeavors are being made to arrange a de Gaulle-Eisenhower meeting ahead of any summit conference. This column recently suggested an exclusively Western summit talk to coordinate Allied policy before the chiefs of government see Khrushchev.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 8 points (20 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- John Joseph Frank, Washington lawyer, was fined $500 today for acting as an agent for Generalissimo Rafael Trujillo and the Dominican Republic without having registered with the Justice Department.

In the past few weeks you have editorialized on the political integrity of Governor Rockefeller, as distinguished from the irresponsible demagoguery of the Democratic minority in our State Assembly. Your analysis is predicated on the conflicting approaches taken to the recent tax legislation.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An extensive overhauling of continental air defense concepts is in prospect. It will affect radar warning systems, anti-aircraft missiles and manned interceptors.
New York offered yesterday to increase its cash bid for the 1960 Republican National Convention from $300,000 to $500,000 -- the highest offer so far by any city.

DETROIT, March 20 (AP) -- Passenger car output in United States plants this week will total 136,409 units. This will be the highest volume for any week so far this year, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. The previous peak for the year was 135,953 cars built from Jan. 12 to 17.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy defended yesterday his department's policy in the handling procedure for out-of-wedlock children. A Kings County grand jury on Thursday had demanded that the department tighten its policy.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 20 -- John Courtsounis, a peanut vender for more than half a century at Columbia University, died here last night of a stroke. He was 82 years old.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 20 -- New Jersey mosquito fighters had a tough time last year. They blamed it on the weather. It was the wettest twelve months recorded in the state since 1893.

For the third successive day stocks declined yesterday but did so in a lively display of the low-price issues. Once again eleven of the fifteen most-active stocks closed at $25 or lower. The average closing price for the fifteen leaders, which was $24.43 a share on Thursday, was $20.93 yesterday.

MECHANICSVILLE, N. Y., Saturday, March 21 (AP) -- Fighting broke out last night as salaried employes attempting to operate the strikebound West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company plant here tried to get through a mass demonstration of pickets, the company reported.

FORT DIX, N. J., March 20 -- The head of the Army ground forces said here this afternoon that the foot soldier was supreme in any kind of war and "anything that fissions, flies or floats can't replace him."

A sharp drop in demand for copper at 34 cents a pound was reported yesterday by custom smelters. They reduced their buying price of scrap copper to 27 1/2 cents a pound for the large-volume grade, off 1/4-cent from Thursday and down 1 cent from the peak quotation early this week.

BASKETS of jelly beans, chocolate eggs, marshmallow chickens and gummy bunnies, all nestling in grass of green paper, are traditional for children on Easter morning. But there also are Easter gifts to wear, not to eat, to mark the occasion.

THE musical world is commemorating the 150th anniversary of the death of Haydn, and a few words about Haydn on records would not be amiss. Before World War II, relatively little of Haydn's' output was available on records, but that little was of high quality.

THE sleek, rocket-shaped plane dominates Moscow airport in the early evening. Red Army officers and some fifty civilians go aboard. They carefully nudge aside the tubes coiling from oxygen attachments at the seats. The plane, a TU-104-A, or Tupolev, a two-engine jet named for its aeronautical designer, wheels onto the runway, and in minutes it is coursing rapidly and smoothly over snow-white drifts of clouds, some 30,000 feet above the earth.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain is demonstrating these days the modern way to win elections. He is whistle-stopping round the world. His theme is the old theme, peace and prosperity, but his route is different: not the little towns at home, but the great capitals -- London, Paris, Bonn, Moscow and Washington.

THERE is a story of a camel who, about to wade across a river, was solicited by a scorpion: "Gentle camel, carry me across on your back. I cannot swim." The camel answered: "I am afraid to, gentle scorpion. You might sting me, and then I would die."
ST. THOMAS, V. I., -- March 21 -- Gov. John D. Merwin, in his first broadcast to the island population since his inauguration, called attention to the spiralling cost of living here.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 21 -- An inventor and a former teacher have pooled their talents to develop a machine that teaches radio-electronics.

AFTER an uncertain start during which the director, Anthony Mann, and the leading lady, Sabina Bethmann, were replaced by Stanley Kubrick and Jean Simmons, filming of "Spartacus" appears to be running smoothly.
BOWIE, Md., March 21 (AP) -- Light-weighted Pen Bolero, with Howard Grant up, blazed through the stretch to win the $36.350 Governor's Gold Cup today at Bowie.

Committees have been chosen to work with Mrs. Henry M. Hunter, chairman, and Mrs. John J. Birgel, vice chairman, on plans for a fashion show and luncheon on April 7 to aid the School Settlement Association. It will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
PHOENIX, Ariz. -- If one judges by the cartoonists, there are only two kinds of cactus -- the ones with sentinel-like arms and the paddleshaped ones cartoon characters are always backing into.

For the first time in twenty years there is an inventory of Scotch whisky in this country "worth mentioning." This is the conclusion of Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc.

PARIS, March 21 -- The French Communist party said today that it had won a "great victory" in the recent municipal elections. It indicated that its primary goal would be to consolidate its gains among the Socialists and other Leftist elements.

EXTRAORDINARY activity in the amateur movie equipment field will be a notable feature of the thirty - fifth annual national trade show and convention of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association which opens at 2 P. M. today in Philadelphia's Trade and Convention Center.

LOUISVILLE, March 21 -- The National Collegiate basketball title went to a Pacific Coast Conference team tonight for the first time since 1942. Fighting off a spine-tingling late challenge, California defeated West Virginia, 71-70, in a down-to-the-wire final witnessed by a capacity crowd of 18,498 in Freedom Hall at the Kentucky Fair and Exposition Center.
LAST Tuesday evening a special event was observed in the Rowayton, Conn., home of Horace McMahon and his family.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -A new joint approach to the economic-development problems of Latin America is about to add substance with the active support of the United States.

THERE has been a dramatic reversal since the last time this column took a time good look at television. The Columbia Broadcasting System, which used to do almost nothing with and for fine music, has discovered its value this season and has taken a decisive over the National Broadcasting Company, which had the field almost to itself among the networks.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 21 -- Soviet scientists may forge ahead of the United States in the discovery of new elements and the study of the structures of heavy nuclei, Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, Nobel Laureate, said here this week.

ATLANTA, March 21 -- A neo-Dixiecrat movement that could spell trouble for the 1960 Democratic Presidential candidate in the Deep South has gained impetus with the repeal of Alabama's party loyalty oath.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Many of the nation's 186 metropolitan areas will be interested in what the national capital area, centering on the District of Columbia, has to propose next month to meet its commuter needs.
Spring came to the city officially yesterday, and it came with good gentle humor and a touch that was as light as a feather.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- A senate search for evidence of wasteful rivalry and duplication in the space and missile program will open Tuesday.
COLUMBUS, Ga., March 21 (AP) -- Rain washed out the third round of the women's Columbus open golf tournament today.
CONCORD, N. H., March 21 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, bowed out of New Hampshire's 1960 Presidential primary picture today.
WASHINGTON, March 21--The Communist bloc signed aid agreements totaling $1,000,000,000 with eighteen underdeveloped countries last year, according to the State Department.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Premier Khrushchev felt impelled this week to defend Arab Communists against the bitter attacks by President Nasser of the United Arab Republic. At the same time it became clear through statements made by the Soviet Premier and the Kremlin's press and radio commentators that there was grave concen in Moscow over the crisis that had arisen in the feud between Cairo and Baghdad.
NOW'S the time when homeowners should be taking out their screens, cleaning off the wire, and coating them if necessary to prevent future corrosion. Scrap pieces of carpet are excellent for this job.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- Senator Mike Mansfield urged today that President Eisenhower strengthen the Western alliance by including Italy in the pending foreign ministers' conference and all future East-West meetings.
LAKEHURST, N. J., March 21 -- The last of the Navy's 134 "K-class" airships, which safely escorted 89,000 surface vessels in World War II, has made its final flight.

IT is undoubtedly true that more hams will be sold in America during the coming week than in any comparable period of the year. Tables for the Easter Sunday feast will be graced with half hams and whole hams, hot hams and cold hams.
JERUSALEM (Israel Sector) March 18 -- The tiny port of Elath, Israel's gateway to the Orient, began celebrating today its tenth birthday.
Four sales this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, will appeal to the collectors of books, Judaica and French period furniture.
A resurgence of interest in the Jewish Festival of Purim was hailed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum in his sermon at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

AS the winter of the first year of the Fifth Republic draws to its close, the tide of ecstatic popular enthusiasm that swept Gen. Charles de Gaulle into a position of extraordinary power in France has begun to ebb.
The Scranton Corporation announced yesterday the election of a new board of directors for its wholly owned subsidiary, Hal Roach Studios, Inc.

OURO PRETO, Brazil -This old town built atop many hills like a minuscule Rome and, in relation to its size, just as rich in magnificent churches, was born of the gold rush two hundred and a score years ago.
Some of the sparkle in the effervescent stock market vanished last week as profit taking and caution spread among investors after the market's recent ascent to new peaks.

HONOLULU -- The newest addition to the United States, which may be officially nicknamed the "Aloha State," consists of a group of islands strung out in the Pacific about 2,100 miles off the coast of California.

FLY-TYING trout fishermen are now turning their homes into night-time sweat shops for the production of wet and dry flies to be used as soon as the season opens. There are several sound methods for non-tying fishermen to get flies away from these people. None of them works.

DEMOCRACY has been crumbling fast in the Middle East and Asia. A series of revolutions and military coups d'etat has placed generals at the helm of Eastern governments, constitutions have been scrapped, representative government has, to a large degree, been repudiated, and constitutional guarantees of individual freedoms have been abrogated.
OLD FORGE, N. Y., March 21 (AP) -- Stan Nichols of Paul Smith's College captured both the slalom and downhill races today in the first McCauley downhill-slalom combined skiing meet.

Many gardeners find unusual rewards in hobby gardening -specializing in a single plant group. A number of perennials were deal for collecting. The secret as related here by three experienced amateurs, is to secure a genus that offers variation in flower and plant forms to blooming seasons.

MIAMI, March 21 -- As the Yankees, awaiting tonight's scheduled game with the Orioles, basked in the sun that bathed the swimming pool at their sumptuous Shamrock Isle quarters on Miami Beach today, only one disturbing note bothered City Stengel.

SHASTA daisies are among the finest and most decorative perennials for the garden. They will prove well worth the original cost per plant since a few plants provide a dramatic showing. Shastas can he planted in spring or fall.
No developments were reported yesterday in attempts to find a peace formula in the dispute between union printers and the publishers of ten daily newspapers in the city.

The perennial fight of the horse player against the law of diminishing returns will start this week, and if past performances are any criterion, don't bet on the law of diminishing returns. It hasn't beaten the horse player yet.

YONKERS, March 21 -- Recently arrived families, the oldtimers whose ancestors came here in colonial days and even many teachers are gaining new insight into the workings of this city's public schools.

LIKE the Nativity story, the Easter theme lends itself to many variations as is evidenced by these four new books. As straightforward and unadorned as its title, Henry Denker's "That First Easter," begins as a young lad follows Jesus as He makes His triumphant entry into Jerusalem.

A six-week Summer Language School will be conducted from June 15 to July 25 at Skidmore College, Saratoga Springs, N. Y. . . .

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., March 21 (AP) -- The International Business Machines Corporation said today that one of its scientists was voicing only his personal opinion when he questioned the value of the United States missile and space program.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 17 -- Not content with annexing Alaska and Hawaii to the American Union, pleasure boat fleets from the States are doing a thorough job this spring of infiltrating the Bahamas. In many of the yacht basins this week there are more Stars and Stripes fluttering from stern staffs of the pleasure boats than Britain's Union Jack.
THE first day of spring can be set by the astronomer with the cold precision of the stars; he knows, to the very second, when we supposedly pass from the dead white of winter into the next season.
At the rail depot in Ithaca, N. Y., at the close of World War II, a stranger approached a traveler waiting with luggage for the New York train.

DERIVED from her articles over the years in Collier's magazine, Martha Gellhorn's "The Face of War," is a brilliant anti-war book that is as fresh as if written for this morning. Seldom can a correspondent assemble past writings from various locations and watch a clear pattern emerge, yet her pieces fall into place in a grand design.

THOSE international war marriages of the G. I.'s, and of the doughboys in that other war, all seemed wonderful. The troops in their uniforms were so dashing, came from so far away, were so comparatively soldierrich and so (it thus seemed) American-rich.

SOON the yellow blooms of forsythia will be appearing in the Northeast. This early splash of color is so welcome in early spring that forsythia has been popular in American gardens for nearly a century.

TIME was, between the two world wars, when only a handful of sculptors were active in Britain and when the opportunities of patronage were slender. Now the situation has changed radically; and that this is so is largely due to Henry Moore.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 21 -- Gov. Buford Ellington continued signing bills today, winding up the business of the Eighty-first Tennessee General Assembly, which adjourned Friday.
