BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 19 -- Civil Defense officials at their national operational headquarters here emphasize that the chances of survival in a nuclear attack are good for most Americans -- provided they take the necessary precautions.

THE big exhibition of work by the Spanish artist, Joan Miro, notably comprehensive and well installed, perhaps raises more questions than it answers. Labels in the art world are notoriously inadequate with fringe qualifications usually necessary and in Miro's case particularly so.

ALBANY, March 21 -- As Governor Rockefeller approaches the end of his first legislative session he can count more pluses than minuses in his dealings with the Republican-controlled Senate and Assembly.

WHAT began as a controversial situation turned out to be an occasion for hilarity at a Broadcast Pioneers dinner here last week. The dinner was held during the annual convention of the National Association of Broadcasters in the Conrad Hilton Hotel.

THE small home vegetable garden can yield a surprisingly large harvest. A plan is essential for success. The grower also must use plants that produce over the full season such as tomatoes and peppers, stake plants where possible and grow short-season crops such as leaf lettuce and beans between the rows of slower growing vegetables.
ALGIERS, March 21--Two to three hundred Algerian rebel soldiers, led by their officers, surrendered with their arms today, the French Army command announced tonight.
OTTAWA, March 21 -- Canadians are disturbed about the difficult position in which events in Newfounland have placed the highly respected Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

All but one of the countries producing motor vehicles will be represented at the Third International Automobile Show opening April 4 at the New York Coliseum. The exhibition will continue through April 12.
The joyous holiday of Purim, the Feast of Lots, will be ushered in at sundown tomorrow night by Jews here and throughout the world.
Twenty-three hundred business leaders honored Elliot V. Walter, retiring chairman of the board of Macy's New York last week at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WHEN the sun comes up next Sunday morning thousands of church-goers who normally gather indoors for worship will congregate throughout the nation on hillsides, in amphitheatres, parks and other natural or man-made scenic places to participate in Easter Sunrise Services.

TENNESSEE WILLIAMS wrote a very moving selfstatement in The Times of March 8. Particularly for one who has just seen his "Sweet Bird of Youth." It seems to me that in his tragically negative way Mr. Williams has put his finger on the great social sickness of our time, and the popularity of his plays are a measure of the extent of that sickness.

WHILE the Italian film industry is facing 1959 with more confidence than it has in many a year, some observers are worried about the consequences of still another change in Government. In Italy, where direct and indirect governmental support still plays a vital role in the medium's existence and direction, the industry is very sensitive to such changes.
CAIRO, March 21 -- For almost three years the relationship between Moscow and Cairo was as delightful an international partnership as Gamal Abdel Nasser could have asked.

No competent teacher need fear unemployment in the coming years, a consultant of the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education said yesterday.

AS virtually every American knows, Adlai Stevenson spent a part of last summer traveling about the Soviet Union with his two sons, Borden and John Fell Stevenson, in order to find out for himself just how that massive country has been faring since the death of Stalin.

HALLANDALE, Fla. -South Florida's hotel construction boom has slowed down noticeably in the past two years, particularly in Miami Beach and its northerly neighbor Bal Harbour. But there has been little slackening in the development of luxury motels that have become an important part of the vacation facilities available along the Gold Coast.
Two prisoners were foiled last night in their movie-script plan to escape the Tombs.
Billie Lynn Daniel, soprano, made an extremely favorable impression in a song program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

There have been all too few books written on Canada's financial history. Here is one that should prove enlightening to bankers generally and to business men with specific interests across the border. Informal hearings on the proposed revision of the city's zoning regulations will be held in April and May in each of the city's five boroughs.

MIAMI, March 22 -- The Yankees, who on Friday staged a couple of day-night performances here, indulged themselves in another springtime rarity today. They engaged the Baltimore Orioles in a doubleheader.

The Versailles Debutante Ball, reduced through disagreements and resignations to but a smoldering ember, is being rekindled by the desire of the French Government and the friends of France in the United States that it take place.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, called on the nation's colleges today to be "sympathetic" toward students whose high school education was hampered by integration problems.

Cardinal Spellman presided at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday marking the opening of Holy Week observance.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Bob Goalby of Belleville, Ill., shot a 3-under par 69 over the windswept Lakewood Course today and took a stroke lead in the $15,000 St. Petersburg open with a total of 205.

DAKAR, Senegal, Monday, March 23 (AP) -- First returns from legislative elections in this new autonomous African republic within the French Overseas Community indicated today that the Progressive Senegalese Union had won all eighty seats.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Important modifications have been made in a pending bill to require cumulative voting for officers and directors of state banks and trust companies in an effort to overcome the objections of upstate banks.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -The most heavily Democratic Congress in twenty years will go back to the country late this week to measure national sentiment toward the new brand of moderation it has evolved during its first eighty days.
NEWTON, Mass., March 22 -President Sean T. O'Kelly of Ireland received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree today at Boston College.

Some major changes in Soviet economic planning appear likely to result from last Friday's appointment of Aleksei N. Kosygin as chief economic planner. He replaced Iosif I. Kuzmin, who was made head of a new Science-Economic Council.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- William Henry Draper Jr. might be said to be the perfect prototype of all those gentlemen who have been called in by President Eisenhower to head special committees.
SEATTLE, March 22 -- The contract bridge pair of Lew Mathe and Ed Taylor, both of Los Angeles, forged far ahead of the field this afternoon in the Open Pairs Championship.

PARIS, March 22 -- Yesterday was an anniversary of special significance to the United States. On March 21, 1790, Thomas Jefferson became our first Secretary of State. As drafter of the Declaration of Independence, former Governor of Virginia, member of the Continental Congress and Minister to France, he brought to his post a more varied experience than any of his successors save, perhaps, James F. Byrnes.

The "Music Forgotten and Remembered" concert on Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera was divided into two fairly well-known works, Mozart's Piano Concerto in F (K. 459) and Haydn's Symphony No. 99 in E flat, and two rarities. Corelli's Concerto Grosso No. 1 in D, from the Op. 6 set, and a Vivaldi Concerto for Violin and Oboe in G minor are seldom-heard works by two celebrated composers.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 22 -- One of three copies of the Gutenberg Bible known to be in private hands was recently given to the library of Indiana University. The Bible is not complete. It has 112 pages of the New Testament but none of the Old Testament. By itself the Bible would be considered an acquisition of major importance.

In reply to A. A. Sproul Jr.'s letter published March 9 I think that some unwarranted assumptions have been made about the advantages of large-scale production. No consideration has been given to the increasingly expensive coordination, supervision and interdepartmental rivalry in addition to increasing conflicts between broad policy directions and operational procedures.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 22 (AP) -- Penn State's Nittany Lions rolled up a record total of 152 points last night in winning their fourth National Collegiate gymnastics title in seven years.

CONSTANTINE, Algeria, March 22 -- Premier Michel Debre of France gave his "solemn affirmation" to the out-numbered Europeans in this East Algerian city today that there would never be "a separation of France and Algeria."

Two agencies which have done yeomen service for many years on behalf of immigrants to this country have joined forces -- the Common Council for American Unity and the American Federation of International Institutes, now merged as the American Council for Nationalities Service.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -The President's special adviser on foreign aid said today that it would be "a tragedy" if Congress sustained the House Appropriations Committee's denial of $225,000,000 sought by the Development Loan Fund.

I Musici, a conductorless group of eleven string players and a pianist, presented three Vivaldi concertos and two contemporary Italian works Saturday evening in the Hunter College Auditorium. The playing was always precise but often spiritless.

ROME, March 22 -- Pope John XXIII opened Holy Week rites today in the basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls, on the western outskirts of Rome. He blessed palm fronds and distributed them to Cardinals and other Roman Catholic prelates.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has broken with the past in ministering to a newly arrived population group.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 22 -- Joy Doniger of Rye, N. Y., won the equitation championship at the Secor Farms Riding Club horse show today. The 14-year-old Rye Country Day School student, who is a riding pupil of Frank Carroll at Secor Farms, also acquired her first A. H. S. A. Medal of the season.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -Los Angeles has been the nation's No. 1 center of new home construction in recent years, outstripping even New York. But the area is so far-flung that there is still plenty of room for both residential and industrial development. The only pinch is price.
AT this season, when home cooks are searching for new and satisfying meatless main dishes, cheese-rice croquettes may be one good suggestion.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -Trading in grain futures appeared to have pointed up again last week the reality that so long as there are huge surpluses, the Government price supports are ceilings over the market instead of floors under it.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -An important aspect of the much-debated "equal time" rule for radio and television stations comes before the Supreme Court for argument tomorrow.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 22 -- Nassau County offered today to pay New York City $5,000,000 for the water-supply property the city owns in Nassau.

The New York Rangers had their chance last night to make the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs but failed. The New Yorkers were eliminated from play-off contention as they finished the regular season by losing to the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 2, at Madison Square Garden.

TEANECK, N. J., March 22 -A black cocker spaniel, Ch. Windjammer's Passkey, became best in show tonight in the twentieth event of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey. It was the 2 1/2-year-old dog's first such award.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Congressmen generally gave bipartisan applause today to the agreement of President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan to meet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in a summer summit conference.
Bids will be opened on April 2 for construction of a 6.27-mile section of the Heckscher State Parkway -- the final link in the 200-mile system of Long Island parkways for pleasure cars.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Devereaux C. Josephs, chairman of the board of the New York Life Insurance Company, has been appointed by Governor Rockefeller to head the new Commission on Economic Expansion.

The sharp rise last year in the Communist bloc's aid commitments to non-Communist underdeveloped countries merits special consideration as the debate over our own foreign-aid program is renewed. From less than $300,000,000 in 1957 the Soviet nations' promises soared last year to more than $1,000,000,000, distributed among eighteen countries.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., March 22 -- Winter played a mean trick on skiers in the Eastern slalom championships today. Just when it seemed they would enjoy slow, safe and sane runs, winter took a parting shot. Temperatures plummeted forty degrees overnight, the winds reached hurricane force and the courses became icy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22 -- The United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiotion will begin its sixth session here tomorrow with unexpected information about the behavior of radioactive debris in the stratosphere.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation announced over the week-end that it had "signed contracts" contemplating the acquisition of the assets and business of Blue Ridge Manufacturers, Inc., and S. Rosenbloom, Inc., a group of clothing manufacturing concerns.

IBADAN, Nigeria, March 22 -- The concluding summaries at a congress here of West African intellectuals and politicians underlined today that Africans from French-influenced areas lean toward the political Left.

An account of the find in Egypt of Coptic documents bearing on early Christianity, described in last Thursday's New York Times, is planned for publication later this year by Viking. Called "The Secret Books of the Egyptian Gnostics," it has been written by Jean Doresse, a French archaeologist associated with Prof. H. C. Puech of the Sorbonne in the recovery of the documents.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- When Gene Littler was 23 years old and a relatively unknown golfer, the great Bobby Jones abandoned his role as a conservative elder statesman. He couldn't help himself.
SPOKANE, March 22 (AP) -The body of a 9-year-old girl was found in the woods today under a pile of pine needles. The victim, Candy Jones, had been raped and strangled.

THE phrase "Just like mother used to make" deserves revival to describe the excellent, old-fashioned cookies that Pepperidge Farm has just introduced. The concern, which bakes a variety of dainty and delicate Belgian biscuits, has now turned to a homelier but equally delicious product.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -The Atomic Energy Commission is turning to pigs, rats and dogs to find out what damage radiation and nuclear fall-out can cause in man.

School teachers threatened "drastic job action" yesterday, including a one-day absence, to protest Mayor Wagner's plan to reduce their forthcoming pay rises. Their threat followed a similar one by other city employes.
Deputy Mayor Paul O'Keefe criticized the Legislature yesterday for "the unconscionable treatment New York City has received at its hands."

The Continental Oil Company has reached a tentative agreement for the purchase of a two-thirds interest in the San Jacinto Petroleum Corporation. L. F. McCollum, president of Continental and Benno C. Schmidt, president of San Jacinto, made the announcement over the week-end.

It was vacation time, but Judy got up earlier every Monday, Wednesday and Fri day than she ever did for school to assist a therapist in training the boys and girls in the cerebral palsy ward in a city hospi tal. AS the deadline approaches for the final selection of articles to be shown at the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer, George Nelson's offices at 18 East Fiftieth Street are humming with activity.
Shubert Alley's most puzzling mystery of the season was solved last night, when Kim Stanley named Eric Portman as the main reason for her quitting the cast of "A Touch of the Poet."
NEW DELHI, India, March 22 -- Communist China's apparent determination to crush the Tibetan revolt gave rise today to official concern about the personal safety of the Dalai Lama.
LONDON, March 22 (AP) -An angry British legislator, shocked at the "massacre" at yesterday's Grand National Steeplechase, wants the Government to ban the race or make it easier.
LIMA, Peru, March 22 (UPI) -- "This is fantastic," said Earl Buchholz of the welcome he shared with Alex Olmedo today.

LIMA, Peru, March 22 -- Alejandro Olmedo, the hero of the United States' Davis Cup tennis victory over Australia, was decorated by the President of Peru today when he returned to his native land after a fiveyear absence.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 22 -- A weekly magazine devoted to literature, philosophical thought and some politics has become the center of a storm here for allegedly attacking the revolutionary reforms of Kemal Ataturk.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York announced liberalized coverage yesterday that would pay for physicians' visits for small employe groups.
BOSTON, March 22 -- The latch string to suburban housing is getting hard to reach even for middle-income groups in metropolitan Boston.

Lawrence Emerson Tuttle, the Brooks School French master who has the appearance of a football tackle or a basketball rebounder -- he's a 6-foot 5-inch 215-pounder -- is to be the new headmaster of Vermont Academy at Saxtons River.
LONDON, March 22 -- The substantial drop in unemployment and the Conservative Government's retention of two House of Commons seats at stake in by-elections helped the stock market last week.
LOS ANGELES, March 22 -Presidential bees are buzzing over vote-carpeted California.
Amid all the movement on Wall Street the New York Stock Exchange has made a move of its own. The exchange's advertising account has been awarded to Compton Advertising, Inc.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A conflict among the Democrats over court reorganization came to light today. Mayor Wagner has, in effect, endorsed the Rockefeller Administration's court bill, which the Senate passed Friday over solid Democratic opposition.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke said today that he "wouldn't be surprised" if Russia tried to match this country's nuclear space shots because it would want the military and scientific data disclosed.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- Peter Ustinov, currently at work with Kirk Douglas in "Spartacus," will join Deborah Kerr and Robert Mitchum in "The Sundowners."

Employment of merchant marine officers and seamen in the privately owned United States-flag fleet showed a marked recovery in the last six months of 1958, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 22 -- The United States and Britain, having decided on a summit conference with the Soviet Union, now have to decide what they will talk about. The discussions between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan at Camp David, in the Maryland mountains, demonstrated that this would be difficult.

HAVANA, March 22 -- Premier Fidel Castro took issue tonight with his long-time friend, former President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica, who said Cuba should be on the side of the United States in the "cold war" with the Soviet Union that Colonel Figueres said might become "a hot war."
Six new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
ST. LOUIS, March 22 -- Land is plentiful in suburban St. Louis for both residential and industrial development, but the prices are steadily rising.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 22 -- A trial lawyer argued today that the bench could be mightier than the typewriter in relieving congestion in New York state courts.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -King Hussein of Jordan, who will arrive in Washington tomorrow from San Francisco, will seek to put United States support of his desert kingdom on a regular and continuing basis.
This is the season when, every year, countless thousands of city dwellers renew their dreams of a home in the suburbs.
Boston, March 22 (AP) -Frank Ramsey came off the Boston bench at the start of the second period today and started the Celtics to a 133-111 victory over the Syracuse Nationals.
WARSAW, March 22 -- Poland's writers have been told that they must get the Government's approval before they sign contracts for publication of their books abroad.

IT was a historic occasion at the Metropolitan Opera House last night when, for the first time, the opera company presented an entire program of dances created expressly for its own ballet contingent.

The James Foundation of New York, Inc., has leased 5,000 square feet of office space in the Seagram Building at 375 Park Avenue, corner of Fiftysecond Street. It was organized in 1941 for a twenty-five-year period under the will of Arthur Curtiss James to make grants to charitable, religious and educational institutions.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Republican legislative leaders met tonight with Governor Rockefeller and other Republican policymakers to agree on measures to be passed before the Legislature adjourns for the year later this week.

YAKIMA, Wash., March 22 (AP) -- Glenn Kotlarek of Duluth, Minn., won the jumping championship and Mel Jodrey of Auburn, Me., took the Nordic combined title as the national junior ski championships ended today at White Pass.
Mississippi Valley barge lines charged yesterday that western railroads were proposing a new "penalty" rate that would be "sufficient to drive all superphosphate traffic off the river."

MADRID, March 22 -- Spain's leading labor newspaper, Pueblo, has denied there is any anti-Americanism, official or otherwise, in this country. It has also pledged Spanish-American collaboration in a battle against "people with no sense of humor."

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week but closed moderately firmer. At the close of futures trading on Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 6 to 20 points (30 cents to $1 a bale) above the preceding week's close.
Jerry West of West Virginia and St. John's Tony Jackson and Alan Seiden were honored yesterday for their performances in college basketball's major post-season tournaments that ended Saturday.
CAIRO, March 22 (AP) -President Gamal Abdel Nasser charged today that Premier Abdul Karim Kassim refused to join with the United Arab Republic in a "decisive battle" against Israel late last year.
The high-altitude explosions of hydrogen and atom bombs last summer are said to have shown that such blasts may be blinding at distances as great as 1,000 miles.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -Abraham A. Redelheim, president of the Zionist Organization of America, sharply scored what he termed "falsehoods spread by the Arab propaganda machine" to bring about a halt of Jewish emigration from East European countries to Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan concluded their exploratory talks on Berlin and the future of Germany with a fortyfive-minute conference tonight with Secretary of State Dulles.
The construction of 32,317 new dwelling units in the city in 1958 was reported by the City Planning Commission yesterday. This was 17 per cent more than the 27,507 built in 1957.
Churches over the city, observing Palm Sunday yesterday, hailed again the triumphal entry of Jesus into Jerusalem.
Mutual fund shareowners and movie stars have one thing in common -- they get lots of mail.
An unusual trio gave a concert in Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- It was clear last week that if there is no steel strike at midyear, steel demand and production would be off sharply in July and August. But last week steel mills were steaming toward a six-month record in steelmaking.
A second attempt to delay the conversion of Third Avenue to one-way traffic operation will be made this week.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -President Eisenhower's noretreat policy on Berlin has overwhelming popular support in the nation though many Americans know little about the history or geography of the crisis.
DETROIT, March 22 (UPI) -Larry Regan scored two goals and set up two tonight, leading the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings and a hard-earned Stanley Cup play-off berth.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., March 22 -- More than 500 hikers from eight organized groups gathered here at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's in the Wilderness this afternoon for the thirty-eighth annual Palm Sunday hikers' services.
Marine safety from operations in nuclear shipbuilding to use of new cargo devices, will be discussed at the spring meeting of the marine section of the National Safety Council.
Eighteen civic, educational and other organizations in this city joined yesterday in urging a substantial increase in state aid for municipal colleges.
Ali Sastroamidjojo, Indonesia's permanent representative at the United Nations, said yesterday that his country's foreign policy had been wrongfully characterized as neutral.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 22 -- The Labor party lost control of one state but retained power in another in elections yesterday.
Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany, assailed yesterday the "shocking treatment of New York City's fiscal problems" by the Republican-controlled legislature in Albany.

A code for sending messages to each other about inter-line cargo shipments has been devised by the scheduled domestic and international airlines. It is similar to a passenger reservations code adopted in 1955.
John Gielgud, will star in a television adaptation of Terence Rattigan's "The Browning Version" on April 23 from 8 to 9:30 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 -- A scientist warned here yesterday that over-population was wiping out the last remnants of the American wilderness and, as one remedy, urged a higher tax on parents.

Yugoslav health officials now report that they are embarking upon what they expect to be their final campaign in the war on malaria. Victory is in sight. The figures are astonishing, nothing less than spectacular. In the last ten-year period the number of reported cases have been cut from almost 80,000 to just a few more than 1,000.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 22 -- On the conjecture that the long-awaited ruling of the Hague Court in the Interhandel case, handed down yesterday, would be favorable to Switzerland, speculators were extremely active all last week.

The march of "progress" appears about to destroy a venerable Revolutionary landmark in Newark. To bulldoze the remains of the founders, as well as colonial and Revolutionary heroes, from the graves in which they rest into a common pit just to make a parking lot is an act of vandalism.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -The Cabinet is shaping up. Four of the ten members attended last Wednesday's joint meeting of Congress for the address by Sean T. O'Kelly, President of Ireland.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -France, Argentina and, to a considerable extent, Turkey are actively trying it.

Manufacturers of patterns and fabrics are using considerable ingenuity to help retailers maintain their share of the yard-goods market. By helping them they hope to help themselves. With the return to stores of attractive, readyto-wear apparel after World War II, yard-goods volume rose to a record total of $730,000,000 at retail in 1949 and then fell to about $500,000,000 in 1954.
Some small improvement in volume was noted last week in the steamship charter market, but the softening of rates continued to plague the tramping industry.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Rockefeller appears to be out to set a record for sparing use of the veto.
There is "urgent need" in the Protestant churches of the nation for "some Scriptural form of confessional," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday.

Profits of Pullman, Inc., and its subsidiaries last year amounted to $7,806,882, or $3.52 a share, according to the annual report of Champ Carry, president. The earning's were nearly halved from the $14,801,657, or $6.67 a share, in 1957.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 22 (AP) -- Paced by Elgin Baylor's 33 points, the Minneapolis Lakers defeated St. Louis, 106 -- 98, today and evened their final play-offs in the National Basketball Association's Western Division at one victory each

The critical shortage of professional nurses reported here by Dorothy Weddige, director of nursing services, is a problem not confined to New York. Most of the same conditions exist at many other points in the country. But this report, supported by the Commissioner of Hospitals, puts some aspects of the question in a dramatic light.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday that the legitimate theatres would be the next target of his fire-prevention program.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 22 -- The annual report by Philips Lamps, which showed a record turnover and profits as well as dynamic expansion, made an excellent impression here.
Bishop Frederick B. Newell called on Americans yesterday to think between Palm Sunday and Good Friday about the sacrifices made by other people in the world "to enable us to lead a better life."
Opposition was mounting yesterday to the proposed adoption of a State law to suspend for one year the maximum ticket broker's charge of $1.25 above the face value of a ticket.
A new battle opened last week between the shipping world's most famous lone-wolf company and the lines that prefer to work in groups.

The blockfront on the west side of Second Avenue from Sixty-eighth to Sixty-ninth Streets has been purchased by Ben Kaufman Associates for improvement with a thirty-story cooperative building containing 500 apartments. L. V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers.

George Alpert, chairman and president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, said yesterday that the commuter crisis was "ultimately a national problem," affecting the economy of all major cities.

EASTER is the time when even the most fastidious homemaker will depart from convention and take a flight into whimsey. Shops around town are aware of this feeling and are overflowing with countless fanciful Easter accessories.
SEBRING, Fla., March 22 (UPI) -- Phil Hill and Olivier Gendebein of the world champion Ferrari team split $3,000 today, their prize for winning the twelve-hour Grand Prix of Endurance.
Sometimes an artist can plug along year in and year out without any breaks. Then, with a whoosh, he'll go right to the top.

"CHRIST IN JEANS," a modern version of the Crucifixion and Resurrection, is a drama of striking power and poignancy. It was seen yesterday afternoon on the program of the Right Rev. James A. Pike, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of California, over Channel 7.

Taking the twenty Latin-American countries and applying all the goodwill in the world, one would have to say that two of them present exceptionally baffling and even exasperating problems to the United States Government. These are Bolivia and Haiti.
MEXICO CITY, March 22 -Jose Gonzalez Torres, a 39-yearold Roman Catholic leader, was elected president of the opposition National Action party last night.

POINTE NOIRE, Congo Republic, March 7 -- American capital is coming into what used to be French Equatorial Africa in important amounts despite the political uncertainty that selfgovernment has brought to the region.
THURMONT, Md., March 22 (AP) -- The President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Britain came down from their mountain conference today to worship in a red brick country church.
A group of New York business men headed by Malcolm E. Smith Jr. announced yesterday the purchase of the Mutual Broadcasting System.
A phase of sports activity that was once an important item on the New York scene made its return last night and was warmly greeted by 5,000 fans.

THE third volume of Lawrence Durrell's proposed four-volume novel about life, love and depravity in the city of Alexandria during the last days of King Farouk's reign in Egypt is published today. It is called "Mountolive"* and it is a selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

The first United States-flag vessel to be equipped with the new HI-PRESS air-conditioning system, the President Garfield of American President Lines, is now on a round-the-world voyage. She will be closely watched by the American maritime industry.
Sidor Belarsky, the basso, has a devoted following, who filled Town Hall for his recital there Saturday evening.
A group of New York business men headed by Malcolm E. Smith Jr. announced yesterday the purchase of the Mutual Broadcasting System.
A phase of sports activity that was once an important item on the New York scene made its return last night and was warmly greeted by 5,000 fans.

THE third volume of Lawrence Durrell's proposed four-volume novel about life, love and depravity in the city of Alexandria during the last days of King Farouk's reign in Egypt is published today. It is called "Mountolive"* and it is a selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

The first United States-flag vessel to be equipped with the new HI-PRESS air-conditioning system, the President Garfield of American President Lines, is now on a round-the-world voyage. She will be closely watched by the American maritime industry.
Sidor Belarsky, the basso, has a devoted following, who filled Town Hall for his recital there Saturday evening.
DETROIT, March 22 -- Thousands of acres are still available within twenty to thirty miles of downtown Detroit for housing or industrial development. Prices have been rising.
Spring, which arrived with soft promise on Saturday, turned blustery cold for Palm Sunday.
Union stereotypers on metropolitan newspapers ratified a two-year contract with the Publishers Association of New York City yesterday. It calls for a $7-a-week wage and welfare package increase.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Representative Overton Brooks, Democrat of Louisiana and chairman of the House Science and Astronautics Committee, said today he was satisfied that the Air Force's elusive Discoverer satellite had gone into orbit but had fallen back to earth after a relatively short time.
PARIS, March 23 -- France suggested today that certain changes be made in BritishUnited States proposals for negotiations with the Soviet Union Comment from London and Washington was awaited.

The annual body-snatching of electronics engineers -- four days of intensive raiding of each others' staffs by hotly competitive companies -- began yesterday with the opening of the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Townsend Investment Company announced yesterday that it had expanded its interests in the mutual fund management field through a contract to purchase 120,000 shares of the Class B, non-voting stock of Hugh W. Long Co., Inc., of Elizabeth, N. J. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

The American and Foreign Power Company announced yesterday in a preliminary report that its net income last year was $12,553,000, or $1.72 a share, compared with $12,577,000, or $1.72 a share in 1957.

The Arkla Air Conditioning Corporation, Little Rock, Ark., announced yesterday the purchase of the Humphrey line of gas heating equipment manufactured by the General Gas Light Company of Kalamazoo, Mich. The price was not disclosed. Manufacturing of the Humphrey heaters and furnaces will be transferred to the Arkla plant at Evansville, Ind. Arkla is a subsidiary of the Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company.
HAVANA, March 23 -- The executions of former Batista aides and soldiers have shocked the people of Latin America, Col. Jose Figueres, former President of Costa Rica, said here today.

ST. LOUIS, March 23 (AP) -- Red Schoendienst, hospitalized for four months with tuberculosis, will return home tomorrow. He predicted today that he would report "bright and early" for 1960 spring training with the Milwaukee Braves.

An offering of 150,000 shares of common stock of Ryder System, Inc., a trucking and truck leasing holding company, is being made today at $48 a share. The offering is being made by an investment banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Legislature was urged today to create a state fund to protect injured workers whose employers ignore the requirement to carry workmen's compensation insurance.
Blood will be given today at the Metropolitan Opera House, Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, to the New York Regional Red Crsos Blood Program.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation suggested yesterday that bank tellers and loan company clerks receive police training in the powers of observation.
CHICAGO, March 23 -- Sean T. O'Kelly, President of Ireland, began a three-day ceremonial visit to Illinois tonight by attending a reception and dinner as the guest of Chicago's Mayor Edward J. Daley.
BRESSANONE, Italy, March 23 -- Intolerance of Italian rule increases as one moves up these Alpine valleys toward the snowcapped peaks of the Dolomites.
AREQUIPA, Peru, March 23 (AP) -- Alejandro Olmedo returned to his home town today a national hero.
The sale of $9,500,000 of school bonds is being planned by Fairfax County, Va., for April 8. The issue will be dated March 1, 1956 (correct) and will come due serially on March 1 from 1960 to 1983.

" Teem" will be the name of the new lemon-lime soft drink to be marketed soon by the Pepsi-Cola Company. It is believed to connote not only the sparkling quality of the beverage but the teaming of two flavors.

Turnover of funds in checking accounts in New York City banks rose 3 1/2 per cent in February, and 4 per cent in banks in the rest of the country, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -The Treasury bill rate was practically unchanged this week, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate on $1,300,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 2.766 per cent compared with 2.763 per cent last week, and the average rate on $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.093 per cent compared with 3.058 per cent last week.
OTTAWA, March 23 (Canadian Press) -- A revised Canadian civil defense organization, in which the Army will play a major role, was announced today by Prime Minister John Diefenbaker.

ALBANY, March 23 -- This hillside city on the Hudson River is the state capital, but it enjoys that distinction by habit rather than by designation. Nowhere in the Constitution does it say Albany is the capital.

MANILA, March 23 -- President Carlos P. Garcia indicated today that the Philippines would reject any solution of the nation's financial difficulties that involved devaluation of the peso or the abrupt lifting of monetary controls.

Socotra, an island off the East Coast of Africa, inhabited by cave-dwelling aborigines, was last visited by a scientific expedition in 1899. Three years ago six young men, forming an Oxford University Expedition, went to the island and spent two months there.

Quietness pervaded the market for prime fixed-income investments yesterday as the banking system and other elements of the investment community entered subscriptions for $2,000,000,000 of new threeyear notes and ten-year bonds offered by the Treasury.
Seamen's illnesses and injuries dropped to a three-year low last year, according to statistics made public yesterday by the Marine Index Bureau, Inc.
An unidentified man plunged from the center of the George Washington Bridge into the Hudson River last night while two bridge policemen were running toward him.

There is a story in The Times of :March 14 about the island of Palmyra, a bit of Hawaii with a status so huggermugger that some people say it "could be proclaimed a principality.'' The State Department is "looking into this problem," The Times reports.

For the man who entrains without his newspaper a short subway ride seems interminable. And his craving for reading matter is usually not much assuaged by the placards mounted on both sides of every subway car at straphanger eye-level --placards advertising everything from shorthand courses to tomato juice.
Another phase of the sevenweek bakery workers' strike was settled yesterday. The terms will bring 600 members of Local 3 of the independend Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union back to work.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 23 (AP) -- Royner Greene, Cornell University's basketball coach for thirteen years, resigned tonight. The athletic director, Robert J. Kane, said the resignation was effective immediately.

WHITE PLAINS, March 23 -- The ghost of the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway rose today to aid Westchester in the development of a new limited-access county highway. Officials said it would be the first road of its kind in the county.

YONKERS, March 23 -Robert Cherrix, the hottest sulky pilot on the grounds, had another winner at Yonkers Raceway this evening. Cherrix wasn't entered in any of the nine races, but when a man is hot it makes no difference.
BONN, Germany, March 23 -The Adenauer Government has instructed its Ambassador in London to indicate anew its opposition to suggestions of a military freeze in Central Europe.
RABAT, Morocco, March 23 (AP) -- French military units will be withdrawn from the four United States Air Force bases in Morocco March 31.
The Penn-Texas Corporation brought suit in the State Supreme Court yesterday seeking an accounting and damages of $10,500,000 from former executives of the company and several realtors.
HERE comes a letter condemning and contemning the Helpless Method of getting fishing tackle in shape for the season.

If the New York City government is really going in for austerity budgeting, a good place to start might be in reduction of the lavishness, frequency and artificialty of entertainment for celebrities. Everybody loves a parade, they keep saying, but an account the other day in this newspaper of how these "ticker-tape" marches up lower Broadway to honor visiting dignitaries and domestic heroes are organized destroyed some of the glamour.
NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru assured the Chinese Communists today that India had no intention of interfering in the revolt in Tibet.

WE had no atomic bombs to use against Hitler before the Allied landings in France on June 6, 1944. Therefore no one could say later that we should have forbidden ourselves the weapon and just let Hitler take his time about coming forward and surrendering.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has told President Eisenhower that he is willing to have Britain supply arms to the Kassim Government of Iraq. President Eisenhower agreed during the week-end talks with Mr. Macmillan that this move might help block Soviet plans in the Middle East by limiting Iraqi dependence on the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- There are several persuasive reasons for the absence of Vice President Nixon from the week-end consultations at Camp David among British and United States high Government officials. But in this community the tendency is to look for political portents of 1960 in any Presidential decision in which the Vice President is involved.
ONE of New York's advantages is the amount of available fashions and fashion accessories with remarkably small price tags. This makes good taste possible for the intrepid shopper on a limited budget.

DETROIT, March 23 (AP) -Passenger car production has continued to hold up despite curtailments in some plants. The curtailments are described as designed to adjust inventories in certain regions only and not to be due to any over-all weakness in the car market, according to Automotive News.
NICE, France, March 23 -- An hour before the meet started, 10,000 persons had jammed Paris' Palais des Sports. Three thousand more milled about the streets, clamoring to get in.
The Federal Housing Administration issued an $8,436,000 mortgage insurance commitment yesterday that will make possible an early start on constructing the long-delayed Kips Bay slum redevelopment.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Mrs. Aileen B. Ryan, an Assemblywoman from the Bronx, mined legislative gold here today against all the laws of political probability. To do so, she had to catch some canny old prospectors napping.
A Surrogate's Court jury upheld yesterday the will of Anna A. McCarthy, sister of the late John A. McCarthy, Tammany politician and contractor. The will disposed of $2,000,000.

LONDON, March 23 -- If there is anything that raises the temperature of a true Savoyard, it's a hot "Mikado." Half a million Britons here and abroad who protest changing one syllable of the W. S. Gilbert librettos took their cause to Parliament today.

LUXEMBOURG, March 23 -The Euorpean coal-steel pool pledged unemployment pay for Belgian miners today, but left undecided whether production and import restrictions should be placed on all six member states.

SEATTLE, March 23 -- The western contract bridge pair of Lew Mathe and Ed Taylor, both of Los Angeles, won the Open Pairs Championship of the Spring National Championships early today by one of the largest margins in tournament history.
ROBBINS, Tenn., March 23 (AP) -- A gas explosion ripped the interior of a small coal mine today, killing nine men.

Mrs. Donald Perkins, chairman for the twelfth annual Salute to Summer tea dance, will be hostess at a cocktail party and business meeting at her home, 23 East Seventy-fourth Street, today. Chairmen of various committees for the fete and officers of the beneficiary, the Society of Memorial Cancer Center, will attend. The tea dance will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 18.
Emile Griffith, a choir boy, reached one note higher on the welterweight scale last night.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 16 -- Discontent is creeping through the Portuguese province of Mozambique on the eastern seaboard of Southern Africa. However, the unrest involves only whites, with the Africans scarcely knowing what it is about.
A modernized health code for this city, the first extensive revision since 1914, was enacted yesterday by the Board of Health.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- The Commission on Human Rights was asked today to rule that a person's flight from religious persecution in his own country was a valid ground for seeking asylum in another.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 23 -- An uproar of Deputies brandishing fists and shouting "Insult!" forced the Grand National Assembly today to postpone a final vote on a United StatesTurkish expropriations agreement.

Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross asserted yesterday that Manhattan City Prison (the Tombs) was "overcrowded with prisoners" and "undermanned by guards." She made her comments on taking reporters and photographers on a tour of the seventh floor of the prison at 100 Centre Street.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan concluded today what they agreed had been a highly successful series of talks.

LONDON, March 23 -- The Colonial Office published details today of a reported plot by African nationalists in Nyasaland to massacre British officials, missionaries, European and Asian residents, including women and children, and nonwhite "quislings."
KALIMPONG, India, March 23 (UPI) -- The revolt against Chinese rule is spreading in the interior of Tibet and the Dalai Lama is safe, Tibetans in this border city said today.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Robert Moses was excoriated tonight in terms seldom heard in the Senate chamber as his nomination for a second five-year term on the State Power Authority came up for action.

Stockholders in the Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., approved an increase in the authorized stock to 10,000,000 from 3,000,000 shares at their annual meeting yesterday in White Plains, N. Y. This paved the way for a proposed two-for-one stock split.
Prospective members of the Girls Club of New York will hear a discussion of the program of the organization at a luncheon at the clubhouse at 312 East Thirtieth Street next Tuesday.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., March 23 -- The chairman of the State Power Authority denounced the Federal Power Commission today for its handling of the authority's Niagara power project license.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 24 -- Rescuers worked unremittingly today to pull a 20-day-old Oxford University student from a cavern 1.000 feet underground at Castleton, Derbyshire.

MAIN dishes that are quick to cook are a boon to the woman who must rush home from the office to prepare dinner. Steaks and chops are the easiest answer to the problem. But even the finest of meats can become monotonous if it is served uninterruptedly.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 23 (UPI) -- A Defense Department official said today that $400,000,000 and a "sympathetic approach" by the Government would give the United States a manned and maneuverable space ship by 1962.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -The Senate passed late today a bill to provide up to $389,500,000 in loans and grants to communities in distress because of unemployment. The vote was 49 to 46.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller said at a press interview today that the state must assume greater responsibility for helping New York City solve its problems.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A Supreme Court decision on the case of Rudolf Ivanovich Abel, convicted Soviet spy, is off until next fall at the earliest.

BRENDA LEWIS sang Marie for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera last night, and the impact of "Wozzeck" remained as powerful as it had been at the season's first two performances, when Eleanor Steber hade the role.

TRENTON, March 23 -- The Assembly voted today to extend the unemployment benefit period from twenty-six to thirty-nine weeks permanently. It also voted to increase the maximum weekly benefit rate from $35 to onehalf, and later two-thirds of the average weekly wage earned in the state.
Before a crowd of 10,350 that paid $30,095.10, Antonino Rocca and his partner won the chief wrestling exhibition match at Madison Square Garden last night.
Easter Sunday commemorates a miraculous awakening. How can people continue to defile it by needless acts of cruelty to helpless chicks and ducklings ?
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, March 20 -- Action by nine Latin American nations for joint measures to stabilize production, marketing and pricing of cotton has been announced here.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel I. Newhouse, publishers of newspapers in a number of cities in the United States, have agreed to purchase what is thought to be a controlling interest in Conde Nast Publications, Inc.
The machine tool industry, which makes the machines that turn out machines, is continuing its slow and steady climb from the recession of 1958.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Rockefeller administration's middle-income housing bill survived its major test in the Assembly today.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Shipper demand, which had been virtually absent for several days from the butcher hog market showed some improvement today but the supply was a liberal 12.000 head and prices were 25 to 40 cents a hundred pounds lower.

In your article of March 15 headed "Nashville Hails Plan on Schools" you list factors responsible for the peaceful admission of Negroes to a second class in previously all-white schools but you omit one very salient factor.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan directed the receivers of the bankrupt Ontario and Western Railroad yesterday to place on the auction block for a second time twelve acres of waterfront property owned by the railroad in West New York, N. J.
The president of a national lawyers' association said yesterday that "insufficiency of judges is the sole reason for the congestion in New York courts."
Unionized employes at eight voluntary hospitals will start balloting today on whether to authorize a strike by Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union.
Robert L. Milano's one-act opera "The Hired Hand," heard last night at Carl Fischer Hall, takes place in New England, but its roots are buried in Italian soil.
It used to be that when a youngster had to stay after school he was looked upon with disdain or pity by his classmates.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Attorney General William P. Rogers designated Malcolm R. Wilkey of Houston, Tex., today as the new head of the Justice Department's Criminal Division and director of the drive on hoodlums and racketeers.
Mayor Wagner's office released a statement yesterday expressing the Mayor's "wholehearted support" for the proposed 1959 Federal Housing Act now being considered by a Senate subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -House leaders of both parties moved today to restore at least a part of the $225,000,000 denied the Development Loan Fund by the House Appropriations Committee.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 23 -- Southern Rhodesia withdrew today its preventive detention bill, the most controversial measure of a series designed to implement a ban on the African National Congress. The Government also said it would release fifty prisoners.
PINEHURST, N. C., March 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone won the nineteenth hole with a par 4 today to defeat Joanne Goodwin for the North and South amateur golf championship.

Two groups are discouraging bowlers from dillydallying on the lanes. One group consists of bowling proprietors who have busy establishments. The other is made up of bowlers waiting to get onto the lanes. A recent program to eliminate unnecessary waiting was instituted by the Bowling Proprietors Asso ciation in Detroit.

The Cuban revolution has never lacked drama, either in itself or in its colorful leader, Fidel Castro. Premier Castro obviously has not yet persuaded himself that the United States would like to be on friendly and helpful terms with the new regime.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today cracked a ring that had allegedly obtained more than $45,000 by getting advance solutions to crossword puzzle contests in newspapers across the United States.
A request by James B. Carey to address formally the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's annual meeting has been rejected, the company said yesterday.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he personally was for spanking. He said he had spanked his own children "with no adverse effects." Legislatively, however, he said he was undecided.

Tickets are still available for the April 2 performance of "First Impressions" at the Alvin Theatre, which will benefit the Speedwell Society. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

The caretakers of "All in the Family" finally have signed the feminine star needed for the comedy. She is Wendy Hiller, last seen here as the frustrated farm girl in "A Moon for the Misbegotten" (1957).
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Fines totaling $106,750 were imposed today on twentyseven Washington area Ford and Oldsmobile dealers charged with conspiring to fix prices on new cars and accessories.

From 1932 until his retirement at the end of 1953 the production of this newspaper six nights a week was under the capable direction of Raymond H. McCaw. He was the night managing editor, and he knew his business. He had learned it the old-fashioned way, by traveling the length and the breadth of the land he loved so much and working at all sorts of jobs on all sorts of newspapers.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it would discontinue ferry service between Weehawken and Manhattan at midnight tonight.

TRENTON, March 23 (AP) -The conviction of a labor-management welfare fund administrator for helping to defraud a Newark insurance concern was reversed by the Appellate Division of Superior Court today.

A hurricane smashes into the Carolina coastline, leaving shattered homes, stunned victims; a heavy snowstorm cripples the northeastern UnitedStates; floods devastate the Ohio Valley -- and Red Cross is there when it is needed most.
Frequently in the past six years, coaches, principals and the Public Schools Athletic League have tried to arrange a football schedule leading to a city championship. Last Friday they succeeded.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -Following is the text of a United States note to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today concerning damage to undersea cables:
WASHINGTON, March 23 -Proposals for Federal legislation to let manufacturers fix retail prices of branded merchandise were denounced today by the Justice Department.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Rockefeller administration has persuaded William H. Morgan, a Democrat, to resign from the state Civil Service Commission to permit the installation of a Republican as president of the three-member commission.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Assembly approved a bill today to permit Westchester County to impose a 5 per cent tax on admissions at Yonkers Raceway.
Mike Nichols and Elaine May, who have appeared as a comedy team on various television shows, will be regular panel members on a new comedy program titled "Laugh Line."
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley charged yesterday that Surface Transit, Inc., was trying to usurp the city's power to regulate the use of its streets.

As described in The Times of March 13, Dr. Alan T. Waterman, director of the National Science Foundation, has once more had to point out the dangers inherent in failing to give adequate financial support to basic research in this country. Dr. Waterman listed the programs of the National Science Foundation which would have to be curtailed or eliminated because of the budgetary cutbacks.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee restored to the Kennedy-Ervin bill today a provision permitting the exemption of small unions from the financial reporting requirements of the bill.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- The nation faces a wheat production crisis that will cost the taxpayers millions upon millions unless Congress intervenes, Assistant Agriculture Secretary Marvin L. McLain declared today.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Speculation about a possible compromise for the omnibus banking bill spread tonight after Governor Rockefeller had clarified his own position on the subject.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -Reports of good moisture over the week-end in much of the major wheat-producing area weakened the new-crop futures of that grain today on the Board of Trade.

SETBACKS, like the possible loss of his party's hopes of getting a majority of the seats in Northern Rhodesia's legislative elections last Friday, are simply routine challenges to slumborn Sir Roy Welensky.
Public and private schools have been refused the use of most National Guard armories in the city in violation of state law, it was charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Soviet scientists have turned up evidence of a continental land mass beneath a great part of the ice-covered expanse of Antarctica, United States scientists reported today.
A maritime career spanning sixty years -- forty-six of which were spent with the Bethlehem Steel Company or its subsidiaries -- will end for H. W. Warley next Tuesday.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 23 (AP) -- The Government announced tonight the closing of an area on the Iranian border.
ST. CHARLES, Va., March 23 (AP) -- A dynamite blast at a nonunion mine in Lee County caused damage to surface facilities estimated at $10,000 to $15,000 early today.
Robert Moses urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to veto a bill that would revise the planned Brooklyn approach to the Narrows Bridge.
Recent market favorites led a retreat on the stock exchanges yesterday.

A device used to flash high altitude weather data to jet aircraft is being employed by the New York Savings Bank to permit customers of its new Grand Central branch to make deposits in or withdrawals from accounts at either of its two other offices.
IF "Our Town" seems familiar at Circle In The Square, where it was acted last evening, it is not because we know the play so well.
The electronic computer is helping the textile industry to determine how and when a new fiber or a new fabric construction will stand stress and strain.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- The United States told the Kremlin today that there was a "strong presumption" that the Soviet trawler Novorossisk had broken five trans-Atlantic submarine cables last month while fishing near Newfoundland.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Assembly today voted its approval by 113 to 27 of a constitutional amendment that would exempt $500,000,000 for school construction from New York City's debt limit. The amendment now goes to the Senate. If approved there, as is expected, it will be submitted to the voters of the state at a referendum in the fall.

Despite some furious jamming between 9 P.M. and 11 P.M. the Italian duo of Fernando Terruzzi and Leandro Faggin held the lead in the seventy-second international six-day bicycle race at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.
PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- Twenty-four cargo ships and 4,500 longshoremen were made idle today by a dispute between employers and the independent International Longshoremen's Association.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, who said he was just using the event as "a trial run for the Masters," shot a 3-under-par 69 in the final round today to win the $15,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 275.
THE money question, which had caused a temporary temporary slowdown in plans for a fashion show at the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer, now appears to be under control.
A tiny factor may have some responsibility for the big boom in electronics stocks recently. It's called miniaturization. Companies by the dozen are getting into the field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Robert Webb will direct the screen version of the Louis L'Amour novel, "Guns of the Timberland," which Alan Ladd's Jaguar Company is producing for Warner Brothers. Mr. Ladd will also star in the Western melodrama.

Plans have been announced for the annual benefit for the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Departing from their custom of giving an annual tea dance, the Lower East Side Committee, sponsors of the event, is arranging a dinner dance. It will be held in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane on April 16.

An illuminating picture of American public opinion on the Berlin crisis was provided by this newspaper's survey published yesterday. It is no surprise that the survey found the American people generally support President Eisenhower's firm stand on Berlin, but large numbers of people, the survey suggests, know little about the Berlin problem and have little appreciation of its potentialities or causes.

Most of the block bounded by Madison and Fourth Avenues and Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets has been acquired by the New York Life Insurance Company for future improvement with an office building.
The Corn Products Company in 1958 had its best year in its fifty-two-year history, William T. Grady, president, reported in the annual statement to 61,425 stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it was ready to consider application for limited tests of pay-as-you-see television.
WASHINGTON, March. 23 -Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that the last forty years of United States economic history had "cast grave doubts" on the theory that budget deficits cause inflation.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- A New Orleans crime fighter said today that law officers in a Louisiana parish gave Mafia mobsters protection for operations that fanned out over several neighboring states.
May Davenport Seymour, curator of the theatre and music collection of the Museum of the City of New York, received the 1959 Kelcey Allen Award yesterday at a luncheon at Sardi's Restaurant.

Alexander L. Guterma was indicted yesterday with three other men on charges that depicted the Bon-Ami Company as having been defrauded of $642,050 and a Long Island bank as having been induced illegally to guarantee $2,525,000 in loans.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Legislation to continue business and commercial rent controls for a year was approved tonight by then Assembly Rules Committee. It applies only to New York City. The bill is scheduled to be voted on in the Assembly tomorrow.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 23 (AP) -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan told the nation today that he would give it a new constitution "only when the mess created in the past looks like it is being cleared up and vital reforms that have been launched get going."
The $50,000 open golf tournament that was held in the metropolitan district last year as a benefit for the Boys Club of New York will not be staged in 1959.

Prime Minister Macmillan flies home today after a week-end of conferences with President Eisenhower which have made him "happy and satisfied" and the results of which are regarded by the President as "fine." This is as it should be, and it could not be otherwise. The Western powers can meet the Soviet challenge successfully only if they reach agreement among themselves on both policy and action.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- A former foreign aid official told Congress under oath today that he had accepted cash, stocks and airline tickets worth a total of about $25,000 from a contractor for United States public works projects in Laos.

THE warm spring sun lured millions of New Yorkers out of doors last Saturday afternoon. But, as far as four young chess enthusiasts were concerned, it could have been midnight inside a submerged submarine.

Steel production reached another high mark last week for the third in a row. But for the first time this year the American Iron and Steel Institute forecast that output would decline slightly this week.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -There was considerable interest and some dismay here as a result of the disclosure in The New York Times this morning that 39 per cent of those questioned in a national spot check did not know that Berlin was an enclave in Communist East Germany 100 miles from the West German border.
The theory that faulty altimeters caused the recent American Airlines crash in the East River was questioned yesterday on several counts.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Supreme Court held today that variable annuity insurance contracts were subject to regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The vote was five to four.
Contract negotiations between union printers and ten newspapers here remained -deadlocked yesterday, although some discussions were held.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 23 -- The site of a sewage disposal plant for a $5,000,000 sewer project in Inwood was approved by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors here today.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 23 (AP) -- The University of Texas made a bid for big-time basketball prestige today, hiring Harold Bradley of Duke as coach.
Representative Francis E. Dorn, Brooklyn Republican, freely acknowledged yesterday that his Brooklyn law partner was on his staff payroll at a salary of $6,700 a year.

TAMPA, Fla., March 23 -- If Luis Aparicio didn't have a sturdy forefinger, he probably would have died of starvation while playing shortstop for Waterloo of the Three-Eye League in 1954. He couldn't speak a word of English, including the most important words in any ballplayer's vocabulary, "I'll have steak."
The Illinois Central Railroad is ready to invest up to $8,000,000 to acquire a major stock interest in the Central of Georgia Railway.

LONDON, March 23 -- Industrials moved irregularly in the stock market today. A slight predominance of minor declines lowered the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares half a point to 220.6.
The theoretical groundwork reportedly has been laid for the design of machines capable of learning from experience and adapting to circumstances.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today left up in the air the question whether the Atomic Energy Commission can make public a hitherto secret invention without the inventor's consent.
An audience of more than 2,700 filled Carnegie Hall last night to hear the second and final recital being given here this season by Zara Doloukanova, Soviet mezzo-soprano.
Opening April 11, the intercollegiate rowing season in the East will offer the most crowded schedule in recent years.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 13 to 28 points yesterday. The rise equaled 65 cents to $1.40 a bale.

There was quick reaction yesterday to the Supreme Court's decision placing variable annuities under the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Variable annuities differ from the usual type of insurance in that payments fluctuate along with the changing market values of the securities on which they are based.

MIAMI, March 23 -- Tom Sturdivant is one of the chattels understood to be acceptable to the Senators in the drawn out trade discussions that eventually may bring one of Washington's crack starters to the Yankees.
A trace of gloom tempered with optimism regarding the team's chances next season was evident yesterday in the New York Rangers' offices in Madison Square Garden.

MONTREAL, March 23 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens, National Hockey League champions, begin their bid for a record fourth consecutive Stanley Cup tomorrow night against the Chicago Black Hawks in the opener of their seven-game semi-final series.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -Two Democratic Senators accused the Atomic Energy Commission today of withholding and "playing down" information on the dangers of radioactive fall-out from tests.

" THE GREEN PASTURES" was offered for the second time on live television last night over channel 4; again it was a presentation of rare beauty, inspiration and warm humor, one of the treasures of the home medium.
A one-day walkout by about 30,000 city employes next Tuesday to protest cuts in pay increases was threatened last night.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan pressed for a summit conference tonight at an offthe-record meeting with Congressional leaders.
Congress will go home on Thursday for a holiday of ten days, mainly to tell its constituents how it thinks it has been doing, why it did it and perhaps what it expects to do next.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 23 -- A Kenya police pathologist testifield today that eleven Mau Mau rebels in the Hola detention camp had died as a result of violence.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -Attorneys for the Farmers Union argued today that a North Dakota television station should be held liable for libelous statements against the union made by a political candidate in 1956.

Negotiations between the Screen Publicists Guild and the management of Twentieth Century-Fox will be resumed this morning at 10:30. The guild, which has asked for higher wages, resumed negotiations last week after announcing its intention of picketing film openings here.
Commodity prices moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Consumer spending rose to a record annual rate at the start of 1959.
Animals ranging from small snakes to elephants and a beerdrinking lion have been finding a temporary home at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
A hold-up man served briefly as a clerk last night in a Harlem liquor store when customers entered while he and his partner were looting the back room.

Voluntary agencies dealing with the resettlement of refugees are deeply concerned by what they say is a change in Federal policy toward aliens whose deportations had been deferred because of possible political persecution abroad.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare deplored today the "drastic action" of the House Appropriations Committee in recommending a $50,300,000 cut in this year's operation of the National Defense Education Act.

SAN SALVADOR, March 23 (UPI) -- The end of dictatorships in the Americas appears at hand, Alberto Gainza Paz, president of the Inter American Press Association, said today in his semi-annual report to the board of directors.
Forty elephants galumphed briskly into town in the chilly early hours yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., March 23 (AP) -- Howard Grant, who established a Bowie riding record last Thursday when he brought home six winners, bounced back this afternoon with another big day. scoring in four consecutive races.
A headline in The Times of March 19 reads "U. S. Atom Blasts 300 Miles Up Mar Radar."
OTTAWA, March 23 -- Charles Edward Rivett-Carnac was appointed Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police today.

BERLIN, March 23 -- The West Berlin city government joined with political and economic leaders today in opening a company for "airlift donations." The campaign is designed to express gratitude to the West for the airlift that saved the city from starvation during the Soviet blockade of 1948-49.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange contracted sharply yesterday, as prices advanced gingerly after declining for four days.
RANGOON, Burma, March 17 -- Rangoon is undergoing a most drastic clean-up.

CAIRO, March 17 -- The United Arab Republic has floated a new production loan of 25,000,000 Egyptian pounds ($71,750,000 at the official rate of $2.87). The issue matures in twelve years and pays 3 1/2 per cent interest.

THE newest innovation in home freezers is General Electric's upright model that freezes without frosting. It will go into production within three weeks and is expected to be available in retail stores about May 1.

As a teacher in a junior high school in New York City where cases of disrespect and misbehavior are a major problem, I wish to take issue with the well-intentioned but unrealistic people who are opposed to corporal punishment in the schools.
LANSING, Mich., March 24 -- The State of Michigan, teetering on the brink of insolvency for weeks, took a step today toward resolving its fiscal crisis.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- The Jessop Steel Company of Washington, Pa., a producer of specialty steels, yesterday disclosed the acquisition of the Steel Warehousing Corporation of Chicago.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher and chairman of the board of The New York Times, was inducted as a fellow of the Jewish Academy of Arts and Sciences last night.

TAMPA, Fla., March 24 (UPI) -- J. Norman Lewis, the New York attorney who helped major league baseball players obtain their handsome pension fund, was dismissed today at a stormy meeting of the sixteen player representatives.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, March 24 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:

Directors of the American Agricultural Chemical Company yesterday proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock and authorized an increase to 2,500,000 from the present 700,000 shares. The company has 627,969 shares outstanding.
The Waterfront Commission announced yesterday that it had suspended two longshoremen in coffee thefts at the Sealand Terminal, Kent and Java Streets, Brooklyn.

HARTFORD, March 24 -- The State Senate approved and sent to the House today a bill abolishing all of the 168 town and city courts in Connecticut and creating a state Circuit Court to take their place. The vote was 33 to 2.

FREEDOM of form is evident in Mills-Denmark's new line of plastic-based upholstered furniture from Denmark. Called "Formpressed," this furniture is now available for the first time in the United States at Mills-Denmark's through - decorator showroom, 227 East Fifty-sixth Street.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate rejected the omnibus banking bill today by a vote of 17 to 39. Indications were that the defeat would be followed by continuing a legislative freeze on bank holding company expansion for another year.

HAVE you ever heard of Nuristan? Neither had I until a few days ago when I read "A Short Walk: A Preposterous Adventure,"* by Eric Newby, which is a highly diverting narrative about an extraordinarily harebrained and foolhardy journey to that country made in the summer of 1956.

The market for bank stocks anticipated the defeat of the omnibus banking bill yesterday. Shares of suburban New York institutions that had traded up sharply in recent weeks had eased considerably before the fate of the bill finally was decided.
Plans to picket the New York Hospital today and possibly cut off most deliveries -- were announced yesterday by a teamster union local in the hospital organizing field.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Virginia and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People clashed in the Supreme Court today over a series of state laws that the association said would put it out of business in Virginia.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Rockefeller signed three bills today clearing the way for staggering the dates for the renewal of automobile plates and drivers' licenses. One measure gives the Motor Vehicle Commissioner power to continue registration plates from year to year, with the issuance of annual tags.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The Treasurer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., testified today that the chemical concern would accumulate more than $2,000,000,000 in cash if a Government plan to divest the concern of its 23 per cent ownership of General Motors Corp. were adopted.

The scholarship fund of Incarnation Camp in Ivoryton, Conn., will benefit from a theatre party to be sponsored by the 209 Club, which is associated with the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Legislature was poised tonight to vote more than $2,000,000 to insure the smooth administration of the new income tax law it had approved earlier this year.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Civil Rights Commission has asked its South Dakota Advisory Committee to "evaluate" broad allegations of discrimination against Indians in that state.

A fight for control of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., was begun yesterday. Three stockholders filed material with the New York Stock Exchange stating their intention to solicit proxies in opposition to management.
A r port on a new study of the Washington Square traffic problem will be put before the Board of Estimate when it takes up the matter today.
New flashing approach lights to add safety measures at La Guardia Airport, Queens, were checked yesterday by Federal Aviation Agency inspectors.

BOSTON, March 24 (UPI) -- Harry Lumley's superb goaltending and a three-goal middle period lifted the Boston Bruins to a 5-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the opening game of their semifinal Stanley Cup play-off series.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Drums went bang, cymbals clanged, and Ireland's President today became an honorary citizen of Chicago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- Thirty years ago, a Turkish girl had her first look at the city of Ankara rising impressively above the plain.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The United States, Britain and France plan to invite the Russians "within a few days" to a foreign ministers' meeting to begin May 11 in Geneva. They will propose an East-West summit meeting as soon as one is justified by the results of the ministerial discussions.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today it was dropping a proceeding designed to label the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America as a Communist-infiltrated union.
