The dean of this port's towboat industry, Eugene F. Moran, received the plaudits of the Port of New York Authority last night for outstanding service to local shipping.

The touchy subject of college-professional relations in baseball was stirred up again the other day when Gene Leeke, who had been playing third base for the University of Arizona, signed a bonus contract with the Cleveland Indians.
An investigation of how the city's Committee on Slum Clearance selects sites for demolition and how it designates sponsors to redevelop them was requested of Mayor Wagner last night.

TOKYO, March 24 -- Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama outlined today numerous changes that Japan wants in her seven-year-old security treaty with the United States. He said he planned to bring these matters before Ambassador Douglas MacArthur 2d in a few days.
The day may be near when women will add "one can of bobby socks" to their shopping lists.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 13 -- Everything, even the weather, seems to be going wrong on the lovely island of Ceylon in the twelfth year of its independence.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- Premier H. C. Hansen of Denmark conferred with President Eisenhower today and afterward expressed support for East-West summit talks.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 24 -- When Eddie Yost was a green young third baseman on the Washington Senators, he was more than awed by the assignment. He was virtually terrified when the colorful Bobo Newsom took his place on the mound for the Senators one day. By his own admission the somewhat eccentric Bobo was the world's greatest pitcher.
George W. Romney, president of the American Motors Corporation, praised Junior Achievement, Inc., last night for "demonstrating to the younger generation the grand drama of business."

BONN, Germany, March 24 -- The prosecution demanded today suspended prison sentences of four months each for two of West Germany's leading diplomats on trial in what has become known as "the striped pants affair."

TUNIS, March 24 -- The Algerian rebel leadership here denied today that a large body of soldiers had defected to the French in acceptance of President Charles de Gaulle's offer of "the peace of the brave."
NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- Not quite nine years ago, when Prime Minister Nehru dared to protest the Communist Chinese invasion of Tibet, he was warned by Peiping to mind his own business.

According to an ancient legend of the Ottawa Indians, the maple tree once produced pure syrup. As in Virgil's dream of the Golden Age, the sweet, amber delicacy oozed forth from the forest trees for the easy delectation of the passerby.
LONDON, March 24 -- A 20-year-old Oxford University student died early today wedged in a fissure of a cave 1,000 feet beneath the earth's surface.
A ranking Senate committeeman said here yesterday he was going abroad to find out what the European maritime countries "are trying to do to us."
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today the nation's unfavorable balance of payments was reduced in the last three months of 1958.

NORWALK, Conn, March 24 -- The Norwalk Jewish Center may continue to operate in the exclusive Shorehaven colony, but some of its recreational activities must be curbed, according to a ruling made yesterday by Superior Court Judge J. Howard Roberts.

Prices of Government debt securities declined small fractions in light trading yesterday as the investment community sat back to await the outcome of the first half of the Treasury's $4,000,000,000 cash borrowing.

King Hussein of Jordan has earned a warm welcome in the United States and wherever men honor courage and rectitude. It is remarkable for so young a man to have shown such ability to cope with the dangerous and intricate problems of the Arab world. The proof that he has done so thus far is his presence here with his Premier.

Textron, Inc. has extended the expiration date of its offer to purchase all stock of the Townsend Company to April 3. This was announced yesterday by Royal Little, chairman of Textron and F. R. Dickinson, president of Townsend.

LONDON, March 24 -- It is precisely twenty-five years since the United States promised full independence to the Philippines and a half century to the week since our last troops were withdrawn from Cuba. The only Americans now in those republics are diplomats, business men, tourists and service men stationed on bases obtained by negotiated agreements.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The disbursing clerk of the House of Representatives put an end today to public scrutiny of reports on what House members did with the $1,800 allowances to them to maintain offices in their home districts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- The United Nations Children's Fund, known widely as UNICEF, is returning donations from United States citizens who may be unaware that they can no longer write off those gifts as deductions on their income tax returns.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Mickey Cohen, who says he has gone straight, refused to say today whether he had shaken down a Los Angeles cigarette machine operator for $11,000.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 24 -- Iraq withdrew today from the Baghdad Pact.
FESTIVALS and anniversary observances assume meaning when they are served with the glowing devotion that went into last night's performance of Handel's "Acis and Galatea" at Carnegie Hall.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Rockefeller Administration had decided to preserve the state building code intact for at least a year.

This week New York City is the electronics capital of the nation, and perhaps the world, with the Institute of Radio Engineers meeting here. It is always pleasant to have these gentlemen in our midst, though many of their technical concerns are beyond the competence or understanding of the average layman, here or elsewhere.

Despite the repeated alarms in Washington, hard evidence of Soviet capability of launching long-range missiles is still absent. No verification has reached this country of numerous reports published here and abroad of the identification of ballistic missile launching pads.
Eighty-five years of serving the city in cultural, athletic and social activities were celebrated last night by the Ninety-second Stret Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

SEATTLE, March 24 -- The contract bridge team of B. Jay Becker, John R. Crawford, George Rapee and Tobias Stone, all of New York City; Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia and Norman Kay of Merchantsville, N. J., need to win only one more thirty-six-hand match to clinch victory in the Vanderbilt Cup Team of Four National Championship.

In your editorial of March 19 concerning unemployment in the United States you express concern over the existence of not only a large number of unemployed, but also a large number of areas which appear to suffer from chronic unemployment.
MONTREAL, March 24 (UPI) -- Dickie Moore turned in the greatest stretch run in history in becoming the first Montreal player to win the National Hockey League scoring championship two straight years.
A special Federal grand jury was impaneled here yesterday to investigate the coin-machine industry -- with particular emphasis on racketeering in the juke box and cigarette vending industries.

KALIMPONG, India, March 24 (UPI) -- Tibetans using captured Communist arms have resumed their battle against Chinese forces in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, according to reports received in this border city today.

The New York Life Insurance company has leased a floor in the new office building at 355 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street, for its largest eastern agency, the Lincoln Agency. Lincoln, now at 60 East Forty-second Street, is the fourth insurance group to get space in the new structure.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Don't count Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas out of the 1960 Presidential election yet. The Democratic pros in this part of the country at least are definitely not doing so, and they were the ones who were supposed to be more opposed to nominating Mr. Johnson than anybody else.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Following is the text of the statement today by John A. McCone, chairman of the Atomic Enerby Commission, before the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee:

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Simca Societe Anonyme, French Automobile producing company, today notified the Securities and Exchange Commission of a proposed $36,500,000 capital stock issue, a substantial part of which would be offered in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House of Representatives approved today $100,000,000 of a $225,000,000 emergency appropriation sought by President Eisenhower for the Development Loan Fund.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower praised King Hussein today as a man who had "withstood the temptations" to weaken his defense of his principles and rights.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Rockefeller sent to the Senate for confirmation today the appointment of Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, retired, of New York City, as chairman of the State Civil Defense Commission. The appointment fills a vacancy left by the resignation of Admiral Alan G. Kirk, chairman.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Legislature acted today to lighten the burden of communities that supply services to federally constructed property leased for private operation.

NEWARK, March 24 -- Two armed bandits held up the priory of the Dominican Fathers at St. Antoninus Roman Catholic church this afternoon. After threatening three priests and three employes, they escaped with $1,500 from the church's Sunday collection.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee adopted today a plan that may narrow the so-called "no man's land" of labor-management relations cases.
The Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., realty concern, issued a statement yesterday defending property sale and lease-back transactions effected in 1956 and 1957 with the Penn-Texas Company.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The State Department's security chief said today that forced granting of passports to hard - core Communists had weakened the nation's internal security.

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., March 24 -- Plans for a historical memorial at Camp Shanks were announced today by Clarence A. Noyes. He is chairman of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors and supervisor of the town of Orangetown, where the World War II camp was located.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan affirmed today that the West would succeed in the "tough task" of negotiating with the Soviet Union. The British leader made this comment on the projected foreign ministers' and summit conferences before he left for London on a jet airliner.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- "Spinster," a first novel by Sylvia Ashton-Warner, has been purchased for filming by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The story, which was published by Simon Schuster, concerns an old-maid school teacher, Anna Vorontosov and her experiences as a teacher of Maori children in New Zealand.
LONDON, March 24 -- The British Government named today a four-man commission of inquiry into recent disturbances in Nyasaland.

In Russia, the phrase "back to the salt mines" has been tantamount to a living death. Not so in this country, evidently. Yesterday, the Morton Salt Company opened a rock salt mine it calls the first new one in this country in twenty-five years and the deepest in the nation.

The $140,000 commerce and industry drive of the United Epilepsy Association was opened yesterday by Dale E. Sharp, the campaign chairman, at a meeting at Twentieth-Century Fox, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.
HIBERNIA, N. J., Wednesday, March 25 -- The wife of a scientist was in police custody tonight after two of her children were found battered to death last night in a summer house here.
Rebel yells rang out and political sabers were rattled at City Hall yesterday as angry Democrats fired the first official shots in the city's "secession" movement.

Across the Hudson and beyond the Palisades lie some salt marshes which must have made the early settlers of this region feel at home. Perhaps, in those days, the Jersey Meadows even looked in places like the polders of Holland. But if the Dutchmen erected windmills there, they have long since given way to smokestacks and towering industrial structures that hug the railway embankments.
CHICAGO, March 24 -- Three universities announced today a joint project to study the half of the visible universe best seen from the Southern Hemisphere.
IT is a lead-pipe cinch now that the trout season will open April 1 instead of April 11. A lead-pipe cinch is a 6-to-5 bet. Anything better than that is a fix.
The deadlock between ten New York newspapers and their union printers over a new contract continued yesterday.
Joseph G. Luberda, the retired police sergeant, spent an uncomfortable three hours yesterday before the Kings County rackets grand jury investigating his finances.
Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Nathan Jr. reserved decision yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus aimed at freeing the two Valenti brothers.
PHILIPPEVILLE, Algeria, March 24 -- Premier Michel Debre of France expressed his belief today that rebel commanders in the interior of Algeria were beginning to respond to offers of a cease-fire.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Legislature approved and sent to the Governor today a bill to make Albany the capital of New York State. Albany's present claim to this distinction is a matter of habit rather than of record. Nothing in the state Constitution says that Albany is the seat of government.
ST. LOUIS, March 24 (UPI) Red Schoendienst of the Milwaukee Braves returned to his home here today, ending a five-month stay in a hospital, where he had been treated for tuberculosis since Nov. 8.

Concern over world economic problems resulted in near-record attendance yesterday at the opening of the forty-second annual convention of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc. More than 1,100 representatives of the export trade and related fields attended the convention sessions, luncheons and dinner at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

Net sales of Montgomery Ward Co. rose nearly 2 per cent in the fiscal year ended Jan. 28 to $1,092,267,472 from $1,073,799,429 the year before. The volume was the chain store's best since 1951. Earnings, however, were lower, according to the annual report of John A. Barr, chairman and president, issued for publication today.
Residents of the Mitchell and Linden communities of Queens will give blood today at Public School 214 at 31-15 140th Street, Flushing to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 16 -- Africa's 1,000,000 Indians have been shaken by the recent violence in Central Africa. They found that their brown skins have given them no protection against African rioters, who seem to have singled out Indian shops for burning and looting.
New York City's 716 air raid warning sirens will be tested today, beginning at 11 A. M.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 24 -- President Alfredo Stroessner is again considering steps to rid his regime of dictatorial features without losing his grip on power. He is finding this not easy.
The Artists Gallery at 851 Lexington Avenue will benefit from a gala preview of "Masterpieces of Eilshemius" on the evening of April 7.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Leon H. Keyserling told the Joint Congressional Economic Committee today that a much higher rate of economic growth would solve virtually all the nation's problems, including much of the problem on inflation.
To a sizable group of enthusiasts, the Jamaica race track will be the exact center of the sports world from today through May 9.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Atomic Energy Commission and the National Academy of Sciences announced plans today for broad new studies of the radiation hazards posed by nuclear fall-out.

H. (for Herman) Eliot Kaplan was born on the Fourth of July, 1897. His patriotism never flagged, and although he became intensely involved in a thirty-year struggle to keep civil service clean, he never soured on democracy. Yesterday, on his appointment by Governor Rockefeller as chairman of the State Civil Service Commission, Mr. Kaplan clung to a hopeful, long-range view.

Mrs. Charles F. Paul, chairman, has announced plans for the second annual Danse Concertante for the benefit of the Long Island Little Orchestra Society. It is scheduled to take place at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L. I., on May 1.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Legislature completed action today on the first major court reorganization plan in 113 years of the state's judicial history.

FLINT, Mich., March 24 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers has netted $450 from a sale of apples here to send a delegation of jobless workers to the A. F. L. C. I. O. unemployment demonstration in Washington April 8.

Eric Sevareid, news commentator for the Columbia Broadcasting System, will take a four-month leave of absence beginning June 1. Now stationed in Washington, he will join the C. B. S. bureau in London after he returns to work.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 9 points (5 to 45 cents a bale), except in the distant May option, which was unchanged.

MONTREAL, March 24 (UPI) -- Marcel Bonin, the third man on the powerful Jean Beliveau-Dickie Moore line, scored twice in leading the Montreal Canadiens to a 4 -- 2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in the opening game of their National Hockey League semifinal Stanley Cup series.

YONKERS, March 24 -- New-comers to harness racing may not know too much about Franklin H. (Hank) Lowden, one of the fifty-three registered drivers on the grounds at Yonkers Raceway. The 47-year-old Irishman from Ventnor, N. J., has been around the horse 'n' buggy sport for more than fifteen years, but until tonight he had not campaigned here since 1952.
"SHE walks in beauty, like a dressing table on wheels." This has been the timeless lament of husbands throughout the ages.

As it indicated last month when it issued its January operating statement, the New York Central Railroad incurred a net loss again in February. The deficit was $1,642,209. In January the road had a net loss of $890,000 and in February of last year the deficit was $9,869,840.

The attorney for George A. Heaney, former Long Island banker, said yesterday that his client planned to plead guilty today to taking an unlawful $22,000 fee for a $250,000 loan to a company then controlled by Alexander L. Guterma.
Commodity futures closed irregularly higher in generally dull and featureless trading yesterday on the New York exchanges.

The president and two past presidents of the New York State Psychological Association yesterday defended the state law governing the qualifications of psychologists as necessary to protect the public from quacks and charlatans.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 24 (AP) -- The Dutch Government announced today that Crown Princess Beatrix had accepted an invitation to visit New York in September.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 24 (UPI) -- President Alberto Lleras Camargo had a new Cabinet today in which portfolios were distributed evenly between Conservatives and Liberals in accordance with the new national policy that called for bipartisan governments for the next sixteen years.

A BASIC wardrobe of gloves should be kept on hand the year 'round. This can be added to as fashion changes demand. This spring, when suit sleeves stop anywhere from the wrist-bone to above the elbow, longer gloves must rise to meet them.
BOSTON, March 24 (UPI) -- John Thomas, holder of the world indoor high jump record, injured his left foot today in an elevator accident at a Boston University dormitory.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Negotiations were completed speedily today to give the Rockefeller Administration control of the State Civil Service Commission.

The tall blonde in ski pants walked with a cat's slumbering grace toward the front row at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday, sat down, and then winked at a dark-haired French bicycle rider who was pedaling slowly by on the pine track below. He winked back.
The largest stock offering so far this year, $80,100,000 of common shares in The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., reach market today.

J. L. Porter of the Yale Club, the defending titleholder, and James Prigoff of the City A. C. reached the final round of the championship tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association last night. They will meet tomorrow at 5:30 P. M. at the Harvard Club.

AN intense and markedly original world has been created and sustained for more than twenty years by Janet Chase, who exhibits this year for the first time. Her exhibition at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue, shows a reticent yet impassioned sensibility that has unwaveringly held fast to a vision.

MIAMI, March 24 -- Alphonse Lopez, the distinguished skipper of the White Sox, who is known as baseball's all-America runner-up because he is forever finishing second, is hopefully looking for better things this year.

Sales of kraft paper by the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company are more running at a rate than double that of a year ago, David L. Luke, president, reported at the annual stockholders' meeting in the Park Lane Hotel yesterday.

White, Weld Co. and associates today are offering $25,000,000 of Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company 4 3/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1994, at 101.625 to yield 4.285 per cent. The White. Weld group bought the issue yesterday from the utility on a bid of 100.9399 for a 4 3/8 per cent coupon.

An appeal for public support of President Eisenhower's pay-as-you-go budget was made here last night by Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior.

The Ferraris had the speed, the endurance, and the drivers. So they "ganged up" on the field and took most of the honors in the ninth annual twelve-hour championship race at Sebring. A contract for the purchase of the fifteen-story building containing 102 apartments at 390 Riverside Drive at West 111th Street was signed by Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators. The property, 101 feet on the Drive and 125 feet on the street, is assessed at $745,000.
DON'T count on the scientists. To judge by Pearl S. Buck's "A Desert Incident," which opened at the John Golden last evening, they are more mixed up than the rest of us.
SEATTLE, March 24 -- Thubten J. Norbu, eldest brother of the Dalai Lama, said here today that about 90 per cent of Tibet's population was resisting the Communist ideology.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Legislature today approved and sent to the Governor a bill calling for the establishment of a state division of motor boats within the Conservation Department. It thus took official notice of the constantly expanding use of motor boats for recreation.
Ornithologists, after a year-long survey, have just termed 1958 a "year of disaster" for eastern land birds.

An American edition of a history of the medical profession in England since 1300 will be issued by St. Martin's Press on April 14. Titled "Call the Doctor,'' it is the work of Ernest S. Turner. He recounts the cures, fee-taking and morals, doctor-patient relationships and the famous conflicts with the public over man-midwifery, women doctors, vivisection, vaccination, psychoanalysis and mercy killing.
Singers cast for principal roles in four new productions of the New York City Opera Company's spring season at the City Center were announced yesterday. The season opens Monday.

The New York Chapter of Americans for Democratic Action deplored yesterday the sight of the Legislature "rushing post-haste to adjourn" while important bills awaited action. It argued that the situation pointed up the need for legislative reform.

A Bronx property with frontages of 100 feet on Bruckner Boulevard, 600 feet on Metcalf Avenue and 100 feet on Story Avenue has been purchased by Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty operators. It was sold by Marie Braun through Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, March 24 -- Sir Roy Welensky's United Federal party has failed in its bid to capture a majority in the balloting for northern Rhodesia's first elected multi-racial Legislative Council.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- The Senate Interior Committee approved legislation today calling for a "vigorous, forward-looking" review of water resource programs.

A radar system that might allow motorists to drive coast-to-coast with hands off the steering wheel was discussed here yesterday at the annual meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
A forecast for continued business recovery for the rest of the year was made last evening by Dr. Jules Backman, professor of economics at New York University.
A PROBLEM often unsolved in television was overcome with entirely pleasing results last night on "Pontiac Star Parade" over Channel 4.
The New York Central Railroad abandoned its Weehawken ferry service last night, leaving 5,000 commuters to find another way to get to work.

The New York City Health Code, effective Oct. 1, is a monument to dedicated and cooperative effort in a free society. And, unlike most monuments, it will be vastly useful. It will protect, better than ever before, the health and welfare of millions of people -- those who live and work here and those who visit the city.
AN UNMISTAKABLE sign of spring is the run of maple syrup in woodlands to the north.

CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- New-crop wheat futures were under fairly heavy selling pressure again today on the Board of Trade, but other grains were steady to strong in a generally slow market.

This point was that in the recent Brown case the Supreme Court majority based its decision on the fact that the procedure it upheld had, through many of its previous rulings, become part of "the fabric of the Constitution," the same argument it rejected in Brown of 1954.

TROUBLED American women are asking questions with the urgency and eagerness that sparks small children. The answers are coming, crisp and clear, from a busy army of professional trouble-shooters often called agony experts.
MASSAPEQUA, L. I., March 25 -- Diplomacy on a grass-roots level is being attempted by pupils at the Parkside Junior High School here and those at the Nishitoyama Junior High School in Tokyo.
WHY do people adopt children? Most childless couples believe they have a right to happiness and that a youngster will help them to enjoy a full and richer life.

A high-ranking spokesman for East and Gulf Coast longshoremen hailed the use of giant cargo containers yesterday as a "revolution in shipping" that could help this country compete with foreign producers in the search for markets abroad.

Scholarship help for Barnard College undergraduates is the goal of the annual Barnard College Thrift Shop Tea to be held on April 10 in the apartment of Mrs. Odgen Reid of 834 Fifth Avenue. She is a former chairman of the board of trustees of the college.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has purchased the four-story apartment house at 600 Third Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street, from the Margaret Aldrich estate. In the same block he bought the four-story house at 610 Third Avenue from William Oxman.

Sol Steinhardt, described by the police as the "No. 1 fence of the country," was convicted in General Sessions Court early yesterday of receiving and concealing stolen property.

By apparently planned coincidence the three leading Western statesmen outlined their position in the East-West conflict yesterday in statements which, despite varying nuances in emphasis, show agreement on general lines and principles and in effect warn Premier Khrushchev to join in honest negotiations and not to embark on reckless adventures that could end in a cataclysm.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic gave Lebanon a carefully worded promise today that he would respect her independence.

MINNEAPOLIS. Minn.. March 25 (UPI) -- Osborne (Ozzie) Cowles, Minnesota's basketball coach for eleven years, resigned today at the end of a disastrous season. Athletic Director Ike Armstrong said he hoped to recommend a successor within a few weeks.

The New York State Power Authority is negotiating with investment bankers for the sale of about $200,000,000 of general revenue bonds on or about April 20. The money would be used to further the permanent financing of the Niagara Project.
Professional societies were urged yesterday to help improve American education by, in effect, building a fire under American educators.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 25 (Reuters) -- Differences between the Greek and Turkish communities over the implementation of two important provisions of the agreement to make Cyprus an independent republic have led to a crisis in the Transitional Committee discussions, informed diplomatic sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee completed action today on a labor-management reform bill. The vote to send it to the Senate was 13 to 2.
CINCINNATI, March 25 -Establishment of the Adolph S. Ochs Chair of American Jewish History at Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion was announced today by Dr. Nelson Glueck, president.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -Revised revenue estimates issued by Congressional tax experts indicated today that President Eisenhower's "balanced" 1960 budget would run a deficit of at least $1,300,000,000.

SYRACUSE, March 25 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals gained a 119-107 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight and evened the Eastern Division play-offs in the National Basketball Association at two games each.

Cultural understanding and closer relations with the Hispanic world will be furthered with the proceeds of Tuesday evening's performance of the new Spanish musical, "Ole!" at the Greenwich Mews Theatre.
General Electric Company refused yesterday to allow James B. Carey to address stockholders at their annual meeting. Mr. Carey is president of the International Union of Electrical Workers.

A former Long Island banker is ready to testify against Alexander L. Guterma on fraud charges. He pleaded guilty yesterday to taking an unlawful fee for a 1956 loan by his bank to a company controlled by Mr. Guterma.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -In a strong appeal for labormanagement statesmanship, President Eisenhower cautioned both sides in the coming steel wage negotiations to avoid any action that would cause a general price increase.

The mellifluous voice of the electric organ is heard more widely in the land. The electric organ, a relatively expensive item as musical instruments go, is outselling brasses, reeds and strings among amateur musicians.
LONDON, March 25 -- The Government announced today that a civil air agreement between Britain and the Soviet Union was signed in Moscow yesterday.
The bond market retreated slightly on all fronts yesterday.
The Port Authority and the city's Marine and Aviation Department got into a public dispute yesterday over which could built a better pier.

There was a sense of inevitability about the withdrawal of Iraq from the Baghdad Pact which took away any great feeling of shock when the event was announced on Tuesday. Ever since the revolt last July, which was aimed against King Faisal and Premier Nuri as-Said, who led Iraq into the agreement, the country has remained aloof.
SKI SKETCH: Lee Berman, the happy-go-lucky director of activities at the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, is happy with his progress as a skier this year. He claims that he has improved 300 per cent.
Banton L. Wyckoff changed his plea yesterday from guilty to not guilty to seventeen violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law at 27 West 118th Street.

THE foyer is one of the most important rooms in the house. It not only is responsible for creating a warm, welcoming atmosphere, but also reflects the taste of the homeowner and gets the tone of her house. Here are some tips for making the foyer an inviting and comfortable area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Jack L. Warner was voted the Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award last night by a unanimous ballot of the board of governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

A warning broadcast by the Philadelphia police against eating poisoned fluke or flounder caused widespread confusion in at least six states last night. It followed the death Tuesday night of a small boy in southern New Jersey after he had eaten fish that had been treated with a poison in the handling process.
Anthony "Tough Tony" Anastasia, Brooklyn waterfront leader, met another attack yesterday from one of the locals in his union complex.
QUEBEC, March 25 (AP) -The Devlin sisters from Baltimore, Judy and Sue, swept into the women's singles quarter finals in the Canadian badminton championships today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -President Eisenhower said today that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles would be used "in some capacity" as long as he feels physically capable of working. [Question 21, Pg 12.]
WASHINGTON, March 25 -Senator Jacob K. Javits announced today that he would not oppose the confirmation of Henry J. Friendly and Lloyd F. MacMahon of New York as Federal judges.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Administration sent Congress today its proposal to ease Alaska's transition into statehood.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- The Government will announce approval tomorrow of a new vaccine providing protection against polio, diphtheria, whooping cough and tetanus, it was learned tonight.

The Railway Express Agency, sentenced to death late last year when the New York Central Railroad announced that it would pull out of the express business on Jan. 1, 1960, appears to be in line for a reprieve.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- The Farm Bureau Federation, this country's largest farm organization, has been taken out of the International Federation of Agricultural Producers, Charles B. Shuman, Farm Bureau president, announced today.
The Cerro de Pasco Corporation acquired the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation yesterday, following approval of the transaction by stockholders of both companies at separate meetings here.

LONDON, March 25 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today the West must maintain a position "in regard to West Berlin" that would permit "the 2,250,000 inhabitants to live the life of their own choice."

The Bank of Montreal has contracted to sell its property at 64 Wall and 68 Wall Street to an investing client of Harvey L. Levine of Newmark Co., brokers. The bank occupies the main-floor store and basement and has leased new quarters in 2 Wall Street.

HARTFORD, March 25 (AP) -- The Connecticut Public Utilities Commission said today that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was delaying needed repair work on some of its equipment and lines.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -President Eisenhower offered a cryptic comment today about the possible Democratic Presidential candidacy of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas in 1960.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Senate voted final approval tonight of a bill authorizing Westchester County to impose a tax of 5 per cent on admissions at Yonkers Raceway.

PARIS, March 25 -- President Charles de Gaulle set forth today his own ideas of what a summit conference should seek. He accepted French participation in a summit meeting that offered real chances of East-West agreement without the sacrifice of basic Western positions on Berlin and Germany.
Mediation sessions between ten New York newspapers and the printers union will be resumed today.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The index of consumer prices in United States cities dropped 0.1 per cent between mid-January and mid-February, thanks to food items.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 25 -- Gov. Michael V. DiSalle's crusade to abolish capital punishment in Ohio received a major setback today. A house judiciary committee defeated two bills and a compromise measure that would have affected the imposition of the death penalty.

BONN, Germany, March 25 -Prime Minister Harold Macmillan sent a personal message to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today seeking to bridge a new and apparently serious breach between Britain and West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The Department of Agriculture was told today that it permitted exporters to reap "windfall profits" on the sale of surplus Government cotton abroad.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices climbed again today with advances running to as much as 50 cents a hundred pounds on weights under 230 pounds, which were in scarce supply.

Mayor Wagner's proposed 1959-60 expense budget contains pay rises of $200 for each of the city's uniformed policemen, firemen and correction officers. There is a small additional percentage increase for those in supervisory posts. The $200 increases will be one-third less than planned.

New York Hospital was picketed yesterday for twelve hours by a teamsters local that is attempting to organize non-professional employes of voluntary hospitals. As a result, drivers of ten trucks loaded with hospital supplies refused to make deliveries.

Only seven performances will represent the length of the New York career of "A Desert Incident." Written by Pearl S. Buck, recipient of the Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes, the drama was appraised by the critics on Tuesday night at the John Golden, where it will close Saturday night.

Lincoln Kirstein, director of the New York City Ballet, has announced that Martha Graham, the American modern dancer, will be associated with George Balanchine, artistic director of the ballet company, in the creation of a new work for the company's spring season. The 1959 session of the New York Legislature was the most controversial of recent years, made so by the determination of a newly elected Governor to start the state back to a genuinely balanced budget regardless of its effect on his political fortunes. Governor Rockefeller succeeded in this momentous test of leadership, resisting all compromise of basic principle, while yielding to sensible correction and amendment of detail.
American exporters were urged yesterday to toughen their selling methods in order to meet aggressive foreign competition in world markets.

PORT SAID, United Arab Republic, March 25 (Reuters) -United Arab Republic authorities held up today the Greek freighter Nicolas Kairis, bound from Haifa, Israel, to Hong Kong with 9,600 tons of cement and steel scrap.

LIMA, Peru, March 18 -- Development of the Acari iron ore mine in the Andean foothills some 350 miles south of Lima and thirty-five miles from the port of San Juan, is proceeding rapidly. According to the present construction schedule, Peru's second major iron ore producer will be put into operation within the next six months.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 25 -Nassau County's over-all water resources are believed to be adequate beyond the year 1980, according to an engineering report made public today.

CHARLES HAIGHT made a triumphant return to Altman's this week through a Palladium arch. The former head of the store's decorating department appeared surrounded by the classical furniture designs he has long dreamed of and is now creating.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26 -- Creation of a national oil company is in the general program of the present Venezuelan Administration. He is for cooperation among nations but against what is called "integration." This applies to the North Atlantic alliance, the movement for European economic and political union, Algeria and the former French empire, now called the French Overseas Community.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 (UPI) -- Three United States reporters were expelled from Baghdad, Iraq, on less than twelve hours notice today.
The hiring of young men and women to do clerical work and relieve policemen for patrol duty is being considered by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Eisenhower nominated Stuart Rothman of St. Paul, Minn., today to be general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $75,000,000 to $600,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves increased $67,000,000 to $431,000,000.

Two works by Boris Pasternak, the only ones among his prose writings that he wants to see published today, will be issued next Friday by Pantheon Books. The two will compose a volume titled "I Remember." The first is an autobiographical sketch finished in 1957 after "Doctor Zhivago" was completed.
LONDON, March 26 -- Industrials moved irregularly in the stock market today with minor losses narrowly outnumbering gains.

Today's new film is "The Sound and the Fury," a Twentieth Century-Fox color version of the novel by William Faulkner, starring Yul Brynner, Joanne Woodward and Margaret Leighton, at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 26 -- The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America condemned today "any attempt to use the antitrust laws as weapons for the destruction of the hard-won labor standards."

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, March 26 -- Flags flew at half-staff today and public buildings were draped with black crepe by order of Premier Joseph R. Smallwood in protest against the Federal Government's interpretation of the terms of union of Newfoundland with Canada.
Henry Feinstein, the labor leader whose drive to organize the city's police kicked up a storm of protest, is planning to quit his $8,500-a-year job in the Manhattan Borough President's office.

A patroness committee has been formed for the Bal des Berceaux, which will be held in the St. Regis Roof next Friday for the benefit of the Refuge des Petits at Hyeres, France, and the Foster Parents Plan's work in France. Mrs. Leonard B. Smith, honorary chairman of the Committee of French-American Wives, sponsor for the fete, heads the new committee.

Songs by a glee club comprising about twenty-five wheelchair patients will serve to highlight the work of the Musicians Emergency Fund and its Hospitalized Veterans Service at its twentieth annual luncheon on April 30.
William H. Olsen is back enjoying his beloved Coney Island rides for the twentieth year.
A lion was loose for ten tense minutes in Madison Square Garden last night during a dress rehearsal of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Morgan S. Kaufman, former Scranton lawyer who was disbarred sixteen years ago, was reinstated today by the seven members of the United States District Court here.

HALIFAX, N. S., March 26 (Canadian Press) -- A British salvage ship operating in the Gulf of St. Lawrence last summer broke the world's recognized practical diving record by 400 feet, it was reported today.

Lawrence and Sandor Mark, realty investors and builders, have purchased a plot of land at Broadway and West 251st Street, opposite the parade ground at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. They plan a five-story motel on the property.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- An inter - American working group has completed a set of economic proposals to lay before the second session of the Committee of Twenty-One in Buenos Aires next month.
The Liberal party said yesterday that much of the action and inaction at the 1959 legislative session had demonstrated the need for reapportionment and a split session in the Legislature.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Railroads serving the ports of New Orleans and Greater Baton Rouge were permitted today to reject higher port charges for freight shipped across their piers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 26 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers squandered a 19-point lead, then came from behind tonight and defeated the St. Louis Hawks, 108 -- 98, in the National Basketball Association's Western Division play-offs. The four-of-seven series now stands at two games apiece.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Only one hurdle -- the Governor's signature -- stood in the way today of implementing a bipartisan deal for the division of five new judgeships in Brooklyn.
More than a touch of temperament appears to be plaguing the hit Broadway play "A Touch of the Poet."
PARIS, March 26 -- Most commentators here assessed the French note delivered to the Soviet Union today as perhaps the firmest of the Western messages sent to the Kremlin.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Stuart Rothman, who was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, has a reputation for "all work and no play."
Salary increases of about $200 annually may be in store for the city's 40,000 teachers, it was indicated yesterday. However, Board of Education sources emphasized that the amount was not yet fixed.
THE New York Philharmonic, which is interlacing a six-week Handel festival of its own through the larger one of New York City, began its particular homage to the composer last night at Carnegie Hall.
The market for prime fixed-income investments went through the motions of a business day yesterday, but the results added up to little more than a holiday overture to the Easter weekend.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Union labor's chief spokesman accused James P. Mitchell, the Secretary of Labor, today of misrepresenting, in a "reprehensible" way, an economic report to justify his opposition to a rise in the Federal minimum wage.
The Western powers have now agreed formally to the Soviet Union's proposal for a summit meeting, but on condition that a preceding foreign ministers' conference paves a promising way to it.

WINTER PARK, Colo., March 26 (UPI) -- Marvin Melville of the University of Utah negotiated a sixty-five-gate course in 119 seconds today to win the slalom event in the National Collegiate ski championships.
A 5,000-gallon water tank, its supports reportedly weakened by corrosion, plunged through three stories of a six-story Manhattan loft building yesterday. Eleven persons were injured, two seriously.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Treasury announced tonight the results of bidding for its new issue of 289-day bills.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 26 -- The halting of foreign-owned freighters attempting to carry Israeli cargoes through the Suez Canal has punctuated a serious economic problem for Israel.
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a note today from Britain to the Soviet Union on a summit conference:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 -- Gov. Michael V. DiSalle disputed inferences today that he was "turning on labor" because of his support for a labor reform bill in the Ohio Legislature.
Approval of regatta dates constituted the main business of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound and its junior affiliate at their spring meetings in the New York Yacht Club yesterday.
Directors of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation yesterday declared a 3 per cent stock dividend.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- West Germany objected today, more in sorrow than in anger, to the apparent recognition by President Charles de Gaulle of France of the Oder-Neisse line as Germany's permanent eastern frontier.
James A. Lundy, chairman of the Public Service Commission, announced today that new automatic devices had been ordered installed at seven railroad crossings in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The United States and Bulgaria have decided to renew diplomatic relations after a lapse of nine years. An announcement is to be made here at 11 A. M. tomorrow.
Grover Cleveland was President of the United States and the events that were to lead to the Spanish-American War were fomenting when Harry Seixas saw his first six-day bicycle race.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters was described yesterday as the most powerful institution in the country -- next to the Federal Government.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Congress recessed today for its Easter vacation amid signs of growing friction with the Eisenhower Administration over the issue of Federal spending.
ONE savory way to make use of pork, which is now plentiful, is in a sweet and pungent dish copied from the Chinese.
Field notes of the Lewis and Clark expedition into the American West in 1803-05 have been turned over to an heir of John Henry Hammond, a Civil War general in whose desk they were found.

The question Mayor Wagner will face when he returns from his short vacation is whether he would rather impose taxes that are distasteful to him politically or do an injustice through diminished pay increases to civil servants including policemen, firemen and public school teachers.

Lumber production last week aggregated 249,119 board feet compared with 249,425 a week earlier, according to reports wired to The New York Times by regional associations. Production was 8.9 per cent higher than the level of a year ago, shipments were up 17 per cent and orders gained 11.3 per cent over the 1958 week.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson explained today that a special bill passed by the Legislature in its closing hours gave him no unwarranted benefits. The bill permitted him to continue as a contributing member of the Legislative Retirement Program.

PIERMONT, N. Y., March 26 -- Police Chief John P. Smith resigned today after having been questioned by state and Rockland County authorities about a rustic gambling den they raided in this village last night. The raid was made without his knowledge.

Directors of Lane Bryant, Inc., voted an extra dividend of 10 per cent in stock yesterday. It will be payable May 10 at the rate of one common share for each ten shares held. The company, which paid its regular quarterly cash dividend of 30 cents on March 2, distributed no stock dividend last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- The Commission on Human Rights heard an oral report today on the progress of desegregation in the United States.
The General Dynamics Corporation earned $36,729,113 last year on sales of $1,511,456,261.

Swift action in tracing 1,800 pounds of poisoned fish that were sold by a Philadelphia wholesaler Tuesday ended a six-state scare yesterday after more than 200 consumers had gone to hospitals for emergency treatment.
LONDON, March 26 -- The Labor party won a key by-election for a House of Commons seat today with a larger majority than it obtained in the 1955 general election.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- This booming metropolis is a refuge for what folks hereabouts euphemistically call "senior citizens." Not far from the shuffle-board pits and the checker dens, a couple of baseball seniors were huddled the other day. Because he's such an unpretentious and friendly person, Stan Musial always acts as a welcoming committee for all visiting firemen.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Following are excerpts from the report on the control of radiation hazards prepared by the National Advisory Committee on Radiation for the Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service:
Almost a ritual with New Yorkers of a certain age at this season of the year is a nostalgic apostrophe to the authenticity of a circus under canvas.

Studebaker-Packard Corporation, independent auto producer, experienced a loss of $13,390,937 last year, compared with one of $11,135,108 in 1957. Sales in the respective years were $180,657,592 and $213,203,741.

The pre-dawn collision of the Santa Rosa and the Valchem yesterday took place along one of the world's busiest stretches of ocean highway -- the New Jersey coast between the Hudson and Delaware Rivers.
The Crucifixion of Jesus will be marked today, Good Friday, at solemn services in churches of the city.
The Bank of Montreal has reported that Canadian business plans $8,300,000,000 of capital expenditures this year, or about 1 per cent less than was spent in 1958.
A $500,000 life insurance policy has been paid after being in force only six days. Premium payments of $258.40 had been made.
Business borrowing at the larger New York City banks declined $72,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, following usual quarterly increase to cover corporate tax payments.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 26 -- Connecticut state policemen are going to the aid of residents near the Connecticut Turnpike who think some Diesel trucks are too noisy.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Western Big Three formally invited the Soviet Union today to join them at a foreign ministers' conference to discuss Germany and to arrange a summit meeting.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 26 -- Michigan State's Bill Steuart retained the 1,500-meter freestyle title today as the thirty-sixth annual National Collegiate swimming championships opened in Cornell University's Teagle Hall pool.

MECHANICVILLE, N. Y., March 26 (AP) -- A free-for-all fight broke out in the streets tonight as plant officials and salaried workers tried to break through 200 pickets massed at the struck West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company plant.
The last straw available to former passengers on New York Central Railroad ferryboats to Weehawken floated away yesterday.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 26 (UPI) -- Eddie Haas, a rookie outfielder of the Milwaukee Braves, suffered a broken right ankle today as the National League champions lost an exhibition to the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 3.
A SYMPATHETIC and often perceptive study of a young man in trouble was shown last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Rockefeller hinted strongly today that he planned to veto a bill that would revise the Brooklyn approach for the Narrows Bridge to Staten Island.
In India I was asked the same question again and again: "Why are you sending Pakistan arms which will be used against us?"
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 26 -- President Chiang Kai-shek told Tibetans today that they would have the right to choose their political future when the Nationalists reconquered the Chinese mainland.
Once again the Greyhound Corporation is trying to get the city to approve its application to enlarge its Thirty-fourth Street bus terminal east of Eighth Avenue.
JONES BEACH, L. I., March 26 -- A new bathing area and a mile-long protective jetty, an enlarged yacht basin and an addition to the ocean drive are being rushed to completion at Jones Beach.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 26 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower began a long Easter weekend here today by playing his first round of golf in four months.
The sleek new cruise ship Santa Rosa, New York-bound from the Caribbean, with 512 persons aboard, knifed into the tanker Valchem about 3 A. M. yesterday twenty-two miles off Atlantic City.

One wishes that President de Gaulle of France would give press conferences often. It has been a long time since any Western statesman spoke with such wisdom, serenity, common sense and high idealism. Whatever subject General de Gaulle touched upon he illuminated -- the cold war, Germany, Algeria, internal politics and economics.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- The fourth successive advance in butcher hog prices this week took the top to $17.25 a hundredweight today, the highest in almost two weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A Government advisory committee recommended today that "ultimate authority" in protecting the public from radiation be transferred immediately from the Atomic Energy Commission to the Public Health Service.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- William Diddel of Indianapolis, 75, scored his third upset in the American Seniors Golf Association tournament today and reached the semi-final round.
For Othmar H. Ammann, one of the great bridge builders of this century, old age does not spell withdrawal or inactivity.
ROME, March 26 -- Negro intellectuals from Africa and the Western Hemisphere opened a cultural congress today to assess the "essentials in the life and soul of Negroes."

" LOOKING back on my childhood," a mother reminisced the other day, "I see that every holiday had a mood and feeling of its own. Christmas was excitement, tension and mystery. Its colors were sharp and bright, its smells pungent and spicy. The Fourth of July was lively, fast-moving, noisy and gay -- a mixture of hot dogs, sand, sunburn and sparklers.
PARIS, March 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a note today from France to the Soviet Union:

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) -- Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that the race for his party's 1960 Presidential nomination would continue right up to the time of the convention next year.

MONTREAL, March 26 (UPI) -- The Beliveau - Moore - Bonin line -- the hottest combination in hockey -- figured in all five goals as the Montreal Canadiens downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 1, tonight to take a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup semi-final play-offs.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Models of the satellite capsules that will eventually carry man into space have successfully passed a series of preliminary flight tests, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The United Electrical Workers accused two big manufacturers today of destroying more than 700 American job opportunities by deliberately overbidding on a Tennessee Valley Authority turbo-generator contract.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts turned down a request today to delay the trial of Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications commissioner, on charges of bribery and conspiracy in the Miami television Channel 10 case.
Soviet mathematicians have made great progress in information theory and cybernetics, two mathematical studies that were condemned as not Marxist a few years ago.

A cocktail party will be given by Mrs. L. Mitchell Paine at her home here next Thursday for the newly formed junior committee that is assisting with plans for a dinner party to be held in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza before the April 8 performance of "Tall Story" at the Belasco Theatre.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- The National Science Foundation announced plans today for a major effort this summer to interest talented high school youths in scientific and engineering careers.
LONDON, March 26 -- Britain is convinced that the Soviet Union's primary objective in the forthcoming round of East-West negotiations will be to maintain the division of Europe between East and West.

ABILENE, Tex., March 26 (AP) -- Bill Alley of Kansas hurled the javelin 258 feet 4 inches today, bettering the National Collegiate record, in the first Abilene Christian College invitation track and field meet.

Sylvan Levin will make his debut with the New York City Opera Company as conductor of the world premiere of Hugo Weisgall's opera, "Six Characters in Search of an Author," on Sunday evening, April 26.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Rockefeller described himself today as highly pleased "with the very constructive" program approved by the 1959 Legislature, which adjourned for the year at 3:57 A. M. today.
A study made by a college professor indicates that while advertising expenditures have risen in this country, they have fallen as a percentage of national income.

The Metropolitan Opera will have the longest subscription season in its history next year. The 1959-60 season, which will run for twenty-five weeks, will open on Monday, Oct. 26, and close on Saturday, April 16.
A man described as a narcotics addict eluded arrest in Brooklyn yesterday by disarming a Treasury agent and using him as a shield.

CINCINNATI, March 26 -- Winners in the finals of the second annual American Opera Auditions were announced today. The organization is financed through a grant made by Hulbert Taft Jr., president of Cincinnati Radio, Inc.
TOK JUNCTION, Alaska, March 26 (AP) -- The last miles were happy ones for the Michigan '59'ers as they rolled through this highway junction today.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 26 -- Reginald Stephen Garfield Todd made it plain today that his new Central Africa party intended to challenge the ruling United Federal party on all possible fronts.

DETROIT, March 27 (AP) -Ward's automotive reports said today a sudden upsurge in new car sales developed in mid-March. It reported retail deliveries for March 11 to 20 averaged 19,420 units daily, for the best mid-month sales rate since June 11 to 20 of 1957.

Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez, ex-dictator of Venezuela, has overstayed his welcome. The District Director of the Immigration Service in Miami notified the ex-President on March 13 that he must leave the country by April 15.

THE contemporary Italian abstract sculptor Luciano Minguzzi, showing new work at the Catherine Viviano Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, is one of the many artists who have restored the prestige of Italian art in the post-war years.
Shortly after the first big bombardment of Quemoy last August an American officer, just back from the beleaguered island, walked into a Red Cross field office on Taiwan.

KUALA LUMPUR, Mayala, Saturday, March 28 -- The Government of Malaya accused the Chinese and other foreign Communist parties today of helping the Malayan Communist party in a campaign to gain control of the country by long-term subversion.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 27 (UPI) -- The Air Force announced today that it had recovered a data capsule ejected from a Thor missile nose cone during a successful flight last night.

The Brierfield Hotel Corporation has sold a twenty-one-year lease on the fifteen-story Brierfield Hotel at 215 West Eighty-third Street to an investing client of E. A. Knight Real Estate, Inc., broker in the deal. The hotel, containing 120 rooms, occupies a plot 74 by 102 feet adjoining Loew's Eighty-third Street Theatre at the northeast corner of Broadway and Eighty-third Street.

Tenants in three buildings managed by Banton L. Wyckoff said yesterday that there had been no let-up in the collection of their rents, although illegal conditions in the tenements had not been corrected.

MOSCOW, March 27 -Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has declared that reunification of Germany "would be unrealistic today." He has urged the East Germans to "make no haste" toward uniting the two Germanys.

The new capital, market in the week now closing was preoccupied with the Treasury's $4,000,000,000 cash borrowing. With the resumption of business after the Easter week-end the interest of the investment community is slated to switch to a wide variety of offerings sponsored by private corporations and local governments.
A remodeled Loew's State, characterized by modern lines in glass, bronze and walnut, will open to the public tonight with the premiere of "Some Like It Hot."
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The outer belt of radiation girdling the earth is created by spurts of hot, energetic gas spurting out from the sun, scientists concluded today.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 24 -- A sentimental little Negro song made into a neighborly game by a couple in Dayton, Ohio, before World War I has been making people happy all over Africa.
DETROIT, March 27 -- Federal Judge Thomas P. Thornton ruled today that the reorganization proceedings involving the F. L. Jacobs Company should be continued here under the jurisdiction of his court.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 27 (UPI) -- Stockholders in Gruen Industries, Inc., approved yesterday a long-term $1,500,000 convertible-note issue to provide working capital for the company.
BUYING an Easter bonnet is a family affair at the Cross County Center in Westchester.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- More than 100 members of the American Kalmuck community demonstrated at the United Nations today against the "bloody terror carried on by the Chinese Communists against the people of Tibet."
Leaders in labor, politics, medicine and religion joined the East Harlem Protestant Parish yesterday to protest to Mayor Wagner the lack of city facilities to treat narcotics addicts.

HUNTING Easter eggs around town should present no great problem. But finders cannot be keepers, except in some cases and for a price. The kind the Easter rabbit leaves for children to find is a scarce commodity in the steel and concrete of New York.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 27 (AP) -- The speech President Eisenhower will make here next week was described today by James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, as an important one on the international situation.

DORTMUND, Germany, March 27 (AP) -- Two New Yorkers, Bernard Bukiet and Robert Gusikoff, won three of four matches each today but the United States men's team gained only a split in the first two rounds of the world table tennis championship.
The third chapter, perhaps the final one, unfolded yesterday for the embattled Broadway stage hit, "A Touch of the Poet."

HARGEISA, British Somaliland, March 27 (Reuters) -- Supporters of the moderate National United Front have won seven of the thirteen seats for elected members in the Legislative Council in British Somaliland's first general election.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that all normal radio and television broadcasting would go off the air for thirty minutes on Friday, April 17, in connection with a Civil Defense air raid drill.
Federal and city officials have been in consultation to see whether there is any basis for legal action against the original sponsors of the Pratt Institute Title I project in Brooklyn.

BOWIE, Md., March 27 (AP) -Vertex, a 5-year-old son of The Rhymer, is a solid choice to win his second $100,000 added race on successive Saturdays when he goes out tomorrow for the John B. Campbell Memorial Handicap.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that if there were any discriminatory practices within the State Employment Service they would be "terminated immediately." Mr. Rockefeller was reacting to press reports that the service had taken care not to send Negro applicants to employers who had said they would not hire them.

WHITE PLAINS, March 27 -- Speed in the development of the new Valhalla campus of the Westchester Community College was asked today by the Board of Trustees. The plea was filed with elected county officials.
NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 (UPI) -- Grant Withers, the actor, was found dead tonight in his apartment. The police said he left a note saying he took his own life.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The first cooperative project in international medicine between a United States Government agency and Medico, a nonprofit organization of private physicians, got under way today. It had been urgently requested by the Government of Vietnam.

ROME, March 27 -- Italy canceled tonight an order barring two Austrian politicians from her territory. The move was avowedly aimed at easing the tension between Rome and Vienna over the Alpine border region of Upper Adige, or South Tyrol.
Roy Campanella has suggested that the major league baseball players' pension fund "rates some kind of revision to cover cases like mine."

United States diplomatic relations with Bulgaria were broken off in the period of intense Stalinist terror in that country, when fantastic charges of espionage were directed by the Bulgarian regime against our Ambassador in Sofia and his subordinates. Those charges have now been withdrawn and the United States Government has decided to resume diplomatic relations with Sofia.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- Maritime workers screened off the waterfront as security risks during the Korean war were barred by a court ruling today from recovering lost wages from the Federal Government.

Final arrangements are being made for the benefit preview of "Art U. S. A." next Friday at the New York Coliseum. Proceeds of the event, which will be followed by a champagne supper there, will aid the American Ballet Theatre.

The report by Drs. Granville Larimore and Henry Brill to Governor Rockefeller on the British system of handling drug addiction, as described in The New York Times of March 9, has a number of puzzling aspects to anyone acquainted with the British and American drug problems.
A well-rested Mayor Wagner will return from his Bermuda vacation Monday night, ready to defend his proposed "austerity" budget of more than $2,000,000,000 against a spreading barrage of criticism.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 27 -The greatest purge in the Arab world has swept Iraq, with the Communists suppressing all opposition in a ruthless drive.
NEWARK, March 27 -- The Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency has approved preliminary plans for $34,871,283 in public housing projects in Newark.
BOSTON, March 27 -- The American Bar Association undertook tonight a search for leadership in world peace through law.
Dawn services tomorrow will begin the observance of Easter, highest and most joyous day of the Christian calendar.

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 27 (UPI) -- Eastern Kentucky coal operators and United Mine Workers officials came out of a mediation meeting with Gov. A. B. Chandler today with an agreement to arrange further talks with international union officers in Washington.
Geoffrey Atkins won the amateur racquets championship of the United States for the fourth time yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Nineteen government officials from a dozen Asian countries will receive an intensive two-month-course in the practical techniques of stimulating foreign trade beginning next Monday in Tokyo. The objective is to aid them in expanding the export volume of their countries to earn more foreign exchange.
Sales and earnings of the American Home Products Corporation last year were the largest in its history, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
Service on twenty commuter trains will be consolidated by the New York Central Railroad for "efficiency" when the tables for Daylight Saving Time go into effect April 26.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Operators of 7.2 per cent of the nation's cotton farms have accepted a Government offer of the right to grow more cotton but receive lower price supports.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The State Department expressed approval today of the action of the Immigration Service in ordering Maj. Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez, exiled Venezuelan dictator, to leave the United States by April 15. Former President Perez Jimenez, his wife and four children have been living at Miami Beach a year.

Seven years ago Henry Viscardi Jr., who is legless, formed a company of disabled persons to prove that "the disabled can work and produce efficiently." In "Give Us the Tools," he tells of the formation of the company that has developed into an organization with 375 "unemployables" doing more than $2,000,000 worth of business in the electronic assembly field.
A controversy developed among officials yesterday over the gambling raid carried out Wednesday night at Piermont, N. Y., without the knowledge of the village's police chief.
WINTER PARK, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- Dave Koblentz pitched Ohio State to its sixth straight victory in the Rollins College baseball tourney today. The Buckeyes defeated New York University, 4 -- 2.

The seventy-second international six-day bicycle race at the 102d Engineers Armory comes to a close tonight and those close to the sport are convinced that they have been witnessing one of the greatest series of thefts since the days of Jesse James.
A teen-ager will be ordained a rabbi tomorrow.
A system for wiping out staphylococcus and other drug-resistant infections in hospitals was reported by a Columbia University physician yesterday.

WINTER PARK, Colo., March 27 (AP) -- Utah's Marvin Melville and Clarence Servold, a 30-year-old Denver University junior, claimed individual titles today as Colorado surged into the team lead in the sixth National Collegiate ski championship.
The American Jewish Congress charged the State Legislature yesterday with "a shocking abandonment of responsibility in the face of critical needs for protecting civil rights and liberties."

LONDON, March 27 (UPI) -Six months of gruelling training by eighteen men reaches its climax tomorrow when the eight-oared shells of the Oxford and Cambridge Universities meet in the 105th annual boat race on London's River Thames.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 27 -- Three adventurous boys were rescued from a drifting rowboat in Long Island Sound off Ship-pan Point here today.

An agreement has been reached for the purchase by All-State Properties, Inc., of the controlling interest in the Montauk Beach Company, owner of a large residential and resort area on the eastern tip of Long Island.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 27 -With sophomores setting the pace, this country's resurgent swimmers made sweeping revisions of the record tables tonight in the first full session of the thirty-sixth annual National Collegiate championships.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -The political brain behind young King Hussein of Jordan is a 60-year-old Palestinian named Samir el-Rifai.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, March 27 -- Israel will continue her efforts to obtain a firm commitment from the United Arab Republic that foreign-owned vessels carrying Israeli cargoes will not be denied passage through the Suez Canal, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 27 (AP) -- New legal complications, including a $750,000 damage suit charging slander, today postponed until April 24 the United Industrial Corporation's annual stockholders' meeting.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 27 -- A safety device on the New Haven Railroad's westbound approach to an open drawbridge over Cos Cob harbor derailed a local passenger train this morning.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- The top price on the butcher hog market reached a two-month high today after five successive days of advances. The market was mostly 25 cents a hundred pounds higher. with a top of $17.50, the first time a price that high had been paid since Jan. 27.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 27 -- The allocation of ten ministries between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes was announced tonight. Together with the Greek Cypriote President and the Turkish Vice President, the ministers will form the provisional government of Cyprus working in conjunction with the Governor, Sir Hugh Foot, and members of the Executive Council.

ABOUT eighteen pounds of facts and opinions about hunting and fishing, a pretty fair proportion of them bearing on something or other, have come in from odd sources recently and there is no particular reason to keep them secret. For example:
PARIS, March 27 -- The dispute stirred by President Charles de Gaulle's implied recognition of the Oder-Neisse line as Germany's eastern border is regarded philosophically in French circles.
NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- The awkward dilemma of the Indian Government over the rebellion in neighboring Tibet grows more awkward by the hour.
BOSTON, March 27 (AP) -The New England Council issued the following reports on ski conditions today along with the weather forecast for New England:
YONKERS, March 27 -Weatherwise, it was hardly a night for anyone to be out, but the trotters and pacers were in business at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
ATLANTA, March 27 (UPI) -- The Druid Hills Presbyterian Church here, previously restricted to whites, has voted to admit Negroes to its services on a segregated basis.
Eight American and two Canadian naval vessels will visit here next week to mark the tenth anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The treaty was signed on April 4, 1949.

" THERE are only two or three human stories," Willa Cather once said, "and they go on repeating themselves as fiercely as if they had never happened before." That's a conversation stopper, isn't it? If, after some reflection, we tried to name just two stories that fitted Miss Cather's extraordinarily strict limit, we might choose, no doubt, "Cinderella" and "Jack the Giant Killer."

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Two experts said today that the Soviet Union was making rapid strides in weather control and meteorology in general. They warned that while the United States was ahead now, there was danger that this country could fall behind.
JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, March 27 (AP) -- Pilgrims retraced the journey of Jesus to Calvary in prayerful procession today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Chadbourn Gotham, Inc., of Charlotte, N. C., registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission today an offering to its stockholders of $3,000,000 of convertible subordinated debentures, due April 1, 1971.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Type B influenza has been identified in outbreaks of respiratory infections in eleven states and the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UPI) -- A Congressional leader in the atomic energy field gave a skeptical reception today to a proposal that responsibility for protecting the nation from radiation be transferred from the Atomic Energy Commission to the Public Health Service.

BEIRUT, March 27 (AP) -- Winston Burdett of the Columbia Broadcasting System said on arrival here yesterday that! Baghdad prisons were filled "until there is no mere room in them for al_:the political detainees."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The nuclear submarine Skate has made a second trip to the North Pole, this time in the darkness and cold of the Arctic winter. ALBANY, March 27 -- For the first time in years, the Legislature has decided to limit rather than expand its off-season investigating and spending.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Exports were off substantially again in February, the Department of Commerce reported today.

KALIMPONG, India, March 27 -- The final crushing of the Lhasa phase of the Tibetan revolt was reported here tonight.

LONDON, March 26 -- A 6-year-old girl jumped down a flight of stairs and twisted her ankle. She was taken to a brusque, hurried physician in the neighborhood. Her ankle was examined and bandaged and she was given a prescription for the replacement of the bandage.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's memory lapsed on the subject of a Soviet peace treaty with East Germany this week. A quick clarification from the White House failed to head off comment from the Soviet Union.
