WASHINGTON, March 28 -At the State Department and along embassy row, there is one big subject of conversation and speculation these days -- a summit conference. One high official pretty well summed up the feeling that prevails when he said the odds favored such an East-West meeting "but I wouldn't even try to say what the odds are."
BONN, Germany, March 22 -West Germany will be ready this year to turn into an atomic military power overnight.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- Moscow views the Western agreement to a summit meeting on Germany as a triumph of Soviet diplomacy. But fears are being expressed in advance that the Western terms for such talks are designed to complicate the work of the heads of government or wreck it altogether.
The picture of the spaceman on the March 1 cover of your magazine will, in my opinion, contribute greatly toward the sale of democracy.

WHETHER people read books forward or backward is of little matter. As far as I am concerned, if they read books at all, they are heading in the right direction. In order to do justice to a good piece of writing, it should be read "forward and backward" -- in that sequence.

The busy time for a Governor of New York State is the first three months of the year when the Legislature is in session. For the rest of the year his administrative duties are relatively light. He is free to make speeches, travel and pursue his Presidential ambitions, if any.

THE provision of sufficient entertainment to attract and please everyone during this usually benign and kindly period of the Easter holidays is a task that the motion-picture people are not up to every year.

EVERY time I read Langston Hughes I am amazed all over again by his genuine gifts -- and depressed that he has done so little with them. A real discussion of his work demands more space than I have here, but this book contains a great deal which a more disciplined poet would have thrown into the waste-basket (almost all of the last section, for example).

THAT the whole non-Western world is in the grip of violent change no one would now deny. But the analyses of this change tend to stress heavily its economic and technological aspects -- the need for capital, the drive for modernization, the transition from subsistence to a dynamic economy.
COS COB, Conn., March 28 (AP) -- The New Haven Railroad has taken out of service the engineer of a passenger train that had to be derailed to keep it from plunging into the Mianus River yesterday.

THE 100th season of Shakespeare's plays at Shakespeare's birthplace is obviously a milestone, but the season that opens at the Memorial Theatre, Stratford-on-Avon, on April 7 would be notable whatever its chronology.
The Children's Zoo in Bronx Park opened yesterday for its nineteenth season and a frosty opening it was.
A Federal appropriation of more than 50 per cent above current budget proposals for refugee relief programs was recommended this week to President Eisenhower.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 28 (AP) -- Art Wall, worried over his young son's measles attack, shot eight birdies today. and took a four-stroke lead after thirty-six holes in the 15,000 Azalea open golf tournament.

For most persons on the shores of the Great Lakes spring comes with the first crocus and the first robin. For a winter-bound and restless minority -- 12,000 mariners -- it comes with the breaking up of the ice in Lake Superior.
Diagrams, also, can be sinners. The one with Mr. Davis' article exemplifies the cardinal sin of a deceptive pictograph.
The president of the nation's largest copper-producing company believes that:
Mr. Neuberger, junior United States Senator from Oregon, is a native son of that state and the author of many books and articles about its wonders.

TODAY, as in the recent case of Soviet Deputy Premier Anastas Mikoyan, one of the first sightseeing stops for prominent foreign visitors is a big new supermarket near Washington. To the rest of the world, the supermarket has become a gaudy symbol of American life, gawked at in wonderment -- and some bewilderment, too -- until its appeal inspires imitation.
HAVANA, March 28 -- Ernesto de la Fe, a leading Cuban anti-Communist who has been in jail since January, has been accused of involvement in an alleged plot to kill Premier Fidel Castro.

PARIS. BULLFIGHTING was originated on the island of Crete as was the Cretan lyre, the favorite instrument of the ancient Greeks to accompany an amorous song. It is typical of the Cretans that, having contributed to the arts of love and of violent death, they felt there was nothing more to accomplish and have rested on their laurels ever since.

ENGINEERS of the New York State Traffic Commission will turn their radar speed meters on the state's major highways next month in an intensive study of the driving habits of motorists. The purpose of this radar search will be not to halt or arrest motorists or issue tickets but rather to determine just how fast most motorists drive.
Monthly incomes for life of between $33 and $87 are awaiting about 900 disabled persons living in Manhattan.
LONDON, March 28 -- Events at home and abroad have sharply reduced the possibility of a general election in Britain this May, politicians of both major parties agreed today.

THE oriental influence on American decor has reached its "epidemic stage." This was one diagnosis advanced at a recent designers' meeting held to discuss the current impact of the East on Western homes.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -When California's Democrats swept last November's election there were numerous predictions that they would soon be fighting among themselves. Although numerically predominant since 1932 they had long been hamstrung by intramural squabbling.

NORTHEAST AIRLINES has filed an application with the Civil Aeronautics Board for a 25 per cent fare reduction on night coach flights between New York and Miami, and on other such flights between cities on the East Coast.

The murder of Leon Trotsky on Aug. 20, 1940, in Coyoacan, Mexico, by the hand of an agent of Joseph Stalin's secret police, is the subject of this elaborate novel by a one-time member of the exiled Russian leader's secretarial staff.

An anti-Communist uprising in Tibet has brought harsh retaliation from the Chinese Communists occupying the country. The Dalai Lama's Government has been overthrown, he has fled and his rival, the Panchen Lama, has been set up in his place.

BORIS BUGAYEV, who wrote under the pen name of Andrey Biely, died in the Caucasus some twenty-five years ago at the age of 53. His death aroused few comments in the Soviet press, but even the short obituaries could not conceal the fact that Biely had been a leading Russian symbolist and also one of the most fascinating and complex personalities of our century.
APALACHIN, N. Y., March 28 (AP) -- Three heart specialists examined Joseph Barbara Sr. today for nearly two hours at the hilltop home where he entertained sixty hoodlums in 1957.
In its lead editorial of March 22, The Times objects to the official hold-up of scientific reports on the "Argus" nuclear explosions above the atmosphere.
BERLIN, March 18 -- A teenage girl told the official East German youth paper Junge Welt earlier this month that her greatest ambition was to meet Elvis Presley. That did it.

IT is somehow appropriate that the expression "Things are seldom what they seem," from the Gilbert and Sullivan spoof on skimmed milk, originally applied to an item of food. The world of cuisine is stocked with seeming contradictions and cream puffs are a case in point. They are so delicate in texture, so light to the touch, one can scarcely believe that they are among the most easily prepared pastries.

In a wild finish that followed a throttles-open session lasting for the better part of an hour, Fernando Terruzzi and Leandro Faggin of Italy won the seventysecond international sixday bike race last night.

WHITE PLAINS, March 28 -- Remedies for the shortage of housing in Westchester County for low-income and middle-income families will be explored at the first Westchester housing conference May 6 at the Gramatan Hotel in Bronxville.
Efforts to achieve a proposed European Economic Association appear to be making progress, but are still faced by many obstacles.
BALBOA, C. Z., March 28 -Because of the continuing high level of traffic through the Panama Canal, the waterway will increase its pilot force of ninety-seven actively employed men.
PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- A dispute between longshoremen and the Philadelphia Marine Trade Association that had tied up the port here since last Monday was tentatively settled late tonight.
ROME, March 28 -- Pope John XXIII offered a prayer for lasting peace tonight in his first Easter message to the world.

THE English writer William Sansom has given witching delight to readers in his four novels and many brilliant short stories. His latest book. "The Icicle and the Sun," reveals new facets of his talent. It is a lustrous commentary, most of the material originally published in Holiday magazine, on his travels, winter and summer, in the four northern countries: Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Finland.

Now comes the day of Resurrection, and the whole of earth is a temple to the eternal truth of rebirth. We are surrounded by the miracle. Phrase it as we may, here it is, manifest, undeniable. And man participates, one way or another. The Psalmist, knowing the wonder and the glory of these things, sang: "The little hills rejoice on every side.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian sector), March 28 (AP) -- Easter week ceremonies approached a joyous climax today with solemn Holy Saturday rites in the Basilica of the Holy Sepulchre.
YONKERS, March 28 -- The Easter eve parade to the mutuel windows at Yonkers Raceway tonight featured fur-bundled women in woolen knee-length socks and men in hooded, sheeplined parkas.

FOR the jacket of Ross Macdonald's new novel, THE GALTON CASE (Knopf, $3), his publisher has supplied ecstatic blurbing: "a novelist of explosive excitement * * * a rising master of a complex and colorful art * * * speaks to people of all sorts, powerfully and imaginatively, about the basic hopes and dreads of life."
A bandit wearing horn-rimmed spectacles without lenses held up a Gristede Brothers truck in the Bronx last night and escaped with $8,000 in cash and checks.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 28 -The Nationalist Government sent a mission to a secret rendezvous with four leaders of the Tibetan anti-Communist revolt, the Nationalist Central News Agency said today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -Officials of New York State and the Department of Agriculture are planning a new program for this year's fight against the gypsy moth in New York. It was understood the program would be small, compared with the large scale effort, including aerial spraying, over New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania two years ago.

JUNEAU, Alaska, March 28 -- The Alaska state government made arrangements this week for Senate Commerce subcommittee hearings here next Wednesday and Thursday on legislation aimed at curbing Japanese fishing in the North Pacific.

THE increased cost of air travel will be felt two ways -- by both the passenger and the airline -on Wednesday. First, a $15 surcharge ($20 in first class) will be levied on trans-Atlantic jet passenger fares, and an across-the-board increase ranging from $3 to Milan and Rome to $8.90 on flights to Zurich, Frankfort and Copenhagen will be applied to all North Atlantic fares from the gateway cities of New York, Montreal and Boston.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -Tourists who come to Florida this spring by automobile, especially those who have not been here in a year or more, will find travel much easier and pleasanter in several sections of the state, but particularly on U. S. 1 south from the Georgia border. On that highway several section of the four laning job that has been under way for many months has now been completed.

The city's taxicab drivers were asked yesterday not to harass Mayor Wagner tomorrow by staging their proposed anti-taxitax demonstration at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The Mayor, whose Bermuda vacation ends tomorrow, is scheduled to arrive at the airport at 8:32 P. M.

THE book industry usually is a pretty staid elderly party, but recently it has been carrying on as though playing musical chairs. First it was learned that Hiram Haydn, Simon Michael Bessie and Alfred Knopf Jr., of Random House, Harper and Knopf, respectively, would open a publishing firm of their own.

AN American bridge tournament almost never develops into a battle of systems, for the simple reason that nearly all the leading players use substantially the same system. The national tournament at Seattle, Wash., which ended last week, was no exception.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, March 28 -- A young Opposition leader, recently released from jail and bearing scars of police violence, asked today for close control by international public opinion of the Government's promised political reforms.

American merchant marine hull underwriters scraped through a narrow gap between earned premiums and incurred losses in 1958, according to a report by Clifford G. Cornwell, chairman of the American Hull Insurance Syndicate.

During his election campaign last fall, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller pledged that if elected he would make every effort to expand and extend rehabilitation services for the handicapped in the State of New York.
Cash registers in the nation's department stores have been singing a merry tune in recent weeks. Clerks and machines busy on credit billing have been working just as hard.

THE title of Claude Simon's oddly fascinating novel refers to the dry, pervasive mistral "rustling against the walls like a thief wearing espadrilles running along the walls, like time itself passing, irremediably flowing."
WASHINGTON, March 28 -The late Justice Robert H. Jackson said once that Federal legislation affecting business price policies had "vacillated and oscillated" between two opposite theories.
Seats are still available for the May 5 performance of "Sweet Bird of Youth," which will benefit the United World Federalists. The play by Tennessee Williams is at the Martin Beck Theatre.

ABILENE, Tex., March 28 (UPI) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, extolled Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate Democratic leader, tonight as a potential Democratic Presidential nominee. He said the Texan's refusal to seek the office was "good policy."

IN his new book, John H. Herz, Associate Professor of Government at City College, has written a lucid, extremely interesting analysis of the nature of international politics in the present age. His theme is that the age is new, that things are different not merely in degree but in their basic nature and that the study and conduct of international relations must, accordingly, be revised.

Post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples will attend the eleventh annual April Ball on April 17. The fete, a subscription dance, will take place in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East under the direction of Mrs. Audrey M. Winston.
The Handicap Yacht Racing Class re-elected Richard L. Wagner president of the association at the annual meeting at the City Island Yacht Club last night.

IRONICALLY titled, Anthony Bailey's aimless and mildly melodramatic entertainment seems perversely dedicated to the artful dodge of getting nowhere in twenty-one chapters. As a virtuoso exhibition of backstroke technique in a distance event, it is fairly impressive.

THE eucomis or pineapple flower is one of the most interesting and unusual plants I have known. I observed "the beautiful topknot" -- the meaning of the Greek word eucomis -- in my neighbor's garden last year.
KANSAS CITY, March 28 -The fate of Kansas City's reform government, which has been in power since April 2, 1940, will be decided in a hotly contested election Tuesday.

NORRIS HOUGHTON hopes that television may prove to be a formidable weapon in driving the masses back to living, legitimate theatre. His aspirations are not a sour commentary on the electronic medium's ability to make people leave home.

GOTEBORK, Sweden (AP) -March 28 -- Floyd Patterson will defend his world heavyweight boxing title against Ingemar Johnsson of Sweden in New York on Thursday, June 25, Bill Rosensohn, the promoter, said today.

SOME of the onions New Yorkers are buying now may have traveled to market from as far away as Egypt, Czechoslovakia, Chile and the Netherlands. Those countries shipped the pungent bulbs here recently to fill a gap in supplies.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -Maurice Couve de Murville, French Foreign Minister, arrived today for the Western foreign ministers' meeting Tuesday and Wednesday. The sessions will precede the tenth anniversary meeting of the North Atlantic Council on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.
VALLETTA, Malta, March 29 -- The British Navy dockyard on Malta was handed over today to a British engineering concern for private operation under a ninety-nine-year lease.
Joseph H. Murphy, president of the State Tax Commission, dangled last night the promise of leniency for persons who had ignored the state income tax in the past.

There was a story in this newspaper the other day about a suburban Los Angeles couple, Elliot and Ruth Handler, who are operating a fourteen-million-dollar-a-year business with more than a thousand employes, including ten industrial engineers.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -Weather and possible legislation were the dominant influences in grain futures trading last week on the Board of Trade and both were mostly bullish, except for new-crop wheat contracts.

NEW DELHI, March 29 (AP) -- Border reports reaching here today said Chinese Communist rule extended only twenty or thirty miles south of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital. A rebel "national defense army" was said to be collecting taxes in the south. A rebel radio station was reported operating there.
BONN, Germany, March 23 -It is respectable again, but not popular, to be a soldier in West Germany.

WHEN Bernard Wolfe was only 21 and full of innocent idealism and political ignorance he served for eight months as one of Leon Trotsky's secretaries. That was in 1937. The world-famous revolutionist was living in Coyoacan, a suburb of Mexico City, an exile who spent much of his time denouncing Joseph Stalin, his for mer colleague.

BANGUI, Central African Republic, March 14 -- Is Western parliamentary democracy compatible with emerging nationalism? Can parliamentary democracy grow out of colonialism and tribalism? Is there any place for an opposition in a nascent state?

MARY MARTIN offered two one-hour special holiday programs yesterday, a 4 o'clock matinee for small children and an 8 o'clock evening performance for their parents. At 9 o'clock, when her two-fold assignment was over, her energy was unflagging. Hers is the gift to make everyone feel a little younger.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- An agreement setting forth the conditions for stationing United States missiles at bases in Italy is understood to have been reached in Rome after nearly a year of negotiation.
HAVANA, March 29 -- Premier Fidel Castro warned capital and industry in Cuba today that they must cooperate with the revolutionary Government or suffer the consequences.

PITTSBURGH, March 29 -The steel industry was heading to new output records last week. It seemed certain that next month would see even greater steel ingot tonnages. Mills attempted to make all the steel possible to meet heavy delivery promises that must be honored before June 30.
Thirty-two persons were injured last night in a collision between a Transit Authority bus and an automobile in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- John A. Burns, Hawaiian delegate, predicted today that the islands would vote 10 to 1 for statehood. Hawaii has 175,000 registered voters.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- As Bill Norman, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, remarked a few days ago, "Some days you win, some days you lose and some days it just rains."

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 29 (AP) -- Robert Lippincott, a Riverton (N.J.) boat builder who has turned out speedy Star Class craft, skippered one of his own products to victory today in the first event of the three - race Mayers Cup series.
The City Planning Commission made public yesterday a research report upon which it had greatly relied when it started its West Side Urban Renewal Project last year.

The line of credit established by Turkey last August is just now beginning to show results in a flow of needed industrial supplies. The warehouses at Istanbul are beginning to bulge with trucks, machinery and medical goods that Turkey has needed for seven years. It is essential that Turkey have this material help. The problem now is how best it can be put to use.
Sr. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- Almost before the ink had dried on his credentials as Cardinal manager, Solly Hemus rocked the baseball world with a pronouncement.

The existence of the Lighthouse and other recognized agencies for blind persons in New York City makes it unnecessary for any blind person to resort to the tin cup. Even so, employment of persons who cannot see is a problem for the Lighthouse, operated by the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, New York 22.
Prison guards and wardens are afraid of the possibility of rioting because of overcrowding in city detention facilities, the Commissioner of Correction said yesterday.
The white with red polka dot silks made famous by the Belair Stud during the last forty years on the nation's racetracks will be seen today for the first time since late in 1955.

On March 5 you printed a letter from Miss Pauli Murray endorsing the suggestion of Governor Collins of Florida that public school desegregation be entrusted to administrative agencies. These bodies would be required to proceed by conciliation and, if this failed, would have power to issue orders embodying desegregation plans.

ROSELLE, N. J., March 29 -The arrest of ten juveniles accused of a series of burglaries at a Central Railroad of New Jersey warehouse and several industrial plants here was announced today by Deputy Police Chief Victor Anderson.
The first of the two Gotham Junior Dances that will benefit the Foundling Hospital will be held tonight in the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- At the age of 15, Rear Admiral John Tucker Hayward decided to run from home and join the Navy. Too young to enter legally, he paid $10 to two friends to sign his parents' names on a document asserting that he was old enough.

Forty-five per cent of the American public appear to be reasonably familiar with the facts of the Berlin crisis, but the rest are confused, vague or know nothing about it, according to the results of a nationwide survey made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- Air Force researchers are developing a gadget like a siphon bottle to enable weightless space travelers to move around inside or outside of their rocket ships.

BERLIN, March 29 (Reuters) -- Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany has accused "some church leaders" of aiding Western spies. His charge was made in a speech reported today by the Communist newspaper Neues Deutschland.

The independent telephone companies now operate 10,184,000 of the 66,943,800 telephones in this country, its territories and possessions, the United States Independent Telephone Association announced over the week-end.
PARIS, March 29 -- The French Army announced tonight that Colonel Amirouche, one of the most effective Algerian rebel leaders, had been killed in battle.

New can-manufacturing equipment that will more than double its present production capacity is being installed at the Maracay (Venezuela) plant of Envases Venezolanos, S. A., in which the American Can Company has a substantial investment.
Clergymen over the city hailed the Resurrection yesterday as the "blazing center" of Christianity.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The United States Information Agency said today it was getting facts about the country to more and more people behind the Iron Curtain.

We applaud President Eisenhower's nomination of Stuart Rothman to be general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board. This is an exceedingly important and difficult assignment, for which Mr. Rothman is exceptionally well qualified.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- Charlton Heston, who recently completed a year's work for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the title role in "Ben-Hur," will return to the studio to co-star with Gary Cooper in "The Wreck of the Mary Deare."
Builders' have assembled property at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street for improvement with a fifteen-story apartment house.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 29 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. continued to master the field and the elements today, shooting a one-under-par 71 and lengthening his lead in the $15,000 Azalea open golf tournament to five strokes.

Alice Shapiro, pianist, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in a varied program. Her works included the Schumann Carnaval, Mozart's Sonata (K. 310), Chopin's Ballade, Op. 52, and Etudes Op. 25, No. 5, and Op. 10, No. 7, the Alban Berg Sonata, Op. 1, and the Bach-Liszt Prelude and Fugue in A Minor.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29 -- Communist China charged in a statement released by its embassy here last night that India harbored at Kalimpong the "command center" of the Tibetan rebellion.

TANANARIVE, Malgache Republic, March 29 (AP) -Torrential rains continued to fall today on Madagascar Island off the southeast African coast. Floods and storms on the island, now known as the Malgache Republic of the French Overseas Community, have taken about 100 lives and left more than 100,000 people homeless.

ZURICH, March 29 -- Speculation shook the Zurich Stock Exchange all last week following the International Court of Justice's ruling on General Aniline and Film Corporation, the chief asset of the Swiss holding company Interhandel.
Christian leaders here and over the nation issued Easter messages yesterday hailing the power of God that raised Jesus from the dead.
More than 6,000 worshipers watched a simulated sunrise as the organ played the prelude to the fortieth annual United Easter Dawn Service in the Radio City Music Hall yesterday.

The seven-story industrial building at 79 to 89 Seventh Avenue, northeast corner of West Fifteenth Street, in the Chelsea section has been sold by Louis and David Cowan after an ownership of fifteen years to an investor.
LONDON, March 29 -- Prices eased slightly in the stock market last week but the general tone was one of firmness.

The Citizens Budget Commission had a consoling word for Mayor Wagner's administration yesterday. It said the city's fiscal troubles were about the same as those confronting seventeen other municipalities in the nation.

John A. Killoran, probate clerk in Manhattan Surrogate's Court, has retired after fortyeight years' service. A farewell dinner is being given in his honor by the court's staff today at 6 P. M. at Whyte's Restaurant, 145 Fulton Street.
A panel of news executives and writers offered varying answers yesterday to the question "Is American Journalism Meeting Its Responsibilities?"

Aaron Frankel has resigned as managing director of the Margo Jones Theatre in Dallas, Tex. He will step aside May 3 at the end of a twenty-sixweek season, which was to have continued four more weeks through May 31. Mr. Frankel succeeded Ramsey Burch, who gave up the post last May 25.
Hundreds of municipalities, special districts and authorities -- competing to meet problems of metropolitan growth -- were pictured yesterday as working "at cross-purposes to the economic system."

Former President Harry S. Truman's seventy-fifth birthday will be marked by a special nation-wide, ninety-minute television show -- for Democrats only.
EASTER Sunday brought the kind of weather that a woman with a new hat always longs for.
NOW that spring is here, the window is due to receive more attention. Aside from washing the panes, homemakers may want to freshen the curtains and install new shades.

MARIAN ANDERSON'S Easter recital used to be an annual event in New York, so it was like old times last night at Carnegie Hall when her single Manhattan recital of the season fell on Easter. There was an audience of more than 2,500 to welcome her.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, accused the Democrats in Congress today of staging a sort of sideshow. He asked the voters to demand an explanation during the Easter recess.

Governor Rockefeller's pleasure over the "very constructive" program approved by the 1959 Legislature must be somewhat tempered, we should think, by the number of bills suddenly dumped on his desk that require action within thirty days after adjournment.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP RIO TUNUYAN, March 29 -This Argentine liner inched back toward New York tonight, severely battered by a fortyeight-hour Atlantic storm in which winds reached hurricane force.

ROME, March 29 -- Pope John XXIII in an Easter homily today made what appeared to be a plea for high-level talks to ease world tension.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), March 29 -- The celebration of Easter by Christians from the Western churches began this morning in the Old City of Jerusalem as an early spring sun rose from behind the Mount of Olives.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- Representative James M. Quigley carried to the Senate today his fight for more money to clear junkyards and beer parlors off two Civil War battlefields.

On Monday and Tuesday, April 6 and 7, the Metropolitan Opera will open its twentyfourth and final week with performances at the Lyric Theatre in Baltimore. "Vanessa" will be performed Monday, with "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" to be presented Tuesday.

The reports of secret nuclear high altitude tests conducted by the United States early last September leave an ordinary lay reader more confused than ever. New York City's 1959 cleanup campaign will get under way this week, Sanitation Commissioner Paul Screvane announced last night.

A five-man National Amateur Athletic Union track and field team, including Parry O'Brien, the shot-put ace, and Don Bragg, the pole vaulter, departed by plane yesterday for Accra, Ghana, for a one-month tour of Africa.

BOSTON, March 29 (AP) -"I'm all right. I'm all right," said the Boston Red Sox slugger, Ted Williams, tonight as he arrived at Logan Airport from Tucson, Ariz., for examination of his sore neck and shoulder.
John A. Moran Jr. was the broker in the recent purchase of land at Broadway and West 251st Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx for improvement with a motel.

Throngs of strollers, all polished and preened, strode up and down Fifth Avenue yesterday in an Easter parade that had its quota of beautiful women, fancy hats and pampered poodles. The temperature was 38 degrees at noon.
MOSCOW, March 29 -- The Soviet Union repeated tonight its demand that the countries of the North Atlantic Alliance sign a nonaggression pact with the Warsaw alliance of Communist nations.
Columbia University will break ground Saturday for the first unit of its new engineering center on 120th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway.
BIL and Cora Baird have created a crew of beguiling marionettes for their new play with music, "Davy Jones' Locker," which began a holiday engagement over the week-end at the Morosco Theatre.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 29 (AP) --The Minneapolis Lakers dethroned the St. Louis Hawks, champions of the National Basketball Association, today. The Lakers triumphed. 106 -- 104, and captured the Western Division play-offs, 4 games to 2.
Three new films are slated to arrived in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 29 -- Arthur Knapp Jr. sailed Agony to victory in Larchmont Yacht Club's championship series frostbite regatta today. He captured four of the eight races, scoring 230 of a possible 240 points, and triumphed for the sixth time this season.

Widely differing appraisals of the 1959 session of the New York Legislature were made in a radio debate last night between Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach, L. I. and Senator Joseph Zaretzki of Manhattan. They were on WNEW.

The merger of Burke Dowling Adams, Inc., and St. Georges Keyes, Inc., reported here several weeks ago, has been made official. The two organizations have started operations as Adams Keyes, Inc., in this city, Chicago and Los Angeles.

Housing accounted for the bulk of a record-breaking volume of new construction work throughout the country last month. Contracts totaled $2,300,000,000, the highest for any February and an increase of 18 per cent over a year ago.
AS the chatelaine of Chateau Saran, the guest house owned by Moet Chandon in Epernay, France, Miss Moyra Campbell plans meals for the guests staying there.

Four out of five persons examined in a spot check of 458 Federal employes here were found to have some ailment, and three out of ten were found "to have potentially pre-cancerous conditions." This was announced yesterday by an official of the American Cancer Society.

A woman is bound to be in fashion this spring if some part of her wardrobe boasts a bit of contrasting binding. Thanks to Chanel, who started it all, this charming detail appears again and again on spring fashions, adding a special dressmaker touch to the simplest jacket, dress, coat or sweater.
Peru, once a major exporter of natural guano fertilizer, will soon have a modern chemical fertilizer plant to help meet her own growing agricultural needs.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -The Montreal Canadiens' hopes of winning a fourth straight Stanley Cup were shaken today with the disclosure that their great scoring forward, Jean Beliveau, probably would be lost for the rest of the play-offs.
For the first time since World War II there has been a decrease in traffic on the Triborough Bridge.
The discovery that radio waves can influence the behavior of cells has been reported by a team of scientists.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 25 -- Baseball in this Central African metropolis (pop. about 250.000) is like international air travel. It's smooth and fast once it gets going. But the paper work is as confusing as cricket -- which, incidentally, is likely to be going on in center field during every game.
A musical project that Harold Arlen has been working on for more than a decade will finally reach the rehearsal stage in July.
A robot that can pluck daisy petals, twirl hula hoops and, better to justify a huge investment, serve as mechanic on a nuclear plane has been built by the General Electric Company.
The General Electric Company announced last week that one of its small gas-turbine engines would be used in hydrofoilboat experiments.

Day after day, volunteer drivers of the Red Cross motor service are called upon to rush a precious cargo -- human eyes -- from hospitals to the New York Eye bank or from the bank to other hospitals and the airlines.
Prices of cotton futures in the New York market closed up last week after fluctuating irregularly within narrow limits. The New York Cotton Exchange was closed on Good Friday.
JERSEY CITY, March 29 (AP) -- Led by Cal Ramsey of N. Y. U., the New York AllStars had little trouble registering a 90-56 victory over the New Jersey College All-Stars today.
DORTMUND, Germany, March 29 (AP) -- Japan, making strong bids for the men's and women's team titles, moved ahead in both groups tonight in the twenty-fifth world table tennis championships.

MOUNT SHASTA, Calif., March 29 (AP) -- Wally Rothgeb, 37, a Lake Tahoe motel owner from Bijou, Calif., won the national veterans combined ski championship today. He was first in the downhill race and third in the slalom.

It is impossible to escape the tone of cynicism and brutality in Peiping's announcement of the most recent conquest of Tibet. The whole regime of the Dalai Lama has been ruthlessly brushed aside and its successors announced with no reference to the will of the people. This "imperialinspired" revolt has been crushed, but even Peiping hints at its scope when it announces that 4,000 prisoners have been taken.
BUFFALO, March 29 (AP) -- The first educational television station in the state will go on the air tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The General Accountthe Office, Gongressional watchdog over Government spending, has critized a Navy order for $68,000,000 worth of aircraft engines.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -The United States, in cooperation with eight North Atlantic Treaty Allies, will establish this spring an international scientific center for oceanographic research in La Spezia, Italy.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -Lo! The winter is past, the flowers appear on the earth and the voice of the tourist is heard in the capital.
Three former owners of the Symphonic Electronic Corporation announced yesterday the repurchase of all stock, rights and equity in Symphonic from the F. L. Jacobs Company.
There may be real fireworks in store for the mutual funds in July.
Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union said yesterday that its members at five New York voluntary hospitals had voted to strike unless the union received official recognition.

The New York Times of March 16 performed a valuable service for all Americans by printing the truth about the extent of unemployment and by vividly describing the faces and desperate eyes of the fathers, mothers and bewildered children that lie behind the statistics.

The Gulf Oil Corporation last year had a consolidated net income of $329,533,000, the second highest in the company's history, according to the company's pamphlet report for 1958. Based on the 32,390,039 capital shares outstanding at the yearend, the earnings were equivalent to $10.17 a share.

A step to prevent undue hardship on the city's building industry as a result of a comprehensive revision of the zoning regulations has been taken by James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
"The Bridge on the River Kwai" was voted the best film of 1958 by critics, reviewers and commentators in the thirtysixth annual poll conducted by The Film Daily, motion picture trade paper.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- The research department of the Security-First National Bank of Los Angeles has just reported evidence that newspaper help-wanted ads not only are a consistent business index, but are more sensitive than some in general use. The bank's statisticians compile a monthly index of business activity in Southern California that is a standard regional economic barometer.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender said today that legislation to increase the minimum wage, expand unemployment compensation and aid depressed areas all spelled Federal control over state matters.

Your editorial in the issue of March 21 on the dispute between Austria and Italy over the rights of the German-speaking inhabitants of the Alto, Adige deserves the widest circulation. As you say, it would be a tragedy if in these perilous times Problems that can with a bit of sweet reasonableness be settled should lead to rifts in our new and still precarious unity.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 23 -- Listing 881 United States companies that have established factories in Australia or acquired joint interests with Australian manufacturers, the Federal Department of Trade here has issued a booklet calling attention to opportunities for investment in Australia.

TOKYO, March 29 (AP) -The Peiping radio broadcast today three letters, described as from the Dalai Lama, which it said upheld Communist China's story that the Tibetan ruler had been abducted by "traitorous" rebels.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -President Eisenhower's $3,930,000,000 foreign aid request received strong bipartisan support today from three members of the Senate.
Easter worshipers thronged St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. About 5,500 persons attended the 10 A. M. pontifical mass celebrated by Cardinal Spellman.
Low activity and low rates characterized the steamship charter market last week.
The moral standards of the nation's teen-agers are as high as ever, a panel of high school and college students agreed yesterday.

In 1932 I joined the faculty of City College, at a stipulated salary, The state immediately cut our salaries 10 per cent, while deducting the pension contribution at the full rate. We realized there was a depression and patriotically, as we thought, accepted the cut.
Revolt against Tammany Hall is cropping up on many sides. The battle now waxing hot in Manhattan's Fifth Assembly District North puts in focus the essentials of the rebellion.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 29 -- The Amsterdam stock market to some extent freed itself from New York influence last week. Trading was based more on developments here. The market showed mostly a firm undertone, with some strong features, despite the approach of the four-days' Easter holiday.

For the second successive Easter Eve, Alexander Schneider presented the orchestral version of Haydn's "Seven Last Words of Christ" at Carnegie Hall. Like last year's performance, Saturday night's was offered at a price well below the cost of the average concert ticket, and again the seats were unreserved so that those who came earliest got the best places.

NOT too long ago, lingerie for little girls was simple, conventional and practical. White was the only "color" choice for the classic batiste slip cotton knit was the favorite fabric for starkly simple panties and the all-in-one drop seat variety was the generally accepted nightie.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A "tremendous advance" toward understanding the effect of the sun's weather on earth has been made with the taking of the first ultra-violet pictures of the sun's stormy atmosphere, scientists said today.
A pronounced drop in fish sales in the city since last week's poisoned fish scare brought reassurance yesterday from the Health Department that the fish supply here was safe and wholesome.
Sean O'Kelly, the President of Ireland, arrived here yesterday for another look at the city before he sails for home today at the end of a two-week tour of the nation.

LONDON, March 30 (Reuters) -- Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said here today that he coud not visualize any form of military disengagement in Europe under present political conditions.
TRENTON, March 30 -- A proposal for an $800 property-tax exemption for all home owners more than 65 years of age was debated here today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Senator Stephen M. Young announced today that he had sold or was selling stock in two sugar companies and one airline because of a possible conflict of interest with his Congressional duties.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- The French pathologist who transplanted healthy bone marrow to five Yugoslov victims of radiation declared today that the experiment had "succeeded completely."
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower, who returned from Gettysburg today, may go to Augusta, Ga., next week in search of warm weather and exercise.
WASHINGTON March 30 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission filed an anti-trust complaint today against the National Tea Company of Chicago, the nation's fifth largest food chain.

ARE you interested in writing short stories? Or, to be at once more specific and more general, are you one of the thousands who, in one hall of learning and another, teach courses in how to write? Or do you simply enjoy a short story well told?

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday took no action to ban trading in the common stock of H. L. Green Company, though the New York Stock Exchange refused to permit trading in the shares until after the company issued a statement on its earnings.

HARRISONBURG, Va., March 30 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge John Paul approved today a school desegregation plan submitted by Charlottesville. The city is under court orders to admit twelve Negroes to its white schools next September.

VISITING various corners of the United States, a television technique first popularized on "Wide Wide World," was applied last night to an entertainment presentation entitled "America Pauses for Springtime."
ATLANTIC CITY, March 30 -- Fast thinking by a neighbor saved a 9-year-old boy visiting in near-by Brigantine yesterday.

Experience gained by Robert Lantz as a talent representative and production associate will be put to use. He is ready to make his Broadway producing bow with "Like Tomorrow." The arrival of the intimate musical is set for May 12.
Two leading paper companies have announced that they are expanding their foreign operations.

President Eisenhower thinks the Federal requirement that radio and television news programs grant equal time to all candidates for public office has "ridiculous" effects. John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, wants Congress to repeal the entire equal-time requirement. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, fears that "negation and paralysis" will from, the present arrangement.
Young Rubicam, Inc., has been awarded the advertising account of American Airlines, whose billings this year may reach an estimated $7,000,000.
A continued decline in the city's pedestrian casualties depends heavily on "the rank and file members of the Police Department," according to a study made by the Greater New York Safety Council.
Giuseppe Cardinal Pizzardo, prefect of the Sacred Congregation of Seminaries and Universities, yesterday urged wider opportunities for the study of sacred doctrine.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The critical situation of Iraq, which seems to be slipping under Communist control, will be discussed by the North Atlantic Council, diplomatic informants said today.
ON Jan. 15, 1957, Newbold Morris made a telephone call to Julius Rudel. Mr. Morris, chairman of the board of the City Center of Music and Drama, asked Mr. Rudel what he was doing that night.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 30 (Reuters) -- The Iraqi Government has shaken up its diplomatic service, Baghdad newspapers reported today. Nine foreign service officers, including Hashem Hilli, consul in New York, and Saleh Mehdy, counselor of the embassy in Washington, were said to have been retired on pension.
WILMINGTON, N. C., March 30 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. went a stroke over par today, but his closing 73 for a 282 total was good enough to win the $15,000 Azalea open golf tournament by three strokes.
Tenants of a private housing cooperative near the Brooklyn State Hospital are circulating a petition demanding that the mental hospital discontinue its "open door" policy.

It is amazing these days how soft and deceptively spring like weather can pop up at the end of blustery March. There is nothing quite so disarming when the mood is as wintry as a barren tree against a slate-gray sky to be confronted with a new morning that is as full of blue as the summer.
TOKYO, March 30 (Reuters) -- Japan announced today that she was ready to seek a settlement of North Pacific fishing disputes with the Soviet Union through the International Court of Justice.
A two-year experiment on insurance against mental illnesses will be made by Group Health Insurance, Inc.

RANGOON, Burma, March 30 (Reuters) -- Burmese troops, military policemen and Vampire jet aircraft have gone into battle against 3,000 Chinese Nationalist troops concentrated in Wa state in northern Burma, government sources reported here today.
THE Gibson Girl rides again. Dismounted by the advent of World War I, her influence has returned once more to fashion's forefront.

The New York Central Railroad paid the Illinois Central Railroad $2,500,000 in open court (Cook County, Ill., Circuit Court) on March 25 and has agreed to pay an additional $2,500,000 by May 15 for breach of contract. The arrangement became known yesterday. It was confirmed by officials of both railroads.
ROME, March 30 -- Disclosure that the United States and Italy had reached an accord on the installation of missile bases in Italy brought violent Communist protests today.
A 1909 double-decker openair bus of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company ran away from ceremonies yesterday planned to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the Queensboro Bridge.

Horse players who complain of being "seconded to death" had some distinguished company yesterday at Jamaica in the person of Hirsch Jacobs, the leading trainer in twenty-one of the last twenty-seven years.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Some Texas farmers are trying to donate thousands of cabbages to coal mine families in Kentucky and Pennsylvania. Many of the mines in the area have been closed by strikes.
MOTHERS concerned over children who eat an excess of sweets that are high in calories and low in nutrition should be interested in today's cooky recipe.

TWO gems among new frozen food products are the cheese and chocolate souffles just introduced by Daniel, the Caterer. They are ideal to keep on hand in the freezer for serving to unexpected guests or for those occasions when the cook lacks the time or energy for involved meal preparation.

MADRID, March 30 -- The coffin and body of Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera, martyred founder of the Spanish Falange, were borne today on the shoulders of Falangist volunteers from the Escorial to the Valley of the Fallen, ten miles away.

A man who can hang a murderer with a hair will retire tomorrow after thirty-seven years of helping New York City fight crime. He is Dr. Benjamin Morgan Vance, deputy chief medical examiner, now 75 years old.
The New York Stock Exchange, whose motto is "Own Your Share of American Business," has become worried about the frenzied interest in the market.
CHICACO, March 30 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices were steady to 15 cents a hundred pounds higher again today, resuming the steady advance of last week.

IT is a curiously mournful, introverted art that Sonia Gechtoff brings to us from San Francisco, where she has already established herself as a prominent young painter. In her exhibition at the Poindexter Gallery,

The agreement just concluded between Italy and the United States to station Jupiter intermediate range ballistic missiles on Italian territory is good news for NATO. It comes at the right time -- on the eve of the tenth anniversary meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Washington.
DANBURY, Conn., March 30 -- City voters here returned Mayor John A. Define Jr. to office today for a third term. All the other Democratic candidates on the ticket were also re-elected.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today asked a Federal District Court to halt the merger of First Western Bank and Trust Company with the California Bank of Los Angeles.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30 -- The first experimental evidence that atoms are not all neat round shapes like billiard balls was presented here today at the opening of a special meeting on solid state physics at the American Physical Society.

Prices of cotton futures advanced 6 to 17 points (30 to 85 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Old-crop May and July closed at about the day's high, spurred by late buying of July by the leading spot house.

HONOLULU, March 30 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York said here tonight that either Vice President Richard M. Nixon or Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York could win the Presidency next year.

Development of a flexible magnetic plastic material that reacts just as metal or ceramic magnets do was announced yesterday by the B. F. Goodrich Company. The material is made of Goodrich's Koroseal vinyl plastic, impregnated with a "powder sensitive to magnetism," the company said, and its magnetism is permanent for all practical purposes.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The State Tax Commission reminded employers today that they need not submit 6,000,000 income tax information reports and 15,000 withholding returns that originally due Wednesday.
HAVANA, March 30 -- A Miami flier was arrested here today. The police said he had flown "war criminals" out of Cuba in his Beechcraft plane.
Like people in the Southern Hemisphere, clothiers here already are contemplating fall.
A 49-year-old printer testified yesterday that he had risen from a $56-a-week "strikebreaker" to a $1,500-a-week "labor consultant" in the newspaper publishing industry.

BOMBAY, India, March 30 -Hundreds of supporters of the rightist Hindu Bharatiya Jan Sangh party, shouting "Hands off Tibet," invaded the grounds of the Chinese Communist consulate here today. The doors of the consulate remained closed.
A gain of 78 per cent over last year was registered during February in privately financed housing starts in New York State, with 4,631 dwelling units begun or authorized.

As the four principal Western foreign ministers meet in Washington today in preparation for the tenth anniversary session of the North Atlantic Council they have before them three major pronouncements to consider.
LONDON, March 30 -- Britain will withdraw Royal Air Force personnel from the base at Habbaniya, Iraq, "at an early date," the Foreign Office announced today.
VIENNA, March 30 -- West Germany has quietly regained its dominant economic position in Austria.

Lorne (Gump) Worsley, the seemingly much maligned New York Rangers' goalie, was richer and happier yesterday. He became the first Ranger to sign a contract for the 1959-60 National Hockey League season.
Two narcotics ring suspects -- one a delegate to the Apalachin gang meeting -- were seized last night in a Bronx apartment house.
The Long Island Rail Road will start a borrow-use-and-return umbrella service tomorrow for commuters caught in sudden April showers.

MONTREAL, March 30 (AP) -- Jean Beliveau, the Montreal Canadiens' high-scoring center, was ordered to bed today for four or five days before a further examination to determine the seriousness of his back injuries.
Marvin (Candy) McFarland sent Samuel (Chico) Rollins to the canvas four times and scored a unanimous decision in their ten-rounder at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 (UPI) -- Bobo Olson, withstanding a brutal body attack by Rory Calhoun, dropped his White Plains, N. Y., opponent once and staggered him twice while pounding out a unanimous decision at the Cow Palace tonight.

Gross income of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., reached last year record $244,821,241, an increase of $8,944,215 over 1957, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported in the annual statement released today.
MILWAUKEE, March 30 (AP) -- Herman Marks, who has risen to the post of Cuban executioner, left a long criminal record behind him in the United States.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income in 1958. Natural gas sales topped 1,000,000,000,000 cubic feet for the second consecutive year.
MEXICO CITY, March 30 (AP) -- Mexico's railways began rolling again today after a strike was called illegal. It hit the 14,000-mile government-owned National Railway system yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Former Gov. W. Averell Harriman of New York told Democratic Congressmen today they would be "extremely foolish and short-sighted" to trim President Eisenhower's foreign aid requests just to punish him for opposing their domestic spending programs.

Investors in tenements managed by Banton L. Wyckoff have asked the sheriff's office to discontinue collecting rents from those houses and turn over to them rents already collected from tenants in the buildings.
The Board of Higher Education reported yesterday that it had found "no pattern of religious discrimination" at Queens College.
The New York Turf Writers Association has urged Governor Rockefeller to veto a bill that it asserts would discriminate against newspapers in sending news from the state's race tracks.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Moscow's acceptance of the Western invitation to a foreign ministers' conference in May has given new urgency to diplomatic gatherings to be held here in the next few days.

Since it is always a pleasure to hear a pretty young lady vocalist who is also musically literate, an imaginative interpreter and a well-disciplined singer, the song program presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Jan DeGaetani, mezzo-soprano, was a gratifying occasion.

DETROIT, March 30 (AP) -- The auto industry still is adjusting new car inventories in certain sections of the nation by production curtailments. But a sharp sales upsurge in mid-March has renewed makers' hopes of a return of the traditional spring buying upswing.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles flew to Florida today for a rest following treatment for cancer.
GENEVA, March 30 -- Rene Lang, 40-year-old Zurich merchant, said here today that he would again resort to "strong-arm" measures if necessary to get back his elder son, Gerald, 9 years old.

BEN WEBER and Virgil Thomson were the guest composers last night at the fifth "Composers' Showcase" of the season. It was given at the Circle in the Square, to which the series moved earlier this year from its old home at the Nonagon.

EMILIO PUCCI, a noble Italian designer, had never met a Hollywood script writer. If that chance encounter ever comes about, the life and times of Pucci probably will become a Vista-Vision spectacular.
Motors and aircrafts almost held their own yesterday in a general but slow-paced retreat of the stock market. Volume remained relatively low.

Long liquidation and stop-loss selling tumbled potato prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The April and May positions fell to new lows for the life of the contracts. The volume was the second largest of this year.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., March 30 -- The State Thruway Authority today cautioned the thousands of motorists who enter and leave the New York Thruway at the major connection with State Route 119 here to change course begiming Monday.
MIAMI, March 30 (AP) -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey suggested today that Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, sit in if a summit conference is held on the Berlin crisis.

A Bayside community blood donation will be made today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church Parish Hall, 214th Street and Fortieth Avenue, Bayside.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 30 (AP) -- Durward Knowles of Nassau won today's second Myers Cup Star Class sailing race by 15 seconds in a craft he dismasted yesterday.
Two groups designed to bring happiness of one kind or another will be honored at the annual Lambs Spring Gambol on Friday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, March 30 (AP) -- The Very Rev. Daniel W. Egan, 53 years old, president of Steubenville College died in a fire in the bedroom of his monastery residence adjoining the college campus early today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Senator Barry Goldwater has written to President Eisenhower formally protesting his nomination of Stuart Rothman as general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board.

India's Prime Minister Nehru is quite right in rejecting out of hand the Chinese Communist suggestion that it would be "impolite" for India to discuss the situation in Tibet. He is also right in his statement that India's sympathies lie with the Tibetan people who have rebelled against Chinese tyranny. The Indian Government, meanwhile, has denied most emphatically the Communist charge that the Tibetan revolt is being directed from a command center on Indian soil.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- George Amick of Rhinelander, Wis., lifted the track record for speedway-type cars to 176.88 miles an hour today at Daytona International Speedway.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 (AP) -- The Hollywood Film Council today asked Congress to investigate "runaway" foreign movie production by American companies.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Senator Mike Mansfield countered Republican critics today by saying the country was lucky to have in the Senate four "responsible Democrats" with a chance for the Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- A new set of records showing how House members spend funds appropriated to Congress was opened today for public inspection by Harry M. Livingston, House disbursing officer.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board's staff recommended today that Northwest Airline's authority to serve Hawaii be renewed on a permanent basis.
PASADENA, Calif., March 30 (AP) -- The Tournament of Roses and the Big Four of Western college football joined hands today to continue the Rose Bowl football game.

When I began to read the opening paragraphs of Sir Roy Welensky's article in The New York Times of March 22, in which he "questioned" that the causes of disorders and rioting in Nyasaland were widely known, I was agog with expectancy. I thought Sir Roy had a lion well caged which he was about to exhibit.
Jimmie was walking with his father on a New York Sidewalk when a truck went out of control, hopped the curb, and struck him, injuring him critically.

For the Raftery family of Kearny, N. J., it always seems to happen at the same time and in the same manner. The telephone rings no sooner than the family sits down to dinner. A voice on the other end says, "Is Bill Raftery there? I represent College and we'd like to give him a basketball scholarship."
BUENOS AIRES, March 30 (UPI) -- New maritime strikes crippled this port today, and it was reported that anti-government unions were seeking a world-wide boycott of ships calling at Argentine ports.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 30 (AP) -- Secretary McElroy warned here today that if the United States and the Soviet Union ever went to war over Berlin it would not be with rifles.
BOSTON, March 30 (AP) -- Ted Williams entered New England Baptist Hospital this morning for treatment of what he called "a kink in my neck."

The International Association of Machinists asserted yesterday that the country's total factory wage bill was lower now than it had been two years ago. It presented statistics intended to refute the charge that higher wages were responsible for higher prices.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Treasury bill rates rose this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,200,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills was 2.841 per cent, compared with 2.766 per cent last week, and the rate of $400,000,000 of 182-day bills was 3.236 per cent, compared with 3.093 per cent last week.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -A Chicago banker testified today that his bank had cut purchases of du Pont stock for its trust accounts since the United States Supreme Court ordered du Pont to dissolve its interest in General Motors Corporation.
To the French, who are worrying about the purity of their language, the advice from linguistic authorities here yesterday was: Borrow and be the richer for it.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- The Air Force used 127 planes to fly civilians and military men to Dallas for a convention of a private and non-Federal group called the Air Force Association.
Domestic raw steel production leveled off at a record high rate last week. It was scheduled to resume its months-long climb this week.
FAIRYHOUSE,Ireland,March 30 (AP) -- Ireland took all the honors today in the Irish Grand National steeplechase.

The Grace Line cruise ship Santa Rosa made a sharp left turn in a vain effort to avoid colliding with the tanker Valchem last Thursday morning. Her captain acknowledged yesterday that the liner made the maneuver while traveling at top speed of 21.5 knots in the hope of clearing the ship approaching on the starboard (right) side.

BANGUI, Central African Republic, March 30 (Reuters) -- Wreckage of a plane that disappeared last night while carrying Premier Barthelemy Boganda was sighted in a marsh 100 miles southwest of here today.

Elmer Brown, president of the International Typographical Union, said yesterday that he and the international executive council considered the deadlocked contract negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City grave.
Numerous disengagement pro-proposals have been advanced in connection with the Berlin crisis to ease the German problem.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Nevada collected more taxes on a per capita basis than any other state last year, the Census Bureau said today.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering today $25,000,000 of Ohio Power Company 4 5/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1989. They are priced at 102.547 to yield 4.47 per cent.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- The Soviet Government formally agreed tonight to an East-West foreign ministers' conference to be followed by a summit meeting to discuss questions related to Germany, including a German peace treaty and Berlin.
Bowling isn't forgetting its elder participants, though the elders themselves are largely responsible for the move to put them in a class for recognition.
PARIS, March 30 -- French officials moved quickly today to exploit the death in combat, announced yesterday, of Col. Amirouche Ait Hamouda, one of their fiercest enemies in the Algerian rebellion.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office criticized the Air Force today for accepting what it called excessive contract prices on driftmeters furnished by Friden, Inc., of San Leandro, Clif.

During the introduction of Macy's spring collection of Paris fashions earlier this month, the stylist of the Piece Goods Department walked into the Better Dress Department and made some sketches. Today, four mannequins dressed in Paris-inspired clothes are in Macy's Piece Goods Department.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman called last night for "the total removal of the judiciary from clubhouse politics" as he stated the objectives of the Democratic reform movement.

Stockholders of General Telephone and Electronics Corporation will be asked at the annual meeting on April 15 at Santa Monica, Calif., to vote on several proposals affecting the company's capital structure.

Mayor Wagner presents his executive budget tomorrow. While it will exceed two billion dollars for the first time, it will not please city employes or department heads, and the taxpayers are equally unhappy.

Guest conductors for the 1959-60 season of the New York Philharmonic will include Bruno Walter, Dimitri Mitropoulos, Leopold Stokowski, Fritz Reiner, Thomas Schippers, Paul Hindemith and Eleazar de Carvalho.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 30 -- "I never look for fights but I got a good memory,'' said Johnny Logan, the pleasant and friendly Braves shortstop. "I remember who comes into second base hard, who tries to knock me down and who acts like a wise guy."

Final arrangements are being made by the junior committee of the Girls Club of New York for a benefit preview Friday of the new musical comedy, "Come Play With Me," at the York Playhouse. First Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street. The show will open on April 7.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The series of decisions by which the Federal courts strongly asserted the constitutional "right to travel," and banned as illegal some of the discretionary practices of the Secretary of State in denying and revoking passports, has since been closely studied by Congress and the department for guidance toward a formula the courts will uphold as both constitutional and authorized by Federal statute.
The Railway Express Agency asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to cancel a pending request for a rate increase of 3 1/2 per cent, which it filed last fall.

The Long Island Rail Road operated in the red again last month but so far this year it has managed to hold its losses to 50 per cent of what they were a year ago. The line's February deficit was $390,117, compared with $859,112 in February, 1958.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 30 (UPI) -- Robert Haillet of France upset Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, today in the final of the Monte Carlo tennis championships.
Restaurants are rapidly joining department stores and supermarkets as essential parts of shopping centers.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 30 -- The Bolivian Government faced a new crisis in the nationalized tin mines today as the deadline approached for a 50 per cent reduction in commissary subsidies for 24,000 miners.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 30 (UPI) -- Pedro Ramos, the Washington Senators' pitcher, beat the Philadelphia Phillies' Richie Ashburn by 8 yards in a 70-yard race today. Ramos immediately challenged Mickey Mantle of the Yankees, also rated among the fastest men in baseboll.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Following are excerpts from testimony on the defense establishment released today by defense subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee:
ST. LOUIS, March 30 (AP) -- A New York educator declared today that gearing the American school system to producing scientists would harm the school system and weaken American society.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- Arthur Hornblow Jr., motion picture producer, has joined Columbia Pictures in a deal under which he will produce four pictures for the studio over the next four years.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Five thousand Pennsylvania blouse makers struck last night in a dispute that centered on the right of an employer association to hire a former union official as its bargaining representative.
CAIRO, March 30 (Reuters) -- Gamal Abdel Nasser was critical tonight of the Communist party domination of the Soviet Union.

The three five-story apartment buildings at 107, 115 and 117 West 138th Street have been sold by the Walsus Realty Corporation, Louis Suslow, president, to Moses Lerner. R. A. Solove were the brokers in the transaction.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- Bobby Shantz, the little southpaw pitched who is forever being counted out but who somehow manages to come bouncing back, has served notice he'll be around for another year.

Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane opened the city's fourth Big Sweep campaign yesterday to make the city cleaner. Education ceases and discipline begins on May 18 when the city will start to issue summonses, he said.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP) -- Charles F. Seabrook, 78-years old of Deerfield, N. J, who organized Seabrook Farms Company, a frozen food processing concern now operated by his three sons, sought today to be released from Fairmount Farm, a private mental institution in Philadelphia's Roxborough section.

The Times has reported Mayor Robert Wagner's austerity program. However, there are occasions when money is saved by spending it. "For want of a nail, the shoe was lost. For want of the horse, the horse was lost."
VALETTA, Malta, March 30 -- A primed home-made bomb containing a plastic explosive was found yesterday on the deck of a British destroyer here.
The pre-holiday lull in the bond market held over for another full trading session yesterday.

A CARD from Sandy Point on the island of Abaco in the Bahamas suggests that this is a good time to come back for the bonefishing, a trip to the reefs and perhaps a day over the deeps. It is signed by Alfred White.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru expressed today India's sympathy for the Tibetans. He said the citizens of the remote mountain land had undergone much suffering in recent weeks during their revolt against Chinese Communist rule.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30 -- The handling of dry cargo was resumed in Delaware River ports today under an agreement that ended a seven-day dispute.
The Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust has granted two fellowships for the completion of novels: one to Zdena Berger of San Francisco, the other to Junius Edwards of Fetsund, Norway.
The Pepsi-Cola Company last year attained the highest sales and earnings in its history, the annual report has disclosed.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission listed today the conditions under which the Government would guarantee the repayment of $9,889,540 in private loans to the New Haven Railroad.

MOSCOW, March 30 (Reuters) -- Pravda published today widespread criticism of party and government officials in Byelorussia for permitting grave deficiencies in the implementa tion of the Soviet economic plan.
Efforts toward improved enforcement in aviation safety have been initiated by the new Federal Aviation Agency.

Seattle, Wash., is planning to borrow $14,500,000 to finance construction of public schools. The money will be raised by the sale of serial bonds on May 13. The borrowing will be in the name of King County, Wash., Seattle School District 1.
LONDON, March 30 -- Britain's biggest campaign for unilateral nuclear disarmament ended in Trafalgar Square today with speakers demanding elimination of United States air bases here.
A person can be subpoenaed for questioning by a grand jury before his indictment, if he is fully apprised of his constitutional rights, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.
GENEVA, March 28 -- The Coordinating Board of Jewish Organizations has appealed to a United Nations conference here to adopt an international agreement on statelessness.

QUITMAN, Ga., March 30 (UPI) -Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said tonight that the Eisenhower Administration was being "totally unrealistic" in reducing military ground forces in advance of an East-West summit conference.
Seven teen-agers went on trial for their lives yesterday in a scene closely resembling the Michael Farmer murder case, which received wide publicity last year.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The tourist season is in full bloom. The annual spring influx of visitors started two weeks ago and is expected to be at its peak this week.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- The good margins built up over the past several days in rye and May wheat brought on profit-taking and fairly broad selling pressure on the Board of Trade today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 30 -- Venezuela will not need the foreign credit that she obtained last year, according to Dr. Jose Antonio Mayobre. Minister of Finance. The fiscal situation of the country has improved to such extent, he said today, that the current budget will be covered by means of local income.

CLINTON, N. J., March 30 -- Triple Cross, a 5-year-old white and lemon pointer, won the open shooting-dog stake today in the North Jersey Field Trial Club's annual spring program at the Public Shooting Grounds. The dog is owned by Al Koch of Philadelphia and handled by George Stymiest of Lambertville, N. J.
LONDON, March 30 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to the United States agreeing to an East-West foreign ministers' conference, as issued in English by the Soviet agency Tass:

A state-wide increase of 18.4 per cent in automobile liability insurance rates will go into effect today. It is the greatest single rise in car coverage rates in the post-war period and will add more than $60,000,000 to premiums.

THE New York City Opera Company and its general manager, Julius Rudel, believe that opera created in America has reached sufficient maturity to command a season of its own. For the second successive spring such a season is being presented at the City Center.

TOKYO, March 30 -- Government experts are studying the possibly far-reaching effects of a Tokyo District Court decision today declaring that the presence of United States military forces in Japan is unconstitutional.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- Half a million Russians can't be wrong and in Moscow pretty bare-legged girls, elegant costumes that light up, full-throated trumpet blues and graceful figure skaters made in the U.S.A. can do no wrong.
When cocks crow in the afternoon, it is too much for a latesleeping Brooklyn milkman.
KALIMPONG, India, March 30 -- The Chinese Communists have started dropping paratroops south of the Brahmaputra River in Tibet in an effort to intercept the Dalai Lama before he can reach India.
A Nassau aircraft plant announced a $101,701,000 Navy contract yesterday at the same time that another Long Island aircraft plant, less than two miles away, told of plans to lay off 2,300 workers.

YONKERS, March 30 -- Favorites have not been faring well at Yonkers Raceway. Four favorites succeeded tonight, but only twenty-two have delivered in the season's first nine nights. The percentage of winning favorities -- 27.2 -- has been a case of so far, not good.

When Secretary General Hammarskjold returned on Sunday from a four weeks' trip to foreign parts a reporter asked him if he had anything to say about his talks with Mr. Kbrushchev. His reply, as officially recorded, was as follows: "Nothing but what I said to your colleagues in Moscow; private talks are private talks."
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A deeply divided Supreme Court held today that a man might be subjected to both state and Federal prosecutions for the same criminal act.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Following are excerpts from the majority Supreme Court opinion today in the Afonso Bartkus double jeopardy case and dissenting opinions by Justices Hugo L. Black and William J. Brennan Jr.:

Today's new film is "Intent to Kill," a British suspense drama presented by Twentieth Century-Fox and starring Richard Todd and Betsy Drake, at neighborhood theatres. The feature was directed by Jack Cardiff and produced by Adrian D. Worker for Zomic Productions. The screen play by Jimmy Sangster is based on the novel by Michael Bryan.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board dealt a blow today to compulsory unionism practices in newspaper composing rooms.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Congress made public today high-level military testimony that the United States was acquiring too many nuclear weapons of the kind that could destroy the Soviet Union "several times over."
A freighter moored in New York Harbor will be the point of origin of a drama based on a sea adventure from life during an "Omnibus" telecast on April 12.
The New York Central Railroad sought authorization yesterday to abandon passenger service on its West Shore division.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 30 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff was assured by two New Haven Railroad executives here today that there would be no "skimping on safety factors."

City employes were warned by Mayor Wagner's office yesterday that if they walked off their jobs today in the work stoppage that has been threatened they would do so on their own time and at their own expense.
ROME, March 30 -- While work on Olympic installations proceeded steadily in various corners of this city last week, some officials began to spy headaches ahead.
DETROIT, March 30 -- Secretary McElroy warned that the United States could destroy the Soviet Union if attacked.
A vicious Atlantic storm continued to rage yesterday.

HONG KONG, March 30 -- The Panchen Lama, appointed Saturday by the Chinese Communists to succeed the Dalai Lama as titular leader of Tibet, telegraphed his full support yesterday to Premier Chou En-lai and Chairman Mao Tse-tung, the Peiping radio said today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued a formal complaint today charging Swift Co. of Chicago with violations of the Packers and Stockyards Act in meat sales in the West in 1956.
An associate of Alexander L. Guterma pleaded not guilty to fraud charges in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

The officer in charge of the tanker Valchem said yesterday that he had ordered a change in course to the right twenty minutes before the liner Santa Rosa collided with the tanker at 3:10 A. M. last Thursday off Atlantic City.
PARIS, March 31 (Reuters) -- The Premier of the flood-ravaged Malgache Republic termed an estimated death toll of 3,000 "unhappily much under the truth."
