ROME, March 31 -- Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella left tonight by air for the United States. Before leaving he voiced the hope, with caution, that the East-West talks may be fruitful.
BOSTON, March 31 (UPI) -- Uncertainty hung over Ted Williams like a rain cloud during a double-header today as doctors hovered around him seeking the cause of a $1,000-a-day pain in the neck.

BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, March 31 (Reuters) -- The Nyasaland Government said today that 953 Africans have been arrested for political crimes since Jan. 1. Of these, 256 were convicted, 535 are in detention camps and 153 were freed. Nine are unaccounted for.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices declined 25 to 75 cents a hundred-weight today on a heavy Tuesday supply of 12,000 head, 2,000 more than expected. The best price of $17.25 went for only 39 head of 200-215 lb. No. 1.
MADRID, March 31 -- Twenty years ago tomorrow Francisco Franco, then a 46 - year - old Spanish infantry general, announced the victory of his rebel forces over the Republican Government of Spain.

LONDON, March 31 -- There is every likelihood that the rest of this year will be taken up with protracted East-West negotiations and that before these have ceased there will be a general election in Britain. Prime Minister Macmillan may choose to capitalize upon his present diplomatic prominence and set the polling date for May.

YONKERS, March 31 -- When, at the behest of Governor Rockefeller, ten additional racing dates were legalized by the Legislature at Albany, the guess was that New York State would pick up about $1,500,000 in added revenue from harness racing. It was a good guess.

We were entirely charmed by the essay written by the Thoughtful Subway Rider under Topics on March 24 upon his discovery that the new "Hi-Speed" local service on the West Side IRT is indeed fast, as The Subway Sun claimed and as he obviously disbelieved until he had visual proof.

Bonds called for redemption in March before maturing totaled $64,780,000, the largest amount for any March since 1955, when $124,678,000 was redeemed. Last month's total, which was also the largest for any month since August, compared with $46,990,000 in February and $14,508,000 in March, 1958.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals stayed today the effectiveness of an order giving to the court-appointed monitors broad powers to enforce cleanup demands on the Teamsters Union.
ALBANY, March 31 -- A $500,000 ski center is scheduled for construction on the northeast slopes of the Catskills.

Today's new film is "Compulsion." a Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of Meyer Levin's novel, with Orson Welles, Diane Varsi, Dean Stockwell and Bradford Dillman, at the Rivoli Theatre, Broadway and Forty-ninth Street.
EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., March 31 -- Scientists are close to naming viruses among the causes of human cancer, according to reports at a meeting arranged here by the American Cancer Society.

BANGUI, Central African Republic, March 31 (AP) -- Premier Barthelemy Boganda, a witch doctor's son who rose to political power in this Negro republic, was found dead today in the wreckage of a plane 100 miles west of here.
NEWARK, March 31 -- United support for a depressed east-west freeway in Essex County was voiced here today by spokesmen for four municipalities through which the proposed road would pass.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 31 (AP) -- A 40-year-old arc welder, whose clothes were on fire, pulled away from a fellow worker who was trying to help him and jumped to his death tonight on the Kitty Hawk, a supercarrier under construction here.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board dropped a proceeding today to have the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America cited as Communist-infiltrated.
HAVANA, March 31 -- Thousands of public employes were dismissed today at the end of a ninety-day reorganization of the Cuban Government.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that rail freight loadings in the second quarter of 1959 were expected to be about 12.4 per cent above the volume in the corresponding quarter of last year.
GARY, Ind., March 31 (AP) -- A strike by more than 100 teachers stopped classes in two suburban schools today. The picketing teachers were protesting loss of union recognition.

PITTSBURGH, March 31 (AP) -- A four-man team from each side will carry the major bargaining burden in the forthcoming contract negotiations between the United Steelworkers Union and the basic steel industry.
KALIMPONG, India, March 31 (AP) -- There are strong indications that India may grant asylum to the Dalai Lama.

Following is the text of the portion of Mayor Wagner's 1959-60 budget message detailing economies and savings effected by the city under management-improvement programs. This section of the Mayor's message was made public yesterday in advance of Mr. Wagner's submission of the budget today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- John Maragon, who served a prison sentence for perjury before a Senate investigation of sellers of influence, lost his job today as an employe of the House of Representatives.

BONN, Germany, March 31 -- The Soviet Union, in a note today, charged Bonn with trying to prejudice the foreign ministers' meeting set for May 11 in Geneva "by unnecessary polemics and unfounded accusations."
RONKONKOMA, L. I., March 31 -- Suburban Long Island is scheduled to start receiving regular airline passenger and cargo service here at MacArthur Airport May 25.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Rockefeller declared today that high jury awards in automobile accident cases had contributed materially to the insurance companies' need for higher liability policy rates.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- The period 1957-58 was a fairly good one for the world's common man, the United Nations reported today. It was not the best since the end of World War II, but, in general, the man did well.

ON THE TUNISIAN - AL - GERIAN BORDER, March 31 -- Belkacem Krim, Nationalist Algerian War Minister and Vice President, mourned today the death of Colonel Amirouche, rebel commander in Kabylia, by saying: "The revolution continues; it is producing scores of leaders just like him."
A defense of the local workings of the Federal-city slum clearance program marked a groundbreaking ceremony yesterday at the site of the long-delayed Kips Bay redevelopment.

While there may be more pressing problems facing the city every day, no one who cares about the cleanliness of his environment can take the Sanitation Department's fourth annual Big Sweep campaign lightly. It is a serious drive involving the efforts of many hired and volunteer workers and a considerable sum of money to make New York City a pleasanter and cleaner place to live in.
The advertising account of Chase Sanborn Instant and Regular coffees, with estimated billings of $6,500,000 a year, is out of Compton Advertising, Inc.

TORONTO, March 31 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich's goal at 11:21 of a sudden-death overtime period gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight and tied their Stanley Cup hockey semi-final at two games apiece.
Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut called yesterday for an investigation of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and what he termed the "inadequacy" of its passenger service.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- After three decades of groping and uncertainty, the future of the United States in Antarctica will probably be decided here within the next two days.
Municipal Court Justice Lester Lazarus ordered preliminary eviction notices yesterday against 107 tenants living in the area of the Lincoln Square project.
Nothing is sure but death and taxes, the saying goes, but Governor Rockefeller's plan for forgiveness of 1958 state income taxes is more beneficial when the taxpayer dies.

The nonresident working in New York will be treated slightly better this year than he has been in the past with respect to his income tax. But his chief source of complaint -- that he is not allowed to itemize deductions -- remains.
The Mid-Century Book Society will come into existence today under the auspices of W. H. Auden, Jacques Barzun and Lionel Trilling. Its offices will be at 107 East Thirty-eighth Street.

The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed $30,000,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance construction. The securities were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Drexel Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co. at an interest cost of 3.584 per cent.
The 2-cent rise in the state tax on a pack of cigarettes is expected to raise the vending-machine price for some types "into the seventh nickel."
MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- The Mexican Government ordered the expulsion of two attaches of the Soviet Embassy tonight, charging they were involved in the national railroad strike last week-end.

A new Kimberly-Ferrari combination has appeared on the international sports car racing scene. Bill Kimberly, 26-year-old nephew of Gentleman Jim Kimberly, former president of the Sports Car Club of America, has taken over the Ferrari driving chores that Gentleman Jim abandoned for the world of sailboating.
WARSAW, March 31 -- The last trainloads of Poles returning to their homeland from the Soviet Union crossed the Bug River into eastern Poland today.
Milton Berle and George Burns have formed a company to produce a half-hour television series on film in which Mr. Berle will act as host and star.

The article by Edwin L. Dale Jr. in your March 27 issue reports official Government figures show that 1,362,000 needy persons in 466,000 families in January were being supported by "general relief" from state and local welfare agencies.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Indignation over Communist China's suppression of the Tibetan revolt is stirring the Asian neutralist world much as Soviet suppression of Hungary's rebellion in 1956 stirred the Western world.

A Roman Catholic theologian said yesterday that college freshmen were "surface readers'' who required skilled guidance before they were ready to cope with such writers as Francois Mauriac or Graham Greene.
LEATHER, a garb for low, primitive types ranging from Neanderthal man to modern juvenile delinquents, finally has soared into the high fashion field.
The Transit Authority had a cheerful message yesterday for the city's subway and bus riders.

OTTAWA, March 31 -- Just before the tenth anniversary of its union with Canada, Newfoundland filed suit for damages today against the Government of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker over the Federal Government's refusal to send reinforcements for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in a period of bitter labor strife.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 31 -- Workers struck some Government tin mines today as prices were increased in mine commissaries. Negotiations to avert a national tin strike were under way.
Nine women and four men were sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court for cheating the Welfare Department out of a total of $17,578 in relief funds over-four years.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Government security program covering 3,000,000 defense plant workers was attacked in the Supreme Court today as being without legal or constitutional basis.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo's next visit to Australia will be as a member of Jack Kramer's touring tennis professionals, the captain of the Australian Davis Cup team said today.

BARBOURVILLE, Ky., March 31 (UPI) -- The State Police reported today that a Knox County mine owner was killed as new violence erupted in the eastern Kentucky coal strike. The walkout has idled 7,000 miners.

KALIMPONG, March 31 (Reuters) -- More than 50,000 Chinese Communist troops combed Himalayan villages and mountain monasteries today in a desperate effort to intercept the Dalai Lama before he could reach, India.
A new rash of inter-union feuding is upsetting the merged labor federation.

Judge Dennis F. Donovan of the Federal District Court, Duluth, Minn., has directed the Mesabi Iron Company to resume arbitration of its dispute with the Reserve Mining Company over mining royalties. This was announced yesterday by Reserve Mining through representatives here.

BURBANK, Calif., March 31 (AP) -- Seeking a role in the atomic submarine business, Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has acquired control of one of the West's oldest shipbuilding, ship repair and general construction concerns, the Puget Sound Bridge and Dredging Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- The part-time prostitute has become as great a problem to the world as the professional, the United Nations has reported.
The following questions include those most frequently asked regarding the state's new income tax law and those applying to the broadest categories of taxpayers:
Four persons were reported yesterday to have drowned in the wild storm on the Atlantic last week-end. The storm disrupted shipping schedules and forced at least one ship to put back into New York.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Representatives of the American textile and apparel industries today disapproved a proposed new formula to regulate imports of Japanese textiles.

KARL AMADEUS HARTMANN is regarded as one of Germany's most important composers, but his work is scarcely known here. It was, therefore, a thoughtful gesture on Eugene Ormandy's part to introduce Herr Hartmann's Symphony No. 6 to New York at last night's Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall.

LONDON, March 31 -- British diplomats insisted today that Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's plan for negotiated limitation of forces and weapons in Central Europe would be proposed by the Western powers at foreign ministers' and summit talks with the Soviet Union.
Officals at the Bronx Zoo and the Coney Island Aquarium prepared yesterday for their yearly siege.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 31 -- A Democratic coalition swept the Non-Partisan Citizens Association out of City Hall today after a nineteen-year reign.
The city's big corporations appear to be taking the state's new income-tax withholding system in their stride.

Nearly 600 scientists and engineers met yesterday in the first sessions of a three-day Symposium on Millimeter Waves at the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.
WICHITA, Kan., March 31 (AP) -- Kansas finally got its official mother of the year today. She is Mrs. Irene Henderson Kelley, a 67-year-old business woman and rancher.

Mlle. Dianne, owned by Harold H. Polk, won the five-and-a-half-furlong sprint that served as the feature on yesterday's program at Jamaica. A crowd of 18,591 saw the event, and the outcome pleased the favorite players.

The Schoois Motion Picture Committee a voluntary organization of parents, lists the fol-I lowing films as suitable for children between $ and /4 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted. I A .-N'

For most taxpayers, particularly the two-thirds whose annual incomes are less than $6,000, the impact of the new withholding system for income tax collection will be moderate, the State Tax Commission insists.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday grants totaling $11,444,010. Of this, $9,161,210 will go to nine colleges and universities to try to achieve what it called "a breakthrough in teacher education."

The $33,000,000 dream will be a reality on Monday, Sept. 14, when the new Aqueduct race track will start operating. Thoroughbred horse-racing activity will be presented at the Queens course for sixty-seven days, through the end of the season in this state.

PAINTINGS by twenty contemporary painters working in advanced modern idioms, selected from the collection of Philippe Dotremont of Brussels, Belgium, will go on view today in the temporary quarters of the Guggenheim Museum, 7 East Seventy-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- The House reopened today its records of rental payments for members' offices in their home districts. Some of the money went to the Congressmen themselves, their relatives, business associates and local political groups.
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- Fishermen had little expectation of reward from tomorrow's early, state-wide opening of the stream trout season. The streams, in general, were too cold.
The Health Department yesterday reported a slight increase in the incidence of upper respiratory illnesses, notably influenza and pneumonia, in March compared with February.
New financing in March declined sharply, with bonds offered here the smallest since October and stocks the lowest since November.
A member of the Board of Higher Education took issue yesterday with some aspects of a board study that found "no pattern of religious discrimination" at Queens College.

Sixty acres in Bedford, Westchester County, have been sold by Edwin O. Holter to Lunmor Homes, Inc., builders, for improvement with homes occupying plots of one-half acre or more. The tract is between Bedford Hills and Katonah and fronts on Cherry Street, Harris Road and Bedford Road (Route 117), off the Saw Mill River Parkway.
Within the last ten years the dozen or so highest mountains in the world have nearly all been climbed for the first time.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Rockefeller today named a nine-member committee to try to solve the problems of Westchester County's outworn parkway system.

NEWARK, March 31 -- Three children died early this morning in an oil-stove blaze that burned out their first-floor bedroom in a three-story brick building at 410 Halsey Street. A 10-year-old girl escaped from the room.

Southern California, barred by its probationary status from competing in last week-end's National Collegiate championships, will get an eagerly awaited opportunity to exhibit its burgeoning swimming strength in the Amateur Athletic Union's title meet at Yale this week-end.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 31 -- A leading educator warned today of overemphasis on the development of science as a special field. He feared it might cause neglect of the relationship of science to social studies and of scientific findings to social, economic and political developments.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France said tonight that a summit meeting with the Soviet Union would depend upon the preparation of constructive proposals at the foreign ministers' conference that is to begin May 11.

Corporation news developments were good yesterday but the market on the New York Stock Exchange continued to act uncertain. Stocks opened lower, climbed until 2 P. M. and then fell, closing the day with a moderate loss.
General Sessions Court was wired for sound yesterday for the first time since it moved into the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street in 1940.

The National Surety Building, a nine-story structure at 4 Albany Street, has been purchased for investment by John A. Dilliard from the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company. The building, also fronting on Carlisle and Washington Streets, is a half block from the American Stock Exchange.

The new state income tax withholding system that went into effect today has presented to the State Tax Commission many unexpected questions and a few knotty problems it has been unable as yet to answer.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 31 -- An intercollegiate conference on "Zen Buddhism in [American Culture" will be held at Sarah Lawrence College here on April 18. Students and faz ulty members from sixty eastern colleges and universities are expected to attend.

The 18.4 per cent increase in automobile liability insurance rates authorized Monday for New York came under Democratic attack yesterday as "another Rockefeller give-away to the special interests at the expense of the family pocketbook."
The development of a small atomic submarine that would require only a dozen or so crewmen and yet outperform current craft is under Pentagon study.

EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., March 31 (UPI) -- Roy J. Gibbons, science editor of The Chicago Tribune, was expelled from the cancer research meeting today. He refused to abide by ground rules covering the release time of news stories.

ALBANY, March 31 -- About 1,000,000 New York residents will have to estimate their year's income in advance and make quarterly payments on the part not covered by withholding under the tax system that goes into effect tomorrow.
The market in high-grade bonds had another day of quiet equilibrium yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- The Government declared today it was standing pat on its original proposal that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., divest itself of its stock interest in General Motors Corporation.
A tour of four gardens in the{ Oyster Bay Cove area of the{ North Shore of Long Island on May 13 will benefit the Faculty Salary Advancement Fund of l Wellesley College.
Three young printers testified yesterday on how they had been recruited in Florida to work in the composing rooms of struck newspapers in Westchester County.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 31 -- In a semi-final of the intercollegiate division of Bermuda's twenty-first annual rugby week, Harvard defeated Massachusetts Institute of Technology today, 11 -- 0.

Two fugitives under indictment as members of narcotics rings were held in bail totaling $250,000 yesterday in Federal Court here. Both had been seized Monday evening in a Bronx apartment house, where they had been living under assumed names.

One of Hawaii's last territorial bond issues came to market yesterday. The borrowing consisted of $14,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance completion of a $23,000,000 improvement at the Honolulu International Airport. The issue will come due in 1984.
Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday large gains in operating revenues and net income for the two and twelve months ended Feb. 28.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., March 31 -- Members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union picketed most of the 121 struck blouse manufacturing plants in the Easton - Bethlehem - Allentown area today.
LONDON, March 31 -- The revolt in Tibet has disclosed the failure of Communist Chinese imperialism to undermine the moral and religious authority of the Dalai Lama, British diplomats said today.
LONDON, March 31 -- Valuable furs and jewelry were stolen from Sir Winston Churchill's London town house last nights.

HONG KONG, March 31 (Reuters) -- Jenmin Jihpao, the official organ of the Chinese Communist party, said today that the Chinese Army had "swiftly put down the rebellion in the Lhasa area and is mopping up the rebels in some other places in Tibet."

TOKYO, March 31 -- The Japanese Government's policies will not be affected by a court decision yesterday that the presence of United States military forces in Japan was unconstitutional. Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama plans to call on Douglas MacArthur 2d, the United States Ambassador, to assure him of this, it was announced today.
ALLENDALE, N. J., March 31 -- The Bluebird Man is afield again in North Jersey.
Hundreds of city employes picketed City Hall for hours yesterday to protest reduced pay rises in the 1959-60 budget.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke said today the state of readiness of the United States Fleet was not so good as it should be, but "we'll do the best we can and that will be plenty good."
A lawyer said yesterday that police protection would be requested for 9 year-old Gerald Lang, whose younger brother Francis was carried off last week to Switzerland by their father.

The April and May potato positions fell to new life-of-contract lows yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market was influenced by reports that large tenders would be made today, the first notice day for April deliveries.
A varied array of new securities offerings worth more than $156,000,000 will reach the market today. The offerings, which include debentures, bonds, preferred and common stocks, follow:
NEW HAVEN, March 31 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee appointed a three-member commission today to investigate the causes of friction and disturbances between Yale University students and the community.

France is not "the weak sister" in the Common Market, but one of the stronger members, the Chase Manhattan Bank said today in its latest economic letter. The Common Market is a joint effort of six European nations that began last Jan. 1 to reduce trade restrictions, looking hopefully toward the elimination of most barriers and toward complete convertibility of currencies.

An announcement the other day by researchers at the University of Illinois indicated that experiments are afoot to improve ways of making ice cream and to look into the possibilities of making it taste better.
CINCINNATI, March 31 (AP) -- The eight clubs of the National Basketball Association drafted a total of eighty-one college players today.
NEW HAVEN, March 31 (UPI) -- A common type of fatty substances, known as triglycerides, may have more to do with heart attacks than cholesterol, the American Heart Association said today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Wages for soft-coal miners will go up tomorrow for the second time this year. Coal prices will go down.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 1 -- Meade Alcorn will resign as chairman of the Republican National Committee, probably today. Highly placed political sources said that Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky would most likely be his successor.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- A view that the younger generation in the South was more racially tolerant than its parents was challenged today.
TRENTON, March 31 -- New Jersey extended today until June 30 its thirty-nine week unemployment benefit period.
Sears, Roebuck Co. in its fiscal year ended Jan. 31 had the highest sales and earnings in its history.

The Fort Hamilton Realty Agency has sold the six-story building containing eighty-three apartments at 130 Fenimore Street, Brooklyn. The buyers were investing clients of Irving Bira, the broker in the sale in conjunction with Harry Rubin.
Ichiro Hatta is a man with a weight problem. The slender, graying Tokyo real estate man must try to keep ten husky young Japanese collegians from over-eating for the next couple of weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A proposal that members of Congress and other leaders of the nation have regular physical check-ups including tests for cancer was made today to the second national Cured Cancer Congress by one of President Eisenhower's physicians.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., increased its operating revenues last year by 8 per cent to a record $284,840,956 from $263,664,554 in 1957.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies tonight traded Stan Lopata and two infielders to the Milwaukee Braves. The Phils received a pitcher, Gene Conley; a shortstop, Joe Koppe, and an infielder-outfielder, Harry Hanebrink.
March has been Red Cross Month. About 30,000 volunteers have been busy in this city in an effort to raise $6,000,000 to help carry on Red Cross tasks in the coming year.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Justice Department announced today the resignation of Leonard B. Sand, an assistant to the Solicitor General.

CLINTON, N. J., March 31 -- Palaboy, a 4-year-old white and liver dog led the parade of pointers today in the $750 free-for-all stake that completed the annual spring program of the North Jersey Field Trial Club at the Public Shooting Grounds.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- The Yankees lost another game today to their rebellious "cousins," the Kansas City Athletics, this time by a score of 4 to 2. However, so far as Casey Stengel and his Bombers were concerned, this was merely a minor development.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The United States firmly rejected today a formal effort by the Soviets to establish a 10,000-foot ceiling for planes flying over East Germany into West Berlin.

ATLANTIC CITY March 31 -- A plan for Roman Catholic schools in overcrowded and underfinanced areas to provide for parochial education needs was put forth here today by the head of the National Catholic Educational Association.

BY the middle of next week, when the average taxpayer will have seen what a $2,000,000,000 state budget can do to his pay check, Edward Dennis Igoe will be the leading publican (tax collector) in New York State.
The Children's Aid Society held its ninth annual regatta yesterday on Conservatory Lake in Central Park.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- A late rally steadied the grain futures market today and lifted nearly all contracts above the previous closes on the Board of Trade after earlier spots of weakness.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused for a second time to order new hearings on the proposed abandonment of the Jay Street Connecting Railroad's operations on the Brooklyn waterfront.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 31 (AP) -- Secretary General Pote Sarasin told military advisers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization today that Communist China was a continuing threat to South- east Asia.

TOTAL escape from the sometimes sunny Southland is not easy. The body gets away and immediately the mind is snapped back. Television did it. Before a returning tourist had a chance to get aclimated, the electronic monster whisked him to Augusta, Ga., where the Masters golf tourney will begin tomorrow.
LONDON, March 31 -- The Stock Exchange opened today after the Easter recess on a quiet note, but prices generally remained firm.
The DC-7, a piston-engine plane that American Airlines called the fastest transport in its fleet five and a half years ago, began to give way yesterday to the faster jetliner.
Columbia College's radio station is shopping for a new site for its antenna, with Riverside Church apparently no longer a possibility.
The Penn-Texas Corporation reported yesterday for 1958 a consolidated net loss of $1,865,952 from net sales and operating revenue of $70,461,604.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, said today that Peiping's repression of the revolt in Tibet was "utterly repulsive."
Your timely editorial of March 27 "The Mayor's Dilemma" impels me to make two observations.
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday proposed a three-for- two split of the company's capital stock for its 75,000 shareholders.

FOR a decade plus one year, Mrs. Helen Worth has been teaching New Yorkers how to cook. In that period she has learned which dishes are the most popular with her pupils and which, in her words, "inevitably lay an egg."
Primarily concerned until now with making investments in Broadway stage ventures, Theatrical Interests Plan, Inc., announced yesterday its intention of becoming a producer on its own.

Soviet military and political views on strategy are surveyed in a book by Herbert S. Dinerstein, a senior staff member of the Rand Corporation. Called "War and the Soviet Union," it is based on an examination of Soviet Russia's press, books and military journals, "one of which is unavailable even to the general Soviet public."
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 31 -- The first African appointed to the Government of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland will be sworn in tomorrow.

THE jewel box of a queen will be opened today, when seventeen custom-designed pieces from the personal collection of Queen Geraldine of Albania go on display and sale. The collection, which includes a bridal diadem and other lavish wedding jewels, will be sold to assist the dependents of King Zog I and former Albanian subjects who have left that country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Columbia Pictures announced today the purchase of screen rights to the hit Broadway play, "A Raisin in the Sun," by Lorraine Hansberry. According to sources in New York, the purchase price for the story of a Negro family in the South Side of Chicago was $300,000.
MIAMI, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- The Ryder Truck and Equipment Leasing System announced today plans to purchase the car and truck fleets of the Dixie Drive-It-Yourself System of Birmingham, Ala.
Nearly 6,000,000 persons who work in New York State will find the pay checks they receive today and hereafter smaller than they were.
Adam Hat Manufacturers, Inc., will guarantee a 20 per cent increase in hat sales over last fall for stores that begin carrying the Adam line next fall.

The doors never opened on most of the city's art treasures yesterday, although there was a steady stream of would-be visitors to the museums. A one-day demonstration of city employes also forced forty-five city playgrounds to close.

PARIS, March 31 -- A proposal for a compromise solution of France's Algerian problem was advanced here today in a newspaper article attributed to an anonymous French official concerned with Algerian affairs.
CHICAGO, March 31 -- A new book publisher who plans to sell full-sized, hard-covered volumes in supermarkets and drug stores said today that books should be "pushed" like cars and food products.
The chief spokesman for organized labor has challenged the right of one of the country's biggest banks to use bank funds to back "right to work" laws.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The State Thruway Authority reported today that it incurred an operating deficit of $2,596,172 last year.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill to taper off the anti-recession program of Federal aid to the unemployed. The plan would have expired at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Navy will establish in the coming year a radio communications link between Washington and Pearl Harbor by way of the moon.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- A United Automobile Workers local in Louisville volunteered today to pay whatever shipping costs are required to get free cabbages from Texas to unemployed miners in Harlan County, Ky.

The Jewel Tea Company's net earnings for the quarter ended last Saturday were below the $1,763,402, or $1.14 a share, cleared in the 1958 period, F. J. Lunding, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday. The $1.14 figure is based on the shares outstanding on March 31, 1958.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in the first three months of this year was the heaviest since 1929, while on the American Stock Exchange trading set a new record. Turnover on the Big Board was 231,496,751 shares, an increase of about 69 per cent above the 136,744,324 shares exchanged in the first quarter of 1958.
A Wild West version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," with Puck sporting a Davy Crockett hat, will camp at seven cities in England and Scotland this summer.

NEW DELHI, March 31 (AP) -- The Tibetan visitors upheld their account of the meeting with Mr. Nehru, even after a Foreign Ministry statement indicated that he was holding to his hands-off policy toward the Tibetan uprising.

The second largest secondary offering of stock in United States corporate history was made here yesterday as 324 underwriters led by Blyth Co., Inc. offered 2,000,000 shares of Ford Motor Company common stock at $56.50 a share.
AN angora goat, girdled with a neatly painted rubber tire and standing on a low platform, is the eye-catcher in the current exhibition at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 4 East Seventy-seventh Street.

FLOWERS that flourish without watering are a specialty at Gilbert-Whitbeck, Inc., 1103 Third Avenue, a shop that transforms sheet metal into flowering trees, long-stemmed posies and inventive chandeliers.
The United Stores Corporation announced yesterday that Maurice Olen, Herschel Harris and Ivan Ezrine had resigned from the board of directors.
Police Chief John J. Smith of Piermont, N. Y., was questioned privately all day yesterday by the State Commission of Investigation.

In an average year, New York State has had to mail about 20,000 refund checks to persons who overpaid their income tax. Nex year, that state expects to have to put between 3,500,000 and 4,000,000 checks in the mail.

MOSCOW, March 31 (AP) -- A purge in the Communist party of Outer Mongolia was reported today by Tass in a dispatch from Ulan Bator, the capital. It was the second reported shake-up in less than a year.

Your editorial of March 27 referring to General de Gaulle's latest comments on Algeria presents the paradox of praising the General's "long-range wisdom" while judging these same views to be "unrealistic."
ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law tonight a $20,000,000 salary increase for state employes. It takes effect tomorrow.

TOKYO, March 26 -- Japanese law enforcement authorities are studying the effect of an anti-prostitution law that will be a year old April 1. Statistics and other indicators tend to show that the law has been difficult to enforce and that commercial vice, previously restricted largely to licensed quarters, has spread to other neighborhoods in both large and small cities.
The state's new 2-cents-a-pack increase in cigarettes found only limited numbers of smokers standing in line yesterday to beat the jump, effective today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Prices of farm products increased 0.4 per cent in the month ended March 15. This offset a decline of the same amount a month earlier. The most important price increases were reported for cotton, beef cattle, onions, tomatoes, cucumbers, corn and wheat.
LONDON, March 31 -- The first round-the-world jet airliner service began tonight with the departure from London airport of a Britannia.
The World-Telegram and Sun chapel of New York Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six) announced yesterday that it had asked for an early strike vote against ten New York newspapers.

Twenty years ago today, with Republican power finally crushed, Generalissimo Francisco Franco became undisputed head of state in all of Spain, "responsible," as he put it, "only to God and to history." What God's judgment will be is beyond knowledge; what history will say cannot be very flattering, for Spain today is an almost bankrupt nation, backward in virtually every material sense, politically unformed, socially divided.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Edward K. Laux, traffic manager for the Port of New York Authority, declared here today that the eastern railroads and the East Coast ports should work in "unison" to fight competition from the St. Lawrence seaway.
NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was said to have assured a Tibetan delegation today that he would try to help the Tibetan cause through diplomatic channels.

Emanuel M. Brotman, vice president of the J. I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation, has been elected to the board of directors of the parent company, J. I. Kislak, Inc., New Jersey realty organization. Mr. Brotman also has been made manager of the mortgage division.

CHICAGO, March 31 (UPI) -- Lorne Ferguson's goal in the third period and another by Glen Skov eased the Chicago Black Hawks into a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The result squared their four-of-seven-game semi-final hockey series for the Stanley Cup at two games each.
COLUMBUS, Ga., March 31 (AP) -- Ralph McGill, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, canceled plans tonight to address the League of Women Voters here on "The Current School Crisis in Georgia."

A WEEK ago today in this space I recorded my admiration for the daring and enterprise of two young Englishmen whose strenuous adventures in Nuristan, a remote and desolate region in northeastern Afghanistan, are described in Eric Newby's entertaining book, "A Short Walk: A Preposterous Adventure." Now that I have read "A Person From England: And Other Travelers to Turkestan,"* by Fitzroy Maclean I realize that I was too easily impressed.

DETROIT, March 31 -- The Chrysler Corporation, whose auto output had to be cut sharply during a long strike against its chief supplier of glass, plans to begin manufacturing its own glass early next year.

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- The Indian Government has authorized a six-month extension of The Times of India's agreement with The Associated Press of the United States, according to authoritative sources.

The second National Library Week sponsored by the National Book Committee in cooperation with the American Library Association will be observed April 12-18. Throughout the United States some 5,000 communities will celebrate the week and in conjunction with its slogan, "Wake Up and Read!" will stress the importance of reading in America and the importance of America's multitude of libraries -- public, private, school and college.

ALMA, Ga., March 31 (AP) -- A cargo plane carrying the bodies of three Michigan men who died in Florida caught fire, exploded and crashed near here last night. The two members of the crew were killed.

The American Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission have begun an investigation of recent buying and selling of two highly active stocks -- those of the General Development Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc.
BONN, Germany, March 31 -- Soviet fighter aircraft repeatedly menaced a United States military transport flying between West Berlin and West Germany Friday, it was disclosed today.
MEXICO CITY, March 31 -- The Mexican Government is faced with a crisis as a result of the railroad strike that began last Wednesday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 31 -- New theories about the motions of electrons through metals appear to have been confirmed by recent experiments, it was reported today at the American Physical Society's meeting here.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A stinging nine-point indictment of the "failures" of the Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy was issued today by the Democratic Advisory Council.
MEXICO CITY, April 1 -Two Soviet diplomats who were ordered last night to leave Mexico will fly to Canada Friday morning en route home.
ROCKLEIGH, N. J., April 1 Bergen County's first publicly owned golf course was opened today by the Park Commission.

CHICAGO April 1 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices declined again today. With the market weak to 25 cents a hundred pounds lower, the top price went to $17 off 25c from the high of yesterday. Mostly prime slaughter steers in the 1,100 to 1,300 lb. range brought $35.25 to $36 on an irregular market. Good to choice wooled slaughter lambs moved at $20.50 to $21.75 with prices strong.
Trading in the stock of the General Development Corporation continued a turbulent, downward course yesterday.
LONDON, Thursday, April 2 (Reuters) -- Gambling Britons increased their spending on legal soccer pools to 85,000,000 ($238,000,000) last year, an average of 1 14s ($4.76) a person.

TRENTON, April 1 -- Spokesmen for two major health groups in New Jersey urged the state today to cease committing patients to mental institutions solely on the ground that they could not distinguish right from wrong.
Even beggars have a Baedeker.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Following is the text of the letters, made public by the White House today, between Meade Alcorn, Republican National Committee chairman who resigned, and President Eisenhower:
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky was reported slated tonight as the next Republican National Chairman.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 1 -- An order for the partial mobilization of Israeli Army units was broadcast tonight by the Government radio station. It was officially described later as "a notification of routine maneuvers."
The city set up new Housing and Building sections of the Magistrates' Court in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday to deal harshly with slum landlords.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 -Arab League efforts to mediate the dispute between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq seemed on the verge of failure tonight.
LONDON, April 1 -- Industrial issues advanced strongly on the stock market today, and gains of a shilling (14 cents) or more were common.
The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that on April 24 it would observe its quarquicentennial even if there is no such thing.
City Hall learned yesterday that the city's firemen want their top salary increased to $7,500 a year. The ceiling for a first-grade fireman now is $5.881 a year.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 1 -- The no-hit relief pitching of Frank Partlow enabled Army to beat Fordham, 6 to 5, in the season's opener for both teams at Doubleday Field today. The game was called at the end of the eighth inning by agreement.

RICHMOND, Va., April 1 (UPI) -- A legislative commission recommended today that communities and individuals in Virginia receive the greatest possible "freedom of choice" in coping with future school integration.

With the approach of spring the time has come for housecleaning. Since it is time for spring cleaning, it also is time for the White Elephant Sale. These go hand in hand, or, since elephants are involved, it might be better to say they go trunk to tail.
The attempt to remedy what the services widely regard as a governmental breach of faith has reached a critical state.

IT takes all kinds of life to animate our town. And its awesome variety inevitably produces all kinds of writers to interpret existence in these parts. Among them they tend to suggest that no generalization about New York is wholly false -- not even this one.

The Consolidated Electrodynamics Corporation announced yesterday plus to file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $7,600,000 of twenty - five - year convertible subordinated debentures.
ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Rockefeller moved today to set up a $956,000 loan fund for students at twenty-three institutions in the State University.
May I concur with your March 27 editorial "The Mayor's Dilemma." As an unaffiliated teacher I too am in a dilemma.

All world and domestic sugar positions fell to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The world sugar spot price was off 4 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to 2.94 cents, the lowest level since the fixed prices of World War II. The domestic futures volume was the largest since Jan. 9, 1957.
TACOMA, Wash., April 1 (AP) -- An Air Force transport plane with four men aboard plunged to earth in flames tonight, fifteen miles east of McChord Air Force Base.
MIAMI, April 1 -- Irritated at the white man's encroaching on what they call their property, representatives of some 180,000 North American Indians have taken steps to form a united Indian Nation.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The Oil Import Administration today set United States allocations for residual fuel oil imports at 347,311 barrels a day for the period ending on June 30.
Robert Moses said yesterday that fires in the city's loft area "ought to teach somebody something" about the "soundness and foresight" of his slum redevelopment projects.
For twelve innings yesterday St. John's Frank Franceschini and New York University's Bruce Campbell waged a remarkable pitching duel in the team's Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference opener.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has notified Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, that an official of his union has refused to testify before a New York County grand jury investigating alleged bribery of union representatives.

The rapid disappearance of mass transportation serving New York - the ferries, many commuter trains, and the elevateds -- is more than an ominous development. Even now we can see what reliance on individual transportation -- a medieval concept in a mass-production age -- is doing to jam our streets, paralyze our traffic and lacerate our nerves.
Prime-risk fixed income investments had another good day yesterday, although mostly on the quiet side.

Sales of the American Tobacco Company show "a very healthy increase" for the first eleven weeks of 1959, Paul M. Hahn, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Flemington, N. J., yesterday. Net income for the first quarter is expected to approach the $12,439,000 or $1.79 a share cleared in the initial three months of last year, he said.
ORLANDO, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- Baltimore traded Billy Loes, its temperamental righthanded pitcher, to the Washington Senators today for Vito Valentinetti, also a righthander.

Eight Union Square store operators were directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein to produce all of their records relating to the sale of Revlon products and to refrain from selling them at below prices set by Revlon.

EXCEPT for the magnificent Spanishness of his name, Generalissimo Francisco Paulino Hermenegildo Teodulo Franco y Bahamonde is said to be remarkably un-Spanish. That is not to say that there is any doubt about is Spanish roots.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Soviet Union has halted temporarily the travel of foreign diplomats outside Moscow except to Leningrad, the State Department announced today. The United States retaliated by forbidding Soviet officials here to travel outside Washington except to New York.
Charges against twenty-four teen-agers accused of disorderly conduct in the vandalizing of a BMT train March 20 were dismissed yesterday.

Sales of the eight major department stores and their branches in the New York area last month dropped 2.5 per cent below the volume of March, 1958, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. The decline, coming in an Easter month, was caused partly by one less Saturday shopping day this year and partly because sales of hard goods were slow.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, March 11 -- African workers in this republic earn the equivalent of less than 50 cents a day. The average African family's annual money income in what used to be French Equatorial Africa is about $40 a year.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 -Golfdom's most unusual tournament, the Masters, will get under way again tomorrow at the Augusta National Golf Club. For the twenty-third time, the long picturesque course through the pines will be the setting for the 72-hole tourney.

As the North Atlantic Council meets in its tenth anniversary session in Washington today to cope with the Soviet threat to Berlin it is confronted with another Soviet attempt to weary the West into step-by-step compliance with Soviet demands.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 1 -- The Commission on Human Rights added a provision today to the draft declaration on the rights of the child that would give social protection to children born out of wedlock.
Dense fog that reduced visibility to zero in the city yesterday caused the deaths of two drivers in a fiery, seven-truck collision on the New Jersey Turnpike.

United States railroads in the last few years have appealed strenuously for an amendment to the Interstate Commerce Act that would permit them to enter any other form of transportation. Last year, when Congress was investigating the "precarious" financial plight of the railroads, two dozen top railroad executives suggested this freedom would go a long way towards increasing earnings.

AS an innovation in its ninety-second annual exhibition the American Watercolor Society is including fifty examples by half that number of British artists in the big show that opens to the public today in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

THE eighth Artur Schnabel Memorial Concert was given last night at the Metropolitan Museum. As customary, there was some Schnabel music on the program -- the Seven Piano Pieces, written in 1946, five years before the pianist-composer's death.

Benefiting from a moderate early pace Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Village Idiot ran stoutly through the stretch at Jamaica yesterday and won the $7,500 Linden. Three-quarters of a length back was Mystic II, the $1.25-to-$1 favorite among six starters.
Joseph Barbara Sr., host at the Apalachin, N. Y., gangland convention in 1957, is physically able to undergo questioning, three heart specialists reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- A majority of House members favor passage of the Kennedy-Ervin labor-management reform bill, a union survey indicated today.
Although she was divorced eighteen years ago, a retired teacher was told yesterday in State Supreme Court that she was entitled to alimony.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The flight of a C-130 cargo plane into Berlin Friday was a longplanned test linked to the crisis over that city, it was indicated today.
Directors of the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. The move is subject to the approval of shareholders at the annual meeting May 11.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower appealed to Chamber of Commerce members today to help keep the budget balanced:

BENEATH the outward sophistication of today's teenagers are an essential innocence and a longing for emotional security. All three qualities are reflected in the music that they have called their own: rock 'n' roll.

YONKERS, April 1 -- Despite an adverse ruling from the Public Service Commission today the ninety members of the Lincoln Commuters Club here were confident that their chartered bus service into Manhattan would continue.
New York City was in gay holiday mood yesterday. The people of city and suburb, converging on Manhattan on a lovely spring day, did the town as it seldom is done, from the Battery to Inwood Hill.
CHICAGO, April 1 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey urged tonight that more attention be paid to the "potentially explosive" Middle East situation.

The H. L. Green Company, big variety store chain, last night chose Joseph H. Unger as its president. The post had been vacant since last Friday, when Maurice E. Olen resigned as president and director.
VIENNA, April 1 -- Independent peasants in Rumania who maraged to survive all previous land-collectivization drives are scheduled to disappear from the economic scene in the near future.
The Spare Realty Corporation, Theodore Ornstein, president, has purchased the twelvestory and penthouse office building at 63 Vesey Street in the City Hall district.
The tanker Valchem was still under way when she and the Grace liner Santa Rosa collided last Thursday, the Santa Rosa's second mate testified yesterday.

A collection of biographical sketches by Max Eastman will be published next Thursday by Farrar, Straus Cudahy, entitled "Great Companions." As a writer, critic, poet, teacher and editor, Mr. Eastman has known many of America's literary and political figures since the turn of the century.
The price of pig lead was reduced 1/2-cent a pound yesterday to 11 cents by a large custom smelter. Other sellers, including smelters and pine producers, soon matched the lower quotation.

When the Senate returns to Washington after its Easter holiday, one of its first responsibilities should be to put an end to the long and wholly frivolous delay which has occurred over confirmation of the President's nomination of Lewis L. Strauss to be Secretary of Commerce. This nomination went to the Senate as soon as it met in January.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Suits to compel the Senate and House to make public payrollexpense records were filed today in Federal District Court.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -Walter S. Robertson, unrelenting opponent of United States recognition of Communist China, resigned today as Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs. The resignation will become effective July 1.
The Ford Foundation has made a terminal grant of $5,000,000 to the National Educational Television and Radio Center.
The Long Island Rail Road's latest experiment in improving commuter relations got off to an uncertain start yesterday. The trouble was it didn't rain.
The city's water chief, Armand D'Angelo, peered through a murky fog from an airplane flying low over Westchester and Putnam Counties yesterday and suddenly looked very unhappy.

The appointment of Albert T. Peagan as vice presidentoperations of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was announced yesterday by George Alpert, president. In other changes, Richard J. Duggan was named general manager-transportation and Russell H. Davis was appointed mechanical superintendent.
Sales of the W. T. Grant Company last year were the highest in the fifty-two-yearhistory of the variety chain. Earnings were the second largest, the company reported yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, April 1 -- A Government official publicly rebuked Peiping today for again accusing India of helping direct the Tibetan uprising.
Mayor Wagner sent to the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday an executive expense budget of $2,173,113,999 for the fiscal year starting July 1.

What lies behind Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's insistence on a meeting at the summit? Why has he maneuvered so stubbornly for Big Four talks? These questions, in the opinion of specialists on Soviet affairs, touch upon a widely neglected aspect of the Berlin crisis.

In your editorial of March 26 entitled "The Legislative Session" you note that "many things were, as usual, left undone, some mistakes were made and the final rush to adjourn was a nightmare example of defective legislative process."
ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

MANY of the "compleat" trout anglers seen on the opening day of the New York State season carried enough equipment to sink a deep-sea trawler. It's all right to have it if you can afford it and are strong enough to carry it, but a man can be sensible and selective, catch fish and be comfortable, too. The general idea, we believe, is not just to kill fish, but to enjoy yourself.

SUMMIT, N. J., April 1 -The merger of the Summit Junior Service League with the Junior League of Morristown was announced today jointly by Mrs. Archibald A. Smith 2d and Mrs. Richard R. Hough, respective presidents of the two groups.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway reported yesterday a gain in both revenues and earnings for March. Gross income rose to $29,508,000 from $28,184,000 a year ago, while net income was $3,840,000, compared with $3,217,000.

R. H. Macy and Company and a union representing its employes reached agreement last night on a new two-year contract. The settlement provides a $5 wage increase, with $3 to be paid the first year and $2 the second.

DETROIT, April 1 -- The American Motors Corporation and Sonotone Corporation announced today a long-range development project to explore the possibilities for what they called a "revolutionary electric automobile."
Mayor Wagner last night told the New York Young Democratic Club that he was about to revive his appeal for the creation of a nine-member commission to revise the city's charter.
One of the largest railroad shipments of lumber ever made into the metropolitan area passed through New York yesterday on its way to lumber dealers on Long Island.

To joyous pealing of bronze bells and ancient Byzantine chanting of an unaccompanied men's choir, amid scores of priests in golden and crimson robes, a new Archbishop of the Greek Orthodox Church ascended his throne here yesterday morning.

Mayor Wagner's executive budget of $2,173,113,999 for the fiscal year 1959-60 is described in his message as having been "very difficult to prepare," and is based on "an inadequate revenue program." But despite the "inadequacy" it represents an increase of $177,640,909 over spending of the current year, described a year ago as a "budget of austerity."
A severe virus infection prevented Claudette Colbert, who is co-starred with Charles Boyer in "The Marriage-Go-Round," from going on yesterday afternoon and evening at the Plymouth.
RALEIGH, N. C., April 1 (AP) -- A bill that would permit sterilization as a means of curbing illegitimate births was debated at a legislative public hearing today.

A health club with gymnasium, bowling alleys and an ice skating rink will be established in the downtown insurance district where Vic Tanny Enterprises has leased space in the building at 9 to 15 Dutch Street and the continguous building at 80 Nassau Street.

OTTAWA, April 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Soviet Union plans to make its already active Northeast sea passage a communications lifeline linking the Soviet west with the Far East under a new seven-year program.
Prices moved irregularly on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
The Scholarship Fund of International House will benefit from the fourth annual Festival of the Arts to be held at the house, 500 Riverside Drive, April 17 to 19.

The Raylite Electric Corporation, manufacturer of Christmas ornaments, has leased the six-story building containing 40,000 square feet of space at 285 East 137th Street, the Bronx, from the Summit Holding Corporation. Goldberg-Kornspun Associates, Inc., was the broker. The building will be used as a warehouse.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 31 -- Shell Company of Thailand, Ltd., and the Standard Vacuum Oil Company, who together have a $30,000,000 investment in Thailand, today notified the Thai Government that they might have to withdraw from this country if the Government should go through with an agreement for giving a monopoly to the Eastern Petroleum Company, which is registered in Panama.
Mayor Wagner called on New Yorkers yesterday to join him in signing a pledge to uphold the city's Fair Housing Practices Law.

ONE of the great merits of the Metropolitan Opera's production of Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" is its strength as an ensemble effort. When that opera was given for the fourth time last night that unified strength was maintained, even though three of the six main roles were in new hands.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Eisenhower has been telling callers he wants to get away from the White House for a few days and will leave for Augusta, Ga., early next week for some golf and sunshine.
A city magistrate who couldn't decide in his courtroom whether two defendants or two patrolmen were correct about traffic signs went to the scenes of the alleged violations yesterday.

EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., April 1 -- Radiation in doses ordinarily lethal to man has greatly prolonged the lives of patients dying of leukemia, according to a report at a meeting here sponsored by the American Cancer Society.

CINCINNATI, April 1 (AP) -- John W. Humphrey, president of the Philip Carey Manufacturing Company, announced today that only one New Yorker from the independent proxy committee had been elected to the board of directors.
MONTREAL, April 1 -- The Port of Montreal opened for the 1959 season today with the arrival of the 5,000-ton German freighter Volumnia.

Discovery of a tax-free situation in Puerto Rico favorable to international base company operations is among the newest of the island commonwealth's development potentials, a business conference was told yesterday.
Exploration of the last eight years has revealed an astonishing richness of life within the trenches that cut into the ocean floors.

The embattled Province of Newfoundland celebrated the tenth anniversary of its confederation with Canada yesterday in a state of profound grievance. Premier Joseph R. Smallwood is fighting with customary zest to defend his labor union methods and to get more money from Ottawa for Newfoundland. From this distance he seems to be fighting a losing, if gallant, battle.
The Secretary of the Navy has approved the retirement of Vice Admiral John M. Will, effective July 1.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 1 (AP) -- Don Kierbow of Los Angeles turned in the biggest upset of the San Juan International tennis tournament today, when he beat Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt, 6 -- 4, 9 -- 7, in the second round.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Committee for a National Trade Policy urged officials today to "exert every effort" to persuade countries to relax restrictions against United States goods.
The president of the International Typographical Union said yesterday that he expected to come here next week to try to settle a dispute between ten New York newspapers and their union printers.

WHITE PLAINS, April 1 -Westchester County expenditures for parkway modernization plans, now pigeonholed, have reached $364,175. The plans have not been used chiefly because of the inadequacy of toll proceeds and the unwillingness of the state to contribute to reconstruction.

The Children's Health Service, an agency that provides health supervision for about 5,000 infants and pre-school children yearly, will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show in the Terrace Room of the Plaza on April 22.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Montgomery Clift has been signed to co-star with Elizabeth Taylor in the film version of Tennessee Williams' play, "Suddenly Last Summer."

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers coasted to an 8-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today on the hitting of Duke Snider and Gil Hodges and the combined seven-hit performance of three pitchers.

MADRID, April 1 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco warned the Spanish nation -- and particularly Spanish youth -- today to remain ever on guard against the menace of communism. It is a Spanish characteristic to relax after great effort into "lassitude and overconfidence," he remarked.

It is hard to realize the extent of the changes in political structures that have swept across Africa in the last ten years -- or even in the last two or three, for that matter. We are witnessing a gigantic political revolution unlike anything in Africa's previous history. For the most part, happily, it has been peaceful. In the light of the immense changes that have been made, the violent episodes have been relatively small.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen was restrained yesterday by a Federal Court order from striking on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad. The court acted pending the outcome of a hearing next Tuesday on an application of the road for a preliminary injunction.
KALIMPONG, India, April 1 -- Communist Chinese troops are carting off thousands of Tibetans to do forced labor, according to authoritative reports from Tibet tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -Railroad industry and labor officials held a private meeting today on the prospects for resuming negotiations on featherbedding or make-work practices.
DORTMUND, Germany, April 1 (UPI) -- The World Table Tennis Federation today rejected a United States proposal to eliminate the middle line in doubles play. The vote was 47 -- 40.

THE sun never sets on the British Empire, but the Empire's greatness certainly was not founded on its heavyweight fist-fighters. If it had been, it would have been built on their prostrate bodies for English heavyweights have an affinity for the horizontal.

Following are textual excerpts (with digests of the remaining parts) from Mayor Wagner's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday in submitting his executive budget for the fiscal year 1959-60, which begins July 1:
MYSTIC, Conn., April 1 (AP) -- Admiral Donald B. McMillan's Artic exploring schooner Bowdoin has been given to the Marine Historical Association here.
Early spring splashes of horticultural color appeared in Central Park yesterday.

A Greenwich Village real estate man whose office sign proclaimed his refusal to show apartments to Negroes failed yesterday in a legal maneuver to avoid appearing before the Commission on Intergroup Relations.

The Justice Department opened an antitrust investigation yesterday into the multimillion-dollar ladies garment industry, with emphasis on racketeering in garment trucking. In an atmosphere of secrecy, a special Federal grand jury was impaneled here and minutes later was hearing evidence presented by the New York office of the Antitrust Division.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- A "very strong" earthquake shook an area from the California coast to central Nevada today.

The State Tax Commission decided yesterday that the pay of merchant seamen was subject to withholding for the state income tax after all. Notice to this effect was telegraphed to a half dozen representatives of steamship lines.
ROME, April 1 -- Pope John XXIII encouraged and blessed today the efforts of Negro intellectuals to promote culture among their people.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday large gains in gross revenues and net income through February.

ATHENS, Ga., April 1 -Stockholders of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation at their annual meeting here today heard Mark W. Cresap Jr., president, predict a moderate gain in new orders this year compared with the 1958 level.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 1 -Roman Catholic teachers were advised here today to get away from the classroom and "invade the community" if they were to meet the problems of juvenile delinquency.
BARBOURVILLE, Ky., April 1 (AP) -- Three United Mine Workers pickets were charged with murder today in the slaying of a non-union mine operator in eastern Kentucky's struck coalfields.
LYONS, N. J., April 1 -- The more potent the tranquilizing drug, the better the results and the fewer side effects, a study on drug therapy for mental illness has found.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities had shown the following principal changes for the week ended last Saturday:
DETROIT, April 1 (AP) -The defending champion, Jim Poole, moved into the semi-finals of the United States badminton championships tonight with three victories.
PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- Charles F. Seabrook, former frozen-food executive, won his release today from a private hospital.
LONDON, April 1 -- With Britain's economy much stronger than at any time in recent years, the Government is planning to continue its policy of economic expansion this year.
GARY, Ind., April 1 (UPI) -Striking school teachers in the Gary area ended their picketing of seven schools today and voted to go back to their classrooms.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- A 20 per cent reduction in automobile insurance rates for safe drivers was announced today by more than 200 companies operating in California. This reduction will be offset by rate increases for reckless motorists.
Talks have been held that may lead to a merger of Cohen Aleshire, Inc., with Fletcher D. Richards, Inc.
Colombia Gas System, Inc., awarded the underwriting yesterday of its 1,799,057-share stockholder subscription offering to a group led by Lehman Brothers and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.

CAOLANH, Vietnam, April 1 -- This tidy little town in the rich Mekong Delta of South Vietnam played a part today in a most important -- and probably the quietest and most orderly -- agrarian land reform movement being carried out anywhere in Southeast Asia.

MUNICH, West Germany, April 1 (Reuters) -- The mother of the Duke of Edinburgh, Princess Alice of Greece, was among the seventy members of the European aristocracy who attended the wedding of Princess Dorothea of Hesse to Prince Friedrich zu Windisch-Graetz here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -The "beat generation" of San Francisco's North Beach and the religious healing cults of the Sudanese bush shared the psychiatrist's couch today at the annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association.
The proposed conversion of Lexington Avenue to one-way southbound traffic was attacked yesterday by a bus company and a property owners and merchants' association.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were mostly higher yesterday. Except for the December option, which was unchanged, gains ran from 3 to 12 points (15 to 60 cents a bale).
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appointed Senator Gordon Allott today to the Alaska International Rail and Highway Commission.
Alexander L. Guterma filed a $10,000,000 damage suit in Federal Court yesterday against a group he accused of causing his troubles with the United States Government.

TOKYO, April 1 -- The commanding general of United States forces in Japan is a hero today to seven enlisted men, all on emergency leave in the United States. He personally put them back on a California-bound airplane after they had

The Louisville and Nashville Railroad, one of the nation's leading bituminous coal carriers and the second largest railroad in the South, announced the election yesterday of William H. Kendall, 49, as president.

NEWARK, April 1 -- Brotherhoods of the New York Central Railroad offered today to waive their "foreign track" bonus if the road agreed with the Pennsylvania Railroad to bring West Shore division trains from Weehawken to Jersey City.
Governor Rockefeller replied yesterday to sharp Democratic criticism of the state's treatment of New York City by counseling "political restraint."
A Brooklyn mother who had promised restitution at 15 cents a week for the $1,335.60 she admitted receiving illegally on relief was sentenced yesterday to a year in the penitentiary.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that Mayor Wagner's executive budget allocations for education were a "disappointment."

BOSTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, pulled together by Bob Cousy and Frank Ramsey, defeating the Syracuse Nationals, 130 -- 125, tonight in the deciding game of the National Basketball Association Eastern play-offs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- The United Nations reported today that an increasing demand for secondary education in non-self-governing territories was rapidly outstripping the available facilities.

THE new Fiberglas Fabric Center of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation will open today on the street floor of Corning's glass skyscraper at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street. The center formerly was at 16 East Fifty-sixth Street.
YONKERS, April 1 -- What has been for the past decade the "best buy" at local harness racing tracks -- the official program -still is a good buy. However, it costs more.
Sgt. Ernie Bilko will leave television's front lines at the end of this season.

Approximately 150 registrants attended yesterday's opening of the American Film Festival at the Statler Hilton Hotel. The initial competitive screening sessions drew nontheatrical film representatives, including producers, sponsors, distributors and educators, from fifteen states, Canada and India.
American Catholic philosophers were encouraged yesterday to engage in continued discussion of problems of common interest with philosophers of other schools of thought.
The strike of 5,000 Pennsylvania blouse makers took on last night major political and legal overtones.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 -- The Yankees rang the bell on a number of fronts today as they polished off the Cardinals, 5 to 1.

Mrs. Victor H. Koltun of Brooklyn was disturbed, so she wrote a letter to this newspaper. She breeds one dachshund in her apartment and three at a friend's place on Long Island. Prospective buyers sometimes laughed when she quoted the price of a puppy, she wrote.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Scientific teams were named today to help develop and put into orbit radio stations and astronomical observatories.
DALLAS, April 1 (AP) -- Roy Harris jabbed his way to a unanimous decision over Donnie Fleeman tonight in a twelve-round nationally televised heavyweight bout.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors has replied strongly to Congressional critics of his invitation to Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba to address the society's mid-April meeting here.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States, Britain, France and West Germany affirmed today their "sincere desire to negotiate constructively with the Soviet Union in the interests of world peace."
BERLIN, April 1 (UPI) -- The East German Foreign Ministry protested tonight that four Western planes had violated its air space since March 25.
Realty men from the city's five boroughs expressed strong opposition yesterday to the real estate transfer tax under consideration by the Wagner administration.

NEWARK, April 1 -- More than 400 volunteers from the Junior Leagues of Montclair, Newark, the Oranges and Short Hills are expected to staff the New Jersey headquarters for the Tri-State Mental Health Telethon.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said tonight that the Western powers must not abandon the 2,000,000 people in West Berlin. In a crowded news...

HAVANA, April 1 -- The Cuban Revolutionary Government today reduced to 4 per cent interest payments of mortgages on houses and apartment buildings affected by a recent rent law. That law reduced rents by 30 to 50 per cent.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- The president of the National Tea Company has denied Government charges that National's acquisitions tended to create a monopoly.
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., April 1 -- Work on the $13,000,000 Suffolk Bomarc Missile Base was brought almost to a halt today by a picket line of five ironwork riggers.
BONN, Germany, April 1 -- The Soviet Embassy in East Berlin said today that incidents might occur if the United States failed to keep its planes below 10,000 feet on their flights to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -New York State has been allotted $102,526,000 in a report on projected airport programs released today by the Federal Aviation Agency. The contemplated program, for the years 1959 through 1962, earmarks $26,552,000 for New Jersey and $11,628,000 for Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Defense Department has told the military services to encourage their equipment makers to share some defense orders with Canadian industry.

An increase of 815,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies aggregated 212,954,000 barrels, compared with 212,139,000 a week earlier and 216,647,000 a year ago.
THE word gourmet has been overworked to the point of nausea," Andre Surmain, a local gastronome, was saying this week. "It is more accurate to talk of foods and menus that have style."
WASHINGTON, April 1 -The Government received today a detailed report with recommendations for spurring the overseas investment and lending of American private business and financial institutions.
RABAT, Morocco, April 1 (Reuters) -- Reliable informants said today thirteen Moroccan Jewish men had been arrested for trying to flee from Morocco clandestinely.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A New York public welfare official told a national conference of voluntary family agencies today that for real rehabilitation one agency must take primary responsibility and initiative for each "multiple-problem" family.

Mixed results were reported in bank statements for the first quarter of 1959. Earnings for most banks were somewhat higher, but deposits, resources and loans were lower than in the corresponding quarter of 1958.
ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -- Thousands of fishermen turned out in fair weather, and many good catches were reported today on the new state-wide opening date for trout and land-locked salmon fishing.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Government argued in the Supreme Court today that some injustice to individuals might be necessary for an effective industrial security program.
The Port of New York Authority battled before the City Planning Commission yesterday to keep new or expanded bus terminals from a section of midtown.
New public revenue bonds to finance purchase of Boston's Sumner Tunnel and the construction of an adjoining twolane tunnel will be sold on April 9, according to investment bankers here.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- A renewal of export business and indications of more to come sparked an active demand for wheat, corn and rye futures on the Board of Trade today.
