For a decade it has not been possible for American newsmen to enter mainland China to observe and report to the American public. This constitutes a violation of our fundamental right to be informed about an entire quarter of the world's population.
EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., April 2 -- An era of relative plenty is dawning in new drugs available for testing in cancer patients.
CATAVI, Bolivia, April 2 -- Three thousand workers at Bolivia's largest tin mine demonstrated here tonight against living costs, the Government and "United States imperialism."
REPRESENTATIVES of the American fashion industry are set to do a hard-sell job when American National Exhibition opens in Moscow this summer.
Ten years ago the J. Walter Thompson Company lost the Chase Sanborn coffee account. Yesterday it got it back.

NEWARK, April 2 -- In the last eight years the composition of Newark's population has undergone some sharp changes. There has been a 1 per cent drop in the city's population from 417,172 in 1950 to 411,288, but the non-white population, mostly Negroes, has increased 109 per cent.

MONTREAL, April 2 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens scored four times in the first 17 minutes and staved off a late rush by the Chicago Black Hawks to nail down a 4-2 triumph tonight. The Canadiens thus gained a 3 -- 2 lead in the semi-final Stanley Cup play-off series.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 (UPI) -- Sal Maglie, a key figure in National League pennant championships won by the Giants and Dodgers, approached the end of his major league career today when the St. Louis Cardinals announced they would release him unconditionally.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The foreign ministers assembled here for the tenth anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization might have abandoned hope of the United States Government as an effective partner if they had accepted as unvarying fact the "greeting card" issued under the authority of the Advisory Council of the Democratic National Committee.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -Arthur S. Flemming said today that all programs and regulations in his department would be keyed to strengthening family life.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said at a news conference today that the great powers had a "serious will to negotiate" on the Berlin question -- not "to mark time but in order to get somewhere."
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations, called Tibet today "the Hungary of Asia."

Members of the committee arranging the Founder's Dinner for the Eleanor Roosevelt Institute for Cancer Research and Representative James Roosevelt of California will be guests at a cocktail party to be given Monday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rosoff of 450 East Sixty-third Street.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., April 2 -- A twenty-two-mile chase through Nassau and Suffolk Counties last night that involved seven police cars resulted in injuries to six persons and the seizure of a teen-ager.

A Visitor, Thinking Aloud The wonder is, said the visitor as he pulled a pocket tin of tobacco from his coat and filled his pipe with pinches of dark and stringy leaf, that the people of the world get along as well as they do.

LAUREL, Md., April 2 (AP) -- Raul Sterling held Battle Neck back from the blistering early pace, then sent his mount ahead late in the stretch for a triumph in the Georgetown Purse at Laurel race course today.
NEW HAVEN, April 2 (AP) -- A Yale University graduate student from England was attacked early today by three youths in the campus area.
The First Boston Corporation and associates today are offering $7,000,000 of 4 3/4 per cent Gulf Power Company's first mortgage bonds, due in 1989, Priced at 101.25 to yield 4.67 per cent.
LONDON, April 2 -- Sir Oswald Mosley, Britain's leading Fascist before World War II, is to seek a seat in the House of Commons at the next general election.

"The King's War 1641-1647"* describes the war itself in England, Scotland and Ireland from its uncertain beginning until the final defeat of the Royalist armies.

All segments of the alcoholic beverage industry should keep a "careful watch" over Federal and state taxes, Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president and secretary of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, urged yesterday.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 2 -- Iraq terminated her contract today with Mackenzie Co., British engineering consultants, for a new steel plant in Baghdad. The work will be carried on by the Soviet Union.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 2 (AP) -- T. C. Chung of San Jose, Calif., the 112-pound intercollegiate boxing champion of 1958, took a big step tonight toward the division title in the national Amateur Athletic Union senior tournament.

TOKYO, April 2 -- Dr. David M. Bosworth, former president of the American Orthopedic Society and director of three hospitals in New York City, has been elected the first foreign member of the Japan Orthopedic Society.

Laramore, Douglass Popham of New York, Inc., engineers, leased a floor in the building at 117 Liberty Street from Frederick Brown. Mr. Brown also leased large space in the same building to the U B S Chemical Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., for its domestic and foreign-sales office.

A United States Assistant Attorney General, George Cochran Doub, presumed to tell the Supreme Court on Wednesday that when it is necessary to balance "an injustice, an inequity," against "the safety of the Government" he thought "the people of the United States have the right to the benefit of the doubt."
PARIS, April 2 -- Financial, political and military problems engendered by the Algerian war brought high Government officials together today for consultation.

SHIKO MUNAKATA, a 55-year-old Japanese artist, has gained broad recognition for his woodblock prints. A large group of his recent woodcuts and several drawings are now on view at the Willard Gallery, 23 West Fifty-sixth Street.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 2 -- Gov. J. Millard Tawes signed the new Potomac River treaty with Virginia today after its approval yesterday by the House of Delegates.

With rival young promoters battling over his future fights, it was revealed yesterday that Floyd Patterson, heavyweight boxing champion, would defend against Ingemar Johansson of Sweden at Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, June 25.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -Prices of grain futures ranged broadly in both directions on the Board of Trade today.

Stockholders of Peoples Gas Light Coke Company were told at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that net income for the first two months of 1959 was $7,915,692, equal to $1.47 a share. This compared with the $4,714,727, or 96 cents a share on fewer shares, reported a year earlier.
TRENTON, April 2 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that New Jersey would reject a request by New York State for cooperation in the administration of its new income tax withholding law.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Communists in the United States are now reported under orders to wear a "new look."

Ogden Phipps' Ingenuity won the feature sprint at the Jamaica race track yesterday, but the accomplishment was hardly a surprise. The daughter of My Request was strongly supported and responded so well that she scored by eight lengths over her nearest rival, the Meadow Stable's Rich Tradition, at five-and-a-half furlongs.

MATTITUCK, L. I., April 2 -- The pressure grew too great tonight and Miss Caroline Bell, a wealthy octogenarian who lives on Love Lane here, decided to give up the stray dogs that she had befriended. It took three station wagons to carry the thirty-nine dogs away.

The annual Spring Festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church will be held in the parish house, 865 Madison Avenue, on the afternoons of April 30 and May 1. The five-story walk-up building containing twenty apartments at 35-38 Ninety-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by the Ilsamek Realty Corporation to an investing client of Herbert Frutkin. The deal was for cash over mortgages amounting to $60,000.

Picketing of the Stork Club, 3 East Fifty-third Street, was resumed last night by two unions under a court stay of a temporary anti-picketing injunction.

Universal-Internationals "Imitation of Life," a color version of the Fannie Hurst novel, with Lana Turner and John Gavin, will have its premiere on April 17 at the Roxy Theatre. Sandra Dee, Dan O'Herlihy, Susan Kohner, Robert Alda and Juanita Moore head the supporting cast.

The New York Women's Bible Society, instead of its yearly benefit luncheon and fashion show, will this year give a tea next Thursday in the parish house of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

Speaking before a distinguished audience representing fifteen allied nations President Eisenhower yesterday called on the free world to close ranks to ward off the Communist menace and to establish a true peace.

CHICAGO, April 2 (UPI) -The price of a haircut for men will go up to $2 in Chicago.
The dense fog that covered the metropolitan area for two days and disrupted land, sea and air travel lifted last night.
NICE, France, April 2 (UPI) -Karol Fageros of Miami scored a 6-1, 6-0 victory over Jeanne Bonnaire of France today in the third round of the Nice international tennis tournament.
DURBAN, South Africa, April 2 -- Serious congestion of the harbor here, by far the busiest in Africa south of the Sahara, has been caused by the refusal of African stevedores to work overtime.

BOSTON, April 2 -- For nearly four hours today, Judge Michael A. Musmanno of the Pennsylvania State Supreme Court pleaded "in the name of universal justice" for a posthumous pardon for the principals in the celebrated Sacco-Venzetti case.

Installation of what is said to be the first electronic computer to control completely a phase of oil refinery operation has just been finished at Port Arthur, Tex.

Several hundred scientists and engineers spent a frustrating afternoon here yesterday discussing some of the wonderful things they might be able to do with ultrahigh frequency radio waves if only someone would present a fresh idea for controlling them.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday for the first time called Mark W. Cresap Jr., president, "chief executive officer of the company."

U Thant, Burma's permanent representative to the United Nations, deplored last night the methods of the West in giving economic aid to underdeveloped countries.

The Lurie Mortgage Corporation, realty financiers, has purchased the four-story business building at 24 East Forty-first Street from a client of Walter Scott Co., L. V. Hoffman Co. was the broker. The building, 25 by 95 feet, will be modernized by the purchasers, who will occupy a floor when the alterations are completed in five or six months.
FOR the homemaker who is planning a new kitchen or is about to remodel an old one, Consolidated Edison will make available, starting Monday, an expanded planning service and several new aids.

Manufacturers of men's clothing are faced with higher production costs and may be forced to raise prices before fall shipments are completed, according to a letter sent yesterday to 7,000 retailers by Jerome I. Udell, chairman of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., clothing manufacturer.

The companies in the Royal Dutch Shell Group last year had a consolidated net income of 150,683,381, or $421,913,467 at the official rate of exchange. This compared with 212,721,031, or $595,618,887, in 1957.

Commodity future closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Wool, coffee, cocoa, hides, rubber, lead and copper rose; sugar and cottonseed oil declined, and price movements for potatoes and zinc were mixed.

SEATTLE, April 2 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board team investigating the sudden 29,000foot plunge of a Pan-Ameriea World Airways 707 Jetliner on Feb. 3 over the North Atlantic heard teatlmony yes/erday' f. hat the accident might not have occurred "if the crew had been properly attentive.

A union once so parochial that its members would not even install electrical equipment made outside the metropolitan area started a mandatory course in world affairs yesterday for all its paid officials and business agents.

ALBANY, April 2 (AP) -- Low bids totaling more than $17,000,000 for three major highway projects were received by the Public Works Department today.

The positive statement which many of his listeners found most interesting was made in response to a question as to his conversations with Russian Premier Khrushchev.
GENEVA, April 2 -- A call for "vigorous measures" to promote economic expansion in Western Europe was sounded today by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

Reductions in the prices of metal cans were announced yesterday by the nation's two leading can manufacturers.

Old crop cotton futures advanced 3 to 7 points yesterday while new crop months were 4 to 10 points lower, but up from the lows of the day. The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest food chain, reported yesterday net income for the first twelve weeks of 1959 totaled $5,878,721. This was an increase of 14 per cent over the $5,146,025 earned in the corresponding period a year ago.
TRENTON, April 3 -- The Appellate Division of Superior Court declared invalid today a Rockleigh zoning ordinance that banned the erection of flatroofed houses in that Bergen County community.

Sugar Ray Robinson's world middleweight boxing title will be vacated on April 15 unless he signs to meet the former titleholder, Carmen Basilio, before thta date, the New York State Athletic Commission ruled yesterday.

Events today: "Don Carlo," 2 P. M., and "La Boheme, 8, Metropolitan Opera; Mikulas Grosz, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Street Scene," City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Glenn Gould, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Helvetia Maennerchor, Town Hall, 8:30; Frantz Casseus, guitarist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:40.
BONN, Germany, April 3 -- West Germany's 600,000 coal miners will go on a five-day, forty-hour week May 1.

DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -Ward's Automative Reports said today the nation's automobile producers would build 577,400 cars in April. The industry built 576,085 cars last month and 316,503 in April last year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 3 -- A campaign of resentful reaction against the United States' Argus atomic bomb experiment in the South Atlantic mounted here today.

The United States investment market wilt be asked to lend $30,000,000 to the Southern Italy Development Fund. This is an undertaking sponsored in 1950 by the Italian Government to carry out a major program of public works, chiefly in the agricultural field, in southern Italy. The fund is officially known as Cassa per il Mezzogiorno.
A crowd, estimated at 2,500 to 3,000, milled through the fourth floor of the Coliseum last night at a benefit preview of a huge art exhibition.

MEXICO CITY, April 3 -- The Soviet Embassy here charged today that the expulsion of two of its diplomats by Mexico was "an unfriendly act which serves those who wish to impede the development of friendly relations between our two countries."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3 -- Three American and four meet records tumbled tonight in the first full session of the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships.

Ralph Ludlam, a land surveyor in Brooklyn for nearly half a century, was the honored guest yesterday at the 150th anniversary celebration of Bartlett, Ludlam, Dill Co. The Brooklyn surveying firm was begun in 1809 by Mr. Ludlam's great-grandfather, Stephen Ludlam.

" I HAVE a problem with cakes sticking to the pan after they have baked. I have tried dusting the bottom of the pan with flour, but the cakes still stick. Nor has it helped to grease the pan with butter before pouring in the batter." Mrs. J. C., New York.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York received a patent this week for its gas "Sniffer" truck, which quietly roams New York City streets looking for trouble. The vehicle is as outwardly conventional as another just patented, a wingless airplane model, is unconventional.

TOLEDO, April 3 (AP) -- Cassius Clay, 17, of Louisville, outpointed the 1957 champion, Lindy Lindmoser of Vancouver, B. C., tonight in the light heavyweight semi-finals of the National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships.

A bank robber suspect was captured yesterday as he was running off with a dummy package of money -- $20 in legitimate $5 bills wrapped around strips of green paper. The bundle had been prepared by the bank for such an occasion.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- An anthropologist told the Family Service Association of America today that the father's role in this country had changed from Victorian lord and master to that of an onlooker at a mother-child coalition.
A 50-year-old fire captain died last night while directing the fight against a small but smoky blaze in a five-story brick building at 539 West 156th Street.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 8 (UPI) -- Calvin Griffith, president of the Washington Senators, asked Commissioner Ford Frick today to void the trade that sent Billy Loes of Baltimore to Washington for Vito Valentinetti. Both players are pitchers.
NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) -- The Dalai Lama reached safety in India by a perilous fifteen-day trek over some of the world's most treacherous mountain territory, his followers said today.

The Miami Window Corporation, makers of aluminum products, yesterday acquired Robert Russell Metals, Inc., producers of aluminum billets. Sidney G. Kusworm Jr., president and general manager of Miami Window in Florida, said the acquisition would give his company an independent production cycle, from the casting of raw aluminum to finished windows and furniture.

Strong trade buying raised world sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Short covering also firmed prices. Final quotations were unchanged to 5 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) up on 46,700 tons.
NORFOLK, Va., April 3 -- Four Navy frogmen emerged from a naval base swimming pool here at 12:06 P. M. today after having set a world record of forty-eight hours under water.

PARIS, April 3 -- When the North Atlantic Treaty was signed ten years ago tomorrow it was foreseen that the alliance's members might meet after a decade to review their commitments with regard to "the development of universal as well as regional arrangements."

The Sprague, one of the largest stern-wheel towboats ever built, is trailing meekly up the Mississippi at the end of a towline drawn by an upstart Diesel craft. The vessels are scheduled to dock at Pittsburgh, Pa., on April 12.

The widows of six men who were among forty-seven persons killed April 6, 1958, in the crash of a Capital Airlines plane in Midland, Mich., filed negligence suits in Federal Court yesterday. They totaled $2,891,380.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Fedreal Communications Commission announced today a reopening of a fourway contest of more than three years ago for television Channel 7 at Miami. The aim is to determine whether any improper influences were involved.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- Corn futures encountered their first solid resistance today after two weeks of moderate to good gains on the Board of Trade.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 -- Fifty of the nation's outstanding sports car rallyists started today in the Jersey 500, second national championship event on the Sports Car Club of America rally calendar. The season opened last month with the Great Orange Blossom Rally in Florida.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 3 -A machine that has been taught to think like a man, and not just for him, was described here today as a means for studying the human problemsolving process.
Protestant concern for the welfare of Puerto Ricans here and in other parts of the country will be expressed this month on three occasions.
" WE'RE not looking for a one-tine fork," John Van Koert said yesterday on the eve of his departure for Europe and the Middle East in search of new sterling silver designers.
NEW DELHI, India, April 3 -- Official confirmation that the Dalai Lama had escaped the Chinese Reds and reached India safely was hailed here today by all quarters except the Indian Communists.
There was no advance warning of the crash between the liner Santa Rosa and the tanker Valchem, Elmir D. Baker ordinary seaman on the tanker said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -Following is the text of a letter today from Senator Pat McNamara, Democrat of Mickigan, to Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Senate Democratic leader:
CATAVI, Bolivia, April 3 -- Victor Urquidi, 28 years old, a tin miner, pulled off his helmet, turned out his head lamp and sat down on an empty dynamite case.
STAATSBURG, N. Y., April 3 (AP) -- The Taconic State Parkway Commission disclosed today plans for an immediate twelve-mile extension of the northern end of the parkway.
Protestants were cautioned yesterday against expecting "too much" from the forthcoming ecumenical council called by Pope John XXIII.

Three four-story buildings at 1256-60 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Eighty-fifth Street, have been sold by the Hemmerdinger Realty Corporation to a client of Arthur Fastenberg, attorney. The structures contain four stores, two offices and eight apartments and are on a lot 62 by 67 feet.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The military was reported today to be stamping as "confidential" all information about its space monkey program. Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, wants to know why.
The largest exhibition of automobiles ever held in this country will open a nine-day run at the New York Coliseum today.
When the Fire Department's Holy Name Society holds its annual communion breakfast tomorrow at the Commodore Hotel, the audience will pay special attention to the Rev. Martin de Porres.

WELLFLEET, Mass., April 3 (UPI) -- Seven fishermen, trapped in an eighty-foot trawler that was being torn apart on a sand bar, plunged into the surf early today. Only four survived the halfmile swim through ten-foot waves.

Some observers contend that the ultimate objective of both the Soviet Union and Arab nationalists is control of oil resources in Iraq. Others hold that Arab nationalists intend to gain greater "prestige" by making Iraq another province of the United Arab Republic, while the Soviets aim to control the entire Persian Gulf area (following the Molotov plan) with Iraq as the logical starting point (in order to outflank the Baghdad Pact).

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 -- The fact that no golfer has won the Masters tournament two years in succession does not disturb Arnold Palmer, who took a two-stroke lead in the second round of the tourney at the Augusta National Golf Club today.
THE trout season will open in West Virginia on April 25. If you'd like to go down and wait for that date, you may have some rewarding days and evenings with large and small - mouth bass and crappie.

The fact that increased United States military aid to Pakistan, in the form of light jet bombers, was announced concurrently with the opening of the annual conference of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization in New Zealand is probably no more than coincidence. Coming at this time, however, the action must be viewed in the light of all its implications and ramifications.

National Securities and Research Corporation, which sponsors and manages National Securities Series, announced yesterday that the combined net assets of its seven openend mutual funds rose to $451,163,635 on March 31.

Your editorial of March 25 "Disengagement" leaves some confusion as to what this term implies in military terms. It has recently been discussed in the press as if it meant the same as a "thinning out" of forces.
MEXICO CITY, April 3 -- "My Fair Lady," under the Spanish title of "Mi Bella Dama," made its debut here last night before a capacity audience in the Palace of Fine Arts.
SCRANTON, Pa., April 3 -The Scranton Corporation today received permission in Federal Court to reorganize under the Bankruptcy Act after charging Alexander L. Guterma with its difficulties.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Another Northern liberal Democratic Senator complained today about the party leadership of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -Old Guard Republican leaders on Capitol Hill opened a fight today to block Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky from becoming the next Republican National Chairman.
New circus acts seem to be virtually impossible to find in the United States, but there are still some in Europe, and specially in the little one-family circuses of Italy and Spain.
The stocks of the General Development Corporation and Universal Controls, Inc., rose sharply in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The gains followed two weeks of sharp slides.
KALIMPONG, India, April 3 -- Sporadic artillery fire was still being heard in Lhasa this week-end, and Kalimpong was the first place in the world to know about it.
PARIS, April 3 (AP) -- The French High Committee of Studies on Alcoholism reported today that wine is a powerful germ killer whose action is comparable with that of penicillin.
Robert Anderson's latest play, "Silent Night, Lonely Night," which is set in a New England college town, will have its Broadway premiere at the Morosco Theatre on Oct. 28.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan charged yesterday that Walter P. Reuther had adopted an attitude that "apparently is at variance with [his] championship of clean unions."
LONDON, April 3 -- A number of politicians, diplomats and experts on foreign affairs have tended recently to see the present crisis in East-West relations in terms of 1938, the year of Munich.

Director George V. Allen of the United States Information Agency told Congress in a report made public Sunday that the Voice of America and other of the agency's activities were building a larger audience behind the Iron Curtain. Earlier this year Mr. Allen had estimated the Voice's listeners in Communist countries at 7,000,000 persons.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 3 (AP) -- Bobby Morrow, the Olympic sprint champion, nipped Ira Murchison in the last 5 yards tonight and won the special 100-meter dash in the Texas Relays. The time was 10.2 seconds, one- tenth of a second over the world record.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 -It was suggested here today that one way of fighting blight in the cities might be to "educate" the average family to spend a bigger share of its income for rent or the purchase of a home.

CARDIFF, Wales, April 3 (Reuters) -- Sir Nicholas Cayzer, president of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom, protested here tonight that the United States had resorted to discriminatory practices to bolster its subsidized shipping.
Vito Genovese was found guilty last night of conspiracy to violate Federal narcotics laws. A Federal court jury here also convicted fourteen of fifteen co-defendants.
James N. Young, a former newspaper man and magazine editor, was found dead yesterday in a room at the Roosevelt Hotel. Mr. Young was 73 years old and lived at 455 East Fifty-first Street.
IJMUIDEN, the Netherlands, April 3 (Reuters) -- The 14,138ton American passenger liner Atlantic ran aground here today. She was refloated less than an hour later.

NICE, France, April 3 (UPI) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., reached the men's singles semi-finals in the Nice international tennis tournament today by defeating Ulf Schmidt of Sweden, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.
Poland has asked for a say is determining the future of Antarctica.

ABOARD THE TARAWA Off New York, April 3 -- There was an explosive roar of engines and a hunter-killer airplane shot off the flight deck of this carrier. Then off went another, a third, a fourth and a fifth. After them the helicopters churned aloft like capsized windmills.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Saturday, April 4 (AP) -- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization military advisers ended a three-day meeting today and announced approval of plans for more training exercises by member armed forces.
ALBANY, April 3 -- The Public Service Commission announced today a new policy on cost accounting by utilities. The policy will weaken the arguments of utilities for rate increases in some instances.
Central Synagogue, a Reform synagogue at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, celebrated last night the eighty-fifth anniversary of its parent body, the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
Stocks made impressive gains for the second day. At the close of trading yesterday they had recovered 55 per cent of their loss from the March 13 peak.
Steel entered competition with concrete for the skeletons of large city housing projects yesterday.
The bond market ended the week on the same note of firm equilibrium on which it began.

A race that once was synonymous with the opening of the New York thoroughbred season will be presented at Jamaica today, ten days late. The Paumonok, with nine likely starters, will serve as the feature at the local park, and the spectacle may attract 35,000 fans, given good weather.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Wilbur A. Dexheimer, Commissioner of the Bureau of Reclamation. Mr. Dexheimer will be succeeded by Floyd E. Dominy, associate commissioner.

" The Mischief-Makers" ("Les Mistons"), a prize-winner at the Belgian International Film Festival last year, will receive its first American showing tomorrow at 11:15 A. M. at the Beekman Theatre under the auspices of Cinema 16.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -United States officials are concerned about growing Communist influence in Guinea, the new West African republic that voted itself out of the French Community last Sept. 28.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Union picketing has scored an advance in National Labor Relations Board doctrine.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- The urgent needs of underdeveloped countries for moderate-price sources of energy will be considered by the Economic and Social Council in Mexico City this month.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Army has developed an electric lamp that is little larger than a pinhead and a radio transmitter about the size of a pencil eraser.

IN early springtime, 1956, the youthful Dalai Lama sat in a new pavilion outside the Potala Palace in Lhasa and, under the watchful eye of the emissary from Peiping, Marshal Chen, Yi, declared dutifully that Tibet's "entry into socialism" could be achieved only under China's leadership.

NEWARK, April 3 -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners turned down petitions today for separate proceedings in determining future gas and electric rates of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.
The Sanitation Department, always on the lookout for ways to keep the city clean, announced yesterday it was investigating the habits of ice cream venders.

CARMEL, N. Y., April 3 (UPI) -- A chartered bus carrying about fifty high school seniors home from an Easter vacation trip to Washington tipped over against a roadside embankment last night. At least twenty of those aboard were injured.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 3 -- The National Catholic Educational Association took a strong stand today against Federal control of education, but at the same time it indicated it was ready to make a fight in Congress for Federal funds.

DORTMUND, Germany, April 3 (AP) -- Dick Miles, a former United States champion from New York, was the only American to survive a triple round of action tonight in the world table tennis singles championship.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 3 -- Columbia University's baseball team scored in every inning except the last today in posting an 11-5 triumph over Lehigh. The Lions have won twice in two outings and have tallied eleven runs in each game.
WITH his Elegy, which had its premiere at the New York Philharmonic concert yesterday, Kenneth Gaburo declares himself a composer of talent and individuality.
WESTPORT, Conn., April 3 -- Mrs. Lewis E. Welsh, a trustee of the Westport Public Library, said today that studies showed commuters used library facilities less than any other group in town.
THE most cheerfully cluttered shop windows in New York are at 211 East Sixth - sixth Street. They make a chaotic facade for Vivienne Designs, one of the city's most unusual boutiques.

Only three umbrellas were returned in yesterday's sunshine to the Long Island Rail Road's "umbrella bar" in the Jamaica station. The rain that fell Thursday had drained the lostand-found umbrella bank of all its eighty-five bumbershoots.
MECHANICVILLE, N. Y., April 3 (AP) -- The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company dismissed twenty-two striking workers today. It said they had participated in picket-line violence at its plant here.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Charley Scott, a Philadelphia welterweight, slammed Isaac Logart to the deck and pounded the Cuban mercilessly against the ropes as he scored a thirdround technical knockout tonight. Referee Marty Gallagher called off the punishment at 1:14 of the round.

DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -- Charoen Wattanasin of Thailand eliminated the defending champion, Jim Poole of San Diego, tonight, 15 -- 6, 18 -- 13, and set up the first all-foreign singles final in the history of the United States badminton championships.
TRENTON, April 3 -- The Jersey Central Railroad asked today for permission to increase its commutation fares by 40 per cent.
CHICAGO, April 3 (UPI) -A report in the Journal of The American Medical Association opposed today the use of antibiotics in cosmetics.
Returning from an eight-year stay abroad, Alan Lomax, the folklorist, offered a "panorama of the contemporary American folk song revival" last night at Carnegie Hall.

The Bolshoi Ballet's performance of "Swan Lake" on the evening of April 27 at the Metropolitan Opera House will benefit the Greer School at Hope Farm, Dutchess County, N. Y. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Ruth A. Nicholson of 178 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Investment banking activity is slated to continue at an active rate next week. New issues coming to market from both local government and corporate sponsorship will put strain on the capital resources and the pricing facilities of distributors of new securities.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 3 (AP) -- William Hartack, one of the nation's leading jockeys for the past three years, goes after his third straight $100,000added Florida Derby victory tomorrow, and the odds are 9 -- 5 that he will get it.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that the tax exemption granted to real estate boards does not apply to those that operate property listing services as a principal activity.
New surgery to help people to speak again after their larynxes have been removed because of cancer was reported here yesterday.
" The Ballad of Baby Doe," winner of a New York Music Critics' Circle award for 1958, returned last night as one of the "oldtimers" on the New York City Opera Company's current season of Americana.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The allies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gave their full support today to the United States, Britain and France in defending their rights in West Berlin.

Prime Minister Nehru yesterday confirmed the good news that the Dalai Lama has escaped to India. The demonstration in India's Parliament that followed his announcement gave eloquent evidence of the vast sympathy which the Indian people have for the brave, though unsuccessful, Tibetan fight for independence.
A British and an American drug concern have agreed to cooperate in developing synthetic penicillins.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 3 (AP) -- A Jupiter missile roared skyward tonight, shortly after the successful launching of two Cape newcomers.
Mayor Wagner will go on television tomorrow to discuss his $2,173,113,999 budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 3 (AP) -- Mexican-Americans, Indians and Negroes get shabby treatment under the "gentlemen's agreement" system in Utah, the state's civil rights advisory committee said in a report released today.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., April 3--President Eisenhower returned to his country estate near here today and prepared for a major address tomorrow calling for better understanding of communism's threat to human dignity and freedom.
OTTAWA, April 3 (Canadian Press) -- An Ottawa biochemist has found a way to remove some strontium 90 from milk without destroying the milk as a food product.
ROME, April 3 -- Italy's two Monarchist parties announced tonight they had reached agreement on reuniting after nearly five years of feuding.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- Automation appears to be "one of the main future contributors to increased production and national prosperity. Its development would be accelerated by exchanges of information and experience at the international level," a British and Soviet study group has suggested.

TOKYO, April 3 -- An Air Force investigating board has found that a complicated mix-up was the cause of the "bumping" of enlisted men on emergency leave to make room on a plane for a vacationing lieutenant colonel and his family.
LONDON, April 3 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said tonight that Nikita S. Khrushchev was ruthless but did not want another war.

After a late reaction in old-crop months, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with losses of 4 to 16 points. A point equals 5 cents a bale. Old crop May and July, which had been firm through most of the session, dropped 15 to 17 points from the early highs, when selling of the nearby months by the leading spot interest, late in the session, started a wave of liquidation.
LONDON, April 3 -- Virtually all share prices continued to surge in the stock market today although the pace of the advance slackened slightly.

IN the Northeast there is a need for wise use of plants in small areas. NO other English poet of the later nineteenth century has so deeply influenced the poets of the twentieth as Gerard Manley Hopkins. Only one or two other poets can have provided editors, critics and biographers with more complicated and tantalizing problems.

The Dalai (Mongol for all-embracing) Lama (priest), a 23-year-old Tibetan who is venerated as the "Living Buddha" and a god-king by his countrymen, fled from the capital city of Lhasa.

Newcomers joining the participation sport of pleasure boating should get acquainted early in their experiences with some of their best friends and allies. The petroleum companies that sell them their gasoline and diesel fuel are vying with one another, it would appear, in making things easy and convenient to the boat skipper.

Long ago, when New York was suffering with the postwar (Revolutionary) blues, when King's College for good reason changed its name to Columbia and when immigrants to this land of freedom were being treated little better than slaves, there came into being what is today one of the oldest charitable organizations in the city.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4 (AP) -- Maryland ratified the Fourteenth Amendment today nearly ninety-one years after it had become part of the United States Constitution.
WESTBURY, L. I. -- American and foreign-built cars will replace the trotters at Roosevelt Raceway here for ten days starting May 8.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 4 -- Another major league baseball campaign is about to get off the mark and already it has distinguished itself on several counts. Opening on Thursday in Washington and Cincinnati, it presents the earliest starting date in the history of the two major circuits.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 4 -- Harvard's rugby fifteen beat Amherst. 3 -- 0, in the final of the intercollegiate section of Bermuda's annual Rugby Week today. The Bermuda Athletic Association squad defeated the Canadian Navy. 8 -- 3, in the international final.
PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -The City of Philadelphia and local real estate men have joined in an educational campaign to eliminate racial discrimination in the sale and rental of housing.
The general business situation is continuing to improve, it was reported yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in its monthly study.

CENTRAL Long Island will have its first regularly scheduled air service when Gateway Airlines starts flying from MacArthur Airport on May 25. The airport, at Ronkonkoma in Islip township, is situated in a sparsely settled section of flatlands, fifty miles from Manhattan, in about the center of Long Island.
ISLIP, L. I., April 4 -- A 17year-old boy was killed and three of his friends were injured here early today when the stolen car in which they were riding crashed into a tree on Commack Road.

THE Dutch diplomat and linguist, Robert van Gulik, has undertaken what seems to me one of the most fascinating tasks ever attempted in the history of crime fiction: the recreation of the ancient Chinese detective story in such a form as to captivate and satisfy the modern mystery reader, oriental or occidental.

A BEAUTIFUL spring garden is easy to achieve, even for a beginner. With the many flowering trees, shrubs and bulbs that bloom in April and May even a tiny garden can be gay with color. A beautiful summer garden is far more difficult to achieve.

TO squirt liquid glue into tight-fitting joints, special hypodermic-like injectors are available. In an emergency a small rubber baby syringe can also be used. A syringe of this type also makes a handy applicator for spreading glue for ordinary jobs since a squeeze dispenses the glue and the tip spreads it at the same time.
A revolution is in progress under the slogan "No More Nonsense!" that is transforming the country's high schools, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday.

WHENEVER George Meany and Walter P. Reuther have a fallingout the gravediggers of the merged labor federation get out their shovels. The most recent and most spectacular exchange of unpleasantries between these two big men of Big Labor, at the federation's midwinter meeting in Puerto Rico in February, evoked a fresh flood of obituaries for the colicky infant they helped sire three and a half years ago.

Anne O'Neill-Barna's article was as skillfully contrived a treatment of its subject as I have ever seen in print. It was pungent with the scent of the "ould sod." amusing, nostalgic, informative. I might add only one thing -- how the legend of St. Patrick and the snakes originated.

MEXICO CITY, April 4 -- A new rift in the Leftist labor bloc here appeared today. The Mexican Petroleum Workers Union announced that it had dissociated itself from a group headed by Demetrio Vallejo, jailed chief of the Mexican Railroad Workers Union.
AT last, foreign sports-car salesmen have discovered how to deal with women. Don't bore them with gears and transmissions -- grapple with their psyche.
High school English students are being taught too many ideals and too few fundamentals. This is the opinion of Dr. David Novarr, director of the Freshman English Program at Cornell University.

THE problems of the one-parent family have been the subject of increasing study and group discussion in recent years. Mothers and, to a lesser degree, fathers -- divorced, separated or widowed -- have met to talk over the difficulties of raising children without the help of a marriage partner and to seek solutions or help.

Colleges, organizations and businesses are beginning this month to make their annual scholarship awards to high school seniors. However, comparatively few of them will help the poor boy or girl go to college.
DETROIT, April 4 -- A priestsociologist told a convention of Roman Catholic laymen today that they had an obligation to strive to strengthen American family life.

Violinists between the ages of 15 and 21 in the metropolitan area are eligible for five scholarships to this summer's International Congress of Strings. April 10 is the closing date for applications for the scholarships, which will be given by Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.
The Democratic state chairman accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of failure to carry out campaign pledges to speed highway construction. He also charged a diversion of new highway funds.

THE controversial remodeling of the east front of the Capitol is now proceeding without incident, which is something few would have dared prophesy a year ago. At that time, when it was first announced, the project aroused a public storm so violent as to give a willfully determined Congress temporary pause.
SINCE the first automobiles were produced for the public 65 years ago engineering stews have boiled all over the Western world.
NEW HAVEN, April 4 -- Half of the talented Yale University graduates of last June who were recruited for a teaching experiment are going to remain in the profession.

THE axiom that alcohol and gasoline don't mix finds unanimous agreement among policemen and traffic safety and motor vehicle experts throughout the world, so long as the discussion is kept to generalities.

HARPERS FERRY, W. Va. -- This village, all but destroyed in the Civil War and practically a ghost town ever since, is coming back to a semblance of life for the centennial of its moment in history: John Brown's raid of Oct. 16, 1859.

TOKYO, April 4 -- Ambassador Nikolai T. Fedorenko of the Soviet Union has praised a decision in the Tokyo District Court that the presence of United States military forces here violates Japan's pacifist Constitution.
THE motor scooter, a jaunty vehicle that first took a firm hold in post-war Europe, has been puttering throughout the country in steadily increasing numbers.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- The era of the 'i'nland seacoast" will dawn in about three weeks when the break-up of the last ice choking the channel near Montreal permits the first deepdraft ships to ply the length of the St. Lawrence Seaway to Chicago.

THE automobile has become more of a master in suburbia than ever. Bankers, planners, developers and sociologists report that saturation mobility is a major catalyst in suburban culture, education, commutation, social life, hobbies, sports, construction, mercantile trade and general economics.
A PANORAMA of foreign automobiles -- and a glimpse of American cars -- is on view at the New York Coliseum. It will be there through next Sunday at the third International Auto Show.

A NEW high-water mark in the cultural advance of motion pictures was indicated here last week with the formation of the Society of Cinematologists. A group of some thirty film educators from twenty-two universities, meeting informally for the third year at the Museum of Modern Art, finally took the plunge toward formal organization as a "learned society" with aims similar to those of equivalent societies in the other fine arts.

Congratulations on Jay K. Hoffman's "Tips for the Innocent Abroad." I wish that a newspaper with the circulation and reputation that you have would run a series of more detailed articles. No such information is available in print.

KALIMPONG, India, April 4 (Reuters) -- Thousands of Chinese Communist troops, foiled in their efforts to prevent the Dalai Lama from escaping to India, were reported tonight to be battling rebels for control of southeastern Tibet.

In a letter published on March 29 President John Stacy Coles of Bowdoin College was extremely critical of statements of mine quoted on the Education Page of The Times for March 22. My statements were in response to a request for comment on an article in The College Board Review entitled "Student Credit Could End Colleges' Financial Plight."

In Hollywood, they're all going thataway. Stars who, in the balmier days of moviemaking, acted solely in sultry sagas of the great indoors -- notably the boudoir and drawing room -- are now all out for the outdoors. Once contemptuous of Westerns, they may soon be seen in boots and saddles, shouting "Reach, pardner" or maybe "We'll head 'em off at the pass" with an ardor usually associated with an Autry or Rogers.

WHEN the Cardinals elected Aeneas Sylvius Piccolomini (1405-1464) Pope in 1458, humanist scholars anticipated his patronage. Aeneas had lived a worldly life, won an early reputation as a poet, and written a novel and a play notable for wit and impropriety.
The do-it-yourself philosophy is the order of the day for thousands of the country's outboard skippers, many of whom look forward to a spring tuneup of their outboard motors.

THE merchandising of imported cars has come a long way since the early post-war days of hit-and-miss sales and servicing. Through ingenious methods foreign manufacturers have increased their sales from a few thousand a year a decade ago to an expected total of 500,000 this year and 1,000,000 by 1965.
" Don Carlo" was yesterday afternoon's opera at the Metropolitan, with Jerome Hines making his first appearance of the season as Philip II.

THIS life of Moliere is frankly presented as a novel and should be read as such. Michael O'Shaughnessy writes vividly, in a sprightly, buoyant style which reveals a lover of the theatre -- and a lover of life in all its forms.
COMMUTER-GARDENERS who spend their days at an office can plan their gardens to accommodate their schedules. Flowers can be planted for bloom during early morning or evening hours.

ANTHONY TROLLOPE, as anyone even faintly interested in him knows, used to begin a new book as soon as he'd finished the last. Let him finish "Dr. Thorne" while he was in Egypt on government business, negotiating a postal treaty with a Pasha; never mind, the next day he took a fresh sheet and, Pasha or no Pasha, he started writing "The Bertrams."
Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has told the Soviet people that he has no fears about the possible consequences of rapid population growth in China.

AFTER reading the review of Sir Robert WatsonWatt's book on the invention of radar. "The Pulse of Radar," I wrote you about the pioneer work done by Christian Huelsmeyer in Dusseldorf in 1903-04. Subsequent correspondence with Sir Robert shows that he was fully aware of the pioneer work done by Huelsmeyer.

THESE days even in the pages of a picture magazine there may lurk the seeds for a Broadway musical. A little more than a year ago, Cleveland Amory, historian of society on its last legs, etc., did an article for Life called "Manners Man." It told of a gentleman who had devoted his career to teaching the young of the famous and the wealthy how to dance -- also the "finishing" facts of life.

LONDON, April 3 -- The United States decision to renew diplomatic relations with Communist Bulgaria is being applauded by Bulgarians and Western diplomats alike, according to residents of Sofia visiting here.
The "three R's" have assumed an important new responsibility in education, according to the Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development, a department of the National Education Association.
BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -Ted Williams, under treatment at New England Baptist Hospital for a pinched nerve in the neck, may be discharged in a few days, his doctor said today.
NORWALK, Conn. -- Most fans maintain their sports cars in a fashion that would warm the heart of an Army officer making a white-glove inspection. But sometimes this loving care can backfire.
DETROIT, April 4 -- Michigan voters will go to the polls Monday in the biennial spring election of judicial and educational officials.
A Greek goddess and a retiring gym instructor will share honors at Barnard College's Fifty-seventh Greek Games celebration next Saturday. It will open in the gymnasium at 2:30 P. M.
CHICAGO, April 4 -- Chicago goes to the polls next Tuesday to elect a Mayor. But the only doubt appears to be the majority by which Mayor Richard J. Daley will be re-elected.

Iran hopes that foreign capital and managerial skill will play an important part in a long-term plan for modernizing the economy of the Middle East state and raising the living standards of its 20,000,000 inhabitants, according to HassanAli Mansour, deputy premier.
Out in the stockroom a youth named Chester H. Roth reported for work early, worked hard all day and, when the day was done, resumed his dream of owning and operating his own company.

Willie Shoemaker's winning way with a horse was demonstrated in sharp detail at Jamaica yesterday. The largest crowd of the local season, 37,738 fans, saw the wiry Californian score so often on the card as to make the occasion an unofficial Willie Shoemaker Day.
Two Cornell graduate students made a study of the best way to cool a hot cup of coffee and compiled a 78-page report complete with graphs and formulas.

NICE, France, April 1 -- Bicycle racers, like baseball players and golfers, follow the sun. They begin training in February on the roads and mountains of the sunny Riviera. Soon they are pedaling 120 or more miles a day.

ALGECIRAS, Spain -- The great New York-Mediterranean liners drop anchor here, in a beautiful harbor which separates this Spanish port from Gibraltar. Passengers come ashore for a few hours on the mountain-rimmed coast of Spain or to visit the British crown colony.

Encouraging results in the treatment of the disabling after-effects resulting from strokes are reported in the Harlem Hospital Bulletin by Drs. Harold L. Ellis and Jacob Jacobson. Thirty-seven patients who had suffered strokes were given injections of a solution of benzyl cinnamate combined with vitamin A for periods up to six months.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A Labor Department analysis shows that no state -- and not even the Federal province of the District of Columbia -- provides unemployment benefits as large as the Administration feels they should be.

The Easter retail figures are in and, on a nation-wide basis, they show up very well indeed. The Federal Reserve Board reports that department store volume in the week ended March 28 was 16 per cent greater than it was in the same calendar week a year ago.

DURBAN, South Africa, April 4 -- A heavy police guard supervised the evacuation of a company barracks today by more than 1,000 Zulu dock workers dismissed for refusal to work overtime. The dispute has already cost shipping interests more than 50,000 ($140,000).

LIKE any other large and expensive piece of equipment, a home should be inspected periodically if it is to be kept in smooth "operating" condition. Since winter months always do the most damage, now is the time for making a seasonal check-up and attending to the necessary repairs.

The Opportunity Shop of the Community Service Society will have a booth at the New York Antiques Fair, which will be held from April 13 to 18 in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

THE cult of symbolism, which was essentially a mystical form of estheticism, swept through European painting, writing and music at the close of the nineteenth century. Its belief that art was the sole means of entry into a world of ideal beauty radiated from Paris in the genius of Mallarme, Debussy and Gustave Moreau.

IN approaching and executing this survey of the American theatre from its greenest buds to its present blossoms, Barnard Hewitt has achieved a sort of "You-Are-There" chronicle. For Mr. Hewitt, who teaches at the University of Illinois and directs plays there, is obviously a man not to be intimidated by a library of books nor a library's basement, where are crated the infrequently consulted sources.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 4 -The recent new upsurge of revolt in Tibet has confronted Peiping with the most serious display of opposition to its rule since the Chinese Communists consolidated their conquest of the Chinese mainland nearly a decade ago.

UNTIL the late Nineteen Forties, the elders of higher education held firmly to the belief that marriage and education could never mix. Then the returning veterans of World War II arrived on college campuses. Some of them brought wives with them: some acquired wives after they came.

DURING 1940-43, while China was going through perhaps the bleakest phase of her war with Japan, the Sawbwa (a sort of rajah) of Mangshih was engaged in a rather determined struggle of his own. Mangshih, a feudal state on the ChinaBurma border, had long been isolated by its semi-tropical terrain and by the prevalence of malaria.

THE controversy concerning modernistic architecture and architecture that is based on the classical and traditional is of great moment for our culture. It is far from being settled despite the present vogue for the secessionist styles.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner said yesterday that he hoped to solve New Jersey's commuter transit problems without increasing its citizens' tax burdens. He said he hoped to have a survey of the situation completed in three weeks.
ATHENS, April 4 -- About 4,000,000 Greek men and women will vote tomorow to elect town councils for the nation's 5,773 communities. The councils will elect mayors and community presidents June 14.

RENO, Nev., April 4 (UPI) -- San Jose State retained the national collegiate boxing title tonight, although Archie Milton, the Spartans' big gun in the heavyweight ranks, was upset by Hal Espy of Idaho State.
The Port of New York will play host to another "new" liner in September.

Last Tuesday afternoon under the bright Florida sun, a group of builders, rehabilitation specialists and community leaders met in front of a typical-appearing Florida retirement home in Pinellas, between Clearwater and St. Petersburg.

WHILE gardeners have been wistfully gazing out of windows at barren landscapes during the winter months, authors and publishers have been readying new books and up-dating the old to include the latest horticultural advances. Here is a round-up and brief summary of the spring crop.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has announced a gift of $2,527,500 for studies in geophysics. The gift is from Mr. an Mrs. Cecil H. Green of Dallas. Mr. Green, an M. I. T. alumnus of the class of '23, is a vice president of Texas Instruments, Inc., a manufacturer of electronic devices.

A technological revolution in the generation of electricity is now under way, both in the United States and in Russia. It has come about as the result of rapid advances in thermoelectricity, the direct transformation of heat energy into electricity without moving parts.

Sales of children s clothing in the period preceding Easter reduced retail inventories to the extent that manufacturers were looking forward to excellent demand during the children's wear summer market here April 5-10.

JERSEY CITY, April 4 -Embarrassed by an outside offer to "rescue" this city's art, historic manuscripts and other rare museum material, the Jersey City Fine Arts Council took steps last night toward construction of a $1,000,000 museum.
Speculative fever in the stock market subsided somewhat early last week in the wake of a rising chorus of warnings from prominent Wall Street sources. The cautious mood was shortlived, however.

LOS ANGELES -- Motorists visiting California this year are likely to run into considerable confusion about driving regulations. To cut down a formidable accident rate, the state is in the midst of a major overhaul of its motor vehicle code.

MACAO -- Any Hong Kong tourist interested in the great dramas of Asia's yesterdays and the tragic turmoil and uncertainties of today should take a day to visit Macao, five and a half square miles of Portuguese territory which lie, seemingly unperturbed, on the Pearl River delta right on the border of Communist China.
VERONICAS or speedwells are among the best of the easy-to-grow blue flowers for the border or rock garden. These perennials make a fine showing from April until late fall.

The Wiltwyck School for Boys at Esopus, N. Y., will benefit from a concert to be given by Harry Belafonte at Carnegie Hall on the evening of April 20. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary chairman for the event and Harry Brandt heads the benefit committee.

FROM a rented, thirty-secondfloor penthouse that affords spectacular views of Central Park on one side and grim but hopeful stages of West Side demolition on the other, a relative newcomer to America -- Michel Saint-Denis -could, if he wished, contemplate at easy rang the tasks set for him.
BUENOS AIRES, April 4 (UPI) -- A bomb exploded in a church in the Palermo district early today, causing damage but harming no one.
ARE you aware that a New York City Handel Festival began on March 1 and will continue until May 20? Do you realize that it was heralded by a proclamation from Mayor Wagner?

WHO buys foreign cars? The chances are the next person to sign a contract will be a professional man just entering middle age. He will plan to drive the car, his only one, to the office or on other business. His wife, whether by preference or not, will seldom use the car for household errands.

Drew MAddleton, in his excellent piece on the English and their cricket ("That Way of Life Called Cricket." March 22), might have retold the legend of the "ashes"--the symbolic prize E,,lgland and (ottinft.ed on Pge 90) Australia battle for in their test matches.

Once again President Alfredo Stroessner of Paraguay has promised to establish constitutional government in his country. If the measures he announced at the opening of a new session of the Chamber of Deputies go into effect, Paraguay will at last start on the road to democracy.

NEARLY any weekday, a score or so of scientists of the American Museum of Natural History gather for lunch in a paneled room a spear's throw from the bronze lions inside the museum's Central Park entrance. There they settle down in heavy, leather-upholstered chairs around a ponderous wooden table fit for a castle.

A special housing committee of the Greenwich Village Association announced a "crash program" yesterday to rehabilitate Greenwich Village while retaining what remains of the character of the neighborhood.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 4 -- The New York Botanical Garden will benefit from an annual spring garden tour to be held on May 14 here and in Greenfield Hill and Southport.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 4 -- The annual Sarah Knipe Herrmann Scholarship dessert bridge of the Westchester Wells College Alumnae Club will be held on April 23 at the Glen Island Casino here. Mrs. Eric Scott of New Rochelle is general chairman of the fete.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A deep and enduring philosophic division in the Supreme Court was illuminated this week by a pair of decisions that went as far as any recent cases toward disclosing the inner compulsions of the present justices.

HARTFORD, April 4 -- Meade Alcorn of Connecticut, who is resigning as Republican National Chairman next week, is expected to maintain an active interest in state Republican politics when he returns here.

MAINTAINING a beautiful garden need not occupy all the home owner's precious leisure time. There are many plants that demand little or no care, once they are established. With careful selection, complete plantings can be designed which will require no more than cursory attention once or twice a year.
Stores throughout most of the country sold some brands of television sets faster than they were made in the first quarter of this year.

Over the longer period of time the Red Chinese assault on Tibet may be more important for its religious rather than temporal significance. The Dalai Lama, who has been forced into exile, is much more than the uneasy ruler of a so-called "autonomous" state within the area of control that Peiping has established. He is the spiritual head of one group of Buddhists and is venerated as such.
A glittering array of rare book treasures of the General Theological Seminary will be on display today for the last time in the seminary's old library in Chelsea Square.

WHEN bigger and better excuses are made, traffic court will be the first to hear them. "Guilty with an explanation" covers a range from "ridiculous to unbelievably ridiculous," according to the magistrates.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 4 -- Big Bill Alley of Kansas threw the javelin 270 feet 1 1/2 inches to better the American and collegiate standards today in headlining the Texas Relays, which produced six records and two record-tying performances.
APRIL marks the beginning of the spring blossom festivals and house and garden tours held north of the Potomac River. In Delaware, plans for springtime events this year follow previous patterns.

TEANECK, N. J., April 4 -The Teaneck Democratic Club will hold an "evening of politics" April 15. The purpose will be to explain the hows and whys of political organization to able persons who thus far have been on the sidelines.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- The East African territory of Somalia has appealed to the United Nations Children's Fund for aid in what threatens to be a general famine in the area.
Two thugs who weigh about 160 pounds made the mistake yesterday of trying to hold up members of House Wreckers Union Local 95 -- who average more than 200 pounds.

THOSE who dig up the artifacts of our civilization might describe the Twentieth Century as the Age of Mobility. If the automobile gives people freedom to move, it also puts wheels under cities and villages, propelling them along broad highways, swallowing meadowland and leveling woods.

A chemical constituent of the brain has been used by Harvard University scientists as a decoy to prevent the harmful effects of two influenza viruses on the brain, it is reported in the current issue of Virology. The chemical decoy, the report states, has been effective in preventing convulsions and death due to the effects of the viruses on the nervous system of animals.

WEST BRANCH, Iowa, April 4 (UPI) -- A museum to preserve the personal papers and mementos of former President Herbert C. Hoover will be built at the Hoover Birthplace Park here, it was announced today.

Among the many art attractions this week are the twentieth biennial international water-color exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and the annual exhibition of work by members of the Sculptors Guild at Lever House, both opening on Tuesday.
TO judge by the reviews and the comments of individual playgoers, everyone is profoundly moved by Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" at the Circle in the Square.
Community restrictions on fence heights often make privacy difficult to achieve in small gardens. Thick screens of shrubs like Japanese pine take up too much space to be a practical substitute.

To the Drama Editor: THIS theatregoer has long believed that "Our Town" is truly deserving of the label, "The Great American Tragedy." This belief is due to the play's poetic explanation of man's relation to the universe and poignant revelation that only through suffering -- even after death -- can one's life be enriched and ennobled.

ANY lingering doubt that the small imported cars are here to stay is dispelled by a look at the new mailorder catalogues. These citadels of the staples in American life now list narrow thirteen-, fifteenand sixteen-inch tires for sale.

WHEN it comes to annuals, I admit to being an addict. No other group of flowering plants gives so much for so little so quickly. In no other group is there more variation in season of bloom, habit of growth, flower form and color.

MOST of the news this April morning seems to be about people who are concerned with the creation of books rather than books themselves. The curtain is up, so let them come out of the wings now, from Italy and Africa, from California, Florida and Connecticut.
WHITE PLAINS, April 4 -The death sentence that Westchester officials have drafted for the County Parkway Authority has been stayed temporarily, perhaps until after the November election.
An official of Seatrain Lines, Inc., asked the Federal Maritime Board last week not to grant an operating subsidy to Waterman Steamship Corporation.

COLORADO has just presented this country with the first biography of famed medical researcher Florence Sabin (1871-1953) as well as with her figure in bronze in Statuary Hall in the United States Capitol.

As usual, Peggy and Pierre Streit make sense. One applauds the way they have collected their information from the people of Asia, instead of relying on such mendacious sources as the Euramerican bars or government handouts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4 -- Africa has seen its share of radical political changes in the last decade but nothing to equal the accelerated tempo of events taking place in recent months. Almost daily, reminders are coming out of Africa of the deep and fundamental breaks occurring in long-established patterns. Some of these changes take explosive form; others are accomplished peacefully.
LOS ANGELES -- California really is being very nice about it.

Adapted drawings of earliest botanical prints provide the theme for this garden calendar. The original drawings were a means of instruction and classification when scientific botany began in the eighteenth century. Plant parts often were labeled and keyed as they are done here decoratively.
RENO, Nev., April 4 -- Nevada gamblers rate the New York Yankees and Milwaukee Braves as solid favorites in the baseball pennant races.

As a new owner of a thirteenfoot day sailer, Flying Dutchman Jr., I am looking forward to a summer in various eastern waters. However, I have some questions regarding the launching of the boat in various locations.

UP in the Province of Quebec, we hear, there are a number of hardy visitors impatiently awaiting the midApril opening of the trout season. The Quebec Fish and Game Department sets the date but this formality, it is said, is academic, for the break-up of the ice and the disappearance of the snow are the signs looked for and wagered on by thousands of eager fishermen.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 -Like a team in a three-legged race, Premier Abdul Karim Kassim and the Communist party of Iraq seem to be running in step lest they fall together.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -Twenty-two foreign and American scientists and engineers are enrolled this year in the Atomic Energy Commission's International School of Science and Engineering.
There is art for all tastes in the enormous exhibition of modern American painting and sculpture that opened yesterday in the Coliseum.

RUSSELL LYNES' point of view in his small and, artistically, somewhat squeaky fable (it has rats as its principal characters) is not a naturalistic one. He makes no attempt to rehabilitate the rat socially, in the style of Audubon's "Defense of the Crow," nor to compile a detailed and exhaustive satire on verminous practices, as in former disquisitions on "Snobs," "Guests," etc.

WHY, asks the author of this provocative and probing book, Tolstoy or Dostoevsky? Because, he says, he intends "to consider their achievements and define the nature of their respective genius through contrast."
LONDON, April 4 -- A prominent Labor Member of Parliament accused United States trade and commercial interests today of following "an aggressive, ruthless policy" against British competitors.

NORWALK, Conn., April 4 -More than 200 aspirants for roles or production jobs in the "Follies of '59", annual variety show sponsored by the Woman's Board of the Norwalk Hospital, will be guests of the board's talent committee at a party on April 13 at the Treadway Inn.

J. Donald Adams, in his "Speaking of Books" column in your Book Review section of March 15 drew attention to the need for more American books in Asia and Africa. He then appealed to the American Book Publishers Council to "give the matter its earnest consideration."

THE rigors of life at an Army outpost on the Michigan frontier in 1811, as portrayed in Col. Red Reeder's "Attack at Fort Lookout," were such that the hardiest recruit could contemplate desertion as simply an equivalent state of jeopardy.

MAINZ, Germany, April 4 -Five thousand Allied troops of nine nations paraded before Gen. Lauris Norstad, their Supreme Commander, today in celebration of the tenth anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

PEIPING, April 4 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Chen Yi of Communist China attacked the "aggressive" NATO bloc today and accused the United States of trying to extend its "subversive" activities in Southeast Asia. He was speaking at the Hungarian Embassy's Liberation Day reception.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -- It was a wonderful dinner party -- good talk, good food, good wine, a cocktail before dinner and cognac with the coffee for that finishing touch. But the Stockholm police did not like it.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 -- Suzanne Hundertmark and Robert Mollman in a Volvo sedan held an early lead in the Jersey 500 sports car rally today.

Bills increasing the city's 1-cent cigarette tax to 2 cents a pack and imposing new taxes on retail sales of cigars and tobacco products are scheduled to be introduced in the City Council on Tuesday. The effective date of the taxes is May 1.

EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo., April 4 -- The discovery that steroid hormones can act as biochemical traffic directors in one of life's most basic processes was described in a report here to a meeting arranged by the American Cancer Society.
Rallying is an unusual sport. At once an intellectual and a physical exercise, it calls for a high degree of cooperation between the driver and his working passenger, who is known as the navigator.
A medium-size family-owned shoe company is attempting to beat the rising price trend in the shoe industry and to compete successfully with large producers.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -The Senate Small Business Committee will start a study on Wednesday of the impact of recent Supreme Court decisions upholding the right of states to tax companies operating in interstate commerce.

TOKYO, April 4 (UPI) -Lieut. Col. Charles H. Platt, cleared by the United States Air Force of charges that he "bumped" seven men on emergency leave from a military transport, said today he had given up plans for a vacation in Hawaii now.

THE new look in foundation plantings throughout southern California can be summed up briefly -- outdoor planter boxes and tropical plant material. Eastern gardeners can adapt many of the contemporary styles to fit their own landscape needs.

If the Federal Reserve Board amends its regulations covering lending on securities by exchange members and by banks, as now proposed, marked changes in the New York money market seem sure to follow. The rules concerned are designated as Regulations T and U, respectively.
The Long Island Lacrosse Club turned back the New York Lacrosse Club, 9 -- 4, at Red Hook Stadium in Brooklyn yesterday.

The scientific name of Hyla crucifer, the tiny tree frog with the shrill, bell-toned April voice, reaches back into Greek legend. Hercules, says the legend, was fond of a boy named Hylas. While they were adventuring with the Argonauts, Hercules sent the boy to bring water from a spring; but the water nymphs captured Hylas and thereafter he lived in the water, calling for Hercules in his sweet young treble voice.

BACK in the early Nineteen Hundreds, when Lillian Russell was the rage and horse-drawn carriages clopped along Fifth Avenue, Albert Stevens Crockett was a rather tireless bon vivant on two continents. TOBAGO, B. W. I. -- The traveler considering a Caribbean holiday need not be baffled by the seemingly endless curving string of small islands -- American, British, Dutch and French -that dot the map from Puerto Rico to the Gulf of Venezuela.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., April 4 -- President Eisenhower urged the nation today to recognize that "mutual security and American security are synonymous" and that timely foreign aid was essential to frustrate the Communist goal of world domination.

EACH year the United States imports approximately 3,750 pounds of saffron. This seemingly low figure becomes considerably more impressive when it is noted that it takes 225,000 stigmas of the plant known as Crocus sativus to make one pound of saffron.

THE New York City Opera Company added an entertaining double bill to its repertory of American opera at the City Center last night.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 5 -- Eleven Protestant social action leaders decried here today what they called the spread of efforts to identify desegregation with subversion. They asserted that this had led to a "Southern version of McCarthyism."

NEW DELHI, April 5 (AP) -- Explaining India's interest in Tibet, Mr. Nehru said at his news conference that Buddha was the "greatest Indian who ever lived, and we in India are still under Buddha's umbrella, so to speak."

The Export - Import Bank announced over the week-end that a credit of $9,300,000 had been granted to Iran to assist that country's nationalized railways system to purchase forty Diesel-electric locomotives and equipment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- "The Disenchanted," the dramatization by Budd Schulberg and Harvey Breit of Mr. Schulberg's novel, which has been a property of considerable interest to Hollywood moviemakers, will be brought to the screen by Ray Stark, producer.

LOUISVILLE, April 5 (AP) -- Seven members of the College All-Stars, winners of the Pan-American basketball trials last night, headed a fourteen-man team selected today to represent the United States in the Pan-American Games in Chicago in August.
A test of plastic street guidelines as a substitute for more quickly fading paint has been started here as a traffic safety measure. The plastic lines reportedly are cheaper and easier to see.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Congress published testimony today that the United States' military strength to deter the Soviet Union from starting a war was weakening.

In a program that by next year will transfer ownership of more than two million acres and give land to 312,000 households that were formerly tenant, South Vietnam is going forward in a genuine land reform. A big step was taken on the lower part of the delta of the Mekong River when 1,175 former tenants received title to landholdings of about seven acres each.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., April 5 (AP) -- A New York City gun dealer paid $5,100 today for an empty rifle cartridge, hand-made eighty-four years ago by the famous rifle maker, Oliver F. Winchester.

SZCZECIN, Poland, March 26 -- For this port city, the Mayor is getting on in years and the shipyard director is almost venerable. The Mayor is 35 years old and the director 38.

Consolidated net income of Botany Mills, Inc., fell to $4,919,514 last year from $8,142,042 in 1957. It was the third consecutive year in which the company made a profit after losses in each year from 1952 to 1955, according to the 1958 report, released today.

A five-story walk-up apartment house for forty families at 2075 Bedford Avenue at the corner of Lenox Road, Brooklyn, has been sold. American Airlines, Inc., has arranged to sell another forty-five of its propellor-driven airplanes. Delivery is contingent on receipt of jet aircraft that the company has ordered.
