This budget has already been on trial before the House Foreign Affairs Committee and is due to come up in a few days before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. These committees can authorize the program.

BANMETHUOT, Vietnam, April 5 -- The new settlers in the high plateau region of South Vietnam will begin this year extensive cultivation of industrial crops. The Saigon Government hopes their output will appreciably reduce the new republic's need for a number of costly imports and eventually pay off in export earnings as well.
SEOUL, Korea, April 5 (Reuters) -- The South Korean Government has rejected proposals for establishing segregated schools for children of mixed blood, most of them of American and Korean extraction.

Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest in New York City and the second largest in the United States, showed a slight decline in earnings in the first quarter of 1959, compared with those a year earlier. Net operating earnings, after taxes, for the three-month period totaled $13,672,495, or $1.04 a share.

A CALIFORNIA scientist declared recently that alcohol was better than milk for older people. His statement got much attention in the press, not only in this country but also in Europe. But before an oldster decides to switch from milk shakes to martinis, he might listen to what Dr. C. G. King, executive director of the Nutrition Foundation, has to say on the subject.
The Dutch and the Japanese have decided that they too can sell automobiles in the United States. They are showing some of their wares at the International Automobile Show in the Coliseum.

Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, said here yesterday that large areas of Alaska were "almost totally lacking in medical services." He said "many of their people live and die without benefit of therapy."
PRIMITIVE art is moving up in the world. Now becoming well entrenched in fashionable decorating schemes, it recently made a formidable appearance on Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -Charles M. Metzner, who lost out last month in a duel for nomination to the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, is likely to win appointment to a new vacancy on that court.

The two five-story apartment houses at 527-29 Brook Avenue in the Bronx have been sold by the Benny Realty Corporation to a client of the Sherman Management Company. The buildings, on a plot of 50 by 100 feet, contain a total of sixteen fiveroom apartments and four stores and have an annual rent roll of $11,200.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (UPI) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that it would speed up its New YorkWashington trains in a campaign to "bring riders back to the rails."
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Federal prosecutors were told today that a yearold offensive against major crime had shown gratifying results. They were urged to keep up the work.
Veterans of the fifth Danish-Norwegian United Nations Emergency Force battalion are preparing to come out of the Gaza Strip on their way home. Other soldiers of the United Nations will replace them.
Federal mediation efforts began yesterday in an attempt to settle an eleven-day strike of Acme grocery-store clerks in northern New Jersey and on Long Island and Staten Island.
NEW HAVEN, April 6 -- A crazed father killed four members of his family and himself today. He also had set fire to their home.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 6 -- Thousands of Thais paid homage on their hands and knees today in this "city of the angels" to the memory of the eight dead kings of the 177-year-old Chakri dynasty.

PARIS, April 6 -- European observers expect that in the near future much more private capital from the United States will be siphoned into Europe, to the benefit of both. They foresee capital movements from Europe to the United States also, with the freer flow back and forth tending to equalize interest rates and earnings on both sides of the Atlantic.

Queens followed Manhattan by a week yesterday in celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the Queensboro Bridge. The ceremony was held under sunny skies, whereas the Manhattan Plaza celebration last Monday was washed away by rain.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -Seven military test pilots have been selected to undergo training as the nation's first astronauts.
A Bronx grand jury has begun an inquiry into the murder of Frank Scalise, who was shot dead by two gunmen in a fruit store in the Bronx on June 17, 1957.
WHITE PLAINS, April 6 -Westchester is in excellent condition financially and physically, County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian announced today.
Stiff withholding her true name, the woman known as Vera Wilson was sentenced yesterday to two to four years in prison for robbing one bank and attempting to rob a second.
Vice Admiral Thomas S. Combs, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, warned yesterday that "the darkest threat in our entire history now hangs over our heads."

The festivities currently marking the 200th anniversary of the death of George Frederick Handel by necessity become a tribute to the organ. For this versatile musician, accomplished in so many aspects of composition and performance, is said to have been without peer as an organist, and among his finest works are three sets of six organ concertos.

NEW DELHI, India April 6 -- Exhausted by his long trek to freedom, the Dalai Lama rested today in a Buddhist monastery at Towang while the Indian Government planned for his comfort and security in exile.

Today is being observed as the annual "World Health Day" of the World Health Organization. The purpose of this observation is to emphasize the "world" aspect of various health problems and seek the widest range in meeting them.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 6 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, told the Texas Legislature today "no one man speaks for the Democratic party in this nation, but one man must speak for this nation."
WASHINGTON, April 6 -The North Atlantic foreign ministers have left the Capital, but the international lawyers are still arguing, about the legal status of Berlin.

JESSUP, Md., April 6 (UPI) -- Thirty-one of thirty-seven youths who escaped from two state mental institutions last night were caught today as search planes fanned out over the countryside. In the hunt 400 state and county policemen were aided by National Guardsmen and members of the military police.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -The Supreme Court ruled today that the small business man was entitled to bring a private antitrust suit without proving that his case would have a particular effect on the public at large.
BUENOS AIRES, April 6 -The expulsion of Soviet and other Communist diplomats from Argentina as a result of last Friday's CommunistPeronist disturbances here was proposed in the press today.

BOSTON, April 6 (UPI) -Nineteen-year-old Joe De Nucci, 166 pounds, of Newton, knocked out Joe Jordan, 162, Bridgeton, N. J., in 1:56 of the third round of a scheduled nine-round bout at the Boston Arena tonight.
Eight liners carrying a total of 3,977 passengers are scheduled to put into port here this morning.
For the second time in as many days, Edmond Rostand's "Cyrano de Bergerac" figures in the theatrical news.
The sidewalks of two Greenwich Village blocks were swept thoroughly yesterday, but only after personal reminders from Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane and sanitation patrolmen.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College won its fight today against admitting women students.

A contestant on a television show was taken to a hospital yesterday after having suffered burns from a sudden burst of flames during a stunt being conducted by Bert Parks, the program's master of ceremonies.
The State Commission of Investigation questioned witnesses in private again yesterday in its inquiry into gambling.

MEXICO CITY, April 6 -The Government continued its crackdown on Communists last night and today in a series of police and secret service raids. The headquarters of the Mexican Communist party here was raided last night.
"The Price of Progress Is Trouble" says a sign over the doorway of a converted cafeteria on Fordham's Rose Hill campus.

TRENTON, April 6 -- The New Jersey Assembly voted today to legalize boardwalk and amusement park games of chance. It also approved a companion bill that would establish a state overseer of such games.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Union on airplane incidents over the Sea of Japan and Baltic Sea.
CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- A good general demand today pushed almost all prices of grain futures through a complete recovery from Friday's setbacks and on into higher levels on the Board of Trade.

An investment banking group headed by Kidder Peabody Co. won the award of $5,700,000 of Erie County, N. Y., Water Authority revenue bonds yesterday. The group bid 100 for the bonds which mature from 1961 to 1998.

LONDON, April 6 -- The Colonial Office announced today that "complete agreement" had been reached with the Sultan of Brunei and a delegation from his State Council on plans for giving Brunei a written constitution and greater autonomy in the control of its internal affairs.
Two more members of the crew of the tanker Valchem testified yesterday that tanker's engines were stopped before the collision with the liner Santa Rosa off Atlantic City, March 26.

OF particular interest to the many people concerned about cutting down on calories, either to lose weight or because of health problems, is the newly revised and enlarged edition of "Low-Fat Cookery" (McGrawHill, 284 pp., $4.50).
The city was urged by a leading builder yesterday to examine and discuss the proposed new zoning ordinance carefully before taking steps to adopt it.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The United States has blamed the Soviet Union for the "atmosphere of hostility" prevailing between the two countries as a result of recent air incidents.

NICE, France, April 6 -- Everywhere one wandered during the international tennis tournament here, which ended yesterday, one heard whispers of Wimbledon. Never before have tennis players regarded those Olympian heights as so accessible.

Despite Soviet charges that the United States is trying to "wreck" the projected East-West negotiations by maintaining the freedom of the airlanes to Berlin, the Western powers continue methodically and by the democratic process of free exchange of views among the free to work out a program for such negotiations.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 6 (UPI) -- The site of the May 1 heavyweight title bout between Floyd Patterson and Brian London was moved to Indianapolis today to steer clear of gambling interests in Las Vegas, Nev., the original site.
Steel production climbed to a record high last week, and was scheduled to remain at that level this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BOSTON, April 6 (AP) -- A chance for hockey's coveted Stanley Cup hangs in the balance tomorrow night when the taped and tired Boston Bruins and Toronto Maple Leafs meet at the Garden.

A TOWN HALL concert was played last night by Roman Totenberg, violinist; Leonid Hambro, pianist; Leonard Rose, 'cellist, and an ensemble of strings and harpsichord conducted by Mr. Totenberg. It was the last of the three-event subscription series presented by Town Hall as its first annual "Festival of Music."

Boxholders and subscribers to the New York Philharmonic pension fund concert at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening have been announced by Mrs. Murray Vanderbilt, chairman.
The McCrory-McLellan Stores Corporation, which resulted from a merger last Jan. 30 of the McCrory Stores Corporation and McLellan Stores Company, issued an annual report yesterday.
BUFFALO, April 6 -- This was Heartbreak Day for scores of jobless workers in the Niagara Frontier district, hardest hit by unemployment of all New York's industrial centers.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -General practitioners of medicine were urged today to block adoption of parts of a report scheduled to come before the American Medical Association at its Atlantic City meeting in June.

John Thomas, the Boston University freshman who lifted the world indoor high jump record to 7 feet 1 1/4 inches at the Amateur Athletic Union's national championships on Feb. 21, was named the outstanding performer of the 1959 indoor track session yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -President Eisenhower will fly to Augusta, Ga., tomorrow for a golfing vacation, the White House announced today.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 6 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion survived an attempt in Parliament today to dismiss him for the April 1 call-up of army reserve units. For a few tense hours the call-up had the world believing that the Middle East was on the brink of a new war.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 6 -New measures applying Ghana's doctrine of "strong Government" have been taken here this week.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -Christian A. Herter, Acting Secretary of State, will meet with Dr. Fidel Castro during the Cuban Premier's visit here next week.
VIENNA, April 6 -- Statistics of Rumania's industrial expansion in 1958 were made available here today.
The Orchestra of America, conducted by Richard Korn, will begin its first season on Oct. 14 with a concert at Carnegie Hall.

Prices were mixed at the close of trading on the stock market yesterday. Drugs were strong, electronics generally lower and the other major groups irregular. There were gains in the morning and a selloff in the afternoon.

A magic figure, long predicted by some investment analysts, was registered on the ticker tape yesterday when shares of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reached 250, just before the close on the Big Board.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Rockefeller approved today a bill designed to give unemployed workers who have exhausted their twenty-six weeks of state benefits an additional benefit period.

FASHIONS from Paris. New York and Hollywood walked right into American living rooms last night as a sizable segment of the country's population watched the telecast of the Academy Awards presentations.
ATHENS, April 6 -- The results of yesterday's Greek municipal elections showed a definite turn against communism throughout the country, the Minister of Interior, Demetrius Makris, declared tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Sophia Loren and John Gavin will co-star in a film version of Ferenc Molnar's play "Olympia." Michael Curtiz will direct.
A Cuban delegation seeking to put into service eight strikebound ships Cuba bought from Canada last year met yesterday with American and Canadian labor leaders.
AMES, Iowa, April 6 (AP) -Iowa State's Bill Strannigan turned down a substantial salary boost today to accept the head basketball coaching position at Wyoming.

A concert and art exhibition at the Kosciuszko Foundation at 15 East Sixty-fifth Street Friday evening will benefit the Walter Damrosch Memorial Scholarship Fund of the Fontainebleau Schools of Music and Fine Arts. A reception will be held after the event.

This is a truly crucial moment for the Bolivian Government. On Thursday the M. N. R. party, which staged the successful revolution of 1952, celebrates the seventh anniversary of its victory. That victory is in the balance.

QUEENS COLLEGE has reason to be proud of its composition department. The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will benefit from the April 30 performance of the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, April 6 -- The Treasury gave further details today of Britain's exceptionally good showing in the economic field last year.
THE man whose closet resembles Fibber McGee's may not be comfortable with his clutter much longer. Spring cleaning time is almost upon him.

SEATTLE, April 6 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, headed by Harry Bridges, opened its thirteenth annual convention here today with interest centered on the union's relationships with other parts of the labor movement.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that the spread of racial hate literature in the South had increased more than 400 per cent since the school intergration crisis began.
LONG BEACH, L. I., April 6 -- The lengthening of the school day here and in New Hyde Park has resulted in greater learning in the last six months, educators of both school districts said today.

Vito Genovese, convicted last Friday on narcotics conspiracy charges, posted an additional $100,000 bail in Federal Court yesterday to remain at liberty pending sentencing April 17. He had already put up a $50,000 bond.

Clergymen were urged yesterday to give extensive premarital counseling. The annual family life conference of the Protestant Council of the City of New York also addressed a plea to young persons to be married in church "with benefit of Christian family guidance."
When an ichthyologist decided recently to go to Nassau for his honeymoon, the Aquarium at Coney Island got an unexpected windfall.
AN extraordinary show called "Mark Twain Tonight!" slipped into the Forty-first Street Theatre last evening. There should have been posters up all over town to herald its arrival.
The Walt Disney organization has rejoined the Motion Picture Association of America. The announcement was made yesterday after a meeting of the M. P. A. A.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of April 4 "Hospital Strike Menace" once again focuses attention on the right of private, non-profit hospital workers to organize and bargain collectively as well as the need to insure uninterrupted service to the patients.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a rare public statement, warned today of "indications of increased manipulative activity" in the stock market. It said speculation "is a field for the experts, and the amateur who 'plays the market' is asking for trouble."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The "double jeopardy" rule of procedure laid down for the Department of Justice by Attorney General Rogers is a model not only for administrators of government. Western Massachusetts Companies has set a subscription price of $25 a share on its 161,626share offering to stockholders. Holders of record April 3 will get rights to subscribe for one new share for each fifteen held.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Treasury bill rate moved up substantially again this week, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate on $1,200,000,000 of 91-day discount bills was 2.948 per cent, compared with 2.841 per cent last week.

Net income of companies accounting for the bulk of the steel produced in the United States declined more than 30 per cent last year. But the cash dividends those concerns declared fell 4.7 per cent. This was reported yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

GROTON, Conn., April 7 -- The atomic submarine Skate glided home from the North Pole today. The Skate, the first ship ever to rest amid the ice hummocks at the top of the world, now is also the only vessel to have explored thoroughly and fairly easily the secret of the Arctic Ocean in summer and in winter.
LONDON, April 7 -- Britons received tax and other concessions equivalent to more than $1,000,000,000 today in a budget for 1959-60 designed primarily to encourage economic expansion.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 7 -- A resolution calling for a State Senate investigation of a strike that has closed The St. Louis Globe-Democrat since Feb. 21 was taken under consid eration tonight by the Senate's Committee on Resolutions.
A senior inspector in the Buildings Department was suspended for thirty days without pay yesterday.
BONN, Germany, April 7 -The Adenauer era, whose end was foreshadowed today, will be remembered as one of the shining decades in German history.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -The Washington International Airport, now under construction, will use a new system of loading and unloading passengers and servicing airplanes.
Stocks went through a seemingly aimless session and closed a little lower yesterday. Chemicals and rubbers were the strongest of the major groups but some issues in both showed losses.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 7 (AP) -- A subsidiary of Aluminium Ltd. of Canada will build a $6,000,000 aluminum fabricating plant in New Zealand, the company said today.

John G. Palfrey, Dean of Columbia College, assured more than 300 students and alumni varsity C letter men that "We are closer to finding a site for the new Columbia gymnasium than I can tell you" at the thirty-eighth annual Varsity C Club dinner in John Jay Hall last night.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 7 -- Nassau County's first historical museum and library is expected to be opened in Salisbury Park next year. A. Holly Patterson, the County Executive, said today.
LONDON, April 7 -- A sinister, rust-covered relic of World War II gave the heart of London a tense ten hours this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke has criticized excessive reliance upon the concept of "massive retaliation" and warned against building up too much nuclear striking power to deter a surprise Soviet attack.
WARSAW, April 7 -- One of Warsaw's non-Communist intellectuals smiled a little the other day when he was asked about Polish reactions to the German problem.

In a surprise development Chancellor Adenauer is stepping down from his powerful if onerous position as head of the West German Government to assume the more ceremonial post of West German President. He is doing so upon request and nomination by his ruling Christian Democratic party, and since this party controls a majority in the Federal Convention that will elect the new President, his election is accepted as a foregone conclusion.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has divested itself of its stock in Broadcast Music, Inc., a music-licensing agency.

In your editorial "All the State's Fault" in The New York Times of April 3 you attempt to blame the city for the state's $10 million cut of the city's allocation (so that the state could balance its budget at the city's expense). You seem to feel that the Democrats should not have opposed but should have swallowed Rockefeller's tax program hook, line and sinker.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Committee for Economic Development endorsed President Eisenhower's balanced budget today. It said spending increases should be matched by higher taxes.

TOKYO, April 7 -- Possibly no American here since General of the Army Douglas MacArthur arrived nearly fourteen years ago has received the concentrated admiration that has been given to Mrs. Elizabeth Gray Vining.

PARIS, April 7 -- Surprise and some concern showed through the discreet official silence with which France greeted the news that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, would quit active direction of his country's affairs.
Robert M. Watson, chairman of Erwin Wasey, Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., will join the Kudner Agency, Inc., on April 15 as a senior vice president.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that it would make a public offering tomorrow in West Germany of 200,000,000deutsche-mark, 5 per cent bonds (about $47,600,000), due from 1965 to 1974.

As the time approaches for a top-level conference on the whole question of Germany, let us not forget -- when discussing the complex trade-cultural and "real-politik" topics -- the ever-present human aspect so tragically ignored at Munich.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 7 (UPI) -- Racing Director Henry Banks of the United States Auto Club gave a clean bill of health to the new Daytona International Speedway today in the wake of two fatal crashes, but said Daytona still was too fast for "the equipment now available."

BOSTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Gerry Ehman of the Leafs converted a pass from Frank Mahovlich with two and one-half minutes remaining tonight as Toronto defeated the Boston Bruins, 3-2. The victory enabled the Leafs to capture the Stanley Cup semi-final play-offs, four games to three.
District Attorneys and high police officials were reassured yesterday that chemical tests for intoxication were still sound. They received the assurance in the form of a scientific lesson.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 7 -- The political power of the atom was discussed here today by a United States Senator, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and a leading electric utility executive.

Sales and earnings of the P. Lorillard Company in the first quarter this year will exceed the records set in the corresponding three months last year, Lewis Gruber, board chairman and chief executive officer, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. A year ago the cigarette producer earned $5,597,012, or $1.90 a share, on sales of $104,094,971.
Senhora Sarah Kubitschek, wife of the President of Brazil, arrived here yesterday morning with her two teenage daughters for a "private" visit of about three weeks in this country.

Seventy-five members of the Parent-Teachers Association of Public School 193 in Whitestone, Queens, will visit the headquarters of the Soviet mission to the United Nations next Tuesday night to hear a cultural attache speak on education in Russian schools.
The German Society, one of the city's oldest nonsectarian philanthropic organizations, celebrated its 175th anniversary last night at a dinner at the Astor Hotel.
Two men named Schweitzer met in court yesterday.
A first effort by a woman playwright yesterday nosed out by one vote two other major contenders for the Drama Critics Circle Award for the best American play.

American Export Lines announced yesterday that Capt. Otto Trautman of Cedar Grove, N. J., was in command of the company's cargo ship Extavia, which is preparing to sail across the Atlantic into the new St. Lawrence Seaway.

A onetime $2.50-a-week messenger boy who did not go beyond the seventh grade will lecture on the life and poetry of Walt Whitman tomorrow night before students and distinguished scholars at New York University.

The 1959 Brandeis University Creative Arts Awards were presented yesterday at a ceremony and reception at the SheratonEast Hotel. The awards were established three years ago to further interest in the arts.
PARIS, April 7 -- Twenty-four hours after police raids on several Moslem quarters of Paris, Algerian terrorists struck back with attacks on two suburban police stations early this morning.

Cecil Rhodes Jr., denying reports that another switch in site was being considered, last night insisted the Floyd PattersonBrian London world heavyweight championship fight would be held in Indianapolis on Friday night, May 1.

LONDON, April 7 -- The British Government has urged its allies to negotiate a relaxation of East-West tensions so that internal pressures in the Soviet Union would have free play, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- A Senate rackets committee witness swore today that Detroit juke box operators had paid Teamster Union president, James R. Hoffa, and an associate $6,000 to keep underworld-backed competitors from getting a union charter.
Mayor Wagner made it clear yesterday that he was assigning a full share of the blame to Governor Rockefeller for the level of state financial aid to the city.
Bond prices were unable yesterday to maintain recent levels. They drifted downward by slight fractions in slow trading.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The first direct conversion of nuclear reactor heat into electricity was described by atomic officials today as an important technological advance that opens new horizons for propulsion in space and generation of electricity on earth.
Young birds, from the egg to first full flight, are in a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History. They are shown in a permanent display in the Sanford Hall of the Biology of Birds.

The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers won bargaining representation yesterday for the employes of the Chester Cable Corporation in Chester, N. Y. Last November, the president of the company shot to death an organizer for a rival union.

LITTLE ROCK Ark., April 7 (AP) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that there would be "trouble and plenty of it" if the courts prohibit use of state funds to finance attendance at segregated schools by students opposed to integration.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In its dismay and disappointment over the pending resignation of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany, official Washington has been reflecting on an old principle of foreign policy.

VIENNA, April 7 -- The Board of Governors of the International Atomic Agency began a twoweek meeting today to review the work in progress and to plan for the systematic expansion of the agency's activities.

ONE of the world's most celebrated autobiographies, Benvenuto Cellini's, has delighted hordes of readers for hundreds of years with its intimate and zestful narrative of an artist's life during the Italian Renaissance. Another autobiography by another great Renaissance personage, although almost as entertaining, is unknown to all save historical scholars.
BOSTON, April 7 -- Each puff of a cigarette may make the smoker grow older and more leathery.

THERE will be an outpouring of genuine baseball fans and historians at Griffith Stadium on the morrow when the Washington Senators open the American League season against the Baltimore Orioles. The Senators don't figure to attract casual customers, but the real zealots will be on tap from force of habit.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Public Health Service is undertaking a five-year study of 40,000 pregnant women in an effort to find the cause of cerebral palsy, mental retardation and other birth injuries.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, April 7 -- The 100th season of Stratford-on-Avon's Shakespeare Memorial Theatre received an impressive send-off tonight when "Othello" was produced. America can justly be proud of the share it has had in it.
New corporate securities valued at more than $75,000,000 are being offered to investors today. The offerings are:

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications Commissioner, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had conspired to influence improperly the award of Miami television Channel 10 to a subsidiary of National Airlines.
Earnings of the General Tire and Rubber Company rose $4,280,423 to $6,034,547 in the quarter ended Feb. 28. Sales were $40,822,520 above the preceding year's level.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 15 points yesterday, except the distant July, which advanced 6 points. The close was near the lows of the day. Prices receded 13 to 27 points from the early highs, following an assurance by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson that the 1959 cotton purchase and sales program would be ready for the start of the new crop season.
BUFFALO, April 7 -- Five present and former city officials were charged here today with accepting bribes in the letting of city street-paving contracts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- An anonymous and over-zealous clock-watcher was the center of conversation in Hollywood this morning, following an Academy Awards television show that ended twenty minutes too soon.

Fifteen Dutch tourists, a Belgian couple and a family from Italy landed here yesterday to explore the United States in their own cars and trailers. They debarked from the Holand-American liner Ryndam in Hoboken.
DETROIT, April 7 (UPI) -The Detroit Harvester Company announced today the purchase of the Weaver Manufacturing Company of Springfield, Ill., for an undisclosed amount of cash.
VICTORIA, Tex., April 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs, with the aid of five home runs, ralliedthree times today to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 8 -- 7, in eleven innings.
SHILLONG, India, April 7 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru will discuss with the Dalai Lama when he arrives in New Delhi the possibility of a return to Tibet, informed sources said today.
An autopsy revealed yesterday that the death-of-Albert E. Hunter, 54-year-old chief engineer of the Grace liner Santa Rosa, had been caused by a heart ailment.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 7 (AP) -- Felix (Doc) Blanchard and Glenn Davis of Army, Christy Mathewson, Johnny Lujack, Jim Crowley and Frank Leahy were among the 1959 nominees listed today for the Football Hall of Fame.
Paperboard production declined last week to 295,358 tons from the record of 318,345 tons in the week before, the National Paperboard Association has reported.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 7 (Reuters) -- Premier Kassim promised a pardon today to any member of the powerful Shammar tribe who seeks it.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

NEWARK, April 7 -- Newark officials had high hopes today that low bids totaling $4,519,889 would mean the construction of an underground parking garage at Military Park in the city's downtown section.
DETROIT, April 7 -- Michigan Democrats capped ten years of steady election gains today by winning control of the state's four major educational boards.
A University of Chicago scientist last night urged greater expenditures for basic research -- with no strings attached -- in the biological sciences.
SAVANNAH, Ga., April 7 -There may be many reasons why the experts do not rate the Cincinnati Reds' pennant chances in the National League too highly, but Casey Stengel couldn't think of one today.

MELBOURNE, April 7 -- Wool prices have risen as much as 10 per cent at the Sydney wool auctions in the last two days. Prices rose sharply on resumption of sales on Monday in the first Australian wool auctions since the three-week Easter recess.

Steve Allen, Fred Astaire, Leonard Bernstein and Orson Welles were announced yesterday as winners of George Foster Peabody television awards for 1958. A total of sixteen awards were presented by the Peabody committee in recognition of distinguished achievement in television and radio.
BUENOS AIRES, April 7 -- Argentina expelled a high Soviet diplomat today on charges that he instigated last Friday's Communist-Peronist disturbances here.
Seven teen-age gang members were accused yesterday of having made "a choice to kill" the night Julio Ramos, a 22-yearold Cuban was fatally beaten in Jefferson Park. The beating occurred last May 30.

Wool prices were sharply higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops rose 1.6 to 2.9 cents a pound and grease wool gained 1.9 to 2.7 cents. Trading was very heavy and the market closed at or near the highs of the day.

BERLIN, April 7 -- Premier Khrushchev's announcement of Soviet intentions to change the status of West Berlin came with as much of a shock to the 17,000,000 East Germans as it did to the people in West Berlin and in the non-Communist world.
An attempt to break a deadlock over a new contract and avert a printers' strike against ten New York newspapers will be made at a meeting here today.
SOMETIMES a whisper speaks louder than a shout. Henri Bendel has proved this in its exclusive collection of Bottier shoes.
DETROIT, April 7 -- The United Automobile Workers announced today that a Toledo official of the union had been discharged for accepting commissions from a New York engineering consultant firm.

TRENTON, April 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner predicted considerable delay today in the enactment of legislation to cope with a State Supreme Court ruling requiring assessments at 100 per cent of true value.
BERLIN, April 7 -- The East German Communists appeared overjoyed today at Chancellor Adenauer's decision to step down from politics and accept the nomination for the West German Presidency.

In "Chamber Music '59," a concert played last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, three composers, William Carlin, Edward Cone, and Malcolm Peyton, were each represented by one distinctive and substantial composition.
The Hanover Bank here has announced the election of John A. Coleman, John E. Heyke and Eugene J. McNeely as trustees.
New York City residents will take shelter for ten minutes on Monday, April 27, as part of the national Civil Defense training exercise, Operation Alert, 1959.

Waters Recently the rising waters of man-made Lake Kariba (the result of a new dam across the Zambezi River), in Southern Rhodesia, took a terrible toll of wildlife in the area. A brave but hopelessly inadequate team of rangers was able to rescue only a small fraction of the marooned animal population.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Government reported today a net rise of 1,106,000 job holders in March and a decrease of 387,000 in the unemployed.
LONDON, April 7 -- The Cairo radio said today that a revolt against the Kassim regime had started in northern Iraq.

IF the baseball record of the Dodgers and the career of Susan Hayward are criteria, then the winning of honors is the roughest of assignments for Brooklynites. The lean years far outnumbered the fat ones at Ebbets Field, as any disgruntled aficionado will attest.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Congress resumed work at a saunter today after an eleven-day Easter vacation.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 -- President Eisenhower stepped from his special plane after a two-hour flight from Washington today and remarked:

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- The Air Force Academy Foundation, Inc., today asked the Air Force to approve a $3,000,000 fund-raising drive to build a 40,000-seat football stadium for the Colorado Springs school.
A "dressed up" public coin telephone that occupies much less space than the customary booth is being tested in Milwaukee by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
THERE can be a lot of living in a small space, according to Bloomingdale's. Practically every model room that goes on view there today is readily adaptable to the one-room apartment.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 7 -Oklahomans voted an end today to fifty-one years of prohibition.
LONDON, April 7 -- Prices showed no decided trend on the stock market today. But a few of the high-price industrial issues advanced sufficiently to raise the Financial Times index by 0.6 to 225.
BOSTON, April 7 (UPI) -- A New Hampshire resident who refused to pay his Massachusetts income tax was arrested today and jailed.

The New York Central Railroad is seeking a Government guarantee from the Interstate Commerce Commission for a fifteen-year collateral loan, according to the company's president, Alfred E. Perlman. He said that Central's vice president-finance, Walter R. Grant, was in Washington yesterday in connection with a filing with the I. C. C. for the loan, under provisions of the Transportation Act of 1958.

Today's new film is "Thunder in the Sun," a Paramount Western drama co-starring Susan Hayward and Jeff Chandler, at neighborhood theatres. Charles Green produced and Russell Rouse directed. Jacques Bergerac and Carl Esmond are among the supporting players.

SEATTLE, April 7 -- Harry Bridges, the labor leader, said here today that a new world economic balance favoring the Soviet bloc countries was possible by 1965. He said this might happen unless the United States experiences a boom in the next five or six years comparable to that of the 1941-45 period.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7 -- Harvard Law School heard tonight an appeal to both the courts and their critics to focus on underlying principles of constitutional law, not on the results in particular cases.

A high figure in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said last night that the fifteen powers in the alliance agreed in their Washington talks last week that there could be no appeasement in the Berlin crisis.
A merger of the Central Public Utility Corporation with Philips Industries, Inc., Consolidated Electronics Corporation and Philips Electronics, Inc., was called "a distinct possibility" yesterday.

Strange goings-on. Program of advanced music last night. Note word "advanced." Not merely "modern." Given at Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. More advanced than anything. Small but select audience.

The New York Heart Association announced yesterday that a research fellowship in cardiovascular diseases had been named in honor of Meyer Berger, the late Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and columnist of The New York Times.
LONDON, April 7 -- Regret contended against relief in the British reaction to the withdrawal of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer from active political leadership in Germany.

A first novel by Austin Coates, son of the English composer Eric Coates, will be issued May 13 by Harper. Called "The Road," it is about the construction of a road in the Far East and its effect on the lives of the British and Chinese concerned with it.

The United States consumes more than 9,000,000 tons of sugar a year, more than any other nation. Some 3,000,000 tons are produced on the mainland and the remainder is imported from foreign countries or obtained from United States possessions.
KALIMPONG, India, April 7 (Reuters) -- There has been a lull in the fighting between Chinese Communist troops and Tibetan rebels in the last few days, according to reports reaching here today.
What was charted as the highest mountain in Antarctica has been surveyed by a trail party and found to be more than 6,000 feet lower than previously estimated.

I join you and others who have protested against Chinese aggression in Tibet. The annexation of Tibet by Communist China through brute force was called by one of the Indian Socialist leaders the "rape of a child." The ruthless Communist regime has rightly been condemned and exposed by all freedom-loving Indians living in India, barring a few naive fellow travelers who still refuse to call a spade a spade.
THE telecast of the presentation of the Oscar motion-picture awards, the foreshortened affair seen on Monday evening over Channel 4, was a bewildering pot-pourri.

TRENTON, April 7 -- A State Supreme Court decision cleared the way today for the construction of the first major reservoir in New Jersey in seventy-five years. Constructioned is scheduled to begin this year.
Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council, declared yesterday he had no intention of asking Governor Rockefeller to sign a bill for five new City Court seats in Brooklyn.

The Child Study Association of America will benefit from an evening at the ballet. Tickets are still available for the April 21 performance of "Swan Lake" by the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House. They may be obtained from the office of the beneficiary at 132 East Seventy-fourth Street.

ABDOL HOSSEIN HAMZAVI is a gentleman from Iran who has dined at the world's finest tables. In his opinion, however, the most subtle cuisine in the world is that of his native Persia. He discussed his homeland's food this week overhelpings of smoked trout and steamed mussels at New York's Cafe Chauveron.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- A Government witness suggested today the setting up of separate corporations to ease the tax impact of a proposed Government plan to divorce the du Pont Company of its 23 per cent interest in General Motors.

LOS ANGELES, April 7 -Evangelical Protestants will not participate in any future ecumenical council called by Pope John XXIII. Dr. Herbert S. Mekell, head of the National Association of Evangelicals, said today. He addressed 1,000 delegates at the association's annual convention.

YONKERS, April 7 -- On this, the sixteenth night, the mutuel handle at Yonkers Raceway reached a total of $26,487,835 for the season after the crowd of 19,997 had wagered $1,772,242 on the nine races and the daily double.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 -The Arab League declined to commit itself tonight on questions of communism in the Arab world and the dispute between Iraq and the United Arab Republic.
WASHINGTON, April 7 --Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's decision to seek the Presidency of West Germany, and thus to withdraw from active politics, caught Washington by surprise.

New York City's municipal colleges have a tradition of free tuition that goes back 110 years. We can understand the strength of sentiment that opposes any suggestion that this principle of a free college education be abandoned. Nevertheless we believe the policy deserves review.
The Port of New York tuned up successfully yesterday for the approaching annual transAtlantic passenger shipping rush.
A strike of 3,450 unionized employes at six voluntary hospitals has been threatened for any time after 6 A. M. April 22 unless the managements agree to recognize and bargain with the union.
The Hungarian Catholic League of America will give a dinner for the benefit of Hungarian victims of communism on April 22 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
WATER-COLORS by artists of the United States, Canada and Mexico are included in the twentieth Biennial International Water-Color Exhibition, which opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 7 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, declared in the Federal Assembly today that he could see no reason why a "tidal wave of African nationalism" should not be checked.

George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, has had to make several trips to Washington from his Boston office in recent months. The trips were in connection with the road's application for an equipment loan of $9,800,000, on which it seeks a Government guarantee.
Dr. John J. Theobald, city Superintendent of Schools, served notice yesterday that teachers who took part in a threatened one-day work stoppage next week would do so at their own expense.

Los Angeles, Calif., School Districts raised $27,000,000 to finance school construction yesterday by the sale of serial bonds due from 1960 to 1984. The obligations were sold at competitive bidding to a syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., April 7 -- The first conversion of energy from an atomic reactor directly into electricity was announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission's laboratory here.
Eight women and two men received jail terms ranging from thirty days to one year yesterday for chiseling relief funds. They were jailed by Kings County Judge John R. Starkey.

North American Aviation, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement to acquire the Foster Wheeler Corporation for about $27,763,000. Combined assets of the two companies are $396,077,526. Their merger would be one of the year's major consolidations.
The City Council unanimously adopted a resolution yesterday reaffirming its support of the year-old city law banning racial and religious discrimination in most private rental housing.

Charles A. Halleck, Minority Leader in the House of Representatives, appealed last night for acceptance of President Eisenhower's $77,000,000,000 budget. He said the sum represented "a proper balance between the needs of the armed forces in the field and the economy at home."

LONDON, April 7 -- British investigators of living cells have achieved a major break-through in their inquiries into the fundamental cause of grave human defects such as Mongoloid idiocy, abnormalities of the sexual organs and possibly leukemia.

PARIS, April 7 -- There is a deceptive air of calm in the West as the clock ticks toward an inevitable crisis. Perhaps this calm is induced by the benevolent effect of spring; perhaps by the fact that the show-down date originally fixed by Khrushchev was postponed by agreement on a foreign ministers' conference.

COLRAIN, Mass., April 7 -There is a persistent oldwives'tale that the strong, hardy outdoorsman loves solitude and all the joys that are supposed to lurk in it. There is obviously no truth in this but it hangs on as senselessly as the idea that there is something intrinsically good about work.

VANCOUVER, B. C., April 7 (AP) -- Dr. Creighton J. Hale, the vice-president of the world Little League Organization, said today that a study had shown the necessity for greater safety in Little League play.

All the horses were ready in the paddock -- all except one. The missing racer was the Brookfield Farm's Inescapable and he was the one the 20,678 fans were betting into odds-on favoritism in the feature event at Jamaica yesterday.
The Transit Authority approved a $6,000,000 project yesterday to cut an IRT express station out of rock seventy-three feet below Lexington Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street.
BONN, Germany, April 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer agreed today to run for election this summer as President of West Germany -- an office of high honor but little power.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- A Government advisory group said today that 1958 was marked by "a slight but definite easing" of tension, especially in propaganda between the United States and the Soviet Union.
The shipping industry yesterday attacked "fly-by-night" and "hit-and-run" ship lines whose rate-cutting practices are troubling older concerns.
Directors of the Brillo Manufacturing Company, Inc., proposed yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock through issuance of two additional shares for each held.
NOT even a toothbrush has been omitted in the typical American home that will be on view at the American National Exhibition in Moscow this summer.
A 32-year-old Navy veteran who gave up the practice of law to do social work on the Bowery was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for having harbored an Army deserter.

Sales of petroleum products by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first three months of this year were at the highest level for such a period, Eugene Holman, chairman, and M. J. Rathbone, president, have reported in the company's 1958 annual report.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Administration asked Congress today to raise unemployment compensation taxes, but maintained that the Government should not prescribe minimum standards for benefits. All such taxes are paid by the employer.

New Yorkers starting to pay higher taxes can well envy the British, who heard splendid news yesterday from Chancellor of the Exchequer Heathcoat Amory. There has been no British budget as cheering as this since well before the second World War.

Twenty thousand Boy Scouts from the five boroughs will participate next week in the largest youth show ever assembled here, the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 7 -- The Kremlin suggested today that Dr. Konrad Adenauer had decided to retire as West German Chancellor because of differences in his Governemnt over the recent British diplomatic initiative.
BALTIMORE, April 7 (AP) -- Gus Triandos hit a grandslam home run in the first inning today to spark the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

THE city unwrapped a glittering, $13,000,000 package yesterday. It is the new home of the Fashion Institute of Technology, the only college in existence whose sole purpose is to teach the art and science of the clothing industry.
United States marshals and postal inspectors yesterday raided the headquarters of three men described as being among the biggest dealers in obscenity on the East Coast.

Edward Specter Productions, Inc., has started suit in the State Supreme Court to establish its right to present on Broadway the late John van Druten's adaptation of the best-selling novel, "Anatomy of a Murder."
ST. PAUL, April 7 (AP) -The Boston Celtics defeated the Minneapolis Lakers tonight, 123 -- 110, and took a 3-0 lead in the National Basketball Associations final play-off.

Not often has a set of statistics been awaited with such eagerness as that which preceded yesterday's release of new data on employment and unemployment. Public interest in such basic indicators of our economic health is of course to be welcomed. At the same time it is always to be hoped that those who use such data will realize that a penumbra of uncertainty surrounds them because of sampling and other errors.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, Soviet Deputy Premier, believes communism will prevail in the United States, Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- An Old Guard Republican fight to block the election of Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky as chairman of the Republican National Committee withered away tonight.
BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- Red Storey, unnerved by criticism of his officiating in last Saturday's Montreal-Chicago play-off game, quit today as a National Hockey League referee.
FREEPORT, L. I., April 7 -One hundred parents waited on the sidewalk as long as sixteen hours last night to enroll their children at Our Holy Redeemer School here.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will send the Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered merchant vessel, down the ways at its launching July 21 at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yards here.

IN the second installment of the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors show at the Riverside Museum. Riverside Drive and 103d Street (the first was held in November), there are paintings and sculptures by some forty artists.
FRANKFURT, Germany, April 7 (AP) -- West Germans were stunned tonight when told that Dr. Konrad Adenauer would retire to the presidency.
A 14-year-old boy was electrocuted last night after he lay down on the elevated IRT tracks at 125th Street to let a train pass over him.

Further evidence of the hard days our railroads have fallen upon is the debasing of the splendid old concourse of Grand Central Terminal with roped-off and spotlighted areas where goods and services are huckstered during the busiest hours of travel each day.
WEST POINT, April 7 -- The new look that Army gave to football a year ago with its lonely-end formation is still the vogue here, though the man who fashioned it is no longer in the picture.
A 6-foot 4-inch youth was arrested last night as a suspected robber who specialized in Central Park muggings.
New York City, as the potential fifty-first state of the union, was visualized yesterday as a great place to visit and a most desirable place to live.
Governor Rockefeller will meet today in Albany with Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan to discuss charges about Mr. Monaghan's office made by the State Investigation Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri, said today that his stepdaughter was resigning from her $5,200-a-year job on the staff of the Senate Constitutional Rights Subcommittee.

The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday the names of four more singers who will join the company's roster next year. They are Elisabeth Soederstroem, Swedish soprano; Christa Ludwig, German mezzo-soprano; Jon Vickers, Canadian tenor, and Kim Borg, Finnish bass-baritone.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -Senator Joseph S. Clark of Pennsylvania has written a private letter to the Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson, apparently joining some of the recent criticism of the leadership.

The one eminently satisfactory part of spring housecleaning lies in washing the windows. This is just as well, for it is the part the cleaners themselves do not do, but farm out to others. To bring this about, they use cajolery, tears and bribery in the form of rich and rare foodstuffs for luncheon.

IT'S probably more curiosity than unrequited love but a few unreformed followers of the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Giants have been asking questions of returning travelers. They inquire after the health and well-being of the departed heroes with a sad solicitude.

ROSLYN, L. I April 8 -- The replacement or expansion of the Town of North Hempstead's incinerator at New Hyde Park was recommended here today in lieu of a $3,600,000 incinerator proposed by the Town Board for Hempstead Harbor.
I refer to your editorial of March 21, "Tension on the Brenner."
TOKYO, April 8 -- Japanese leaders were reported to have agreed today on the main concessions to be sought in a revision of the security treaty with the United States.
DETROIT, April 8 (AP) -The Ford Motor Company reestablished today its $2.40 annual dividend rate.

YONKERS, April 8 -- When a racegoer at Yonkers Raceway "goes for broke," there is no need to fret about getting home. That is, if home is within a $2 traveling range of the swanky Westchester harness racing plant.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -unlike previous Washington incisions by angry men, today's March of the unemployed was dangerous as a box, social.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -Medical schools were urged today to go vigorously into the "dirty area" of evaluating new drugs offered by pharmaceutical manufacturers for physicians' use.
Automobile deaths, injuries and accidents in the last three months showed a "frightening increase" compared with the same period last year, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

ROME, April 8 -- A 21-year-old girl was tossed about today in the political storm over missile bases in Italy. She is Signorina Wanda Pella, the only child of Giuseppe Pella, Foreign Minister of Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer's decision to step down as Chancellor to seek the West German Presidency was viewed in Washington today as wise, courageous and praiseworthy.

The uranium subsidiaries of the Atlas Corporation, investment company, are operating profitably and the prospect is for higher production and sales in 1959. This was announced in the annual report, released today.
CHICAGO, April 8 -- Diamond rings were reduced 15 per cent by Montgomery Ward Co. today in a special sales catalogue mailed to 5,000,000 persons.
CHICAGO, April 8 -- Fatin Rustu Zorlu, Turkish Foreign Minister, suggested today that a Marshall-Plan type of organization be set up by the Western powers to help under-developed countries.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., April 8 -- Two business men and six salesmen were arrested today by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and charged with fraud in kickbacks to homeowners to induce them to make fraudulent applications for home improvement loans.

The First National City Bank of New York said yesterday that it had completed arrangements with International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the installation of an automatic system to process bank checks, perform deposit accounting and accomplish related reporting and analysis.
The mark of a New Yorker yesterday was a light topcoat, a fur stole or perhaps a raincoat slung over the arm. Some residents even stripped down to shirtsleeves in the near-80-degree weather.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 8 -- The chief of Iraq's Army General Staff said today a civilian militia had been "supplied with adequate arms to enable them to carry out their duties."

VIENNA, April 8 -- The United States Government informed the International Atomic Energy Agency today that it was prepared to contribute $600,000 toward the construction and equipping of a laboratory.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The House voted today to let United States Boy Scouts travel on military transport ships to the World Scout Jamboree in the Philippines this summer.

BOSTON, April 8 -- A woman chemist from the Johns Hopkins University Radiation Laboratory said today that a smoke from plastics used in ordinary household items might be used to shield workers from experimental nuclear blasts.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8 -- Following is the text of an address on the challenge of Soviet power, delivered today by Allen W. Dulles, Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, before the Edison Electric Institute:

GYPSY ROSE LEE, author, art collector and doyenne of the runway, joined the lobster shift of raconteurs on Channel 13 Tuesday evening. In her new program, running from 11 P. M. to 12:20 A. M., the stately subject of a forthcoming musical quickly proved one of the medium's most attractive test patterns.

For every dollar by which Americans increased their debt to buy homes, cars and other goods during 1958, they added $1.33 to their savings in life insurance, savings bank accounts and United States Savings Bonds.

One of the most valuable social institutions in the city, Henry Street Settlement, works quietly on the lower East Side. It serves more than 11,000 members of forty different racial and religious groups ranging in age from the pre-school nursery group to the "Good Companions," men and women over 60 who gather daily to enjoy a variety of activities.

LORRAINE HANSBERRY began by wanting to be a painter. She was a "lousy painter," in her own words. She then turned to writing. That she is not a "lousy" writer is attested to by the fact that Tuesday she won the New York Drama Critics Circle award for the best American play of the season.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A conference of the unemployed lashed the Administration with five hours of oratory today.
OTTAWA, April 8 -- Premier Joseph Smallwood of Newfoundland carried his feud with Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Federal Government into Canada's capital here today.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced last night that his investigation into the alleged bribery of union representatives would not be halted by the discharge of an official of the United Automobile Workers in Toledo.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A shortage of Government-owned grain estimated at more than $1,000,000 was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its consolidated subsidiaries have reported an increase in net income for the six months ended Feb. 28 to $12,332,320 from $11,838,932 in the period a year earlier. The net for the latest period equaled $1.43 a share compared with $1.38.

SEATTLE, April 8 -- Delegates to the thirteenth biennial convention of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union took sharp issue today with President Eisenhower's handling of the Berlin crisis.
ELEA, Cyprus, April 8 -- Turkish Cypriote leaders have asked for an assessment of farmland their people have abandoned since the inter-communal fighting last summer.
The details of an enlarged municipal Aquarium at Coney Island became available yesterday.
The Coast Guard yesterday concluded its seven-day investigation of the collision between the Grace liner Santa Rosa and the tanker Valchem.

Ever since that historic afternoon of Dec. 2, 1942, when Enrico Fermi and his team lighted the first atomic fire on earth on the University of Chicago squash court, leaders in electrical science and technology the world over have been concentrating their skills and know-how on the problem of converting the vast heat energy liberated in a nuclear reactor into electricity in a system competitive with conventional methods of generating electrical energy.

A WILDLY disheveled spoof on the folkways of Organization Man is presented in Shepherd Mead's new novel, "The Four Window Girl, or How to Make More Money Than Men."* This is one of the funniest books of the season. But don't let your unabridged enjoyment of it blind you to its awesome message. If any.

Mayor Wagner has been urged to consider stripping Park Commissioner Robert Moses of his authority over traffic on city parkways. The jurisdiction would be given to Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley to achieve "uniformity of standards."
Mayor Wagner charged last night that the city's proposal for a $12,000,000-a-year bank check tax had been killed as a result of pressure by "big business firms" on New York banks.
CHICAGO, April 8 -- Mayor Richard J. Dales, re-elected yesterday, made clear today that he regarded his victory as a mandate to re-make the city.

Major breakthroughs in cerebral palsy research for the near future were forecast yesterday by Dr. Brewster S. Miller, director of research for the United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational Foundation.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Detroit juke box operators surrendered to the underworld when William Bufalino, an associate of James R. Hoffa, took control of the Teamster Union's juke box local, Senate investigators were told today.
BONN, Germany, April 8 ( Reuters ) -- Following, in an unofficial translation from the German, is the text of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's radio address tonight:
RYE, N. Y., April 8 -- Two Princeton University students completed a roundabout trip by horse and buggy today from Princeton, N. J., to this city.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen charged the Democratic Advisory Council today with a "destructive, negative, blindly partisan attack" in its recent report criticizing the Administration's foreign policy.
ALBANY, April 8 -- George L. Hinman, Binghamton lawyer who has been one of Governor Rockefeller's closest political advisers, was named today as the state's new Republican National Committeeman.
A dock dispute at Port Newark yesterday halted the loading of the freighter Astwi and idled some 300 dockworkers.
LONDON, April 8 -- The Labor party and the trade unions criticized the Government's taxreduction budget today on the ground that it neglected the unemployed and the aged.
Tom Mboya of Kenya, an African nationalist leader, arrived here yesterday for a scheduled African Freedom Day observance next Wednesday.
The possible use of the antituberculosis drug isoniazid as a mass preventive of the disease, as well as a treatment, was discussed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- Neil McElroy has reassured Alaskans that national military planning called for "full defense" of the new northern state.

A 12,160-ton Japanese freighter and a railroad barge collided in the East River just below the Williamsburg Bridge last night. A hole was ripped in the freighter's bow, above the water line, but there were no casualties.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Warren Olney 3d, director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, has resigned from the American Bar Association because of its criticism of the Supreme Court.
Your editorial of April 1 ascribes increased insurance rates to unfit drivers. Instead of blaming the motorist for a high accident rate why not put the blame where it belongs?
NEW DELHI India April 8 -- Reports from the frontier said today the Dalai Lama's followers had proclaimed a provisional government inside Tibet to fight for independence from Communist China.

Sales of beer by Anheuser-Busch, Inc., St. Louis, in the first quarter of 1959, aggregated 1,584,919 barrels, for a gain of 218,756 barrels over the 1958 volume, August A. Busch Jr., president, told the annual meeting yesterday. He predicted that dollar sales in the first quarter of 1959 would about equal the $2,199,896, or 46 cents a share, cleared in 1958 period.
Following are three recipes utilizing ingredients that are not generally available throughout the city but that are available in the Fifty-ninth Street area.
AN audience palpably steeped in nostalgia cheered, guffawed and wept with Ethel Waters at the Renata Theatre last evening.

ON Manhattan, gastronomically speaking, good things come in small parcels of real estate. One of this city's most exciting stretches of pavement is a single block on Fiftyninth Street, between Second and Third Avenues.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 8 -- The Israeli press has in the last few days published articles expressing concern over the fate of North African Jews.
WHITESBURG, Ky., April 8 (UPI) -- A scale house for weighing coal trucks was destroyed today near a nonunion mine at Blackey, Ky.
The Protestant churches should regard newcomers from Puerto Rico as an opportunity, not a problem, the executive director of the City Mission Society said yesterday.

The election of Edward J. Goett as president of Industrial Reactor Laboratories, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Goett is executive vice president of the Atlas Powder Company, one of the ten companies that own Industrial Reactor, which operates a nuclear research reactor in Plainsboro, N. J.
A suit has been started in Queens Supreme Court to stop the Tenth District Dental Society from interfering with a group dental care program here.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 8 (AP) -- A record total of 80,000 National Guardsmen and Army Reservists will train at near-by Camp Drum this summer.
A major relighting project and a gas pipeline construction job have met by chance at the Seventy-second Street roadway in Central Park.
A new kind of airplane altimeter said to reduce errors and reading time was demonstrated yesterday by its developer, the Bulova Watch Company.
LONDON, April 8 (UPI) -Dick Miles of New York won three matches today in the English open table tennis championships.

The filming of "Anniversary Waltz" will begin here on April 27, according to United Artists, which is releasing the film version of the stage play by Joseph Fields and Jerome Chodorov. David Niven, who on Monday won an Academy Award as last year's best actor, and Mitzi Gaynor will be the stars.

DOROTHY MAGEE began her career as a designer by sitting next to a swimming pool and shivering as she sipped a cocktail. It was last summer when she first wished that something could be done to convert a large towel into a robe. This spring, she has done it herself. Working only with Martex terry cloth, she has created a line of sportswear now at Lord Taylor.
A suit to declare unconstitutional the city's Fair Housing Practices Law was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The annual award of the United Service Organizations' board of governors, a bronze plaque, was given today to Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, "for his contribution toward the general welfare of the United States Armed Forces at home and overseas."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 8 (AP) -- The Council of Ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization opened its fifth meeting today with emphasis on improving economic conditions to combat communism.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The flight of the Dalai Lama to India marks the climax and at least temporary defeat of Tibetan resistance.

NEW HAVEN, April 8 -George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, told the annual meeting here today that he did not know whether he had the support of preferred stockholders for the road to proceed with plans for obtaining a $9,800,000 fifteen-year Government-guaranteed loan.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The twenty-one American republics completed today the charter of a $1,000,000,000 inter-American bank to promote economic development in Latin America.
IF Soviet Zone women appear to be dressed better these days, they owe this mainly to the initiative, talent and success of one man.
LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- Harry S. Truman spoke on academic freedom at the University of California today. He may essay the role of a visiting lecturer there.
BOSTON, April 8 (AP) -- A Massachusetts legislative committee turned down today a proposal for a posthumous pardon for Sacco and Vanzetti.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- The Post Office Department has decided that Goya's famous 155-year old painting "The Naked Maja" is obscene.

A giant's anvil chorus of pile drivers in Little Bay, Queens, is honing neighborhood tempers to a fine edge these quiet spring nights. Steel piles are being driven for the foundations of the new Throgs Neck Bridge to the Bronx.
OTTAWA, April 8 -- Canada will end the 1958-59 fiscal year with a budget deficit estimated at $616,600,000, according to a White Paper released today.
BONN, Germany, April 7 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, "Mr. Prosperity" to West Germans, emerged today as the front runner in the contest to succeed Dr. Konrad Adenauer as Chancellor.

C. Sterling Bunnell, senior vice president, has been made chairman of the money committee of the First National City Bank of New York, it was announced yesterday. He will supervise the bank's credit policy.
OTTAWA, April 8 -- Canada and the United States today exchanged historical documents in commemoration of National Library Week, which will be held in both countries April 12-18.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- A plan for extending to Hollywood producers, the benefits of "co-financing" deals now being made with European filmmakers, was announced today by Walter Reade Jr., chairman of the board of Continental Distributing, Inc.
Two mannequins designed to stand in for humans and take the risks of nuclear and space research were completed here yesterday.

The Townsend Investment Company announced yesterday it had contracted to acquire the majority of the outstanding stock of the Power Equipment Company, Galion, Ohio, for $6,000,000. It will be paid for partly in cash, but mostly in convertible debentures.
WEST HARTFORD, April 8 -- Republicans regained control of the town council for the first time in four years in an election yesterday.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 8 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Safety Commissioner, who was prominent in bringing legal liquor to Oklahoma, announced today that he would resign to become legal adviser to the Governor.
SEVERAL former chorus girls have joined forces with some determined amateurs to present a non-Equity show with a "message."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 8 (UPI) -- The head football coach of Navy, Eddie Erdelatz, hinted at broad disagreement with Navy brass when he surprised the sports world tonight by handing in his resignation, effective immediately.

The Breakers, famous Cornelius Vanderbilt mansion at Newport, R. I., which is now a museum, will be the scene of gaiety once more when the Gorham Silver Ball is held there on Aug. 1. The fete will benefit the Newport and Providence Preservation Societies.

In solemnly voting a study of secession from the State of New York the City Council was doing what it does best, dreaming of what might have been, in a never-never world shut off from reality, a paradise unspoiled by Republicans and ruled benignly by Democrats. In this best of possible worlds, all south of the Westchester boundary, tax money would remain at home.
Jack Benny, television comedian; Leonard Bernstein, conductor, and the members of the New York Philharmonic put on a show at Carnegie Hall last night that netted the orchestra's pension fund $35,600.
Talk among exhibitors at the third International Automobile Show at the Coliseum turned yesterday to sales -- and predictions of the future.

Stockholders in the Boston and Maine Railroad at the annual meeting yesterday in Boston authorized directors to carry out any necessary refunding, refinancing or extension of the road's $47,077,300 of first mortgage, 4 per cent, series RR bonds that mature July 1, 1960.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Arthur S. Flemming urged the House Public Works Committee today to endorse the Administration plan to have the states pay stream pollution control costs through a Federal Government rebate of part of the 10 per cent Federal tax on local telephone calls.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- The Government prosecutor said today that he might call thirty-seven witnesses in the conspiracy trial of Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications Commissioner, and Thurman A. Whiteside, a Miami lawyer.
KODIAK, Alaska, April 8 (AP) -- A Russian seaman injured four days ago in a fall aboard a Soviet trawler in the Bering Sea was transferred to the United States Coast Guard cutter Storis tonight.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Light, scattered profit taking today brought the first setback this week in corn futures prices on the Board of Trade. The grain, however, pushed ahead in the cash market.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- "Peaceful competition" between East and West was put on ice today under the vast roof of the Lenin Sports Palace. And the hearts of 5,000 Moscovites thawed at the remarkable sight of American and Soviet skating artists sharing the spotlight.

The Arab League meeting in Beirut can hardly be described as a success. Of the ten members, Iraq, Jordan, Tunisia and Libya were absent. Of those attending, the Sudan abstained from the vote on the innocuous resolution condemning "external influence, whatever the source." Since the influences being brought to bear on Iraq are not only Communist but United Arab Republic, which dominated the Arab League conference, the resolution cannot mean much.
LONDON, April 8 (Reuters) -- Plans for ultramodern ocean liners to replace the Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth on the North Atlantic run are under discussion, the Government disclosed today.

First-quarter earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America approximated 64 cents a common share, compared with 23 cents a share in the initial three months of last year. This was reported yesterday by Harold Blancke, president, at the annual meeting here in the Biltmore Hotel.

Imports of crude oil and products in the week ended last Friday averaged 2,270,000 barrels a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The sharp increase from 1,785,300 barrels a day in the preceding week resulted from a desire of importers to bring oil products in before mandatory controls become effective on April 1.
Employers and unions in the $60,000,000,000-a-year construction industry set up yesterday a permanent agency for co-operation to cut costs, prevent strikes and increase productivity.
ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Rockefeller told New Yorkers tonight that the 1959 legislative session had put New York "upon the high road to a stronger, sounder, better state."
NEW ORLEANS, La., April 8 -- Electric utility executives were told here today that sales of electricity twenty years from now might be five-and-a-half times the present levels.

First-quarter net income of the Western Union Telegraph Company was about $3,470,000, or 55 cents a common share. This estimate was made yesterday by Walter P. Marshall, president, at the annual meeting at 60 Hudson Street.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles and the Washington Senators open the 1959 American League season tomorrow, thus assuring one or the other a moment of baseball glory.
The General Motors Corporation charged the Justice Department yesterday with engaging in a "politically inspired fishing expedition" in an attempt to develop a civil antitrust action.

HARTFORD, April 8 -- Connecticut Republican legislators and leaders assailed today a proposal by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, a Democrat, that $21,000,000 be diverted from the State Highway Fund to the General Fund to help balance the state budget.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 8 -- Thailand would like a grant of about $60,000,000 from the United States for economic development, Lieut. Gen. Thanom Kittikachorn, the Acting Premier, declared in an interview today.

Investors reportedly were selling stocks to raise money for tax purposes yesterday. Payments are to be made April 14 for yesterday's sales. As a result the market dipped, losing most ground in the final ninety minutes of trading.
Marian Anderson will star on the next Coca-Cola Company special TV variety show next month.
Robert Battipaglia, Democratic leader of Queens, announced yesterday his support of State Senator Thomas J. Mackell for Borough President. A Democratic primary contest in the borough is now certain.

ALBANY, April 8 -- George P. Monaghan, the state's Harness Racing Commissioner, was questioned for nearly three hours in the Governor's office today on charges made by the State Investigation Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- The Defense Department told the Navy today to proceed immediately with construction of three more Polarismissile-firing submarines.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended April 1:

CLEVELAND, April 8 -- Scientists at the Lewis Flight Propulsion Laboratory here are working toward a late summer target date when a capsule capable of bearing a man in orbit will be tested at Cape Canaveral, Fla.
