SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- The convincing of medical educators of the need for family physicians was set tonight as the foremost 1959 goal of the American Academy of General Practice.
WARSAW, April 8 -- Political Poland was in something of a holiday mood today as a result of Dr. Konrad Adenauer's decision to leave the Chancellorship of West Germany.

A partial listing of reports on stock transactions made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by companies and persons involved and made available by the New York and American Stock Exchanges follows:

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 8 (UPI) -- A 5,000-mile test of a new design for a warhead protector ended successfully in the South Atlantic today with the first recovery of a nose cone hurled for intercontinental distance.
BALTIMORE, April 8 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles took back their problem baseball pitcher, Billy Loes, today.

The tax-exempt bonds of local governments are absorbing the attention of investment houses to the greatest extent in history. With the market for Treasury obligations and prime-risk corporates turning inactive and defensive, dealings in municipal issues have, for the moment, taken over the market leadership.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 8 -The handwritten will of Maxwell Anderson, the Pulitzer-Prize winning playwright, was rejected today because it had not been witnessed.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The State Department said today it would grant a passport to Alger Hiss.

A ten-story loft building at 733-35 Broadway, near Eighth Street, has been sold by Irving Feller to Harry Horwitz, realty operator. It is 54 by 100 feet and is occupied largely by hat manufacturers. L. V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers in the sale. E. Louis Gothelf was the attorney for the buyer and Robert Levine for the seller.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Administration is planning to ask Congress for a new refugee admissions law to contribute to a dramatic evacuation of European refugee camps.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 8 (UPI) -- Anti-Faubus forces attained a majority on the Little Rock School Board today in a recount of school board election votes.

This is the seventeenth anniversary of the fall of Bataan, and Americans and Filipinos celebrate it as a commemoration of their shared sacrifice in defense of freedom. Solemn ceremonies are being held in Manila and there will be many private observances in this country.
To celebrate its 125th anniversary, the Long Island Rail Road will run a special train to Riverhead April 24.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that United States Reds who attended a Communist party congress in Moscow earlier this year had gotten fresh instructions for renewed party activity in this country.
Seventy-five "Sunday painters" are showing their painting and sculptures in an exhibition that opened yesterday at Columbia University.
Representatives of ten New York newspapers and their union printers met for more than two hours yesterday in an attempt to avert a strike.
A woman who was with Julio Ramos on the evening he was fatally attacked in an East Harlem park said yesterday she had heard someone say "excuse me" before a water jug was smashed on Mr. Ramos' head.
The Brooklyn Academy of Music, where some of the greatest artists and political leaders of the last century have appeared, will be honored by the city next week.
Newspapers will seek a larger share of the advertising revenues resulting from the May and June family gift and outdoor living goods markets, which represent about $1,622,000,000 in sales.

The Travelers Insurance Company has leased a floor in 330 Fifth Avenue at Thirty-third Street for its Fifth Avenue branch, which will move from its present quarters in the Empire State Building at 350 Fifth Avenue.

BOSTON, April 8 (AP) -- A New Hampshire man, adamant in his refusal to pay a Massachusetts income tax, remained in jail for the second day today as Government officials and lawyers refused to give ground.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A convention site committee of the Republican National Committee today put off until Saturday a final recommendation on the party's 1960 meeting place.

Dillon, Read Co., Inc., Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering today $20,000,000 of 4 5/8 per cent first mortgage pipeline bonds, due 1979, of Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, at 99.68 to yield 4.65 per cent.
Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana called last night for a realistic give-and-take between the United States and the Soviet Union in the forthcoming conferences over Berlin.
The Army and Oklahoma football teams will collide at Yankee Stadium on Nov. 18, 1961, if plans now in the works are resolved.
RICHMOND, Va., April 8 -- The Yankees rewrote history today: They took Richmond by storm. Yet a crowd of 13,440 seemed to enjoy the show immensely.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Government asked the Court of Appeals here today to stay its mandate in the Tuscarora Indian case while the Government sought review in the Supreme Court.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 8 -Roberto Campos, president of the Brazilian Government's Economic Development Bank, announced today that he had prepared the way for Communist countries to compete more with Western nations in trade with Brazil.
LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- Dr. Mont Follick, former Laborite member of Parliament and author, has left thousands of pounds for a professorship to reform spelling.

An American edition of a Russian book about travel in space will be issued by Basic Books on April 27 under the title "Soviet Space Science." The author is Ari Shternfeld, a Soviet authority on astronautics.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 8 -- President Luis A. Somoza Debayle said tonight that if the political situation did not become stabilized soon, "I will have to tighten the fist a little."

When Carmen Basilio got back into the news last week in connection with his trade of prizefighting, there was a reminder that there were times when his ring fame was overshadowed by his field trial dog.
Galina Ulanova, the great Russian ballerina, twinkled down the thirteen steps of an airliner ramp onto United States soil at 8 A. M. yesterday.

A 14-year-old boy led seven members of his family to safety early yesterday morning when a fire broke out in a tenement at 28 Canal Street. Five persons were injured in the fire, one of them seriously.
Hide futures rose the daily limit of 2 cents a pound yesterday Cottonseed oil and potatoes registered the largest volume of the year and copper had the eighth highest number of trades.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I rail carriers for February at $19,240,000. There was a loss of $10,000,000 in the like month of last year.
Cargo shippers argued yesterday the role of dual standards of ocean freight rates in promoting the nation's foreign trade.

In his speech yesterday describing his sudden decision to exchange his powerful position as head of the German Government for the hitherto mainly ceremonial post of West German President Chancellor Adenauer made several declarations that are reassuring. Thus he made it plain that, far from retiring "upstairs," he will continue to guide his nation.
The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday record net assets of $300,485,968, or $28.40 a share, for the quarter ended March 31.

' Stone Flower' Ballet at 'Met' on May 6 Will Be Benefit The Bolshoi Ballet's performance of "Stone Flower," with music by Prokofieff, at the Metropolitan Opera House on May 6 will be a benefit for the Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc.

CARACAS, April 8 -- Venezuela will officially protest the action of British companies recently in lowering oil prices by 5 to 15 cents a barrel. The Minister of Mines, Dr. Juan Pablo Perez Alfonso, said yesterday that he would send a memorandum to Britain's Ambassador John Walker here.

CHICAGO April 8 (AP) -- Butcher hog trade was fairly active today, with prices up 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds. The ,highest price for slaughter uteers in almt a year went for mostly prime 1.100 to 1.500 lb weights. About a dozen loads brought $36-$37 The sheep supply of 500 head was hardly sufficient Ior a thorough test of prices.
Banton L. Wyckoff was directed in state Supreme Court yesterday to supply information and records concerning his real estate operations to the New York City Department of Investigation.

DUTCH furniture, heretofore basically traditional in design, has taken on a new expression that reflects the experimental character of postwar Holland. And now, for the first time, several leading Dutch furniture manufacturers are exporting their creations to the United States.

John J. Monaco's Tinkalero carried top weight of 122 pounds to victory in the $28,150 Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The event was the first stakes race for fillies and mares at the current meeting, but the success was hardly a novel one for Tinkalero.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that foreign airlines may not carry commercial traffic that moved only between United States cities.
The metropolitan area has been undergoing more colds, grippe and other respiratory ailments than usual.

HAVANA, April 8 -- A military court of the revolutionary government today sentenced Heriberto Bertematy Rodriguez, who had been convicted of selling marijuana, to execution by a firing squad. He is the first person to be condemned to death in Cuba for traffic in narcotics.

PARIS, April 8 -- President Charles de Gaulle reiterated today his belief that a meeting of heads of government of the Big Four would be useful only if their foreign ministers first made progress toward a settlement of East-West differences.

CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) -- Eddie Perkins peppered the California lightweight champion, Paul Armstead, tonight with a relentless body attack and earned a spilt ten-round decision in the weekly television fight.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -Senate Democrats made good today their promise to clip Ezra Taft Benson's authority over loans for rural electrification.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 8 (AP) -- Connecticut employers who hire New York residents were advised today against withholding income taxes for New York State.

THE Conservation Department has just completed one of its important but not widely celebrated annual duties -- providing turkey feathers for the egg-stirrers of the great Lake Chautauqua Muskellunge Hatchery.
MEXICO CITY, April 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Union offered today to help underdeveloped nations by lending them money at low rates, selling machinery on long-term deals and providing technicians free.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The careers of important public servants are constantly awash in the shifting tides of attack and praise, and this occupational experience is particularly illustrated at the moment by what is happening to two of the most dedicated among them, both Virginians.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -Fifty organizations favoring strong civil rights legislation opened an attack today on a bill by Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Senate Democratic leader.
ROME, April 8 -- The commander of the Papal Swiss Guard, Col. Robert Nuenlist, was wounded today by two pistol shots fired by a former subordinate.
BONN, Germany, April 8 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer told the world tonight that West German foreign policy would not change "by one iota" when he stepped down as head of the Government.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The nation's long-range program to explore space -- from the core of the earth to the outer stretches of the universe -- was presented to Congress today.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman predicted yesterday that Tammany district leaders would face opposition in this year's primary for a third of the thirty-three district leaderships in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, said today Senators were inviting suspicion through "seemingly clandestine efforts to conceal" the facts about their office payrolls.

PEIPING, April 8 (Reuters) -- Chinese newspapers published today photographs of three letters they said the Dalai Lama wrote to a Chinese general saying he was endangered by "reactionary evil elements."
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will give thorough consideration to the nomination of Ogden R. Reid as Ambassador to Israel, its chairman said today.
PARIS, April 8 -- A French career diplomat was named by the Government today to administer the Comedie Francaise, world-famed repertory theatre.
The Women's Auxiliary of the Presbyterian Hospital will benefit from a tour of homes on the afternoon of April 28.

COLONIAL BEACH, Va., April 8 (UPI) -- Pistol fire from a Maryland government boat raked a fleeing Virginia fishing dory today, killing one man and wounding another in a renewal of the 175-year-old Potomac River "oyster war."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- President Eisenhower will be in "regular" communication with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles on any world developments during the President's vacation here, the temporary White House announced today.
BOSTON, April 8 (AP) -- Ted Williams walked briskly from New England Baptist Hospital today wearing an obviously uncomfortable surgical collar. He will miss the start of the 1959 baseball season.
LONDON, April 8 -- The stock market responded to yesterday's budget disclosure with a general advance that raised the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares to a record level.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, April 8 -- Clement Jumelle, former Presidential candidate, was reported critically ill today, after emerging from twenty-one months in hiding.
CHICAGO, April 8 -- William Benton said tonight that the Soviet Union was plotting a "revolution in international finance" designed to drive the dollar out of world trade.
LONDON, April 8 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will decide the date of Britain's general election before the end of this month, authoritative sources disclosed today.

William P. Rosensohn, the promoter of the Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight title fight on June 25, said yesterday that he wanted Johansson to train in Central Park, that he favored street banners welcoming the fight, and that the Diners Club had guaranteed the sale of 20,000 seats.
CINCINNATI, April 8 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and Cincinnati Reds will open the National League's eighty-fourth season here tomorrow, a day ahead of all other clubs in the league.

Local government bodies made heavy demands on the public bond market yesterday. Major issues sold to banking syndicates at public bidding totaled more than $50,000,000. Big borrowers were Connecticut, the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority, Fairfax County, Va., and Birmingham, Ala.
Elmer Rice has withdrawn from the Playwrights Company, after more than two decades of membership, for reasons of basic company policies, among other things.

A national lawyers' committee declared yesterday that "in many places in the United States today, justice is not equal and accessible for all." It urged community drives to provide systems of counsel for poor defendants.
Down in the choir practice room under St. Thomas Chapel this week a transportable organ of the baroque period is being built to the specifications of a dream, and under heavy pressure of time.

Smelter shipments of slab zinc last month were the largest since last December, the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday. Production rose to the highest level in fourteen months. And smelter stocks continued to rise for the third month.

ST. LOUIS, April 8 (AP) -- Democrats won the presidency of the St. Louis Board of Aldermen by a wide margin, as expected, and retained their margin of 24 to 4 on the board in yesterday's city election.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8 -- Allen W. Dulles, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that United States industrial production would remain well ahead of the Soviet Union's output through 1970.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The seven Mercury Astronauts identified today went through one of the most rigorous selection programs ever devised.

Three Jackson Pollock paintings, back from a 20,000-mile exhibition tour abroad, took the last lap of their journey yesterday up the side of an apartment building. Hauled in three giant crates to the tenth floor by block and tackle, they just managed to scrape through a window opening.
A special subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee yesterday ended a three-day hearing on the controversial dual rate question.
MOSCOW, April 9 -- Pravda departed from its usual policy today to publish most of the text of President Eisenhower's speech on foreign policy at Gettysburg College April 4.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The United States has agreed in principle to France's purchase and eventual production of the intermediate-range guided missile Regulus II.
LAVENDER powder, penciled dimples, green eyelashes and shiny lower lips are all part of a serious day's work for a red-headed make-up artist named Deidre.

ALBANY, April 9 (AP) -- The board chairman of the Pepsi-Cola Company, looking down his nose at the United States State Department, said today that his company could spread information abroad much faster.
LONDON, April 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan rejected today any delay in the nuclear armament of West German troops while the search for European security was pursued at the conference table.
LONDON, April 9 -- The British Government replaced today the Royal Air Force officer on Gan Island who had been under attack by the Government of the Maldives.
IN one of his infrequent television appearances, Jose Iturbi performed brilliantly last night on the "Bell Telephone Hour" over Channel 4.
MILAN, Italy, April 9 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, the West German Chancellor, arrived at Lake Como near here today for a vacation. He is scheduled to spend three weeks in Italy.

The five - and - a - half - story building containing thirty-seven apartments at 1116 Woodycrest Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Joseph Melhon to an investing client of Herbert Felner, lawyer. The property is 100 by 62 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $87,000 through the Philip Fogel Company, broker.

A last-minute addition to the personnel of the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow, which opens its first American tour at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 16, is Maya Plisetskaya, one of the top stars of the company.

BOSTON, April 9 (AP) -- Federal Judge Bailey Aldrich refused today to admit to bail Annis Vautier, 41 year old of Pelham, N. H.., who is spending his third day in jail rather than pay a non-resident Massachusetts income tax.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, called today for early hearings on President Eisenhower's nomination of Ogden R. Reid to be Ambassador to Israel. Mr. Reid, 33 years old, is former editor of The New York Herald Tribune.
JERSEY CITY, April 9 -- Mayor Charles S. Witkowski proposed today that the Pollak Hospital for Chest Diseases be turned into a new City Hall for Jersey City and the old one be made into a museum.

Two five-story apartment buildings at 72 and 74 Richardson Avenue in Brooklyn have been sold by A. Haferkamp to an investing client of Leo Liebler, attorney. They are on a plot 70 by 100 feet and contain forty apartments and two stores. The sale was made by Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., broker, for cash over mortgages amounting to $53,000.

Trading volume increased in most New York commodity futures markets yesterday. Prices moved irregularly. The domestic sugar months, cocoa, wool, rubber and tin rose; potatoes, cottonseed oil, copper, hides, burlap, lead and zinc declined, and price movements for the world sugar contract and coffee were mixed.
PARIS, April 9 -- French youth is thirsting for culture and France's new republic is out to satisfy its thirst.

HONOLULU, March 31 -- Trustees of Bernice P. Bishop Estate and Kaiser-Burns-Becket Organization announced today that they planned to build a model city on 6,040 acres of estate land on East Oahu in the Koko Head area.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- Max Hirsh, 68 years old, of New York, was killed last night when a car hit him as he crossed Beach Boulevard on the edge of the city.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- The opening of the enlarged St. Lawrence Seaway will provide new business opportunities for America's hard-pressed merchant marine, Thomas E. Stakem, a Federal Maritime Board member, said today.
Directors of the Long Island Trust Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one stock split, a reduction in par value to $5 from $10 and the sale of more shares of new stock.

Money for the construction of a vehicular tunnel adjoining the Sumner Tunnel in Boston was raised yesterday in the bond market by the sale of $52,800,000 of special revenue obligations of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority.

VIENNA, April 9 (Reuters) -- The board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency announced today that it had approved draft agreements with the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union for the supply of nuclear materials to the agency.
SEATTLE, April 9 -- Harry Bridges' longshoremen's union today condemned the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission as a "police body." It said the commission should have been abolished long ago.
LONDON, April 9 -- Heavy profit-taking after yesterday's advance sharply lowered prices of industrials on the stock exchange today.
Peter Ustinov, Britain's bewhiskered actor, playwright, director and raconteur extraordinary, will return to Broadway next season in a triple capacity.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- The temporary White House greeted with silence today a suggestion that the President abandon his Southern vacation to tour areas of chronic unemployment.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee, in a surprise move, voted today to abolish the central reserve city classification for reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System.

The Reserve Mining Company yesterday attacked a stock option proposal that would permit the president of the Mesabi Iron Company, Arnold Hoffman, to buy 30,000 shares of Mesabi common stock at about $41 a share over a five-year period.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 9 (AP) -- Bill Sharman blunted the Minneapolis Lakers last-gasp challenge tonight as the Boston Celtics won the National Basketball Association championship with a 118-113 victory. It was the first time a team had scored a clean sweep in the title play-offs.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Don Carlo," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Street Scene," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Amato Opera, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; "Rigoletto," University Heights Workshop, Hall of Fame Playhouse, New York University Heights Campus, the Bronx.

Five men in the field of mass communications will discuss the question "Are Americans Well Informed?" tomorrow afternoon at the twelfth annual Alumni Saturday of New York University's Washington Square College.
MOSCOW, April 9 -- The Soviet press gave its readers an advance tip today about the United States exhibition in Moscow next July: Don't believe a word of it.

LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- Ferenc Sido of Hungary, a former world champion, tonight eliminated Dick Miles, the last of the Americans in singles, in the fourth round of the English open table tennis championships.
The development of an electronic device designed to help establish new standards of chemical purity for industry, science and medicine, was announced yesterday by Beckman Instruments, Inc.
LIKE the Whooping Crane, a woman's personal preferences in choosing a home are all but extinct.
Ingemar Johansson of Sweden will not be permitted to use Central Park as a training site for his June 25 heavyweight title match against Floyd Patterson, the Parks Department decided yesterday.
The Yankees are going to open the local American League season at the Stadium at 2 o'clock this afternoon against the Boston Rel Sox. A crowd of 30,000 is expected.

A contract in Long Island potato futures was approved yesterday by the executive committee of the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading in the new contract, which begins on May 4, will supplement activity in the Maine potato contract.
PATUXENT RIVER, Md., April 9 (UPI) -- A tiny plane made of inflated rubber suffered a "blowout" in the air today and crashed. Its pilot bailed out safely at the Patuxent Naval Air Base.
MILWAUKEE, April 9 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today that religion was a proper matter for discussion in political campaigns.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The State Department is moving into the breach between West Germany and Britain with a set of principles for European security and German unification.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday rose 25.1 per cent to $24,171,414,000 from $19,320,021,000 in the 1958 week. The report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., explained yesterday that the rise was due to the occurrence of Good Friday in the 1958 week, when many banks were closed.

MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, April 9 (AP) -- Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina tied for first place in an international chess tournament that ended today. Each wound up with 10 1/2 points.
Studies of the most energetic atomic event ever observed by man suggests that the earth has been bombarded by the center of a hydrogen atom speeding in from outside its galaxy, the Milky Way.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 9 -- Frank Lloyd Wright, regarded by many as the greatest architect of the twentieth century, died early today in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 89 years old.
The Maritime Administration of the Department of Commerce has agreed to underwrite mortgage insurance on three tankers for Victory Carriers, Inc.

THE Dalai Lama and the Panchen Lama have been pictured as rivals for rule over Tibet. Actually, neither the gentle, good-humored, reclusive, 23-year-old monk who is the Dalai Lama nor the gentle, good-humored, reclusive, 21-year-old monk who is the Panchen Lama rules anything.

Mrs.. Anita O'Keeffe Young, widow of Robert R. Young, has decided to seek part in the direction of the Alleghany Corporation. This is the holding company of which her husband was chairman until his death last year.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 9 -- The quarrel between Iraq and the United Arab Republic appears to have dimmed chances for early agreement among the Arab states on a common oil policy.

PARIS. FOR most people, it is spring in Paris; but for Chanel, it must be the time of harvest. Her success can be measured by the little suits, with their braided edges, brass buttons and little square pockets, which can be seen in every shop window.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 9 (UPI) -- A Coast Guard plane carrying an injured Soviet seaman arrived at Elmendorf Air Force Base here today, completing a rescue mission that started nearly three days ago.
The Railway Express Agency, Inc., has canceled its domestic rail advertising program. If the curtailment should continue through the end of the year the saving would be $400,000.
Textron, Inc., yesterday registered $30,000,000 of 5 per cent 25-year sinking fund subordinated debentures with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 590,133 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday for 1958 a consolidated net income of 61,922,563, or $173,383,176, at the official exchange rate. This was equivalent to 85 cents each on the 202,400,340 ordinary shares of 1 par value outstanding.

A CAPE COD work crew a few days ago picked up two tons of trash left on the shores of a public fishing pond last fall. Two tons. The stuff was thrown there by a class of people who love to chatter about their sportsmanship and their love of nature: fishermen.

NO matter how deplorable the regime now in power in China may be the Chinese are unquestionably a wonderful people. Their art and their cookery are superb. Their contributions to civilization include gunpowder, paper and macaroni. These are major accomplishments. But whether the Chinese invention of the detective story was a good idea is less certain.
TOKYO, April 9 -- Some of the world's outstanding artists will perform for Japanese and visiting foreigners starting tomorrow at the second annual international festival at Osaka.
CINCINNATI, April 9 -- A match between hopeful pennant contenders saw Cincinnati defeat Pittsburgh, 4 -- 1, as the National League's eighty-fourth championship season opened today.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The first Mercury Astronaut to fly off into space will circle the earth two or three times before returning to a soft and safe landing in the Atlantic Ocean.
The Chicago Telephone Supply Corporation and the International Resistance Company announced yesterday a program for joint manufacture and distribution of certain of their electronics products.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Judge Walter J. La Buy of the United States District Court took under advisement today evidence for and against a plan to strip E. I du Pont de Nemours Co. of its stock interest in the General Motors Corporation.
A spokesman for the United States Rubber Company said that 25,000 workers at eighteen plants in eleven states began a strike at 12:01 A. M. today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) -- Gen. Lauris Norstad told Congress today that United States foreign military aid was "indispensable" to the defense of Western Europe and the rest of the non-Communist world.

The scholarship funds of Wells and Wheaton Colleges will be aided by a theatre benefit being planned by their New York alumnae. It will be the April 28 performance of "Destry Rides Again" at the Imperial Theatre.

Twenty-four more persons were indicted here yesterday for grand larceny in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's crackdown on relief frauds. They were accused of fraudulently obtaining a total of $33,275 in relief payments.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 9 -- The white-washed walls of Greek Cypriote houses in most parts of Cyprus were covered today with the letters E. D. M. A. crudely painted in traditional Aegean blue.

A $5,000,000 pier will be built by the city for the Cunard Line at West Fifty-fourth Street under a twenty-year lease, Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday.
Willie Shoemaker had three winners at Jamaica yesterday. Then he tried so hard to make it four that he was penalized for his zeal.
A far-reaching proposal to promote unity among seafaring, waterfront and associated unions was enthusiastically received here yesterday by officials of fourteen labor organizations.

Money market pressures were particularly heavy in New York City in the week ended Wednesday, figures published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed. The tight money conditions here resulted from the New York City banks' role as principal underwriters for the Treasury's recent $4,000,000,000 financing.

DETROIT, April 9 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers executive board voted today to hold a union trial for a staff member who was dismissed Tuesday for what the union called unethical conduct in accepting commissions from a private employer.
The Electric Bond and Share Company expects to be exempt from the Holding Company Act within the next six months.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) -- The United States has fired a test version of a rocket engine with more than 1,000,000 pounds of thrust. It is considered the forerunner of even mightier rockets that will power satellites and space ships.

After weeks of political infighting the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee has brought forth a new incarnation of the Kennedy labor union regulation measure (now S. 1555), approved by a vote of 13 to 2. Its essentials are the same as the original bill, in spite of some forty-six amendments which, on the whole, are strengthening.

OSSINING, N. Y., April 9 -- The Very Rev. John William Comber was consecrated a Roman Catholic Bishop today in a ritual attended by 250 prelates, priests and religious. Two Cardinals and thirty-eight Archbishops and Bishops were among them.
ALBANY, April 9 -- Beginning today, you can bind your telephone book in Florentine leather, slip it into a plastic advertising cover or wrap it in old newspapers.
Norman Thomas, director emeritus of the American Civil Liberties Union, has sent an appeal to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru to grant political asylum in India to all Tibetans who seek it.
LONDON, Friday, April 10 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev accused President Eisenhower today of "making a definite contribution" to attempts to raise tension, the Soviet agency Tass reported.

TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- Tokyo's famous Imperial Hotel a monument to Frank Lloyd Wright, has survived numerous vicissitudes, it was recalled today by Tetsuzo Inumaru, manager of the hotel since it was opened on July 4, 1922.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Rockefeller approved today an extension of the Temporary State Commission on Rents and Rental Conditions for another year. The bill he signed also reduces the size of the agency from nineteen to nine members.
A Bronx man was beaten in a self-service elevator last night and a Manhattan man was robbed while walking his dogs on Fifth Avenue.
Stocks loafed, with a touch of spring fever yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Why did the space officials pick men in the 30-year age bracket for the first spacemen?

The five Long Island Sound skippers who will compete against Bermudians for the Amorita Cup off Hamilton, Bermuda, emerged from the spring meeting of the International One-Design Class at the New York Yacht Club last night. The team series will begin on April 20.
A charge against Giovanni Scalisi, arrested last week-end for possession of a pistol while en route from Mexico City to Rome, was dismissed yesterday in Ridgewood Felony Court, Queens.

DANVILLE, Va., April 9 -- Stockholders of Dan River Mills, Inc., at the annual meeting here today elected three new directors, lifting the total to eighteen. They were Oliver Iselin Jr., Floyd W. Jefferson Jr., and H. M. Ferguson, all of New York. The other incumbents were re-elected.
The special ceremonial openings out of the way at Washington and at Cincinnati, more than 200,000 fans are expected to attend the major leagues' opening games in seven other cities today.

BONN, Germany, April 9 -- The heart of the Allied proposals for the forthcoming negotiations with the Soviet Union will concern general disarmament and enhanced contacts between East and West Germany.
The leaders of seventeen American Jewish organizations called on their members yesterday to increase their support of the United Jewish Appeal.
Domenick G. Rainone, a Welfare Department investigator who has been a bitter critic of the department's operations, was dismissed yesterday from his $82-a-week job.
The Rockefeller administration was reported under pressure sure yesterday to broaden the State Investigation Commission's inquiry into harness racing.

MONTREAL, April 9 (UPI) -- Dickie Moore and Marcel Bonin scored third-period goals that led the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-3 victory over the Toronto Leafs tonight in the opening game of the Stanley Cup play-off finals.

FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT, the celebrated, controversial architect who died yesterday at the age of 89, helped change the landscape of America. He built everything -- banks, schools, houses, museums, churches, exposition halls and even factories -- but some of his most revolutionary ideas centered about the interior of the American home.

Eddie Erdelatz maintained a tight-lipped silence in Annapolis, Md., yesterday in refusing to explain the specific reasons behind his dumfounding resignation as head football coach at the United States Naval Academy.

Your editorial of April 4 can be characterized in no way other than a spiteful attack on President Nasser personally. Its significance, apart from the choice of timing, belies a tendentious effort to sow seeds of distrust in him by the West, using the Arab countries and their so-called "disagreements" as criteria indicative of a deterioration in his leadership.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- Three defenders retained their titles, one was dethroned and another lost by default today in opening events of the women's senior national amateur athletic union indoor swimming and diving championships.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., April 9 (AP) -- The story of a crash-landing in frozen Lake Huron and an escape to an empty lighthouse was told today in a letter left behind by an airman who apparently perished in an attempt to walk across ice eleven miles to land.

In another column on this page we publish a letter from Abdel-Mawgoud Hassan, representative of the United Arab Republic, objecting to one of our editorials about President Nasser. He accuses us of being enemies of Arab nationalism and unity and of adhering to a policy of divide and rule.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Washington soon may be playing its usual role of being first in everything except the American League, where it usually finishes last. But on this day at least, the capital's Senators are trailing no one.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 9 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad said today it would post notices tomorrow announcing its intention to discontinue service on lines serving 25,000 riders by June 9 unless New Jersey and New York offered financial assistance.
THERE is one elementary difficulty with Shimon Wincelberg's "Kataki," which opened at the Ambassador last evening.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 13 points (65 cents a bale) lower to 1 point (5 cents a bale) higher. Old crop months were easiest, although declines were attributed more to the limited demands than to any real selling pressure.

NEWARK, April 9 -- Paul M. Butler assailed tonight what he called the "soak the poor" tax policies of the Rockefeller administration in New York and charged that the New York Legislature had treated New York City "disgracefully" in its bid for new tax power.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Seven young military test pilots were presented today as the nation's future pioneers in space.
The president of the Board of Education said yesterday that higher salaries for teachers was the "first and foremost" need of the school system.
The place of Sid W. Richardson on the board of the New York Central Railroad was taken yesterday by John B. Connally, an associate of Mr. Richardson.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April -- A "grass roots" premiere caravan to introduce a group of young screen personalities to the heart of America," was announced today by Warner Brothers. The caravan will be on conjunction with the world premiere of its picture "The Young Philadelphians" in Philadelphia on May 19.

The stockholders of the Avco Manufacturing Company elected Earl H. Blaik and James R. Kerr to the board of directors at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Mass., yesterday. They also voted to change the company's name to the Avco Corporation.
Five two-story garden apartment houses known as Henderson Gardens at 185th Street and 104th Avenue in Hollis, Queens, have been sold by Henderson Gardens, Inc., to the 490 Realty Corporation.

After more than a half-century of renown Frank Lloyd Wright received in 1945 his first commission in New York -- the new home of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Streets. He did not live to see it completed.

Mayor Wagner hinted last night that the city might try to balance its 1959-60 expense budget of $2,173,113,999 without imposing all of the new or increased special taxes authorized by the 1959 Legislature.
The state of teen-age art appears to augur well for future collectors, according to judges in a recent countrywide competition.

The Paul Roberts Choir of Philadelphia, under the direction of Mr. Roberts, gave a concert last night in Town Hall. This group is a mixed chorus of twenty-nine members. In its ambitious program it was assisted by members of the Philadelphia Orchestra.
