WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Sales and profits of manufacturing corporations increased sharply in the last three months of 1958, the Government reported today. Higher auto sales accounted for about half the advance.

PARIS, April 9 -- A plan of disarmament by concentric rings centering on disputed Berlin was advanced today by Jules Moch, French delegate to the United Nations Disarmament Commission, in his private rather than official capacity.

Ever since Cardinal Richelieu founded the French Academy to stand eternally vigilant over the virtue of the French language this has been a matter of the greatest concern in France, and now agitation has reached a peak because French speech and writing are being more and more sullied by foreign barbarisms.
S. Sloan Colt, the banker, was elected chairman of the Port of New York Authority yesterday.

YONKERS, April 9 -- From time to time there are bargains to be found in harness racing. For example, in the featured mile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, Gay Dancer, a 6-year-old black horse, opened at 4 -- 1, closed at 9 -- 1 and won going away by a length and a half.

George E. Judd Jr. has been named managing director of the New York Philharmonic. His appointment will become effective on June 1. He will succeed Bruno Zirato, who last year had announced his intention of retiring.

Sigmund Rothschild, New York appraiser, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy in Federal Court yesterday. Although the petition listed liabilities of $367,180 and no assets, Mr. Rothschild said that the actual amount of debt was nearer $35,000.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court came under a barrage of critical questions from Southern Senators today as the long-delayed hearings on his confirmation began.
A new 1959 pleasure craft is so logical it is a wonder it wasn't conceived twenty years ago.

LONDON, April 9 -- Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade, complained today that the pressures of certain interests in the United States to bar foreign competition had injured important British industries that depend on exports.
Spring's strengthening sun burned through partly cloudy skies yesterday to push the temperature up to 73.9 degrees, below Wednesday's 79.6 degrees, but nevertheless a record for the date.
LONDON, April 9 -- A new method of operating on the heart by lowering the patient's temperature sufficiently to stop blood circulation completely for at least forty-five minutes was described today.
A Loyalty Day Parade will be held Saturday, April 25, on midtown Fifth Avenue. Sixty thousand marchers are expected to participate.
A MELODRAMA about the Civil War, "The Day Before Atlanta," was last night's offering on Channel 2's "Playhouse 90."

Government efforts to use the antitrust laws to upset the complex labor-management structure in the garment industry seemed likely yesterday to touch off a legal battle as bitter as that involved in the famous Danbury Hatters case a half-century ago.

In these days, when a sort of "speculative fever" seems to have gripped a portion of the stock market, a note of reassurance to long-term investors is welcome. Such a note was struck yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange in its latest report on dividend longevity.
ROME, April 9 -- The Romans are being told they no longer can afford siestas.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 9 (AP) -- The United States told the ministers conference of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization here today that freedom would be threatened "unless there is hope for economic and social progress."
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Corn futures experienced their second setback of the week today.
Prices of high-grade bonds moved irregularly yesterday.

HANOVER, N. H., April 9 -- The State Department's restriction of travel by Soviet diplomats was blamed today for preventing Mikhail A. Menshikov, the Soviet Ambassador, from addressing students at Dartmouth College April 20.
The Catholic Teachers Association of the Diocese of Brooklyn took issue yesterday with a recent Board of Higher Education report that found "no pattern of religious discrinimation" at Queens College.
TWO of the most delectable harbingers of spring, fresh rhubarb and asparagus, are now readily available in markets here. Both are greeted with enthusiasm, for both have outstanding flavor.
MEXICO CITY, April 9 (AP) -- The head of the International Monetary Fund said today there was "a welcome absence of any serious crisis in the economic and financial field" in 1959.
TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- The imperial wedding that changes 2,619 years of rigid tradition in the Japanese royal court was celebrated throughout Japan today with great festivity.
TRENTON April 9 (AP) -- A New Jersey regional attack on city slums -- reportedly the first in the nation -- was made possible today with a $130,106 Federal grant.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- In the public debate over what proposals the United States, Great Britain, France and West Germany shall make to the Soviet Union for peaceful negotiation of the acute issues involving Berlin and the two Germanys an old epithet has reappeared.

IT was the biggest mistake John McGraw ever made. For the better part of fifty years the Giants owned New York. The Yankees were nobodies who played their games at the Polo Grounds under sufferance. The Little Napoleon, the dominating figure in the sport, could afford to be condescending. But when the Yankees got Babe Ruth, they surged past the Giants in crowd appeal.

LAWRENCE, L. I., April 9 -- A controversy over the saying of the Lord's Prayer in some of the schools of District 15 apparently ended today. The School Board discontinued the prayer in favor of the fourth stanza of "America."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 9 (AP) -- A movie nominated for an Academy Award has been canceled by a Montgomery theatre after the pro-segregation White Citizens Council protested against scenes showing a white man and a Negro fighting.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- President Eisenhower is prepared to express a preference for Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky as Republican National Chairman to the nominating committee. The ten-member group arrives here tomorrow to elicit his views or his endorsement of their choice.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Proposals by the Federal Reserve Board for lower bank reserve requirements were described today by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, as a Treasury "grab" by commercial banks.

A union leader urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to look into charges that political pressure had been responsible for ending the state's investigation into reported strike-breaking activity in the newspaper industry.

Not all the news about relations between Russia and America is bad. It is good news that the wonderful ballerina of the Bolshoi Theatre, Galina Ulanova, has arrived in New York and that she and the Bolshoi ballet will tour the United States and show us the artistry of which we have heard so much.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 9 (AP) -- Mike Fetchick, a Yonkers pro, carded a five-under-par 66 today to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $15,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.
ALBANY, April 9 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of 223 physicians who successfully completed the latest examination for licenses to practice medicine.
ALBANY, April 9 -- The Court of Appeals today denied the claim of six discharged New York City college teachers and staff members for $177,000 in back salary.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- A troubled Indian Parliament heard assurances today that the Government was not taking a "calculated risk" by cutting back defense expenditures this year.

IN his latest opera, "Wuthering Heights," Carlisle Floyd's reach has exceeded his grasp. But once again, as in "Susannah," his first success, he has established his immense flair for the theatre. And credit him with the ambition and courage to measure himself against so powerful a work as Emily Bronte's strange, doom-laden novel.
First-quarter sales of the Admiral Corporation were up 15 per cent over the $38,418,799 volume for the 1958 period, Ross D. Siragusa, president reported

NEW DELHI, April 9 -- Prime Minister Nehru is believed to have told a closed meeting of Congress party members of Parliament that the Dalai Llama would reach the place where he would stay in twelve days.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., will spend $420,000,000 this year for capital and exploratory purposes, Albert L. Nickerson, president, announced in the company's 1958 annual report. This is $22,000,000 more than the company spent in 1958 and approximates the record expenditures of 1957.

Even though fully expected for months, the news that all twenty states of the inter-American system have initialed a charter for a development bank and fund is a landmark. This has long been sought by the Latin-American nations and was long rejected by the United States. The hemisphere can thank Vice President Nixon's dramatic experience in South America last May and the "agonizing reappraisal" of American policies that followed it.
The wounds suffered in the fatal beating given Julio Ramos in an East Harlem park last May 30 were described by two physicians yesterday in General Sessions Court.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- These are the seven Project Mercury Astronauts from whom the nation's first man into space will be chosen:
HAVANA, April 9 -- A group of six young Haitian revolutionists forced a Haitian DC-3 passenger plane to land in Santiago de Cuba this afternoon. The plane had been on a Haitian domestic flight.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Ten Democratic House members and six members of the British Parliament proposed today that the United Nations take over the policing of all Berlin.

TOKYO, Friday, April 10 -- Crown Prince Akihito and Michiko Shoda were married in brief but very colorful Shinto rites this morning. The young couple, in brilliant court robes of a past era, entered the sacred palace shrine together promptly at 10 A. M. (8 P. M. Thursday, Eastern standard time). the Crown Prince and his bride leave their homes for the imperial palace earlier this morning.

Judge Learned Hand has broken judicial records by completing this month fifty years of service as a Federal judge. Today there will be a special session of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in this city to commemorate Judge Hand's character and achievements. Even though his years of public service are noteworthy, it is not so much the number of them as the shining quality of them that should be remembered.
Former President Harry S. Truman will be honored at a series of testimonial dinners and other affairs over the country on May 8, his seventy-fifth birthday.
A project is under development whereby the Ford Motor Company would sponsor next season a weekly television series consisting of one-hour, ninety - minute and two - hour shows of various types.

Publishers and leaders of the printers' union announced yesterday that "some more progress'' had been made toward settling a dispute that has threatened a printers' strike against ten New York newspapers.
TORONTO, April 9 (Canadian Press) -- Higher taxes in Ontario force the transfer of manufacturing to other provinces whenever and wherever this is possible.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- Fighting has broken out between Tibetan rebels and Chinese Communist forces in Tsinghai Province and the Sikang area, both in China, press reports said today.
Harold A. Felix, the City Labor Commissioner, expressed "serious and grave concern" yesterday over the threat of a strike in six voluntary hospitals.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Greater public recognition of the "cold war" sacrifices of service men was urged today by Vice Admiral Ralph E. Wilson, Deputy Chief of Naval Operations.

America is the greatest democracy on earth. We believe in liberty and justice for all and in the supreme worth of the individual. Yet how often in practice we corrode our beliefs. Only recently we have had scandals in Congress where our elected representatives have placed their wives or children on high salaries paid for by the Government.

April 10 commemorates the fiftieth anniversary of Learned Hand's induction as a judge. It is well to underline the contribution which a great judge can make to the American idea. Judge Hand has earned the title of "votary of civil liberties and human rights."

CHICAGO, April 9 -- About a dozen members of the American Bar Association have resigned, Joseph D. Stecher, executive director of the association, said today, as a result of the recent action by the association's House of Delegates that was interpreted in some quarters as criticism of Supreme Court decisions in cases involving communism.

Abbott Laboratories announced yesterday the election of Elmer B. Vliet as chairman. Mr. Vliet had been vice president and scientific administrator of the pharmaceutical company since 1952. He succeeds Dr. Ernest H. Volwiler, who has retired.
A controversy over rights in the United States to show a Charlie Chaplin film has developed between two motion-picture distributors.
TRENTON, April 9 -- New Jersey has decided to extend the State Turnpike north to the Bergen - Passaic Expressway, now under construction.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) -- Organized labor endorsed today Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's proposal to create a Federal fact-finding commission that would study the unemployment problem and recommend soltutions within sixty days.

OTTAWA, April 9 -- The budget presented to Parliament tonight by Donald Fleming, Minister of Finance, dampened the springtime joy of life of many Canadians just emerging from a long and bitter winter. Taxes went up almost all along the line.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- The butcher hog market fell sharply today. Prices were off 25 to 75 cents a hundred pounds. In the cattle market, slaughter steers and heifers were steady in active trading. The sheep market was steady to weak.
SAN SALVADOR, April 9 -- United States Ambassadors from twelve Caribbean countries began here this afternoon a discussion of likely United States political and economic policy in the area.
The police lured a narcotics suspect into a Yorkville bank yesterday and arrested him for caching thirty ounces of heroin in a safe deposit box.
INSTANBUL, Turkey, April 9 -- The boom of ceremonial cannon over the Bosphorus this morning turned Istanbul from a city of fasting to one of feast and festival.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 9 -- The General Assembly adopted a resolution today directing the State Public Utilities Commission to investigate the New Haven Railroad, especially its commuter service.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 9 -- The demand for a purge in the Iraqi Government, originally made by the Communists, is gathering force, it was said here today. It has been adopted by the Free Democrats and today received support from the National Democrat (Socialist) organ.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri moved a little closer today to an avowed candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination next year.
BONN, Germany, April 9 -- A contest between Dr. Ludwig Erhard and Franz Etzel for the succession to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer became evident today.

A dinner dance to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 13 will serve a twofold purpose. Funds will be raised for the Cardinal Spellman Servicemen's Club at 641 Lexington Avenue and the seventieth birthday of Cardinal Spellman, founder of the club, will be observed.
RICHMOND, Va., April 9 -- Virginia's massive-resistance bloc introduced its program for combating racial integration in the Legislature here today.
A statement of policy prohibiting the use of Washington Square Park to all but emergency traffic was approved by the Board of Estimate last night.
AGAIN, the literature of the Irish stage has provided the material for an absorbing performance.

The Fifty-two Association of New York, formed by fifty-two men in 1945 so that "The Wounded Shall Never Be Forgotten," is celebrating its fourteenth anniversary of providing personal morale and rehabilitation services to hospitalized and disabled veterans from Massachusetts to North Carolina. The 1,800 men and women members of Fifty-two of New York, with their associated chapters in Los Angeles, Chicago and Miami Beach have faithfully kept their founders' pledge.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 10 -- Pakistani fighter planes shot down today a twin-engine jet aircraft reported to be an Indian Air Force bomber.

Directors of the Grand Union Company yesterday proposed a 1 1/2 for one split of the common stock and an increase in the authorized common to 6,000,000 from 4,000,000 shares. Stockholders of the Eastern food chain will vote on these proposals at the annual meeting on May 27.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., April 10 (UPI) -- C. Douglas Dillon, United States Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today that in 1958 the Communist Chinese resorted to new economic pressures to gain their political goals in Asia.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that he had serious reservations on proposals by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, to set up Federal standards for wage, housing and transportation for farm labor.

The Belding Holding Corporation has sold the nine-story building containing thirty-six apartments at 250 West Seventy-fifth Street to the Investors Funding Corporation. Eric Oling was the broker. The plot is 60 by 100 feet.

I was shocked to read your editorial of April 2 "Newfoundland's Dilemma." Not only does this editorial fail to appreciate the issues at stake in the recent crisis in Newfoundland but also the facts which you quote are entirely wrong.
DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -- Rick Ferrell was named general manager and vice president of the Detroit Tigers today.

WHITESBURG, Ky., April 10 (AP) -- Gov. A. B. Chandler said today that National Guardsmen would move into eastern Kentucky' struck coal fields unless both sides assured him there would be no more violence.
George Jacob Keller has fulfilled his life's ambition. At the age of 62 the retired college professor is a full-fledged lion trainer with the Ringling Bros. and Barnum Bailey Circus.
PARIS, April 10 -- In an attempt to keep the Algerian terrorist organization in France off balance, French police forces arrested 465 Algerians in raids in various parts of France early today.

WARSAW, April 10 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Poland is making a special point of emphasizing the particular interest of Pope John XXIII in this nation where communism and Catholicism dominate all life.

KANSAS CITY, April 10 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians survived a wild performance by Herb Score in the ninth inning today and defeated the Athletics, 6 -- 4, in a loosely played American League opener.
In a news year of extraordinary activity, The Associated Press performed with distinction,its general manager, Frank J. Starzel, said in his annual report for 1958.
A special ninety-minute dramatic telecast, "The White House Saga," will be shown by the National Broadcasting company, probably near next year's Presidential election.
ANNAPOLIS, April 10 (AP) -- A 62-year-old retired sailor arrived unannounced after a 600-mile bus trip at the office of Capt. Slade Cutter, Naval Academy athletic director.

MEXICO CITY, April 10 -- Speaking before the United Nations Economic and Social Council, which held its fourth day's session here, Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, reported that the rate of loans made by the bank in the last twelve months had been the highest in the bank's history.

With the spotlight of world publicity blazing on the differences between the Western allies rather than their basic agreement, the United States is advancing a program that merits general support as the best way both to resolve the differences and to safeguard Western principles and security.
BONN, Germany, April 10 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard said last night that "open-mindedness and flexibility" made for a successful foreign policy provided that basic principles were defended.
THE waning Metropolitan season was still able to produce three "firsts" in last night's performance of Verdi's "Don Carlo," the final one of the season.

American Telephone and Telegraph Company apparently strengthened its claim as the world's biggest corporate money earner during the first quarter. The giant utility was the largest corporation in assets, number of employes and stockholders.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- The State Department has instructed the United States delegation to request a meeting May 6 of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space.

The American Theatre Wing's Antoinette Perry Awards, the highly-prized silver medallions presented for accomplishments in the legitimate theatre, will be distributed tomorrow night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Greater Syria party has opened a drive for an antiCommunist front in the Middle East. It believes that President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic would cooperate at this time, the party's president, Assad al Ashkar, said here yesterday.
Following are excerpts from remarks by Chief Justice Earl Warren and the text of a talk by Associate Justice Felix Frankfurter at ceremonies here yesterday honoring Judge Learned Hand:
An aged Brooklyn woman's two-year fight against eviction from her rent-free apartment has been given new life by the State Court of Appeals.
"UNQUESTIONABLY first among American judges." So Learned Hand was described a decade ago by one of the great figures of the American bar, C. C. Burlingham of New York.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, April 10 (AP)---The 16,231-ton Swiss-owned passenger liner Arosa Sun went under the hammer here today, but all bidders stayed below the legal limit and there was no sale to satisfy creditors.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Legislation to coordinate under the Public Health Service efforts to protect the public from all types of radiation was introduced today by Senator Lister Hill and Representative Kenneth A. Robers, Alabama Democrats.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Congressional investigators asked Bernard Goldfine questions that were obtained illegally by "theft and electronic eavesdropping," a lawyer representing the Boston industrialist argued today.
A pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman will be read tomorrow at all masses in every Roman Catholic church in the New York Archdiocese.
Two former patrolmen of the Brooklyn morals squad pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of illegal wiretapping and falsifying reports on a bookmaker's arrest.
LONDON, April 10 -- Despite a strong Liberal bid, John Brewis, Conservative candidate, won a Parliamentary by-election in Galloway, Scotland, yesterday.

Freight revenues of the Western Pacific Railroad last month were 25 per cent above those of March, 1958. The carrier expects to report a net income of $1,300,000 for the first quarter, according to Frederick B. Whitman, president.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Average primary prices remained unchanged at 119.5 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LONDON, April 10 -- Profit-taking continued to depress the stock market today and shares had another long list of declines. Losses among industrials generally were limited to pennies. There were a few good exceptions in response to bargain-hunting late in the day or good profit and dividend statements.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said tonight a puppy's head had been successfully added to an Alsatian dog and the dog was doing well.
LONDON, April 10 -- The Peiping radio said today that the Tibetan uprising was aided by anti-Communist rebels from Communist China.

The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation acquired through subsidiaries yesterday Blue Ridge Manufacturers, Inc., the Imperial Shirt Company, the Marlboro Shirt Company, the Boys Tone Shirt Company and other components of the Blue Ridge and S. Rosenbloom groups.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -The Japanese continued to dominate the main play but American players salvaged some honors tonight in the English open table tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A Connecticut member of the House made public today what he described as "the case of the disappeared deputy."

The masters of the Japanese freighter Shimane Maru and of the tugboat Dalzell 2 testified here yesterday at a Coast Guard hearing into the collision of the two craft in the East River last Wednesday. The tug was towing two railroad carfloats at the time.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A major enlargement of the Federal field force charged with prosecuting racketeering and organized crime was announced today by Attorney General William P. Rogers.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Moving with extraordinary speed, the Senate voted unanimously today to create a Special Commission on Unemployment.
Prices moved a bit higher in a lackluster session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. All major groups were mixed, but the oils made a fairly general advance and rails were firm.
OTTAWA, April 10 -- Canada's new tax structure will blow a chill wind upon the United States farmer and fruit grower.
ALBANY, April 10 -- The state moved today to block the Long Island Rail Road from regaining authority to increase its commuter fares without state permission.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -Robert W. Kean, for twenty years a Republican Representative of Congress from New Jersey, was appointed chairman of the National Advisory Committee today for the White House Conference on Aging in 1961.

NORWALK, Conn, April 10 -- The Zoning Commission last night approved a rezoning in the Strawberry Hill area, paving the way for a multi-million dollar plant for the Norden Division of United Aircraft, Inc.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -Warren Spahn, whose varied baseball skills paradoxically seem to grow with his mounting age, sent the Milwaukee Braves off to a flying start in defense of their National League title today.

QUEBEC, April 10 (Canadian Press) -- Plans for the construction this summer of a $12,000,000 pig iron and semi-steel manufacturing plant at Varennes, on the St. Lawrence River south shore near Montreal, were announced yesterday. It would use a new type of smelting process.

The prediction that automobile sales this year would top the 6,000,000 mark was made yesterday by James O. Wright, vice president of the Ford Motor Company and general manager of the company's bread-and-butter Ford division.
ALBANY, April 10 -- The Seventh Avenue approach to the Narrows bridge that will link Brooklyn and Staten Island was upheld today by Governor Rockefeller.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- Following are the texts of a letter sent by twelve steel companies today to David J. McDonald, president of the United Steel Workers of America, and of the statement Mr. McDonald issued in reply:
ALBANY, April 10 -- It looks now as if the winter kill of deer, in the Adirondacks at least, will be as bad as the terrible winter of 1947-48 when deer died by the thousands in the deep snow.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- A sharp deterioration in the caliber of college teaching was reported today at the opening of a two-day workshop on higher education.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 9 -- In the world's diplomatic maneuvering over the German question the Yugoslavs are in the position of a kibitzer holding his breath for fear the wrong card will be played despite his advice.
Governor Rockefeller's veto yesterday of a proposed Shore Parkway approach to the Narrows Bridge now establishes the Seventh Avenue route through Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, as the official approach.
CLEVELAND, April 10 (UPI) -- Throat-clearing in the audience at a concert last night brought a caustic comment from George Szell, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra.
LAUREL, April 10 (AP) -The first running of the Maturity, which Laurel Race Course hopes will grow into another $100,000 event, drew seven 4-year-olds for tomorrow.

Events today: "Tosca," 2 P. M., and "La Gioconda," 8, Metropolitan Opera; Mary Judd, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30; Ellen Pahl, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Street Scene," New York City Opera, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor Lukas Foss, harpsichordist, pianist and conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Columbia University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, April 10 -- Foreign Minister Louis Mars accused the Communists today of responsibility for the hijacking of a Haitian airliner and the murder of its pilot.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A Dearborn, Mich., car wash operator who was bombed out of business after a dispute with the Teamsters Union appealed to the Senate Rackets Committee today for help.

NEWARK, April 10 -- The switching operation involved in getting New York Central's West Shore trains onto tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Jersey City would be "pregnant with disaster," it was said here today.
It is shocking beyond belief to read the dispatch by Juan de Onis in The Times of April 4 describing the frightful conditions in the Siglo Veinte (i. e., Twentieth Century) tin mine in Bolivia.
Manufacturers of prefinished plywood panels are cashing in on the public's desire for lowcost luxury.

THE New York City Handel Festival continued last night with a program by the Gotham Baroque Ensemble in Carnegie Recital Hall. The instrumentalists -- Sonya Monosoff and Alan Grishman, violinists; Joan Brockway, 'cellist, and Stoddard Lincoln, harpsichordist -- played three Trio Sonatas.

Lawyers, judges and the President paid tribute to Judge Learned Hand yesterday at ceremonies celebrating his fiftieth year on the Federal bench. A letter from President Eisenhower was read by the Attorney General, William P. Rogers. The President said:

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- President Eisenhower named Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky as his choice today for Republican National Chairman. Those in charge of the nominating process said afterward that Mr. Morton was as good as elected.

Eddie Arcaro found himself in the unusual situation of being cheered at Jamaica yesterday. One of the closest approaches to a sure thing at the track ordinarily is that Arcaro will be the subject of jeers, whether he wins or loses.
A VISITOR from Mars trying to find contemporary art's common denominator would give up the search as a bad job when faced with the variety of eight of this week's exhibitions.

HAVANA, April 10 -- Premier Castro warned the people of Cuba last night to be "alert" against the increasing enemies of the revolution. He said that elections would be held when Cuba was free from corruption and the reforms of the revolution had been put into effect.
An off-duty patrolman shopping with his fiancee for wedding rings, captured a payroll robbery suspect yesterday shortly after the man had allegedly snatched $1,100 from a woman bookkeeper.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union was ordered last night by the United States Court of Appeals in Philadelphia to bargain collectively with the Slate Belt Apparel Contractors Association.

A strike by all thirty-three Hebrew teachers at the Hebrew Institute of Long Island has caused the suspension of all morning classes for 730 pupils. Hebrew subjects are taught exclusively in the morning. The strike started Thursday.
JANESVILLE, Wis., April 10 -- Swinging through four cities by car and light airplane, Senator John F. Kennedy called today for a reinvigorated Democratic party program.
Truckers and railroaders, like brothers, sometimes get along arm in arm and sometimes fist to fist.

Net income of the St. Regis Paper Company in the first quarter rose 52 per cent above the 1958 period on a sales gain of 12 per cent. This was announced by Roy K. Ferguson, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, at the annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for a look at material uncovered by the C. A. B.'s review of records of the Air Transport Association.

The DX Sunray Oil Company, subsidiary of the Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company, announced yesterday a reduction of 11,500 barrels a day in its crude oil runs at its two Oklahoma refineries. R. W. McDowell, president of the subsidiary, said the move represented a reduction of about 10 per cent and that the cut was being made despite the fact the company's inventories of refined products were substantially below those of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr., Democrat of Missouri, introduced a bill today to require broader representation of economic interests on the Federal Reserve Board.
Three thousand five hundred city teachers voted yesterday to stay away from their jobs next Thursday to reinforce their demands for higher salaries.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- California's organized labor leaders were adjudged free today of the type of hoodlums that captured a segment of the labor movement in New York.

APPLETON, Wis., April 10 (AP) -- A prominent Democrat here quit the party last night, charging that the Democrats were "trying to use the Roman Catholic Church as a tool" to promote the Presidential candidacy of Senator Kennedy.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -No game, snow.

FOR anyone who has a yen for sewing, Bloomingdale's fabric department -- it is sprawled out all over the mezzanine -- is the place to go. Here one can be persuaded to make a shirtwaist dress despite the fact that every department in the store that sells dresses is loaded to the hilt with them.

CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit, upheld today a decision of the Tax Court of the United States that held that Cyrus S. Eaton and William R. Daley, Cleveland financiers, were not liable individually for income taxes in a stock deal with Steep Rock Mines, Ltd., of Canada.
A new test for identifying potential diabetics long before the onset of disease was reported promising at a scientific meeting here yesterday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 10 (UPI) -- Nancy Ramey of Seattle won her third straight 100-yard butterfly title tonight in the national women's senior Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming championships.
Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" and Beethoven's "Fidelio" will receive new productions next season at the Metropolitan Opera, it was announced yesterday. This brings the total of new presentations to six.
The nation's steel industry turned out more raw steel in March than in any other month in history, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Further progress was reported yesterday in efforts to settle a dispute that has threatened a printers' strike against ten New York newspapers.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 10 -A collector of used clothing, who has been accused of pocketing $1,000 a week in a charity fraud, was enjoined today from making collections in Nassau County.

A hand printing press used in print shops here more than 100 years ago was demonstrated yesterday. The occasion was the centennial exhibition of the Union Dime Savings Bank, Avenue of the Americas at Fortieth Street. The equipment is known as the Washington Press.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Cabinet-level representatives of five major wheat - exporting countries will meet here May 5 and 6 on the use of wheat as a part of President Eisenhower's program of "food for peace."
TORONTO, April 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada said today its Canadian dealers sold more new cars in the first three months of 1959 than in any first quarter since 1954.

Van Brunt Co., advertising agency, leased office space in the new building at 355 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fortieth Street, and will move about May 1 from 230 Park Avenue. Arthur Collins Jr. of Collins, Tuttle Co. was the broker.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- To improve the flavor of coffee, a Connecticut company floods the beans with sound waves. A patent for the process was granted this week to Luther G. Simjian of Stamford. The dried coffee beans, just as they are received from the importer, are placed in a water tank and a vibrator bombards them for a few minutes with sound waves, either in the audible or in the supersonic range.
WANTAGH, L. I., April 10 -This is the story of a chain letter and two suburbanites -- Boris Pasternak of Peredelkino, in the Soviet Union, and Mrs. Jack Roth of Wantagh.
ALTHOUGH most home appliances in Europe today are direct copies of American and British products, some of our appliances soon may be based on designs from abroad.

QUANTICO, Va., April 10 -- Victories by Penn State in the day's two top relay track finals -- the distance medley and four-mile -- provided the highlights as the third Marine Corps Schools Relays started at Butler Stadium today.

Supreme Court Justice Irving Saypol deferred decision yesterday on whether to arrest and imprison Banton L. Wyckoff, real estate operator, for failure to cooperate with the Department of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Former Representative Brooks Hays appealed today for a House investigation of last November's Little Rock, Ark., election in which he was defeated by a pro-segregation write-in candidate.
The Anheuser-Busch, Inc., brewery in Newark was shut down yesterday by a strike of 237 brewers and machinists. More than 450 other employes refused to cross a Teamster Union picket line.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Sponsors of the Communist-directed World Youth Festival to be held in Vienna this summer plan to use it to bid for the sympathies and support of young people from Asia, Africa and Latin America.
Winter is relaxing its grip along the St. Lawrence Seaway, but it will be another ten or eleven days before the first seagoing ship starts up the waterway from Montreal.
AKRON, Ohio, April 10 (UPI) -- A strike of 27,000 rubber workers threatened today to spread to 56,000 oters in five days.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A second Titan intercontinental ballistic missile squadron will be located in the area of Denver, Colo., the Air Force announced today.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- Robert Breen, Broadway producer-director, today filed a $5,000,000 damage action against Sam Goldwyn Pruductions and Irving Laza, artists' agent, alleging they took his film rights to "Porgy and Bess" by "false and fraudulent promises."
George P. Monaghan, the state's Harness Racing Commissioner, asked Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday for a clarification of his powers with respect to stock ownership in harness tracks.
Fitful April showers cast a gloom over New York all day, but in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night it was the City of Light -- courtesy of Paris in honor of the April in Paris Ball.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- George Meany told Congress today that a "record of failure" by State Legislatures had demonstrated the need for Federal action to liberalize unemployment compensation benefits.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- According to reliable sources, the intervention of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was responsible for the tough position taken by West Germany in the talks in Washington last week on the Berlin situation.

CHAPEL HILL N. C. April 10 -- Husbands and wives consult marriage counselors today much as their grandparents consulted dentists; that is, only when the pain of their problems has become almost unbearable and considerable damage has been done.
Efforts to avert a strike against six of the city's voluntary hospitals were begun yesterday by Harold A. Felix, city Labor Commissioner.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points up to 3 points off yesterday. One point equals one hundredth of a cent a pound.

PARIS, April 10 -- Middle Eastern oil and the new political situation in West Germany will be the principal topics French leaders plan to raise with the British Government during a visit to London Monday and Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will have an informal meeting with Dr. Fidel Castro during the Cuban Premier's unofficial visit here.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -The Keating-Javits press-release machine, long feared and respected as the fiercest on Capitol Hill, finally stripped its gears today and began racing wildly ahead of the news.

The six-story apartment house at 3971 Gouverneur Avenue in the Bronx was purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation, which immediately resold it to a client of Moses Honig subject to mortgages amounting to $340,000. The building was erected in 1928 and contains sixty-six apartments.
Mrs. Clinton I. Smullyan, chairman of the Irvington House annual spring theatre benefit, has announce a change in plans at a recent meeting with her committee at Carlton House.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (UPI) -- Robin Roberts snuffed out a ninth-inning rally tonight in pitching the Philadelphia Phils to a 2-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. This was his tenth straight start as the Phillies' opening-game hurler.

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices were steady to strong today with a few head bringing $17, equal to the high of Thursday. Slaughter steers and heifers were scarce but prices were quotably steady on the few sales.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- A woman who did not let the rain upset her plans to see the United Nations today suddenly found herself one of the building's main attractions.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today legislation authorizing five additional ships for the Navy at an estimated cost of more than $110,000,000. The House has passed the measure.
The pace of new financing next week will be moderate for both corporations and municipalities when compared with the heavy schedule of this week.

WASHINGTON, -- April 10 (AP) -- The manning of twenty-four more Nike anti-aircraft missile batteries will be taken over from the Regular Army by National Guard units between June 30 and Sept. 1, the Army announced today.

We live in an age of heroic adventure. The past few years have seen such feats of courage and skill as the climbing of Mount Everest, overland treks across the Antarctic wastes and the cruises of the Nautilus and the Skate under the waters of the Arctic Ocean. But even these bold accomplishments pale before the adventure now on humanity's agenda: man's first flight into space.
The Federal Government granted $8,070,168 yesterday for slum clearance in the Hammels and Seaside sections of Rockaway, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Lincoln White, State Department spokesman, said today that "there are no negotiations in progress between the United States and French Governments concerning the purchase of the intermediate-range guided missile Regulus II."

A famous symbol disappeared yesterday from the ticker tape of the New York Stock Exchange. It had been there for more than thirty-seven years. The symbol was "RJB," for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, makers of Camel cigarettes and other tobacco prodducts.

Shades of Kitty Foyle: The white-collar girl has come into her own again. Paris is responsible for reminding American women what fresh white collars and cuffs can do for a simple, sober spring costume.

ST. LOUIS, April 10 (AP) -Jackie Brandt beat his former St. Louis Cardinal team-mates with a ninth-inning double tonight as the San Francisco Giants and Johnny Antonelli took a 6-5 opening night victory.
The International Longshoremen's Association yesterday won a delay in court argument on an order to show why it had not honored an arbitrator's decision on a strike at Port Newark.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 10 -- The fear that Communist China will dump cut-price rice in Southeast Asia this year haunts the predominantly rice economy of Thailand.

Mayor Wagner's request that Fire Commissioner Cavanagh make a thorough study of possible economies in his department's operations has brought to light some interesting changes. Mr. Cavanagh reports that they will save the taxpayers $1.6 million this year without impairing the department's effectiveness -- even improving it.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- The basic steel industry proposed today a one-year freeze on its workers' wages and benefits. The suggestion brought a prompt and emphatic rejection from the United Steelworkers of America.
Mayor Wagner and his aides were undecided yesterday on the kind of real estate transfer tax bill to be submitted to the City Council.

Harold U. Faulkner, Professor Emeritus of History at Smith College, looks at the last decade of the nineteenth century in his new book called "Politics, Reform and Expansion, 1890-1900." He says "the Nineties were neither gay, naughty nor 'mauve.'

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Charges of "vested interests'' figured prominently today in a suit brought by the Dixon-Yates utility combine to collect damages in excess of $1,800,000 from the Government.

A "dance-satire" by Harry Partch called "The Bewitched" was presented last night at the Juilliard Concert Hall by Columbia University in cooperation with the University of Illinois. That it should have been prevailingly academic in quality is quite legitimate and not at all surprising under such auspices; theatrically, however, it is perhaps more bewitched than bewitching.
WOMEN are hoarding stockings like they did during World War II, but shortages are not the reason.
ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Rockefeller approved today the extension for another year of the state's "loyalty" program to keep subversives out of government.

The State Lottery Control Commission advised municipalities yesterday that bingo playing without a license should not b permitted under any circumstances, according to an announcement by Richards W. Hannah, commission chairman.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP) -Nellie Fox hit a home run with two out in the fourteenth inning today and lifted the Chicago White Sox to a 9-7 victory over the Detroit Tigers in an American League opener at Briggs Stadium.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- A late rally, mostly on short-covering for the week-end, sent old-crop corn futures higher today after two successive setbacks earlier this week on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The nation's first seven space pilots were given a few weeks of vacation today to find living space for their families.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 10 -- Two Portuguese have been expelled from this East African colony for the distribution of leaflets attacking the Salazar regime on the ground that it suppressed human rights.
The welcome mat was put out yesterday for the Soviet Ambassador at the typical American house that Tass, the official Soviet press service, has ridiculed as a lot of propaganda.
Thousands of persons stood in line through an intermittent rain for five, six and seven hours yesterday to get tickets for the Bolshoi Ballet.
An attempt to smuggle a knife to one of seven teen-agers on trial for murder in General Sessions Court was frustrated yesterday by an alert court officer.

The pinch in big city bank reserves brought further weakness to the market for United States Government securities yesterday, forcing new low prices on issues that figured in the Treasury's recent $4,000,000,000 cash financing.

Your editorial of April 6 "A Pedestrian Can't Hit Back" succinctly summarizes the views of many New Yorkers who have communicated their thoughts to the Greater New York Safety Council as one of the organizations privileged to participate in the pedestrian safety campaign which you aptly describe as "worth while."
SYRACUSE, April 10 (UPI) -- Paoli Rosi scored a third-round technical knockout over Frankie Ryff tonight in a nationally televised bout.

ATLANTA, April 10 (UPI) -- Atlanta officials told the Federal Civil Rights Commission today that segregation was in the best interest of Negro housing in the South and, that in effect, integrated housing policies or laws would not work.

ROME, April 10 -- The Italian Government indicated today that it wished to avoid a split within the North Atlantic Alliance. However, it suggested that it preferred the West German and French position of firmness to British "flexibility" in the West's approach to the Soviet Union.

Rain washed New York's major league baseball opener down the drain yesterday. Everything that was scheduled was postponed until this afternoon, when another effort will be made to get the Yankees and Boston Red Sox on their way at 2 o'clock at the Stadium.

SAN SALVADOR, April 10 -There is no immediate possibility of a successful invasion in the Caribbean area, a country by country poll of the United States Ambassadors to twelve nations in the area indicated today.

IN Lukas Foss, German-born American-trained musician, the New York Philharmonic this week has a guest whose versatility can compare with that of its music director, Leonard Bernstein. Given a kit more experience and glamour, Mr. Foss could serve as a stand-in for Mr. Bernstein.

Some Ancient Codes Historians have indicated that even before the reign of Hammurabi, king of Babylonia (approximately 2100 B.C.), codes in one form or another were drawn up with the sole intent of governing human conduct.
LONDON, April 10 (Reuters) -- The British Government announced last night that after two years of sporadic fighting troops had quelled a revolt by Oman tribesmen in the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Fred A. Seaten, Interior Secretary, announced today that he had appointed Arthur V. Watkins, former Republican Senator from Utah, as a special Interior Department consultant on water and power affairs.
Net income of the Eaton Manufacturing Company in the first quarter this year rose to $4,300,948 from $2,390,536 a year before. Sales of $70,028,593 compared with $52,688,115.

PARIS, April 10 -- Between the two World Wars Paris played a peculiar role as the center of stimulus for much that was new in the artistic and literary development of the United States. For a variety of reasons, not least among which were Prohibition at home and a favorable dollar exchange rate in France, talented young Americans congregated here to dream, converse and work.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- A spokesman for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said today that Congress helped bring on the Little Rock school crisis by failing to enact a stronger civil rights bill in 1957.

YONKERS, April 10 -- Those who know harness racing best insist that in the sport of standardbreds there is no such animal as a "good mudder" or a "bad mudder." Sooner or later, the experts contend, a trotter or a pacer will win a race regardless of the track's condition.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -American consumers bought more in retail shops in March than in any previous month, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved the nominations of two new Defense Department officials today after they had agreed to sell stocks that might constitute a conflict of interest.

THE peach tree bloomed last week on our terrace. The Giants are getting ready to win the National League pennant. These are signs of spring -- but not any more reliable than the appearance of books like Edward Shenton's "The Rib and Adam,"* trumpeting the joys and perils of country life in America.
"The Cat," ("La Chatte"), a French drama about Paris during the German occupation in World War II, will open today at the World Theatre, ,Forty-ninth Street, east of Seventh Avenue.
LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP) -- The National Association of Evangelicals ended in annual convention today after hearing a talk against election of a Roman Catholic president.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Western Allies are sharply divided on the question whether Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev is serious about negotiating a settlement of major East-West problems.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A Federal crop survey indicated today that this year's wheat crop -- like most of its predecessors in recent years -would add to the record surplus.
THAT amiable virtuoso of the clarinet, Benny Goodman, led a melodious crew through a pleasant musical hour, "Swing into Spring," on Channel 2 last night.

HUE, Vietnam, April 8 -- This former capital of Annam, with its moldering royal tombs and ruined palaces, is almost in the front line of dissension between Communist North Vietnam and non-Communist South Vietnam.

AS homeward-bound revelers made their way through the dawn-drenched streets this morning, New York society knew it had had a ball. Climaxing a year of planning, the April in Paris Ball, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night for the benefit of Franco-American charitable and cultural organizations, is one of the outstanding fashion events of the season.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Eastern railroads filed proposals today with the Interstate Commerce Commission to offer special discount rates on large volume shipments of bituminous steam coal moving to tidewater points extending from New York City to Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon called on the Republican National Committee today for new party unity efforts to assure victory in 1960.
An altimeter on an American Airlines Electra gave a faulty reading by some 600 feet as the plane was landing in Detroit ten days ago.
David Campanella was put on probation for an indefinite period in Queens Children's Court yesterday.
COMMACK, L. I., April 10 -Three masked bandits, two of them armed, escaped with $10,273 this morning in a hasty hold-up of the Commack branch of the Bank of Smithtown.
The International Business Machines Corporation had the highest sales and earnings in the first quarter this year for any similar period in its history.

"The Rape of Lucrece," a sculpture by Reuben Nakian, was moved into the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, yesterday. It will be on public display after it is assembled in about one week.
PROVIDENCE, April 11 -Brown's sophomore-packed varsity crew pulled away from Boston University shortly after the start and went on to score a length-and-a-half victory today on the Seekonk River.

The Girls Service League has announced that more than 80 per cent of subscribers to its scheduled benefit theatre party at the April 2 performance of "Juno," which closed before that date, have transferred their reservations to a performance of "Triple Play" at the Playhouse on May 5.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 11 (UPI) -- Ambassador Stepan P. Kirsanov returned to his post here today after a long absence, quieting persistent rumors he would be replaced by Vyacheslav M. Molotov.
WEST HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., April 11 -- Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, declared tonight that the state's safety programs were being jeopardized by "a malicious political hatchet job."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -Supporters of the multibillion-dollar omnibus housing bill predicted today that the House Rules Committee would permit the much-disputed measure to go before the House within a week or so.

Discovery of a layer of clean white ash on and beneath the bed of the Pacific Ocean is reported in the current Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences by Columbia University scientists. The find, believed to record a notable event in the earth's history, was made aboard Columbia's research vessel Vema and is described by Dr. J. Lamar Worzel, professor of geology and assistant director of the Lamont Geological Observatory.
George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, denied yesterday that the State Investigation Commission had criticized his handling of undesirables connected with racing.
CARACAS, April 1 -- Diversification of Venezuelan industry will be the long-range goal of his Government, President Romulo Betancourt said in a series of statements and speeches this week.

THIS magnificent history of British armored warfare was begun by Capt. B. H. Liddell Hart in 1946 at the commission of the Royal Tank Regiment, but in fact he has been writing it all his life. He was one of the earliest and most influential champions of the tank and of the tactics of shock and mobility which the tank restored to the battlefield.

AN UNUSUALLY good opportunity is present this week to survey the whole field of contemporary water-colors. The big annual of the American Watercolor Society is still current at the National Academy, and the Brooklyn Museum has opened its twentieth biennial international water-color show with 200 examples, chiefly in the more advanced modes of the day by Canadian, Mexican and United States artists.

A performance of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "Princess Ida" will be presented by the Barnard College Gilbert and Sullivan Society at the Oceanside (L. I.) Senior High School next Saturday evening.

Crockett Johnson's new picture book about Harold is a fine follow-up for all the young children who have seen this year's circus and a come-on for those who will. PORTSMOUTH, Va. -- Visitors to Virginia during the state's annual Historic Garden Week rarely go away disappointed, even though they can scarcely help missing a great deal. WASHINGTON, April 11 -The Secretary of Labor has asked Congress for funds to start a periodic general revision of the Consumer Price Index. The Queen will attend the bicentennial garden party on the grounds and will also visit, and perhaps officially open, its reconstructed Palm House and its Orangerie.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 11 -- The nominating committee of the Democratic county committee failed today to agree on a candidate for Bergen County chairman. COLOR will be the dominant theme of the thirteenth annual National Photographic Show opening Saturday at the Coliseum, according to Wilfred L. Knighton, managing director. ELIZABETH, N. J., April 11 -- A gasoline tank truck burst into flames at a busy intersection here this evening. Hundreds of bystanders watched firemen fight the blaze for ninety minutes. Flames shot fifty feet into the air.

ROME, April 12 -- Pope John XXIII proclaimed an Italian friar and a Spanish nun saints of the Roman Catholic Church today. The four-hour ceremony in St. Peter's Basilica, an occasion of one of the most solemn Vatican rites, was the first canonization of the new Pope's pontificate.

SIX New York homes decorated by leading interior decorators have been chosen for a tour tomorrow. The tour is for the benefit of the New York chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. Tickets can be purchased at the foundation's office, 432 Fourth Avenue. They are $8.50 each.

THE dessert ordered most often at the Coach House restaurant, 110 Waverly Place, just west of Washington Square, is pecan pie. The pie is in the old southern tradition.
