Grant Beglarian, whose award-winning "Diversion for Orchestra" was performed by the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, is of Armenian descent, was born in Tiflis, Georgia, in the Soviet Union, was reared in Iran and is now a violist in the Plymouth Symphony Orchestra in a suburb of Detroit.

M. Shapiro Son, Inc., of White Plains, builders, have purchased three four-story brownstone buildings at 238 to 242 East Fifty-fifth Street between Second and Third Avenues from Nancy Golub. Herman Ackman of Ackman Brothers was the broker.
Much has been written about various schemes for utilizing Ellis Island. Plans have been described for establishing a home for drug addicts, schools, marinas, pleasure resorts, luxury apartments, etc.
Sales of the Allied Chemical Corporation in the first quarter set a new record for the period and earnings rose 68 per cent above the 1958 level.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 12 -- W. Emlen Roosevelt's black cocker spaniel, Ch. Windjammer's Passkey, from Far Hills, N. J., found New Jersey show competition the finest anywhere tonight. The 2 1/2-yearold dog became best in show in the 909-dog event of the Twin Brooks Kennel Club.

Albert Axelrod and Alan Kwartler of Salle Santelli joined Andre Deladrier, Navy's coach, as champions as the fifth annual masters tournament of the Metropolitan Division of the Amateur Fencers League of America ended yesterday at the Fencers Club.

There's a new rapid-transit system of delivering varsity sports results to the students at Governor Dummer Academy in South Byfield, Mass. When the teams are playing away, the boys back home depend on Susie the pigeon to keep them posted.
Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, wants educators not to forget to teach moral and cultural values in the current clamor for more general and scientific education.

The chief worry these days of the nation's mutual funds, outside of where the soaring securities market will lead, is the May 29 deadline for completion of the final section of the Securities and Exchange Commission's questionnaire.

" THE right book for the right child at the right time." This is a good rule for parents to follow, according to Mrs. Frances Spain, co-ordinator of children's services of the New York Public Library.
Youth Aliyah, an international agency for the rehabilitation of homeless Jewish children in Israel, celebrated Child's Day yesterday at a ceremony in the Israeli Consulate, 11 East Seventieth Street.
NEW DELHI, India, April 12 (Reuters) -- The two-man crew of an Indian Air Force plane shot down Friday over Pakistan returned to India today.
NEW HAVEN, April 12 -John P. Marquand, the writer, has given all his literary manuscripts to Yale University.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 12 -- Senator John F. Kennedy challenged American Negro colleges today to train students for "global responsibilities" in the light of the fact that the vast majority of the people in the uncommitted countries were colored.

In 1904 "Caesar" Young, a well-known gambler, bookmaker and man-about-New York, was shot dead in a hansom cab on West Broadway. Beside him sat his mistress, Nan Patterson, a former member of the famous sextette in a road company of "Florodora."

The times in which we live show the most startling contrast between the blackest darkness and the brightest light in all secular history. These are the days in which seven young volunteers are chosen for the supreme adventure of space travel and another young man, remembering his ordered share in the Hiroshima bombing, goes into an emotional darkness of his own.
CALLAO, Peru, April 12 (AP) -- Two Czechoslovaks, a Peruvian and an Argentine set out aboard a raft today for the South Sea Islands.

The Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City yesterday announced its annual awards for outstanding reporting during 1958. The presentations will be made at the yearly installation dinner at the Manhattan Hotel on May 13.
Thirteen urban renewal projects, with a total of 22,000 new dwelling units, have been completed or are under contract under the Title I slum-clearance program, Robert Moses reported yesterday.

Representatives of the 400 Roman Catholic parishes in the New York Archdiocese attended a communion breakfast yesterday at the New York Foundling Hospital, Sixty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, in preparation for the annual fund appeal of the New York Catholic Charities.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Dr. Homer Edward Newell Jr., one of the nation's leading space scientists, has the singular distinction of having left a group of Senators speechless but impressed recently.
Two time-honored symbols of the good life -- great cuisine in the French tradition and elegant table service -- are passing from the American scene.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The grain futures market opened up a wide variety of tempting contracts for profit takers last week but it attracted relatively few of them.
CLARENCE CAMPBELL, the president of the National Hockey League, was seriously stricken the other day with foot-in-mouth trouble.

DETROIT, April 12 (AP) -Rudy Arias and Bob Shaw, pitching in relief, checked the Detroit Tigers with the bases loaded in the seventh and eighth innings today, enabling the Chicago White Sox to score a 5-3 victory for a sweep of their three-game series.
The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday expressed its opposition to any blanket ban on strikes by Federal, state or city employes.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 12 (AP) -- The royal palace announced today the engagement of Prince Albert, brother of King Baudouin, to an Italian princess, Dona Paola Ruffo di Calabria.
LONDON, April 12 -- After an initial enthusiastic response to the budget, the stock markets fell back heavily last week.

The main party of Moscow's Bolshoi Theatre ballet company, a group of men and women with an appealing quality that combines curiosity with laughter and shyness, arrived yesterday. They spent their first evening in the United States at the circus.

The New York City Mission Society's Camp Green Acres will be the beneficiary of the premiere of the motion picture "Warlock" on April 30 at the Paramount Theatre. Tickets may be obtained from the society at 105 East Twenty-second Street.
HARWICH, England, April 12 (AP) -- An American woman was landed dazed and injured from a crippled yacht today after she had seen her husband swept overboard off England's east coast.
Dr. Leona Baumgartner, the city's Health Commissioner, said yesterday she was "deeply concerned" by a rising venereal disease rate, especially among teen-agers.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Director of the Budget predicted today that the country would have a lower, balanced budget and a tax reduction if Congress approved eighteen economy suggestions by President Eisenhower.
The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, voiced a plea yesterday for increased support of the diocese's 175th Anniversary Fund.
The Most Rev. Joseph M. Pernicone, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, suggested yesterday that churchgoers make Jesus "more active" in their lives.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey yesterday termed "unconstitutional" the proposal of Senator Clifford P. Case to tax the income of New Yorkers working in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- Milk samples from St. Louis contained more radioactive strontium 90 last year than any other tested, the United States Public Health Service reported today.

The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt took "sadistic" delight in telling Prime Minister Winston Churchill that the end of the British Empire was at hand, former Gov. W. Averell Harriman told a television audience yesterday.
Mayor Wagner indicated last night that there was no hope that the city administration would heed the strong opposition to the proposed 10-cent tax on taxi rides.

National Library Week, which began yesterday, is an appropriate time for an appraisal of the cooperative "library systems" which are rapidly developing in this state with government assistance. The article by Lettie Gay Carson in yesterday's Times Magazine tells the story -- with the statistics of need and growth brought to life by personal vignettes of how the systems are working.
Three new films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, April 12 -- Clement Jumelle, former Presidential candidate who had been in hiding for twenty-one months, died of uremia here last night in asylum at the Cuban Embassy. He was 42 years old.

An appeal for world support of Israel's desire to establish peace in the Middle East based on democratic principles and concern "for the one natural resource, the human being," was made yesterday by Simcha Pratt, Israel's Consul General in New York.
Tom Mboya, Kenya political and labor leader, said yesterday that the African goal was to remove European colonialism, not Europeans as individuals, from the continent.
In a setting as frosty as you'll find in a refrigerator, the Yankees finally got around yesterday to opening the American League season at the Stadium.

New group life insurance written last year by the Union Labor Life Insurance Company totaled $99,614,000, or 114 per cent more than in 1957, according to the company's annual report. New individual life insurance written in 1958 totaled $4,832,000, or 15 per cent more than in 1957.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 12 (AP) -- A Soviet Committee for African-Asian Solidarity arrived by plane from Moscow today to attend a congress of Iraqi Peace Partisans.

THE opera that Robert Ward, composer, and Bernard Stambler, librettist, fashioned out of Leonid Andreyev's play, "He Who Gets Slapped," will make no musical revolution. But it is unabashedly and continuously lyrical, and it occasionally captures a bittersweet atmosphere.
The steamship charter market became more active last week and achieved some slight rate gains, but the over-all picture remained gloomy.

In the nature of things the Central Intelligence Agency is the most secretive agency of our Government. It was therefore an event of considerable importance last week when the head of the agency, Allen W. Dulles, gave the American people his estimate of the nature and magnitude of the Soviet challenge. His speech, printed in this newspaper, deserves study.

The offer by private interests headed by O. Roy Chalk, New York and Washington financier, to negotiate for the purchase of all city-owned transit facilities will have to run the gantlet of a hostile Board of Estimate.
The Columbia University Glee Club, directed by Bailey Harvey, gave a concert of music for men's voices Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.
The Teachers Union has urged its members to honor Teachers Guild picket lines next Thursday "where a majority or even a significant number" of teachers participate.

GROTON, Conn., April 12 -- The Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy met yesterday aboard the Skipjack, below the Atlantic, as the latest nuclear submarine set two records on an overnight cruise.

The time has come, pardners, to set the record straight. New York is not the Wild West, City Sheriff John J. McCloskey said yesterday, and he is not required to gallop up and down Broadway on horseback.
BONN, Germany, April 12 -The basic effort of West German foreign policy now is to devise a means of accepting the present without foreclosing the future.
Several million-dollar advertising accounts are involved in shifts on Madison Avenue. Just how many millions are involved in each case, depends on who supplies the figures.
HACKENSACK, N. J., April 12 -- A suit to restrain the Port of New York Authority from developing a large tract near Teterboro Airport for industrial purposes is planned in Superior Court this week.

PARIS, April 12 -- Adenauer's decision to seek the West German Presidency is linked to the deep political split within NATO. One group of allies, headed by Britain, wishes to deal softly with Russia in forthcoming negotiations. Another group, headed by France and West Germany, wants to present an unyielding front.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The United States will propose to the Soviet Union tomorrow that only those tests of nuclear weapons causing dangerous fall-out be banned.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- A Georgia Senator said today civil rights enthusiasts treated the South like "a conquered province." A New York Senator said the South was trying to return to pre-Civil War days.

MILAN, Italy, April 12 -- The Milan Sample Fair, which was opened this morning, affords ample proof that Europe is rapidly recovering from the recession that produced a stagnation of business in 1958.

TOKYO, April 12 -- Japanese physicians at the Hiroshima Atomic Disease Hospital, a Government institution for treating victims of the atomic bombing of the city, have decided to stop announcing further deaths resulting from the radioactive blast thirteen years and eight months ago.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 -The possibility of an imminent decision on the continued tenure of John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State was suggested here today.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 12 -- The Communist underground in South Vietnam has stepped up its activities in recent months.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- With the April 15 deadline nearing, a question is puzzling the Internal Revenue Service: Where is the taxpayer line-up?

A second major career will end for Vice Admiral Calvin T. Durgin, U. S. N. (retired), when he retires on Sept. 30 as president of the State University of New York Maritime College, at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

BALBOA, C. Z., April 12 -- Because of the increasing number of larger ships seeking transit through the Panama Canal, it has become necessary to restrict the draft limitations for commercial vessels of more than 30,000 deadweight tons.

As noted recently in this space and frequently elsewhere, the arrival of warmer breezes on a fairly dependable schedule induces people of the most down-to-earth, everyday, practical sort to recall scraps and fragments of poetry.

HONG KONG, April 4 -- Despite Peiping's determination to become a major oil producer within the next decade, Communist China produced last year only the equivalent of two days' crude oil output of the United States.
The heads of the committee that led the fight to close Washington Square to traffic agreed last night to stay in business until the Board of Estimate's decision in their favor was implemented.

SAN SALVADOR, April 12 -- The importance of the Caribbean area in United States policy planning was emphasized here today as the three - day conference of ambassadors assigned to Caribbean countries closed.
A long-standing controversy over how much tax abatement should be granted to new housing for middle-income families was headed yesterday toward a showdown in the Board of Estimate.

LONDON, April 12 -- The British Government completed today preparations for a series of diplomatic talks in which it hopes to convince the Atlantic Treaty allies of the importance of flexibility in the Western policy approach to the Soviet Union.
A National Advisory Council of fourteen business and safety executives has been recruited by Columbia University to pick traffic research projects.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Television personality Dennis Weaver will portray Lieut. Comdr. Andrew Lowe in "The Admiral Halsey Story," which stars James Cagney in the title role. The part of Admiral Halsey's chief aide will be Mr. Weaver's first major theatrical screen appearance since he signed for the role of Chester in the "Gunsmoke" television series.
Local governments posted $34,857,000 of proposed market borrowings over the week-end. The new issues will include bonds of eleven municipal and other governmental subdivisions.
GREENSBORO, N. C., April 12 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald of Tequesta, Fla., sloshed through some of the worst weather of the year today to win the $15,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

AS a foretaste of what it intends to offer next season, the New York Theatre Society put on for a single performance last night two plays of William Butler Yeats' Cuchulain cycle. They are a sort of a Celtic counterpart of the Homeric legends of Greece and up until now -- at least so say the theatrical historians -- they have never been given a professional New York performance.
By estimates of city assessors, New York's city-owned transit system is officially valued at $1,206,000,000.
" Armstrong Circle Theatre" plans to dramatize a major East-West incident of last February when a United States Army convoy was detained by Soviet guards just inside the East German border.

The changes in both the volume and direction of the flow of the country's 110 largest foundations' grants, revealed in the Foundation Library Center's Annual Report for 1958, reflect the public's changing needs and how they are being met. The figures also put in striking perspective the gigantic gifts of the Ford Foundation in 1957.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 12 -- The Army has ordered two new missiles and has authorized the development of a third in a major overhaul of its anti-tank program.
MONTAUK POINT, L. I., April 12 -Two crew members of a forty-foot fishing trawler leaped to safety this afternoon minutes before the vessel sank in a collision with another fishing boat.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 12 -- Great strength and activity again developed on the stock exchange last week.
A survey by the International Press Institute reports that the post-Stalin "thaw" has brought some amelioration of press conditions in Communist countries.
PITTSBURGH, April 12 -- A blinding snowstorm swirled over Forbes Field today and the finale of a three-game series between the Milwaukee Braves and the Pittsburgh Pirates was called off.
City Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that about 20,000 children in New York City needed foster care each year. He predicted that the number would increase.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- A Unitarian Church leader said today that members of that denomination were willing to pay higher taxes if Federal aid to education could not be financed out of present revenues.
William Ryan, baritone, was heard last night in his local debut at Carnegie Recital Hall, with Gibner King as his excellent piano accompanist.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad and the Erie Railroad have decided to begin "immediate negotiations" toward a merger. The two roads announced this decision yesterday immediately after they, together with the Delaware and Hudson Company, had decided to terminate talks concerning a three-way merger.

THE secretary who is wed to the comforts of home, American style, need not apply to the State Department for work abroad. Even if she qualified, the chances are she would be in for a grave disappointment.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 13 (AP) -The Air Force launched here today a satellite rocket containing a space capsule that it hoped to catch in the air near Hawaii. It is the Discoverer II.
STRATFORD, Conn., April 13 -- A flying crane designed to tow a destroyer or handle a telephone pole as if it were a toothpick was displayed here today.

Trading increased in most commodity futures contracts yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, potatoes and the domestic sugar contract registered the second largest volumes of the year. Copper volume was the third largest. Wool volume also was heavy.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. conciliated yesterday a dispute between two high-ranking department officials.

Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver announced yesterday that his staff had started an inquiry into complaints that mobsters were seeking to get control of the $10,000,000-a-year bowling alley operations in Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 (UPI) -- Local fans paid tribute tonight to Roy Campanella, Stan Musial and the Dodgers at the second annual Dodger dinner sponsored by the Los Angeles chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 13 (AP) -- Sales volume of the E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc., for the first quarter was the highest of any quarter in the company's history, Crawford H. Greenewalt, president, told stockholders today.

BUENOS AIRES, April 13 -The violence in the labor conflict at the Kaiser automotive plant in Cordoba is being watched closely by United States companies here as a test of the Government's labormanagement relations policy.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -Vice President Nixon sent aloft in New York tonight a fairly important trial balloon on how to negotiate future agreements with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -President Eisenhower summoned the Advertising Council today to help prove that the world's choice was not between "freedom and bread."
TRENTON, April 13 -- The Assembly tonight approved two bills to alleviate the critical commuter railroad problem in the metropolitan area. The measures now go to the Senate.
A further tightening in the money market yesterday produced still higher yields on Treasury bills and a continued drift to lower prices in long and intermediate Government bonds.

On April 12, 1759, The Whitehall Evening Post reported "Mr. Handel, who was in hopes to have set out for Bath last Saturday, has continued so ill that he could not undertake the journey.'' Had the eighteenth-century journalist known it, the composer was preparing for his ultimate journey, for he died during the night dividing April 13 from April 14.
Wine accounts continue to be as restless as the bubbles in a glass of champagne.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- With only two Republicans on hand, the Senate extended its "warm regards" to former President Harry S. Truman today in anticipation of his seventy-fifth birthday, May 8.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 13 -- The trend of official thinking here appears to point to the probability that Thailand's next Constitution will lean more toward authoritarianism than parliamentary democracy.

TORONTO, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- A $25,000,000 issue of 5 1/2-per-cent cumulative convertible preferred shares of Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., is being offered at $100 a share by a group of investment dealers headed by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

SOME of the best taste in town can be found underground these days. A tour through Bloomingdale's basement the other day -- or the Downstairs Store as it is called -- unearthed a fine array of excellent buys. The plain fact is that Bloomingdale's has succeeded in its campaign, begun a few years ago, to bring fashion and good taste down to rock-bottom career -girl prices.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -The United States placed a military satellite into orbit around the poles of the earth today. But it failed in an attempt to launch two other scientific satellites.
Granting the British air rights to Tokyo-United States traffic would undermine United States airlines, Northwest Airlines declared yesterday.

Thomas Ewing Sherman, second son of Maj. Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, is the subject of a biography by the Rev. Joseph T. Durkin entitled "General Sherman's Son." Thomas, without telling his family, abruptly left the study of law in his early twenties and entered the Jesuit novitiate, causing a serious breach with his nonCatholic father.
NATHANIEL BANKS' "Season of Choice," which opened at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening, is a drama about the unfortunate consequences of mesalliance in the South.
TORONTO, April 13 (UPI) -- Ontario plans to place classified advertisements in provincial newspapers offering children for adoption, it was announced today.

TO fulfill its function, the first course should look attractive. When it is tasted, it should whet the appetite for what is to follow. Two cold hors d'oeuvres that meet these qualifications are a liver mousse in aspic and cucumber stuffed with vegetables and topped with green mayonnaise.
LANSING, Mich., April 13 (UPI) -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams announced tonight that he had signed bills appropriating nearly $28,000,000 to make up deficits in Michigan's school aid.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles decided today to delay a decision on Mr. Dulles' future as Secretary of State. Meanwhile, Mr. Dulles will undergo new treatment for his abdominal cancer.

LONDON, April 13 -- Premier Michel Debre of France asked the West today to look beyond the foreign ministers' meeting with the Soviet Union to "important questions" connected with a summit conference.
The New York Philharmonic will offer a Mahler Festival, a Pergolesi Festival, a Spring Festival of Theatre Music and other special events during its 1959-60 season, Oct. 15 through May 15, 1960.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP) -The auto makers expect a substantial spring sales upsurge. They have scheduled 577,000 cars for production this month, approximately the same number as was turned out in March.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Members of Cotton Exchanges and an official of the Plains Cotton Growers Association testified today in support of direct compensatory payments to cotton farmers.
BURGOS, Spain, April 13 (AP) -Two American women, one the daughter of a former United States diplomat, died last night in an automobile crash near Bahabon de Esgueva, forty miles south of here.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would not support any plan from private investors to buy the city's transit system if the plan did not limit fare increases.
Four persons were stabbed, one fatally, yesterday when a 26-year-old man apparently went beserk in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -The United States told the Soviet Union today it would fly planes into Berlin at any altitude it wanted.

VICTOR Borge once blandly told an audience thirsting moderately for musical enlightenment that "Tchaikovsky was born in 1840 and was a rather obscure musician until 1958 when he was discovered by a Texan."
A drop in Manhattan property sales since 1955 has been cited by the Real Estate Board of New York as an argument against the proposed transfer tax on realty sales.
BOSTON, April 13 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox said today there had been no "bias" in a decision to send Jerry (Pumpsie) Green, a Negro infielder, back to the minors.

Charges of burglary and felonious assault against Henry (Hank) Thompson, former third baseman for the New York Giants, now the San Francisco Giants, were reduced yesterday in Felony Court to unlawful entry and third-degree assault.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- The American Management Association's National Packaging Exposition and Conference opened here today.

Full sponsorship reportedly has been obtained for a series of seven ninety-minute programs to be co-produced next season by the television subsidiary of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures. All dramas will be adapted from M-G-M movies produced before 1948.

"Aparajito" ("The Unvanquished"), the second feature film in the Indian-made trilogy produced and directed by Satyajit Ray, will have its American premiere on April 28 at the Fifth Avenue Cinema. Edward Harrison is the distributor.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A research program is under way to learn how cows take in strontium 90 and how it contaminates their milk. The study also aims at means of preventing such radioactive contamination.
Custom smelters reduced the price of refined copper 1 cent a pound yesterday, to 32 cents a pound. This was the second 1-cent cut in as many business days.
San Diego Unified School District, Calif., has set June 30 as the day on which it will open bids for $7,000,000 of school building bonds. The issue will mature from 1960 to 1979.
MIAMI BEACH, April 13 (AP) -- A New York legislator called today for "a salvo from Blue Cross guns" to clear the way toward including care for mental patients in the prepaid hospitalization plans.

PEIPING, April 13 (Reuters) -- Thousands of Chinese office workers, back at their desks after a year's manual labor on farms and in factories to help rid them of "wrong ideas," are being warned that their complete salvation is still some way off.
McKEESPORT, Pa., April 13 (AP) -- The G. C. Murphy Company, operator of a large chain of variety stores, expanded today with the purchase of Morgan and Lindsey Company.

If you're an undergraduate, striving for a college degree, you're just the person for a bowling tournament. A spare $6 scraped from the weekly allowance helps. But a bowling ball is no requirement -- the house will have plenty of the sixteen-pounders.

WHITE PLAINS, April 13 -- Mrs. Gordon B. M. Walker of Rye, chairman of the Family Service of Westchester, Inc., benefit tennis matches, has announced a partial list of eighty patrons for the events. Steel production set a historic high last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It estimated that output had been scheduled at an even higher rate this week.

Truck drivers and platform loaders for the Horn Hardart chain of Automat restaurants in the metropolitan area have voted to be represented by Local 816 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Sales and earnings of North American Aviation, Inc., in the quarter and six months ended March 31 were above the levels of a year before. The company produces military aircraft and missiles.

After fifty years as part of the K. C. Kent holdings, the parcel at 62-64 Howard Street in Irvington, N. J., has been acquired by the Star Stationery Company, according to Leslie R. Hauser, executive vice president of Hauser Associates, industrial real estate brokers who negotiated the deal. The property extends through to Grace Street.
The acceptance by Don Belding of Los Angeles of the 1959 national campaign chairmanship of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Broadening of two state social insurance programs to cover thousands of employes in smaller shops and plants was approved today by Governor Rockefeller.

SAN GERMAN, P. R., April 13 (AP) -- Dr. Edwin T. Dahlberg of St Louis, president of the National Protestant Council, said tonight that one of mankind's main responsibilities was providing food for the world's hungry.

YONKERS, April 13 -- Working for Billy Haughton a harness racing driver does not get to pilot many winners. After all, the boss is the fellow who has topped the nation's drivers for the past six years. Last season, for example, Haughton started 833 times and guided home 176 winners, earning $816,659 in purses.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- The Army and Air Force are working on a secret project they hope will be a flying saucer.

Today is Pan American Day, anniversary of the day in 1890 when the First Inter-American Conference created the Pan American Union, forerunner of the Organization of American States. It is an annual moment of stock-taking and dedication to the policies and principles that animate what is universally considered to be the most successful regional organization in the world.

Customs revenues in the Port of New York last month rose almost one-third above the March, 1958, level.

For seven big-league baseball cities, today is opening day. The clubs that opened on the road last week will make their 1959 home bows. If the weather is right, attendance is likely to total more than the nine other openers of last week, when the weather generally was wrong.

West Germany's Defense Minister, Franz Josef Strauss, said here yesterday he was convinced the Soviet Union would not risk another war but would rely on political means to extend its power.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Conversationally, baseball is a blockbuster today among top movie officials. But, professionally, it is a dud.

John Gielgud and Margaret Leighton are to be starred in "Much Ado About Nothing" under Mr. Gielgud's direction. Mr. Gielgud will be seen as Benedick and Miss Leighton as Beatrice. They will appear first at the Cambridge Drama Festival in Boston and subsequently here.
Jan Peerce, who had not appeared here in recital in more than ten years, sang a Carnegie Hall performance last night for the benefit of Madison House.
MEN, women and children in training for honest television quiz programs of the future ought to pay more attention to press agents who deal with hunting and fishing affairs. Press agents know a heap.
Enthusiasm for drug stocks dominated the stock market yesterday. Every other major group was mixed or lower.

A syndicate headed by Maurice Epstein has purchased the nine-story building at 139 Centre Street, at the southwest corner of Walker Street. The structure, which contains a gross area of more than 104,000 square feet, is occupied by offices of the United States Navy and the Agricultural Department.

The day may not be far off when candidates for Congress who can do so will be making their knowledge of higher mathematics or advanced physics a prime theme in seeking support at the polls. Certainly public attention is now closely concentrated on the current and future rocket launching and space exploration plans both of the National Aeronautics and Space Agency and of its military counterpart.

Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, warned the city's teachers yesterday that he would invoke "the fullest extent of the law" if they participated in a scheduled work stoppage on Thursday.

That or which. Those are the words that (which) confront nearly every writer at one fork or another in the grammatical path. His pen wavers or his typewriter stops. And when at length he decides which fork to take, he is apt to feel as he goes on that the other would have been better.
Christopher T. Chenery's First Landing regained his standing among the nation's top 3-year-old colts with a three-length victory over five rivals at Jamaica yesterday.
GENEVA, April 13 (AP) -- North Korea proposes to repatriate Koreans from Japan in unarmed and unescorted Soviet ships, a North Korean official disclosed today.
The members of the Bolshoi Theatre ballet company, including prima ballerina Galina Ulanova, were distressed yesterday at the condition of the floor of the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House.
The art of ancient Egypt can now be seen in an unbroken flow at the Brooklyn Museum. A reinstalled gallery spans the art from 4000 B. C. to the tenth century A. D.
Yesterday was the golden anniversary of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., one of the world's leading oil organizations.
TORONTO, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., had an estimated net income in 1958 of $11,074,300, compared with $26,367,403 in 1957.

Sugar Ray Robinson, a specialist in the unexpected, had the New York State Athletic Commission served with a show-cause order yesterday. He wants to restrain the commission from stripping him of the middleweight championship.
Housewives may soon be cashing their green stamps for culture as well as carving sets and percolators.
MOSCOW, April 13 (AP) -- The Government reported today that in the first quarter of 1959 Soviet industry produced 11 per cent more than in the like period of 1958.
Mayor Wagner appointed a three-man citizens committee yesterday to try to help resolve the deadlocked contract negotiations between the United Parcel Service of New York and four teamster locals.
Harold A. Felix, city Labor Commissioner, yesterday asked six voluntary hospitals threatened with a strike to meet with him today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- (UPI) -- Carlos Ortiz of New York, a 7 -- 5 short-ender, scored a technical knockout over Len Matthews after 2 minutes 21 seconds of the sixth round in a scheduled ten-round lightweight bout tonight.

The United Steelworkers of America called on the steel industry last night to freeze steel prices as a contribution to "economic stability." The proposal was the union's reply to an industry call for a one-year wage freeze.
Prescott Neighborhood House will be the beneficiary of the May 5 performance of "A Raisin in the Sun" at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

The nomination of six new governors of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by the exchange's nominating committee. Edward C. Werle was nominated for a second one-year term as chairman.

The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company announced yesterday the opening of a new $1,750,000 laboratory at Hastings-on-Hudson, Westchester, for development research and testing of extra-high voltage (230,000 volts and up) cable and accessory equipment.
I read with interest the recent report emanating from the Bureau of Narcotics that the "number of narcotic addicts is steadily but surely declining."

Federal income-tax reports are due by midnight tomorrow. Internal Revenue Service officials said here yesterday that returns in the metropolitan area were arriving at a normal rate -- even though taxpayer inquiries were fewer than usual.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- The Government told a Federal jury today that "personal pleas and financial inducements" influenced the vote of Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications Commissioner, in the 1957 award of television Channel 10 in Miami.
State Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit yesterday reserved his decision on a petition by waterfront employers to confirm a no-strike ruling that had been issued by an impartial arbitrator.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, the new chairman of the Republican National Committee, demonstrated in his speech of acceptance that he understands the basic purpose of his job when he said he would be strictly neutral among individuals and factions, and concentrate on "organizing" the party.

LONDON, April 13 -- The Labor party's objections to the Government's budget took the form tonight of a motion of censure that declared that proposed tax relief measures neglected the old-age pensioners and other who really needed help.

Under present conditions it is only a matter of time before the Soviet Union will push the United States out of its No. 2 position in the world fishing industry, L. Vernon Drape, president of the National Fisheries Institute, said yesterday. Japan holds the No. 1 position and Russia the third spot.
Political associates and friends of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia, who for years prided themselves on "the forward look," paused yesterday for an unabashed and almost reverential backward look.
ROME, April 13 -- Pope John XXIII forbade Roman Catholics throughout the world today to vote for candidates or parties that supported or gave comfort to the Communists.
The first public hearing on a comprehensive new zoning regulation proposed on Feb. 16 by consultants to the City Planning Commission was held yesterday. It drew more praise than criticism.
Social workers were urged yesterday to support their own inclusion under one of the social insurances -- unemployment insurance.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission issued regulations today relating to outflows and levels of Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River.
HAVANA, April 13 -- A prominent figure in the Cuban revolutionary movement, Col. Antonio Dahud, has been arrested by the Goverment of Premier Fidel Castro, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- A Congressional subcommittee charged today that a United States official had received $500 from a Hong Kong concern that later got a $275,000 contract to provide tugs and barges for a foreign aid projects in Laos.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- The counsel for a Congressional investigating committee denied today that questions asked Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, had been based on illegal evidence and "electronic eavesdropping."

NICE, France, April 13 -- When Tony Vandervell said last week that he was willing to race one Vanwall car provided Stirling Moss drove it, Moss suddenly found himself the most envied unemployed driver in racing.

THE boundaries of antiques have become, it seems, almost limitless, More and more, categories of objects are entering a field from which, only a few years ago, they would have been excluded for being without interest or too late.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A minority report on the KennedyErvin labor-management bill declares it is wanting in six important areas and full of "gimmicks."
The cost of providing care for patients at Maimonides Hospital of Brooklyn last year rose to $28.88 a day, according to Dr. J. A. Katzive, executive director.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 (AP) -- The fugitive Dalai Lama of Tibet will be given residence at Mussoorie, a hill town 150 miles northeast of New Delhi, while he is in exile in India, the Foreign Ministry announced tonight.
ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) -- Sal (The Barber) Maglie, a 42-year-old former pitching great for the Giants and Dodgers, was signed today as a minor league pitching instructor by the St. Louis Cardinals.
A report that financial arrangements had been completed for the start of a third major league in 1961 brought cautious comment yesterday from Mayor Wagner's baseball committee.

THE Army-Navy football game just won't seem the same any more. The teeming excitement of the last nine years was generated to a vast extent by two fellows who nervously paced the sidelines and thought deep thoughts. One was Red Blaik of Army, an established genius as a coach. The other was Eddie Erdelatz of Navy, a budding genius who already had ascended to the upper echelons of the coaching fraternity.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 13 -- Senator John F. Kennedy coined today a word for the lexicon of atomic science -- "fall-in."
"IT'S the challenge," says O. (for Oscar) Roy Chalk of his ventures into the public transit business. "I don't need the money, but I like to meet a challenge."
BOSTON, April 13 -- Annis A. Vautier, who went to jail rather than pay a nonresident income tax to Massachusetts, will be released on bail tomorrow.
ALBANY, April 13 -- Legislation setting up a new Department of Real Estate in New York City has been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller. It will replace the scandal-ridden Bureau of Real Estate.

The General Electric Company, in the first quarter of this year, had the second highest sales and earnings for any similar three months on record. Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman, said the results reflected the recovery begun in the latter half of 1958.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- More than 20,000 enlisted men are serving their country as waiters, chauffeurs, yardmen, houseboys and "servants" to officers, the Defense Department reported today.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, April 13 (AP) -- A jurisdictional labor dispute tied up construction work today at the Atomic Energy Commission's national reactor testing station in eastern Idaho.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- San Franciscans developed a severe case of pennant fever today. They hailed the Giants as 1959 world champions even before the former Polo Grounders had played their first home game of the National League baseball schedule.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 14 (AP) -- Communist China announced today that its first five-year plan, for 1953-57, had been overfulfilled.
VANCOUVER, B. C., April 13 -- Control of the Sons of Freedom Doukhobors, a Russian pacifist sect in British Columbia, has been taken over by the sect's women.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Moscow's reaction to a new Western plan for a phased ban on test nuclear explosions is expected by diplomats here to indicate whether the Soviet Union is really interested in solving East-West differences.
HOLLYWOOD could have learned a lesson from Broadway during the telecast of the Tony awards, which ended early yesterday over Channel 2.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Treasury bill rate rose again this week and reached a point slightly higher than the 3 per cent current Federal reserve discount rate, the treasury disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Clifford P. Case urged today that the New Jersey Constitution be amended to permit a tax on the income of New Yorkers working in the state.
With regard to your editorial of April 3 "Sugar and the Revolution":

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 13 -- Police Chief Daniel Beauvoir admitted today that a hearse containing the body of Clement Jumelle, a former Presidential candidate, had been diverted to St. Marc to avert possible disorders at a funeral here.

It is no use ticking off the recent cry for secession of New York City from the state as a foolish notion. The fact is that from time to time over the past century serious-minded people have responded to the badgering of the city by the State Legislature in pretty much the same way.
Former President Hoover sought without success to persuade The Associated Press on the eve of the 1933 bank holiday to suppress news that he feared might alarm the public.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP) -- Detroit Steel Corporation cleared $2,550,000, or 83 cents a share in the first quarter of this year compared with a net loss of $303,678 in the 1958 period, Max Zivian, President, told the annual meeting today.

COTONOU, Dahomey, April 12 -- The political situation in this new republic of the French Overseas Community appears to be developing in favor of a four-state association dominated by Felix Houphouet-Boigny's African Democratic Rally.
Alonzo Johnson, 187 1/2 pounds, of Pittsburgh, gained a split decision over Billy Hunter, 192, of Detroit, in the feature ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
