Following is the text of a letter sent to the twelve major steel producers yesterday by David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America:
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 13 -- The Western world's first all-weather fighter-bomber, the Republic F-105D, will be delivered to Air Force units in Europe next spring, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Administration's hopes of achieving a balanced budget are perking up.
WASHINGTON April 13 -- President Eisenhower asserted tonight that the price of political extravagance was increased taxes.

I am astonished and distressed to see that the sponsors of the Loyalty Day parade and the City Fathers seem to think that they arouse patriotic fervor by disrupting business and inconveniencing the public. Certainly a parade through the business district of Fifth Avenue on a weekday must cause the city to lose a large amount in sales taxes and also incur unnecessary expenses.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon proposed last night that the International Court of Justice be made the arbiter of disputes arising under future East-West agreements.

Leaders in retailing and marketing gathered at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel yesterday to honor Emile Bernheim, Belgian merchant, for advancing the cause of retailing throughout the world and for furthering international cooperation.
Because of a dispute with his landlord, Harry Belafonte will not be visited on Friday evening by Edward R. Murrow's "Person to Person" television program.
GENEVA, April 13 -- The United States proposed today a step-by-step approach to a controlled ban on all testing of nuclear weapons.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 13 -- The European Atomic Energy Community invited proposals today for nuclear power plants under the agency's joint program with the United States.
Safety and traffic experts, engineers, police officers, homemakers, and industrialists, about 2,500 in all, assembled at the Statler-Hilton Hotel yesterday to discuss safety.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- Israel has been left off the invitation list for a celebration Wednesday of Africa Freedom Day.
BUFFALO, N. Y., April 13 (AP) -- First-quarter earnings of Twin Coach Company were more than $100,000 above the 1958 figure, stockholders were told at the annual meeting today.

ROME, April 13 (AP) -- The commander of the United Nations Emergency Force said today that those trying to keep the peace for the world organization often were treated as enemies by opposing military men.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman said today that newsmen were "sponging on Uncle Sam" when they used typewriters, desks and chairs supplied by the Government for the Congressional press galleries.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The twenty - fifth anniversary of Talking Books for the Blind was celebrated today at the Library of Congress.
For the occasion of the Spoleto Festival Ball last night the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria was transformed into an eighteenth-century theatre.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -The May wheat futures contract, which has attracted considerable attention recently both inside and outside the market, led a general and steep decline today on the Board of Trade.

SO deep are baseball's fascinations that events of historic significance and warmth can occasionally be found lurking in the emotionless statistics of a box score. One such discovery was made by a Washington researcher, L. Robert Davids, for The Sporting News and even at this late date it is a trifle startling.

Chemical Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that its assets and value per share were the greatest for any quarter in its twentyone years of operation. The big mutual fund showed March 31 assets of $214,908,581, equal to $10.39 a share on the 20,675,632 shares outstanding.

Wall Street seemed to emerge from the shadow of warnings yesterday into the sunlight of renewed optimism. Under the leadership of rails, steels, drugs, electronics, business machines and building materials, it mounted toward its historic highs.
The "Voice of Firestone," a thirty - year - old concert series that is said to be the oldest network program on the air, will be discontinued after June 1.

BONN, Germany, April 14 -Dr. Ludwig Erhard refused today to answer the direct question whether he wanted to be West Germany's next Chancellor. But he discussed the future like a man who felt sure that he had the job in the bag.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 14 -The seven-year-old project for harnessing the Volta River has come to life again.
BONN, April 14 (Reuters) -One of Chancellor Adenauer's party lawyers rejected today an interpretation of the West German Constitution that gives wide power over foreign policy to the President.
BERLIN, April 10 -- The East German Government has granted considerable wage increases in the vital mining and chemical industries and several categories of light industry.

LONDON, April 14 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Premier Michel Debre emphasized today the success of their two-day conference on the issues facing Britain and France in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- O. Roy Chalk, who is bidding for New York's transit system, is seeking his second fare concession since taking over Washington's bus and trolley car operations thirty-two months ago.
The Madison Avenue Sports Car Driving and Chowder Society has outgrown its name. No longer is this monthly gathering at Sardi's a closed sports car event. Everybody has got into the act.

The city has raised its estimates of general fund revenues by $12,500,000 for the fifteen months ending June 30, 1960. But reduced forecasts for some tax yields will cut this potential windfall to $1,700,000.

JERSEY CITY, April 14 -Hudson County Judge Furman W. Reeves directed a verdict of acquittal in the trial of Arthur Hoffman, former Jersey City Medical Center administrator, who was under indictment on a charge of misconduct in office.

HONG KONG, April 14 -- The Panchen Lama of Tibet was given an imposing welcome on his arrival in Peiping today. He joined with Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, in denouncing the Tibetan rebellion.

The president of the New York Teachers Guild asserted yesterday that the work stoppage scheduled for tomorrow would force the city to close between one-third and one-half of the more than 800 public schools.

THE New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy, an organization devoted to theatre experimentation, concluded its third season of matinees yesterday at the Theatre de Lys with a double bill of plays.
An industrial chemical will get a medical tryout here soon on patients with advanced cancer of the prostate gland.
NEWMARKET, England, April 14 (AP) -- Pindari, a colt owned by Queen Elizabeth, won the Craven Stakes for 3-year-olds today. The favored United States entry, Hieroglyph, finished fourth.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies were 16.4 per cent higher in March than a year earlier, according to a survey just completed by The New York Times. This represented the best month-to-month percentage gain since March, 1951, when sales rose 19 per cent.
NAIROBI, April 14 (Reuters) -- The Mau Mau terrorist organization was mainly restricted to Kenya's Kikuyu tribe and pledged to drive the whites out of this colony.
GENEVA, April 14 -- The Big Three agreed today on how the proposed treaty on a suspension of nuclear weapon tests can be amended.
LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) -- The International Transport Workers Federation adopted a new plan today to fight shipowners using "flags of convenience" to avoid high wages.
ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Rockefeller gave New York City an estimated $127,000,000 worth of new taxing power today to help balance the city's record budget.
LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) -- Britain's trade balance took a slight turn for the worse last month from its position in February, a Board of Trade announcement disclosed today.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 (AP) -- A crowd of 61,552 -- the largest in history for a single night game in the National League -- saw the Los Angeles Dodgers drop a 6-2 decision in their home opener with the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

References have now appeared in the American press to the sad and dramatic events in Tibet under such terms as "Second Hungary," "Mao's Hungary," "Asian Hungary." Though there are superficial similarities in the recent tragedies of Tibet and of Hungary, I believe that the emphasis is misleading.

Eight automobile dealer associations pleaded no contest yesterday to indictments charging a conspiracy to fix prices in the sale of new cars. They then were fined a total of $86,500 by Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy.
Banton L. Wyckoff pleaded not guilty yesterday in Special Sessions Court to charges of permitting unsafe and unsanitary conditions in three tenements he managed.
ALBANY, April 14 -- A new $100,000 state agency designed to help localities deal with their governmental problems was established today.
CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds used home-run power tonight to defeat Pittsburgh, 3 -- 2, behind the seven-hit pitching of Bob Purkey, a right-hander.
BALTIMORE, April 14 -- The Yankees attended to another 1959 baseball opener today and this one they really launched in the grand manner.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Tom Yawkey and Bucky Harris of the Red Sox received invitations today to discuss the team's have been charged with racial employment policies with the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination.

Operators of ships in the North Atlantic are agreed informally on a need for stricter passenger-ship adherence to established shipping routes. They want these routes used regularly by passenger ships only.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 14 (Reuters) -- Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the United States Federal Maritime Board, said that today he was pleased to hear about plans for replacing the Cunard liners Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Two companies have been awarded contracts for building small, experimental thermoelectric generators, which produce electric power by heating dissimilar metallic substances.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Senators Jacob K. Javits of New York and John Sherman Cooper of Kentucky said today they were co-sponsoring the Kennedy labor bill as "a wholesome and substantial contribution to the law at this time."
Governor Rockefeller reported last night that there were still 562,000 persons unemployed in the state.

The long attempt to settle the legal controversy over ownership of General Aniline and Film Corporation has not yet resulted in proposals "sufficiently concrete or satisfactory" for submission to the Attorney General. Stockholders were so informed at the annual meeting yesterday by Dallas S. Townsend, Director of the Office of Alien Property, and Assistant Attorney General.
G. Russell Clark, State Superintendent of Banks, said yesterday that a new effort would be made next year to obtain an over-all settlement of the New York branch banking and holding company problems.
BERLIN, April 14 -- Soviet jet fighters have buzzed an unarmed United States Air Force transport over Germany for the second time, it was revealed today.
Major steel producers indicated yesterday that a wage freeze in steel would be accompanied by a price freeze.
" Live, creative, non-violent" television programs are the "best commercial environment" for advertisers, according to a study made public yesterday by Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc.
Another record in sales was achieved last year by the country's department and specialty stores, but profits after taxes fell slightly.
A member of the Transit Authority conceded yesterday that a sharp fare increase would be necessary if the agency was required to make a 6 1/2 per cent profit.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- The Soviet Union's scientists were told today that mere possession of a doctor's degree would no longer guarantee a lifetime of luxury in the nation's top salary brackets.
Refined copper shipments to fabricators last month were the largest for any month since last November, the Copper Institute reported yesterday.
The City Council passed a bill yesterday excluding tenements slated for demolition from the two-year-old law requiring central heating and hot water in multiple dwellings.
Stockholders of the Marquardt Aircraft Company will be asked at the annual meeting May 5 to approve an increase in authorized shares from 1,000,000 to 2,000,000.
The Central Power and Light Company yesterday raised $11,000,000 on thirty-year, first mortgage bonds at a net borrowing cost of about 4.65 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The nation's money supply took a sharp upward spurt in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 14 (AP) -- Neal Marcus, a 17-yearold junior star from Tampa, Fla., upset the defending champion, Barry MacKay, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, today in the opening round of the twenty-fifth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

An important and far-reaching proposal for realizing the guiding ideal of both the United States and the United Nations was made by Vice President Nixon in his speech before the Academy of Political Science.

MADRAS, India, April 14 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said here today that the shooting down Friday of an unarmed Indian Canberra bomber by Pakistani jet fighters has "almost no parallel in the world."
A GROUP of talented artists did honor to the late George Gershwin in an outstanding musical program over WNTA-TV (Channel 13) from 11 o'clock Monday night until 12:30 A. M. yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- Israel has complained to Ghana and Liberia about her exclusion from the Africa Freedom Day celebration tomorrow, diplomatic sources said today. The objections were made in the African capitals but became known today to diplomats at the United Nations.
Spokesmen for commercial printers, outdoor advertisers and some builders said yesterday that parts of the city's proposed new zoning resolution would hurt their business.

CHATHAM TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 14 -- Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight boxing champion of the world, admitted today that he was among those who were surprised when Brian London of England was named as his opponent for his next title fight, on May 1.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission has turned down requests that it begin action to increase cheese imports.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Gov. Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina told Senators today he had been shocked last October by evidence of antiCatholic feeling in Dayton, Ohio.
The Port of New York Authority said yesterday it was erecting and leasing a commercial building at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey to produce revenue.
Union officials met briefly here yesterday with representatives of the United States Rubber Company in an effort to end the strike that has closed company plants in eleven states since last Friday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 14 -- The racial policy now being followed by the Government of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is described as "panic partnership" by those who are skeptical of the ruling United Federal party's sudden conversion to liberalism.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14 -- The Government took another step today toward the ultimate separation of races, which is the goal of the apartheid policy.

Broadway has been promised a song-and-dance variation of "Mrs. 'Arris Goes to Paris," which has been on the bestseller list for seventeen weeks. The job of turning Paul Gallico's popular 156-page book into a musical will bring together Howard Teichmann (adapter), Howard Dietz (lyrics) and Arthur Schwartz (melodies).
Active trading returned in the market for new corporate issues yesterday, as new, lower price levels were set for AArated utility bonds.

TORONTO, April 14 (UPI) -- Dick Duff scored at 10:06 of a sudden-death overtime period tonight, enabling the Toronto Maple Leafs to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 2. The triumph cut the Canadiens' margin to two games to one in the Stanley Cup play-off finals.

George Fry Associates, management consultant, leased 6,000 square feet in the new Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue at Forty-seventh Street, and will move about May 1, 1960, from 100 Park Avenue. The new office will be almost double the size of the present one.

THE most disappointed member of last night's audience at the Carnegie Recital Hall program presented by the Composers Group of New York was possibly Irwin Swack, who had come in from Zanesville, Ohio, to hear his Quintet for Woodwinds in its premiere.
Harry Horwitz, one of the most active realty operators along Second and Third Avenues, has purchased two more properties on Third Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- People apparently are having less trouble this year filling out income-tax returns, Federal revenue agents said today on the eve of the filing deadline.

CHICAGO, April 14 (UPI) -Luis Aparacio drove in both runs with a fifth-inning single today to lead the unbeaten Chicago White Sox to their fourth straight victory, a 2-0 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics. The Chicago home-opener was marked by tricks and treats from the new owner, Bill Veeck.

Fidel Castro arrives in Washington today on an eleven-day visit to the United States that holds great possibilities for good or ill. In some ways this is the most important test he has yet faced. Therefore, for him, for Cuba and for the important issue of Cuban-American relations this trip may prove crucial.

Directors of the BristolMyers Company increased the dividend yesterday and proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock. The company makes proprietary drugs, toiletries, penicillin and streptomycin, fiber glass, cosmetics and plastic products.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- Probably nowhere in the world are anniversaries as popular as in the Soviet Union. And probably nowhere in the world will today's two-hundredth anniversary of the death of the composer George Frederick Handel receive more widespread publicity.

The Fiftieth Anniversary Fund of Connecticut College at New London will receive the proceeds of a theatre party at next Tuesday's performance of "A Party with Betty Comden and Adolph Green," which will begin a return engagement at the Golden Theatre on Thursday.

Prima ballerina Galina Ulanova and the members of the Bolshoi Theatre ballet company went through a strenuous allday rehearsal yesterday in preparation for their opening performance of "Romeo and Juliet" tomorrow night.
The New York School of Social Work will become a member of the Columbia University Corporation July 1.

The Superintendent of Schools is tardy in reminding New York City's public school teachers that a strike, even a one-day work stoppage, to demonstrate salary dissatisfaction, would be illegal. But in doing so at all Dr. John J. Theobald has the distinction of being the first city official in memory to have the courage to say that he would abide by and invoke the state law when a strike of governmental employes was threatening.

YONKERS, April 14 -- Some early arrivals at Yonkers Raceway tonight wondered what it all was about when at 6 o'clock, two and a half hours before post time, five trotters were seen engaging in brisk competition.
Massachusetts sold $60,161,000 of various purpose general obligation bonds, due from 1960 to 2009, yesterday to a syndicate managed jointly by seven commercial and investment banks.
Mayor Wagner pressed a demand on the City Council yesterday for swift passage of legislation to pave the way for revising the City Charter.
Twenty Revenue Service offices will be open in the metropolitan area today to assist taxpayers in making out Federal returns. The deadline for filing is midnight tonight.

It is, to be sure, the middle of April. And it is also, to be sure, about the time one should really be doing something about the garden. Just as the neighbors are doing. They are cleaning last autumn's leaves from their hedges, scratching away dead grass from obviously hopeless patches in their lawns and putting grass seed on those patches from shining green cardboard boxes filled with costly seed.

TO judge by "The Smokeweaver's Daughter," which opened at the Fourth Street Theatre last evening, Thomas Barbour has a praiseworthy attitude toward the profession of playwriting. He does not take it seriously.
ROME, April 14 (AP) -- L'Osservatore Romano accused Hungary's Communist regime today of trying to convert Roman Catholic student priests into a "sort of ecclesiastical police."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The Soviet Union urged today that the United Nations again attempt to frame a formal definition of "aggression" -- a subject that has engaged the world organization and the League of Nations since 1933.

ALBANY, April 14 (AP) -The number of persons on home relief in the state has jumped nearly 70 per cent from the precession level of February, 1957, the State Social Welfare Department said today, and further increases are expected.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 14 -- Two highranking Israeli Army officers were relieved of their posts today as a result of mobilization orders issued April 1.
A subcommittee on the resetting of advertisements was appointed yesterday in an attempt to solve a key problem in the dispute between ten New York newspapers and their union printers.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- Too much Ernie Banks spoiled the San Francisco Giants' home opener of 1959 today before a stadium-full of alternately cheering and groaning baseball customers.

LONDON, April 14 -- The Timken Roller Bearing Company of Canton, Ohio, announced here today that it would offer more than 10,000,000 ($28,000,000) for the minority interest in its subsidiary here, British Timken.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -The "What's My Line?" television panel members were unable to guess Dana Latham's occupation when he appeared before them several Sundays ago. Mr. Latham is the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

CLEVELAND, April 14 (UPI) -- The unbeaten Cleveland Indians backed Herb Score's fivehit pitching with four home runs, two by Woody Held, and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8 -- 1, today before a home openingday crowd of 33,098.
Efforts to settle the fifteenday-old strike of 5,000 Pennsylvania blousemakers broke down here last night.

MILWAUKEE, April 14 (UPI) -- Little Johnny O'Brien, bench strength picked up in a recent trade, singled home Hank Aaron from third base in the tenth inning as the Milwaukee Braves gained their sixth home-opener victory in seven tries, 4-3 over the Philadelphia Phillies today.
A Federal marshal seized last night a print of the Charlie Chaplin film, "Modern Times," in the projection booth of the Inwood Theatre in Forest Hills, Queens.

A HUNDRED years ago, on the centennial of Handel's death, there was a performance of "Messiah" in London's Crystal Palace that employed a chorus of 3,000. Last night at Carnegie Hall the bicentennial of the master's death was commemorated with a "Messiah" that used a modest chorus and orchestra and that conformed to the spirit of the composer's time.
Trading continued active yesterday on most New York Commodity Exchanges. Lead registered the second largest volume of the year, and the world sugar months had the third most active day.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 14 -A fuzzy photograph of a tangled coil of protein from the muscle of a sperm whale may provide much of the theoretical basis for medicine of the future.
Cardinal Spellman will become a Franciscan friar tomorrow "by adoption."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Following are the texts of the remarks by President Eisenhower and former President Herbert Hoover at the dedication ceremony this morning of the Robert A. Taft Memorial Bell Tower:
The Davega Stores Corporation, which operates a chain of stores dealing in household appliances and sporting goods, is going into the food supermarket business.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals stayed today an order by Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, banning fish traps in Alaskan waters.
THREE of America's foremost fashion designers bit the hand that fed them yesterday.

HAVANA, April 14 -- Nine persons, including a former councilman of the municipality of Regla across the bay from Havana, have been arrested on a charge of conspiring against the revolutionary Government. The group was arrested in a meeting in a house in Regla.
NEWARK, April 14 -- The Public Utility Commission took steps today for a show down with the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

Philip Morris, Inc., increased sales by 6 per cent in the first quarter to $105,445,063 from $99,383,411 a year ago, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Richmond, Va., yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- A suit to compel Rock Hudson, actor, to comply with a 1955 contract calling for his appearance in five motion pictures during a seven-year period was filed today in Superior Court.

Mayor Wagner's annual message to the City Council, presenting his detailed fifth yearly report, for 1958, is a combination of pride in some progress attained toward better government, political attack on the state administration and the modest admission that a Mayor's work is never done in the sense of being completed.
Modern music in several aspects held sway last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -A maximum security detail has been assigned to Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba during his stay in the capital, officials said today.
Seats are still available for the theatre party to be held at next Tuesday's performance of "Sweet Bird of Youth," at the Martin Beck Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Mechanical bugs today wrecked an attempt to fire an Atlas intercontinental missile at Cape Canaveral, Fla. The missile was destroyed in the air fifteen seconds after it was launched.
BONN, Germany, April 14 -The West German Government has asked France to stop recruiting German youths into her Foreign Legion.

The Pan Pacific and South East Asia Women's Association will hold its third annual pageant of Asian custom, costume, music, dance and drama in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on the evening of April 24.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 14 (AP) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim said today that Iraq was a country of peace partisans.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 14 -Jomo Kenyatta, leader of the Mau Mau rebellion in 1952, was released from prison today after serving five years of a sevenyear sentence.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- A Florida judge testified today that he had tried to enlist the help of Thurman A. Whiteside in obtaining Miami television Channel 10 for a subsidiary of National Airlines.

JUDGES and justices of the peace in this state appear generally to have taken a new and more interested look at the game laws during the last year or so. The penalties they impose are progressively heavier.
A quiet little girl won a sad victory yesterday -- four clowns failed to make her smile.
Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson yesterday temporarily enjoined the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen from striking the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company.

" Germany and the East-West Crisis: The Decisive Challenge to American Policy," by William S. Schlamm, will be published this season by David McKay. It is an analysis of the Berlin crisis and what the Soviet leaders are seeking and how their aims affect this country.

I have always admired and respected The New York Times for its complete coverage of the news. I recognize that editorial policy must be your own. However, in response to your editorial of March 12 entitled "Oil Import Quotas" I would like to offer the following:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A White House administrative officer told the seventh annual Republican Women's Conference today that the party's failure to win the Negro vote caused "ignominious defeat" last November.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Franz Josef Strauss, Defense Minister of West Germany, arrived here today to review the European military situation and the Berlin crisis.

TWO New York societies whose greatest concerns are wine and gastronomy recently celebrated the new season with feasting. On Monday night, members of Les Amis d'Escoffier tucked their napkins under their chins and dined on an eight-course meal prepared by Manuel Orta, executive chef of the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 14 --Many who supported him -- and some who opposed him -- gathered on spring-green Capitol Hill today to pay tribute to a blunt, pragmatic, flat-voiced son of the Midwest who fought for the truth as he saw it and gave short shrift to those who begged to differ.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's annual address to the City Council, delivered in person yesterday as he transmitted his report for 1958:
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it was preparing to order the removal from the market of seventeen coal-tar colors, which are used principally in lipstick.

Several hundred technicians and workmen bustled about the huge Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx yesterday. Today the big building should be packed with some 12,000 stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Whale Oil Company, New York, asked today for emergency relief under the oil import program to enable it to unload 240,000 barrels of residual fuel oil due in New York on two tankers this week.

The Electric Storage Battery Company of Philadelphia and Reeves Bros., Inc., of this city, textile concern, have formed a jointly owned company to develop and possibly eventually to manufacture microporous plastic materials for clothing and industrial uses.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 14 -- The Air Force plans to equip seventy B-52 bombers with a new turbo-fan engine that should increase the plane's range 400 to 500 miles.
CALVERTON, L. I., April 14 -- The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation's newest airplane, looking like a throwback from today's sleek jets to World War I fighters, was demonstrated here today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -The State Department announced today that Acting Secretary Christian A. Herter would lead the United States delegation to the Western foreign ministers' meeting in Paris April 29.

FIFTEEN years ago today an emaciated and exhausted young American second lieutenant was worrying as usual about his communications platoon somewhere in the jungles of northern Burma. He was there with the 3,000 other members of the 5307th Composite Unit (Provisional). That ineptly named Long Range Penetration group consisted of three battalions, all of them volunteers, all of them supposedly trained in jungle warfare.

One hundred and forty-five city properties, including the old Washington Market bounded by West, Vesey, Washington and Fulton Streets, will be offered at an auction sale to be held by Joseph P. Day, Inc., in the Biltmore Hotel tomorrow morning.

Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver called yesterday upon owners of bowling alleys in Brooklyn to cooperate in his inquiry into threatened mobster control of the $10,000,000-a-year industry in the borough.

Price increases were posted yesterday, effective at once, for rayon staple produced by American Enka Corporation and Courtaulds Alabama, Inc. The action followed similar rises announced over the last few weeks by other manufacturers.
WARSAW, April 14 -- Polish officialdom has discreetly withdrawn from its attempt to control the publication abroad of books by Polish writers.
Rear Admiral George J. Dufek relinquished his post yesterday as commander of United States Naval Support Forces, Antarctica.
A gamp, the Long Island Rail Road found out this week, is what Scots sometimes call an umbrella.

LISBON, Portugal, April 14 -- The Portuguese Corporative Chamber has approved a new system of Presidential election under which the Chief of State, hitherto elected by direct suffrage, will be chosen by an electoral college.
The continuing debate on foreign military aid, now resumed after the Congressional recess, has become a recurring phenomenon of each legislative session.

The political chief of the merged labor federation in this state charged yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was trying to "out-Nixon Nixon" in an attempt to win the Republican Presidential nomination.

COATESVILLE, Pa., April 14 (AP) -- The Lukens Steel Company today reported a profit of $1,008,394 for the first three months of 1959. This was about 30 per cent less than that in the similar 1958 period when profits totalled $1,470,230.

LONDON, April 14 -- "Dark Halo," a first play by Sylvia Leigh, a New York actress, opened at the Arts Theatre here tonight. It was welcomed by most of the newspaper critics, although not enthusiastically.
DESPITE the prophets of gloom and doom, children in this country today can look forward to longer, richer and healthier lives.

Fifty-two members of the Parent-Teachers Association of Public School 193 in Whitestone, Queens, visited the headquarters of the Soviet mission to the United Nations last night for a lecture on education in Soviet schools.

King Hussein of Jordan arrived here yesterday and pledged himself to aid his people in "the pursuit of happiness" if the United States continued to help Jordan, "not as charity, but as investment in the future of a free and determined people."
Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, forecast failure last night for Gamal Abdel Nasser's attempt to establish "centralized domination" of the Middle East.
Most companies whose stocks are traded on the Big Board shudder at the possibility of delisting, but Johnson Johnson may, seek it.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -A few prime steers weighing 1,239 pounds brought $37.00 here, equal to the highest price paid since the $37.75 top on April 9 last year. The market was steady to mostly strong but some average good to low choice steers were 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds higher.

The apartment house for twenty-four families at 1239 Simpson Street in the Bronx was purchased by clients of Elihu A. Novick, lawyer. The buyers took title and then resold the property to the Ace Hardware Company, which was represented by Morris Karp. The property is 50 by 100 feet and is assessed $45,000.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Defense Department abandoned plans today to attempt to recover an instrument capsule from the orbiting Discoverer II satellite.
The strength of this nation's enemies rather than budgetary economy should dictate the size of United States military preparations, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington said here last night.

Reflecting the sharp recovery in steel operations, the net income of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries rose more than $14,000,000 in the first quarter and sales climbed $91,800,000 above the 1958 levels.
TEZPUR, India, April 14 -This quiet corner of northeastern India has a long memory for earthquakes, tiger shoots and the price of tea.

TOKYO, April 14 -- Relatives who went to welcome Japanese fishermen returning from captivity in Communist China today were kept waiting while the men attended a Leftist rally in their honor, according to Tokyo newspaper accounts.

PARIS, April 14 -- The war now being fought by France in Algeria is not, as Clausewitz would have had it, a continuation of policy by other means but a substitute for policy. After four and a half years this war still devours French energies and ravages the Algerian countryside for the simple reason that nobody has devised a satisfactory formula for ending it.
AMERICANA continues to flood New York furniture and accessory shops. One of the newest proponents is Country Imports at 1143 First Avenue, near Sixty-third Street.

Students from New York City who apply for admission to the nation's colleges have two strikes on them before they start, according to Dr. Frank H. Bowles, Director of the College Entrance Examination Board.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Americans, when in Latin America, should "Go Slow."
" If I had to rate them again, I'd still put the big horse on top. But it would be difficult to split the other two."

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 14 -- The Haitian Chamber of Deputies has decided against having any contact with Deputy Franck Seraphin, an Opposition member, until the Supreme Court rules on a charge of infamous conduct against him.

CORTLAND, N. Y., April 14 -- Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller played a teacher's role today to about 1,000 children, speaking on closed-circuit television. The topic of the lesson was the family life of the Governor.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Two major employer organizations today opposed Congressional proposals that they contend would federalize and possibly wreck the present Federal -state unemployment insurance system.

The New York State censor did not ban a single film in the year ending March, 1959. The previous year four films were banned by the censor board, officially known as the Division of Motion Pictures of the New York State Board of Education.

Norman P. Mason, the nation's housing administrator, said last night that the time had not yet come for President Eisenhower to appoint a committee to find a way of ending racial discrimination in all Federally aided housing.
The way has been opened for a deep cut in the operations of the Waterfront Commission and a saving of about one-third of its annual expenditures.

Tom Leder, a 6-foot 6-inch sophomore pitcher, scattered five hits as Manhattan College's baseball team blanked Wagner College, 5 to 0, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium in the Bronx yesterday.
Federal and interstate responsibility in motor - vehicle traffic control was emphasized yesterday by speakers at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council.

LONDON, April 14 -- A patient in a London hospital who was considered to be intersexual has been classified as a "human mosaic." In appearance he is an undeveloped male, but geneticists have found that his body cells are a mixture of male and female characters.
ALPHA TWO, Arctic Ocean, April 15 (AP) -- Ice Skate, a cold-weather scientific mission with strong military overtones was begun yesterday on this tiny block of ice in the Arctic.

LONDON, April 15 -- Britain's leaders, past and present, paid warm tribute today to John Foster Dulles' contributions to Western leadership. They expressed regret at his resignation at a critical juncture in Western affairs.
The controversial Riverside-Amsterdam slum clearance project ran into new difficulty yesterday.
BOB HOPE, the indefatigable quipper of the airwaves, guided an amusing show through a diverting sixty minutes on Channel 4 last night.

Secession by New York City from the state is just a lot of silly talk to John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association. At City Hall yesterday he employed histrionics, and costume to argue his point.

The celebration of "Africa Freedom Day" in New York, in Africa and pretty well everywhere in the world yesterday, calls attention again to one of the outstanding phenomena of the contemporary world. This is the sudden, thrilling, agonizing upheaval of the African races after countless centuries of primitiveness, subjection and isolation from the civilized world.

The Soviet Government has reprimanded Igor Moiseyev, the dance troupe director, for having given Soviet artists too glowing an account of life and art in the United States, according to persons recently arrived from Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Railroad labor leaders asked state and city officials in the New York area today to prevail upon the commuter railroads "to do an about-face and attempt to build up their passenger services instead of destroying them."
ALBANY, April 15 -- A bill that would have barred transmitting race results from a track until a half-hour after the official results were posted was disapproved today by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, proposed today a Federal program for construction of civil-defense shelters in connection with urban redevelopment.
THIS week-end ought to be the first fairly good one for trout fishermen, if the weather hold.
LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The future King of England benefited from a royal prerogative yesterday, and drew a lively objection from a Cockney schoolboy.
BALTIMORE, April 15 -- As expected, the Yankees are gaining early momentum in the American League flag race. If anyone is to arrest their flight he hasn't yet put in an appearance.

New York harbor craft operators announced yesterday that they had no objection to the construction of a fixed bridge across the mouth of busy Flushing Creek. This was a reversal of their previous position.
OTTAWA, April 15 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway will be opened to shipping on April 25, it was announced today.

A 54-year-old labor leader refused yesterday to testify before a Kings County rackets grand jury investigating complaints that "mobsters" had sought to take over control of the $10,000,000-a-year bowling alley business in the borough.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the abandonment of the Jay Street Connecting Railroad in Brooklyn and its car float and lighterage operations in the harbor.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that the new Eleanor Roosevelt Institute for Cancer Research would be the first institution to which she had permitted the use of her name.

The steel industry rejected last night a union proposal for a freeze on steel prices. The twelve biggest steel companies reiterated their call for a wage freeze but asserted that it would be "completely unlawful" for them to make any joint commitment on prices.

Money continues tighter than at any time since the recession shift to credit ease in the fall of 1957. Pressure on member back reserves, which was concentrated in New York a week ago, has spread throughout the country.

PEIPING, April 15 (Reuters) -- Communist China met its main production goals last year but fell short in its output of raw cotton and cotton textiles, according to official statistics published here today.

The nation's inventories of gasoline increased 979,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the week-end, total supplies were 214,594,000 barrels, compared with 213,615,000 a week earlier and 213,786,000 a year ago.

BAY SHORE, L. I., April 15 -- Norman Thomas told high school students here today that their generation's greatest problem would be "to keep out of war that would mean total annihilation and to obtain peace on terms consistent with freedom."

HONG KONG, April 14 -- The People's Daily of Peiping took exception today to criticisms in India of Chinese Communist actions in Tibet but expressed confidence in continued friendship between India and Communist China.

A manuscript dealing with recollections of the late Lajpat Rai, a leader for freedom for India, during a six-year exile in this country and Japan was presented yesterday to India's Ambassador Mahomed-Ali Currim Chagla.
Cotton futures declined 2 to 17 points yesterday, with the near months the weakest. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The mystery of the where-abouts of Brian London, British heavyweight, was solved yesterday. He's registered under an assumed name at a New York hotel and he has been working out at Cus D'Amato's Gramercy Gymnasium and Health Club, 116 East Fourteenth Street.
The public will be required to "take cover" for ten minutes at 1:30 P. M. tomorrow in "Operation Alert 1959."
The election of George P. Norton and George W. Griffin Jr, as vice presidents of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Rockefeller set up a new commission today and gave it the emergency assignment of reducing unemployment in the state.

Sugar Ray Robinson chose yesterday to defend his world middleweight title in court rather than in the ring against Carmen Basilio. LONDON, April 15 -- The stock market retained its buoyancy today. But net gains, although widespread, were fairly modest. Yesterday's tone on Wall Street plus some good dividend statements brought an expansion of early business.

A criminal lawyer won a delicate point of law yesterday. The Court of Special Sessions found his client not guilty of violating the Sullivan Law although a pistol had been found in the defendant's car and he had admitted knowing it was there.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today the "poor man's investment portfolio" -- various forms of social insurance -- would increase substantially during the next decade.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- After withstanding another surge of broad selling, the grains futures market made a moderate and fairly general recovery in late dealings today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee ended, today its investigation of William Bufalino's teamster local in Detroit. It called the local an ally of racketeers and "a leech preying upon working men and women."
Lord Kilmuir, Lord Chancellor of England, and his wife, Lady Kulmuir, arrived by air yesterday for a five-day visit to the United States. He said he planned to call on Chief Justice Earl Warren.

King Hussein of Jordan lunched at the Harvard Club and visited the United Nations yesterday, his second day in New York.
