John Foster Dulles has valiantly served the people of this country and of the free world since he became Secretary of State in January, 1953, and for a long time before that. He has not spared himself. His travels, mostly by air, have run into the hundreds of thousands of miles. The strain of his journeys, the labors of his long days and sleepless nights may have hastened the breakdown of his health.

BOSTON, April 15 (AP) -- Jerry Casale made his big-league starting debut in stirring fashion today, hitting a long three-run homer in addition to pitching the Boston Red Sox to a 7-3 triumph over the Washington Senators.

I agree emphatically with the recommendation that we exchange newsmen with China, as stated in a letter to you published April 2 and signed by Henry Cabot et al. However, the sticker is not our issuing passports to newsmen. This has been done for a limited number. The Chinese refuse to give visas to these journalists because we won't agree to admit their newsmen without the scrutiny required by the Walter-McCarran Act.
Textbook publishers were asked yesterday by the city to include non-whites in their illustrations of the American scene.
A private eye will displace New York's Finest on American Broadcasting Company television next season.

Trading in commodity futures again was active on the New York exchanges yesterday. The copper volume of 1,180 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot) was the largest since trading began in 1933. The previous high was 1,082 lots on March 18. Potato volume of 1,659 car lots (50,000 pounds to a lot) was the largest of the year.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 15 (AP) -- Skepticism concerning the Floyd Patterson-Brian London meeting for the world heavyweight championship here May 1 was apparent today among the men in the street.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Fifty-one Methodist Bishops met today with Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts, a Roman Catholic and a contender for the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.
LONDON, April 15 -- Sir Humphrey Trevelyan, British Ambassador to Iraq, arrived tonight for consultations with Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd on the rapidly deteriorating situation in Iraq.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -The historic assessment of John Foster Dulles, sixty-ninth Secretary of State of the United States, started today and will probably continue as long as this turbulent era of American history is studied.
YONKERS, April 15 -This was supposed to have been the night when an 8-8 daily double was going to click for the first time in nearly six years at Yonkers Raceway.

THE early morning sun gave a glow to the rich, brown coat of First Landing as he paused in the walking ring outside his Belmont Park barn yesterday to pose for a photographer. The rangy son of Turn-to and Hilldene perked up his ears, coyly curled a hind leg, stared soulfully into the lens with his soft, brown eyes and demonstrated no more camera shyness than Jayne Mansfield.
The P. Lorillard Company, makers of Kent, Old Gold and Newport cigarettes, achieved record high sales and earnings in the first three months of this year, according to the report issued yesterday.
A metallic knocking and banging has been awakening a Rye, N. Y., family at 5 o'clock every morning for the past ten days.

HAVANA, April 15 -- Premier Castro said as he left for Washington that his trip was a "truth operation" to tell the United States people about "revolutionary justice" and to refute adverse propaganda against the Cuban Revolutionary Government.

Senator John L. McClellan warned last night that if James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, succeeded in establishing a transportation empire, the nation's economy would be at his mercy.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today legislation to create a twenty-four - member Congressional committee to act as liaison with the Canadian Parliament.
KONA, Ky., April 15 -- Fire and an explosion wrecked a home in this strikebound eastern Kentucky coal area today and destroyed a coal loading ramp. There were no injuries.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived here tonight to begin an eleven-day unofficial visit to the United States.
Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk of 16 Erwin Park Road, Montclair, N. J., will give a tea at her home Monday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 8:

New York City is happy to have in its midst another distinguished visitor who in spite of his young years has won the respect of the world for his courage, his brains and his personality. He is King Hussein of Jordan, who has been able to stand up successfully against the two most formidable forces threatening him and his country -- Nasserism and communism.
Smith, Barney Co and associates today are offering $22,000,000 of Philco Corporation 4 1/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 1984, at par and accrued interest.

HOUSTON, April 15 (AP) -- Neal Marcus, the surprising Rice Institute freshman, gained the quarter-finals of the River Oaks tennis tournament today by defeating Armando Ferla, Sao Paulo, Brazil, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses has informed the New York Shakespeare Festival that unless it abandons its policy of free admissions it will no longer be permitted to operate in Central Park.
The Inwood Art Theatre in Forest Hills, Queens, showed three Charlie Chaplin short films and three W. C. Fields shorts last night instead of Mr. Chaplin's full-length feature, "Modern Times."
BOSTON, April 15 -- Annis A. Vautier, who still owes his 1956 non-resident state income taxes to Massachusetts, was released today from jail.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A medical bulletin reported this afternoon that the physical condition of John Foster Dulles was unchanged from yesterday and that his spirits were good.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union reported last night that it had signed individual settlements with twelve strikebound blouse contracting shops in the Bethlehem-Allentown-Easton district of Pennsylvania.
GENEVA, April 15 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that it would insist that the three-power conference here keep to its objective of a total ban on nuclear weapon testing.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -Vice Admiral John T. Hayward, Chief of Navy Research and Development, told Congress today the national space program was in danger of becoming bogged down in organizational confusion.
The Bolshoi Theatre ballet company will open its tour of the United States tonight with its presentation of "Romeo and Juliet" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

IN the foreword to his new volume, "The James Beard Cookbook," the author declares that it is designed to help two sorts of people: those who are beginning to cook and say they do not know how to boil water and those who have tried to cook but without great success.
The "big three" of the automotive industry retained their top spots as the largest national advertisers in newspapers during recession-ridden 1958, but all slashed expenditures.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) -- The Administration opposed today a bill to provide health and medical benefits to Federal employes and their dependents.
Queens set about the hopeful task yesterday of making all its mosquitos good ones -- dead ones, that is.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Four Senators, two from New York and two from Pennslyvania, today made public details of their office payrolls.
The election of Joseph W. Mooney as senior vice president of the American Sugar Refining Company and of Edward Tindall as vice president was announced yesterday by William F. Oliver, president.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Kansas City loosed an extra-base bombardment, including Bob Grim's grand slam, and defeated the Chicago White Sox, 10 -- 8, today to snap the White Sox winning streak at four.

BALTIMORE, April 15 -- The record crowd of 61,552 that saw the Dodgers play the Cardinals in the Los Angeles Coliseum last night had baseball men today taking a fresh appraisal on what California holds for them.
A public mass meeting for Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba during his visit here from next Tuesday to Saturday probably will be held at the Polo Grounds Friday, it was indicated yesterday.
The scholarship fund of Mount Holyoke College will benefit from a tour of East Side homes, some of them belonging to well-known interior decorators, on Sunday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Rancor was forgotten today as John Foster Dulles' fiercest enemies of the past joined his admirers in an outpouring of messages of affection and respect that has not been matched here during the Eisenhower years.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 15 -John Foster Dulles resigned today as Secretary of State.

In the April 10 issue of The New York Times you quote the executive secretary of the American Bar Association as stating that only about a dozen members of the American Bar Association have resigned as a result of the recent action taken by the association House of Delegates with respect to the Supreme Court.

Two thugs were captured yesterday in a Brooklyn apartment after a free-for-all. The battle developed when the police, attempting to take the hold-up men by surprise, were misled by a lookout who passed himself off as a member of the household.

ST. LOUIS, April 15 (UPI) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, predicted today a manpower problem in 1965. He said it would be caused by a shortage of men between the ages of 25 and 44, the group traditionally sought by employers.

THE Music in Our Time Series presented two premieres last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. They were Louis Calabro's Piano Sonata and Josef Alexander's "Songs for Eve."
Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, called yesterday for an immediate, cooperative attack on metropolitan area commuting problems.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Federal Reserve Board's index of industrial production capped a series of booming March statistics today with a rise of two points to a record of 147.

EVEN before a needle is threaded, many mistakes are made by home seamstresses, who plan to decorate the windows, the Celanese Corporation of America contends. To avoid costly errors, the following tips on measuring windows are offered by the fiber concern.
The New York Teachers Guild last night called off the work stoppage that was scheduled for today. It urged all teachers here to report for work this morning as usual.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 15 -- Dr. Harlow Shapley, former head of the Harvard Observatory, put forward today a new theory of life on stars beyond the range of the largest telescope.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The House of Representatives passed today a Senate bill to remove the Agriculture Secretary's authority over rural electric loans.

Steels, chemicals, aluminums, electronics and oils gave a strong tone to the stock market yesterday and there were good gains on a broad front. Volume expanded and -- after a little hesitation in mid-afternoon -prices pushed forward to close at or near their highs for the day.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 15 -- The Ghanian Government announced today the signing of a contract with the Kaiser Industries Corporation for the immediate start of preliminary work on the long-projected Volta River dam and hydroelectric plant.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 15 (AP) -- Mesabi Iron Company today filed a $67,500,000 suit in United States District Court against the Republic Steel Corporation and Armco Steel Corporation, charging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
BERLIN, April 15 -- The United States flew a C-130 turboprop transport between the West and Berlin today for the second time at an altitude above the 10,000-foot ceiling set by the Soviet Union.
LONDON, April 15 -- Joseph R. Smallwood, Premier of Newfoundland, left London by air today after a four-day visit.
AT 11 A. M. yesterday, as customers cheerfully rummaged through racks of marked-down clothes, Gunther Jaeckel passed on to new ownership.

American Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had arranged to sell privately $30,1000,000 of 5 per cent notes, due in 1996, and $40,000,000 of subordinated debentures convertible into stock at 335 a share. The company did not identify the new creditors.
Directors of the Liggett and Myers Tobacco Company yesterday raised the dividend on the common stock with the declaration of a quarterly dividend of $1.25, for payment on June 1.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., April 15 (AP) -- Five of the abandoned Weehawken ferryboats may be taking a slow tow to South America.

A sand dredge caught fire in the Narrows early this morning, causing a spectacular display for residents in the Bay Ridge area of Brooklyn. Two crewmen were overcome by smoke in fighting the forty-minute fire.
Sweaters and swimwear are setting new records for sales volume. So far this year sales have topped all previous marks and it now appears that the season's total will set a new high.

The six-story building containing twenty apartments and three stores at 92 Perry Street, corner of Bleecker Street, in Greenwich Village, has been sold by a client of Emanuel Fine, attorney. On a plot of 43 by 70 feet, it was bought for cash over a first mortgage of $90,000. Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., was the broker.
TUNIS, April 15 -- An agreement to continue French technical assistance to Tunisia for eighteen months was signed here today. Provisions were made for renewal.

Henry Denker, author of Time Limit!" will turn producer next season with a play by Sumner Arthur Long called Cradle and All" The work will be tested this summer at Michael Ellis' Bucks County Pa.) Playhouse preparatory to a New York opening in the fall.
Long-term United States Government bonds sold at new lows yesterday amid reports of increased business activity and rumors of a rise in the Federal Reserve discount rate.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- At an age when most boys are studying the mystery of baseball, the story goes, John Foster Dulles decided he would grow up to be Secretary of State.
PARIS, April 15 -- The Government of the newly independent African state of Guinea declared today that its acceptance of arms from Czechoslovakia did not mean it had chosen the East against the West.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mich., April 15 (AP) -- Sale of the D. and C. Stores of Michigan to the H. L. Green Company of New York has been rescinded by mutual agreement, the companies said today in a joint statement. The statement was issued by J. H. Dancer, president of D. and C. Stores, with headquarters at Stockbridge, and Joseph H. Unger, president of H. L. Green Company.

SEOUL, Korea, April 15 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, 84-year-old President of South Korea, declared today he would run for a fourth term next year "to fulfill my lifelong desire" to gain an independent, unified Korea.
City employes who did not get hoped-for pay rises in Mayor Wagner's 1959-60 executive budget of $2,173,133,999 gave the Board of Estimate a pleasant surprise yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors ran into sharp criticism today for banning television coverage of Fidel Castro's appearance before the society next Friday.

The State of New Jersey announced yesterday that it would offer $25,000,000 of water development bonds on May 13. The issue, which was to have been offered on Feb. 16, had been postponed. Maturities, according to original plans, were to have been from 1964 to 1984.

Events tonight: "The Triumph of St. Joan" and "The Medium," City Center, 8; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein conducting, Isaac Stern, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Eva Kovach, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; new music concert, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30; Martina Arroyo, soprano, Mannes College of Music, 8:30.

A REVOLUTION of some proportions is occurring in the field of electric coffee makers. The most recent departure in design is the disappearance of the spout from some models. A second innovation is an electric glass, percolator, introduced by the Silex Company. The third development, immersibility, which made its bow only last year, has become increasingly important.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., April 15 -- The supervisor of Haverstraw notified the town assessors today of the town Council's decision last night to end the $25,000 tax reduction granted the New York Central Railroad last year.

About 6 P. M. yesterday New York University's baseball players weren't so much concerned about gaining their first Metropolitan Conference victory of the season as they were about getting home for dinner.

CAIRO, April 15 (AP) -- A leading Arab oil expert said today that an Arab oil conference beginning here tomorrow would pave the way for a unified oil policy linking Middle Eastern and Caribbean producing countries.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Two judges asked today whether the court-appointed monitors of the Teamsters Union should not have sought contempt action against the union for not complying with their orders.
THE accent this week in the downtown area is on one-man exhibitions. At the Tanager Gallery, 90 East Tenth Street, Morton Lucks shows for the first time in New York after an extended stay in London.

The chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that strikes in the steel industry in future years would be a "great hazard" to each individual, to the industry and to a free society.

LONDON, April 15 -- The British Government affirmed today its belief in the "great value" of its proposal for a Central European zone in which arms and forces would be limited and under inspection by East and West.

PARIS, April 15 -- The decision of Secretary Dulles to resign produced expressions of regret and tributes to his courage, tenacity and lucidity here today, even from Frenchmen who often found themselves at odds with some aspects of his policies.

HOLLYWOOD, April 15 -- Screen and television writers are arriving here from various parts of the county to settle down to anguished preliminary rewrites over the week-end on some subjects very important to them.

Your April 8 editorial on "Tuition at City Colleges" is primarily based on financial considerations. You wish to be "fair to taxpayers" and you are quite certain that reasonable tuition charges will not deprive any deserving student of the opportunity for a college education, since enrollment capacity will be enlarged "through more support funds."
Optimism about the rehabilitation and redevelopment of downtown New York was expressed last night by leaders of finance, shipping and business.

SUEDE shoes, a year-round favorite with many women, often present care problems. The nap tends to thin and the surface, if not properly cared for, is inclined to become discolored. Following are basic rules for keeping suede looking new:
The elevator that slipped and caused the death of a 14-year-old boy last December was "not properly counterbalanced," District Attorney Frank S. Hogan reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, warned the Senate today that it might kill the chances of labor reform legislation again this year if it added too many amendments on his own pending measure.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 15 (UPI) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus disclosed today that on three different occasions the Federal Bureau of Investigation had warned him that an attempt would be made on his life.
TO Norman Ginsberg, one of the most important stories in home furnishings today is best described as "two characters in search of each other."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the United Nations could play "a very useful role" in the coming negotiations on Berlin even if it was not represented at the conference "table."

Oils, rails and a handful of chemicals provided the impetus yesterday for a new successful assault on stock market records. The New York Times combined and industrial averages made historic highs. The rail stock average and the industrial bond average made new tops for 1959.

WHEN the intermission came at the end of the first half of "Ping-Pong" at the Seven Arts Theatre last evening, your correspondent retired defeated. Richard Watts of The Post and John McClain of The Journal - American, veterans of many a ruckus in the theatre, also withdrew, feeling unhinged, suffering from vertigo.

FOR a man who stands five feet two inches tall and weighs 125 pounds, Charles Cogen has thrown a lot of weight around in city and school circles in recent weeks. It is the weight not of one man, Mr. Cogen says, but of several thousand city school teachers who are determined to win higher salaries.

High Bid enjoyed a brisk Workout while competing against five rivals at Jamaica yesterday. Established the 3-10 choice by the crowd of 22,624, High Bid romped to success in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race for 3-year-old fillies.
Starting Monday night it will be cheaper to travel between New England and Florida by air than by either train or bus.
RYE, N. Y., April 16 -- A woodpecker that prefers a TV antenna to trees for hammering out mating calls was a little out of form this morning.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower played thirty-six holes of golf today. This is believed to be the most he has played in any one day since his heart attack in 1955.
NEXT month may see the first occasion on which the letter of the law was ever sealed with a kiss.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson announced plans today for an unusual inquiry into the Government's methods for arriving at strategic policies and particularly the operations of the National Security Council.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will fly to the Soviet Union in July at the request of President Eisenhower.

The H. L. Green Company, Inc., operator of a chain of retail variety stores, filed suit yesterday in State Supreme Court to "recover $3,300,000" from its former president, Maurice E. Olen, and from Industrial Development, Inc., said to be a personal holding company of Mr. Olen.

YONKERS, April 16 -- Perhaps there have been busier days in the life of Billy Haughton than the one the winningest trainer-driver in harness racing endured today. If there have been, he couldn't pinpoint the date.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, April 17 -- A South Korean Army court-martial sentenced a battalion commander to death today for the killing of his division commander on the Armistice Line front in February.

Four art students in pinafores stood before their easels yesterday, solemnly applying paint to paper with abandon. Colors ran together in the friendliest fashion. Design, when there was design, was of the primitive school.

BUENOS AIRES, April 16 -- A decree outlawing the Communist party as a political organization for the duration of the state of siege is under Government consideration, President Arturo Frondizi announced tonight.
"Gypsy," in which Ethel Merman is starred, will arrive at the Broadway Theatre on May 21 instead of May 14.

CAIRO, April 16 -- Oil companies should revise their contracts with Arab governments, a spokesman of the Arab League declared today at the start of an international oil conference convened by the league.
Motor vehicle tolls alone covered all of the operating expenses of the Port of New York authority last year, with $3,104,000 to/spare, the authority's annual report showed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 17 (UPI) -- Sigma Delta Chi, honorary journalism fraternity, announced today that its twenty-seventh annual award for general reporting would go to Victor Cohn of The Minneapolis Tribune.
DEER LODGE, Mont., April 16 -- Convicts rioted at Montana State Prison today. They killed the deputy warden and held the warden prisoner for two and a half hours.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The resignation of Secretary of State Dulles removes the last of the great personal power centers under President Eisenhower.
Mayor Wagner gave an unqualified endorsement last night to Carmine G. De Sapio's leadership of the New York County Democratic organization.
PARIS, April 16 -- Cautious optimism over France's economic outlook has begun to blossom in Government and financial circles on the basis of the results of three months of the austerity program.

STRASBOURG, France, April 16 (UPI) -- The European Coal and Steel Community's parliamentary Assembly closed a stormy session tonight after having voted broad approval of urgent steps to meet Europe's coal crisis.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Senate Interior Committee approved today a resolution opposing the sale of any stockpile copper at this time, to prevent a further depression of the Western Hemisphere's copper market.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 16 -- Turkey officially opened today an ambitious program to build a defense force of literate soldiers, sailors and airmen.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed today a five-year program to use farm surpluses for "building conditions for peace in the world."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Labor Department -- by coincidence rather than design -- published today a set of productivity figures for the steel industry that could affect the forthcoming wage bargaining.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The United States reiterated today its intention to send C-130 cargo planes to Berlin at high altitudes regardless of protests by the Soviet Union and questions raised by Britain.

IN the four years since her last previous New York showing, May Stevens has developed a persuasive, assured, distinctive style in her low-keyed blond landscapes. Recent paintings at the A. C. A. Gallery also include some uncompromising portraits, but this artist has real feeling for landscape and to it her allegiance belongs.
AUXERRE, France, April 16 -- President Charles de Gaulle, France's most prominent traveling salesman for her past and future greatness, took to the road again today.

THE opening of the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was about as unproletarian an affair as can be imagined, with seats selling for as high as $50 and with virtually everybody in the auditorium dressed in his best bib and tucker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Several days ago, in one of the few unobtrusive buildings in the heart of Hollywood, the phone rang and an advertising man wanted to know if Chinese ideographs for "Thanks a Million" could be found there.
GENEVA, April 16 -- The three major nuclear powers adopted today a ninth draft article for their proposed treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.

TORONTO, April 16 (UPI) -- Big Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion scored one goal and set up to others tonight as the Montreal Canadiens downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2. The Canadiens moved to within one victory of their fourth straight Stanley Cup. They lead the best-of-seven series, 3 -- 1.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 16 -- A warning against lax air-crew practices, such as fraternizing with passengers during flight, was issued today by the Deputy Director of the Federal Aviation Agency.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 16 -- Webb Knapp, Inc., New York real estate concern, has offered to purchase the entire nine-acre slum-clearance area on Washington Avenue here for redevelopment, it was announced today.

The second day of public hearings on Mayor Wagner's executive budget, held before the Board of Estimate, raised the hope not only that this 1959-60 budget may be improved in important respects, but also that, in education especially, a pattern of greater reliance on the judgment of department heads may be set for the future.
TY COBB is an impetuous man. When Harry Heilmann lay dying in a Detroit hospital a half-dozen years ago, the fiery Cobb tried with all his blazing intensity to speed the Hall of Fame elections.
Supreme Court Justice Willaim O. Douglas said yesterday that the United States appeared "frightened and hysterical" to the rest of the world.
The Air Force is expected to urge in the near future the establishment of a Strategic Force or Command to include the Navy's new missile-firing submarines.
The bond markets were in the doldrums yesterday as no word came from Washington on a rumored rise in the Federal Reserve discount rate.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation was accused today of shutting independent lending concerns out of 50 per cent of the automobile finance business.
The Floyd Patterson-Brian London heavyweight title fight in Indianapolis on May 1 got a new promoter yesterday in Bill Rosensohn after Cecil Rhodes Jr., the original promoter, dropped out.

PEIPING, April 16 (Reuters) -- Farmers from China's communes mingled with city dwellers in Peiping today as 2,000 delegates assembled for tomorrow's opening of the second Parliament of the Communist regime.
Business is going to be "generally good" over the next year, according to Edwin B. George, director of economics of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The "Du Pont Show of the Month," which had planned to present its first original drama next month, has postponed it until next fail. An adaptation of Herman Melville's "Billy Budd" has been substituted.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was a luncheon guest today of Acting Secretary of State Christian A. Herter. Dr. Castro flew to Washington last night to begin an eleven-day speaking tour of the eastern United States and Canada. United states press has distorted the facts in reporting the revolution against the regime of President Fulgencio Batista and the subsequent military trials and executions of many Batista followers.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) -- Lewis L. Strauss, Secretary of Commerce, today opposed enactment of a bill to create a new Cabinet-level Department of Science and Technology.
ROME, April 16 -- The Senate rejected tonight a Communist motion against setting up Allied missile bases in Italy. The vote was 133 to 87, with one abstention.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 16 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer carded a six-under-par 66 and took the lead in the first round of the $30,000 Houston invitation golf tournament today.
The New York Blue Cross announced the election of four new directors yesterday. Three of them are leaders of unions affiliated with the merged labor movement.

The lowest accident rate in eighteen years was achieved in the 1958 safe-driving campaign arranged by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the International Circulation Managers Association.
Consumption of purchased iron and steel scrap rose to 2,321,000 gross tons 2,240 pounds in February from 2,088,000 tons the previous month, the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel estimated yesterday.
Two stubborn brush fires in Staten Island, one on the shorefront along Lower New York Bay and the other on Todt Hill, kept the Fire Department busy yesterday.

Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright, Republican of Huntington, L. I., has defended a Federal payment of $75 a month for space in an office that he says was erroneously identified as "his law office" in an article from United Press International in The New York Times of April 1.
Elmer Brown, president of the International Typographical Union said yesterday that he hoped that the dispute between ten New York newspapers and their printers could be settled without a strike.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 16 -- The University of the Witwatersrand canceled all classes after 11 A. M. today and staged a solemn protest against apartheid in higher education.
Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said last night that the choice facing European democracies was: "Federate or perish."

On the busy and bustling island of Manhattan, where most people are caught in the rush and routine, there are a number of small but successful havens. One of them was created by Samuel L. Kuhn, a retired management engineer, who derived so much satisfaction from amateur woodworking that he decided to provide others with an opportunity to share his lifelong hobby.

THE human figure, until recently the most magnetic subject for sculptors, dominates a large exhibition at the Widdifield Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue. This show includes pieces by major nineteenth-century artists such as Degas, Rodin and Renoir, as well as work by well-known twentieth-century men.
The Soviet Union's Bolshoi ballet opened its first American tour last night to the thunderous applause and excited bravos of a glittering audience at the Metropolitan Opera House.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 16 -- Officials said today that more than 49 per cent of the arable land in Hungary had been put into the "Socialist sector" since the new collectivization drive began last autumn.
Money-market pressures increased substantially in New York City in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PASSOVER, the eight-day holiday that begins next Wednesday, is a happy celebration for Jewish families. Certain foods cannot be eaten during the festival, which commemorates the exodus of the Jews from slavery in Egypt.

The chorus of T-shirted youngsters whose serenade opened the dinner dance in the Plaza last night, offered a striking contrast to the assemblage of black-tied men and their smartly gowned women. The "Kips Bay Boys Club" emblazoned on their T shirts made it clear just who the beneficiary of last night's fete was to be.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume declined in most markets. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, rubber, copper, lead and burlap rose; Wool declined, and price movements for sugar, coffee, potatoes, hides and zinc were mixed.

There are many comments being made concerning Mayor Wagner's "austerity budget." The patrolmen, firemen and correction officers complain they cannot live on their present salaries, which include an increase now in the making ($200). These men are doing a fine job and rate an increase.

Directors of the Cessna Aircraft Company have declared a dividend of 50 cents a common share, payable on May 12 to holders of record of April 29. The company paid 40 cents a share in previous quarters and 10 per cent in stock last December.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House General Education subcommittee approved today $4,400,000,000 in Federal aid to school construction and teachers salaries over the next four years.

When U. N. Secretary General Hammarskjold was recently in Russia he went down to the semi-tropical pleasure resort of Sochi on the Black Sea to talk with Premier Khrushchev, and Mr. Khrushchev took him rowing. Mr. Hammarskjold confirmed this incident in his press conference at U. N. headquarters yesterday, although he did not explain what he and Mr. Khrushchev talked about except that it was in "the language of the sea."

A contract agreement covering 23,000 employes of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was reached yesterday by company and union negotiators. The pact was expected to set a pattern for swift settlement of strikes by 57,000 other members of the United Rubber Workers in three other big tire companies.
The fifth annual Queens-Iona Relay Carnival, New York's first major event of the outdoor track and field season, will get under way today at Downing Memorial Stadium on Randall's Island.
The fourth and last of the season's New Music Concerts conducted by Eric Simon took place at Carl Fischer Concert Hall last night.

The Republic Steel Corporation and the Armco Steel Corporation issued a joint statement in Cleveland yesterday commenting on an anti-trust suit filed against them in the Delaware Federal district court on Wednesday by the Mesabi Iron Company.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 16 (AP) -- Michael A. Prendergast accused Governor Rockefeller today of "an unholy alliance with the Republican legislative leaders to thwart the will of the people through quickie laws."

INDIANAPOLIS, April 16 (AP) -- Brian London, Britain's phantom fighter, came to life here today and warned Americans to be cautious about counting his heavyweight title bout as just a warm-up for the champion, Floyd Patterson.
Roosevelt S. Zanders is a chauffeur who has a chauffeur.

Alfred S. Mills, president of The Bank for Savings in the City of New York, has been elected chairman of Group Four of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Richard L. Maloney Jr., president of The New York Savings Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Senate Republicans counter-attacked today against Senator Wayne Morse's harassing action to block Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce's confirmation as Ambassador to Brazil.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States in March exceeded the 1958 level for the third consecutive month, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther said today that the need for voluntary donations to the Red Cross blood bank had increased vastly in the last five years, due to open heart surgery.

BERLIN, April 16 -- A spokesman of the Soviet Embassy in East Berlin charged the United States today with "poisoning the atmosphere on the eve of the Geneva foreign ministers' conference" by its high-altitude flights.

"The Southern Temper," a view of today's South by William Peters, will be issued next Thursday by Doubleday. Mr. Peters gives an appraisal of Southern Negro leadership, looks at the Southern white "liberal" and probes the feelings of Southern segregationists.
Eva Kovach, violinist, gave her local debut recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. David Garvey was her accomplished partner at the piano.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- A United Nations committee disagreed today on when the world organization should attempt to frame a definition of aggression. The Charter bans aggression but does not state specifically what it is.

HOUSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Unseeded Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn advanced to the semi-finals of the River Oaks tennis tournament today with a 6-0, 6-8, 6-3, 6-3 victory over Neal Marcus, a Rice freshman from Tampa, Fla.
A higher dividend and a new president for the National Dairy Products Corporation, as hinted to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday morning, became a reality later in the day.

BY bracketing Norman Dello Joio's "The Triumph of St. Joan" and Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Medium," the New York City Opera Company is able to offer an uncommonly strong evening of opera created in this country.
King Hussein of Jordan said yesterday that he and his people would fight on the side of the free world in "a world-wide clash."

TRENTON, April 16 -- Almost 100 operators and owners of commercial boats appeared at a public hearing today to protest vehemently pending legislation under which all power boats and their operators would be licensed.
Directors of the Hazeltine Corporation approved a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. The action is subject to stockholder approval at a meeting to be held June 10.
The existence of unrealistic highway speed limits has resulted in the "utter disregard of speed laws" in New York State, Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults said yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 (AP) -- Following is the exchange of letters between President Eisenhower and John Foster Dulles, made public today at the President's vacation headquarters:
BALTIMORE, April 16 -- The Yankees were on the verge of going into orbit in the American League pennant race today then something went wrong.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Although a few small plus signs were scattered through the list, the grain futures market generally registered its third consecutive price decline today on the Board of Trade.
WHITESBURG, Ky., April 16 -- A guard was fatally shot tonight in a pitched gun battle at a coal - processing plant three miles from here.
ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Rockefeller approved today this state's participation in a program to rescue foundering New York-New Jersey commuter facilities.
THE courtroom at Nuremberg, Germany, during the trials of Nazi war criminals was the setting for last evening's drama on "Playhouse 90."

LONDON, April 16 -- Prices of industrials continued to make small gains in selective buying on a quiet stock market here today. Against this trend, falls of a few pence were scattered among leading share groups.

IF a pregnant woman procrastinates about wearing maternity clothes, Bonwit Telle will banish all negative thoughts. Fashions in the store's eighthfloor "Anticipation Shop" are so pretty that even the shyest, expectant mother might feel eager to wear them.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) -- A South Carolina Negro leader said today that in parts of the state Negroes were afraid to talk "above a whisper" about voting.

AMERICANS intending to visit friends overseas can leave the kitchen sink at home. Also potato peelers, egg slicers and tools that remove the eyes of pineapples. What kitchen-proud housewives in other countries want in the way of a present is a small electric appliance or a goodlooking plastic object.
There is a grave fear among Britons that an American company is seeking control of Jaguar Motors.
The official spokesmen for management and labor in the steel industry decided yesterday to substitute face-to-face negotiation for long-distance sparring through the mails.
The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Maryland, sold $9,000,000 of various purpose general obligation bonds yesterday to a group led by Glore, Forgan Co.
Privately owned American shipyards are on the threshold of an era of steadily improving work volume and expanding income, according to E. F. Hutton Co., New York investment broker.
ALGIERS, April 16 (Reuters) -- Work began today on demolishing the Algiers Casbah, an ancient district of tortuous alleys housing 80,000 Moslems on a hillside over-looking Algiers Bay.
HOUSTON, April 16 (UPI) -- A group of Houston residents and entertainers pitched in today to throw a big benefit party tomorrow night so two broke and stranded Canadian hockey teams can go home.
Mahomed Ali C. Chagla, India's Ambassador to the United States, yesterday urged American business men to make more investments in his country.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Having appointed Under Secretary of State Herter, prior to Secretary Dulles' resignation, to speak for the United States at the conference of foreign ministers, the President doubtless does not desire to suggest that he evaluates this as a second-level role.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Paul M. Butler warned the South today that the 1960 Democratic platform would back school desegregation and oppose "massive resistance."

A new process for dyeing glass cloth, which up to now has presented a variety of seemingly insurmountable technical obstacles, was announced yesterday by the Silicones Division of Union Carbide Corporation.

THIS figures out to be a good striped-bass year, according to many a wise old head, but nobody can prove it yet. Jersey fishermen have been taking stripers briskly now and then, but only now and then. Long Island can-count only the stray striper.
Many persons entertained last night in connection with a dinner dance given by the Lower East Side Committee of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane.
LAST year, an estimated 166,980 women living in New York had good reason to wonder what to wear. They were pregnant.

MONTREAL, April 16 (Canadian Press) -- Texaco Canada Ltd. today reported net income of $2,634,493, or 80 cents a share, for the first quarter of 1959, against $2,213,669, or 67 cents a share, for the corresponding period in 1958.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 16 (AP) -- Connie Nicholas was sentenced today to a two-to-twenty-one-year term on a charge of manslaughter in the slaying of her married lover. She was expected to be freed on appeal bond by tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A free-swinging floor fight over the Taft-Hartley Labor law of 1947 was foreshadowed today for the Senate next week.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Christian A. Herter, Acting Secretary of State and likely successor to John Foster Dulles, has passed a complete physical check-up that President Eisenhower requested.

Cotton futures of the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday, with both ends of the list showing sharp gains. Old May rose 22 points and new October, for 1960 delivery, 22 points. Other months were 2 to 10 points higher. One point equals one-hundredth of a cent a pound.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; National Music Orchestra, public rehearsal, High School of Performing Arts, 3:30; "The Scarf," and "The Warhl and Daniel Webster," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; "The Barber of Seville," Opera Workshop, Hall of Fame Playhouse, New York University Heights Campus, the Bronx, 8:30.

The Board of Estimate gave its blessing tentatively yesterday to a proposal under which the Board of Education hopes to give its teachers about $20,000,000 in pay rises in 1959-60. Only $10,000,000 is allocated in Mayor Wagner's executive budget of $2,173,113,999.

Barring an unprecedented reversal of the public stand taken by their Geneva delegate, the Soviets have turned thumbs down on the American-British proposal to stop immediately all nuclear weapons tests producing poisonous fallout. Having demanded an end to the tests because of the fail-out menace (to which they have contributed more than any other power), the Soviets are again exposing their hypocrisy in this affair.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, April 16 (AP) -- Armco Steel Corporation announced today that earnings for the first quarter of 1959 were more than 100 per cent above these of a year ago.

The property at 1408-10 Second Avenue, corner of Seventy third Street, formerly operated by the city as a public market was sold at auction yesterday for $550,000. The buyer was the H. C Bohack Company, operator of a chain of food markets in Brooklyn and on Long Island. The upset price was $290,000.
ALBANY, April 16 -- The first state assistance to the general operating costs of New York City's four municipal colleges was authorized today by Governor Rockefeller.

LONDON, April 16 -- A parliamentary tribunal of inquiry into charges that a policeman assaulted John Waters, a 16-year-old Scottish grocer's boy, ended today with a report reprimanding both for bad conduct.
ALBANY, April 16 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller signed legislation today making every worker in the state, except domestic servants, eligible for unemployment insurance benefits.

The Tri-Bridge View Realty Corporation sold the six-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 1750 Montgomery Avenue in the Bronx to an investing client of B. Kessler, attorney. The property, 150 by 100 feet, was sold subject to mortgages amounting to $210,000.

The future opportunities for nuclear-powered merchant ships are so tremendous that this country should be encouraged to build more than just one such vessel, a leading ship builder said here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 16 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America today reported a first- quarter decline in its net income, compared with that last year. Alcoa cahirman I. W. Wilson, said aluminum prices had suffered because of "tough" world competition.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Rumors of changes in the membership of the Civil Aeronautics Board were revived today.
WARSAW, April 16 -- The Polish press has printed its first direct attack against Pope John XXIII.
MIAMI BEACH, April 16 (AP) -- Railway labor accused management today of "trying to picture railroad workers as all featherbedders and overpaid incompetents."
Two members of the Board of Estimate took issue yesterday with Park Commissioner Robert Moses on his ruling that Shakespearean performances in Central Park could no longer be free.

TENNESSEE ERNIE FORD, whose Thursday evening variety show tends to be obscured in the public prints by "Playhouse 90," came up last night with a charming little sleeper, a thirty-minute version of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "The Mikado." The program was seen over Channel 4.
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) -- George T. Baker, president of National Airlines, denied today that he ever authorized any bribes to Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications Commissioner, in the Miami Television Channel 10 case.
MILWAUKEE, April 16 (UPI) -- The unbeaten Milwaukee Braves ran their string to four today when they scored four runs in the eighth inning for a 7-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Government's proposals to tighten or clarify the regulations pertaining to tax exemptions for nonprofit organizations drew criticism today from a battery of those now exempt.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 16 -- Lew Hoad defeated Pancho Gonzales, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, before 2,200 fans at the Westchester County Center tonight. It was the tenth time in their fifteen matches that the Australian had downed the world professional champion on the present tour.
Negotiations aimed at merging the Thiokol Chemical Corporation of Bristol, Pa., and the Marquardt Aircraft Company of Van Nuys, Calif., were disclosed yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Board's monthly index of industrial production, just made public, broke through to an all-time high in March. At 147 it stood two points above the February mark (which had been revised upward in the meantime from 144 to 145) and this was enough to carry it one point above the previous record. The latter was reached first in December, 1956, and again in February, 1957.

SETIF, Algeria, April 16 -- This eastern Algerian city, home town of Ferhat Abbas, premier of the Algerian rebel government, reflected today on the frustrations and hopes of the French administration in Algeria.

A tentative settlement was reached last night in the sixteen-day-old strike of 5,000 Pennsylvania blouse makers. The pact is subject to ratification at union and employer meetings in the Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton district today.
O. Roy Chalk was questioned for three hours yesterday by the reactivated Mayor's Committee on Transit Power Plants concerning his offer to negotiate for the purchase of the city's transit system.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Consecutive fourth-inning home runs by Bob Allison and Norm Zauchin sparked the Washington Senators to a 7-5 triumph over the Boston Red Sox today.

Edmond Martin, who has challenged in state Supreme Court the constitutionality of the city's anti-discrimination housing law, must appear next Friday before the Commission on Intergroup Relations to answer a complaint that he has been violating that law.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House Rules Committee refused today to let the omnibus housing bill go the floor for consideration. The vote was 6 -- 6. A tie vote means "no."
WASHINGTON, April 16, (AP) -- A House subcommittee voted today to hold hearings on complaints that thousands of servicemen are assigned unnecessarily to jobs as chauffeurs, waiters and aides.
Gustave L. Levy, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, yesterday deplored "overlapping appeals" to combat various diseases.

STILLWATER, Okla., April 16 (AP) -- Offensive tactics stood out today as a field of 187 wrestlers opened the freestyle division of the National Amateur Athletic Union championships. There were sixty-three falls in the 114 matches.

THE National Home Fashions League presented its ninth annual "Trail Blazer" awards yesterday. They are given to those who have had the greatest influence on the home furnishings industry since World War II.
I have read with considerable dismay your articles on the need for foster child care.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 16 -- Premier Tage Erlander declared today that Sweden's ruling Social Democrats were planning no further major social reforms.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 618,359 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The wheel has turned and a new cycle of interest in bicycle racing has started in the colleges.
AN egghead need no longer cry out against conformity. His hat can do it for him.

WHEN rioting mobs stormed out of the slums of Cairo on Jan. 26, 1952, and looted, burned and killed, reasonably well-informed survivors of the twentieth century's disasters were not particularly surprised. For most of their adult lives they had been accustomed to more dismaying events.
Residents of the city will join people throughout the state and nation today in observing Operation Alert 1959, the sixth annual Civil Defense Training Exercise.
TRENTON, N. J., April 16 (AP) -- Thiokol's X-15 rocket engine was given its first public unveiling today at the annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- W. Averell Harriman cautioned today against hasty United States moves that might help Communist China escape Asian indignation over its treatment of the Tibetan Dalai Lama.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., April 16 -- A valuable art collection was destroyed here early today when a fire wrecked the interior of the Entwistle Galleries and School of Art. Neighbors reported they had seen three youths running from the scene.

Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that the Board of Hospitals "strongly recommends" closing the in-patient section of Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn until modernization was completed.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 16 (AP) -- A victory by Calumet Farms Kentucky Derby hope, On-and-On, overshadowed Hidden Talent's triumph in the $20,650 Ashland Stakes today at Keeneland.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16 -- Evidence that all living organisms from single-celled plants and animals to man himself may be responsive to geophysical events caused by the earth, the sun and the moon was presented here today.
BONN, Germany, April 16 -- The public prosecutor of Frankfurt charged today that a quasi-official French organization was waging a terrorist campaign against Algerian rebel agents in West Germany.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Rockefeller administration told Congress today that it was "unalterably opposed" to any Constitutional amendment restricting a state's power to tax nonresidents' incomes.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Air Force mounted an air search today for the small instrument capsule from the Discoverer II satellite. It is believed to have landed in the Arctic region.

BOMBAY, India, April 16 (Reuters) -- Gamal Abdel Nasser again has accused Arab Communists of plotting, with Soviet backing, to seize Iraq, split Syria and Egypt and establish a "Red Fertile Crescent" in the Middle East.

Four apartment houses occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet a 301 to 307 East Twenty-fourth Street, between First and Second Avenues, have been sold by the Maintained Realty Corporation. The buyers were Long Beach Associates. Adele Kirsch was the broker.
The Metropolitan Opera House last night had one of its most spectacular fashion evenings with the opening of the Bolshoi Ballet.

Business spending for plant and equipment this year will be 7 per cent higher than in 1958, according to a survey by the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. The report, issued yesterday, estimated capital expenditures in 1959 at $34,209,000,000, up from $32,091,000,000 last year.
Former Deputy Police Inspector Dominic J. Masella denied yesterday at his trial in Kings County Court that he had participated in any illegal wiretapping on a Brooklyn bookmaker's telephone.
MEXICO CITY, April 16 (AP) -- The Government oil monopoly Pemex accused an army officer today of stealing $720,000 worth of gasoline over the last eight years.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 -- President Eisenhower accepted formally today the resignation of John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State. It was generally assumed that the President's choice of a suc cessor would be Christian A. Herter, now Acting Secretary.

The oil of the Middle East represents vast wealth and it provides the sinews of Western European industry. It is also a prize of great political importance, linked to the fate of governments, the persistent pressures for social justice, the conflict of Premier Kassim of Iraq with President Nasser of the United Arab Republic and, by the same token, it is linked to the global cold war.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A member of Congress and the General Counsel of the Defense Department argued publicly today over whether it was a violation of the nation's security to talk about the use of monkeys in space research.
Landlubbers are welcomed on pleasure-boat cruises every season. In fact, they are needed. A few chores not considered pleasant are usually left for the newcomers.

The American Jewish Committee received assurances from President Theodor Heuss of West Germany yesterday that he would call a conference of ministers of education to discuss the problem of anti-Semitism.
PARIS, April 16 -- Air France demonstrated confidence in its new Caravelle jet airliner today by cutting out one of the plane's two engines on the take-off and both of them at 40,000 feet.

Mayor Wagner asked the Fire and Building Departments yesterday for new regulations for structures housing truck-loading platforms.
MANILA, April 16 -- C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, left a regional meeting of United States Ambassadors in Asia today for Washington.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An inter-American military force to maintain stability in the Western Hemisphere and prevent Communist encroachment has been proposed by Senator George A. Smathers.
ROME, April 16 -- Pope John participated today in rites commemorating the 750th anniversary of the foundation of the Franciscan Order.
The likelihood of a strike Wednesday at six voluntary hospitals increased yesterday.
A jury in Federal Court late yesterday began deliberating a tax-fix conspiracy charge against Daniel A. Bolich, formet Assistant Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Max Halperin, a New York lawyer.

LOS ANGELES, April 16 (UPI) -- Don Demeter and Jim Baxes drove in six runs tonight, leading the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The Cards set a major league record by using twenty-five players and a National League mark with eight pinch hitters.

Jack D. Weiler, realty investor and builder, has returned to his office at 711 Third Avenue after recuperang in Florida from a recent illness. He at-! tended the annual dinner of the Realty Foundation at the Astor Hotel on Monday night. He is a supporter of the foundation which gives cash grants to persons in the realty field who are in need of temporary financial assistance.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UPI) -- Ned Garver shut out the Chicago White Sox on five hits today as the Kansas City Athletics coasted to a 6-0 triumph. Bob Cerv and Frank House each contributed a two-run homer to the attack.
As the products of the Colgate-Palmolive Company go, so grows the business of Ted Bates, Inc.

PARIS, April 16 -- Jean Rostand, a noted biologist and a son of Edmond Rostand, the late playwright and poet, was elected today to the French Academy, France's official arbiter of language and literature.
MIAMI, Fla., April 16 -- Four enemies of the Castro regime hijacked a Cuban domestic airliner today and forced its pilot to fly them to Miami in search of political asylum.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The most important section of the Civil Rights Act of 1957 was held unconstitutional today by a Federal district judge in Macon, Ga. Judge T. Hoyt Davis struck down the provisions allowing the Federal Government to seek injunctions on behalf of Negro voting rights. This was the only significant addition to civil rights law in the 1957 act and was regarded as the mainstay of Federal power in the voting field.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- A newspaper editor told Congressmen today that they must have "clean hands" in the fight against secrecy in government. He said "many people are suspicious you also are guilty of hiding public information."

At the suggestion of the Fifth Avenue Association, whose interests exceed the boundaries of its name, two bills have been put before the City Council to "upgrade" Fourth Avenue from Seventeenth Street to Thirty-second Street. The association feels that this program would benefit not only Fourth Avenue but also the entire district, cost the taxpayers nothing and might eventually through encouragement of new construction add thousands of dollars to city revenues from taxes.
Stockholders of the Scott Paper Company elected Charles B. Harding and Jay L. Taylor to the board of directors at the annual meeting in Chester, Pa., yesterday.

The net crude oil production in Iran last year averaged 821,000 barrels a day, compared with 716,000 a day in 1957, according to a review of oil operations in that country for 1958 by the consortium. The Abadan refinery processed an average of 310,000 barrels of oil a day, about the same as in 1957.
GENEVA, April l7 -- The angry resignation of its chairman today threw a forty-nation conference here on stateless persons into confusion.
The only thing that got New Yorkers off the city's streets yesterday was the air raid drill, which forced them to take shelter at 1:30 P. M. for ten minutes.

The "magical" forked stick and its use to locate underground water are the subject of a book by Evon Z. Vogt, an anthropologist, and Ray Hyman, a psychologist. The volume is called "Water Witching, U.S.A." The authors explain what water witching is, how it works and how extensively it is practiced.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, asked today an investigation of military buying and property disposal programs, with special emphasis on what he called a scandalous situation in Carpentersville, Ill.

The New York Times of March 28 carried an interesting report from its Moscow correspondent Osgood Caruthers. He reported a speech Mr. Khrushchev had made on March 7 at Leipzig which was kept secret by the Soviet Government until March 27, when it was made public in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Government could appeal a judge s decision to suppress evidence in criminal cases under legislation proposed today by Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York.
CAIRO, April 17 (Reuters) -- Iraq has asked a major Western-owned oil company to build an $800,000,000 pipeline to carry her oil to the Persian Gulf, the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram said today.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Rockefeller today approved a bill extending cities' authority to relocate displaced families in public housing temporarily, even if their income exceeds the statutory limit for the project.

Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday authorizing a representation election among the 30,000 hourly rated employes of the City Transit Authority.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 8 points off to 15 points up. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
ANKARA, Turkey, April 17 -- The Turkish Government has ordered emergency action this week-end to clear a jam of foreign aid supplies from the port of Istanbul.
Sentences totaling 162 years were imposed yesterday in Federal Court here on fourteen men and one woman convicted of conspiracy to violate the narcotics laws.

JERSEY CITY, April 17 --A report on negotiations to merge various segments of the Lutheran Church in the United States and Canada into a united group of more than 7,500,000 members will be made here next Wednesday.

Two five-story buildings containing forty apartments and two stores at 516-18 West Fiftieth Street have been sold by Benard Renzy to an investor. Title was insured with the City Title Insurance Company. The property, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, is assessed at $42,000.

The office building at 206 Central Avenue, Jersey City, has been purchased by an investor. It was constructed in 1956 for the Prudential Life Insurance Company, the principal tenant. Other occupants are the New Jersey Manufacturers Hospital Association and the L. W. Forester Company.

TRENTON, April 17 -- The state Attorney General's office called on the Prudential Insurance Company today to stop withholding New York taxes from residents of that state who work for Prudential in New Jersey.

MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev observed his sixty-fifth birthday today with the publication of his book, "To Victory in Peaceful Competition With Capitalism." It is a sure best seller.
JACKSON, Miss., April 17 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater, Arizona Republican, said today that he regarded Chief Justice Earl Warren as a socialist and unqualified to head the high court.
The New York delegation to Congress agreed at a meeting with Governor Rockefeller and other state officials last night to act as a unit in promoting the state's economic interests in Washington.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Rumanian Government has offered to renew negotiations with the United States on the two countries' financial claims against each other.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Northwest Airlines won a preliminary round today in its fight to block British Overseas Airways Corporation from adding Tokyo to its trans-Pacific route.
CHICAGO, April 17 -- Replacement of rule by terror with rule by law in the world was the theme of a conference of Midwest lawyers, which opened tonight in the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 17 -- Songs, hymns and chants give both rhythm and morale to African nationalist meetings throughout east, central and south Africa.
After an early rally, seemingly based on no change in the Federal Reserve discount rate, long-term Treasury bonds again drifted to new lows yesterday.

OTTAWA, April 17 (Canadian Press) -- A Royal Commission report recommended today that all persons found by the courts to be dangerous sexual offenders be sentenced to an indeterminate penitentiary term.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Babies born in sections of the state where the rocky terrain is abnormally radioactive show an abnormally high rate of mal-formation, a State Health Department study indicated today.
MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- A baby born during the plane's flight was one of the twenty-six Mexicans reported killed when an airliner crashed near Hermosillo today.
HAZARD, Ky., April 17 -- Two National Guard battalions were mobilized today for duty here in the strike-bound coal fields of the eastern Kentucky hill country.

WINNIPEG, Man., April 17 (Canadian Press) -- Western Canada's oldest farmer-owned grain company, United Grain Growers, Ltd., has completed five months of negotiations with the purchase of the Canadian Consolidated Grain Company.
Biaggio Velluzzi was the toast of Broadway yesterday.

Events today: National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30; George Bennette, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Susannah," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Isaac Stern, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Balalaika Symphonic Orchestra and Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30.

The Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street, will be host tomorrow at an interfaith, interracial seder commemorating the Jewish Festival of Passover. The holy days, emphasizing freedom as every man's birthright as a child of God, will begin at sundown on Wednesday.

TEZPUR, India, April 17 -- A great public welcome has been prepared for the Dalai Lama here. It will mark the end of his thirty-two-day journey over some of the cruelest terrain in the world to escape the Chinese Communist overlords of Tibet.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 17 (AP) -- Tomy Lee, unhampered by a two-month layoff, set a Keeneland track record for seven furlongs today in the $6,000 Stepping Stone Purse and easily beat eight other Kentucky Derby nominees.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 17 -- Suburban homemakers should find lots of winners at the Roosevelt Raceway here this week. The track is playing host to a Fashions in Living Exposition, of which the Long Island Home Builders Institute is the sponsor.
Two Midwestern teen-agers have won the 1959 national youth leadership contest of the Elks.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Plans for linking the new State of Alaska with the continental United States by highway and railroad routes got a push today from the Senate Commerce Committee.
BOSTON, April 17 -- It seems that at this business of romping off with another American League pennant isn't going to be such a simple trick after all.
BONN, Germany, April 17 -- West Germany would veto any German reunification plan that contemplated even a temporary or limited confederation of the two Germanys.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The Common Pleas Court today ordered officers of Bayuk Cigars, Inc., to turn over some books and records of the company to Howard Mack, leader of a group of insurgent stockholders.
Mayor Wagner's 1959-60 executive budget of $2,173,113,999, already attacked by city employes, including school teachers, took another pounding yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, suggested today that Congress try to "consolidate our gains' in civil rights legislation this year instead of "standing up to be counted" on stiff measures with little chance of passage.
Ingrida and Karina Gutbergs gave a program of music for two pianos, and four hands at one piano, last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

WARSAW, April 17 -- In Poland this week wreaths were laid and speeches were made and resolutions were passed. In Warsaw, an occasional visitor walked down the steps of the cellar of a great gray building and peered at the terrible inscriptions on the wall.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York adopted a resolution recently on an issue of vital interest to anyone who might take an international airline flight. It recommended that the United States ratify a revision of the Warsaw Convention -- a multilateral treaty that limits the liability of an airline in accident suits involving international flights. Under the revision, the limitation would be raised from $8,300 to $16,600.
