GENEVA, April 17 -- The three major atomic powers said today that they hoped all nations would join them in banning the testing of nuclear weapons for all time under effective international controls.

Tie-ups from three to seven blocks long slowed traffic on the Manhattan approaches to the George Washington Bridge late yesterday afternoon. But whether the delays were any greater than usual was a matter of opinion.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 17 -- The Play Troupe of Port Washington, the oldest amateur theatrical group in Nassau County, is presenting its 100th production this week-end.

New York has many attractions, but for George M. Code nothing can equal its fire stations. The 81-year-old resident of Winnipeg, Man., has found a simple way to locate the engine houses that fascinate him.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican floor leader, said today that he had been assured that Acting Secretary of State Christian A. Herter would be appointed to succeed John Foster Dulles. He added that he expected the announcement soon, probably tomorrow.

MILWAUKEE, April 17 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves and the Pittsburgh Pirates played a 2-2 tie in the rain at County Stadium today. The decision of the umpires to call the game before play started in the top of the tenth left the undefeated Braves alone at the head of the National League with four victories.

"THE NATURAL SCIENCE OF HUMAN STUPIDITY,"* by Paul Tabori, shows that there is no subject under the stars so illimitably awesome that no writer will touch it. The book should probably be required reading for mankind -- which has done so much to make it possible.
Governor Rockefeller threw the switch yesterday that opened a show at the Coliseum called Scouting in Action for America.

AINTREE, England, April 17 -- For more than 135 years this track was strictly for horses. They roamed the lush lawns of the paddock, they galloped down the straight, they plunged head first over the most photographed hedges in the world -- hedges tough enough to stop a Grand Prix racer.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba denied today charges of Communist influence in his regime.
The Maritime Administration of the Department of Commerce has asked a private research firm to study collisions at sea.
PEIPING, April l7 -- Repentant Chinese "Rightists," purged from top posts last year for attacking the Communist regime, were publicly accepted back into the fold today, though at lower levels.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 17 -- Studies suggesting that it may be possible to overcome the resistance that cancers develop to anti-cancer drugs were presented here today at the final session of the Federation of American Biology.
Although they lost a little ground in the final fifteen minutes of trading, stocks scored strong advances yesterday and established a series of new highs.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has decreed what seems to amount to a death sentence on the New York Shakespeare Festival, which has been supplying excellent summer productions of the Bard in Central Park, by commanding it to charge admissions where hitherto entry was free. This has been an enterprise important enough to be cited as evidence of the nation's cultural achievements in our propaganda behind the Iron Curtain.

OSLO, April 17 (UPI) -- United States Air Force planes droned over a vast area around Norway's Spitzbergen Island today in their search for the instrument capsule from the United States earth satellite "Discoverer II."

Final plans have been announced by Mrs. William C. Langley, chairman of special projects for the New York Heart Association, for the fourth annual Heart of America Ball. The event, a benefit for the Heart Fund, will take place at the Plaza on April 28.
DETROIT, April 17 -- A shift in the top command of the Buick division of the General Motors Corporation was announced today.
The nation began its sixth annual Civil Defense maneuvers yesterday -- Operation Alert 1959.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Immigration subcommittee, said tonight that no new refugee legislation was needed.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- A bill to finance college educations for ex-servicemen of the last four years was opposed today by the Eisenhower Administration.
THIS is the season for the little fur. The clutch, the brief jacket and the light-weight stole eschew moth balls to carry on as long as there is a breeze to whisper across the summer scene.

The inscription on a fountain in the main plaza in Cuzco, Peru, says that the statue at the top represents the last Inca, Atahualpa. But for the last hundred years the city fathers have known this to be untrue.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Victor R. Hansen as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division.

LONDON, April 17 -- Industrials again scored more rises than falls in the stock market here today. The Financial Times index of thirty industrial ordinary shares rose 0.9 to 224.9, a gain of 2.6 points for the week.
REDDING, Conn., April 17 -- Wealth has accrued to the estate of Mark Twain in a manner that might have astonished him.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce appeared before a Senate Government Operations subcommittee today in support of a bill to create a department of Science and Technology.

THE season for cooking on the patio and picnicking in the meadow is not far off. Ever-alert New York stores, in preparation for such outdoor activities, have been busy accumulating a sorts of new accessories.
Salvador de Madariaga, former diplomat under the Spanish Republic, charged yesterday that the policies of Generalissimo Francisco Franco were aiding the underground spread of communism in Spain.
NEW HAVEN, April 17 (AP) -- Yale's undergraduates are again in the university's good graces.
The city may have to find $4,000,000 to $5,000,000 in additional funds for pay increases for about 40,000 employes if higher salary rises for teachers are granted.
ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Rockefeller approved today a state-wide police training bill that he called "a great forward step in strengthening law enforcement in the state."
Reflecting a sharp rise in sales, the net income of the Borg - Warner Corporation surged in the first quarter more than 50 per cent above the 1958 level.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17 -- Slovenian resentment against limitations on bilingual schools in southern Austria has erupted in demonstrations against Austrian commerce.
NEWARK, April 17 -- The Public Utility Commission today granted the Central Railroad of New Jersey permission to discontinue twenty-six weekday trains on its main line.
Seventy - five tenants at 404 Riverside Drive wished their building a happy birthday last night. The building is fifty years old.
New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is conducting an inquiry into the proposed merger of Guaranty Trust Company of New York and J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- The May wheat future closed on the Board of Trade today with a loss of 9 cents a bushel on the week. The setback was the largest sustained by any contract in a five-day trading period in more than a year.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The level of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent to 119.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Canadian Transport Minister George Hees expressed optimism today that an agreement could be reached on a uniform international pilot law for the Great Lakes.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration was criticized sharply today for devising what Representative Phil Weaver, Republican of Nebraska, called "means of guaranteeing a profit" to some defense contractors.

CONTEMPORARY American printmaking is in a thriving condition. Hardly a year passes without some new technique being developed, and the technical discipline involved seems to attract and challenge many artists for whom oil paint is insufficiently resourceful as a medium.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A new technique for directly cooling the internal organs for heart surgery instead of having to immerse the patient in ice-water was announced today by the Veterans Administration.

HOLLYWOOD, April 17 (UPI) -- Kenny Lane of Muskegon, Mich., scored a sixth-round technical knockout tonight over Johnny Busso of New York in a nationally-televised lightweight fight at Hollywood Legion Stadium.
"The House I Live In," a Russian-made drama of World War II, will open today at the Cameo Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- The United States formally requested today that the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Use of Outer Space meet here May 6.
I was amazed at your editorial of April 3 entitled "All the State's Fault."

LAST night Yuri Faier conducted the orchestra for the Bolshoi Ballet, just as he has done since 1918. Not many in the audience realized that Mr. Faier is almost blind. He was born with an affliction described in the medical books as retinitis pigmentosa.
Commodity futures prices moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Metals led the advance. Evening of positions for the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

PARIS, April 17 -- President Charles de Gaulle paid his first visit today to Vichy, where the wartime collaborationist regime of Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain had condemned him to death for carrying on the fight against Germany despite the armistice.
"SOME stores here are now selling dandelion greens. Can these be used raw in salads or do they have to be cooked? And if they require cooking, how should this be done?" Mrs. J. S., New York.

A horse race that has become one of this region's most popular sports events will be run at Jamaica this afternoon, with the presentation of the mile-and-an-eighth Wood Memorial. Christopher T. Chenery's First Landing heads the list of 3-year-olds that will compete, and a crowd of 40,000 fans may turn out for the thirty-fifth running of the fixture.

In 1917 a 27-year-old Orthodox rabbi by the name of Herbert S. Goldstein made a major decision. He gave up the security of a congregation on the fashionable East Side to cast his lot with the poverty-ridden Jews of Harlem.

The favored economic position of Soviet scientists has often been cited as a key reason for Moscow's rapid scientific advance. In a country where the average monthly wage of a worker is under $100, Soviet scientists enjoy comfortable apartments, servants, cars, country homes and the like. The Kremlin, it has been clear, has not stinted in providing incentives for its creative scientific minds.
Four meet schoolboy records were broken and another was tied yesterday as the fifth annual Queens-Iona track relay carnival opened in perfect weather at Downing Memorial Stadium on Randalls Island.
YONKERS, April 18 -- Everything at Yonkers Raceway was big tonight.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 17 -- Eight Greek Cypriotes were arrested late last night following clashes with the British police in Paphos and Ktima.
Cardinal Spellman gave King Hussein a check for. $5,000 yesterday "to alleviate the suffering of the poor and homeless in the Kingdom of Jordan, regardless of race, color or creed."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 17 (AP) -- The film version of "The Diary of Anne Frank" had its European premiere here last night in the city in which the young Jewish girl wrote her diary while hiding from the Nazis.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 17 -- Governor General Henri Cornelis will return to his post in the Belgian Congo Sunday as the result of the personal preference of King Baudouin.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- February electric production reflected the nation's industrial recovery, statistics of the Federal Power Commission showed today.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- The prosecution produced today $1,550 in checks that it said Richard A. Mack, former member of the Federal Communications Commission, had received as part of a conspiracy to influence his vote in the case of Miami television Channel 10.
ALBANY, April 17 -- The State Health Commissioner reported today that there was not longer any practical objection to the fluoridation of the New York City water system.
The appointment of Charles Marion Rice, director of admissions at the Choate School, Wallingford, Conn., as president of Athens College in Greece, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright charged today that a Republican colleague had exceeded "proper bounds" of Senatorial conduct in likening his treatment of Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce to tactics of the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

IN its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Bolshoi Ballet presented its second major ballerina of the season last night in a repetition of "Romeo and Juliet." She is Raissa Struchkova, a lovely looking and appealing Juliet and a superb dancer.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad may know next week whether it has the support of a minority stockholders' group to proceed with its plans for borrowing $9,800,000 for fifteen years with a Government guarantee, under the Transportation Act of 1958. Proceeds of the borrowing would be used for new equipment and for shop improvements.
An obviously frightened 16-year-old prosecution witness, who was in Jefferson Park the night Julio Ramos was fatally assaulted, proved a reluctant and hostile witness yesterday.
A somewhat somber picture of the defense readiness of the American merchant marine has been presented to a Senate committee.

HIGH POINT, N. C., April 17 -- It is going to be a colorful autumn inside the American home. Color streaks across the new collections at the wholesale furniture market in progress here. Manufacturers who timidly dipped into the palette with a few pieces of colored furniture for their spring lines have gone all out in their fall ones.

HAVANA, April 17 -- Forty-nine men and one woman have been lodged in the jail at Cardenas on the north coast of Matanzas Province. They are accused of having conspired against the revolutionary government.
The state's highest court unanimously affirmed yesterday a thirty-day sentence for contempt imposed two years ago on Frank Costello.

Space in the Coliseum Office Building, 10 Columbus Circle, has been leased by the Medical Society of the County of New York, which will move its executive offices and other departments from the New York Academy of Medicine Building at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 17 -- An experiment involving a nuclear blast 100,000,000 miles in space is being actively considered in the scientific community, Dr. Edward Teller disclosed today.

It is Saturday night, and the head of the house, is working. As he sits at the typewriter he feels swollen with virtue. He knows that all about New York little groups of people are gathered together, perhaps over a steak and a bottle.

WITH a reassuring ballast of Beethoven's Violin Concerto and Isaac Stern as the discerning soloist, the New York Philharmonic took off yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall on contemporary exploration.

In its surge to record highs this week, the stock market has been marked by unusual activity in nine "when issued" stocks listed on the Big Board. These are new issues due to replace old ones following a stock split. They are not yet outstanding but they can be traded.

The volume of new capital issues in the market next week will be fairly large though mostly spread out in a number of medium and small size issues. The week will begin a thirty-day period in which the pace will slacken though still remaining above the four weeks beginning April 13.

Jean J. P. Baltzell, Democratic leader in Manhattan's Ninth Assembly District, declared last night that Carmine G. De Sapio should recognize that the Democratic party here had lost the confidence of the voters.
Two men accused of conspiracy to fix Federal income tax cases were acquitted last night in Federal Court.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 17 (UPI) -- Mario Llamas of Mexico gained the semi-finals of the Masters tennis tournament today with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Don Kierbow, Beverly Hills, Calif.

Two top figures in the legitimate theatre field yesterday voiced criticism of Park Commissioner Robert Moses' recent edict prohibiting the New York Shakespeare Festival from giving free performances of the classics in Central Park.
A suspended policeman, who had been indicted for first-degree murder in the rape-slaying of a 60-year-old woman, was permitted to plead guilty yesterday to second-degree murder.
CAIRO, April 17 -- Venezuela's delegation to the petroleum conference here has persuaded the Arab delegates that oil from Arab lands is being sold at too low a price.
The Mesabi Iron Company announced yesterday that it had started court action to recover 148,700 shares of Mesabi common stock held by the Reserve Mining Company.

VIENNA, April 17 -- The International Atomic Energy Agency's governing board announced today plans to send three expert missions to Latin America and the Far East to study atomic power and technical assistance possibilities.

BERLIN, April 17 -- Mrs. Eleanor Lansing Dulles, sister of John Foster Dulles, who arrived in Berlin today for a three-week stay, declared that her visit was "proof of continued interest" by her brother in the Berlin problem.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday endorsed the proposal of the Italian Historical Society of America to name the proposed Narrows Bridge to Staten Island in memory of Giovanni da Verrazano, the Florentine navigator.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast Republic, April 17 -- As in the other emergent states of Africa, the political opposition has withered in this autonomous republic of the new Fernch Community.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Foreign aid officials reported today a noticeable upturn in foreign investment by United States industries.
ALBANY, April 17 -- The State reported today that there were 110,000 more registered Democrats in New York than there were Republicans at the last election.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Police sirens pierced the spring air. Pickets paraded. High school students shouted from buses, "Hi, Fidel!" And Fidel Castro waved, smiled, shook hands and talked.

New York University celebrated its 128th anniversary last night.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan threw his weight today behind a fight to remove amendments to the Taft-Hartley Law from the Kennedy-Ervin Labor-Reform bill.

The sale of Christmas Seals to help the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association fight T. B. naturally comes late in the year. But before the sale can be made truly effective there must be accurate, up-to-date mailing lists of mail purchasers. If the association's lists are not revised periodically they become obsolete.

Patronesses have been announced for the benefit flower festival, bridge and canasta party that the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church is sponsoring in the ballroom of the Pierre on Monday.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 17 (AP) -- Members of the American Newspaper Guild, which is conducting a strike against The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, filed incorporation papers today for a new morning newspaper in St. Louis.
A leader of the American Jewish Committee declared yesterday that the improvement of the nation's economic status was not reducing tensions among religious and ethnic groups.
A special filmed report made in Communist China will be shown by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, May 10.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 17 -- Kurdish tribesmen were strongly represented in a procession here today of the so-called Peace Partisans Congress.
DEER LODGE, Mont., April 17 -- Mutinous convicts at the Montana State Prison released two of twenty-three hostages late today but pressed new demands under threat of death for their captives.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that an engine failure, combined with an overload of gasoline and ice caused the plane crash that killed Mike Todd, the producer, and three other men last year.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A handwritten letter from the new Crown Princess of Japan is the prized joint possession of a Sacred Heart Alumnae Association here.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Dr. Peter Schlumbohm, who invents things in a New York penthouse, has discovered a way to take a perfect cup of coffee along with him on his trips to Long Island. It requires a pair of attached vacuum bottles, a tall one for black coffee and a short one for cream.
A Welfare Department investigator and seven other persons who had pleaded guilty to frauds received suspended sentences yesterday from Judge Thomas Dickens in General Sessions Court.
Pennsylvania blouse makers voted yesterday to accept tentative terms that would end their seventeen-day strike against more than 100 employers.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Western Senators showed their strength today in pushing through a resolution expressing the Senate's opposition to the sale of copper from the Government's stockpile.
BUENOS AIRES, April 17 (UPI) -- At least twenty-nine persons died as a result of floods in Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay this week, a check showed today.

PARIS, April 17 -- There have been Secretaries of State who held office longer than John Foster Dulles, namely Hull, Madison, Monroe, Fish and John Quincy Adams; and there have been Secretaries of State who had more consistent and successful careers, perhaps because they bore responsibility in easier times.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 17 (AP) -- Brian London whizzed through a two-hour workout today in preparation for his heavyweight championship bout with Floyd Patterson May 1. At least that's what his followers said.
Executives of the General Motors Corporation received substantially less compensation in 1958 than in 1957.

Supreme Court Justice Saul Streit reserved decision yesterday for at least one week on Sugar Ray Robinson's move to prevent the New York State Athletic Commission from vacating his world middleweight boxing championship.

HOUSTON, April 17 (UPI) -- Amiable Fred Haas Jr., playing only his fourth tournament this year, fired a six-under-par 66 today to tie for the lead at 134 with Arnold Palmer in the second round of the $30,000 Houston invitation golf classic.

Charges of violating union rules have been made against a group of supervisory pilots of Pan American World Airways by the Air Line Pilots Association. The union accused the pilots of flying jets without a contract.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Heads of the major party national committees today upheld the profession of politics as an honorable one and said teachers should participate in that field.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The seven Mercury Astronauts, one of whom may be America's first spaceman, have a lawyer to advise them on selling accounts of their lives and experiences in space.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today it had gathered from official Soviet sources detailed statistics on the Soviet Union's foreign trade. The figures are the first of their kind to be made public since 1938.
MAINE'S salmon anglers are in something of an uproar because the state's Sea-Run salmon Commission has opened the Narraguagus for black-salmon fishing.

WASHINGTON April 17 (AP) -- The State Department expressed dismay today at the timidity it said certain British newspapers were expressing toward the use of high-flying United States cargo planes on the air routes to Berlin in the face of Soviet objections.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- A United Nations committee declined today to act on a Soviet proposal to have the General Assembly frame a definition of aggression at its session later this year.

THE object of any work of art is to evoke an emotion. A book is a work of art or should be. It can evoke an emotion not only through the words it contains but through its color, size, shape and texture; even perhaps through its smell.

ALONG with the vast increase in the number of exhibitions of contemporary work there has been a steadily mounting interest in the careers and achievements of artists who made individual contributions to the mounting movement in the years between the First World War and the rise of non-figurative painting in the last decade.

The American Can Company introduced a can recently that could be opened with a key and then locked tight after use. The purpose: To protect oatmeal being shipped to tropical climates from excessive moisture.

Lee Petty, Jim Reed, Junior Thompson and Tom Pistone are among the nation's crack auto drivers who will compete when the Polo Grounds Speedway opens Saturday night at 8:15 o'clock. Petty is the NASCAR 1958 Grand National Circuit and Short Track champion.

Building permits for the week ended April 11 increased moderately to $1,383,000, but volume for the year has not yet overtaken that of 1958. Residential permits were issued in fairly substantial volume for the second successive week, totaling $621,000. Included were permits for forty new homes. The reduction in claims for state unemployment compensation continued in the week ended April 11.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A Government report on the 200 largest savings and loan associations shows that more than half of them are in five states and the rest widely scattered.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 18 -- A tremendous closing drive carried the Rutgers varsity crew to a four-foot victory over Columbia in a two-mile duel over the Rattan today.

There have been more spots observed in the sun in recent months than have ever been recorded before, it was reported last week by the Mount Wilson Solar Observatory, operated jointly by the California Institute of Technology and the Carnegie Institution of Washington. WHITE SPRINGS, Fla. -- One of the major events of the year at the Stephen Foster Memorial here is the Florida Folk Festival. Columbia's undefeated baseball team rolled up its seventh victory of the season behind the pitching of Walter Bernson, as it defeated Dartmouth, 6-3, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest at Baker Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- This city's Superintendent of Schools reported today that progress under the "four-track" system for the schools that he introduced three years ago had exceeded expectations and resulted in "a startling growth" in many respects.

Everett C. Drake has demonstrated his business ability from earliest childhood. But if he is asked what he bases his success on, he will answer that it has been a matter of timing -- that he always happened to be at the right place at the right time.
Prices of hides have about doubled in the last four months, and the consumer, as a result can expect higher retail prices for shoes next fall.

At various times you have published information on design and construction features desirable in a marina. Can you apprise me of the dates on which such data appeared and if possible furnish reprints of this material.

CAIRO, April 18 -- A representative of Saudi Arabia at the Arab petroleum congress meeting here said today the oil-producing countries had the right to modify or eliminate provisions in existing petroleum concessions.

DEER LODGE, Mont., April 18 -- National Guardsmen rescued twenty-one hostages from rioting convicts at Montana State Prison early today with an attack that put an end to thirty-six hours of rebellion.

BOSTON, April 18 -- Lest any wrong impressions get abroad as to what may be expected in the American League flag race this year, the Yankees today cracked down with a heavy hand on Mike Higgins' ambitious Red Sox, routing them, 16 -- 7.

THREE Polish children are separated from their parents during World War II. Their father is taken to prison camp, their mother to a German farm. Their house is blown up. Though this story tells of the terrible things war does to minds and bodies, it is essentially cheering, for its real concern is the good that war can, paradoxically, produce: courage, self-reliance, generosity and love.
On a recent visit to this country the Lord Mayor of Dublin, Mrs. Catherine Byrne, said: "You never know what the Irish are going to do. We like something out of the ordinary to happen now and then."
What follows are quotations, on various aspects of foreign policy and world affairs, from the writings, speeches and press conferences of retired Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.
ALBANY, April 18 (AP) -- Legislation setting up state controls on financial dealings of union leaders was signed today by Governor Rockefeller, who had proposed the bill.

ONE immediate, bright aftermath of the recent nontheatrical American Film Festival, which drew nation-wide attendance here, typifies the practical farsightedness of the sponsoring Educational Film Library Association, whose staff made the assembly perhaps the best-organized, large 16-mm undertaking of its kind to date.
The Port of New York Authority last year increased its investments in marine and air terminals here to $395,845,000, the agency's annual report, released last week, indicated.

THIS is a chatty, humorous and perceptive account of a journey which two Englishmen made in 1956 into Nuristan, a hard-to-reach and therefore mysterious region in northeast Afghanistan. Eric Newby, previously the author of "The Last Grain Race," was in the dress business in London and a complete novice at mountaineering.

FOLLOWING the recent publication in this country of two books concerned with Madame de Stael and her friends -- Maurice Levaillant's "Passionate Exiles" and J. Christopher Herold's "Mistress to an Age" -- Scribner's has reissued a modern biographical classic in which Madame de Stael plays a secondary but decisive role.

A VARIED program of thirteen amateur films, each with its own sound track, is scheduled for the twenty-sixth annual Gala Night Show of the Metropolitan Motion Picture Club. The program includes many prize winners in amateur film competitions. The event is to be held at 8 P. M. Saturday in the Assembly Hall of Hunter College at Sixty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- Navy's 150-pound varsity crew won the Callow Cup for the fourth straight year today. The Middies spurted away from Pennsylvania in the last 100 yards of the race on the Schuylkill.

WIDE boards and cabinet doors which have warped can frequently be straightened out by applying heat with an ordinary heat lamp on the convex side. Do not hold so close that the surface is burnt, and remove the source of heat as soon as the warp disappears.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Californians awoke this week to the existence of a threat against one of their long-established political institutions, the Presidential primary.
HARTFORD, April 18. -- The Finance Committees of the General Assembly approved this week a bond issue to finance a $346,000,000 state highway program in the next four years.

SEOUL, Korea, April 14 -- Two hundred and ninety-five houses for American military dependents will be available for occupancy in three key Korean cities by June 1, a spokesman for the United States Military Assistance Advisory Group in Korea has announced.
TEZPUR, India, April 18 -- The Dalai Lama, safe on Indian soil and free to speak his mind, accused the Chinese Communists today of having broken all their promises to respect Tibetan autonomy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Prospects for the European timber industry in 1959 are estimated as moderately favorable in a joint assessment by the Food and Agriculture Organization and the Economic Commission for Europe.

"I DO not believe in kowtowing to the taste of old-time habitues." This verdict on the Opera and the Opera-Comique was delivered by Andre Malraux, France's dynamic Minister of Cultural Affairs, and it showed that he intends to go all out in his drive to rejuvenate Paris' opera program.
It is only natural that many Asian intellectuals see recent Soviet experience as more relevant to their nation's needs than recent British or Amer ican experience. Much of it surely is more relevant.
GENEVA, April 18 -- A forty-nation conference convened to reduce statelessness ended in failure today.
BONN, Germany, April 18 -- Mr. Herter's appointment was welcomed in West German Government quarters today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- Asian countries are busy developing petroleum resources. Their prospects are encouraging, as their exploration and exploitation activities increasingly borrow new techniques.

Many of the nation's leading advertising agency people are to meet Thursday in the sylvan confines of White Sulphur Springs, West Va., to take stock of the state of the industry and to play some golf.

IT was strangely appropriate that when Sir Ernest Shackleton's ship was crushed and his men were cast away on the Antarctic ice he should have torn from the Bible, as solace, a page from the Book of Job. If any polar expedition suffered an ordeal comparable to Job's, it was Shackleton's.

NEW automatic slide projectors have been recently introduced by three major companies. The Anscomatic Projector, $119.50 machine for screening 35mm, 828 and 127 (superslide) slides in 2x2-inch mounts at pre-selected intervals of 5 to 60 seconds, is announced by Ansco of Binghamton.

EXPATRIATE Bohemia, in the old sense, is disappearing from the Paris scene. Rebellion, that indispensable ingredient of Bohemianism, is growing rare. As time passes there are fewer and fewer American expatriates here, and more and more Americans who are just abroad.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the city's Superintendent of Schools, suggested yesterday that an impartial, nonpartisan citizens' committee be formed to study the teacher salary problem.

AS if Victor Hugo had written about turbulent, despairing Egypt during the reign of chameleon-like King Farouk, gourmet and comic-book appreciator, Joan Vatsek fills in a broad Egyptian canvas depicting intrigue and violence resulting from the marrow-chilling poverty of the fellaheen from the tug-of-war of political leaders, from fevered love-duels, from the still more fevered spirit of nationalism fomented, oddly enough, by foreigners to the north.
When spring and the bulldozers come, Dr. Theodore Kazimiroff is never far behind. He is an Indian-relic buff.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 18 -- The Hungarian Communists, like other Communists in Eastern Europe, are placing great hopes on the forthcoming foreign ministers' and summit conferences.

ONCE there was, in far-off India, an elephant that ga-lumphed. He was a very ordinary elephant except for one thing: he just couldn't put his feet down quietly. He was the despair of all and, more shame, he was proud of himself.

LIBERALISM is based upon a deep belief in the sacredness of human freedom and emphasizes the importance of protecting and expanding that freedom. To me, the essence of liberalism is devotion to the principle of individual liberty.

MONTREAL, April 18 -- The Montreal Canadiens, flashing championship hockey form, won a record fourth consecutive Stanley Cup tonight as they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-3, and took the four-out-of-seven series, four games to one.

Writing in 1946, Charles Delaunay declared with enthusiasm that discography in its ten-year existence had become a "veritable science." It would appear that the lexicographers were less certain. "Discography" was not admitted to a dictionary until another decade had passed.

THE successor to Stan Musial as the best left-handed hitter in the National League is Bob Skinner, a gangling young man who patrols adequately the left-field sector for the Pittsburgh Pirates. At least the experts agree that he's the heir apparent. It also would seem that the players' fraternity holds him in the same high respect.
I must express my appreciation to Senator Javits for his article urging the establish ment of a United States Art Foundation.

THE glad tidings from this reviewer's corner are of the appearance of a newcomer possessed of an all-too-infrequent literary virtue -- the comic vision. Grace Paley is the writer, and heretofore, apparently, her light has been confined to some of the smaller quarterlies.

The Most Distinguished Alumnus Award of Horace Mann School was presented yesterday to Clayton (Bud) Collyer, television personality and president of the New York Chapter of the American Federation of Radio Artists.

THE handsome new installation of the Brooklyn Museum's Egyptian collection presents, for the first time, everything of importance and calls attention to the high quality of individual objects here dating from 1300 B. C. to the time of Christ.

About 3,000 employes of the United Parcel Service went on strike at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. Deliveries for most of the large department, furniture and specialty stores in the metropolitan area were canceled immediately.
Leading this week's art attractions is the big exhibition of oil paintings, water-colors, drawings, prints and sculpture by Paul Gauguin, which will open at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday.
As an active sports spectator, I would like to offer several reasons why baseball stadiums are rapidly becoming echo chambers and baseball teams are playing only to each other.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 18 -- On the Mount Holyoke College campus this morning a group of nutritious-looking girls in Bermuda shorts pedaled their bicycles slowly through a breeze that was gentle and cool -- and not hot like the literary breeze within Glesmann's drug store.
JUNEAU, Alaska, April 18 -- The first session of the first state Legislature of Alaska was history today.

MAN-MADE satellites have transformed astronomy into a more experimental science than either scientists or philosophers ever thought possible, and have led to talk about science on an unprecedented scale. John G. Kemeny, a brilliant philosopher - mathematician, tells us that his book is not science but philosophy of science, which is scientific talk about science.

Pioneer experiments suggesting the possibility of greatly enhancing the destructive effect on cancer of a given dose of radiation were described last week at the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology at Atlantic City.

SKANEATELES, N. Y., April 18 (AP) -- The State Health Department officer who reported finding a possible relationship between naturally radioactive rocky terrain and malformations in infants listed today the towns where he found what he called an unusually high number of malformations.

THE Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., will present its April Garden Show from 1 to 4:30 P. M. on Wednesday in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, 160 Central Park South. Horticultural and artistic classes will feature narcissus.
TOKYO, April 18 -- A "talking magazine" appeared on Japanese newsstands today without advance publicity.

THE philosophy of political liberalism is not the private property of either major political party in the United States. Rather is it the indispensable ingredient in both parties which most often generates the vigor, provides the flexibility, and supplies the vision required to shape forward-looking policies and programs that will best meet the fast-changing needs of our society and of the free world.

Emil Dolce's Manassa Mauler packed the punch of Jack Dempsey in winning the $88,100 Wood Memorial at Jamaica yesterday. Competing in a 3-year-old field that included First Landing, Atoll and Intentionally, Manassa Mauler, 64 to 1, scored a smashing victory that amazed the crowd of 40,063.

TRENTON -- One of the most popular sports in New Jersey, from now through late November, is canoeing. The little craft can be rented at a number of the 800 lakes, and ponds that iot the state from Delaware Breakwater to the Palisades as well as at points along some of the rivers and streams. Boat iveries are numerous and the usual rental fee is $2 to $4 a day.

The American Merchant Marine Institute and the New York Tow Boat Exchange favor a Sunday-to-Friday closing of Arthur Kill to navigation. They prefer this to the Monday-to-Saturday closing that is being sought in connection with the building of the new railroad bridge between Elizabeth, N. J., and Howland Hook, S. I.

Compliance with the Federal Welfare and Pension Plans Disclosure Act is lagging. Many of the reports required by the law were not received on April 1, when they were to be filed with the Department of Labor.
WITHIN the past several years a difficult-to-control armored scale insect has become increasingly serious on hemlock trees from Massachusetts to Maryland. It sometimes infests fir and spruce.

The Foreign Policy Association said yesterday that a sampling of 4,500 people who had just completed a two-month study program on current challenges to United States foreign policy showed that 90 per cent supported greater use of the United Nations by the United States.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation plant at San Pedro, Calif. lart week submitted the apparent low bid for the construction of three new cargo ships for American Mail Lines of Seattle, Wash., it has been announced by the Maritime Administration.

New York City's Board of Estimate is composed of the Mayor, the Comptroller, the President of the City Council and the Presidents of the five boroughs. Its principal job is to pass on the city's budget. Last week the Board opened public hearings on Mayor Wagner's budget for fiscal 1959-1960, which starts July 1. The budget calls for $2.1 billion in expenditures -- the city's first over the $2 billion mark.
With another Treasury refunding in the offing the Government securities market seems more unprepared than ever for any attempt to lengthen the maturity of the Federal debt.

Wall Street received a double-barreled stimulus last week, which carried stock prices to historic highs. The first shot in the arm came from sharp advances in drug issues. These were in the limelight because of a flurry of reports of promising progress in several important fields of medicine.
HAVANA -- As a special inducement for spring tourists, Cuba's new revolutionary Government is sponsoring a late carnival season. It began last Saturday and will continue through May 3.
The zoning ordinance announced last February will be discussed and evaluated extensively before a definite proposal is offered to the Board of Estimate for approval, James Felt said yesterday.

This past week in the sprawling Palazzo dei Congressi on the outskirts of Rome, veterans' leaders from thirty-six nations met to discuss world politics, veterans' legislation and rehabilitation of the handicapped.

HARDY phlox provides a long season of colorful bloom in the garden after early-flowering perennials have died. Phlox is all the more welcome since peak bloom comes in the heat of midsummer when few other plants are showy.

MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company and the United Auto Workers reached agreement today on settlement of strikes at eight plants that had kept 14,000 U. A. W. members idle since Feb. 2.
More than 1,200 newspaper executives will gather in New York this week for the seventy-third annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
Louis XV furniture and other French period pieces will be auctioned on Saturday at the Parke - Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
GENUINE liberalism is less a system of doctrines or programs than an attitude and an approach to the affairs of men.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Discoverer II satellite is now expected to plunge to destruction in the earth's atmosphere in three to five days, some twenty days earlier than had first been estimated.

An old gesture of sentiment, long cherished by West Side longshoremen, has been abandoned by dockers at the Grace Line terminal in favor of a more practical way of showing their respect for men who die on the piers.

The Police Department, always at pains to insure the safety of visiting dignitaries, will provide maximum protection for Premier Fidel Castro when the Cuban revolutionary leader visits New York this week.
LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- California's new Democratic Governor stirred speculation about his possible 1960 national campaign role this week with an unusual flier in political salesmanship.

Trinity School, 139 West Ninety-first Street, which once occupied the belfry tower of Trinity Church on lower Broadway when New York was little more than a village, is celebrating its 250th anniversary with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel April 27. . . . A summer institute on the sociology of American Catholicism will be held at Boston College June 22-27. . . .

Resident offices report that warmer weather through much of the country has stimulated the sale of cotton dresses, coordinates and cotton and silk suits. Newly created styles in these items have moved quickly from factories to stores.

Final plans have been made for the annual bridge party of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island. The Grand Ballroom of the St. George in Brooklyn will be the setting for the fete next Friday afternoon.

LONDON -- Statistically the Thames, 210 miles long -- and rarely, if ever, wide enough for one to be unable to make out whether a man riding a bicycle on the other side is wearing a beard -- is not a very significant river matched with, say, the Mississippi, which is eleven times longer.
An unheralded javelin thrower from the University of Connecticut accounted for the most significant achievement of the fifth annual Queens-Iona Relay Carnival yesterday.

TEN years ago I noted in these columns: "There is, unfortunately, no book which does for American proverbs what Apperson and Smith do for British." Now we welcome here a book which fills that need for American proverbs published between 1820 and 1880.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., April 18 -- Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, wrote off Governor Rockefeller today as a possible Republican candidate for the Presidency next year.

Baseball returned to Flatbush yesterday. The game, the players and the grandstand crowd were only a diminutive version of years past, but the enthusiasm was as adult as any ever displayed at Ebbets Field.

A purplish green pigeon, the feathered friend of 11-year-old Sandra Gary, is back in the old homestead again. On April 13 the bird laid an egg on Sandra's windowsill on the thirteenth floor of 1212 Fifth Avenue. Last year the same bird laid two eggs on the windowsill on June 13.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- At 4 P. M. the day after tomorrow Dr. Fidel Castro, Prime Minister of Cuba, will -- if he can be prevailed upon not to shake the hand of everyone in the waiting room, or make a speech, or hold an impromptu press conference -- board a train in Union Station here and head for Princeton, N. J.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- The concern of Californians and residents of Southwestern states over water supplies for 1959 was reflected this week in report from snow surveys throughout the West.
An operation reminiscent of turn - of - the - century pierside cargo handling has been started in Port Newark.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 18 -- Rhodes scholars spending a third year at Oxford University may now be allowed to marry without forfeiting their scholarships.

WHEN television was very young, a company that made eyelash curlers sent one of its products to a staff member of the Milton Berle show. She would be allowed to keep the curler if she would persuade Sophie Tucker, a guest, to use Lit during the program. The $2 curler was returned. It almost figured in history's first television plug.

Leo Durocher, fresh from the Coast for his week-end National Broadcasting Company broadcast, reports that the Roy Campanella benefit game between the Yanks and the Dodgers in the Los Angeles Stadium on May 7 will draw "about 90,000."
Life insurance companies are taking many occupations out of the hazardous class and lowering the premiums for persons engaged in such endeavors.
COVERING up the architectural errors in many of New York City's older apartments presents a major challenge to the interior designer.

PEIPING, April 18 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China insisted today that the Dalai Lama of Tibet had been "abducted" to India. Mr. Chou voiced the hope that the Tibetan leader would be able to "free" himself.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 18 -- A national boycott of goods manufactured by supporters of apartheid -- racial segregation -- is being considered by the African National Congress.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Christian Archibald Herter, soon to be seventieth Secretary of State of the United States, is an authentic son of the Atlantic community.

A NEW kind of plastic rain gutter and downspout can be installed on any house, and, under normal use, will never require painting or other maintenance. Reinforced with Fibreglass and called Permadrain, the new gutters and downspouts do not rot, rust or split due to freezing.

AT book length Art Buchwald seems an original and altogether diverting anomaly, like a banquet of sumptuous splendor and endless variety composed exclusively of hors d'oeuvres. But, if Art is fleeting, Time is long.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he had not asked George P. Monaghan, the Harness Racing Commissioner, to resign.

MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- A declaration has been drafted to put the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations on record as approving in principle freedom of information. It will be submitted by the United States to the council at is first plenary session here. The council probably will deal with the declaration Monday.

I want to protest the review by Robert Trumbull of B. R. Nanda's "Mahatma Gandhi." In his effort to slap Nehru's wrist for what he thinks is Nehru's insufficient anti-communism, he succeeds in making Gandhi merely one more anti-Communist.
Sir Winston Churchill has described the role of the United States in the post-war world as "the great counter-poise upon which the freedom and future of our civilization depends."

ANYONE interested in the magical fleshing of a towering American literary figure, departed forty-nine years ago Tuesday, and an evocation of the dusty lyceums and vanished Chautauquas in which he lectured, may witness both by a rite no more occult than going to the Forty-first Street Theatre, where a 34-year-old actor named Hal Holbrook is playing a 70-year-old writer named Mark Twain.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The American Bar Association was urged today to reconsider its recent call for Congressional revision of Supreme Court decisions on internal security matters. The American Civil Liberties Union, in a letter to the Bar Association's Board of Governors, said that the bar's proposalswould upset this country's "precious balance" between individual freedom and security restrictions.

Tezpur is a quiet town in the northeastern corner of India, a town whose people tend the tea gardens on the slopes of the Himalayan foothills while planters of the old school sip gin and lime and discuss tiger shoots at their club. Recently, Tezpur has been jolted out of its customary drowsiness by the rebellion hundreds of miles away in Tibet.
STILLWATER, Okla., April 18 (AP) -- Terry McCann of Tulsa won his third straight title tonight in the national Amateur Athletic Union wrestling tournament.
THE battle over television in Central America, getting more heated month by month, at this moment is centering on Costa Rica.
The results of the first two months of "double bottom" truck operation on the New York Thruway have been "encouraging," according to Clinton B. F. Brill, Chairman of the Thruway Authority.
MEXICO CITY, April 17 -- A program to rehabilitate housing and pipe water into the 80 per cent of rural homes that lack it will get under way here about the end of this year.

ON the southern tip of Vancouver Island are some of the world's horticultural spectaculars - the rock gardens of Victoria, B. C. Protected from the Arctic chill by mountain ranges and warmed by the Japanese sea current, Victoria is favored by great natural outcroppings of rock that edge the coastline.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- The danger of referendum action hung this week-end over California's new Fair Employment Practices Act.

THIS, the first authoritative biography of John Millington Synge, is the story of a miracle. Like Synge's own "Playboy of the Western World," it tells of "a quiet, simple poor fellow with no man giving me heed" who was transformed into "a great hand at racing and lepping and licking the world."

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 18 -- Warren Sausville of Roslyn, L. I., won the New York Athletic Club's handicap trapshooting championship today by a single target. He broke eighteen out of twenty-five targets in a shoot-off with Ralph Matregano at Travers Island.
SINGAPORE, April 18 -- Political circles here were thrown into turmoil this morning by the resignation of Mayor Ong Eng Guan and thirteen members of the City Council.
PROVIDENCE, April 18 -- Dartmouth's favored heavy-weight crew rallied in the last half-mile today to beat Brown on the Seekonk River.

EVER since John Lomax, some fifty years ago, introduced Harvard and the world to cowboy songs and ballads, we have grown to expect much of Texas folklore and the distinguished company of Texas folklorists who have followed him.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 17 -- Venezuela's fiscal situation has improved to the point where a foreign loan will not be needed, an official spokesman said this week.
Miss Dawn Mello has been appointed coordinator of fashion accessories of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, here. Since 1956, Miss Mello has been assistant fashion coordinator of B. Altman Co.

A LOCAL film company, like the scientists who have sent satellites into orbit around our comparatively tiny planet, is preparing to probe the mysteries of the universe. Last week, it was learned that Storyboard, Inc., has acquired rights to Dr. Harlow Shapley's book, "Of Stars and Men," as source material for its first feature-length production.
CLEVELAND, April 18 (AP) -- The Lake Carriers Association elected five new directors and a new treasurer at an annual meeting this week.

A New York bank securities dealer predicted last week that banking would expand more in the next decade than it has in the last. Morris A. Schapiro of the investment concern bearing his name, said that the volume and variety of services would be increased as banks strived to meet the competition for public patronage among banks and from nonbank financial sources.

PARIS, April 18 (AP) -- Wine producers of southern France, nursing a massive forty-year-old headache that has nothing to do with imbibing their own product, are calling for a remedy, from the Government.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 18 (AP) -- Sweden's Ingemar Johansson has hired a seasoned New York trainer, Whitey Bimstein, to help him prepare for his title fight with the world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, at Yankee Stadium on June 25.
The tenth anniversary of the death of Rabbi Stephen S. Wise was commemorated in several synagogues over the city yesterday and Friday.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- The keel for the first of two 485-foot-long cargo passenger ships will be laid by Todd Shipyards Corporation in its Los Angeles harbor yard May 11. This was announced today by J. T. Gilbride, president of the corporation.
LONDON, April 18 -- The prospect of being outside a European "common market" in civil aviation is adding to Britain's air worries.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- A massive reorganization of Soviet sports, aimed at drawing 50,000,000 citizens into regular sports activities in the next seven years, has begun in Moscow. More than 500 delegates, the bulk of them members of the Communist party and Communist youth organizations and trade unionists, gathered in Moscow yesterday to form a new central body to be called the Union of Sports Societies and Organizations of U.S.S.R.

The decision of the New York delegation to Congress to act as a unit in promoting the state's economic interests was seen yesterday as a major gain in the Rockefeller Administration's drive to improve job opportunities.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent word to a delegation of student youth marchers today that he would never be satisfied until the last vestige of racial discrimination had disappeared in this country.
THE Eastern varmint hunter is grinding his teeth now about what he is fixing to do to the woodchucks and crows. They are really the only varmints in this batch of territory that count for much.
IF Mark Twain was as pungent on the lecture platform as Hal Holbrook is on the stage of the 41st Street Theatre, no wonder America, England and Europe were vastly entertained.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- When the new Secretary of State closes the door of John Foster Dulles' old office on the fifth floor of the State Department, he will find himself alone with a perplexing and frightening accumulation of foreign policy problems.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon brushed aside tonight suggestions that he might seek a third term as Vice President if he could not win the Republican Presidential nomination.

MORE than a century ago, it was customary for the Union Debating Societies in Oxford and Cambridge to use as a theme for discussion the rights and wrongs of the English civil war -- one side supporting the King and the other Parliament.
I was very glad to read that New York is among those states which are preparing the way for more realistic speed limits through scientific determination.

NORTH BRANFORD, Conn., April 18 (AP) -- A North Branford town official shot and killed his wife in their home here today. He then wounded his daughter, and attempted to kill himself with a carving knife.

A NEW fruit, the apple-crab, has been introduced by the Minnesota Agricultural Experiment Station after years of testing. The apple-crab combines the good qualities of both the apple and the crabapple.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 18 -- The New York Athletic Club eight and Fordham's varsity were among the winners in the New York Rowing Association's regatta for schools, colleges and clubs off Travers Island today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 18 (AP) -- The cooperative planning conference of the National Protestant Council today approved plans to increase the number of bilingual ministers in areas of the United States with large Puerto Rican and other Spanish-speaking groups.
The question of integration was injected into the field of school textbooks last week as the Board of Education requested textbook publishers to consider using "nonwhite illustrations."

Your lead editorial of April 15 refers to Vice President Nixon's proposal that the International Court of Justice be empowered to make "binding decisions" as designed to establish a peaceful world in which the rule of force will have been supplanted by the rule of law.

LIKE a number of recent fictional witches, Clancy's is really a good sort. Capable, hard-working, she uses all the traditional tools of her sisterhood (seven black pots, seven black cats and thirteen brooms), but her job is to unhaunt houses, in this case Number 13 Moody Street. Clancy, the small boy next door, discovers this after some extraordinary phenomena have bewildered the grownups in the neighborhood.

IN view of the tears wept here, almost a year ago, about the dearth of chamber music recordings on stereo, it is only fitting that the yeoman work of Concert-Disc now be mentioned. This noble company, which operates in Illinois, has just issued the first stereo recordings of eight disks ranging from Mozart through Bartok.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, B. W. I. -- Just over one year ago the British West Indies became a new, single nation, uniting under its Federal flag many islands scattered across a thousand miles of the Caribbean.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will meet on Tuesday to consider the nomination of Christian A. Herter as Secretary of State. Quick approval is assured.
Among the problems facing the American maritime industry are three of major proportions, Leigh R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said last week.
CHICAGO, April 18 (UPI) -- Tom Morgan stifled a seventh-inning rally today to give Billy Hoeft and the Detroit Tigers their first victory of the season, 5 -- 2, over the Chicago White Sox.

Chancellor Adenauer's willingness to assume the Presidency of West Germany has caused wide speculation about the political role which he might play in the new office. It is therefore important to note that the constitutional provisions for the Presidency are not as vague as would be implied in the statement of your editorial of April 8 that "The German Presidency is what a strong man can make it * * *."
DERBY, Conn., April 18 (AP) -- Three Yale crews successfully opend their heavyweight rowing season this afternoon, defeating Boston University rivals on the Housatonic River.

TEANECK, N. J., April 18 -- The Bergen Community Museum will open a series of seminars for adults tomorrow night at its headquarters on Fort Lee Road here. Richard Ammerman of Rutherford will speak on the Dutch settlers of Bergen County.

JAPANESE producers are preparing the tools of their trade for some tricky and sensitive shooting. Toho Studios has scheduled a film featuring veteran actress Setsuko Hara as Amaterasuomikami, the Sun Goddess and Toshiro Mifune as Takerunomikoto Yamato, the founder of the Yamato, or Japanese race, and a descendant of the Sun Goddess.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 -- Princeton University has elected two vice presidents for the first time in the 213 years since it was founded as the College of New Jersey in 1745.

Leslie Bassett's Five Pieces for String Quartet provided the high point of yesterday afternoon's concert of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors. It was the last of four Carnegie Recital Hall programs this season.

The announced intention of the New York State Traffic Commission to undertake an intensive study of the driving habits of motorists -- with the view toward making speed limits on highways more compatible with the rates of speed at which most drivers travel -- is a major stride forward in helping to make our highways safer.

Roger Kahn writes feelingly about baseball with some apprehension as to its future. Baseball owners, managers, players, writers, sing nearly the same theme with no suggestions that might change the game to revive interest in it.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 18 (AP) -- Dave Mills, Purdue's sensational freshman sprinter, twice defeated Glenn Davis, an Olympic champion, today at the seventeenth annual Ohio Relays.
LONDON, April 18 -- The Iraqi Embassy has denied that Baghdad had put pressure on Iraqi students in Britain to join only a students' society approved by the Kassim Government.
A storm is blowing up in shipping circles over proposed changes in the Coast Guard's administrative procedures.
King Hussein of Jordan received Mayor Wagner in the Presidential suite at the Waldorf Tower yesterday two and a half hours before the King boarded a plane for London.

MACON, Ga. -- Just outside this city stands the Ocmulgee National Monument which this year is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary, but whose purpose is to record activities there over a vastly greater period of time -- no less than 10,000 years.

DEEP in the North African desert, Belele shimmers and drowses in the dry, burning air. Long ago the Portuguese had built a castle there and flown their banner from the main tower before they drifted away, leaving the place to the lizards and the wind that piled the sand against the walls.

YACHTING in the Caribbean is another rich man's pastime now within reach of anyone with a two-week vacation and enough cash to stay at a good resort hotel in the United States. Two of us chartered a boat, complete with a British captain as sea-worthy as the 36-foot ketch itself, and sailed southward from Antigua along the West Indies island chain.

The late Frank Lloyd Wright's famous workshops, Taliesen West, at Scottsdale near Phoenix, Ariz., and Taliesen at Spring Green, Wis., which he conducted as an architectural school based on actual practice, will be continued in the same manner by the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation.

ABOUT a year ago I was complaining in this space that Robert Bloch, as a murder writer, is rarely as effective as he can and should be. Now, in his sixth suspense novel, PSYCHO (Simon Schuster, $2.95), he is more chillingly effective than any writer might reasonably be expected to be, and I will have my words with sauce bearnaise please.

THE daturas, close relatives of the petunia, tomato and eggplant, create bold accents in the border. As a green-and-white annual hedge they are cucumber-cool. With vivid annuals they provide dramatic contrast. Typical flower forms resemble gigantic petunias. The plants are similar in size and shape to the eggplant.
PARIS, April 18 -- Mr. Herter's nomination was welcomed today with satisfaction but not surprise.

While I do not want to take issue with the Senator's thesis -- it may be that direct subsidies of the kind he suggests may become necessary -- I think it should be pointed out that the arts in the United States already enjoy very substantial indirect subsidies through the operation of the income tax laws.

Steel wages and steel prices have bounded upward in tandem during the last ten years. Average hourly earnings have risen from $1.65 an hour in 1949 to $3.03 now. Wholesale prices of iron and steel as measured by the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index (1947-49 equals 100) have risen from 106 to 172 in the same period.
Plans are being completed by Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, chairman, and her committee for the annual benefit for the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

The Southampton (L. I.) Hospital, which this year is celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of its founding, will benefit from the third Midsummer Night Ball, to be held at the Meadow Club in Southampton on July 18.
The purpose of this letter is to utter a loud amen, by way of a bit of autobiography, to Professor Hook's paragraph beginning, "Above all, we must heal the wounds of the Civil War * * * ".

"HUGHIE" is the last play by Eugene O'Neill that is likely to be published. Ironically, in view of the fact that O'Neill spent a lifetime planning and writing double and triple-length plays and play-cycles, this final, posthumous volume is one of his shortest.
WARSAW, April 18 -- The Polish press has carried its first word of the Papal ban against Roman Catholic voting for Communist candidates.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- A cross-section of the nation's newspaper editors believes that Vice President Richard M. Nixon will be the Republican Presidential nominee next year and that the Democrats may tap Adlai E. Stevenson again to challenge him.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The office of Secretary of State in the Cabinet, where Christian A. Herter is about to succeed John Foster Dulles, was the final stepping-stone to the Presidency or to the Presidential nomination of a major party until the Eighteen Eighties. Since then no incumbent has risen to either height (one had previously been a nominee) though some have been ambitious to do so.

CONVENTIONAL darkroom processing has been reduced to the amazing simplicity of a single bath virtually free of time and temperature restrictions. The revolutionary new product that makes it possible is Cormac Unibath, the invention of Harry S. Keelan, a photo chemist. The product was introduced yesterday at the National Photographic Show in the Coliseum by the Cormac Chemical Corporation, 80 Fifth Avenue.

KINGSTON, N. Y., April 18 -- A visit of Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands has been includede on a program being prepared for celebration of the 300th anniversary of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church.

The Communists, like the poor, are always with us, and Latin America is no exception. In recent weeks we have seen Russian diplomatic representatives expelled from Mexico and Argentina for being involved in strikes of violence. Red nationals in both these countries were arrested. In Uruguay the Government was reported recently to be considering a rupture of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

BOOKS on wine can be as ponderous and dull as a chemistry manual. Most of them are written with connoisseurs in mind and the rank amateur, eager though he may be to penetrate the mysteries of wines, is frequently lost in a vineyard of obscure terms such as "cuvage" and "chaptalization."*.
Despite the earnest efforts of the city's Fire Department and of many employers and workers, New York's loft district remains an explosive tinder box -- the worst fire hazard in the city.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 -- Navy's varsity eight - oared crew, largely the same that finished second to Cornell in the championship of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association last June, defeated Princeton on Carnegie Lake today in the season's opening regatta for both crews.

ONE of the most attractive ways of introducing native wild flowers on the home landscape is to plant them in a rock garden. The home owner who plans to start a wildflower rockery or add plants to an existing rock garden can purchase or dig and transplant many of the native species this month.
Oslo, Oshkosh or Olongapo -- it happens all over. In spring, fancy turns naturally to thoughts of flowers. And Interflora rejoices.
MOVIE producers, who have always had enough troubles trying to anticipate the taste of the American public, are doubly harassed these days in guessing what foreigners would prefer in American movies.

In your issue of March 29, 1959, you reproduced an interior scene of a New York apartment. The caption under the picture reported that the room was "decorated almost authentically in Japanese manner" including "isolated decorations such as a painting."
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 18 -- The Government took control today of Pakistan's biggest chain of newspapers, the Pakistan Times group. and dismissed the management.
SINGAPORE, April 16 (Reuters) -- The Government has accused Communist publishing houses of distorting Chinese classics.

The imagination of James H. Rand 3d has brought forth such varied inventions as a metallic-coated fabric which he says is many times warmer than wool, an air mattress that massages the bodies of sick people and prevents bed sores, a better drying process for automatic washing machines and an improved system for regulating the supply of oxygen in airplane cabins.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- It was a modest establishment indeed that Thomas Jefferson directed as the nation's first Secretary of State: two chief clerks, three other clerks, a French interpreter and two messengers. The Secretary's salary was $3,500 and the budget for the entire department in its first year of existence was $5,950.

Retailers who were slow in promoting merchandise before Easter are making up for lost time. This is evident in the gains made by department stores in the week ended on April 11, when they chalked up an advance of 18 per cent over the corresponding week of last year.

WITH its facilities considerably expanded over previous years, the thirteenth annual National Photographic Show opened yesterday at the Coliseum with a varied and balanced program of activities and exhibits which will last through next Sunday.

The President's nomination of Christian A. Herter to succeed John Foster Dulles as Secretary of State reminds us again that in a democracy there can be no indispensable man. We again salute Mr. Dulles as he hauls down his flag of office, we again acknowledge his six heroic years of service in his terrific job, but he would be the last to ask us to believe that his retreat will change the course of history.
LAUREL, Md., April 18 (AP) -- Rare Rice provided Mrs. Ada L. Rice of Chicago with a dark-horse candidate for the Kentucky Derby by leading all the way in winning the $29,500 Chesapeake Stakes today.
Eight Japanese newsmen will attend a series of seminars at Columbia University beginning tomorrow in an attempt to learn about American science-writing techniques.

THOSE, who take a professional interest in promoting interest in bridge-playing -- the playing-card manufacturers, the tournament associations such as the American Contract Bridge League and the bridge teachers and tournament directors -- have long acknowledged team matches to be the best breeding ground of future serious bridge players.

A lecturer in Hebrew and Semitic Studies at Emerson College in Boston has come into possession of a copy of the first Hebrew prayerbook printed in the Soviet Union in the last forty-two years. The book is not without propaganda overtones.

O. Ray Chalk, financier, promised yesterday he would give the city administration a price on Friday as his bid for all of the municipally owned rapid transit system. Mr. Chalk heads a syndicate of investors who would like to buy the system and operate it for profit.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand April 10 -- New Zealand has further to go than many other countries before emerging from a recession. Yet unemployment is so small as to be negligible. In fact there are more vacant jobs than unemployed.
Whitney North Seymour's article on Judge Learned Hand ("Tribute to the 'Old Chief' of the Bench," April 5) was a useful reminder of a half-.
LONDON, April 18 -- The British government expressed today its warm approval of the appointment of Christian A. Herter as United States Secretary of State.

Experiments indicating that the learning process is directly related to a decrease in the electrical resistance in the portion of the brain known as the hypothalamus were described last week at the annual meeting of the American Physiological Society at Atlantic City, N. J., by George W. Brown, Ph. D., principal scientist in the medical research laboratory of the Veterans Administration Hospital at Iowa City, Iowa.

ACROSS the front of the jacket of Hugh Ross Williamson's latest historical diversion his publishers have spread the legend, "The True story of Elizabeth and Mary Tudor," and opposite its first page they have put a notice to the reader: "The book reads like a novel.

Sooner than later the world of pleasure boating is going to expect all the Central Park lakes in the country and all the bodies of water such as those that beautify Prospect Park in Brooklyn will be turned over to small-fry sailors.

Revolutionary changes are taking place in Soviet economic planning and thinking as a result of recent decisions to take over Western concepts and techniques. These innovations may substantially improve the operation of the Soviet economy.
BUENOS AIRES, April 18 -- President Arturo Frondizi has adopted the White House technique of the presidential news conference to parry and thrust with the many critics of his regime.

UNPRECEDENTED acceleration in production and apparently in consumer demand has brought the 35mm single-lens reflex camera design up to the fore in popular favor. If the trend continues to grow at the present pace, it is not improbable that the reflex may even threaten the supremacy of the 35mm rangefinder camera, the established leader.

LONG ago, Shakespeare, in speaking of the vagaries of love, compared them to "the uncertain glory of an April day." As usual, he was apt. Now is the season of weather's pretty fickleness and ahead lie the summer days when sun will give way to squalls and fog will yield to the clean sweep of a northwest wind -- all in a matter of hours.
