SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Jack Sanford of the San Francisco Giants survived a siege of wildness in the first inning today and set the St. Louis Cardinals down, 8 -- 1, with one-hit pitching.
A DELECTABLE way to give spring menus a lift is with a dessert laced with rum. For generations, here and abroad, rum has been used to add its magic touch to some of the great dessert masterpieces.
DARIEN, Conn., April 18 -- Town officials here are pondering whether to use an as yet unpurchased sixty-three acre tract as a public park or as a real estate development.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Through the failure of a temperamental second-stage rocket, the United States failed this week to score a spectacular triple play in space by placing three satellites into orbit on the same day.
AT a recent national conference of the Society of Plastics Engineers, the chairman began his speech by addressing the 2,000 members present as follows: "Lady -- and gentlemen."

Manassa Mauler upset a field that included three leading Kentucky Derby candidates in winning the $88,100 Wood Memorial at Jamaica yesterday. Manassa Mauler was not nominated for the Derby. Ridden by Ray Broussard, he triumphed by three-quarters of a length and paid $129.50 for $2 to win. First Landing was second and Our Dad third.
WITH the start of the annual summer rush abroad only about two months away, many attractive low-cost opportunities still exist for the student traveler who has been late in making plans.

SCENE designer - producer Leo Kerz, whose devotion to Marcel Ayme finally resulted in a rewarding production here of the French playwright's "Clerambard," is proving equally dedicated in behalf of M. Ayme's "Moonbirds."

The nation's growing need for college teachers is usually estimated at 30,000 to 40,000 a year for the next ten years. The colleges would prefer persons with Ph. D. degrees. The demands of government and industry for Ph. D.'s are growing even faster, in the view of some Federal manpower officials.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- Only a few delegates who worked with John Foster Dulles in the early days of the United Nations are still connected with the organization.
An increasingly acute surplus of tankers appears to be inevitable in the years immediately ahead unless there is a substantial rise in the world demand for ocean transportation of oil.
PARIS, April 18 -- Continuing his tour of south-central France today, President Charles de Gaulle left an enigma behind him in Montlucon and a soft gesture to discontented wine growers at Macon.
THE recent comprehensive article by Joseph C. Ingraham about speed limits in the State of New York points up a pressing problem that certainly needs correction.

The 150th anniversary of the founding of the Sisters of Charity, a Roman Catholic teaching and charitable order, was marked yesterday at a pontifical mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal Spellman was the celebrant.

THE article "A Family Grows Up in a Car" described a very delightful trip for a family of five, noting all the benefits of taking a long trip in a car (my family and I agree whole-heartedly), and then proceeded to discourage ninety-nine out of every 100 readers by concluding that two weeks are not enough.
Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, cautioned against "jumping on educational bandwagons" in her report yesterday for the 1956-58 school years.
HONG KONG, April 18 -- Premier Chou said in his report today that the Tibetan people had "warmly welcomed" the taking over the powers of the dissolved local government by the Preparatory Committee.
The third annual luncheon of the St. Francis Cardiac Guild will be given on May 20 at the Plaza for the benefit of St. Francis Hospital and Sanatorium in Roslyn, L. I.

WHEN Hilde Somer practices the piano in her Manhattan apartment, she can look out on a terrace garden that is colorful from summer until frost. Despite a busy concert schedule, she grows all annuals from seed sown in a miniature greenhouse in April.

An analysis of large contracts awarded for new industrial plants in the Chicago metropolitan area during 1958 and the five years 1954-1958 highlighted the heavy expenditures made in the area by primary metal firms.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The nation, but not New York City, has been gradually reducing the number of dilapidated dwelling places.

BONN, Germany, April 18 -- The cancellation by Nikita S. Khrushchev of his May 27 deadline and his agreement to negotiate on Berlin have obscured the hard fact that the Western allies will be negotiating with the Soviet Union in the coming months under duress.

When the graceful weeping cherries are laden with blossoms it is time for motorists to take to the highways. Nature lovers planning trips this week-end to see spring bloom will not be disappointed. Besides the early flowering cherry trees, magnolias, forsythia, daffodils, hyacinths and waterlily tulips brighten the New York City area. Those who are headed South will find brilliant displays of azaleas, red buds, and crabapples.

FOR THIS WEEK: Finish pruning rosebushes. . . . Plant hardy seed and perennials. . . . Move trees and shrubbery. . . . Set out strawberries soon after they arrive from nurseries. . . . Divide fall-blooming peren nials now -- chrysanthemums, asters and hardy ageratums. . . . Prune old forsythia shrubs after flower petals fall. . . . Grub-proof lawns with chlordane-DDT mixture. . . . Plant the hardy waterlilies.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 18 (AP) -- W. F. Miller's Better Bee whipped Belleau Chief by a half-length in a furious stretch duel today in the $25,000 Southern Handicap at Gulf-stream Park.
WARSAW, April 18 -- Polish Communists are discussing the possibility of a temporary shift in the Government leadership that would make Wladyslaw Gomulka Premier.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- The Philadelphia Fellowship Commission honored the motion-picture industry here tonight for its production of films that help to promote racial and religious understanding.

The Rev. John LaFarge, prominent Roman Catholic clergyman, warned last night that the increased dissemination of hate literature in the United States could have a serious, long-range effect on the nation's youth.

The Texas Club of New York City will celebrate its golden anniversary at its annual San Jacinto party Tuesday in the ballroom of the Pierre. Proceeds of the event will go to the club's scholarship fund.

The national economy is built on pillars of steel. For each of the 500,000 workers directly employed in steel mills, nine others hold jobs in plants making steel products. The total accounts for more than one-third of all factory employment.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 -- Wayne Hardin, described as "a man who knows the problems at the Naval Academy and sympathizes with them," was named head football coach at Navy today to succeed Eddie Erdelatz.
LONDON, April 18 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told his countrymen today that appeasement or retreat were out of the question in the series of high-level meetings he seeks with the Soviet Union.

"KIDS are lucky who grow up in a small town," a city-bred girl in her earliest twenties complained to an older friend. "If you live in a small town you can come to the city. APPARENTLY man's pride always needs puncturing. Each age is intoxicated by its own illusions. Today our sense of progress and well-being is constantly fed by the presence of efficient plumbing and spectacular automobiles, of tall buildings and even taller advertising.
LANSING, Mich., April 18 -- A showdown in Michigan's cash crisis appeared imminent today.
MANHASSET, L. I., April 18 -- North Hempstead taxpayers voted today to build a 600-ton incinerator on the shore of Hempstead Harbor.
GARFIELD, N. J., April 18 -- This industrial city on the Passaic River, which lost two large manufacturing operations in the last year, is finding a new sense of well-being through diversification.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Of the 60,000,000 persons who had filed a Federal income tax return by last Wednesday midnight, upwards of 3,000,000 are going to wind up eventually paying the Government more money, if past experience is a guide.

John A. Birch, chief of the State Department's Trade Agreements Division, pledged last week that the United States would exert all possible effort in Geneva next month to obtain the removal of discriminatory quotas and tariffs.

IT is one of the more prevalent assumptions in television that sponsorship holds the solution to almost all problems. The theory goes that if only enlightened advertisers would see the wisdom of catering to specialized audiences and do their part in appealing to the minority as well as majority groups the whole shape of TV could be changed and evening schedules would blossom with more diversified fare.

AMERICA, in accepting Hawaii as the fiftieth state, is much like a man who finds himself married to a picture bride. He does not really know her, but as he starts living with her he discovers that she is beautiful, intelligent and gifted with a dowry.

AINTREE, England, April 18 -- Blood-red Ferraris that had appeared badly beaten, finished first and second in the international 200-mile race of Formula I cars today.

HAVING won ovations from theatre audiences in many parts of the United States for a program of readings from Shakespeare, entitled "Ages of Man," John Gielgud was preparing last week for a major television venture.
HOUSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer carded a third-round 71 and a one-stroke lead over Freddie Haas in the $30,000 Houston Golf tourney.

THE trend to ever-widening lens coverage has reached a new limit in the Brooks-Plaubel Veriwide rollfilm camera that made its public debut yesterday at the Coliseum show. A striking example of its potentials is reproduced on this page.

HONG KONG, April 18 -- No other development inside Communist China in recent years has attracted quite so much attention in Asia as the Tibetan revolt. Perhaps the reason for this lies in the fact that the uprising has been religious as well as political.

Last year at the Coliseum Boat Show I was particularly interested in the exhibit of Styrofoam float usable for small boat dockage. I also believe you had an article on the subject last summer in the Sunday boating section.

YONKERS, April 18 -- Model Heir, an ancient campaigner who appears to improve with age, made a show of five younger rivals tonight as he captured the $8,000 Monitor Trot before 34,387 persons at Yonkers Raceway.

THE latest records for children indicate that a serious effort continues to be made by a number of labels to create original works. According to parents, there is some difficulty in obtaining the records that appeal to their own instincts of what they would like their children to hear.

New Jersey took the top honors in the thirty-first annual Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association tournament yesterday. Dufek, for four years the commander of the United States Naval Support Force in Antarctica, turned over his command to Rear Admiral David M. Tyree.

The surplus wheat problem, with which Washington has been wrestling for years, promises to become more aggravated with the harvest of this year's crop. As a result, Congress may make some changes in the Government's wheat program at the present session.

A clerk was kidnapped and forced to disclose the combination to a safe of an American Express Company office last night while two gunmen drove him through the streets of Brooklyn.

It was a moving and eloquent statement that the Dalai Lama issued Saturday in India, but its key points can hardly have been surprising to anyone whose memory of world affairs goes back more than a decade. His story of the Communist Chinese take-over in Tibet essentially recounts the old melancholy pattern of Communist imperialism. All the elements are there which marked the similar process in Eastern Europe little more than ten years ago.
STOCKHOLM, April 19 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin has taken advantage of a homecoming week-end here to try to convince neutral Sweden that Berlin is a Swedish problem too.

LONDON, April 19 -- The stock markets advanced last week on a steady wave of buying. Investors threw off their fit of post-budget blues and prices rose from the start of the new bookkeeping account on Wednesday as if no one had been calculating the date of the next general election.

HAVANA, April 19 (AP) -- Maj. Ernesto Guevara, a Left-wing aide of Dr. Castro, is charging that foreign influences are trying to prevent the success of the Cuban revolution. He has made the accusation in speeches on two successive nights.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery will appear on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network April 28 (7:30 to 8:30 P.M.) in a filmed discussion of current issues and past events.
The Board of Education said yesterday that it was considering a proposal to require applicants for teaching and school supervisory posts to be fingerprinted.

TOKYO, April 19 -- For the last week or more, Japan's cities, towns and villages have been reverberating with the staccato racket of election slogans delivered by slow - moving cars equipped with portable public-address systems.
PARIS, April 19 -- For the first time in thirty years, a devaluation of the franc has not produced a general increase in prices.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Justice Department has decided to damn the political torpedoes and steam ahead with another controversial judicial appointment in New York.
DESIGNING suitable interior for living in a space ship has proved more than a flight of fancy for the senior class of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A sudden burst of activity in recent days has put Vice President Richard M. Nixon back into the political limelight.
Six new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

BUENOS AIRES, April 19 -- The revolt attributed to the Socialist Falange party has shattered an uneasy political peace that has prevailed in Bolivia despite some violent incidents since last June's congressional elections.
Herbert Brucker, editor of The Hartford Courant, was elected president of the American Council of Education for Journalism yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union made preparations yesterday for a strike on Wednesday against six voluntary hospitals. The local said a pre-strike rally would be held today at Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.
A practical nurse who is said to have paid to have her husband murdered and the man accused of doing the job were arrested on homicide charges yesterday in Brooklyn.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that "the urgent requirements of national security" demanded "a massive research and action program" on the causes of intergroup problems and their possible cures.

The National Safety Council has established a committee to help protect children against unsafe toys. Represented on the committee are the United States Public Health Service, the American Medical Association, the United States Children's Bureau, the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Public Health Association and others.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 19 -- A brief revolt flared in the capital of economically shaky Bolivia today. The Government announced that loyal militia had intervened quickly to crush the uprising staged by the right-wing Bolivian Socialist Falange party.

Mary Lou Muller, a pianist from Houston, Tex., played a debut recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Miss Muller, who began her musical studies in Texas, won a Fulbright Scholarship for further work in Paris with Alfred Cortot and Marcel Ciampi.

Many groups of municipal employes have presented convincing arguments to the Board of Estimate for salary increases. Among them, none has been more convincing than the internes and residents in our municipal hospitals.
LONDON, April 19 -- The Labor party will demand this week that the British Government urge the United States to halt "provocative" flights to Berlin, a Labor Member of Parliament said today.

HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Dick Savitt defaulted after two games in the fourth set today, and Bernard (Tut) Bartzen won the twenty-fifth River Oaks invitation tennis tournament. The scores were 6 -- 2, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 0, 2 -- 0, default.

SINGAPORE, April 19 -- Leftists in the Singapore branch of the United Malays National Organization forced the resignation today of the colony's moderate Minister for Local Government, Dato Abdul Hamid bin Jumat.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Franz Joseph Strauss, the West German Defense Minister, said today the Western allies must maintain their right to fly the Berlin corridor at any altitude or the Soviet Union could force them to take "a submarine to get to Berlin."
HE is a mere slip of a Bishop, with graying hair and blue eyes, but the size of the Right Rev. Stephen Fielding Bayne Jr. is deceiving.
The advertising account of Nebs, an anelgesic, probably is causing headaches for some agency people.
The Women's Division, United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, will sponsor its second annual luncheon and entertainment on May 25 at the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba denied today that he favored neutrality and said that his country would live up to its international agreements.

THE New York City Opera last night gave the first performance of the eleventh production of its spring season of American opera. It was Marc Blitzstein's "Regina," one of the four works carried over from the company's first American season last spring.
MEXICO CITY, April 19 -- Mexico, which recently expelled several Soviet Embassy officials, has decided to observe May Day with an anti-Communist demonstration.
The city plans to widen the most congested parts of the Grand Central Parkway in central Queens at a cost of $22,000,000.

MIAMI BEACH, April 19 (UPI) -- Paul M. Butler. National Democratic Chairman, disclosed today that the party's executive committee would appoint several new advisory groups to aid in writing the Democratic platform for 1960.

HOLLYWOOD, April 17 -- Mack Sennett, who nearly half a century ago donated the Keystone Kops to the lexicon of American humor, was depressed today as he considered Hollywood's current approach to comedy.
Crowds thronged the "Scouting for America" exposition at the Coliseum yesterday, forcing it to remain open for ninety extra minutes.

CAIRO, April 19 -- The argument of an American lawyer, Frank Hyndrex, that a sovereign nation has virtually unlimited legal right unilaterally to modify oil concessions was attacked today at the Arab oil congress by representatives of both Arab governments and the oil companies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 19 (Reuters) -- President Tito, speaking on the fortieth anniversary of the Yugoslav Communist party, accused Stalin today of liquidating more than 100 Yugoslav Communist leaders who took refuge in Russia before World War II.

You are to be congratulated for your April 12 editorial "New Focus on the Jobless." As you so well stated, the issue, unemployment of upward of' four million persons, is "a major weakness of the American economy and a curse to many millions today."
MOSCOW, April 19 (AP) -- Two days late, the Soviet leadership commemorated today the sixty-fifth birthday of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev with a torrent of praise.

Three acres on Jamaica Avenue between 251st Street and Little Neck Parkway, Bellerose, Queens, have been leased for ninety-nine years by L. Philip Falk, realty investor and builder. The tract adjoins the Nassau County line and was leased from Elbert Burt.

The Ford Motor Company had net consolidated earnings of $134,800,000, or $2.46 a share, in the first quarter of this year, Henry Ford 2d, president and chief executive officer, announced over the week-end, Consolidated sales were $1,475,300,000.

MILWAUKEE, April 19 (AP) -- Production employes of the West Allis works of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, the concern's main plant, ratified today the contract agreement reached between the company and the United Auto Workers last night.

HOUSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Julius Boros and Jack Burke Jr. caught and passed Arnold Palmer on the second nine today while posting 72-hole 277's, to force a two-way 18-hole play-off tomorrow for top money in the $30,000 Houston golf tournament.
A deficit of $8,000 has forced the Greater New York Safety Council to cut its services.
LONDON, April 19 -- Duncan Sandys, Minister of Defense, who is in Strasbourg for tomorrow's tenth anniversary meeting of the council of Europe, will fly on to Cyprus.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, yesterday established a $10,000 Abba Eban Medical Fellowship Fund in honor of the retiring Israeli Ambassador to the United States. It will be used for the retraining of immigrant Rumanian physicians in Israel.

There is a word that, though it didn't originate here, has shown a tendency to insinuate itself -- through its sheer appropriateness -- into more than one column dedicated to the subject of housing. That is the word "puissant," and when it has been employed it has been employed to suggest not only the exceptional power, but the pervasiveness of housing as a stimulating force in the national economy.
PANAMA, April 19 -- The Panamanian National Guard began a search today for a fishing boat carrying Dr. Roberto Arias, son of a former President.

A pictorial biography of Boris Pasternak by Gerd Ruge will be published May 4 by McGraw-Hill. Called "Pasternak," the volume will contain 112 photographs showing the Russian author as a child, as a young man and as the man who was offered the Nobel Prize. It also will include photographs of paintings of the Pasternak family done by Boris' father, who was a distinguished artist. Mr. Ruge, a German writer, is an acquaintance of Pasternak.
BEVANS, N. J., April 19 -Radar's Tar Heel Prince, 4-year-old white-and-lemon pointer, today won the open shooting-dog stake at the spring program of the Sussex County Field Trial Club.

LONDON, April 19 -- The ruling authority of soccer bowed tonight before the storm of protest that arose when it was proposed to omit the singing of "Abide With Me" from the preliminaries of the Cup Final.
Union pressmen rejected yesterday a proposed contract negotiated by their representatives and the Publishers Association of New York City.
DEER LODGE, Mont., April 19 (UPI) -- Warden Floyd E. Powell began a crackdown today on inmates in the state prison after a thirty-five-hour outbreak in which three men were killed.

Armino A. Campagna, realty investor and builder, has purchased 863 Park Avenue, a twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at the northeast corner of Seventy-seventh Street, from Loventhal Brothers and David J. Hurwitz.
LOS ANGELES, April 19 -Forty teen-agers here are proving that you can go to high school and college at the same time, if you are bright.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey declared yesterday that the current level of unemployment was "little short of a national disgrace."
St. Francis Prep captured team honors yesterday in the All Hallows Eastern Catholic High Schools invitation track and field meet at John J. Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
A man suspected of being a narcotics dealer was shot and killed yesterday when he and a companion fought three detectives in a running battle on a setback and stairway of a West Side rooming house.

HENDERSON, N. C., April (AP) -- Striking textile worker of the Henderson-Harriet Colton Mills voted today to accept a new contract. This action officially ended the five-months-old strike, which was marked by violence.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Highway planners said today that they had devised a sort of electronic crystal ball that should ease traffic problems and save cities millions of taxpayers' dollars.
ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Rockefeller today blocked a move to limit the use of radar records in prosecuting speeders.

Awards to 321 scholars and artists were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. They total more than $1,500,000 and go to recipients in thirty-four states, Hawaii and the District of Columbia.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 19 -- The Stamford Historical Society's annual entertainment to aid maintenance of its headquarters will be held at the Young Women's Christian Association here Tuesday afternoon. Betsy Barnum House, which dates from 1725 and is one of New England's oldest public buildings, will be the beneficiary of the dessert-bridge, fashion show and antiques exhibit.
A tri-state commission to map all the transportation needs of the metropolitan area for the next twenty-five years was proposed yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

The program of the Columbia University Orchestra Saturday evening at McMillin Theater was full of novelty. There was the world premiere of Otto Luening's Fantasia for String Quartet and Orchestra. All listed as first New York performances were Spohr's Concerto for String Quartet and Orchestra, Alessandro Scarlatti's "De Tenebroso Lacu" for contralto, strings and continuo, and Dittersdorf's "Le Carneval ou la Dedoute."

Your editorial of April 14 "City Transit for Sale?" hits the nail on the head. With fanfare, if without the blowing of trumpets, the magic wand of the Chalk proposal is waved before the public. It ignores the sad experience of the past, plain arithmetic and the most elementary caution.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 19 -- Racial segregation has been extended to committees directing boys' clubs for Negroes in Johannesburg, where juvenile delinquency is a problem of both Negroes and whites.
AMHERST, Mass., April 19 -- The resignation of Dr. Charles W. Cole as president of Amherst College was announced today.

HAVANA, April 19 -- More than 100 persons were arrested yesterday when the Cuban Army raided a Nicaraguan rebel training camp near San Diego de los Banos in Pinar del Rio Province. Machine guns as well as other arms and equipment were seized.

BUENOS AIRES, April 19 -- Each weekday morning a telegram arrives from the Commodity Credit Corporation in Washington with tips on grain prices and sales for its Argentine counterpart, the National Grain Board.

It certainly seems, in this age of Univacs, computers, earth satellites, quantum theories and all manner of such strange and wondrous achievements, that science could come up with an answer to the riddle of the paintbrush.

CLEVELAND, April 19 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics snapped Cleveland's winning streak at six games with a ninth-inning rally against Herb Score today. The 4-3 defeat was the Indians' first loss of the year.
NEW LONDON, Conn., April 19 -- There is something new in the United States Navy's fleet ballistic missile submarine program.
In spite of the movement to the suburbs, the middle-income group remains the core of New York's population, a City Planning Commission survey has found.
HAZARD, Ky., April 19 -- At decision on whether to move troops into the strike-bound coalfields of Eastern Kentucky was deferred tonight pending a third attempt at mediation by Gov. A. B. Chandler.
Mickey Rooney, who has been a Hollywood actor for thirty-one of his thirty-six years, may make his Broadway debut this fall in the guise of Fiorello H. La Guardia.
The first public hearing on charges that a waterfront union has refused to admit Negroes has been scheduled by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
Department store executives expressed fear last night that sales in major stores would drop sharply as a result of the strike of 3,000 United Parcel Service employes.
Interest in lacrosse at Northeastern prep schools continues to grow. In 1954, only ten New England schools had lacrosse teams. Now there are twenty.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 19 -- Boys' wear manufacturers can no longer hold to traditional low price lines under today's high costs, it was asserted here today by Manny Eagle, president of the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- Steel demand quickened last week. Most steel consumers, who up to last week had thought there was no reason for acquiring heavy inventories, were changing their minds. But most steel companies were unable to arrange to increase June shipment. That meant that some users would be forced, if there were a strike, to depend heavily upon their own supplies and upon those of steel warehouses.

Old-timers in the New York locals of the International Association of Machinists have some advice for their younger union brothers. It is: Put more emphasis on the importance of future security and less on immediate wage gains.
CINCINNATI, April 19 (UPI) -- Frank Robinson hit his third homer and drove in four runs today as the Cincinnati Reds whipped the Philadelphia Phillies, 12 to 5.

Some 450 children and about seventy-five parents of varying religions and races participated yesterday in an interfaith and interracial Seder commemorating the Jewish Festival of Passover at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street.
ALGIERS, April 19 -- Terrorists killed at least eight persons, wounded about eighty and kidnapped more than twenty today during the first day of municipal elections in Algeria.

A HALF-HOUR account of the marriage of Crown Prince Akihito and Michiko Shoda was shown yesterday afternoon over the local outlet of the Columbia Broadcasting System. The television report, some of it taped from the coverage of the Japanese video networks, afforded striking views of the wedding preliminaries and the procession through the streets of Tokyo.
Say this for Park Commissioner Robert Moses: He is never boring. He does not let his admirers get in a rut.
CAIRO, April 19 (Reuters) -- A 5-year-old boy selected the name of the new leader of the Coptic Christian Church out of an enevelope today in St. Mark's Cathedral here.
Simca, French automobile manufacturer, has set a subscription price of 2,750 francs ($5.61) a share on its offering to stockholders here of 2,000,000 American shares on a one-for-one basis.
A Jesuit priest lashed out yesterday against racial discrimination as morally indefensible, blasphemous, cancerous and "a pagan desecration of Christian civilization."
A union suspected of being under racketeer influence has lost an effort to win certification as the collective bargaining agent for pari-mutuel clerks at Yonkers Raceway.

BOSTON, April 19 -- "It should be a good day for homers," said Gil McDougald. "The flags are hanging limp. No wind." The only notable aspect of this observation was that it virtually was the last conversational foothold any Yankee ballplayer was able to take for the next half hour. Leo Durocher, the Great Mouthpiece, moved assuredly to the middle of Trainer Gus Mauch's repair room at Fenway Park today and never stopped talking.

NEW DELHI, India, April 19 -- Suppression of the Tibetan revolt by the Chinese Commu nist army last month and the arrival of the Dalai Lama in India have resulted in sharp criticism of Peiping by the Indian press.

ELIAS FRIEDENSOHN has always been interested in the symbols of human suffering. In his recent paintings at the Isaacson Gallery, 32 East Sixty-sixth Street, Friedensohn has furthered his search for expressive symbols by condensing his imagery. His paintings are free of minor detail, and, when necessary, are couched in abstract terms that enforce his melancholy vision.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee predicted today that a summit conference this summer might ease the Berlin crisis. He also foresaw that the conference might lead to a series of similar meetings to bring about gradual readjustment of East-West differences.

MUNICH, Germany, Monday, April 20 -- The voters in two West German states gave about equal percentage increases yesterday to the country's major parties -- the Christian Democratic Union and the Social Democrats -- without establishing any significant new trend.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- The United States funneled $5,000,000,000 in grants and loans to foreign nations last year to help them resist the twin threats of Communists' military and economic infiltration.
Mayor Wagner and Budget Director Abraham D. Beame were on a television quiz program yesterday. There were no prizes, and no one announced whether their answers were right or wrong.
The National Bureau of Economic Research, with the support of a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, is currently engaged in a broad study of the controversial question of Soviet economic growth.

To commemorate Pan-American Day, a joint appearance was made at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Robert McFerrin, baritone, and Salvador Ley, pianist-composer, who heads the Guatemalan Conservatory of Music.
A rift in the newly cemented unity of maritime labor may be opened by a new organizational drive that will start soon on the Pacific Coast.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, who has accused Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas of cutting other Senators out of the picture, admitted today that he had been doing the same to Mr. Johnson.

A New York-born clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church, who for a time was chaplain at Columbia University, has been elevated to a new post in Christendom: executive officer of the world-wide Anglican Communion.
The Long Island Rail Road, hardier than changing times, bankruptcy and a generation of bad jokes, will be 125 years old Friday.
NEW HAVEN, April 19 -- A rare Tibet religious painting has been presented to Yale University.
ALBANY, April 19 -- The State Health Department's survey showing a coincidence of high natural radioactivity and abnormal rates of malformed births does not list any towns in Rockland County.
A bright pageant of ancient Greece passed in review up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon.

TIMONIUM, Md., April 19 (AP) -- A black and tan cocker spaniel, Champion Pinetop's Fancy Parade, was judged best of 903 dogs today at the Baltimore County Kennel Club show, held on the State Fairgrounds.

DARIEN, Conn., April 19 -Fifteen Darien High School seniors, many of them college preparatory students, are under a two-week suspension because of an early morning beach incident featuring a case of beer.

HONG KONG, April 19 -- The speech of Premier Chou En-lai at yesterday's first formal meeting of Communist China's National People's Congress indicated that 1959 would see maximum pressure kept on the Chinese people for high farm and industrial production.
Cotton futures prices continued along an irregular course last week.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 19 -- Last Friday the Zurich Stock Exchange management committee published figures showing that in March the aggregate paid value of the turnovers in stocks was 1,647,000,000 francs.

When Mr. Herter met the press at Augusta, Ga., last Saturday he dodged a question about changes in our foreign policy by the judicious remark that "there will be time enough, if and when I am confirmed, to be talking about that."

Time, Inc., and Rockefeller Center, Inc., co-owners of the forty-eight-story Time and Life Building under construction on the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) at Fiftieth Street, have placed six tower floors of the skyscraper on the market for subleasing.
Charles Abrams, former chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, agreed yesterday with two teen-agers that young people were less prejudiced than their elders.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -Plans for an extensive exchange of scientists between the United States and the Soviet Union have become stalled by an unexplained delay by the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
MILAN, Italy, April 19 (AP) -- Duilio Loi, Italy's European lightweight boxing champion, today won the European welterweight crown by outpointing Emilio Marconi of Italy in a fifteen-round bout.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, 'Haiti, April 19 (UPI) -- President Francois Duvalier has shaken up his Cabinet in an effort to cope with growing economic problems and political unrest in Haiti, it was announced today.

SPRING fever does not grip every woman in the same way. For some, who aim at success, it means a frenzy of formal balls, benefits and opening nights, which. with the right push from the proper publicist, will set their satin shoes on the first rung to fame.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, April 10 -- In a great vaulted loft here the air resounds with the ceaseless tapping of aluminum hammers on nuts shaped like bloated lima beans.
Faith Epstein, a young pianist who studies at the High School of Music and Art, made her New York debut yesterday in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Crank L. Magee, president of the Aluminum Company of America, has been named chief executive officer, it was announced over the week-end by I. W. Wilson, chairman. Mr. Wilson, who previously held the post, will remain as chairman.
I should like to congratulate Loren Pope on his excellent analysis of the limited value of college scholarship gifts in The Times on April 5.
TRENTON, April 19 (AP) -- Dick Linder, a 36-year-old Pittsburgh driver, was killed today when his car spun over the fence during the United States Auto Club's 100-mile race of champions.
Optimistic reports of a nation generally climbing rapidly from the recession of a year ago were heard yesterday in talks with newspaper publishers gathering here for Press Week meetings.

WELL known for its savory sweet bacon that is pungent with hickory smoke, George Kern, Inc., has been wholesale meat provisioner here since 1866. In addition, the concern operates a small retail outlet on Ninth Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets. A visit there would be rewarding for anyone with a taste for pork products that are fresh, smoked or corned.

BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP) -- Homers by Harmon Killebrew and Jim Lemon plus two runs scored without a hit enabled the Washington Senators to beat the Baltimore Orioles 4 -- 2, today in the second game of a double-header.
